DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, March 1, or the 21st day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1555: The "Book of Centuries," a book of prophecies telling the 500-year history of the future, is published in France by Nostradamus, or Michel de Notredame, French physician and astrologer.
1562: Catholics massacre more than 1,000 Huguenot Protestants at Vassy in France, starting the First War of Religion.
1803: Ohio becomes the 17th state of the United States.
1810: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born.
1872: Yellowstone becomes the world's first national park.
1880: Pennsylvania becomes the first U.S. state to abolish slavery.
1919: The March 1st Movement, or the Samil Independence Movement, starts in Korea.
1934: Henry Pu Yi is enthroned as the "Emperor of Manchukuo" in Changchun by Japanese militarists.
1941: The first session of the Second People's Political Council is convened in Chungking.
1947: Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Ltd. is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1949: Boxer Joe Louis retires at the age of 35 after having beaten 25 contenders competing for his title.
1950: After relocating from mainland China to Taiwan, Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek resumes office.
1950: Chiang Wei-kuo becomes brigade commander of the ROC military's armored force tank division.
1954: The United States explodes the world's first full-scale hydrogen bomb on the tiny Bikini Atoll in the South Pacific with what is hailed as complete success.
1955: The Taiwan provincial government approves the renaming of Taiwan Provincial Teachers College as National Taiwan Normal University.
1958: Construction of the section of the East-West Cross-Island Highway stretching from Taroko to Tienhsiang is completed.
1960: An earthquake and tsunami hit Morocco, killing more than 10,000 people and leaving more than 30,000 homeless.
1961: President John F. Kennedy of the United States sets up the Peace Corps to work in Third World countries.
1966: The Soviet spacecraft Venus III lands on its namesake, the second planet from the Sun.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Acred F. Miossi, executive vice president of U.S. firm Continental Bank.
1979: The U.S. embassy in Taipei formally closes, to be succeeded by the American Institute in Taiwan.
1979: The Washington Office of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs of the Republic of China opens.
1984: The ROC's first domestically developed jet trainer, the AT-3, Rolls off the assembly line. The twin-seater, fitted with two Garrett TFE 731-2-2L engines, each with a thrust of 1,590 kilograms, was developed by the Aeronautical Institute of Science and Technology.
1985: Legislator Tsai Cheng-chou is detained on charges of being involved in bank fraud involving the Taipei 10th Credit Cooperative.
1990: The Executive Yuan approves direct trade between the Republic of China and both the Soviet Union and Albania.
1995: The National Health Insurance program is formally inaugurated.
1997: The cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung officially launch a system that prohibits physicians from directly dispensing medicine.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang's Discipline Commission expels from the party 16 of independent presidential candidate James Soong's supporters.
2000: The Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission inaugurates a satellite television channel, called MSTV, to provide TV programming free of charge to overseas Chinese around the world.
2001: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, says that "one China, different interpretations" is the only way to break the impasse between Beijing and Taipei over the so-called "one China" issue.
2004: The Republic of China's representative office in Bangladesh becomes operational.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The general of an army may be carried off, but a man of the common people cannot be robbed of his free will."

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD ANNOUNCES RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Lin Chia-lung, director-general of the Government Information Office, announced Tuesday that he has officially tendered his resignation to Premier Hsieh in order to prepare to run in the year-end Taichung City mayoral election.
Lin, who made the announcement at a press conference, also said that the premier needs ten to fifteen days to choose a replacement and that he will remain in the post until that time.
Lin said that he has also informed his superiors at the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party about his plans to run in the mayoral election.

Through Shu Chin-chiang, chairman of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the GIO head further said that he has also made a report to former President Len Teng-hui about his intention to run for Taichung mayor.
Lin also announced that he was switching his domicile from Taipei City to Taichung the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUPS IN CANADA VOICE OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Wu Shien-kung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwanese groups in Ottawa and Montreal issued a joint declaration Monday, strongly protesting against Beijing's proposed anti-secession law aimed at Taiwan.

In the statement, the two groups of Taiwanese expatriates in Canada urged Beijing to drop the plan immediately to help quell tensions between Taiwan and mainland China. They also called on the Canadian government and the international community to take concrete measures to stop Beijing from enacting the law for the sake of peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.

The statement said that the People's Republic of China has never ruled Taiwan for a single day, and Beijing has no right to manage Taiwan's affairs or unilaterally define Taiwan-mainland relations through domestic legislation.

The anti-secession bill totally ignores the reality existing between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and is contradictory to the international understanding of the situation in the region, the statement said.

Calling the proposed law a scheme to create a legal basis for the invasion of Taiwan, the statement stressed that its enactment would seriously damage the cross-strait status quo and greatly affect peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region.
The full National People's Congress -- mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament -- is expected to pass the bill into law in mid-March.

The Straits Times : Business MPs want more help for SMEs.
The business community's disappointment over this year's Budget loomed large in Parliament yesterday, as business MPs protested that the sector had been left out in the cold.
Too few and too cautious were the measures announced by the Government, they argued, calling for bigger and bolder boosters, even if it meant going into another year of budget deficit.
The smaller local enterprises, especially, needed urgent help, they said.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PSA International completes purchase of two HK port terminals for S$630m.
Port operator PSA International has sealed its foothold in the world's busiest container port.
PSA said yesterday it has completed the purchase of the Hong Kong port assets of NWS Holdings.
The landmark deal, announced earlier this month but subject to certain approvals, cost PSA HK$3 billion Hong Kong dollars, or S$630 million.
The investment will add Hong Kong's Container Terminal No. 3 and Container Terminal No. 8 West to PSA's portfolio.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS SET FOR MAY 14: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) on Tuesday announced that the mission-oriented National Assembly elections will be held May 14.

The polls to elect 300 delegates to the National Assembly will be open from 7: 30 a.m. to 4 p.m. to give those taking part in a national vocational college examination the same day time to vote, CEC officials said.
All candidates must register with the CEC between March 26 and 30, and the list of candidates and the campaign period will be announced May 3, the officials added.
The 300 delegates elected will be assigned exclusively for the task of reviewing a draft package of constitutional amendment proposals passed by the Legislative Yuan last year.

The legislature passed several constitutional amendment proposals at an extraordinary session last August, including the halving of the number of seats in the current 225-seat legislature, the adoption of a "single seat, two votes" electoral system for the legislature, the abrogation of the National Assembly, and the inclusion of the referendum right into the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, UNI AIRWAYS LAUNCH SCHEDULED TAIPEI-SEOUL FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) and UNI Airways -- upgraded their regular daily charter flights to the South Korean capital of Seoul to scheduled flights Tuesday.

CAL, Taiwan's largest carrier, has operated one charter flight between Taipei and Seoul per day since late last year. A CAL spokesman said the airline will maintain its current one daily flight for the time being after changing from a charter basis to a scheduled one.
Nevertheless, the spokesman said, the airline will replace its B737-800 passenger plane on the Seoul route with the larger A300-600R plane to meet market demand.
From March 28, he added, the carrier will add an additional Taipei-Seoul flight on Mondays and Fridays.

Meanwhile, UNI Airways began to operate scheduled flights daily between the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung and Seoul from Tuesday. It plans to inaugurate scheduled flights between Kaohsiung and Jijou from March 29.

Taiwan suspended direct air links with South Korea Sept. 15, 1992, after Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in August of that year. Charter flights were resumed in 2003, and the two countries finally signed a new aviation agreement in late 2004 to resume normal direct air links.

The CAL spokesman said South Koreans made a total of 8 million overseas trips in 2004, with about 150,000 visiting Taiwan. Thanks in part to the growing popularity of South Korean TV soap operas, Taiwan citizens made 300,000 visits to South Korea last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTHING BEING RULED OUT ON COUNTERING ANTI-SECESSION LAW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government will not rule out any possibilities on countering Beijing's proposed anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Premier Frank Shieh said Tuesday.

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmaker Ho Min-ho, who asked the premier whether the government would consider holding a defensive referendum to counter the anti-secession bill, which is expected to be enacted in the middle of this month.
If mainland China enacts the law, it must be held accountable for the consequences, Hsieh said, adding that the law totally goes against Beijing's claims of respecting the people of Taiwan.

He stressed that the government is firmly opposed to the anti-secession law and that it will strongly voice this opposition to the international community. He warned that complications arising from Beijing's anti-secession law scheme will aggravate the cross-strait situation.

Regarding a government campaign to change the official titles of Taiwan's offices overseas and its state-run enterprises to distinguish them from those of mainland China, the premier said that the issue will be dealt with on a case by case basis. Relevant government authorities will devise a set of mechanisms to serve that end within two or three months, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA DOES NOT RECOGNIZE TAIWAN AS PART OF CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the United States' Taiwan Relations Act does not recognize Taiwan as being part of the People's Republic of China.
The Taiwan Relations Act deals with Washington's unofficial relations with Taiwan after the severance of diplomatic ties between the two countries in 1979.
The premier made the comments while responding to questions raised by Lin Te-fu, legislator from opposition People First Party, in a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Asked about the views of the United States and China regarding the one-China policy and whether enactment of China's proposed anti-secession law will harm the climate of cross-strait reconciliation, Hsieh said that according to his understanding, China and the United States see the one-China policy slightly differently.

Beijing claims that Taiwan is part of China, the premier noted, while the United States does not use the word "recognize" to describe its stance on China's claim, and instead only uses the words "acknowledges and respects."
The premier urged the Beijing regime to intuitively perceive Taiwan's concern over the anti-secession bill issue and to adjust its plan of enacting it.

The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress adopted in December of last year a draft of the proposed law, and the congress is set to pass the bill into law at its annual plenary session slated to be held in early March.

Cross-strait exchanges will be affected if China adopts the proposed bill, Hsieh continued, adding that China should consider the feelings of the Taiwan people. He said that the government will react appropriately in accordance with Beijing's future actions.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said the same day that Taiwan's current tactic is to urge friendly countries in the international community to try to stop enactment of the law, adding that leaders of some countries, including the United States, have voiced their concerns about the issue.

Pointing out that Taiwan has not yet considered the measures it will take to counter the law if China enacts it, Wu said that currently, Taiwan is doing whatever it can to try to prevent its enactment.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER REVEALS INTENT TO RUN FOR KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that he might run for the Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship if incumbent chairman Lien Chan decides not to take part in the vote among party members.
Wang made the comments while responding to questions from local media at the Legislative Yuan.

Wang reiterated that he would consider running for the party's highest post only if Lien eventually decides not to participate in the race. This was the first time that Wang, a vice chairman of the main opposition party, revealed his intent to run.

As to a media report that P. K. Chiang, currently a legislator and also a KMT vice chairman, might also join the contest and stands a good chance of winning, Wang claimed that he was not aware of the matter and said that he came to learn about the issue from newspaper reports.
Meanwhile, aides to Chiang said that he has no idea about all the developments and ascribed them to media speculation.

The issue regarding the new KMT chairmanship has triggered rampant media speculation over a fierce competition, in particular between Wang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PRO-TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE PRESIDENTIAL ADVISERS QUIT

TEXT.P: Two pro-Taiwan independence advisers to President Chen Shui-bian resigned Tuesday to show their displeasure over the president's remarks on the nation's status during his meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong last Thursday.

Koo Kuan-min, senior adviser to the president, and Ng Chiau-tong, national policy adviser to the president, said they were disappointed at President Chen's joint statement with Soong in which Chen reaffirmed his "five noes" from his first inaugural address.

The "five noes" refer to no declaration of independence, no change of the nation's name, no inclusion of "state-to-state" relations with mainland China in the Constitution, no referendum to change the nation's status quo and no revocation of the National Unification Guidelines or the National Unification Council.
In response, Presidential Office officials said they are continuing to communicate with Koo and Ng, hoping to persuade them to stay on.

The officials also explained that President Chen's meeting with Soong was arranged to put an end to inter-party rivalry and confrontation and move toward party-to-party cooperation and reconciliation.
Koo announced in a news conference Tuesday that he will quit the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as well as his post as a senior adviser to the president.

Koo scathingly criticized the ruling DPP administration and stressed that from now on he will dedicate himself to the promotion of writing a new constitution for the nation and rectifying the nation's name from the ROC to Taiwan.
He said that he will watch what President Chen does and that "if he is willing to turn back, we are still partners."

He said that during his five-odd years as an adviser to the president, he has mentioned several times to Chen that the "five noes" would seriously undermine the existence and development of the nation, so it was with great disappointment that he learned of the president's reaffirmation of the "five noes" during his meeting with Soong.
"One day the president wants to write a new constitution and the next day he wants to amend it; this gives the public the impression that he is constantly wavering," Koo said.

He harshly criticized Premier Frank Hsieh's remarks that he will not forcefully promote the writing a new constitution or the rectification of the nation's name, saying that the DPP won the right to rule exactly because these two stances were put forward as needed changes for the country and Hsieh shouldn't forget why they are attractive to people.
Ng, also chairman of the World United Formosans for Independence, sent his letter of resignation to the presidential Office Tuesday.
Ng said that he has not fulfilled his duty as a national policy adviser, and that his advice to the president did not receive the attention it deserved.
In addition, though he supported inter-party cooperation, Ng said the president paid too high a price in issuing the 10-point joint statement with Soong.

Meanwhile, the pro-independence party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), said that Koo and Ng had worked with the DPP because of their long-term dedication to creating a new constitution for the nation and rectifying the nation's name.

Lo Chih-ming, caucus whip of the TSU in the Legislative Yuan, said that Koo and Ng hoped that President Chen would help them realize their ideals, but their dream was shattered after Chen's meeting with Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained 31 points to close at 6,250, with 21,190 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved up 28 points to finish at 6,248, with 301 contracts traded, while June futures gained 21 points to finish at 6,240, with eight contracts traded.
September futures gained 26 points to finish at 6,176, with nine contracts traded, while December futures moved up 27 points to close at 6,150, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,219 for March, 6,220 for April, 6,219 for June, 6,150 for September and 6,123 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

March TE futures moved down 0.2 points to close at 237.1, with 3,522 contracts traded, while April TE futures remained unchanged at 237.25, with 40 contract transactions. June TE futures lost 0.05 points to close at 236.75, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

March TF futures gained seven points to finish at 1,031.6, with 4,787 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved up nine points to end at 1,032.8, with 51 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 6.4 points to close at 1,028, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened up and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 51.86 points to close at 6,259.69.
The bourse opened at 6,227.42 and fluctuated between 6,260.32 and 6,207.78 during trading. A total of 4.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$103.47 billion (US$3.33 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most at 3.8 percent, followed by construction issues at 3.7 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.6 percent, textile stocks at 1.5 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.1 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent.
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 481 to 423, with 87 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS SPECIAL NT$610.8 BILLION ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Tuesday spoke in defense of a special budget proposed by the Cabinet for a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States.

Hsieh emphasized during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan that it is necessary for the government to plan a special budget for the package, saying it will squeeze the other 204 arms procurement items covered by the regular budget if the package is to be included in the regular budget as well.
The package includes six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.
Hsieh said the Ministry of National Defense will step up communication with the public to try to win their support for the special budget.
Hsieh said he understands that there is a prevailing opinion among the public that such a large amount of money should have been used to finance social welfare programs.
However, he said, Taiwan does not have a choice because cross-Taiwan Strait peace does not lie unilaterally with the island, which is targeted by more than 700 missiles deployed by mainland China.

With the NT$610.8 billion to be spread over a 15-year period, the annual defense budget of the country will be NT$300 billion, or 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) , after a NT$260 billion defense spending package in the regular budget has been taken into consideration, Hsieh pointed out.

Meanwhile, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye denied reports suggesting that the government will have to repay NT$1.2 trillion including interest for a NT$400 billion loan to fund the special arms package.

On issues regarding reforms to the military service system, Hsieh said the government is planning to introduce a voluntary military service system in parallel with the mandatory military service system in the short run.
It is hoped that a ratio of six volunteers to four conscripts will be achieved by the year 2008, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER WELCOMES VISIT OF U.S. PROCUREMENT GROUP

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien said Tuesday the ministry welcomes a foreign procurement group from the U.S. Department of Defense to visit Taiwan this weekend.

Tsai was responding to media reports that the group will come to Taiwan Saturday for a five-day visit. During their stay in Taiwan, they will inspect the island's defense industry, meet with officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) as well as hold presentations to brief Taiwan manufacturers on the requirements and procedures for U.S. military procurement, the reports also said.

Tsai, speaking on the sidelines of a ceremony to honor outstanding military units and individuals on Military Service Day, welcomed the U.S. group, but said that the MOEA will be in charge of the arrangement of the group's visit.

If necessary, the MND will also arrange for the group to visit the Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology -- a military-run research and development institute under the Armaments Bureau of the MND.

Noting that mainland China's defense budget is growing at a double-digit pace, Tsai said this is why the MND needs to procure weaponry from the United States, referring to the six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft, to maintain stability and peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Meanwhile, asked whether he will run for Taichung mayor, Tsai said that he is not very keen on the post, although he understands the high expectations of Taichung voters.

Earlier in the day, Lin Chia-lung, director-general of the Government Information Office, announced that he was resigning his post to focus on his campaign for Taichung mayor in the year-end election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE OF THREE LOBBYING GROUPS TO EUROPE CANCELS TRIP

TEXT.P: One of three delegations scheduled to visit Europe to lobby on Taiwan's behalf has canceled the trip, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng, who is the co-leader of the delegation that was slated to visit the Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia and Italy, said through his staff Tuesday that he has decided to cancel the trip.

Huang said that the MAC has a heavy workload and that Beijing's National People's Congress, the rubber-stamp parliament, is about to meet to review the "anti-secession law" and is expected to approve it; therefore, the MAC will have to make preparations for any contingency, and he has no time for the trip.

However, MOFA officials said privately that the trip was probably aborted because it was announced too early and some countries have been under pressure by mainland China. Reports have said that Poland and Italy were considering denying visas to members of the delegation.
Despite the pressure from Beijing, the other delegations to Scandinavian and Baltic countries will be able to go as scheduled in early March, the officials added.

Yang Maysing, chairwoman of the foreign ministry's Research and Planning Committee, said last month that in view of mainland China's proposed "anti-secession law" against Taiwan and the European Union leaning toward lifting an arms embargo against China, the delegations hope to help the international community learn more about the threat faced by Taiwan.

Yang said that the delegations will try to impress upon the international community the threat faced by Taiwan, prevent Beijing from enacting its proposed law and oppose the lifting an arms embargo against Beijing, imposed in the wake of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO HIT 4.5 PERCENT THIS YEAR: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to post an economic growth rate of more than 4.5 percent this year while keeping unemployment below 4 percent, despite the slowdown of the global economic expansion, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

Fielding questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan, the premier said the economy has been improving continuously over the last five years since the Democratic Progressive Party was voted into power, with the growth rate rising from a minus 2.2 percent in 2000 to a positive 5.71 percent last year, while unemployment figures have continued to fall.
The projected growth rate of 4.5 percent seems small compared to the 5.71 percent of the previous year but is still remarkable compared with other countries, the premier said.
As for the government's debt, standing at 30 percent of the gross domestic production (GDP), it is lower than Japan's, he said.
Hsieh said he favors a balanced government budget and an increase in government spending that stimulates economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU WANTS DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT CRUISES

TEXT.P: With the successful end of direct charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China for the lunar new year holiday, cruise organizers and tourist agencies are optimistic that direct cross-Taiwan Strait voyages can begin in line with existing guidelines for offshore transshipments.

Star Cruises Group -- the world's third-largest cruise operator -- is keenly interested in opening such a link, which would be modeled after the offshore transshipment center at Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan, which only handles transshipped products between Taiwan and mainland China or those destined for a third country or area.
K. C. Lu, Star Cruises general manager in Taiwan, expects direct cruises between Taiwan and mainland China to attract a large number of tourists from around the world.
Should direct cruises be permitted across the strait, foreign tourists would be very willing to visit Taiwan, Lu said.

This is not the first time that Star Cruises has attempted to open the door between the two sides of the Taiwan strait. Its vessels, although registered in Hong Kong and flying the Panamanian flag, have been forced to detour across the strait due to government policy restrictions.

More then two years ago, the group envisaged a voyage for enthusiastic local worshipers of the goddess Matsu to her native land -- Meizhou in Fujian province in southern mainland China -- departing from southern Taiwan and detouring via a third place. But the plan was aborted due to the ensuing breakout of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).
Last year, Star Cruises embarked on an eight-day Keelung-Okinawa-Shanghai cruise, but customer response was lackluster as a result of lengthy time spent at sea.

Echoing calls from other cruise operators, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications is also keen on promoting the business. But rather than direct cross-strait routes, the bureau is more interested in wooing visitors traveling from a third country or area who will head for mainland China via Taiwan.

Tourism Bureau Director General C. T. Su said that such services will not violate the government ban on direct shipping with the mainland, as only foreign passengers would be allowed to enter Taiwan for sightseeing.
Su expressed his belief that such a service will help bring in foreign tourists to Taiwan, as long as the Mainland Affairs Council does not insist on cruises detouring via a third place.

Although the government has since 2000 been hoping to double tourist arrivals by 2008 to five million a year, the number has failed to break three million until now because of the SARS outbreaks and the heated presidential election last year.
There were about 2.62 million foreign arrivals to Taiwan in 2000. The figure once rose to around 2.97 million in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUJIAN OFFICIALS VISIT MATSU TO INSPECT TOURIST ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese delegation, headed by Fujian Provincial Tourism Bureau Director Huang Xiaoyen, is visiting Matsu to examine tourist spots on the Taiwan-held frontline island.

After touring local attractions including Tienhou Temple, Tunnel 88 --where "kaoliang" rice liquor is made -- and Chinpi village, Huang said Tuesday that the island is more interesting than he thought.

The delegation, organized by the Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu branch of the Fujian Provincial Association of travel agencies, arrived in Matsu Monday via the direct "mini three links" route. Members of the group included a provincial official in charge of Taiwan affairs, Dai Xiaofeng.
This was the branch's first inspection-oriented visit to Matsu since its inauguration over a year ago. The delegation will also travel to Matsu's islets of Nankan, Peikan and Tungyin.
The tour is aimed at assessing Matsu's tourist value, a member of the delegation said.

Up until last September the Fujian Province Government did not allow its residents to make sightseeing trips to the two Taiwanese territories of Kinmen and Matsu. However, despite the opening, Matsu people still haven't seen any mainland Chinese tour groups so far, only several inspection delegations.

Taiwan opened direct postal, trade and shipping links between its two outlying islands and the Fujian cities of Xiamen and Mawei in January 2002 on an experimental basis, better known as the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES TO BE DECIDED BY THE PEOPLE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the government will keep its mind open to any possibilities on the eventual development of relations between Taiwan and mainland China and will respect the decision of the 23 million people on the island.

Hsieh made the remarks during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan in response to a proposal by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung that Taiwan and the mainland form a confederation similar to the European Union to normalize cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Ting also suggested that a referendum be held to let the people vote on this proposed model.
Hsieh said the government is open to any possibilities under a framework of cross-strait peace and stability.
Hsieh agreed that Ting's proposal could be a creative resolution to the cross-strait sovereignty dispute, but he also said that the choice of the people must be respected.

On issues concerning cross-strait agricultural exchanges, Hsieh said they should be carried out step by step because they cover a wide range of issues including products, technology, information, anti-smuggling raids and division of fishery labor.
According to Council of Agriculture Chairman Lee Chin-lung, Taiwan exported agricultural products worth US$290 million to the mainland in 2004, up 66.1 percent compared with the 2003 figure.
Lee noted that the country insists on the principles of "Taiwan first," reciprocity and risk management while conducting agricultural exchanges with the mainland.
The island must also protect itself against the invasion of farm diseases and pests from the mainland, which would cause great losses to Taiwan's agricultural sector, Lee said.
He said Taiwan is promoting its agricultural products for the mainland and is targeting markets in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.

An official at the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office said last week that Beijing welcomes Taiwan's agricultural sector to make investments on the mainland and will help Taiwanese farmers establish operations there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF DOES NOT RULE OUT VISIT TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Tuesday he would not rule out the possibility of visiting mainland China as a representative of the government to promote reconciliation and peace across the Taiwan Strait.

"But as mainland China remains suspicious about the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's promise not to declare Taiwan independence, I don't think I will be able to visit the mainland, even if the DPP administration authorizes me to talk with the Beijing authorities," Soong said.

Under the present circumstances, Soong said, it is more practical that the ruling and opposition camps work together to complete the enactment of a PFP-initiated cross-strait peace promotion bill to create an institutionalized mechanism to boost cross-strait reconciliation and peace.
Soong made the remarks while attending a changeover ceremony for senior executives of the PFP legislative caucus.

He also took advantage of the occasion to defend his Feb. 24 meeting with President Chen Shui-bian, in which they reached a 10-point agreement on Taiwan's status, cross-strait relations, ethnic harmony and constitutional re-engineering. The agreement has drawn a backlash from pro-independence activists who criticized Chen for compromising on his promises to write a new constitution for Taiwan and change the nation's name from the Republic of China to Taiwan.

"Neither of us has compromised on our basic stances. Given Taiwan's ever-closer economic interdependence with mainland China, a majority of Taiwan people hope to see cross-strait reconciliation, " Soong said.
He further claimed that both he and the PFP learned true democratic principles through his meeting with Chen.

"We have learned the gist of democracy. The ruling and opposition parties should consult to sort out a consensus as well as mutually acceptable public policy initiatives and common goals," Soong said.

In his view, Soong said, the most critical consensus reached in his meeting with Chen lies in their common recognition that both the ruling and opposition parties should be loyal to the Republic of China. "Opposition and ruling parties should communicate sincerely and pragmatically. Pragmatism is the best way. Taiwan must reconcile with mainland China, but it cannot waver on its fundamental stance as well as its liberal, democratic system," Soong said.

He further said the PFP legislative caucus is willing to rationally discuss with its DPP and Kuomintang (KMT) counterparts crucial bills such as draft amendments to the Executive Yuan organizational law, the National Assembly operational law, the cross-strait peace promotion bill, the ethnic equality bill and major bills regarding people's livelihoods.
"The PFP will not hesitate to support reasonably crafted bills or amendments and will refrain from irrational boycotts implemented for partisan interests," Soong said.
As an opposition party, Soong added, the PFP will continue to play a strict supervisory role in monitoring the government to prevent corruption and irregularities.
Soong, who served as KMT Chairman Lien Chan's running mate in the 2004 presidential election, said the PFP still insists on the pursuit of the truth of the election-eve shooting of Chen.
"Nevertheless, the case is now a judicial one and should be resolved by judicial means, not anything else," Soong said.

The Lien-Soong ticket narrowly lost to the DPP ticket of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu in the election last March. Lien and Soong have filed two lawsuits to have the Chen-Lu ticket's re-election and even the entire election invalidated. The Taiwan High Court rejected both suits and Lien has appealed the case to the Supreme Court, which has yet to rule on the lawsuits.
Core supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP were unhappy with Soong's meeting with Chen, as they regarded the meeting as a move by Soong to recognize Chen's presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES LEGISLATIVE RESOLUTION TO OPPOSE TO 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Tuesday urged the caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan to work out a resolution to express the will of the people of Taiwan to oppose the legislation of a proposed 'anti-secession law" in mainland China.
The "anti-secession law" will soon be reviewed by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament, and is expected to be approved when it meets in early March.

The TSU, in its version of a counter-resolution, noted that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state, and that Taiwan people have the right to decide their own future and fate. China should not enact any laws that cover the territory and people of Taiwan. The encroachment on Taiwan's sovereignty is bound to trigger resistance from Taiwan people.

According to the resolution, Beijing's willful promotion of the "anti-secession law" will undermine cross-strait peaceful development and trigger tensions in the Asia and Pacific region. As a member of the international community, Beijing should respect the aspirations of the region and suspend the promotion of the "anti-secession law."

The legislation will not help advance cross-trait peace or contribute to cross-strait exchanges, but will hurt the feelings of tens of thousands of mainland-based Taiwan businessmen and 23 million people on Taiwan and put a damper on Taiwan businessmen's willingness to invest in the mainland, the resolution said.

Lo Chih-ming, TSU party whip, said that Speaker Wang Jin-pyng had promised to coordinate with other party caucuses Thursday to produce a resolution that is agreed upon by all parties to convey the sense of strong protest against Beijing's "anti-secession law."

Lo also said that the TSU will go to the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association of Japan, Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties, to impress upon them that Taiwan people hope China will forego the enactment of the law.
The TSU will also call on the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, hoping that the U.S. will convey the feelings of Taiwan people toward the law, he said.
On March 6, the TSU will sponsor a large demonstration in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, to protest the proposed law, Lo added. (By Lilian

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The shoe bomber from a Gloucester grammar.
For two years Saajid Badat hid the evidence of his secret life as an al-Qaeda suicide bomber in a green case under his bed in his parents' terraced house in Gloucester. In that bag was the detonator for the high-explosive device with which he had been ordered to blow up a transatlantic airliner, killing himself and the hundreds of passengers on board. Badat, 25, a grammar school boy with four A levels, was part of the same terrorist until as Richard Reid -- the British shoe bomber now in prison in the United States. In a plot hatched by Osama bin Laden and his associates in their Afghan hideaway, the two britons were to begin the second wave of spectacular terrorist attacks after those in New York and Washington on September 11, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXTENDS OLIVE BRANCH TO BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Luis Huang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said in a recent interview with Newsweek magazine that his administration is willing to discuss any kind of peace treaty with mainland China in an effort to secure peace across the Taiwan Strait.
"We are willing to discuss and talk about any sort of peace agreement -- short-term, long-term, mid-term, " Chen told staff reporters at the Presidential Office in Taipei.

Chen made the remarks when asked to express his viewpoints on a proposal by Kenneth Lieberthal, an advisor to former U.S. President Bill Clinton on East Asia, that Taiwan and the mainland delay a final resolution of the island's status for a generation to avoid war, during which Taipei would agree not to declare independence and Beijing would agree not to use force against the island.

As for another Lieberthal proposal -- that sensitive cross-strait issues be set aside for 30 years -- Chen said that 30 years is just a proposed time frame, adding that "if by then China has not achieved a mature democracy, we could delay it to 50 or 100 years."

Asked to envision a future in which Taiwan and the mainland unify, Chen noted that if the people of Taiwan choose to unify with the mainland one day, it must be done after their political situations have achieved complete synergy in which both sides enjoy democratic elections, multiparty politics, a truly neutral military and freedom of speech.
Moreover, Chen added, by then the average income on the mainland should be about equal to that of Taiwan.

In reply to the question of whether Beijing's plan to enact a new "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan will impact the island, Chen expressed deep concern over the issue, pointing out that Taiwan might not be able to change Beijing's decision.

"This year we successfully arranged charter flights from the mainland to Taiwan for the Lunar New Year holiday, signifying that cross-strait relations are making advancements, like flowers blossoming in the spring. But if they insist on passing the "anti-secession law, " it would be like casting a shadow and causing torrential rain, " Chen said, adding that groups in Taiwan have started talking about enacting counterlegislation such as an anti-annexation law. "Is this the result the Beijing authorities want to achieve?" the president asked.

Touching on several critics' statement that he has contributed to cross-strait tension by being needlessly provocative, Chen said Beijing should understand that the referendum and protests last year only reflected the people's love for their homeland.

"Some want to misrepresent such events as provocative gestures. But they have overlooked the aspirations of Taiwan's 23 million people to be the masters of their own land, and the fact that China has deployed 706 ballistic missiles targeting us. Should Taiwan just raise a white flag and surrender?"

As for whether any configuration of the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" formula for unification are acceptable, Chen said that "we hope to see only one system everywhere, and that is the democratic system."

The president voiced the hope that Taiwan's democracy can serve as a lighthouse for Beijing and that the mainland will become democratic, even more so than Taiwan is today. "But China lacks important elements like elections, multiparty politics and a neutral military," he went on.

Asked what he achieved by meeting opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong last week, Chen said the meeting has proved that anything is possible, even reconciliation between the ruling party and the opposition.
Chen further said he took the opportunity to reaffirm his promises, including no declaration of Taiwan independence and no change of the name of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT SETS UP PRIZES FOR FEMALE TALENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Tuesday that she has decided to establish a series of prizes for female talent.
Making the announcement in a meeting with Presidential Office reporters, Lu said the prizes will cover two major categories -- prizes for women and scholarships for aboriginal women.

According to Lu, the "vice president scholarship for female aboriginal talent" will provide subsidies fund of between NT$200,000 (US$6,450) and NT$400,000 to each female aboriginal student who wins the opportunity to study abroad on government sponsorship.

Also, a subsidy of NT$100,000 will be offered to each female aboriginal student in the third year of undergraduate programs and above in the fields of law, accounting, finance and economics, science and technology, and international affairs, Lu said.
Lu said applications for the scholarships will be processed by the Council of Indigenous Peoples and the Ministry of Education, with recommendations by local universities accepted.
A ceremony is expected to be held May 20 to award the scholarships, she said.
As for the "vice president prizes for female talent, " a committee will select 10 outstanding women based on public recommendations at the end of this year, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REPORT RECOGNIZES TAIWAN'S HUMAN RIGHTS CONDITIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 28 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department gave a positive evaluation of Taiwan's human rights conditions in its newly released annual statement on global human rights practices.

Titled "Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for the Year 2004, " it examines the status of human rights in 197 countries. The 10,000-word section on Taiwan recognizes Taiwan's progress in democratic development, market economy, freedom of the press, freedom of speech, religious freedom and various human rights protection measures.

Nevertheless, the report also points out several flaws and deficiencies in Taiwan's human rights practices, including a few corrupt cases involving judicial personnel, alleged abuse of detained suspects by police, overcrowding in some prisons and human smuggling practices.
The report begins by defining Taiwan as a multi-party democracy that underwent its first-ever transition of power between different political parties in 2000.

In the 2004 presidential election, the report says, incumbent President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu won re-election a day after they were shot and slightly injured. Even though the beaten opposition camp filed two unsuccessful lawsuits to challenge the electoral result, the report says the election is generally recognized as free and open.
The report further says the opposition "pan-blue alliance" won a majority in last December's free and open Legislative Yuan elections.
The report says the 23 million people of Taiwan enjoy a high standard of living and that their incomes are generally equitable.

According to the report, Taiwan's government generally respects human rights, but it points out that there is still room for improvement, especially in areas such as official corruption, abuse of detained suspects and human smuggling for the sex trade.

Over the past year, the report says, no cases involving illegal killing by the government or government officials were reported. There were also no reports about the disappearance of any person for political reasons, the report says, adding that there were no political prisoners and no forced exiles. All Taiwan people enjoy the freedom to travel around the country or abroad, the report adds.

The report also recognizes Taiwan's freedom of assembly, citing as an example the large crowds of "pan-blue alliance" supporters that staged massive protests in front of the Presidential Office after the presidential election.

Meanwhile, the report notes the steady rise of Taiwan women's role in the political arena, saying that the nation's first-ever female vice president, Annette Lu, was re-elected and that Yeh Chu-lan became Taiwan's first-ever female vice premier following the presidential election.

Of the 36 Cabinet members, eight were female; of the 25 Control Yuan members, two were female; of the 20 Examination Yuan members, three were women; of the 34 Central Standing Committee members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, eight were female; and of the 225 legislators, 47 were women.
According to the report, Taiwan has not imposed any restrictions on and has cooperated closely with human rights surveys by international human rights organizations or non-government organizations.

The report lauds Taiwan's prisons as "meeting international standards." It further says the Taiwan authorities allow representatives of international human rights organizations to visit prison inmates. But it points out that 47 Taiwan prisons are overcrowded and require further improvements.
The report praises Taiwan's efforts to upgrade the quality of police officers by setting up the Central Police University.

It also recognizes the DPP administration's efforts at eliminating vote-buying and official corruption, saying that 1,276 people were indicted in 2003, with 640 cases involving corruption and the remaining involving vote-buying. Among those indicted, 687 were government officials and 65 were elected representatives.

Regarding press freedom, the report says Taiwan's news media are vibrant. But it adds that Taiwan's market may be unable to support such a large-scale media industry, leading to the phenomenon whereby some media organizations have to rely on government advertisements and loans from state-owned banks, which the report says could make those media become reserved in criticizing the government.

The report also notes that the legislature passed into law a bill in late 2003 that requires political parties, the government and the military to relinquish their stake in the media to rid them of political interference.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF ARRIVES IN TOKYO FOR 5-DAY VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 1 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung arrived in Tokyo Tuesday for a five-day visit.

Lin just announced his decision earlier in the day to resign from his Cabinet post to seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run for the mayorship of the central Taiwan city of Taichung.

During his Japan visit, Lin will meet with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara as well as mayors of two major Japanese port cities of Yokohama and Nagoya. Lin will tour Yokohama's newly developed commercial zone and the exhibition site of the 2005 World Expo scheduled to open in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi later this month.

In addition, Lin will attend a seminar on East Asia security and prosperity to be held at the Japanese Press club in Tokyo. The seminar will bring together scholars, experts and parliamentarians from Japan, the United States and Taiwan to discuss the content of the new U.S.-Japanese security treaty as well as the possible impact of Beijing's anti-secession law and Taiwan's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE VOLUME TOPS US$61.63 BILLION IN 2004

TEXT.P: The volume of trade between Taiwan and mainland China amounted to US$61.63 billion in 2004, up 33.1 percent from the previous year, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported Tuesday.
The figure accounted for 18 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade volume, representing an increase of 0.9 percent from 2003, according to the report.
Exports to the mainland rose 27.2 percent year-on-year to US$44.96 billion in 2004, which corresponded to 25.8 percent of total exports by Taiwan.
Imports from the mainland also jumped 52.2 percent year-on-year to US$16.67 billion in 2004, which accounted for 9.9 percent of total imports by Taiwan.
Trade surplus towards the mainland amounted to US$28.28 billion in 2004, up 15.9 percent from 2003.

BOFT officials said cross-strait trade continued to expand last year owing to rapid economic growth on the mainland, with monthly export volume from Taiwan to the mainland registering at between US$3.7 billion to US$4 billion, despite negative factors such as Beijing's measures to cool its overheated economy, soaring international oil prices and appreciation of major currencies.
Meanwhile, the robust global demand for Taiwan products also boosted the import of raw materials, electronic parts and components and intermediates from the mainland, they said.

Major items exported by Taiwan to the mainland in 2004 included electrical equipment and parts, optical products and parts, machinery and parts, plastics, steel, organic chemical products, man-made fibers, copper and industrial textiles.

Major items imported from the mainland in 2004 were electrical equipment and parts, machinery and parts, steel, fossil fuel, optical products and parts, organic chemical products, aluminum, plastics, cement, and automobiles and parts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY RATED GREEN LIGHT FOR JANUARY: CEPD

TEXT.P: A green light was recorded for Taiwan's economy in January for the fourth consecutive month, meaning that the domestic economy has been growing steadily, according to a government report released Monday.

The report, compiled by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan, shows that the composite index, which combines both leading and current indicators, fell to 24 points for January from December's 26 points.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, attributed the decrease in the composite index mainly to poor performance of the domestic financial and stock markets during that period.
He added that should the score continue to drop to the 22-point level, a "yellow-blue light" will be signalled to reflect a lackluster economy.

According to the report, the index of leading indicators for January stood at 102. points, down 2.1 percent from the previous month's 104. 3 points, the largest decrease since October 2000, while the index of current indicators moved up by 0.8 percent to 109.0 points.

In the CEPD-devised five-color rating system, a red light signifies an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates a heating-up economy, green reflects steady growth, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue represents recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATIZATION OF STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES IS VITAL: MOF

TEXT.P: The privatization of state-run enterprises is vital to the country's economy, according to a statement issued Tuesday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
The MOF said in the statement that the privatization is aimed at increasing Taiwan's overall competitiveness and that the government has been following processes approved by the Legislative Yuan.

Commenting on reports that state-run Taiwan Cooperative Bank, Chunghua Telecom and Changhua Commercial Bank will issue a large number of global depository receipts (GDRs) in overseas markets, MOF officials said that Taiwan's financial institutions will further improve their international credit rating and sharpen their international competitiveness through issuing the GDRs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY LAUNCHES HOTLINE FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior launched a multi-lingual telephone hotline Tuesday to serve foreign and mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens.

The "0800-088-885" hotline provides counseling to foreign spouses on topics concerning adapting to life here, education and culture, employment, medical services and health, and residency applications.
It is available in Mandarin, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Thai, English and Cambodian, ministry officials said.

Mandarin and Vietnamese services will be available between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. from Monday to Friday, while services in the other four languages will be available between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m., the officials said.

Vice Interior Minister Lin Yung-chien pointed out that the number of foreigners and mainland Chinese married to Taiwanese totaled 330,000 people as of December 2004 and that the ministry has set up a NT$3 billion (US$96.7 million) fund to provide care and guidance for this increasing demographic.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOTTERY TO BE USED TO BOOST ELECTION TURNOUT: CEC HEAD

TEXT.P: A section titled "Questions with Prizes" will be tacked on to the election notice for the election of National Assembly members in May to boost voter turnout, an election official said Tuesday.

Chang Cheng-hsiung, chairman of the Central Election Commission (CEC) , said that voters who answer "Yes" or "No" to the two questions, which are in fact not questions at all but rather statements, will be eligible for a lottery with a first prize of NT$1 million by simply handing the section to election officials at polling stations.
They may opt to not hand back the section, the CEC chief said.

According to Chang, the first "question" will be: "If the National Assembly produced through this election approves amendments to the Constitution, the electoral system of the legislators will be switched from the current multiple lawmakers per constituency to a single lawmaker per constituency."

The second "question" will be: "In line with the switch of the electoral system, voters will get two ballots in legislative elections -- one ballot for their favored party, one for their favored candidate."
Both statements are correct.
Chang said the winners of the lottery will be chosen through a two-phase drawing, with the first phase choosing a county or city from which the winners will be chosen in the second phase.
The game, designed to encourage voters to go to the polls, will be unprecedented, said Chang.
Also, the ballots for the election will be printed in horizontal type, in line with the change in all official documents, rather than the traditional vertical type, Chang said.

The National Assembly members elected will be charged with the task of amending the Constitution by simply approving or denying the proposals already tabled and agreed upon by the various political parties in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM MARKS 10TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) under the Department of Health (DOH) invited six people Tuesday who have not seen a doctor over the past five years to explain their methods of staying healthy as part of the celebration of the bureau's 10th anniversary.

Three of them -- Kung Li-chu, Shih Ming-shang and Chang chao-hsiung -- are in their late 60s. None of them have ever used their national health insurance cards to seek medical treatment over the past five years. They attributed their health to regular exercise, an optimistic and open-minded attitude toward life and leading a simple, regulated way of life.

According to BNHI tallies, 56,979 people have never seen a doctor under the national health insurance (NHI) program over the past 10 years and 128,975 people have never used their NHI cards in the past five years.
The BNHI offered special gifts to more than 2,000 of them through a lottery draw to express its appreciation for their contributions to the financially troubled insurance program.

BNHI tallies show that the health insurance program has offered medical services to an average of 920,000 insured people every day for the past decade, with its daily medical spending reaching an average of NT$1.1 billion.
The statistics also show that NT$24 out of every NT$100 spent under the NHI program was used to care for patients with serious diseases or injuries.
Meanwhile, there are 16 doctors to serve every 10,000 people.
According to BNHI estimates, people from low-income families can receive NT$5-worth of medical services for every NT$1 they actually pay.

An official said the BNHI is now working on a second-generation health insurance program under which the insurance premium will be calculated in terms of household income instead of personal salaries, as is the case under the current system.

The BNHI has offered interest-free loans to more than 60,000 low-income families annually to pay their insurance premiums, the official said, adding that the national health insurance program has had an approval rating of over 70 percent over the past five years.

Meanwhile, the DOH said it plans to raise the ceiling on the index insurance premiums from the current NT$87,600 to NT$131,700 from April to help keep the shaky insurance program afloat. About 167,000 people will have to pay an average additional NT$145 in monthly premiums.
Moreover, the insured amount of the 600,000 government employees, teachers and military personnel will be raised from the current 82.42 percent of their monthly salary to 87.04 percent.
After these two measures are implemented, the BNHI will have an additional income of NT$3.4 billion annually to support the health insurance program.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST MANUFACTURERS NEUTRAL ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC OUTLOOK: POLL

TEXT.P: Taipei, Jan. 1 (CAN) Nearly 60 percent of Taiwan manufacturers are neutral about their economic prospects for the next three months, according to the results of a government survey released Tuesday.

The poll, conducted by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development Council (CEPD) in January, shows that 23 percent of those polled expected the domestic economy to take a turn for the better, in comparison with December's 12 percent.
The ratio for those who expect the economic outlook to take a turn for the worse during the coming three months remained unchanged at 17 percent, the survey indicates.
In January, sales in Taiwan's manufacturing sector increased by 28.2 percent in value year-to-year, while new orders received by manufacturers grew by 19.1 percent.

At the same time, the utilization rate of installed facilities averaged 80.3 percent, up 3.2 percent from the same period of last year. The average sales profit rate stood at 4.9 percent, posting an annual growth rate of 0.2 percent.
The CEPD carries out the survey every month to gauge changes in the domestic business community.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Retail Deal Could Signal The End For Hecht's.
The 61-store Hecht's chain, and most other May Department Stores Co. regional brands, are likely to be converted into Macy's or Bloomingdale's under a proposed acquisition agreement with Federated Department Stores Inc., executives said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 2 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, March 2:

09:00, The Cisco Solutions Showcase 2005 will open at the Taipei International Convention Center.

10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will decorate former Premier Yu Shyi-kun, former Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan and former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Yeh Kuo-hsin at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES E.U. NOT TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO ON MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the European Union Tuesday to support Taiwan and not to lift its arms embargo on mainland China.

In a teleconference with several European parliamentarians and journalists in Brussels, Chen said the E.U.'s possible lifting of the embargo is a cause of serious concern to the United States and Japan because both countries understand it would tip the military balance between Taiwan and the mainland.

Citing the repeated resolution of the European Parliament demanding that Beijing withdraw its missiles targeting Taiwan, the president said that the number of Beijing's missiles has increased from 496 in 2003 to 706 this year.
The lifting of the arms embargo would also send the wrong message to the mainland authorities that the communist regime need neither improve its human rights record nor move toward democracy.

He also urged the European states to realize the mainland's attempts to unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait by enacting an anti-secession law designed to prevent Taiwan from pursuing its own political identity.

The law would give the mainland the legal basis to dictate the status of Taiwan, which would disrupt the stability across the strait and pose a serious risk to peace in the Asian Pacific region, Chen claimed.

He rebutted the criticism from "leaders of certain countries" of his decision to hold a national referendum along with the 2004 presidential election, saying that referendum is an inherent part of democracy, and questioned "Why can France hold a referendum but Taiwan cannot?"

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DENIES ANY CROSS-STRAIT CONSENSUS ON `ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh denied Tuesday that Taiwan and mainland China ever reached consensus on the definition of "one China" in their landmark 1992 negotiations in Hong Kong -- the so-called "'92 Consensus."

During an interpellation in the Legislative Yuan, the premier turned down a request from a lawmaker of the opposition Kuomintang to acknowledge the existence of the "'92 Consensus, " saying that at best, the two sides merely "agreed to disagree" on the issue.
"'Agree to disagree' means 'no coalescence of opinion' at all, " the premier pointed out.

The consensus, purporting to be agreed upon by Taiwan and China during the 1992 negotiations, has been considered by Beijing as the basis for its engagement with Taiwan. Beijing insisted on Taiwan's acknowledgement of the consensus as a condition for the resumption of bilateral dialogue.
Hsieh's denial means the political impasse will continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPLITTING TAIWAN WEAKENS ITS POSITION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The consensus of a Taiwan-centric identity would be better built through reconciliation among the political groups than through fierce partisan bickering, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

In a defense of his "charm offensive" on the opposition parties, Hsieh told a lawmaker from his Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan that splitting Taiwan would only weaken the country's international position and give an "alien regime" an opportunity to manipulate the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will leave for Japan Wednesday for a four-day visit, according to a press release issued Tuesday by the Taipei city government.
During his visit, Ma will meet with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada and Republic of China Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai, according to the statement.
Ma will invite both Ishihara and Nakada to attend the Taipei International Healthy City Expo 2005.

He will also tour economic and public transport facilities of Tokyo and Yokohama and learn about their construction and operation experiences for his city's reference before departing for home March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, March 2, or the 22nd day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to th e lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1791: John Wesley, British religious leader and founder of Methodism, dies at the age of 88.
1793: Sam Houston, the American soldier who was responsible for winning control of Texas from Mexico and who became the first president of the Republic of Texas, is born.
1864: President Abraham Lincoln, who led the Union during the American Civil War, rejects Gen. Robert E. Lee's call for peace talks, demanding surrender.
1900: Legation ministers of various countries in Beijing demand that China's Ching court take severe disciplinary measures against the "Righteous Harmony Fist" Boxers, who laid siege to the foreign legation, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russian and American troops held out for over a month.
1931: Mikhail Gorbachev, the last president of the Soviet Union, who introduced liberalizing reforms popularly referred to as "Glasnost" and "Perestroika," is born.
1943: Allied planes sink 12 Japanese ships carrying reinforcements into battle in New Guinea, killing nearly 4,000.
1946: Ho Chi Minh is elected president of North Vietnam.
1949: Captain James Gallagher lands at Forth Worth in Texas after completing the first round-the-world nonstop flight aboard a U.S. Air Force B-50 bomber.
1955: Floods kill 200 people and leave 400,000 others homeless in Australia.
1956: The Ministry of Education of the Republic of China approves the upgrading of Tainan College of Technology to National Chengkung University.
1956: France and Morocco issue a joint statement recognizing Morocco's independence.
1961: Four divisions of Communist Chinese troops enter northern Burma in an attempt to wipe out ROC anti-communist guerrillas remaining there.
1962: General Ne Win overthrows Premier U Nu in a military coup in Burma.
1969: Communist Chinese and Soviet troops engage in heavy fighting around Chenpao (Damansky) Island along their shared border, with each side accusing the other of intruding upon their national territory.
1969: The French prototype 001 Concorde, the supersonic Anglo-French airliner, makes a successful first test flight from Toulouse, France.
1971: Gen. Kim Kye Won, new Korean ambassador to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1971: The first Australian Industrial and Trade display in the ROC opens in Taipei.
1982: South Korea releases 2,863 political prisoners and reduces the prison term of Kim Young Sam from life to 20 years. Kim would later become president of the country.
1986: Taiwan's first confirmed AIDS patient dies.
1986: Queen Elizabeth II signs the Australian Bill, severing Britain's formal ties with its former colony almost two centuries after British convicts were first shipped to Botany Bay in 1788.
1989: The first Vietnamese boat people to volunteer to return home leave Hong Kong.
1991: Referendums are held in both Latvia and Estonia, with most people in the Baltic Sea countries voting for independence.
1994: The ROC and Belize sign a joint communique pledging bilateral cooperation.
1996: The Labor Party led by Paul Keating suffers a massive defeat in Australian elections.
2000: The ROC Navy dispatches a frigate to rescue crew members on board the Cambodian freighter Golden Dragon, which suffered mechanical failure off the coast of Oluanpi, Pintung County.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu presides over a ceremony where US$570,000 in cash and US$270,000 worth of relief goods are formally donated to India which was hit by a devastating earthquake on Jan 26.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the cold of winter comes, it is then you know that the pine tree and the cypress are the last to lose their green."

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. LAWMAKER TO TABLE MOTION AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, March 1 (CNA) (By Y. S. Lo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A German member of the European Parliament expressed explicit opposition Tuesday to Beijing's plans to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.
E.U. Parliamentarian Georg Jazembowski said he will initiate a resolution at the Parliament soon to give the E.U. lawmakers an opportunity to try to prevent enactment of the proposed law.

Jazembowski said the European Parliament should, via a resolution, tell the Chinese categorically that what the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need is politicial dialogue, instead of weapons aimed at each other.

Jazembowski made the remarks during a teleconference held Tuesday, during which Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian exchanged views with a number of E.U. lawmakers as well as journalists stationed in Brussels.

During the video-conference, President Chen called on the European Union not to lift its ban on arms sales to mainland China, saying that the possible lifting of the embargo has been a cause of serious concern to the United States and Japan because both countries understand it would tilt the military balance across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen also urged the E.U. member states to realize the mainland's attempts to unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait by enacting an anti-secession law designed to prevent Taiwan from pursuing its own political identity.

Jazembowski, who has visited Taiwan in the past and who referred to President Chen as "my dear friend" during the teleconference, claimed that the proposed anti-secession law is a "political weapon" aimed at Taiwan.

Jazembowski added that he has been pushing for the European Union to pay closer attention to the security situations in the Asia-Pacific region, including some "sensitive" issues involving Korea, China, Japan and Taiwan.

During the video-conference, President Chen said that the number of mainland Chinese missiles aimed at Taiwan has increased from 496 in 2003 to 706 this year despite repeated European Parliament resolutions demanding that Beijing withdraw the missiles.

A lifting of the arms embargo would also send the wrong message to the mainland authorities that the communist regime need neither improve its human rights record nor move toward democracy, Chen said.

He added that the law would give the mainland the legal basis to dictate the status of Taiwan, which would disrupt the stability across the strait and pose a serious risk to peace in the Asian Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER MIGHT ANNOUNCE BID TO RUN FOR KMT CHAIRMAN SOON

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who also serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , said Wednesday he is likely to run for the party's chairmanship if incumbent Chairman Lien Chan decides not to seek re-election.
Wang said he will see what Lien's true attitude is before making his next move.
According to Wang, although Lien has expressed a lack of interest in continuing his chairmanship, this does not mean he definitely will not run for re-election.
While it is widely believed that Wang will run for the next KMT chairmanship, he has not made an official announcement.
The KMT is scheduled to promulgate on March 21 details of the chairmanship election which is set for May.
Wang said he will make an announcement before the deadline for registration and start campaigning for his bid if he decides to join the election.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, another KMT vice chairman, who announced his decision to run in the chairmanship election last month, said he has not set up a campaign office.
Also on Wednesday, Wang called for unity of the "pan-blue" alliance of the KMT, People First Party and New Party while delivering a report to the KMT's Central Standing Committee.

Wang pointed out that Premier Frank Hsieh's policy of reconciliation and coexistence, which differs from the hard-line policy adopted by his predecessor Yu Shyi-kun, seems to have won much popular support.

However, Wang said, the adjustments of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are only a compromise following its setback in last year's legislative elections, and not a reflection of its past mistakes.
Wang warned that the DPP will restore its old attitude if the "pan-blue" alliance falls apart.

With polls showing skepticism of Bush's proposal and some Republicans opposed to the approach, GOP leaders signal that they may have no choice.
