DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF MEETS TOP TAIWAN ENVOY IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 2 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung met with Taiwan's top representative to Japan, Koh Se-kai, Wednesday to exchange views mainly on Beijing's plans to enact an anti-secession law and its possible impact on Taiwan.
Lin called for consolidation among the political parties in Taiwan to jointly deal with the challenges that Taiwan now faces, including Beijing's move to enact an anti-secession law.

Lin, who arrived in Tokyo Tuesday for a five-day visit, also called for the Beijing leadership to stop enactment of the anti-secession law before it's too late to avoid the Taiwanese people from taking to the streets or moving to enact an anti-annexation law in response.

The GIO chief is one of the Taiwan officials, including Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, who have been traveling abroad recently to amplify Taiwan's opposition to and concerns about China's proposed anti-secession law.

During the meeting with Lin, Koh was asked by reporters about Japanese news reports that President Chen Shui-bian's wife, Wu Shu-jen, is planning to visit Japan in the near future. Koh said that his office has yet received any information on the matter.

Commenting on President Chen's remarks a day earlier that he is unable to change the nation's official designation of "the Republic of China" to "the Republic of Taiwan" during his term, Koh said that changing the national designation and changing the names of Taiwan offices overseas are two different matters.

Noting that changing the names of Taiwan's overseas offices or missions to include the word "Taiwan" would help Taiwan to be more clearly identified in the international community, Koh said the name-change drive should be forged ahead with.

Lin, who announced his decision Tuesday to resign from his Cabinet post to seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run for the mayorship of the central Taiwan city of Taichung, is expected to meet with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara as well as Mayor Hiroshi Nakada of the Japanese port city of Yokohama, during his stay in Japan.
He will also tour Yokohama's newly developed commercial zone and the exhibition site of the 2005 World Expo scheduled to open in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi later this month.

In addition, Lin will attend a seminar on East Asia security and prosperity to be held at the Japanese Press Club in Tokyo. The seminar will bring together scholars, experts and lawmakers from Japan, the United States and Taiwan to discuss the contents of the new U.S.-Japanese security treaty as well as the possible impact of Beijing's anti-secession law and Taiwan's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SELECT TOP GEOGRAPHERS FOR INTERNATIONAL COMPETITION

TEXT.P: A nationwide geography tournament among teenage students is about to kick off with the aim of finding the three best geographers in Taiwan who will represent the country in the 2005 National Geographic World Championship.

The Taiwan district tournament, jointly organized by the Ministry of Education, the Taipei-based Geographical Society of China and National Geographic Magazine, will be held in three stages -- the premier contests, qualifying contests in counties and cities, then the national final.

In the premier competitions, some 1.2 million students around the island who are between sixth grade in elementary school and third grade in middle school will participate. They will have to pass a common test on paper or acquire the recommendation of school authorities to enter the second stage, according to the organizers.
Only 90 students who get through the qualifying rounds will be chosen to compete in the final to fight for the ticket to Hungary for the world championship in July.

Top geographers from more than 20 nations will take part in the biannual contest, according to a statement released by the organizers of the Taiwan tournament. It also said that it is the first time Taiwan has been invited to compete.

Deputy Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu has said that geography is an essential basic course in the civic education because it trains students to open their eyes to the world and to know where they come from.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March lost 50 points to close at 6,200, with 27,486 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved down 43 points to finish at 6,205, with 420 contracts traded, while June futures lost 39 points to finish at 6,200, with 10 contracts traded.
September futures lost 39 points to finish at 6,137, with 16 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 20 points to close at 6,150, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,250 for March, 6,248 for April, 6,239 for June, 6,176 for September and 6,170 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
March TE futures moved down 2.3 points to close at 234.8, with 3,873 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 2.75 points to finish at 234.5, with 34 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

March TF futures lost 8.4 points to finish at 1,023.2, with 3,315 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 8.8 points to end at 1,024, with 41 contracts traded. September TF futures lost 4.2 points to finish at 1,023.8, with four contracts changing hands. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-INDEPENDENT LAWMAKER NAMES ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS COUNCIL CHIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh announced Wednesday the appointment of former independent aboriginal Legislator Walis Pelin as chairman of the Council of Aboriginal Affairs, scheduled to take effect March 10.
Hsieh said that Walis Pelin has been an independent legislator elected by aborigine voters for many terms and has constantly kept abreast of aboriginal affairs and related developments.

Walis Pelin, himself an aborigine, has also been supportive of President Chen Shui-bian's vow to allow Taiwan's aboriginal population of around 450,000 to run their own autonomous communities, Hsieh noted.

Hsieh added that he exchanged views with Walis Pelin before making the decision on the appointment and that during the talks, he became aware that the legislator's perspective on projects to save or co-operate in aboriginal communities islandwide match those of his own "islandwide community development plans."

Hsieh also made known his admiration for Chen Chien-nien, the outgoing chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs, who offered to resign recently after he was charged by Taitung prosecutors with vote-buying.
Hsieh accepted Chen's resignation Tuesday but noted that being prosecuted does not necessarily mean Chen is guilty.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS NO COMMENT ON PRESIDENT'S ASSURANCE OF NO ROC NAME-CHANGE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 1 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department declined to comment Tuesday on President Chen Shui-bian's latest remarks that he will not change the official name of his country from the Republic of China to "Republic of Taiwan."
State Department Deputy Spokesman Adam Ereli told a daily press briefing he was unaware of Chen's comments.
However, he pointed out that Chen has made similar assurances before and that Washington takes them very seriously.
"He has certainly made assurances regarding unilateral steps in the past. We have welcomed those assurances and we continue to put great store by them," Ereli said.
He reiterated that Washington opposes unilateral action on either side of the Taiwan Strait and believes cross-strait tension should be resolved through dialogue.
In a teleconference with a group of European parliamentarians on that same day (Taipei time) , Chen said it is unnecessary for Taiwan to declare independence because it is already a sovereign state.

Furthermore, he said, it will be impossible during his term to change the official name of the country as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party controls less than 50 percent of seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan.

Chen also reaffirmed that his planned constitutional reforms will not involve changes to national sovereignty and territory or issues regarding unification and independence, on which a majority consensus is still lacking.
Any amendments to the Constitution require the approval of three fourths of the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: No More Free Flats for Many People.
Ushering in new rules that promise to change the way people live, a Housing Code came into force Tuesday that abolishes free apartments for scores of people in need of better housing, bans unauthorized apartment remodeling and allows residents of apartment blocks to turn to private companies for communal housing services. Supporters of the code, which was passed by the State Duma and signed into law by President Vladimir Putin in December, said it will bring order to a sector that has been largely chaotic in post-Soviet years and will give more rights to apartment owners.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 19TH IN THE WORLD IN DEFENSE SPENDING

TEXT.P: Taiwan spent US$7.3 billion on national defense in 2003, ranking 19th in the world, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) reported Wednesday.
Taiwan's 2003 defense budget was far less than the US$32.8 billion spent by mainland China in the same year, DGBAS officials said.

Quoting the latest yearbook published by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), DGBAS officials said that the world spent US$879 billion on arms in 2003, a record high since 1992, when such world spending totaled around US$847 billion.

The world military spending has gradually dropped since 1992 and the end of the Cold War, when the Soviet Union disintegrated, to the lowest point in six years of US$693 billion in 1998, DGBAS officials quoted the SIPRI report as indicating.
Beginning in 1998, however, world defense expenditure has risen yearly, to the 11-year high of US$879 billion in 2003, DGBAS officials said.

According to the SIPRI Yearbook, the United States, Japan, the United Kingdom, France and mainland China, in that order, were the top five defense-spending countries in the world, accounting for a total of more than 60 percent of the total military spending worldwide in 2003. The United States now accounts for 43 percent of world military expenditure.

The yearbook also notes marked regional disparities in military expenditure, DGBAS officials said, adding that in 2003, Saudi Arabia spent 9.8 percent of its GDP on the military, compared to the United States' 3.4 percent, Taiwan's 2.3 percent and China's 2.5 percent. Following Saudi Arabia, the four other top countries in terms of disparity were Israel, with 9.2 percent, Turkey, with 4.9 percent, Russia, with 4.0 percent and Iran, also with 4.0 percent.
Taiwan spent 2.3 percent of its GDP on defense in 2003, a decline of 2.3 percentage points from the 1994 level, DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES BEIJING TO HEED TAIWAN PUBIC OPINION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged mainland China Wednesday to heed President Chen Shui-bian's recent comment on the nation's sovereignty and not miscalculate Taiwan public opinion.

The premier was referring to Chen's statement Feb. 24 that the "Republic of China is a sovereign independent country, that the ROC's sovereignty belongs to the 23 million people of Taiwan and that only the 23 million people of Taiwan can make a final decision on any change of the nation's future."

The premier made the remarks as mainland China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress is about to meet to review and approve Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law." The law will lay the legal basis for Beijing to use force against Taiwan should the island declare independence.
Hsieh said the proposed law has caused revulsion among a great majority of the Taiwan people and that lawmakers across the party spectrum are opposed to it.

He urged Beijing not to miscalculate Taiwan public opinion and to adhere to its earlier statement that it "pins its hopes on the Taiwan people and respects the will of the Taiwan people to be their own masters."

Hsieh said that the recent outcry over the proposed law has shown to the international community and Beijing the voice of the Taiwan people, which says they love peace, want to maintain the status quo and insist on Taiwan's own identity.
He urged the international community to pay attention to peace in the Taiwan Strait and to work toward preventing Beijing's anti-secession legislation.

Hsieh also said that passing the "anti-secession law" would lack wisdom and undermine the basis for cross-strait co-existence. The enactment will not only sabotage the positive atmosphere between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that developed in the wake of the charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday, but will also have negative impact on cross-strait exchanges.
The premier also urged Beijing to contribute more positively to cross-strait peace and to stop using intimidation as an approach.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Labour shrugs off risk from pre-election rate increase.
Home owners are facing the prospect of an interest rate rise just weeks before an expected general election, although Labour insisted yesterday that the move would not cost it votes. A quarter-point increase would add 15 a month to the cost of a 100,000 home loan. Ed Balls, Gordon Brown's closest ally, said the Chancellor was fully prepared for a pre-election rise of a quarter point and claimed that a hike would highlight the strength of the economy rather than anger voters facing higher mortgage payments.
Financial Times: IMF casts doubt on German economy.
Germany's economic prospects have deteriorated sharply, the International Monetary Fund believes. Draft figures to be released shortly and obtained by Financial Times Deutschland, the FT's German sister paper, show the IMF expects the German economy to grow only 0.8 per cent in 2005 against its 1.8 per cent forecast last September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOBACCO TAX TO BE HIKED

TEXT.P: To reinforce efforts to counter and prevent tobacco hazards, the Cabinet passed Wednesday draft amendments to the Tobacco Control Act and the Tobacco and Liquor Tax Law.

Executive Yuan spokesman Chuo Jung-tai said at a news briefing that the amendments are centered on a move to double taxes on tobacco products, which will as a result hike the price of a pack of cigarettes by at least NT$5 (US$0.161) if the revisions are approved by the legislature.
Under the revised laws, cigarette taxes will be increased from NT$5 to NT$10 per pack. It has been assessed that the hike can add about NT$6 billion to the government's tax revenues.
The money will be used to support national heath insurance operations, according to Chuo.

Referring to the world's first global public health treaty -- the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) -- which entered into force Feb. 27, Chuo indicated that a tax increase on cigarettes is regarded as the most effective and powerful measure to reduce cigarette consumption in every class of consumers, especially teenagers.

Even though Taiwan is a not a member of the World Health Organization, which implemented the FCTC, the Legislative Yuan ratified the convention Jan. 14 to demonstrate the country's commitment to public health issues.

According to a survey conducted by the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, the number of smokers in Taiwan are estimated to be 4.89 million. The country spends some NT$30 billion a year on smoking-related illnesses that take the lives of an estimated 18,000 people on the island every year, the survey shows.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT VOICES CONCERN OVER TAIWAN SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, March 2 (CNA) (By Y.C. Jiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Former South Korean President Kim Young Sam voiced concern Wednesday over Taiwan's security and claimed that the international community will not allow Beijing to use its proposed anti-secession law to invade Taiwan.

Kim made the remarks during a meeting with a group of lawmakers from Taiwan led by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Shen Chih-hwei and composed of Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Yang Li-huan, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chang Hua-kuan and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Liu Kuan-ping, among others.

Kim pointed out that the international community is gravely concerned about Beijing's planned legislation of an anti-secession law aimed at Taiwan and said that the United States and Japan have made their stance clear by calling Taiwan a common strategic objective.
Shen urged Kim to help transmit Taiwan's opposition to the law to Beijing and claimed that its enactment will engulf the whole Asia in the danger of war should Beijing launch an attack of Taiwan.
"The legislation will provide Beijing with the legal basis to wage a preemptive war against Taiwan, " Shen said.

She also criticized Beijing's insistence on enacting the law despite Taiwan's show of goodwill, referring to the 10-point joint statement made public late last month by President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman James Soong.
Beijing's National People's Congress is expected to pass the anti-secession bill into law in the middle of this month.

For her part, Chang extended an invitation on behalf of President Chen inviting Kim to visit Taiwan again in the near future, and relayed the president's aspiration for peace in the Taiwan Strait and his pledge not to change the Republic of China's moniker during his term. Kim visited Taiwan in late October last year.
Chang also called for enhanced and closer exchanges between Taiwan and South Korea, given that the two countries share much common ground in their political developments.

Yang said that the imposition of Beijing's anti-secession law will undoubtedly stir up strong opposition among the people of Taiwan and she asked Kim to play the role of a bridge to help ease tension between Taiwan and the mainland.
Although the KMT is an opposition party, she said that it shares a common view with the government on protecting Taiwan's security and interests.
Echoing Yang's remarks, Liu said that the TSU stands firm with the Taiwan people against Beijing's scheme to swallow up Taiwan.
The legislative delegation will take part in a breakfast prayer meeting Thursday organized by the South Korean government on behalf of the Republic of China's Legislative Yuan.
While here, the Taiwan lawmakers will also visit the South Korean parliament and meet with their South Korean counterparts before flying back to Taiwan Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE CAMP ANGERED BY PRESIDENT'S 'NO NAME-CHANGE' WORDS

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) accused President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday of evading his responsibility after he claimed it will be impossible during his term to change the official name of the country.

Chen told a group of European parliamentarians through a teleconference a day earlier that the bid to change the name of the country from the Republic of China to "Republic of Taiwan" will not be achieved during his term in light of the fact that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) controls less than 50 percent of the seats in the Legislative Yuan.

Also, Chen noted that his predecessor, Lee Teng-hui, failed to change the name during his 12-year term and that he believes Lee would not be able to attain this goal, either, if he were still president today.
Lee is now the so-called "spiritual leader" of the TSU and is promoting a campaign to officially call the country "Taiwan" and to draft a new constitution.
Responding to the president's comments, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming claimed that Lee never put forth any ideas to change the name of the country during his terms as president.

However, he continued, President Chen has expressed on many occasions his support for efforts by pro-independence groups to change the name and to introduce a new constitution, but has done very little to honor his promises.
Lo Chih-ming, convener of the TSU legislative caucus, urged President Chen to stop using Lee as an excuse for evading his own responsibility.
Lo agreed that the goal to make Taiwan a truly independent, sovereign state is not attainable by the president alone because it requires the collective willpower of all Taiwanese people.
However, he said, Chen can call the tune for the 23 million people on the island and encourage them to work toward the goal, instead of dampening their spirits.
Meanwhile, independence supporters Koo Kuan-min and Ng Chiau-tong accused Chen of being capricious for backing away from his own promise to implement a new constitution for Taiwan in 2008.

Koo and Ng resigned in protest Tuesday as senior presidential adviser and national policy adviser, respectively, after Chen reaffirmed his "five noes" commitment, including no independence for Taiwan and no name-change for the country, during a meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong last week.

In the face of the widespread displeasure within the pro-independence camp at Chen's recent statements, DPP legislative caucus leader Lai Ching-teh proposed that senior party members visit pro-independence groups to seek their support.

Lai said the DPP has no intention of alienating the TSU or the pro-independence camp and he urged the TSU to work together with the DPP for the unity of Taiwan in order to counter the military threat from mainland China.

Lai pointed out that Lee's efforts to promote democratic reforms during his 12-year term encountered much obstruction even with the majority backing of the Kuomintang in the past, and said the situation faced by Chen now is even more difficult, given that the DPP and the TSU together enjoy only 101 seats in the 225-member legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN URGES E.U. NOT TO LET ARMS DEALERS DICTATE POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 2 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. House Representative Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) urged the European Union Tuesday not to let the vested interests of a few arms dealers dictate E.U. policy and not to lift its arms embargo on mainland China imposed in the wake of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
Chabot, co-leader of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a group friendly toward Taiwan in the U.S. Congress, made the remarks during a press conference for the Taiwan media at his office.

"Clearly, it would be a mistake for the Europeans to lift the arms embargo," Chabot said, adding that it is "against the interests of Taiwan, the interests to the United States and ultimately against the interest of Europeans."
He said the House has overwhelmingly passed the resolution opposing an E.U. lifting of the embargo and expressed the hope that the E.U. will take that into consideration.
Asked if the U.S. Congress will introduce a bill to sanction the E.U. if it lifts the embargo, Chabot said it is premature to talk about what the U.S. might or might not do.

But he expressed hope that the Europeans will act in their own interest, as the lifting will not be in anybody's best interests, particularly in light of what happened in Tiananmen Square and with mainland China's human rights record.

He also pointed out that although the United States is trying to work with the E.U. as closely as possible on a whole range of issues, he has not seen any weakening of the U.S. opposition to a lifting of the embargo.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF MOTORCYCLES TOPS 12.79 MILLION: MOTC

TEXT.P: As of the end of 2004, Taiwan had a total of 12.79 million scooters and motorcycles, up 3.5 percent over the previous year's level, officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Wednesday.

Taiwan ranked the first in major Asian countries in 2004 in terms of the number of vehicles owned by every 1,000 people and also came in first in terms of the number of vehicles per kilometer of road, the officials said.

According to the tallies released by the ministry, mainland China possessed the most scooters and motorcycles among major Asian countries, with a total of 33.17 million recorded in 2000, more than 13.54 million recorded in Japan in 2002, 11.98 million recorded in Taiwan, 5.84 million recorded in Malaysia and 1.47 million recorded in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER, THREE OTHERS DECORATED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decorated former Premier Yu Shyi-kun and three other former officials at a ceremony held at the Presidential Office Wednesday.
The three others honored were former Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, former Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang and former Executive Yuan Secretary-General Arthur Yap.

Yu was presented with the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon, while Yeh and Su received the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Grand Cordon, and Yap the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon.
All four said it was a great honor for them to be decorated.
Yu, who is now secretary-general to the president, expressed appreciation for the support of Chen and of his colleagues and family.
Su, who is now chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, expressed appreciation for the support of Chen and Yu and vowed to continued to work for the nation.

Yeh recalled that over the past 16 years, she has worked in the Legislative Yuan and later in the Executive Yuan and has followed President Chen all the way and is gratified to see that the core values of Taiwan are taking root in the country.
She expressed hope that Taiwan can become a normal and healthy country under Chen's leadership.
Yap said that earning a medal was a welcome bonus for simply carrying out his duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE FAVOR LIMITS ON HI-TECH OUTFLOWS: POLL

TEXT.P: Most of the people in Taiwan are in favor of imposing restrictions on the outflow of the country's high technologies, especially when the issue comes to national security in terms of mainland China, according to the results of a survey made public Wednesday.

The public opinion poll carried out by Taiwan Advocates, a private think tank promoting Taiwan independence, showed that nearly 70 percent of the people agreed with the government's control of outflows of Taiwan's hi-tech know-how amid aggressive foreign competition.

The ratio further went up to 72.6 percent when national security was taken into account, with 65 percent of the respondents favoring implementing such measures when it comes to the mainland, the poll discovered. Only 22 percent were in favor of a policy opening.
The survey was conducted Feb. 26-27, with 1,103 valid questionnaires recovered. It had a margin of error of 2.95 percent.
In line with the release of the survey results, Taiwan Advocates also held a seminar the same day in which scholars and specialists voiced their views on the issue.

Lo Cheng-fang, a professor at National Cheng Kung University, urged Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, formerly a well-known economist, to wholly review the government's policy on the grounds that Taiwan's leadership role in the global semiconductor industry has been seriously eroded by mainland China, which is posing a great threat to Taiwan's competitive edge and economic strength.

National Chiao Tung University Professor Wu Chung-hsing said that technology flight to mainland China will have a big impact on Taiwan's national security, accelerating industry's relocations and worsening unemployment at home.
Taiwan Advocates made the survey after a court case involving United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) provoked a heated debate in society.

UMC, the world's second-largest chipmaker on a contract basis, was charged last month by prosecutors with illegal investment in a mainland-based chip company based in Suzhou. The semiconductor giant's headquarters and factories in Taipei and Hsinchu were stormed by more than 80 prosecutors on tips provided by an informant.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASING ECONOMIC GROWTH A GOVERNMENT GOAL: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Striving to raise the economic growth rate this year above the projected 4.21 percent is a government goal, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.
Hsieh made the comment during a Cabinet meeting after listening to a briefing from the Council for Economic Planning and Development on the current economic situation.
Referring to the latest official report that shows the unemployment has steadily decreased to 4.06 percent in January, Hsieh said the figure proved the government's economic policies are working.
Taiwan had an economic growth rate of 5.71 percent last year, the best since 2001.

Since the global economy will be impacted by various factors, including fluctuations in exchange rates and interest rates, as well as changes in oil prices, the premier instructed his Cabinet to pay close attention to possible impacts on Taiwan and at the same time to take action to carry out major construction projects and boost private investments in public construction plans to preserve economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND STARTS NEW CAMPAIGN TO DRUM UP SUPPORT FOR ARMS DEAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) started a new campaign Wednesday to drum up support for its proposed purchase of arms from the United States.

The campaign features eight different posters appealing to the public's desire for peace and security, said Gen. Hu Cheng-pu, the chief of the Political Warfare Bureau, at a news conference to unveil the posters.

Hu said the posters were designed to bring home to the general public the importance of pursuing peace through strength and to steer clear of the political disputes between the ruling and opposition parties.

With each of the eight posters targeting a different group of people, Hu said the whole campaign will cover most demographics in Taiwan. The purchase, carrying a price tag of NT$610.8 billion (about US$ 18.23 billion) , has caused alarm in the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan because of its huge amount and because the government put it in a special budget that is exempt from the legal cap that exists on the government's ordinary budget.

The ministry's campaign last year focused on downplaying the cost of the package, claiming that the price would only be the cost of a cup of "pearl milk tea" per person per day, which only angered the opposition, who dismissed it as misleading.

The ministry is eager to have the budget approved as soon as possible, and Defense Minister Lee Jye has put his career at stake by threatening to step down if the arms purchase is killed by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO CUT STAFF BY NEARLY IN HALF WITHIN TWO YEARS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced a streamlining plan Wednesday to trim its staff to 600 from the current 1,100 in two years.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen made the announcement following a weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee -- the party's decision-making body.
The KMT hopes to keep 100 at party headquarters and 500 at local chapters, Cheng said.

The KMT will also divest itself of its properties and companies, the proceeds of which will be used as retirement funds, she said, adding that the party will not continue to own or run businesses in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN WANTS RESOLUTION AGAINST CHINA'S 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 2 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: U. S. Congressman Steve Chabot said Tuesday that he is urging the Congress to pass a resolution introduced by him on Feb. 17 to oppose China moving forward with its "anti-secession law."

Worrying that the legislation could upset the stability and the status quo in the region, Chabot who is the co-chairman of a pro-Taiwan group in the Congress -- the Congressional Taiwan Caucus -- said it would be a great mistake on the part of China to enact the law.

Although outsiders haven't seen the text of the Chinese law at this point, Chabot said, "We have a pretty good idea of what that language is going to say...what we've heard is it is very damaging to the stability of the region."

Noting that mainland China may move on the legislation next week, Chabot said the Congress has to act quickly. "We would encourage the State Department to join the Congress in convincing the PRC [People's Republic of China] not to move ahead with this," he said.

Asked to comment on Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's statement Tuesday in Taipei that he won't change the name of the Republic of China into the Republic of Taiwan, Chabot said Chen has made a good effort to try to lower tensions with mainland China. "I think he has handled this very responsibly and I commend him for his actions thus far," Chabot said.

In light of mainland China's substantial military buildup, Chabot urged Taiwan to move forward to modernize its military, saying that the U.S. is working with Taiwan, but there has been some foot-dragging in this regard for some time now.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE LACK GEOGRAPHY KNOWLEDGE: MAGAZINE INVESTIGATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan people are not good geographers, as results of a recent investigation made public Wednesday showed that nearly 70 percent of the public do not have adequate knowledge about their country and the rest of the world.

According to the results of a survey jointly carried out last month by the National Geographic Magazine and the Geographical Society of China based in Taiwan, 69 percent of Taiwan people failed to pass the test. The public received an average score of 46.8 points -- well below the passing level of 60 points based on a 100 scale.
Among the more than 1,000 people aged between 15 and 50 years tested, only nine people received a 100, and 334 people got a passing grade -- an average passing rate of about 31 percent.
Men outperformed women on the test, with a passing percentage of 30 percent to 24 percent, the investigation found.
In terms of age, the 31 to 35 age group was the most knowledgeable, while people living in northern Taiwan noticeably possess stronger geography knowledge than those residing in southern Taiwan.
The question most often missed was "Which country earns the most money from Taiwan?" The answer is Japan instead of mainland China.
Only 21 percent know the location of Afghanistan in West Asia, and 26 percent do not have any idea about Taiwan's population.

All this is an indication that Taiwan people are indifferent to this world and lack a basic understanding of their own country and the international community, a National Geographic Magazine executive said.

Shen Shu-min, a professor at National Taiwan Normal University, pointed out that the results should signal an urgent need for greater education reform to increase local people's knowledge about their own land and their international prospective.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL CYCLE SHOW TO OPEN MARCH 4

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taipei International Cycle Show will open March 4 at the Taipei World Trade Center, organizers of the event said Wednesday.
A total of 620 domestic and foreign companies have registered to take part in the annual trade fair and will display their products at 2,019 booths. The exhibition will run through March 7.

For the first time this year the organizers will hold an international cycling competition during the exhibition to increase the trade fair's international profile, officials of the Taiwan Foreign Trade Development Council said.
The Taipei International Elimination Road Race 2005 will be held March 6 with 40 athletes from 16 countries taking part, they added.
The venue of the competition will be a circuit of about 1.6 km around the Taipei World Trade Center Hall 3 and the winner of the race will win NT$100,000 (US$3,175) in cash, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE CALLS FOR GLOBAL COMMUNITY TO STRENGTHEN

TEXT.P: Saving energy and accelerating globalization must be key programs for global sustainability, Lee Yuan-tseh, winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, said Wednesday.

Lee, who serves as president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, warned in a speech on "living in the rapidly changing world" that a global crisis will erupt in 20 years if global consumption of crude oil maintains its current pace.
If this is the case, a war among nations that vie for energy resources may happen, he said.
The resolution to the problem would be saving on energy consumption and accelerating the globalization, he suggested.

Globalization would blur the boundaries between nations and countries would see problems in every corner of the world as their own domestic affairs and would not resort to the use of force to resolve international disputes, he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ARRIVES IN TOKYO FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou arrived in Tokyo Wednesday for a four-day visit.
He was greeted at the airport by a dozen leaders from the Chinese community, including an overseas legislator, Hsieh Wen-cheng.

During his visit, Ma will meet with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada and Republic of China Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai, according to an itinerary issued by the Taipei City Government in Taipei the previous day.
Ma is expected to invite both Ishihara and Nakada to attend the Taipei International Healthy City Expo 2005, which is expected to bring together 40 to 50 city chiefs from around the world.
The expo last year in Taipei brought together the chiefs of 16 international cities.
Before departing for home March 5, Ma will also visit economic and public transport facilities in Tokyo and Yokohama, and learn about their construction and operations for his city's reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL WORRIES ABOUT PEOPLE'S REACTION TO 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said Wednesday he is worried that the people of Taiwan will react drastically against mainland China if it moves forward with its "anti-secession law" in defiance of strong disapproval by those on Taiwan.

Citing a survey conducted by the Institute of International Relations (IIR) under National Chengchi University, Chiu said 82.3 percent of Taiwanese oppose the legislation which analysts say could justify an attack by mainland China against Taiwan, and 74.1 percent said they don't believe Beijing's claims that the law won't compromise the rights of Taiwan people.
With this law in place, Chiu claimed that mainland China would be capable of punishing Taiwanese considered by it as separatists, and this is especially offensive to 80 percent of those surveyed.

As a result, the survey found that 61 percent of the people said the law would hinder exchanges between the two sides, while 55 percent said it would cast a shadow over future dialogue between Taiwan and the mainland.

The MAC vice chairman said the government is bracing itself for any negative impacts because of the legislation but is worried that some people who are not satisfied with the government's moderate response to mainland China may resort to more violent action.
By having recourse to an "anti-secession law," Chiu said mainland China has left Taiwanese with the impression that it is "insensitive," "moody" and is pursuing "hegemony."

Chiu said the law will also betray mainland China's new definition of "one China, " which will say that there is only one China, with mainland and Taiwan being a part of it; thereby deepen Taiwanese fear of mainland China.
The IIR's survey was based on 1,088 valid samples collected by phone Feb. 25-27 among the island's adults. The margin of error was not given.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY LISTS FIVE PRIORITY BILLS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has earmarked five priority bills for this legislative session, Ker Chien-ming, the chief of the DPP's Policy Coordination Committee, said Wednesday.

The five bills include a revision to the National Health Insurance Statute, a special statute for arms purchases, a revision to the Organic Law for the Executive Yuan, a revision to the law governing the exercise of power of the National Assembly, and a special statute for the 2008 Taiwan Expo.
Ker said the list was made after a meeting of his committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, March 3, or the 23rd day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1802: Germany's Ludwig van Beethoven, considered the greatest composer of his day, publishes his "Moonlight Sonata."
1845: Florida becomes the 27th state of the United States.
1847: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish inventor who immigrated to the United States and invented the telephone, is born.
1848: Spurred by hunger, economic depression and the political demands of a growing middle class, revolution sweeps across Europe.
1857: Britain and France declare war on China, using the killing of a missionary as a pretext, setting off the so-called "Second Opium War."
1910: John Davison Rockefeller, the U.S. oil magnate who amassed great wealth through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$12 million to set up the Rockefeller Foundation to carry out philanthropic work.
1919: International airmail service is implemented for the first time in such cities as Washington, D.C., Seattle and London.
1919: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, announces plans to set Europe ablaze with communist revolution.
1923: Americans with no time to read a daily newspaper can now buy Time Magazine, which puts the week's news between two covers.
1931: The United States adopts "The Star-Spangled Banner" as its national anthem.
1932: Republic of China troops are driven back from Shanghai by invading Japanese forces.
1942: The west coast of the United States is declared a military zone and 100,000 people are evacuated.
1944: U.S. fighter planes make their first appearance in the skies over Berlin.
1950: The Republic of China pulls out of GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade) in order to make Communist China lose its rights to reciprocal tariff reductions.
1950: The U.S. Congress votes to admit Alaska as the 49th state.
1955: Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles exchange instruments of ratification of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in Taipei.
1962: Defecting mainland Chinese pilot Liu Cheng-shih arrives in Taiwan aboard his MiG-15 jet fighter.
1974: Dr. Edward Binyah Kesselly, Liberian minister of information, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1983: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Ivory Coast, now called the Republic of Cote D'Ivoire.
1985: An earthquake in Chile kills more than 150 people.
1988: The ROC Council for Economic Planning and Development approves the establishment of the US$11 billion International Economic Cooperation and Development Fund to assist developing countries.
1988: The times and locations for opening ocean fishing to the public in Taiwan are announced. Except for 21 military and national defense areas which are off-limits, fishing will be permitted in all other areas within a scope of 12 nautical miles.
1991: Queen Elizabeth II sustains an injury to her finger, which requires three stitches, while trying to break up a dogfight between corgis on the grounds of Windsor Castle.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs an executive order that moves toward retaliatory tariffs on Japanese imports.
2000: Yuan T. Lee, Nobel laureate and president of Academia Sinica, says that he will not side with Chen Shui-bien, the presidential candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
2001: Indonesia formally lifts its 23-year ban on importing and publishing Chinese-language books and magazines, a move highly welcomed by the Chinese community in the Southeast Asian country.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men of intelligence are free from doubts, moral men from anxiety, and men of courage from fear."
