DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO CONTINUE TO WORK TO MAINTAIN PEACE, STABILITY IN TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 2 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A ranking U.S. State Department official said Wednesday that the United States will continue to do its utmost to secure peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Evans J. R. Revere, acting assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, made the remarks while speaking at a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing to explain the department's budget and strategic goals for the East Asia and Pacific region for fiscal year 2006.

Noting that regional stability is important for general growth in the Asian Pacific region as well as in the interests of the United States, Revere said the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs has placed maintenance of regional stability at the top of its list of strategic goals for fiscal year 2006.

Pointing out that U.S. goals become more difficult to achieve in an unstable region, Revere said that success in countering terrorism, enhancing economic prosperity, eliminating weapons of mass destruction, promoting democracy and addressing transnational issues will strengthen regional stability.

Talking about the Northeast Asia region, he said that the United States will continue to focus on the Korean Peninsula and China. "We will also continue to do all we can to keep peace and ensure stability in the Taiwan Strait," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Supreme Court Bans Execution of Juveniles. The Supreme Court abolished the death penalty for juveniles,ruling that it was excessive and cruel to execute a person who was under 18 when the crime was committed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 280 deportees from Malaysia arrive
Two-hundred eighty Filipinos deported from Malaysia in the wake of the country's crackdown on undocumented workers and migrants arrived in Zamboanga City yesterday even as the Philippine labor department warned Filipino workers against attempting to illegally enter and work in Malaysia.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Pork barrel behind budget OK
THE SENATE adopted on Tuesday night the 2005 budget that the House of Representatives had approved to foil the plan of members of the House to restore their pork barrel from P40 million to P70 million during a bicameral conference committee, several senators said yesterday.
The Philippine Star: Congressmen grumble over 'pork'
Congressmen are complaining about the surprise Senate decision to adopt the House version of the 2005 budget, which prevented them from adding at least P7 billion more to their pork barrel.
The Manila Times: Jamby crucifies Defensor again
Sen. Jamby Madrigal had another chance to put the heat on Environment Secretary Michael Defensor at the Senate Wed-nes-day, and gave hints that she was just warming up.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : PM: Vital to balance Budget this year.
In a robust defence of his first Budget as Prime Minister, Mr Lee Hsien Loong yesterday rejected a chorus of calls for a more business- friendly spending programme.
Take a look at the big picture, he told Parliament.
Look at what the Government has done for businesses over the past five years: A raft of tax changes have saved business at least $1.8 billion a year.
And consider the Government's fiscal position, he said during the Budget debate.
It must balance its books in this year of steady growth.
If it does not, it has little hope of balancing its accounts over any business cycle.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM: No need to hold a referendum on the casino issue.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who disclosed yesterday, two days after the deadline for submissions, said Government will not hold a referendum for Singaporeans to vote on the casino issue. Neither will it lift the Party Whip for Members of Parliament (MPs) to vote freely,he said, turning down recent suggestions from menbers of the House.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO PASS RESOLUTION AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will pass a resolution against Beijing's anti-secession legislation, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
Wang made the announcement after a cross-party consultative meeting to discuss certain critical legislative bills.

During the meeting, Wang said, legislative whips of ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus on adopting a resolution to voice opposition to Beijing's so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DISAPPOINTED BY PRESENT PRESIDENT'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui is disappointed by President Chen Shui-bian's recent remarks that even Lee himself couldn't change the name of the country if he were president today, Lee's daughter said Thursday.

Lee An-ni, vice president of the Taiwan Research Institute think tank, was referring to President Chen's remarks during a videoconference with members of the European Parliament, as well as academics and journalists in Brussels Tuesday night.

Chen said that he couldn't change the official name of the country from "the Republic of China" to "the Republic of Taiwan" within the remaining three years of his term and that to say he could would be fooling himself and others.

The daughter of the former president said that to embrace the idea of a "Republic of China" that doesn't exist internationally and the goal of unification with China is in itself fooling oneself and others.
Lee defended her father's campaign of rectifying the nation's name, saying that everything cannot be achieved in a single leap and that one has to set the goal and work toward it courageously.
Lee, a researcher on gender equality, made the remarks on the sidelines of a press conference sponsored by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to unveil five top priority bills for women.

The five bills include an amendment to the domestic violence prevention law, a childbirth health bill, and a gender equality basic law bill. The remaining two bills call for the establishment of a gender equality committee and a national pension system.
TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang urged all legislators across the party spectrum to lend support to the five bills to promote the rights of women.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESIGNED KMT VICE CHAIRMAN DENIES PLAN TO ACCEPT SEF POST

TEXT.P: Vincent Siew, who resigned as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) a day earlier, denied Thursday that his resignation has anything to do with a reported offer for him to head the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

A local daily reported that Siew, who is now chairman of the government-funded Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research and founder of an organization promoting a common market across the Taiwan Strait, could accept the Democratic Progressive Party government's offer to serve as chairman of SEF after leaving the KMT position.
However, Siew said the report is totally untrue and urged the media to stop engaging in such speculation.
Siew said that President Chen Shui-bian never offered him any public offices and that he is not interested in accepting any such offers.

Siew announced his decision to resign as KMT vice chairman in a written statement on Wednesday, saying the move was taken in response to KMT Chairman Lien Chan's call for changeover of the party leadership and a request by party members to downsize the KMT's organization.
Siew said that he had tendered resignation several times before this but was rejected on each occasion and that he thinks the timing is good for him to leave now.
Siew said although he no longer has any official post in the party, he is still a member of the KMT and will continue to support the development and reforms of the party.
Asked about the matter, Lien confirmed that Siew had made up his mind to resign long ago and he thanked Siew for his contribution to the party over the past five years.

According to KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng, Lien hopes that Siew can finish his term, which is set to expire this August. He added that Lien will try to contact Siew to discuss this possibility with him.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also a KMT vice chairman, expressed the hope that Siew could stay to assist Lien in leading the party. Wang added that he thinks Siew is a perfect candidate for the post of SEF chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: CIA Detention Practices Remain Largely Secret.
Afghan prisoner's death took two years to become public, illustrating agency's lack of scrutiny on detainee treatment and allegations of abuse.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS, POLICE TO WORK TOGETHER CLOSELY TO COMBAT CRIME: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mau-lin said Thursday that prosecutors and police will work together closely to combat criminal activities.

Shih made the remarks as the nation is launching an islandwide campaign to improve social order. He said that his ministry will lend support to the campaign as well as promote the "165" anti-fraud hot line to raise public awareness to guard against rampant fraud.
He also touched on the issue of rampant burglary, saying the ministry has communicated its hope to the Judicial Yuan that offenders will be given the maximum punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA-BASED TAIWANESE BUSINESSPEOPLE OPPOSED TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese Chamber of Commerces in the Canadian cities of Ottawa and Montreal recently released a statement voicing their firm opposition to China's proposed anti-secession law.

In the statement, the organization said that neither side of the Taiwan Strait is subordinate to the other and that the two sides must resolve the cross-strait differences in a rational and peaceful manner through consultations.

The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress adopted last December a draft of the proposed law, and the congress is set to review the draft at its annual plenary session slated to open March 8.

Pointing out that Beijing's unilateral enactment of an anti-secession law, which is an attempt to dominate the development of cross-strait relations in the future, is not consistent with the current status quo in the Taiwan Strait, the statement said.

Noting that cross-strait relations might be improved in the future as both sides of the strait reached an agreement on Lunar New Year holiday direct charter flights and are planning to push for the signing of a further agreement establishing a definite cross-strait charter flights system as well as the holding of discussions on other "three links" issues, the statement said that recent remarks made by President Chen Shui-bian to urge the two sides to discuss the signing of a peaceful agreement to replace the anti-secession law have demonstrated the president's goodwill toward China.

Taiwanese businesspeople at home and abroad hope that Beijing can respond to Chen's goodwill in order to make room for positive interactions and better economic and trade exchanges between the two sides of the strait, the statement continued, adding that if China insists on enacting the law, this will cast a shadow over the development of future cross-strait relations.

The statement called on Beijing not to enact the proposed law so as to avoid escalating cross-strait tensions and creating obstacles in exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China as well as jeopardizing positive cross-strait interactions and opportunities to resolve cross-strait disputes peacefully.

It also expressed the hope that the Canadian government and the international community will work to prevent Beijing from enacting the law so as to avoid destroying the current status quo in the Taiwan Strait and undermining peace, stability and security in the Pacific region and other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN TO PASS RESOLUTION AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan will pass a resolution against Beijing's anti-secession legislation, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.
Wang made the announcement after a cross-party consultative meeting to discuss certain critical legislative bills.

During the meeting, Wang said, the legislative whips of ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus on adopting a resolution to voice opposition to Beijing's so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Wang said the legislative caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang and the Taiwan Solidarity Union have all presented their own versions for the resolution.

"As the party whips have yet to come to terms on the wording of the common resolution, they will meet again Friday to further discuss the contents. Once a mutually acceptable version is worked out, it will be put forth for passage at a legislative plenary session," Wang said.
According to Wang, the basic tone of the resolution will lie in urging Beijing to respect Taiwan's identity and work together with the island to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
The DPP caucus was the first to come up with a draft resolution opposing Beijing's proposed anti-secession legislation.

Speaking at the consultative meeting, DPP legislative whip Chen Ching-chun urged the opposition parties to support the DPP-initiated draft resolution, titled "Defending the Republic of China's Sovereignty."

Pointing out that the Republic of China is an independent sovereign state, the DPP draft resolution said the ROC does not belong to the People's Republic of China and is ruled by a government distinct from that of the PRC.

"And this status quo cannot be changed without the consent of the people of Taiwan by a democratic referendum and should be respected and safeguarded by all countries around the world including the the PRC," the resolution said.

It further said any country which intends to challenge this status quo, regardless of whether through legislation or policy statements, and especially if by force, will be scathingly condemned and fiercely opposed by the people of Taiwan.

Chen said the proposed resolution is in line with the spirit of the DPP's previous Resolution on Taiwan's Future as well as President Chen Shui-bian's 2000 and 2004 inaugural speeches and the 10-point consensus reached at the recent high-profile meeting between Chen and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATRIATES IN FRANCE TAKE ACTION AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, March 2 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates in France have urged the international community to voice its concerns and opposition to mainland China's proposed anti-secession law.
Twenty-three local Taiwanese organizations in the country have made the call in a statement that will appear in the March 3 edition of the "Europe Journal," a Paris-based Chinese-language newspaper.

The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress adopted a draft of the law last December, and the congress is widely expected to pass the bill into law at its annual plenary session which is set to open March 8.

Meanwhile, several Taiwanese organizations in France have also launched a campaign to urge their members to write letters to local media and members of the French National Assembly to express the Taiwan people's opposition to the proposed law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained four points to close at 6,204, with 32,997 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved up six points to finish at 6,211, with 548 contracts traded, while June futures gained 11 points to finish at 6,219, with 33 contracts traded.
September futures gained 15 points to finish at 6,140, with 25 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 11 points to close at 6,147, with one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,200 for March, 6,205 for April, 6,208 for June, 6,125 for September and 6,136 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

March TE futures moved down 0.2 points to close at 234.6, with 4,316 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 0.1 points to finish at 234.7, with 37 contract transactions. September TE futures gained 2.25 points to close at 235, with one contract traded, while December TE futures moved up 0.95 points to finish at 233.1, with six contract transactions.

March TF futures lost 2.8 points to finish at 1,020.4, with 3,985 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 3.2 points to end at 1,020.8, with 70 contracts traded. June TF futures lost 5.2 points to finish at 1,015.4, with one contract changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 10.6 points to close at 1,012.4, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 22.87 points to close at 6,202.38.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,219.71 and hit a low of 6,164.15 during trading. A total of 3.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.43 billion (US$2.54 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up at 0.5 percent and textile stocks gaining 0.1 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent and cement stocks and construction issues both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 474 to 414, with 111 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTRY TO TAKE ANOTHER STAB AT PUBLICITY FOR U.S. ARMS DEAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense is to increase its publicity and lobbying for a special budget for a major military procurement plan, defense ministry officials said Thursday.

The new wave of publicity will skirt sensitive political issues and focus on national security and peace in the hope of winning greater public backing, they said, admitting that last year's promotion urging people to "save a cup of tea every day in exchange for weapons" did little to further the defense ministry's cause.

This time around, Defense Minister Lee Jye, Chief of the General Staff Gen. Lee Tien-yu and Chief of the Political Warfare Bureau Gen. Hu Cheng-pu have decided to adopt a three-pronged strategy targeting the public, the legislative caucuses and several individual legislators to increase understanding of the issue, the officials said.

The ministry will lobby hard at the Legislative Yuan in an effort to win the support of a number of hardliners, they said. The defense ministry intends to first push for the passage of the special statute governing the major arms procurement project during the current legislative session and then have the arms package budget bill screened.

As a result of boycotts from the opposition "pan blue alliance, " bills pertaining to the NT$610.8 billion (about US$18 billion) arms procurement plan failed to be put on the agenda of the steering committee 14 times before the previous legislature ended in January.
The huge budget spurred heated debate at the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan and provoked disapproval from the public due to the government's strained financial situation.

With the opening of the sixth Legislative Yuan in February, Lee said recently at a Spring Festival gathering with reporters that his ministry is prepared to slash the budget for the deal to NT$590 billion to compromise with the "pan blue alliance" composed of the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party.
The price could be further lowered to NT$480 billion should a final decision be made not to build the eight diesel-powered submarines in Taiwan, Lee pointed out.
The "pan blue alliance" had asked the defense ministry to cut the budget by at least NT$300 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: STREAMLINE MEDICAL OPERATIONS TO AVOID WASTE: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Better grading of medical facilities and patient referrals must be implemented to streamline operations and avoid wasting resources, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Thursday.

The former president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research made the comments during a seminar on the review and prospects of the national health insurance system, which is 10 years old this year.
Wu said that it is important to have those who suffer moderate or minor illnesses to seek medical treatment at local clinics or health care units, instead of big hospitals.
Only by grading medical institutions and implementing patient referrals can precious hospital resources be efficiently used for patients with serious diseases, Wu explained.

Saying that "there's no free lunch, " Wu said that the national health insurance is not a civic welfare program supported by the national treasury, but is a kind of insurance, as its name implies. All of those insured must pay for using the system's resources, the vice premier stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO TAKE 'EXTRAORDINARY STEPS' FOR CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: An American expert on cross-Taiwan Strait issues urged leaders on both sides Wednesday to take into consideration the well-being of their people and their relations with the United States before making any decisions that may upset regional stability.

Alan D. Romberg, senior associate and director of the East Asia Program at the Henry L. Stimson Center, made the call in an article entitled "Promoting Cross-Strait Stability, Avoiding Catastrophe, " ahead of the passage of an "anti-secession law" by mainland China.

While both mainland China and Taiwan expect the United States to take their sides, both will be disappointed because Washington will only side with cross-strait stability, which is in the interests of the United States, Romberg said.
According to Romberg, Washington will stand up to oppose any moves by either side that are likely to destabilize the situation across the Strait and will take "extraordinary steps" if necessary.

For example, during a meeting with Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao in December 2003, U.S. President George W. Bush publicly rebuked President Chen Shui-bian for going ahead with his plan to hold a referendum alongside the 2004 presidential election; and during the cross-strait missile crisis in 1996, then-President Bill Clinton dispatched two aircraft-carrier battle groups to areas near the Taiwan Strait, Romberg noted.

He pointed out that mainland China has been pondering enacting a "unification law" or an "anti-secession law" since the 1990s, but Beijing only started to put the wheels in motion last year after President Chen pledged during his re-election campaign to hold a referendum in 2006 for a new constitution.
By enacting the "anti-secession law," Beijing is trying to compel present and future Chinese leaders to take military action if Taiwan moves towards permanent separation from mainland China, he said.
Very often, Taiwan and China act from their respective standpoints, prompting the other side to counteract, which feeds a vicious circle across the Strait, he said.

He urged Beijing to take some constructive action, such as considering allowing Taiwan to take part in the World Health Organization as an observer, in order to facilitate positive cross-strait developments.

If the "anti-secession law" is to dictate the use of "non-peaceful means," insist on the "one country, two systems" format for unification and even make supporting Taiwan independence a crime, it is foreseeable as to how Taiwan will react, he said.
He predicted that the United States will take an "extraordinary step" like it did in the past if the content of this legislation is worrying to Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN FREIGHTER RUNS AGROUND, CREW SAFE

TEXT.P: All 20 crew members aboard a grounded Indonesian cargo ship are believed to be safe after some of them were airlifted by helicopter to Penghu Island off Taiwan's southwest coast Thursday, while the rest await rescue, coast guard sources reported.

The Indonesian bulk carrier "Shinko Ocean" sent out an SOS around 2 p.m. from waters some 14 nautical miles from Makung, Penghu after the vessel ran aground because of engine failure and stormy weather.

A Seagull rescue helicopter took off from an air base in Chiayi, southern Taiwan and successfully airlifted part of the crew to Makung Airport, where they were transferred to two hospitals in Penghu for treatment.
The Seagull shuttled back and forth from Penghu to transfer the crew ashore.

The Indonesian freighter was on its way from Malaysia to Taichung, central Taiwan, when its engines failed. Stormy weather then caused the captain of the ship to lose control and the vessel eventually hit a rock formation in shallow water off Penghu Island.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO ALLOW CITIZENS TO GO TO TAIWAN'S OUTLYING ISLANDS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland China will allow more mainland citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan's three outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu, a Hong Kong newspaper reported Thursday.

The Beijing-backed Ta Kung Pao daily quoted Dai Xiaofong, a division chief at the mainland State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, as having said that besides Fujian residents, those residing in other mainland provinces will also be allowed to make pleasure trips to the three outlying islands in the future.

According to the Hong Kong paper, Dai made the remarks Wednesday after a travel market inspection tour of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to the southeastern mainland province of Fujian than to Taiwan.

Mainland authorities formally allowed Fujian residents to make pleasure trips to Kinmen last December and will soon allow Fujian residents to travel to Matsu and Penghu for sightseeing. Moreover, Dai said the Taiwan Affairs Office is also planning to allow residents in other mainland provinces to make pleasure trips to the three outlying islands in a gradual manner.

At present, Taiwan has only opened Kinmen and Matsu for direct shipping links with Fujian, while Penghu, which lies close to Taiwan proper, remains an off-limits area for direct contact with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF WELCOMES U.S.-JAPAN CONCERN OVER TAIWAN SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 3 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung welcomed a recent joint U.S.-Japan statement that cited Taiwan as a "joint strategic objective" and said that the two countries have sent a clear anti-war message to Beijing in doing so, a Japanese newspaper reported Thursday.

Lin said in the report published by the Maichi Shimbun that the two countries' inclusion of peace in the Taiwan Strait as a concern in their joint statement represents a clear point in the Japan- U.S. security alliance and that he very much welcomes the move which will help lay a cornerstone of peace in the Asia-Pacific region.
In addition, he pointed out, the two countries transmitted a clear message to the Beijing leadership about their grave concerns over peace across the Strait, the report said.

Commenting on Beijing's plan to enact a proposed "anti-secession law" in the middle of this month, Lin claimed that it will only pour cold water on efforts to ease tensions between Taiwan and mainland China, the report said.

According to Lin, the purpose of the Beijing's law is to empower itself to define and alter the cross-strait status quo and to use it to split the Taiwan people and increase its grip on Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.
The law can also be used as an excuse by Beijing to attack Taiwan and apply it to deal with the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, mainland China and Japan, he said.
The GIO head ascribed Beijing's scheme to the re-election of President Chen Shui-bian in March 2004 out of its distrust of the president's Taiwan-centric stance.

Describing the Taiwan-mainland charter flight service during the lunar new year holidays as a part of President Chen's sunshine policy to improve cross-strait ties, he said that Beijing's "anti-secession law" will not only dampen Chen's peace-making efforts but will also annoy the people of Taiwan.

The Taiwan government might be pushed by its angry people to counter the "anti-secession law " by holding a defensive referendum in protest against Beijing, he said, adding that it is now facing a huge test at this juncture.
Beijing's National People's Congress is expected to pass the "anti-secession law" in the middle of this month during its 10th plenary session, which will open on March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, losing NT$0.015 to close at NT$30.863.
A total of US$1.07 billion changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.930 and slid to a low of NT$30.820 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS GROUPS POSITIVE ABOUT CHEN-SOONG MEETING

TEXT.P: Business and industrial groups are very positive about a recent meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong and its historical significance in ending inter-party rivalry.

The Chinese National Federation of Industries, the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and other groups issued a statement Thursday to hail the move for inter-party reconciliation.

The groups said in the statement that there will be room for economic development only if the political situation is stable, adding that with the confrontation between the ruling and opposition parties after the 2000 presidential election, which saw the first power transition between different parties in Taiwan for over five decades, the continued bickering between the ruling and opposition parties has seriously undermined economic growth and social harmony in Taiwan.

The statement said that the people on the island favor all kinds of voices but are opposed to rivalries and divisions; they hope for inter-party reconciliation and an easing of cross-strait tensions so that Taiwan can better develop.

It also said that the gist of democracy is to obey the views of the majority. As past polls have shown that the majority of people on Taiwan are in favor of maintaining the status quo, it said those who are in favor of immediate independence are few.
Although the voice of the few should be given due respect, as head of state, President Chen should listen to the voice of all the people and not be dictated by a few of them, the statement said.

Reconciliation instead of confrontation is the mainstream view of the public, it also said, adding that business groups are happy to see a truce between various political groups, and that the public was happy to see the Chen-Soong meeting too, a mood reflected by the rise in the stock and real estate markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' TO AFFECT CHINESE LIBERALS, DISSIDENTS: WANG DAN

TEXT.P: Prominent Chinese democracy activist Wang Dan predicted Thursday that lives of Chinese dissidents and liberal intellectuals will become even more difficult after Beijing enacts its "anti-secession law."

Wang, a Harvard University doctoral candidate who is currently on a research project in Taiwan, said during a talk with Taipei media Thursday that he has no idea why the Beijing leadership is enacting the controversial "anti-secession law, " but he speculated that one reason was an attempt to rein in the growing nationalism around mainland China.

On whether and how the "anti-secession law" -- expected to be passed by Beijing's National People's Congress March 14 -- will impact cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Wang said that this will only be known after the articles of the law are publicized and examined.

Wang, whose six-month research project at Academia Sinica's Institute of Modern History is scheduled to conclude Saturday, said that he is confident in Taiwan's democratization despite the fact that political party conflicts have been rife.
Taiwan's democratization, although raucous, has always been a window of inspiration for mainland China, Wang noted.

On the development of cross-strait relations, Wang said that improving cross-strait relations is not an issue simply for the government to address, pointing out that it is a problem for the people from both sides to tackle.
He called for the building of a platform on which intellectuals from the two sides can talk to try to break the cross-strait political deadlock.

Wang's news conference was arranged by the Taipei Society, which was founded by a group of liberal scholars who oppose nuclear plants and social injustice. Wang is the only member of the group from overseas.

In response to Wang's call, Ku Chung-hua, an executive director of the Taipei Society, said that the group will begin this year to push for the establishment of a private cross-strait dialogue platform to allow intellectuals from both sides first to understand each other and then contribute in efforts to address the cross-strait political stalemate.

On opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's forthcoming visit to Guangdong to lay a wreath on the tomb of the Republic of China founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen, Wang suggested that when the KMT is engaging the Chinese authorities, the KMT people encourage the Chinese communists to accelerate China's democratization, including pushing for the freedom of speech.
Wang, founder of the Chinese Constitutional Reform Association in the United States, has visited Taiwan many times since he first set foot on the island on March 18, 1999.
He was in Taipei in January 2003 to launch his two new books written in Chinese -- one a collection of poems and the other a work of prose -- both published by Taipei's Locus Publishing Co.
He was in Taipei again in July 2003 for six weeks at the invitation of the Taipei City Government as an artist-in-residence.
Wang was jailed in July 1989 for his part in the pro-democracy demonstrations and was released in February 1993. He was arrested again in October 1996 and sentenced to a further 11-year prison term.
In April of 1998, he was released on parole on medical grounds and permitted to travel to the United States for treatment -- a move that effectively sent him into exile.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO CREATE TASK FORCE ON CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: A special task force will be assembled by legislators from across the party spectrum to address cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday.

Wang said that legislators from the various parties have agreed to create the task force with the principle of representation according to the ratio of political parties' presence in the legislature. The members will be decided by March 20. The task force will be made up of the legislative speaker, vice speaker and 23 legislators.

However, Lai Chin-teh, caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, cautioned in the legislature that matters relating to cross-strait ties are the responsibility of the president according to the Constitution.
Lai urged respect for the Constitution, adding that if the cross-strait task force affects the purview of the president, then it will undermine the Constitution.
He also asked that the task force not be formed until after mainland China' s National People's Congress debates its proposed "anti-secession law" so as to avoid possible trouble.

But Wang said that this will not be a problem, adding that mainland China's National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament, is expected to deliberate on the proposed law, which some observers say could be an attempt by Beijing to lay a legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan should it declare independence, and approve of it even before Taiwan's cross-strait task force is created.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO BEGIN FLIGHTS TO VIENNA IN MAY

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, will inaugurate flight services to Vienna in May, a company spokesman said Thursday.
Initially, the spokesman said, CAL will operate two Taipei-Vienna flights per week. In the future, he added, the company plans to add an additional flight per week.

According to a Taiwan-Austria aviation agreement signed in 1990, Taiwan can operate seven weekly flights, regardless of whether they are passenger or cargo flights, between Taipei and Vienna. Over the past 15 years, only EVA Airways, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, has been allowed to fly the route. At present, EVA operates three passenger and two cargo flights.

In September 2004, the Taiwan-Austria aviation accord was revised to allow a second Taiwan airline to ply the route. The revised pact does not impose any restrictions on the number of cargo flights, while raising the number of passenger flights to seven per week.
Deducting the three passenger flights that EVA now operates, the Civil Aeronautics Administration assigns the remaining four evenly to CAL and EVA.
EVA said it plans to increase its Taipei-Vienna passenger flights from the current three to five by mid-May.
Despite high gasoline prices and rising interest rates, CAL posted a record high pre-tax profit of NT$4.02 billion last year on a business turnover of NT$96.1 billion.
CAL President Wei Hsing-hsiung said the airline's business turnover is expected to break the NT$100 billion mark for the first time this year, with pre-tax profit expected to hit NT$4.4 billion.
EVA also set new records in its business turnover and profit last year, with its pre-tax profit amounting to NT$3.6 billion on a turnover of NT$82.6 billion.

Both CAL and EVA executives said they are optimistic about the civil aviation market this year because regular charter flights across the Taiwan Strait are likely to open in the not-too-distant future.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER TO STAY AFTER TALK WITH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Senior presidential adviser Wu Li-pei said Thursday that after talking with the president, he has decided not to step down from his post.
Wu, a long-time advocate of Taiwan democracy and independence, made the remarks after nearly two hours of discussions with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.

Wu offered to resign over a recent meeting between Chen and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in which the president reaffirmed his "five noes, " which are: no declaration of independence, no change of the nation's official name, no inclusion of the "state-to-state" theory on cross-strait relations in the nation's Constitution, no national referendum on changing the status of the island regarding unification or independence, and no abolition of the National Unification Guidelines or National Unification Council.

Wu noted that Soong said "Taiwan independence is not an option" after his meeting with Chen to the dismay of many pro-Taiwan independence supporters, but the president did not respond or clarify these remarks, disappointing and upsetting a multitude of supporters of the president overseas. This was the reason why he offered to resign, he added.
But Wu said that the president explained to him during the meeting that he had not changed his long-term goals nor had he reneged on the ideals of the Taiwanese.

But as the momentum for inter-party reconciliation has just begun to build up, it is not appropriate for him to rebut the other party if the latter has expressed a different stance, according to the president's remarks to Wu.
The president regretted that his reticence has caused misunderstandings, referring to the recent backlash from pro-independence supporters, Wu said.

The president stressed to him that to avoid the administration being mired in constant bickering between the ruling and the opposition parties, and to allow the government to move forward, he needed to promote inter-party reconciliation and cooperation, Wu added.

Wu said that he suggested to the president that he should come forward to mend fences given the number of misunderstandings. Wu said that he felt that the president will do this eventually at the right time.
But he also said that his staying on does not mean that he agrees thoroughly with the 10-point agreement reached between Chen and Soong.

Wu said that he agreed with Chen that it is impossible to change the country's name from the "Republic of China" to the "Republic of Taiwan" during his term, adding that such a change could only be achieved by two methods -- revolution or legal procedure, and only legal procedure applies to Taiwan.
Therefore, if the president is unable to achieve that during his term, he should talk about something that everyone can strive for, Wu added.

Wu also said that though he is staying on, he won't be of much use, and the president said that he is considering formulating a mechanism to have presidential advisers provide views regularly and take part in discussions prior to the formulation of national policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU ACCUSED OF CUTTING DPP'S THROAT FOR TRYING TO WOO MEMBERS AWAY

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials Thursday accused their ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , of cutting one another's throats after the TSU openly encouraged DPP members to join the party.

Angered by recent statements by President Chen Shui-bian that he has no plan to declare independence for Taiwan and change the official name of the country during his term, officials of the pro-independence TSU made a public call on Wednesday for DPP members to join the TSU.
In reaction, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin criticized the TSU's move as violating the principle of fair competition between different political parties.
Yen said the TSU should not have tried to expand it size by making the other party "lose blood" and that he believes the majority of DPP members will not support such an idea, either.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said it is undemocratic of the TSU to mislead the public with mistaken information and attack the president with emotional language.
Cheng urged the TSU to stop the campaign immediately for the sake of its brotherhood with the DPP and work on their common objective of attaining political stability in Taiwan.
Disagreeing with Yen and Cheng, TSU Chairman Shu Chin-chiang said his party has no reason to reject anyone who identifies with the party's ideals.
Shu denied the TSU has taken the initiative to woo DPP members away.

Just as the TSU has shown respect for the DPP and President Chen, the party expects the DPP to pay due respect to former President Lee Teng-hui, who is the TSU's spiritual leader, and other pro-independence groups, Shu said.

President Chen said during a teleconference with a group of European parliamentarians on Tuesday that it is unnecessary for Taiwan to declare independence and that it would also be impossible to change the name of the country from the Republic of China to the "Republic of Taiwan" during his term.

The TSU promotes calling the country "Taiwan" and drafting a new constitution, things that Chen said Lee would not have been able to achieve if he were still president today, a comment that irked the TSU.
The TSU is also unhappy with Chen's meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong last week, in which Chen made similar assurances.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO WAIVE VISA REQUIREMENT FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS FROM MARCH 11
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 3 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan will waive its visa requirements for Taiwan tourists from March 11 through Sept. 25 as part of its efforts to attract visitors to the 2005 World Exposition in Aichi Prefecture in central Japan, government sources said Thursday.

The Japanese Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transportation (MLIT) has finalized the visa-waiving plan and will present it for final approval at a Japanese Cabinet meeting Friday, the sources said.

The eco-friendly Aichi Expo is scheduled to open March 25 and last through Sept. 25. To attract more foreign visitors, Japan has decided to offer visa-free entry to South Korean and Taiwan tourists between March and September. South Korea is Japan's largest source of foreign tourists and Taiwan comes in second.

As Japan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the Japanese Diet passed special regulations Feb. 16 to allow Taiwan citizens to enter Japan without a visa for a maximum 90-day stay between March 11 and Sept. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTERS CHALLENGED BY SURGING LOCAL CURRENCY

TEXT.P: In the face of a surging new Taiwan dollar in recent days, domestic export-oriented businesses are urging the government to effectively curb the inflow of hot money to help maintain their competitive edge.

Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, said that the recent stronger-than-expected appreciation of the local currency has taken many Taiwan companies by surprise and he called on the government to take countermeasures to stem serious consequences over the long term.

According to Hsu, many domestic businesses had expected the local unit to rise to around 31.5 against the U.S. dollar by this time, but its rapid gains over the past week have dealt a blow to them, he said, pointing out that gradual strengthening is more acceptable to them.
The new Taiwan dollar ended at 30.863 against the U.S. unit Thursday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, breaking the 31.0 mark and moving up slightly by NT$0.015 from the previous day's finish.

Yeh I-chang, secretary-general of the Taiwan Silk and Filament Weaving Industrial Association, said a continuously appreciating local currency has become a major problem for may export-oriented textile makers. The situation is forcing them to buy production materials in new Taiwan dollars but sell their goods abroad in U.S. currency, he said.
The rapid surge in value of the local currency has slashed their profits, Yeh said, noting that what they earn is hardly enough to pay what they lose in currency exchanges.

He attributed the development to the inflow of international hot money speculating on a stronger new Taiwan dollar over a weaker U.S. dollar and he called on the government to clamp down on such speculation to prevent fallout on domestic companies.

Kevin Grice, a senior economist at American Express Bank, forecast a day earlier that the new Taiwan dollar is expected to rise to 30.0 to the greenback by the end of this year, marking a departure from other analysts who predicted that the local unit will further rise to a range of between 26.0 and 28.0 by that time.

Grice contended that mainland China's renminbi will be allowed to float in a narrow range of 5 percent this year and that the new Taiwan dollar will continue to strengthen as long as the renminbi is under pressure to go up in value on a weak U.S. dollar.

However, he said that Taiwan's central bank will intervene gradually to ward off a sharp appreciation of the local unit and maintain a stable economic growth rate and that the new Taiwan dollar will not pick up to the 26.0 - 28.0 level this year.

He forecast that the Taiwan economy will expand by 5 percent for 2005, higher than the 4.21 percent target set by the Cabinet-level Directorate of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, given that Taiwan's unemployment has improved and that the average interest rate of Taiwan banks remains low.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Computer tax set to replace TV licence fee.
The BBC licence fee should be replaced by a tax on the ownership of a personal computer instead of a television, ministers said yesterday.
Tessa Jowell told the BBC that the licence fee would be retained for at least another ten years until 2017 in return for abolishing the Board of Governors. But the Culture Secretary conceded that technological advances would mean that a fee based on "television ownership could become redundant".
Financial Times: BBC told board of governors to be axed.
The BBC paid the price for the governance failures highlighted in the Hutton report when Tessa Jowell, culture secretary, on Wednesday branded its 78-year-old system of self-regulation "unsustainable" and scrapped its board of governors in favour of an independent trust.
But it escaped a far more dramatic overhaul when the green paper, which paves the way for the renewal of the corporation's royal charter in 2007, concluded that the BBC should be allowed to retain the licence fee until 2016 in return for exhibiting a greater commitment to public service broadcasting and driving the switchover to digital TV services.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S MENTOR CALLS FOR STOP TO IN-FIGHTING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's mentor Lee Hong-hsi called Thursday for a stop to in-fighting among the pro-independence camp and some members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over Chen's recent "no national name-change" statement.

Lee, who was Chen's lecturer at National Taiwan University and is currently superintendent of Chen's Ketagalan Institute, urged members of the "pan-green camp" formed by the DPP, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and some pro-Taiwan independence activists residing overseas, to be rational and considerate toward Chen's statement that it will be impossible during his term to change the official name of the country.

Lee said that the gist of democracy is to obey the views of the majority. Since the DPP fared badly in the Dec. 11 legislative elections and the majority of people of Taiwan, according to recent opinion polls, are in favor of maintaining the status quo while those who are in favor of immediate independence are few, the president had no option but to listen to the people and call a halt to his plans for a name-change and constitutional re-engineering, Lee said.

He made the remarks after several pro-independence senior presidential advisers threatened to resign as an expression of their anger with Chen's statement and his recent meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in which they agreed to continue to promote inter-party and cross-Taiwan Strait reconciliation.

Although Chen was determined to push for constitutional re-engineering and a name-change, Lee said that as head of state, Chen must listen to the voice of the people and follow the mainstream view of society.

Describing Taiwan's diplomatic situation in the international community as a small boat in a stormy sea, Lee appealed to all members of the "pan-green camp" to throw their support behind the president, who has been carefully piloting the ship of state.

It would be worthy if the president's efforts can win consensus and support from the majority of the people, who can in turn help tide him over the difficulties in steering the country in the coming three years, according to Lee.
He claimed that it is cherishable and "exceptional in Taiwan" to find a politician like Chen who loves his people, has a clear mind and always demonstrates grass-roots modesty.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE MIGHT PASS ANTI-ANNEXATION LAW: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan does not rule out the possibility of enacting an anti-annexation law to counter mainland China's so-called anti-secession law, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday.

Speaking at a seminar on the possible impact of the mainland's proposed anti-secession legislation targeting Taiwan, Lai Ching-teh said the legislative caucuses of ruling and opposition parties have reached a consensus on adopting a common resolution urging Beijing to abandon its plan.

"This indicates that lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition camps have felt the pinch of Beijing's new legislative plan and are determined to take action against it, " Lai said, adding that if the content of Beijing's new law is too outrageous, the legislature will not rule out the possibility of passing an anti-annexation law in retaliation.
The National People's Congress -- the mainland's rubber-stamp parliament -- is expected to screen and approve the law in mid-March.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lo Chih-cheng, chief executive of the National Policy Research Institute, and Lin Cheng-yi, director of the International Relations Institute of National Chengchi University, suggested that if Beijing passes a "grave" anti-secession law, Taiwan should hold a referendum simultaneously with the year-end local government chief elections to express its strong opposition to Beijing's policy toward Taiwan.

Lo and Lin said the referendum could ask the people whether they agree with Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula as the only option for Taiwan's future. Such a referendum, they claimed, would not violate President Chen Shui-bian's promise of no referendum on cross-Taiwan Strait unification or Taiwan independence.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng said the government has prepared comprehensive response measures to cope with Beijing's anti-secession legislation.
Describing the anti-secession law is a "war authorization" law, Huang said the legislation would give the People's Liberation Army a "blank check" to attack Taiwan.
"Such a law would hurt the Taiwan people and hinder regional peace, " Huang said, adding that it would be an "evil law" for both Taiwan and the mainland.
With the enactment of such a law, Huang said, the mainland would lose flexibility in dealing with cross-strait affairs.
While the government has worked out response measures to cope with various possible mainland versions of the law, Huang said, the package cannot be divulged at the moment.
"Premature revelation would only give mainland China a pretext for justifying its planned legislation," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME 'SILK ROAD' TO EAST ASIA: ECONOMIC PLANNERS

TEXT.P: The government will develop Taiwan into a research and development center in East Asia and a new "silk road" for multinational companies venturing into the East Asian market, according to a report issued Thursday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the government's economic planners.

Noting that the combined exports of East Asian countries accounted for 25.8 percent of the world's total foreign trade in 2003, the report says foreign trade between countries in the region made up 12.8 percent of the world's total, following Europe's 23.3 percent and surpassing the 8.5 percent recorded for the United States.
Trade among the countries of East Asia has grown so fast in the period between 2000 and 2003, it has outpaced trade between the region and the United States, according to the report.
The trade surplus accumulated by Taiwan, Singapore, and South Korea against mainland China and Hong Kong hit US$40.4 billion in 1996 and US$60.8 billion in 2003, the report says.

Along with the emergence of the mainland and India as major economic powers in Asia, the report says, a division of labor among Asian states is taking shape and the continent is expected to turn into a world economic powerhouse in the near future.

To brace for the new development, the report says the government is making good use of the island's well-developed infrastructure and advanced technology to develop the country into a research and development center in the region and a gateway for multinational companies breaking into the East Asian market.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECRIES BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian decried Thursday Beijing's proposed anti-secession law as a dangerous move to alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen told a group of foreign ministers from Taiwan's allies in Central America that the mainland will use the law to provide a legal basis for a possible attack on Taiwan.

Noting that the mainland is targeting Taiwan with 706 missiles, which poses a serious threat to the stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Chen called on the international community not to turn a blind eye to the mainland's attempts to expand its territory because of the potential economic benefit in tapping the mainland market.
The ministers were in Taiwan for an annual economic conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MISSES TARGET WITH ITS PROPOSED LAW: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: China is missing the target in its attempt to rob Taiwan of its option for pursuing independence with an anti-secession law, former President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday.

In an interview with Formosa Television, Lee said Taiwan has long been a sovereign state that does not belong to China and does not need to be split from any other country. He also raised the rather obvious question of how Beijing can apply its laws outside its jurisdiction.

As China's National People's Congress is set to review and enact the anti-secession law before March 15, Lee called on Taiwanese to take to the streets March 6 to protest the proposed legislation and to show to the world that Taiwan is not a part of China.
As long as the people of the island unite, Lee said, "we can show to the world that China's anti-secession law is not grounded on any legal basis."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, March 4, or the 24th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1193: Saladin, sultan of Egypt and Syria and legendary Muslim commander during the Crusades, dies in Damascus at the age of 56. He captured Jerusalem and defended it during the Third Crusade.
1394: Henry the Navigator, prince of Portugal, is born. He established an observatory and school of navigation as well as directed voyages that spurred the growth of Portugal's colonial empire.
1791: Vermont becomes the 14th state of the United States.
1861: Abraham Lincoln is sworn in as the 16th president of the United States, which is a country on the threshold of civil war.
1913: Democrat Woodrow Wilson becomes the 28th president of the United States.
1917: The German army begins a major retreat along the Western Front during World War I.
1933: Franklin D. Roosevelt is sworn in as the 32nd president of the United States.
1941: German leader Adolf Hitler meets with Prince Paul in Belgrade to ask Yugoslavia to join the Axis powers led by Germany and Italy.
1942: Gen. Joseph Stilwell arrives in Chungking to assume office as chief of staff of the China Theater of War and also to take command of all American armed forces in China, Burma and India.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines, where the capital Manila has been taken by his troops after months of heavy fighting against Japanese occupying forces.
1951: The first Asian Games opens in New Delhi, India.
1966: A Canadian DC-8 airliner crashes near Haneda airport in Japan, killing 64 people and injuring eight others.
1968: Professional tennis players are allowed to compete at Wimbledon, the world's oldest amateur tennis tournament.
1970: The French submarine Euridice is lost along with all 57 people onboard in the Mediterranean Sea off the coast of Toulon.
1971: Pierre Trudeau, the 52-year-old prime minister of Canada, secretly marries 22-year-old Margaret Sinclair.
1973: The U.S. ambassador-at-large, David M. Kennedy, arrives in the Republic of China for a four-day visit and talks with officials on trade and monetary problems.
1973: Simon Pierre Kibanda arrives in Taipei to assume office as the Central African Republic ambassador to the ROC.
1974: Labor leader Harold Wilson becomes prime minister after his party wins the British elections.
1975: Charlie Chaplin, the British-born actor, director and producer who gained fame for his role as a tramp in baggy trousers and a bowler hat, is knighted at Buckingham Palace.
1975: The first Pan American World Airways flight to serve Taiwan touches down at Taipei International Airport.
1976: The Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei enters into sisterhood ties with the Overseas Chinese Exporters and Importers Association of the United States.
1977: An earthquake rocks Romania, killing 1,541 people and injuring 1,200 others.
1991: Idriss Deby becomes the new president of Chad.
1994: Beijing authorities arrest Chinese democratic activist Wei Jingsheng.
1996: British Prime Minister John Major says all of Hong Kong's permanent residents will be allowed visa-free entry into Britain after Communist China takes over the British colony in 1997.
2000: Wu Ta-you, an internationally renown physicist and former president of Academia Sinica, dies of illness at National Taiwan University Hospital at the age of 95.
2001: National Palace Museum Director Tu Cheng-sheng offers to help preserve the priceless ancient Buddha statues in Afghanistan that face possible destruction on religious grounds by the Taliban regime.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not expect to find a saint today. But if I find a gentleman, I shall be quite satisfied."

The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Scrap Senate, House urges

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN FREIGHTER SINKS OFF PENGHU

TEXT.P: A Panamanian cargo ship that ran aground near Penghu Thursday due to engine failure and stormy weather sank at around 1 a.m. Friday, with all but one of the 20 crew members having been rescued, coast guard authorities reported.
The first mate of the Panamanian bulk carrier "Shinko Ocean, " named Siman Juntak, remains missing after having fallen overboard during Thursday's mishap. Rescuers continue their search for Juntak.
The nineteen other crew members have been safely helicoptered to Makung, the capital of Penghu, after being rescued by the Republic of China Seagull Squad.

The bulk carrier sent out an SOS at around 2 p.m. Thursday from waters some 14 nautical miles from Penghu, located off Taiwan's southwest coast, after the vessel ran aground because of engine failure and stormy weather.

A Seagull rescue helicopter took off from an air base in Chiayi, southern Taiwan and successfully airlifted the crew, in marathon back-and-forth shuttles, to Makung Airport, where they were transferred to two hospitals in Penghu for treatment.

The Panamanian freighter was on its way from Malaysia to Taichung, central Taiwan, transporting logs, when its engines failed. Stormy weather then caused the captain of the ship to lose control, and the vessel eventually hit a rock formation in shallow waters off Penghu Island.
The ship then drifted further away from the northeastern coast of Makung before sinking at around 1 a.m. Friday as a result of leakage, coast guard authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BAN ON FARM PRODUCE EXPORTS TO CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: The government has not imposed any ban on exports of agricultural products to mainland China, a senior mainland affairs official said Friday.
Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san was responding to a recent announcement by mainland Chinese authorities that they will offer Taiwan farmers greater access to the mainland market.

Chiu said Taiwan has not banned sales of locally produced agricultural products to mainland China. However, Chiu said that due to mainland China's tariffs and non-tariff trade barriers, such as restrictions in marketing, customs clearance and quarantine, Taiwan's agricultural exports to mainland China have consistently been lower than its agricultural imports from the mainland.
Pointing out that farm produce has a relatively short shelf life, Chiu said distribution channels are very important in farm trade.

"Unless mainland China provides easier and more convenient transportation and distribution channels, Taiwan's farm goods exports to the mainland are not expected to grow substantially with just lip service from Beijing," Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AFFIRMS PRESIDENT'S RECENT MEETING WITH SOONG

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislative Yuan said Friday that it fully supports President Chen Shui-bian's move to seek inter-party reconciliation and expressed the hope of ending the row triggered by Chen's recent meeting with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

The DPP caucus made the remarks amid criticism from some quarters within the DPP and from its ally, the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), of the Chen-Soong meeting last Thursday in which the president reaffirmed the "five noes" pledge, including no declaration of Taiwan independence and no change of the nation's official name.

Ker Chien-ming, executive director of the DPP's Central Policy Committee, said the party supports the president's intentions of pursuing inter-party reconciliation and stable politics through the holding of the meeting with Soong.

As the National People's Congress, mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament, will soon review the proposed "anti-secession law" aimed at Taiwan, Ker said the ruling and opposition parties should unite to face the "national crisis."

Ker said that the DPP is willing to accept the criticism from the TSU with humility. He also invited the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP to join a DPP-sponsored "Protect Taiwan, Oppose Annexation" rally set to take place in Taipei Sunday.

Meanwhile, several DPP legislators issued a joint statement Friday to voice opposition to the proposed anti-secession law, urging the leaders of the opposition parties to declare their stance clearly.

DPP Legislator Pan Meng-an said that on the eve of Beijing's enactment of the anti-secession law, KMT Chairman Lien Chan is planning to send KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang to head a delegation to the mainland, which Pan said will send the wrong message to Beijing.

Another DPP legislator, Huang Wei-tze, claimed that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- both of whom are KMT vice chairmen -- are ambivalent about Beijing's proposed law, and called for them to unequivocally state their opposition.
Several legislators also urged the government to send lobbying delegations to the United States, Japan and European Union to explain the government's stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCIAL MINISTER SOLICITS FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 3 (CNA) (By C.Y. Tseng and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top financial official said Thursday in New York that Taiwan's financial reforms will change the structure of the country's financial market and that this change will be to the island's advantage in competing with China to attract foreign investment.

Minister of Financial Affairs Lin Chuan, at the head of a delegation visiting the city, made the comments while introducing Taiwan's financial reforms and investment opportunities to local businesspeople and investors at a seminar.

Lin expressed the hope that by attending the seminar, foreign investors can better understand that Taiwan does not necessarily want to sell its state-run banks and that they can instead invest in the banks by means of joint ventures, technology transfers or the purchase of stocks in the banks.
On competition with mainland China to attract foreign investment, Lin said that Taiwan's stance is to open its financial market and let market forces decide the value of investments.

The aim of the delegation's visit is to give foreign investors a better understanding of the changes in Taiwan's financial market, particularly the policies regarding future consolidation and privatization of the state-run banks, Lin said.

A total of 200 representatives from international investment institutions and agencies as well as local businesspeople and investors attended the seminar to listen to introductions made by Lin, Thomas Yeh, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan, and a ranking official from the Financial Supervision Commission on Taiwan's financial climate and financial reform, and its policies concerning state-run banks' privatization and consolidation.

The ROC Ministry of Finance has actively worked on the consolidation and privatization of state-run banks since President Chen Shui-bian expressed last year the hope that the number of state-run banks in Taiwan should be halved to six within a year.

Other members of the delegation include top executives from state-own financial institutions, such as Hua Nan Financial Holding and Mega Financial Holding, Land Bank of Taiwan, Central Trust of China, as well as executives from the state-run Tobacco and Liquor Co.
The delegation will also visit leading investment institutions in the city before heading for London next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN BUDDHISM MASTER FROM SIKKIM DIES FROM PNEUMONIA IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, March 4 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Tibetan Buddhist master Khenpo Loden Rinpoche died recently of acute pneumonia days after arriving in Taiwan for a Buddhism promotion tour, religious sources said Friday.

The 79-year-old Loden Rinpoche arrived in Taiwan Feb. 22 to promote Tibetan Buddhism but became ill two days later. He was rushed to the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linko, Taoyuan Feb. 24 and died early the next morning, according to a spokesman for the Vajrayana Buddhist Institute, which invited the Rinpoche to Taiwan.

The body of the Tibetan Buddhism master, who was from the Indian state of Sikkim located in northeastern India between Nepal and Bhuttan, was cremated in accordance with Tibetan Buddhist custom. Rinpoche's ashes will be kept in Taiwan for 49 to be worshipped by his disciples before being transported back to Sikkim to be buried.
Rinpoche, who had co-presided over important Tibetan Buddhism rituals with the Dalai Lama, was one of the most revered and influential Tibetan Buddhist masters in Sikkim.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN WARNS OF GRAVE CONSEQUENCES OF ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tan-san urged Beijing Friday not to enact its proposed anti-secession law, warning of serious consequences if it does so.
Chiu made the remarks at a regular weekly news conference

Claiming that enactment of the proposed anti-secession law would clear the way for a mainland Chinese attack against Taiwan at any time, alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, undermine peace and security in East Asia, and hinder cross-strait exchanges, Chiu urged Beijing to think twice before doing so.

Chiu said that the MAC, Taiwan's top agency in charge of mainland China policy, is collecting all relevant information on the contents of the anti-secession law. He added that the agency has yet to work out countermeasures.

Responding to questions on whether enactment of the anti-secession law would affect the promotion of cargo services between the two sides of the strait, Chiu asserted that it would certainly cause pressure on two-way exchanges, as Taiwan is a pluralistic society, in which freedom of speech and basic human rights are fully protected.
The MAC vice chairman pointed out that the government must make the people of Taiwan and the mainland leadership aware of the serious consequences if the law is enacted.
The National People's Congress, mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament, is expected to enact the law in the middle of this month after it opens its 10th plenary session Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME-CHANGE SHOULD NOT BECOME IDEOLOGICAL: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday the issue concerning changing the country's official name should not be made to become an ideological argument.

Speaking to legislators during a legislative interpellation session, Hsieh proposed that the issue be put aside until a consciousness of common destiny is established in Taiwan so as to reduce the controversies surrounding the issue.
Hsieh agreed that it would be convenient and practical to change the country's name to "Taiwan" from the "Republic of China" as the current name can be abbreviated to become "China."

However, Hsieh pointed out that Taiwan faces diplomatic deadlock resulting from an international isolation campaign against the island initiated by mainland China, which claims "Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China."
In these circumstances, it is difficult for Taiwan to expand its foreign relations regardless of whether is uses the name "Republic of China" or "Taiwan," Hsieh said.

According to Hsieh, the pro-independence movement in Taiwan is confusing the international community, making many countries believe that Taiwan is not yet an independent country and that it is now trying to gain independence from the PRC.

Therefore, Taiwan should from now on avoid calling for independence and instead emphasize that the ROC is an independent and sovereign state separate from the PRC and that it is not necessary to declare independence from any country, he said.

He said another reason for Taiwan to follow this course is its own security, as it needs to consider the possible reaction of the mainland, which has vowed to take military action against the island if it were to declare independence.
Hsieh's remarks were apparently aimed at quelling widespread anger among pro-independence hard-liners with recent statements made by President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen told a group of European parliamentarians in a teleconference earlier this week that it is unnecessary for Taiwan to declare independence and that it is not possible to change the official name of the country to "Republic of Taiwan" during his term in light of the currrent political reality on the island.
Chen made similar assurances during a meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO HARM STABILITY IN THE TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh expressed hope Friday that China will not make the decision to harm stability in the Taiwan Strait.
The premier made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan while referring to China's preparations to enact an anti-secession law.

Pointing out that the Executive Yuan already made a serious statement Wednesday to voice its strong opposition to the proposed law, Hsieh said the Legislative Yuan should also adopt unanimously an "anti-annexation law" to counter China's proposed bill.

Despite the fact that the ruling and opposition parties differ in their methods of expressing their stances, they are united in their determination to support the adoption of an anti-annexation law, the premier claimed.

The Standing Committee of the Chinese National People's Congress adopted last December a draft of the anti-secession law and the congress is set to review the draft and pass it into law at its annual plenary session slated to open March 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Saudis Urge Syria to Withdraw From Lebanon.
Saudi Arabia's rulers add voice to a chorus of demands already emanating from Washington and European capitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU DRUMS UP SUPPORT FOR ANTI-ANNEXATION DEMONSTRATION

TEXT.P: Legislators of the opposition pro-Taiwan independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the public Friday to take part Sunday in an anti-annexation demonstration in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Several TSU legislators spoke in the Legislative Yuan, urging the public to oppose Beijing's so-called anti-secession law that will soon be reviewed and approved by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament.

To drum up public support, they also held signs bearing "anti-annexation, protect Taiwan" slogans outside the legislature, donned headbands and displayed "306 anti-annexation" stickers on their faces.

Lo Chih-ming, caucus whip of the TSU in the legislature, urged the public, whether they are in favor of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the TSU, or the opposition alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT) , People First Party (PFP) and the New Party, to either join a "protect Taiwan and oppose annexation " rally in Taipei Sunday sponsored by the DPP or take part in a "306 anti-annexation" demonstration held by the TSU in Kaohsiung on the same day.

Lo said it is high time that all parties put aside their differences and jointly stand against Beijing's anti-secession law, which seeks to lay a legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan should the island declare independence.

Noting that former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's spiritual leader, will attend the Kaohsiung demonstration, Lo expressed hope that KMT Chairman Lien Chan, PFP Chairman James Soong and President Chen Shui-bian will also join the demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PUBLICITY MATERIALS ON ARMS PROCUREMENT SENT TO LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense delivered a new set of publicity materials to the Legislative Yuan Friday in a fresh attempt to lobby for lawmakers' support for a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States.
The 13-page booklet underlines the theme of "hope and peace" and uses simple images to illustrate the connection between the arms procurement and national security.

It makes a clear difference from the controversial material released by the ministry last year that used a large quantity of statistics and claimed that the cost of the package would be equal to "one glass of pearl milk tea every day" per person in Taiwan.

The booklet emphasizes that it would be most appropriate for the government to finance the arms procurement in the form of a special budget because it would squeeze other spending if the package were included in the government's regular budget.

The special budget proposed by the Cabinet to buy six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft was shelved by the previous legislature owing to objections from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party, which argued that the weapons were unnecessary and too expensive.
The budget bill is expected to remain a centerpiece in the new legislature that started Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ATTENDS OPENING OF TAIPEI CYCLE SHOW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised Friday the domestic bicycle industry for setting a textbook model for Taiwan companies in their quest for industrial upgrading and business expansion.
Chen made the remarks while giving a speech at the opening of the 2005 Taipei Cycle Show at the World Trade Center that will run through March 7.

Chen recalled his childhood riding a bicycle on adventures as a fascinating and exciting experience and expressed hope that his grandsons will grow up to enjoy the same happiness as he did as a youngster.
The president encouraged local governments to build bicycle pathways in urban areas to allow their citizens to ride safely -- an ideal way for commuters that is both healthy and non-polluting.
He also hailed Taiwan bike makers, saying that their efforts and innovation have turned what was formerly a cheap commodity into a high-priced product sold in exclusive shops.
