This year's exhibition, the 18th of its kind, has drawn participants from 620 companies in 29 countries to display their sophisticated bikes in 2,019 booths -- a more than 20 percent increase over last year's number.
It was the first time that the president had visited the show -- the world's third-largest and Asia's biggest.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN URGES BEIJING TO RE-THINK ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan drafted a statement Friday urging China to re-think its proposed anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

The wording of the statement was moderate as it adopted mostly the versions of the opposition Kuomintang and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union. Versions produced by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- which says that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are under separate rule -- and by the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which states that "Taiwan is not part of China," were not included in the resolution.
The statement is expected to be passed as a resolution in a full Legislative Yuan floor meeting next Tuesday at the earliest.

The statement says that the Legislative Yuan is issuing a proposed resolution on behalf of the Taiwan people on the anti-secession law that will soon be reviewed and approved by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament.

The proposed resolution says that the Republic of China, since its founding in 1912, has been a "sovereign, independent county" and any move to unilaterally change the status quo or try to denigrate the sovereignty of the nation will run counter to the common will of the Taiwan people and the international community.

The people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait aspire for peaceful development, the resolution says, adding that if the proposed law of China violates the rights of the Taiwan people, it will incite vehement opposition from Taiwan.

It also says that the cross-strait atmosphere has improved in the wake of the cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday and that the governments on both sides should cherish the opportunity to embark on consultation based on equality and dignity to create a situation that is beneficial for both sides.
The political parties will also promote a China policy based on equality and reciprocity and do their best to promote cross-strait peaceful development, it says.
The legislative caucuses of the ruling and the opposition parties said that this is a preliminary appeal and that they will respond further if Beijing goes ahead to enact the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEMALE DPP LAWMAKERS LAUNCH CYBER PROTEST AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: A group of female legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched a cyber lobby movement Friday, appealing to the world to heed Taiwan's concerns and oppose Beijing's imminent enactment of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

In an open letter initiating the lobby Web site -- www.mammycare.org.tw -- the DPP legislators, including Kuan Pi-ling, Lan Mei-chin, Wang Shu-hui, Hsiao Bi-khim and Chang Ching-hui, urged Taiwan citizens, particularly mothers, to relay the open letter to influential organizations around the world to let the world know their concerns and worries over Beijing's plans to pass the law.

The open letter, titled "Concerns of an Ordinary Mother, " says that "China, one of our neighbors and a sister in whose veins runs the same blood as us, claims sovereignty over Taiwan that nourishes us, and demands our admission that Taiwan is a part of China despite the fact that both sides have completely different systems, cultural backgrounds and institutions. China forces us to accept the logic of her thinking, and will not take 'no' for an answer."

"China is poised to enact the anti-secession law by the end of March, to provide a legal basis for confining Taiwan, the country my children and I live in, and unification with China without any autonomous development. The only choice left for us would be war, " the open letter says.

It is hoped, said Kuan, that the open letter will be forwarded, with Taiwan mothers' signatures, to people in the European Union, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the United Nations Security Council, Japan, the United States and other countries to voice Taiwan's opposition to the anti-secession legislation and to disclose Beijing's attempts to annex Taiwan, moves that would eventually undermine cross-strait and regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER DEFENDS RIGHTS OF LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has rights in terms of cross-Taiwan Strait affairs as long as it acts within the law and does not affect the rights of the president at the diplomatic and administrative level, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday.

Wang made the remarks one day after a majority of legislators reached consensus on the formation of a task force within the legislature to handle cross-strait affairs, although lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) also cautioned that matters related to cross-strait ties are the power of the president according to the Constitution.

The DPP and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Friday that they are opposed to a re-activation of the cross-strait task force and will not allow members of their parties to be a part of it. The TSU also pointed out that the task force existed in the previous legislature but claimed that it was ineffectual and a waste of time.

Members of the task force will include the legislative speaker, vice speaker and 23 legislators who will be selected in proportion to the number of the seats each party holds in the legislature. The members will be decided by March 20.
Wang said that if the DPP and the TSU refuse to nominate delegates, it is their right and will not affect the operations of the task force.

Wang said that the responsibility of the president on cross-strait ties is mainly centered on the diplomatic and administrative level, while the Legislative Yuan is monitoring cross-strait affairs and formulating related laws. The task force has not encroached on the Executive rights, and its operations are governed by the law, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS FOR BEIJING NOT TO ENACT ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called on Beijing Friday not to enact its proposed "anti-secession law" as it is a unilateral move that dwarfs Taiwan's status and harms cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

China should cease immediately the legislation of the controversial bill, which threatens to alter the cross-strait status quo and endanger the livelihoods of the people across the strait, " said Chen Chieh, a KMT party whip at the Legislative Yuan.

At a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Chen Chieh urged President Chen Shui-bian to continue to push for cross-strait dialogue on peace, noting that KMT Chairman Lien Chan has expressed his willingness to visit China in his capacity as KMT chief to help accelerate peaceful engagement between the two sides.

Underlining a quote by Lien -- "Radical independence means radical unification, " Chen Chieh said the quote proved to be prophetic, claiming that the president's previous statements about pushing for a referendum on constitutional re-engineering were what prompted Beijing to propose the anti-secession law.

Chen Chieh called for the president to respect the ROC Constitution, to try to secure an environment in which the two sides of the strait can co-exist peacefully, to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue and to seek developments that are beneficial to both sides.
The KMT party whip also urged the Beijing leadership to respect the will of the Taiwan people and to refrain from taking action harmful to cross-strait peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES STAND AT US$246.628 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$246.628 billion at the end of February, up US$3.844 billion from a month earlier, according to tallies released Friday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The figure represents a new high, the CBC officials said.
They attributed the increase to an influx of foreign capital, revenue from foreign exchange reserves investment and the appreciation of the Euro against the U.S. dollar.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rank third in the world, behind only those of Japan and China, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES TAIWAN, CHINA TO STOP PROVOKING EACH OTHER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 4 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou called on Taiwan and China Friday to stop making provocative moves so as not to intensify cross-Taiwan Strait tension.

Addressing a Tokyo gathering with a group of Taiwanese expatriates in Japan, Ma said the government in Taiwan should drop the ideological pursuit of changing the official name of the country and drafting a new constitution, which he said will impede the development of the island.
The government should instead concentrate on efforts to improve the economy, law and order, and national development, Ma said.
He also said he believes last week's meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong will be helpful to Taiwan's political stability.

Chen declared in the meeting that he has no plan to change the country's name during his term and that his planned constitutional reforms will not involve changes to national sovereignty, territory or cross-strait status quo.

Ma said it is incomprehensible as to why Beijing decided to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan after the victory in last year's legislative elections of the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party and New Party, which opposes independence for Taiwan.
He suggested that both sides of the strait stop such provocative moves and enhance exchanges to build up mutual trust.
Meanwhile, the mayor, who is also a vice chairman of the KMT, said he will start campaigning for his bid to run for the party's chairmanship after registering his candidacy in late March.
He said taking part in the chairmanship election is not necessarily related to the question of whether he will run for the 2008 presidency.
Ma arrived in Japan earlier this week for a four-day visit. He is scheduled to meet Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara and Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March lost six points to close at 6,198, with 21,080 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved down 11 points to finish at 6,200, with 357 contracts traded, while June futures lost 24 points to finish at 6,190, with 79 contracts traded.
September futures lost 27 points to finish at 6,110, with 62 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 37 points to close at 6,110, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,204 for March, 6,211 for April, 6,214 for June, 6,137 for September and 6,147 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
March TE futures moved down 1.1 points to close at 233.5, with 3,681 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost one point to finish at 233.7 , with 51 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

March TF futures lost 1.8 points to finish at 1,018.6, with 2,400 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 1.4 points to end at 1,019.4, with 58 contracts traded. September TF futures lost 11.6 points to finish at 1,006, with one contract changing hands. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 8.76 points to close at 6,193.62.
The bourse opened at 6,191.42 and fluctuated between 6,219.07 and 6,178.26 during trading. A total of 3.45 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$81.29 billion (US$2.62 billion).
Only three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up at 0.6 percent and cement stocks and paper and pulp issues both gaining 0.4 percent.

Five other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent, textile stocks at 0.5 percent and machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 468 to 387, with 146 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BIKE INDUSTRY ENJOYS GREAT SUCCESS

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taipei International Cycle Show opened Friday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with a new high of 620 companies from 29 countries taking part to show their advanced items at a record 2,019 booths.

Taiwan External Trade Development Council Chairman Hsu Chih-jen hailed Taiwan bike makers for their success in turning the domestic industry into a value-added business through their innovation, making Taiwan a world key supply hub for high-end bicycles.
The Taipei cycle show is the world's third-largest and the largest in Asia. President Chen Shui-bian also attended the opening of the exhibition.

Taiwan Bicycle Exporters' Association Chairman Yang Yin-ming said that under a labor division strategy between Taiwan and mainland China, the domestic cycle industry will still be able to register noticeable sales growth this year.
According to Yang, the domestic bike industry has come a long way in building its own distinguished brand names over the past 30 years.

Although the domestic industry experienced the largest slump in outbound shipments in 2003 as a result of company relocations to mainland China and Vietnam, Yang said that it has got back to its feet in recent years thanks to its exploration of new materials and new designs.

Taiwan bike exports once peaked at a level of more than 10 million units during the heyday in the 1990s, he noted, adding that the total export level of Taiwan, China and Vietnam reached 30 million units now.
Statistics show that Taiwan bike outbound shipments were about 4.38 million units in 2004, up by some 13 percent compared to the 2003 amount of 3.88 million units.

The 2004 export value totaled US$720 million, an increase of 23.7 percent over the 2003 level of US$580 million. Meanwhile, the average unit price rose to US$164 in 2004 from the previous year's US$150.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU TO SET UP TAIWAN UMAP SCHOLARSHIP TO ATTRACT FOREIGN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) announced Friday that it will set up a scholarship program to allow foreign students from member countries of the University Mobility in Asia and the Pacific (UMAP) to pursue advanced studies at domestic universities.
Chou Chia-pei, director of the NTU International Academic Exchange Center, made the announcement during a UMAP board meeting attended by 20 representatives from 11 member countries.

The UMAP Taiwan Scholarship Program will be a three-year student exchange plan effective between 2005 and 2008, during which 10 excellent students selected from the association's member countries will be allowed to study at domestic universities every year, while 10 Taiwan students will be sent to those countries to study, Chou said.
Under the program, each student will be offered a scholarship worth NT$150,000 (US$4,840) annually, she went on.
Saying that the program has received support from the Ministry of Education, Chou said NTU authorities will further discuss related regulations over how to apply for the scholarships.
According to Chou, the scholarship program is expected to come into force in mid-April.

UMAP, a voluntary association of government and non-government representatives of the higher education (university) sector in the Asia-Pacific region, was founded in 1993 with the aim of achieving enhanced international understanding through mobility of university students and staff.
Currently, the association has 19 member countries, including Australia, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, Taiwan and the United States. NTU President Chen Wei-jao serves as UMAP board chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOT ATTEND `PAN-GREEN' ANTI-ANNEXATION ACTIVITIES: KMT WHIP

TEXT.P: Responding to an invitation from the "pan-green camp" to an "anti-annexation" rally and demonstration March 6, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) whip said Friday that his party will not take part.

Chen Jie told reporters at the KMT legislative caucus office that the KMT opposes Beijing's move to enact an anti-secession law and hopes that relations between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait will maintain the status quo. However, he continued, the March 6 protests are being organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and the KMT "does not want to dance with them."

Chen said that his party believes China's drafting of the anti-secession law was a consequence of President Chen Shui-bian's vows since assuming power in 2000 to hold a referendum on Taiwan independence and the writing of a new constitution.

The moves have irritated Beijing, the lawmaker said. He noted that the KMT wants the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to get along with each other peacefully while trying to jointly boost economic development on both sides.
The "pan-green camp" plans to hold a "protect Taiwan and oppose annexation" rally in Taipei Sunday while staging a "306 anti-annexation" demonstration in Kaohsiung on the same day.
The National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament -- is expected to screen and approve the proposed anti-secession law in mid-March.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE DONATES RICE TO INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 4 (CNA) (By Olive Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Washington, D.C. decided Friday to donate 10,000 tons of rice to tsunami refugees in Indonesia on behalf of the ROC government.

The donation was made through the United States-based Feed the Children, officials of which will travel to Taiwan to witness the delivery of the rice, which will be transported from Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan to Jakarta in a month, according to ROC diplomats.

The transport process will be documented and will probably be broadcast in advertisements sponsored by the charity organization on U. S. TV channels, they said, adding that the rice, with a market value of US$10 million, was the largest donation ever received by by Feed the Children since it launched a campaign to help tsunami refugees in Southeast Asia and South Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WILL NOT ATTEND DPP-LED PROTEST AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) will not send any officials to take part in a March 6 demonstration against Beijing's anti-secession law organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Taipei, but will not prevent its supporters from doing so, a party official said Friday.

Chen Chih-pin, a PFP legislative caucus whip, made the remarks after DPP caucus members invited officials of the main opposition Kuomintang and the PFP to take part in the protest earlier the same day. Premier Frank Hsieh and Secretary - General to the President Yu Shyi-kun will participate in the activity.
Chen also ascribed Beijing's plan to enact the law, apparently aimed at Taiwan, to what he described as President Chen Shui-bian's "poor handling" of relations between Taiwan and China.

Chen and Soong released a 10-point joint statement late last month promising not to declare Taiwan independence and to keep the national moniker of the Republic of China in a gesture of reconciliation.
Beijing's National People's Congress is expected to approve the law in the middle of this month after it opens its 10th plenary session Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO CREATE WOMEN-FRIENDLY ENVIRONMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday his administration will do its utmost to create a women-friendly work and living environment.
Chen made the pledge while visiting Chunghwa Telecom Co.'s Taipei mobile phone call center to greet women workers there ahead of the March 8 International Women's Day.

Chunghwa Telecom has hired a total of 500 women employees with tertiary education to serve its 8 million-plus mobile phone subscribers round the clock. The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) especially arranged for the president to visit the center ahead of Women's Day to see for himself the work situation of local career women.
About 90 employees were on duty when Chen arrived in the company of CLA Chairwoman Chen Chu and Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Ho-Chen Tan and the president presented a cut rose to each female staffer.

With the assistance of Chunghwa Telecom staff, Chen acted as a call center staffer to answer two phone calls from Chunghwa mobile phone subscribers, who were surprised when they heard the president's voice. Chen told the subscribers that he is the real president, not a fake. He also answered the subscribers' questions.

Afterwards, Chen delivered a brief speech in which he said that the government has enacted a workplace gender equality law to prevent discrimination against women and a package of regulations to help women land jobs.

Nevertheless, he acknowledged that there is still ample room for the government to improve welfare services for women, including assistance in day care, child education, senior citizen care and personal safety.

Noting that creating a women-friendly environment is the government's unshirkable responsibility, Chen said neither career women nor homemakers should be discriminated against because of their gender.

Chen said the government will take steps to help women who have quit the job market due to marriage or child-bearing to return to work by offering vocational training programs catering to their special professional needs.

During this era of focusing on cultivating a humanistic, congenial working environment, Chen said, women can play a constructive role in realizing that goal "with their tender hearts and attentive work attitude."

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO GOVERNOR REBUKES CHINA FOR PUSHING ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara rebuked China Friday for planning to pass an anti-secession law that targets Taiwan, calling Beijing a troublemaker that is making neighboring countries nervous.
Ishihara made the remarks during a meeting with visiting Republic of China Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung.
According to Ishihara, such a law is not a guarantee of territorial integrity, because China will fall apart before it can use the law against Taiwan if it cannot solve its many domestic problems.
Ishihara said he had exchanged views with U.S. State Department officials on the issue and that they share his views.

On the recent decision by the United States and Japan to list peace in the Taiwan Strait part of their common strategic objectives in the region, Ishihara pointed out that China has repeatedly sent survey vessels and even submarines to areas near Japan's territorial waters and Guam, which he said prompted Washington and Tokyo to action.
Ishihara said China's military buildup and threat are not only against Taiwan, but are also targeting the United States and Japan.
Under these circumstances, it is necessary for the United States, Japan and Taiwan to enhance their cooperation to jointly deal with the problem, he said.
Lin went to Nagoya to visit Mayor Takehisa Matsubara after concluding his meeting with Ishihara.
Lin, who arrived in Japan Tuesday for a five-day visit, also met Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada and attended a Tokyo seminar on East Asia security and prosperity.
Lin has announced his decision to resign from his GIO post to seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run for Taichung mayor in year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Saudis Join Call for Syrian Force to Quit Lebanon
Saudi Arabia's demand added substantially to Syria's international isolation just a day after Russia made a similar call.
Wall Street Journal: Oil's Run Is Likely to Keep Fast Clip
Oil analysts expect price spikes to over $60 a barrel this year. Prices neared a new high yesterday before settling at $53.57.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: 18 Teens Eagerly Join Pro-Putin Club
To the strains of the national anthem, a group of students at Balashikha's School No. 1 joined the ranks of United Russia's youth group Thursday with promises of new friends, better careers and summer work.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH ARCHITECTS TO ATTEND TAIPEI SEMINAR ON URBAN RENEWAL

TEXT.P: A six-member team from Foster & Partners, a prominent British firm of architects, will arrive in Taipei March 13 to attend an international seminar on urban renewal and cultural renaissance, the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) said Friday.
The team will be headed by Andrew Miller, a senior partner of Foster & Partners, CCA Chairman Chen Chi-nan said.

Chen met with Sir Norman Foster, the 1999 laureate of the Pritzker Architecture Prize, who heads Foster & Partners, during a visit to Britain last autumn. Chen invited the company's architects and urban development planners to visit Taiwan this year to exchange views on how to inject new life into several of Taipei's historic relics and old buildings.

In addition to attending the March 14-15 seminar, Chen said, the six visitors will tour several Taipei cultural facilities and old buildings, including the Huashan Art Center, the National Taiwan Museum, the Chungshan Hall and the old Taipei Railway Ministry building.
Chen said he hopes the visitors will offer professional counseling on urban renewal with a cultural perspective, sustainable urban cultural development and renovation of old buildings.
Chen said one of the CCA's future tasks is to cultivate Taipei's new cultural image.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50,000 PEOPLE SIGN UP FOR MARCH 6 DEMONSTRATION: TSU

TEXT.P: Nearly 50,000 people have signed up to take part in a March 6 "anti-annexation, protect Taiwan" demonstration in Kaohsiung, according to a claim by the organizer, the opposition pro-Taiwan independence Taiwan Solidarity Union.

Deputy TSU Secretary-General Huang Chao-chan said Friday that Taiwan should speak out loudly against China's enactment of an anti-secession law that will provide a legal basis for the use of force against Taiwan should the latter declare independence.
Taiwan ought not only to stand against Beijing's attempt to annex Taiwan, it should also sent a protest to the world, Huang said, while urging people to join in the demonstration.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung City Councilor Chao Tien-lin of the TSU, who will preside over the March 6 event, called on Taiwan citizens, regardless of political links, age and gender, to take to the streets to express their opposition to China's annexation, claiming that the move is for the safety of the next Taiwanese generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE WARNS BEIJING OVER ANTI-SECESSION BILL IN RESOLUTION

TEXT.P: The various political parties in the Legislative Yuan warned Beijing Friday of Taiwan's resentment over China's proposed anti-secession bill and urged it to halt immediately the legislation of the bill.

The legislature said it passed a resolution on behalf of the Taiwan people on the anti-secession law that will soon be reviewed and approved by the National People's Congress, Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament.

The resolution says that since its founding in 1912, the Republic of China has been a "sovereign, independent country" and that any move that tries to unilaterally change the status quo or denigrate the sovereignty of the nation will run counter to the common will of the Taiwan people and the international community.

The people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait aspire to peaceful development, the resolution says, adding that if China's proposed law violates the rights of the Taiwan people, it will incite vehement opposition from Taiwan.

It also says that the cross-strait atmosphere has improved in the wake of the cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday and that the governments on both sides should cherish the opportunity to embark on consultation based on equality and dignity to create a situation that is beneficial for both sides.
The political parties will also promote a China policy based on equality and reciprocity and do their best to promote cross-strait peaceful development, it says.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR RISE ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.087 to close at NT$30.950.
A total of US$947 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$30.915, and was traded between NT$30.821 and NT$30.985.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUP CALLS FOR REFERENDUM ON ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE

TEXT.P: A private group urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Friday to pass a resolution authorizing the holding of a referendum on the government's proposed massive arms procurement package.

The Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) , which groups scholars and social activists, said the legislature should pass the resolution in line with the existing Referendum Law to allow for the arms procurement referendum to be held simultaneously with the elections for the mission-oriented National Assembly.
The Central Election Commission has set May 14 as the polling day for the mission-oriented National Assembly election.
Chang Ya-chung, the DAA convener, said voters should be given the chance to express their opinions on the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement project through a referendum.

Under the arms procurement package, Taiwan plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.
Chang said such a huge arms procurement package should not be decided just by a handful of politicians.
"Ordinary voters or taxpayers should have a say in deciding the project's fate," Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIC GROUP URGES PRESIDENT TO DELIVER ON NAME-CHANGE PROMISE

TEXT.P: The Central Taiwan Society (CTS) , a pro-independence group, called on President Chen Shui-bian Friday to deliver on his promises to "rectify" or rather, change the country's official name and to write a new constitution.
The group made the appeal in a statement issued in response to a 10-point agreement reached between Chen and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong during a Feb. 24 meeting.

Among the agreements was that the national status of the Republic of China as stated in the Constitution defines the de facto and de jure status quo across the Taiwan Strait and that this sovereignty status of the ROC deserves recognition and respect by both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the international community.

Chen also reaffirmed his long-standing commitment that during his term, he will not declare independence for Taiwan, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council.

The CTS claimed that the Chen-Soong meeting has "strongly impacted" the people of Taiwan who are working to build their country, while the 10-point agreement has brought Taiwan back to the former Kuomintang government's ideology.
The group said in its statement that efforts made by the president to seek inter-party reconciliation should be recognized, but that he should not lose his own stance for reconciliation's sake.

Since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2000, Chen has constantly shown goodwill gesture towards both China and pro-unification activists, the statement says, adding that the people of Taiwan have refrained from expressing their disappointment with the president's "coddling" toward his political rivals because they feel that this is just a transitional expediency adopted by the president.
But after the Chen-Soong meeting, CTS said they thinks the president has fallen short of the expectations of the people of Taiwan, according to the statement.
The statement also says that Chen should stop before committing a serious blunder and refrain from playing political games.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED FOR TAIWAN TO DECLARE INDEPENDENCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Since the ruling Democratic Progressive Party passed a resolution regarding Taiwan's future in 1999 when it was still an opposition party, there has been a consensus among party members that the Republic of China is already an independent and sovereign state and that it is not necessary to declare independence from any country, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Hsieh made the comment while answering questions during a legislative interpellation session. He also said that the conclusion of a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong does not contravene the 1999 resolution. On the contrary, it met the resolution's spirit, he claimed.

The resolution, proposed by Chen in 1999, states that Taiwan is a sovereign and independent country and that any change in the status quo must be decided by all the residents of Taiwan by means of a plebiscite.
Hsieh noted that both Chen and Soong have agreed that any change in Taiwan's status quo has to be decided by the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BETTER TIES WITH CHINA WILL HELP TAIWAN'S DIPLOMACY: FORMER FM

TEXT.P: Former President of the Control Yuan Fredrick Chien, who served as the minister of foreign affairs between 1990 and 1996, said Friday that better ties with China would be helpful for Taiwan's diplomacy.
In a news conference to introduce the first two volumes of his memoirs, Chien said, contrary to public opinion, better ties with China would help Taiwan to associate with other countries.
Public opinion holds that ties with China would actually make it more difficult for Taiwan to engage with other countries.

Chien, who joined the diplomatic service in 1962 and was involved in the shaping of the country's diplomatic policy for many years, said the country's top diplomatic priority of joining the World Health Organization and the United Nations would not be easier if Taiwan maintained better ties with China.
Chien said he would explain his points in the third volume of his memoirs, which is not yet finished.
Chien is the only foreign minister who has claimed while taking the reins at the foreign minstry that diplomacy should be dictated by the country's policy toward China.

Taiwan has tried to join the United Nations since 1993 and to enter the World Health Organization since 1997, only to see its repeated bids defeated by China, which has gone out of its way to shut Taiwan out of the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIGHTS OF DIPLOMATS IN SWITZERLAND REMAIN INTACT: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has "effectively defended" the diplomatic rights of its officials posted to the World Trade Organization in Geneva, despite China's attempts to get Switzerland to suspended them, Foreign Ministry spokesman Michel Lu said Friday.

Lu said the secretariat of the WTO, urged by China, tried to downgrade Taiwan into a local government of China when it published its list of member states in 2002, but claimed that it was stopped by the Foreign Ministry and Taiwan diplomats in Geneva.
The rights of Taiwan's diplomats in the WTO, as well as the country's dignity, has not been compromised in any way, according to Lu.

He made the statement after Premier Frank Hsieh told the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day that any official who agreed to Switzerland's attempt to downgrade the country's status in the WTO would be disciplined severely.
The premier made the statement after the issue was raised by a lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW WILL AUTHORIZE BEIJING TO USE FORCE: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A legislator of the pro-Taiwan independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) quoted Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng as saying Friday that China's proposed anti-secession law would authorize Beijing to use force against Taiwan.

Ho Min-hao, deputy convener of the TSU legislative caucus, said Huang made the remarks while delivering a report on Beijing's plan to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan at a closed-door meeting with TSU lawmakers.
Beijing officials have disclosed that China will use non-peaceful means against Taiwan if necessary, Huang was quoted as saying.
"Judging from the statement, the anti-secession law will be an act authorizing the Beijing authorities to wage war on Taiwan, " said Huang.
As for the government's countermeasures to the proposed legislation, Ho said that the government should join hands with friendly countries to protect the rights and interests of the people of Taiwan.

While continuing to push for the establishment of a peaceful and stable cross-Taiwan Strait interaction framework, the government should intensify its international publicity campaign to let the international community understand that Taiwan is a sovereign independent country and that neither side of the Taiwan Strait has jurisdiction over the other, said Ho.

In addition, he said, the government should also call on the international community to help cope with Beijing's intention to use force against the island by enacting its so-called anti-secession law.
Meanwhile, Ho disclosed that the MAC, the top agency in charge of drafting Taiwan's China policy, will do its utmost to deter China from sabotaging peace and stability across the strait.
Once the National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament -- approves the law in a plenary session slated to be held March 8-14, the MAC will make an appropriate response, Ho went on.

He further said that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has sent five delegations to the United States, Europe and Japan to meet with government officials, parliamentarians, think tank experts and local media in those countries to brief them on Taiwan's basic stance, in the hope that they will help block the anti-secession law from going into force.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 5 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, March 5:
10: 30, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the funeral of Chen Chih-ling, a police officer who died in the line of duty, at Chen's home in Chunan, Miaoli County.
12: 00, A group of university students will hold a sit-in at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to protest China's attempt to enact an anti-secession law.

14: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a ceremony at the Civil Service Personnel Development Center in Taipei to mark the donation of late Vice President Chen Cheng's personal documents to the government's archives.
19: 30, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will return to the Chiang Kai-shek Airport after a four-day trip to Japan.
19: 40, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the closing ceremony of the Taiwan Lantern Festival in Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, March 5, or the 25th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1534: Antonio Corregio, Italian Renaissance painter of sensuous mythological scenes who was known for his use of chiaroscuro, dies at the age of 40.
1751: James Madison, the fourth president of the United States and sponsor of the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, is born.
1770: British troops open fire on a hostile crowd in Boston, killing five Americans. The incident, which was dubbed the "Boston Massacre," hastens the approach of the American Revolutionary War.
1898: Soong Mayling, better known as Madame Chiang, the wife of late Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and the president and founder of the National Women's League of the Republic of China, is born.
1916: The Spanish ocean liner Principe de Asturias sinks off the coast of Brazil, killing 445 people.
1933: The Nazis and their allies win 52 percent of the seats in the Reichstag in German elections, with Chancellor Adolf Hitler gaining dictatorship.
1936: The Spitfire, a fighter plane produced by Britain's aircraft industry to counter the startling build-up in the number of military aircraft in Hitler's Germany, makes its maiden flight in Southamton.
1940: Tsai Yuan-pei, president of Academia Sinica, dies in Hong Kong at the age of 74.
1945: China, the United States, the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union issue joint invitations to the United Nations Conference in San Francisco on April 25.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces that China has rejected Soviet claims to all Japanese military enterprises in Manchuria.
1946: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill calls for joint Anglo-American efforts to face the Russian threat in his tour of the United States by saying that "an Iron Curtain has descended across Europe."
1953: Joseph Stalin, who forged the Soviet Union into a global superpower via an oppressive regime which killed millions of citizens, dies of a brain hemorrhage in Moscow at the age of 73.
1960: Indonesian President Sukarno suspends the country's parliament.
1965: Vice President Chen Cheng dies of liver cancer at the age of 68.
1966: A British Airways' Boeing 707 passenger plane crashes on Japan's Mount Fuji, killing all 124 people aboard.
1970: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications selects the route of the South Link Railway. Construction of the 97-kilometer railway from Fangliao to Pinan was scheduled to be completed in 1990.
1974: World Campus Afloat, a shipboard program sponsored by Chapman College of Orange, California, arrives at Keelung for a four-day visit.
1974: Dr. Choi Hyung Sup, Korean minister of science and technology, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China announces the appropriation of an additional NT$500 million to accelerate rural development in the first half of 1975.
1976: More than 3,000 Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts gather at Taipei's Youth Park to celebrate Chinese Scout Day.
1977: In the first presidential phone-in, U.S. President Jimmy Carter answers questions from listeners from over 26 states.
1990: Soviet reformist leader Boris Nikolayerich Yeltsin is elected as a representative to the Russian parliament.
1994: Mainland China's Standing Committee of the National People's Congress formally approves the "Taiwan Compatriot Investment Protection Act."
1994: Gratified by Beijing's release of democracy campaigner Wei Jingsheng, the United States presses for an explanation of the troubling events that led to his arrest.
2000: The Republic of China embassy in Palau is inaugurated, with ROC Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen and Sabino Ansatacio, a Palauan cabinet minister, jointly presiding over the opening ceremony.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian formally becomes the new chief of the National Council of Scouts of the Republic of China in a ceremony held at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men of the last generation, in matters of the arts and refinement, are considered to have been rude; men of the present generation are, in those matters, considered polite. But in my practice, I prefer men of the last generation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times: Unknown rascals dominate a debt-laden public company's teleconferenced investor conference.
The United Daily News: Both sides of Taiwan Straits belong to a same China: Hu Jintao.
The Liberty Times: Foreign currencies to be exchanged at stores with permits.
The Taiwan Daily: Tension across Taiwan Strait eased: Hu Jintao.
The Central Daily News: Legislature urges Beijing to halt legislation of anti-secession law in a resolution.
The China Post: Hu vows to crush independence, says strife easing.
The Taiwan News: Resolution on PRC law adopted by Legislature.
The Taipei Times: Hu warns against independence moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Lawmakers call for peace
After days of bickering by legislators, members of both chambers of Congress have now come to their senses by opting to stop issuing further incendiary statements and instead appeal for sobriety and peace.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Oil price hikes more often, warns energy dep't WITH world oil prices surging to unprecedented levels the past week, the energy department has warned motorists and commuters to brace themselves for much more frequent increases in petroleum pump prices.
The Philippine Star: GMA: No ceasefire in Sulu
President Arroyo turned down calls for a ceasefire yesterday and ordered the military to continue its offensive against Muslim rebels in Sulu, nearly a month into clashes that have killed over 100 and sparked terrorist bomb attacks.
The Manila Times: President says no to ceasefire in Jolo.
PRESIDENT Arroyo has rejected calls for a ceasefire with Muslim rebels on the island of Jolo and ordered the Armed Forces to pursue its offensive, her chief aides said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Big push to bring arts to heartland.
A new S$10 million Creative Community Singapore (CCS) fund will be given out over three years, to co-fund or market arts projects by the community for the community.
Lee Boon Yang, the minister of Information, Communications and the Arts, wants to turn Singapore into a nation of museum-loving, theatre-going, and arts-loving people.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Maxtor to slash its 5500 Singapore workers.
Maxtor, the world's number two hard disk drive maker, announced yesterday is slashing 5500 jobs as a result of its previously- announced decision to move one Singapore factory to China, while closing another.
Maxtor is cutting almost half or 42 percent of its workforce in Singapore.
It says it will spend US$12 million this quarter on severance costs, and about US$6 million in retention bonuses over a two-year period.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Tsutsumi held over Seibu share scam, insider trade Financial statements believed falsified for 40 years
Prosecutors arrested former Kokudo Corp. Chairman Yoshiaki Tsutsumi on Thursday for allegedly falsifying financial statements on share-holdings in Seibu Railway Co. and engaging in insider trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATROL RAFT COLLIDES WITH CHINSE SAMPAN NEAR KINMEN, TWO KILLED

TEXT.P: A patrol raft of the Kinmen Coast Guard collided Friday night with a sampan from Fujian, southern China, off the coast of the outlying county of Kinmen, killing two Chinese fishermen aboard the sampan, according to the Coast Guard Office on Kinmen.
The patrol raft lost power and ran aground after the collision and the crew were picked up by anther patrol raft after the accident, said the Kinmen Coast Guard Office.
The accident took place when Kinmen Coast Guard radar spotted a Chinese sampan suspected of carrying smuggled goods sailing toward Chinyu on Kinmen.
Two patrol rafts were sent to intercept the sampan and at about 10 p.m., the sampan, finding it was being trailed by the patrol rafts, tried to jettison its contraband and escape at speed.
The two patrol rafts approached the sampan to stop it, but one of them collided with the sampan head-on in the dark when the sampan made a sudden turn in an attempt to escape.
Two of the four crew aboard the sampan fell into the sea during the collision and were rescued by a Chinese fishing boat operating nearby.
After the accident, the Kinmen Coast Guard Office sent another three patrol boats to the scene to search for the other two crewmen, only to find their bodies still on the sampan.

After checking with their counterparts in the Chinese port of Xiamen, the Kinmen Coast Guard Office said the sampan came from Dadeng, Xiamen City. The dead were named as skipper Chang Fucheng and crew member Zhang Zongrong.

After the accident, a dozen Chinese fishing boats surrounded the abandoned patrol raft and the sampan until six Chinese patrol boats arrived on the scene Saturday morning to investigate, according to the Kinmen Coast Guard Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, PFP DENY REPORT ON COOPERATION IN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition People First Party (PFP) politicians denied Saturday a report in a local daily suggesting that the two parties are planning to cooperate in the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections.
Commenting on the report, DPP legislative caucus leader Lai Ching-teh said he had not heard of any such proposal being discussed by the party leadership.

Lai pointed out that such cooperation would have to involve many practical difficulties because it would lessen the chances of DPP politicians who wish to take part in the elections and would damage the DPP's cooperation with its ally, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union.
DPP support for a PFP candidate in the elections would likely also turn "pan-blue alliance" voters away, which would benefit the KMT, Lai pointed out.

Agreeing with Lai, PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung, who is planning to run for Keelung mayor, said it would be unlikely that the PFP and DPP will cooperate in the elections in light of the obvious ideological differences between the two parties.
Lu Hsueh-chang, another PFP legislator, said the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and PFP would have little chance of winning if the alliance should fall apart.
Liao Feng-teh, head of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, said his party will continue to monitor the situation to see if there is any substance to the report.

Another KMT official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, pointed out that the KMT is prepared to recommend joint candidates with the PFP in the year-end elections and has revised related rules to facilitate such cooperation.
However, if the PFP wishes to cooperate with the DPP, the KMT will not object to it, either, the official said.
According to the report, the possibility of the DPP and PFP cooperating in the elections rose after last week's meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman James Soong.

The newspaper claimed that the two parties had reached a high degree of consensus on cooperation in Hsinchu County and might expand their partnership to Hsinchu City, Miaoli County and Keelung City. All these localities are currently controlled by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), a long-time "pan-blue" ally of the PFP.
In one scenario speculated upon, the PFP might support the DPP's candidate in Hsinchu County in exchange for the DPP's support for its candidate in Miaoli County.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO FEAR BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan does not need to fear or overreact to Beijing's proposed enactment of an anti-secession law, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Cho-shui said Saturday.

Pointing out that Beijing does not need to make a law to attack Taiwan and crush its independence movement, Lin told the Central News Agency in an interview that it is simply disapproval from the international community rather than any lack of a legal basis that has prevented Beijing from doing so.

Lin said that Beijing's planned legislation of the anti-secession law reflects its discontent with Washington's Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and that Beijing intends to use it to counter what it sees as U.S. meddling in Taiwan affairs, which Beijing views as an internal issue.

However, Lin pointed out that Beijing's anti-secession law differs hugely to the TRA, given that the U.S. law only governs two-way ties and does not infringe upon Taiwan's sovereignty or intervene in its policy making.
On the contrary, Beijing's anti-secession law is drafted with the aim of seeking to arbitrate Taiwan's policy making and dictate Taiwan affairs as a domestic issue of China, Lin said.
But he asserted that Beijing will have no say over Taiwan's rejection of its law, as Taiwan is not a part of China.

Therefore, he went on, there is no need for Taiwan to fear or overreact to it, since international objections to Beijing's use of force against Taiwan will not disappear just because of a new piece of legislation. He urged the Taiwan people to strongly air their opposition to Beijing's scheme to alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
Lin's remarks came at a time when Beijing is expected to enact the law later this month, despite olive branches held out by the Taiwan authorities.

President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong released a 10-point joint statement Feb. 24, pledging not to declare Taiwan independence and to secure cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 TAIWAN IT PRODUCTS ENJOY NO. 1 SHARES IN WORLD MARKET: III

TEXT.P: Twelve information technology (IT) goods made by Taiwan companies enjoyed the largest or second-largest shares in the world market last year, the semi-official Institute for Information Industry (III) reported Saturday.
According to the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) at the III, 12 IT products manufactured by Taiwan companies boasted either the No. 1 or No. 2 market shares around the world.

Routers posted the largest stake of 89.2 percent in the global market, followed by WLAN products with 80.3 percent, motherboards and notebook computers with 78.3 percent, and DSLCPE with 70.9 percent, MIC statistics show. Other products enjoying the world's leading market shares included LCD monitors with 67.6 percent, cable modems with 66.3 percent and switches with 59 percent.

However, the largest market share is not equal to a guarantee of handsome earnings, MIC tallies pointed out, indicating that notebook computers, motherboards and LCD monitors contributed a combined 77 percent of the IT industry's overall output value last year -- some US$51.9 billion out of US$67.3 billion generated both at home and abroad.
The domestic industry is expected to put out more than US$70 billion in value for 2005. The figure stood at US$54.4 billion last year.

Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that Taiwan computer firms at home and abroad yielded a total of US$62.7 billion in production value in 2004, up by 21.5 percent over the previous year's level.
Notebook computers and LCD monitors made up the lion's share of 63 percent of the industry's total revenue last year, or a combined production value of US$39.7 billion.

Some 85.1 percent of the total was put out last year in China, an increase of 21.8 percentage points year on year, according to the DGBAS tallies. As high as 91.7 percent of Taiwan companies' main hardware products are manufactured overseas out of their quest for cheaper costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT PROPOSES 'TWO CHINAS' TO COUNTER BEIJING'S 'ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu proposed Saturday that the government declare to the world the existence of "two Chinas" to counter Beijing's "one China" policy.

Lu put forth the idea during an interview with a local media organization in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's recent statements that he has no plans to change the official name of the country from the Republic of China to "Republic of Taiwan" during his term.
Lu pointed out that while there is a communist People's Republic of China, there is also a free and democratic Republic of China on Taiwan.

Under this "two Chinas" framework, the anti-secession law that Beijing is planning to enact will be inapplicable to Taiwan, because the law will only be effective in territory controlled by the PRC, Lu argued.

According to Lu, Beijing compelled Taipei to accept the "one China" policy during talks held in Hong Kong in 1992, and both sides later came to a compromise that allowed either side to express in oral form their respective interpretations of the meaning of "one China, " with Beijing insisting that "one China" refers to the PRC and Taipei insisting that "one China" refers to the ROC.
This so-called "1992 consensus" established during the time of the former Kuomintang (KMT) government reflected the fact that there are "two Chinas," Lu said.
Lu suggested that the opposition KMT, as a supporter of the "1992 consensus, " openly confess it is following a policy of "two Chinas" and take the lead in promoting the idea of "two Chinas."
She agreed with Chen that the ROC is the largest area of common ground between the different political camps in Taiwan on the controversial issue of national identity.

In response to the vice president's proposal, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said that although the concept of "two Chinas" is closest to the reality, it cannot solve the problems across the Taiwan Strait.
Chang said the KMT believes the government should allow a certain extent of ambiguity in dealing with cross-strait issues, because anything else will only lead to confrontation.

Meanwhile, the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for "deceiving itself and the people of Taiwan" by putting forth the idea of "two Chinas."
According to TSU legislative caucus convener Lo Chih-ming, the idea will be accepted by neither Beijing nor the international community.

Lo claimed that the ROC vanished from the world after its United Nations membership was replaced by the PRC in 1971, noting that nobody recognizes the existence of the ROC today with the exception of a group of fewer than 30 diplomatic allies bought by Taiwan through checkbook diplomacy.
Lo insisted that the cross-strait status quo is "one China, one Taiwan" or "one country on either side" and that the destiny of Taiwan should be decided by its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT REFLECTS BEIJING'S REFUSAL TO RENOUNCE USE OF FORCE: MAC

TEXT.P: Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's latest policy report unmistakably reflects Beijing's unwillingness to renounce the option of using force against Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Saturday.

The MAC, the nation's top mainland China policy planning agency, made the comments in a press release issued after Wen said in his annual administrative report to the National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament -- earlier in the day that China will beef up its military strength to ensure eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to information published by the Beijing authorities, the MAC press statement said, China's defense budget for 2005 will increase 12.6 percent from the year-earlier level to reach US$30 billion. The amount does not include many other stealth defense funds.
The MAC statement pointed out that China's largely increased defense budget will mainly be used to expand its military deployment against Taiwan and upgrade its international influence.

"This trend will become even more concrete and conspicuous after its so-called anti-secession law is enacted," the MAC statement said, adding that such a development will have a grave adverse impact on regional security and stability.

While Wen claimed that the Chinese government will work "sincerely and energetically to bring about peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, " the MAC statement said, Beijing's proposed anti-secession law definitely runs against Wen's claimed goal.
Cross-strait relations and regional peace and stability will certainly be at stake if Beijing insists on going ahead with its anti-secession legislation, the MAC statement said.
Beijing's parliament is expected to screen and approve the so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan during its current plenary session.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTHING NEW IN CHINA'S REMARKS ABOUT TAIWAN: FORMER MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang lawmaker and former chief of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Su Chi said Saturday that the four points spelled out by Chinese President Hu Jintao the previous day are nothing but a reiteration of China's long-standing stick-and-carrot approach toward dealing with Taiwan.

In an interview with CNA, Su said Hu's statement is similar to one made by Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference March 3 in Beijing wherein it separates pro-independence Taiwanese from the rest of the population and treats them differently.

The main points of Hu's remarks are that his administration will stick to its "one China" policy, will not give up the aim of using peaceful means to "reunite" with Taiwan until the last and will never accept a Taiwan permanently independent from China.
Su said the anti-secession law contemplated by Beijing is intended to send a red light warning for Taiwan instead of keeping flashing a yellow light.
With the red light, Su said, Beijing wants to make its bottom line known to Taiwan rather than let some people on the island keep pushing the envelope without knowing what will be the last straw.

Of course Taiwan should speak out against Beijing's anti-secession law, but it should be careful not to spoil the more relaxed atmosphere with China following the charter flights during the Chinese New Year holidays, Su said, suggesting that President Chen Shui-bian refrain from commenting on Beijing's move and to let the MAC to do it instead.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Freed Hostage Wounded by U.S. Troops; Italian Agent Slain as Car Carrying Journalist Approaches Baghdad Checkpoint.
U.S. troops near Baghdad fired on a car Friday night carrying an
Italian journalist who had just been freed after a month in
captivity, wounding her and another passenger and killing an
Italian military intelligence officer, according to Italian and
U.S. officials, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, TSU TO COMPETE FOR ATTENTION IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union will compete for public attention in Sunday's protest against China in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, according to sources close to the two parties.
TSU Deputy Secretary-General Huang Chao-chang said TSU leaders will take part in the demonstration to arouse public opposition to China's hegemony, and hopefully to get the most publicity.
Meanwhile the DPP Kaohsiung branch office is mobilizing party members to participate in the demonstration wearing camouflage uniform to show their determination to fight against China.
The DPP even organized a fleet of heavy motorcycles and trucks decorated as tanks to show up at the demonstration.
The protesters will divide into two teams to march through the city along different routes before converging at the city's Cultural Center at 3 p.m. to hear a speech by former President Lee Teng-hui.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS STAGE SIT-IN TO PROTEST AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: A small group of university students staged a sit-in Saturday at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in Taipei to protest against Beijing's move to enact a so-called anti-secession law.

Before starting their sit-in, the students, numbering only around 10 and from schools including National Taiwan University, National Chengchi University and National Changhua University of Education, displayed a big white banner bearing Chinese characters reading "protest against China's enactment of the anti-secession law" and read out a protest statement.

The statement expressed opposition to communist China's move to enact an anti-secession law, and a petition for Beijing to respect Taiwan's right to freedom. It also declared that the future of the Republic of China should be decided by the people of the country and that no country can assault Taiwan's sovereignty and democratic values.
The statement urged local politicians to stop being aggressive toward others with different political ideas and asked them to seek unity in the face of China's attempts to annex Taiwan.
The joint statement also urged the parliaments and people of other countries around the world to condemn Beijing and to help maintain peace in the region.
After releasing the statement, two students with white headbands sat down to launch the 24-hour sit-in in relays. Every two hours, a two-strong team would take over the baton of the protest movement.
Kao Ming-lin, a National Taiwan University student in entomology who was acting as spokesman for the protesters, said they hope more students and members of the public will join in the protest.
The controversial law, which is expected to be screened and enacted in mid-March, provides a legal basis for China to use force against Taiwan should the island declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY URGED TO STICK TO ITS CROSS-STRAIT POLICY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should stick firm to its policy in terms of Taiwan's ties with China to avoid public confusion, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Su Chi said Saturday.
Su's comments came after Vice President Annette Lu said earlier in the day that the Taiwan authorities should apply a "two Chinas" policy to deal with the delicate situation across the Taiwan Strait.

As President Chen Shui-bian has recently said in public that he will not change Taiwan's official designation during his term in office, Lu suggested in an interview that the "two Chinas" concept -- a reference to the free Republic of China in Taiwan and the communist People's Republic of China in China -- be used to tackle relations between the two sides of the strait.
She also urged the main opposition KMT to echo her proposal.

Pointing out that the KMT is always supportive of the "one China, respective interpretations" principle and has never deviated from that idea, Su said that this is the key point that distinguishes the KMT from the pro-Taiwan independence DPP.
He urged Chen to respond with a clear explanation of Lu's remarks so as not to further confuse the Taiwan people.
Su once served as chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, Taiwan's top China policy planning agency, in the previous KMT-led government.

Meanwhile, KMT spokesman Chang Jong-kung said that Lu's "two Chinas" proposal is not helpful in easing cross-strait tension and he suggested that the DPP government refrain from confronting China and maintain an ambiguous position in Taiwan-China dealings.

Cross-strait relations have been sensitive in recent days prior to an anticipated enactment of an anti-secession law in the middle of this month by Beijing's National People's Congress -- a move widely believed to be designed to provide a legal basis for China to attack Taiwan should the country continue moving toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW TO MARK WATERSHED IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu predicted Saturday that the passage of an anti-secession law by China will mark a watershed in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
In an interview with a local media organization, Lu speculated that Beijing will shift to a proactive approach in dealing with relations with Taiwan after the enactment of the law.

Although China has not made public the content of the legislation, intelligence shows that Beijing will stick to the principles of "one China, " "peaceful unification," "one country, two systems" and "no toleration of Taiwan independence" in the law, according to Lu.
She said China has made the Taiwan question an international issue and is imposing its "one China" policy in the international community.

She also urged the public to take part in "anti-annexation" demonstrations organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Sunday in Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively, to express their objection to the anti-secession law.
However, Lu said she and President Chen Shui-bian will not participate in the activities, because it would not be appropriate for the head of state to make such an eye-catching move.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG PEOPLE TO ADVOCATE DEMOCRATIC SPIRIT

TEXT.P: A two-day training camp to foster democratic spirit among young people and train them to advocate democracy in modern society, the first of its kind in Taiwan, opened in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Saturday.

The event, organized by the National Youth Commission (NYC), was held at the Bureau of Human Resource Development for Civil Servants and Teachers under the Kaohsiung city government, with around 60 young people participating.
NYC Chairwoman Cheng Li-chun and Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai were on hand to deliver opening speeches.

The training camp can serve as a continuation of last year's National Youth Conference, Cheng said, adding that disagreements are normal in a democracy, while respecting individual differences is one of the true democratic principles.

Chen encouraged the participants to advocate the democratic essence in their communities after finishing the training so that the public can exercise their right to join in formulating public policies.

The commission intends to foster in the young participants the abilities to organize and facilitate public discussion forums on democracy and will select some of them to act as hosts of this year's National Youth Conference, Cheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INVESTORS TAKE SIDELINES PRIOR TO BEIJING ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Foreign investors have taken to the sidelines in the Taiwan Stock Exchange out of concern over possible negative impact on the domestic bourse of an anticipated anti-secession law by Beijing against Taiwan, market analysts said Saturday.

Foreign investors are reserved about buying Taiwan shares due to Beijing's move to enact the law, evidence in that market turnovers in recent days were markedly lower than usual, market watchers said.

The weighted index, the key gauge for the domestic stock market, finished 8.76 points lower Friday at 6,193.62 points on a market turnover of NT$81.29 billion (US$2.62 billion) . The market closed at 6,202.38 points Thursday on a market turnover of NT$78.43 billion, down by 22.87 points from Wednesday's finish.

Market analysts, however, were positive about the mid-term and long-term prospects for the domestic bourse if Beijing does not come up with provocative content in the anti-secession law, which is expected to be passed in the middle of this month.

The market will be provided with new leads should the law fail to clear Beijing's parliament or contain only lax rules, they contended, adding that the falls in the Taiwan Stock Exchange over the past few days only represent a temporary break amid a continued inflow of foreign capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE VICE PRESIDENT'S PERSONAL EFFECTS DONATED TO ACADEMIA HISTORICA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian accepted on behalf of the government Saturday a collection of the late Vice President Chen Cheng's personal effects and documents donated by his family.

Chen Li-an, Chen's son who once served as Control Yuan president, handed over the large collection of historical documents, photos and artifacts to President Chen in a ceremony held at Academia Historica.
The donation ceremony coincided with the 40th anniversary of the late vice president's death March 5, 1965.
It was the first batch of historical documents handed over to Academia Sinica since the presidential and vice presidential archives management statute was enacted in January 2004.
The collection includes more than 5,600 historical documents, more than 17,000 photos and more than 1,100 of the late vice president's personal effects.

Chen Cheng joined the military in China and took part in many important battles in the Republic of China's history, including the fight against warlords, the War of Resistance against Japan and the campaign against Mao Zedong's Chinese communist army.
After the Kuomintang-led government moved its seat to Taiwan from China, Chen Cheng contributed greatly to re-organizing the ROC troops and subsequent land reforms.
President Chen lauded Chen Cheng as one of the ROC's most outstanding military strategists and politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE URGED TO REVIEW COLLEGE PROGRAMS DUE TO RISING UNEMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: The head of the Council of Labor Affairs urged educational authorities Saturday to review college and university courses and adjust them to reflect social and industrial changes.
Chen Chu made the call while addressing the opening ceremony for a job exposition in Kaohsiung, in which 46 businesses looking for new blood were offering a total of more than 2,000 jobs.

Citing the latest official statistics, Chen said the unemployment rate was recorded at 4.06 percent in January, down 0.03 percent from the same month of previous year. However, the January jobless rate among new college and university graduates reached 3.68 percent, posing a 0.11 percent growth over the previous month and a 0.02 percent rise over the previous year, she noted.

To stop the rise, Chen said, her ministry is now working with the Ministry of Education on efforts to adjust lecture contents in college and university departments to reflect the changes in the industrial sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROGRESS EXPECTED IN KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ELECTION NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan is expected to issue a statement calling for changeover in the party leadership next week as the party finalizes a timetable for its chairmanship election set for May, officials said Saturday.
The KMT will pass a proposed schedule for the election during its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting next Wednesday.

According to the plan, the KMT will release an annoucement on the chairmanship election on March 21, pronounce the names of candidates and their serial numbers on April 28 and hold the vote on May 28.

Although Lien will not directly specify that he will "not continue in the chairmanship, " he will call for "generational transition" and encourage interested parties to take part in the election during the meeting, according to sources close to Lien.
Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who serves as a vice chairman of the KMT, has said that he will run for the chairmanship if Lien decides not to seek re-election.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, another KMT vice chairman, has also announced his bid for the chairmanship.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TIES WITH DIPLOMATIC ALLIES REMAIN STEADFAST: MOFA

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and its three Central American allies -- Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras -- have remained steadfast, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Saturday.

Lu was responding to media reports that Wang Zhen, deputy director of the international affairs office of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is heading a delegation on visits to the three ROC allies in an effort to lure them into switching diplomatic allegiance from Taipei to Beijing.

Lu said the ROC embassies in the three Central American countries have been closely monitoring the mainland delegation's activities. The governments of the three countries have assured the ROC embassies that their diplomatic relations with the ROC have remained unchanged and steadfast.

In the face of Beijing's constant diplomatic offensive against Taiwan, Lu said the government has spared no efforts to cement ties with the country's diplomatic allies. Lu said he hopes local people will not worry about the nation's diplomatic prospects.

Ko Chi-sheng, director of the MOFA's Central and South American Affairs Department, said the mainland delegation's visits to the three Central American will not affect Vice President Annette Lu's upcoming visit to the region.

With its economic strength growing in recent years, Ko said, China has often organized the so-called trade missions to visit the ROC's diplomatic allies and take advantage of such trips to lobby them to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. However, Ko said, mainland China's such efforts have so far not succeeded.

Vice President Lu is scheduled to leave Taipei March 12 at the head of a delegation of industry and business executives to visit Guatemala and El Salvador to survey investment opportunities and promote bilateral exchanges and cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO DELIVER MAJOR POLICY SPEECH AT ANTI-ANNEXATION RALLY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will deliver an important policy speech at an anti-annexation rally Sunday to clearly explain the government's stance on Beijing's proposed anti-secession legislation targeting Taiwan, political sources said Saturday.

The rally will be organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at Chengyuan Senior High School in Taipei to express Taiwan's opposition against China's soon-to-be-passed anti-secession law.

During the rally, DPP sources said, Hsieh will reiterate the government's strong opposition to China's legislative plan and will also for the first time offer a comprehensive report on the government's thinking, attitude and response measures toward the so-called anti-secession law.
In his speech, the sources said, Hsieh will remind local people to pay heed to China's concrete action instead of its lip service.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and representatives of major local pro-independence private groups will attend the rally.

DPP Chairman Su will also speak on the occasion with a softer tone than Hsieh's, urging Beijing leaders to respect Taiwan people's rights to determine their own future and let the two sides of the Taiwan Strait co-exist peacefully, the sources said.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, the DPP's traditional ally, will sponsor an "anti-annexation, protect Taiwan" march in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaoshiung Sunday to express Taiwan people's determination to pursue peace while opposing Beijing's attempt to annex the island.
Mainland China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- is scheduled to screen and approve the so-called anti-secession law at its ongoing plenary session.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN WORRYING ABOUT BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LEGISLATION: GIO CHIEF

TEXT.P: Japan is worrying about China's planned enactment of a so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin chia-lung said Saturday.
Lin made the remarks after his return from a five-day visit to Japan.
During his visit, Lin attended an international seminar on the new U.S.-Japan security agreement, Beijing's anti-secession legislation and regional security issues.
Lin said many of the Japanese politicians, scholars, experts and journalists he met during the visit had expressed serious concern about Beijing's anti-secession legislation.
