"They worry that such a law could destabilize the Taiwan Strait situation, " Lin said, adding that he hopes the Japanese government can dissuade Beijing from enacting such a detrimental law.

During the visit, Lin, who has announced his decision to quit his current post to seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the year-end mayoral election in the central city of Taichung, said he also met with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihar and mayors of two large Japanese cities -- Yokohama and Nagoya to learn from their experience in municipal administration.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou also concluded a visit to Japan and returned to Taipei Saturday.

Ma said he invited Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara and Yokohama Mayor Hiroshi Nakada to attend a "healthy city" forum to be held in Taipei late this year. Nakada has agreed to attend the forum while Ishihara has yet to make a final decision, Ma said.
Ma added that he has learned much from the just-concluded visit. "The experience will be conducive to boosting Taipei's urban development and municipal administration," he explained.

The Times: Internet music pirates made to pay up.
Computer users who have illegally downloaded music from the internet will discover this week whether they will face prosecution.
The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) revealed last night that it had made 23 people who downloaded files in breach of copyright laws pay 50,000 in compensation.
Financial Times: Sharp fall in foreign students.
British universities have seen a dramatic fall in the number of students from Asia enrolling on post-graduate courses.
A survey from Universities UK, the umbrella body for British higher education, shows a drop of up to 50 percent in students from China. Admissions departments say there has been a greater decline in recruiting to post-graduate research posts and courses than to undergraduate programmes.

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, March 6:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, March 6, or the 26th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that occurred on this date in the past:
1619: Savinien Cyrano de Bergerac, French novelist and playwright, is born. He is said to have fought over 1,000 duels to avenge unkind remarks about the size of his nose.
1836: After 12 days of artillery bombardment, 6,000 Mexican troops under Gen. Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna capture the Alamo and massacre the defenders, including famous Texan Davy Crockett.
1888: Louisa May Alcott, American novelist, feminist, abolitionist, temperance campaigner and author of "Little Women," dies hours after her father is buried. She was 56.
1899: Acetylsalicylic acid, better known as aspirin, a new pain relief drug, is patented by chemist Felix Hoffmann.
1900: Gottlieb Daimler, the German motor engineer, inventor of the motorcycle, and pioneer automobile manufacturer who produced the first high-speed internal-combustion engine, dies at the age of 66.
1911: Ronald Reagan, the 40th president of the United States, an actor-turned-politician whose administration was marked by economic recovery, military involvement in Grenada, Central America, Lebanon and Libya, and improved relations with the Soviet Union, is born.
1918: Precious forest cover on Alishan (Mt. Ali) in Taiwan's Chiayi County is razed by three days of fire.
1932: John Philip Sousa, American bandmaster and composer known as "the March King," dies at the age of 78. He wrote marches such as "Stars and Stripes Forever."
1941: Gutzon Borglum, an American sculptor noted for his monumental works, particularly the busts of four U.S. presidents carved into Mount Rushmore, South Dakota, dies at the age of 74.
1944: U.S. Air Force bombers start daylight bombing raids on Berlin from U.S. bases in Britain in an attempt to force Germany to surrender.
1957: Britain gives the Gold Coast its independence within the Commonwealth. British Togoland becomes part of the new West African nation, which is renamed Ghana.
1953: Georgy Malenkov becomes Soviet premier and first secretary of the Soviet Communist Party following the death of Joseph Stalin.
1959: The 36,000-ton Faith, the first tanker to be built in the Republic of China, is launched at Keelung.
1967: Joseph Stalin's daughter Svetlana Alliluyeva requests political asylum at the U.S. embassy in New Delhi.
1973: Pearl Sydenstricker Buck, an American writer whose life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, which included "The Good Earth," dies at the age of 81. She won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature.
1983: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his Christian Democrats regain power.
1987: The Herald of Free Enterprise, a British ferry which plied a route across the English Channel, capsizes in shallow water outside the Belgian port of Zeebrugge. More than 200 people drowned.
1988: Kurt Waldheim, Austrian president and former director-general of the United Nations, admits that he knew Allied commandos held by his unit during World War II would be executed contrary to the Geneva Convention.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui arrives in Singapore for a four-day visit.
1993: Shin Kanemaru, former vice president of the Liberal-Democratic Party, a conservative party which has held more seats in Japan's Diet than any other party has since 1955, is arrested for alleged tax evasion.
1995: The first world summit meeting on social development sponsored by the United Nations is held in Copenhagen, with government officials from 184 nations attending.
1995: A Coordination and Service Office for the Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center (also known as the APROC Window) is established at the ROC Council for Economic Planning and Development to ensure that the ROC's Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center plan is faithfully implemented.
1999: Ta Mok, the last Khmer Rouge leader still at large, is nabbed near northern Cambodia's border with Thailand.
2000: Japanese police crack down on one of the country's largest-ever amphetamine-smuggling rings, using information supplied by ROC police authorities.
2001: David Ho, a leading U.S. AIDS researcher, says in a speech in Taipei that he will begin human testing of an AIDS vaccine in mainland China later this year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A fleck on a stone may be ground away; a word misspoken will remain always."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY NOT PLANNING TO GO ABROAD: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: An official of the Presidential Office said Saturday that first lady Wu Shu-jen has no plans to visit any foreign countries.

Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office, said plans for the first lady's visits abroad have to take several factors into consideration, including the state of her health.

He made the remarks to dismiss media rumors that the wheelchair-bound first lady will visit Japan in May for the World Expo 2005 to be held in Aichi Prefecture March 25-Sept. 25 and receive an honorary doctorate.
Wu has visited Japan several times with her family and friends in the past few years and she said at the beginning of this year that she wishes to visit again.
The Japanese government has decided to grant Taiwan tourists 90-day visa-free entry to Japan between March 25 and Sept. 25 in an effort to boost tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ENGAGEMENT AS "CONTEST OF BRAVERY" DANGEROUS: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait Sunday to make reciprocal concessions in dealing with China's proposed anti-secession law, saying that engaging in a cross-Taiwan Strait "contest of bravery" in handling the matter is very dangerous.
The mayor made the remarks at a refugee house donation ceremony held at a campsite in suburban Taipei.
Ma said that China's preparations to enact the law will not only harm the cross-strait status quo but will also escalate tension in the strait.

A statement made by Chinese President Hu Jin-tao Friday, which came after President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong recently reached an agreement on various issues, including constitutional reform and future cross-strait relations, eased cross-strait tensions, Ma claimed, adding that even if Beijing insists on enacting the anti-secession law, it should not excessively irritate those who support Taiwan independence.
In the statement, Hu refereed to some positive factors in cross-strait relations and the Chen-Soong agreement is believed to be one of the positive factors.

Saying that the basic rule in maintaining peace between the two sides of the strait is that "China does not use force and Taiwan does not declare independence, " the mayor noted that if neither side can respect this rule, cross-strait relations will be jeopardized.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO FOLLOW CANADA IN PROMOTING DEMOCRACY IN AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, March 5 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Saturday that her party will follow Canada to help push for democracy in Africa and share Taiwan's democratic experience with other countries.

Chou Ching-yu, a member of the DPP's Standing Committee, made the comments while speaking at a workshop presided over by Raymonde Folco, vice president of Liberal International, held during the Biennial Convention of the Liberal Party of Canada.
Saying that the DPP has a permanent human rights representative at London-based Liberal International, Chou expressed the hope that the DPP can follow Canada in promoting democracy in Africa.
She also said that her party can learn a lot from the Liberal Party of Canada, which has had years of experience in governing the country.

A group of farsighted people formed the DPP 18 years ago when Taiwan was still under the rule of martial law, Chou said, adding that the island has gradually moved toward democratization and freedom after the lifting of martial law and introducing a direct presidential suffrage system. "We would like to share these experience with other countries, " she said.

Pointing out that China's hostility and Taiwan's lack of membership in the World Health Organization and the United Nations have done Taiwan a lot of harm, Chou said that the island needs everyone's support.

During the convention, Chou, accompanied by H.H. Hsieh, deputy director of the DPP's department of international affairs, also met with Canadian Defense Minister William Graham, Canadian Leader of the Government in the House of Commons Tony Valeri, Minister of Public Works Scott Brison and Don Boudria, chairman of the Canada-Taiwan Congressional Friendly Association, and exchanged views on various issues with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5.9-MAGNITUDE JOLTS WAKE TAIWAN, NO MAJOR DAMAGE REPORTED

TEXT.P: Two magnitude 5.9 earthquakes struck at around 3 a.m. Sunday in Ilan County, eastern Taiwan, waking people in eastern and northern Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

According to the CWB Seismology Center, the two 5.9-magnitude quakes rattled Ilan in two consecutive minutes beginning at 3:06 a.m., with the epicenter of both jolts located 6.4 km northeast of Ilan at a depth of 8.5 km beneath the surface of the sea, CWB seismologists said.
Because the quakes occurred in a relatively shallow area, it was felt in almost every area from eastern Taiwan to northern and central parts of the island.
More than 200 aftershocks, including several of magnitude 5.0, were recorded afterwards, the seismologists said.

As of noon Sunday, no major damage or injury had been reported, although walls in two hospitals in Ilan were reported to have cracked and rocks fell along some sections of the Central Cross-Island Highway, the weather bureau reported.
"We can expect to see aftershocks with a magnitude of around 5.0 on the Richter scale over the next two weeks or one month, " said Kuo Kai-wen, director of the CWB Seismology Center.

According to Kuo, as the geological structure around Ilan is uniquely complicated, earthquakes in those areas could be results of both squeezing and rupturing actions when the Pacific Plate and the Eurasian Plate collide, and when another deep-sea fault is broken.

The quakes had an intensity of 5.0 in Ilan City, 4.0 in the eastern county of Hualien and the northern county of Taipei, 3.0 in Taipei City, Taoyuan County, Keelung City and Hualien City, and 2.0 in Miaoli, Nantou, Changhua and Toulio in central Taiwan.

The administration of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- the prime mover of Taiwan's high-technology industries -- reported Sunday that the earthquakes, which had an intensity of 3.0 in Hsinchu, did not disrupt the power system and that no damage was caused at the science park.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAUP CALLS FOR PROTECTION OF TAIWAN'S STATUS IN WTO

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) called on the government Sunday to take concrete measures to prevent Taiwan's designation and status in the World Trade Organization (WTO) from being degraded.

TAUP Chairman Tai Pao-tsung told a news conference that the WTO Secretariat is planning to issue a new correspondence directory in mid-March and that Taiwan's designation and sovereignty implications will probably be changed by WTO Director-General Supachai Panitchapkdi in the directory.

Even the current embassy-equivalent status of Taiwan's mission in world trade regulatory body could also be degraded due to China's strong pressure on Supachai and the Taiwan government's inadequate response to the issue, Tai said.
Tai urged the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other related government agencies to study and adopt concrete countermeasures to protect the nation's rights and interests in the WTO.

"If Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen compromises with Supachai on his action to alter the designation of the country's mission to the WTO, Taiwan will be deprived of its status implying national sovereignty and the Democratic Progressive Party government will thus become a traitor," Tai claimed.

Speaking on the same occasion, Huang Chao-tang, chairman of the Taiwan Independence Union and a TAUP member, said that the government should make it clear to the world that Taiwan is an independent country with national sovereignty and do its utmost to safeguard the country's WTO interests and rights.
According to Taiwan's WTO admission terms, its representative office at the WTO is the "Permanent Mission of the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."

Claiming that the "Permanent Mission" has "sovereignty" implications, Beijing has asked the WTO Secretariat to change Taiwan's designation to the "Permanent Representative Office" in line with the formula adopted by Hong Kong and Macau.

In response to the TAUP's appeal, Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman Michel Lu reiterated that the Foreign Ministry has never asked Taiwan's WTO mission to waiver its formal diplomatic title granted by the Swiss government.
Despite Beijing's intention to degrade Taiwan's international position, Lu said, Taiwan's status in the WTO remains unchanged thanks to untiring efforts by the WTO mission.

According to Lu, the Beijing authorities pushed for the WTO Secretariat to downgrade Taiwan to the level of a local government by changing the designation of its mission last year when the secretariat reprint the roster of WTO permanent member states.
The WTO is one of the few international organizations that admit both Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TERMS ANTI-SECESSION LAW AS ACT OF AGGRESSION

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui blasted China Sunday for its plan to enact a so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, saying that such legislation is tantamount to an act of aggression.

Lee, who is the so-called "spiritual leader" of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , made the remarks while addressing a joint graduation ceremony for three groups of students who had completed their studies at the Lee Teng-hui School.

The Beijing authorities are seeking to annex Taiwan by enacting an anti-secession law that will probably provide China with a legal basis to use force against the island, Lee pointed out, adding that the people of Taiwan should join hands to block such a barbaric act of aggression.
Lee urged the public to voice their strong protest against China's proposed law to draw the international community's attention to the growing military threat the island is facing.

The outspoken former president said that building a Taiwanese identity and making the island a normal country are common goals of all the people of Taiwan, while changing the country's official name and writing a new constitution are the most important missions to be achieved at the current stage.

Some people who are concerned over the future of Taiwan are disappointed with the results of the Dec. 11 legislative elections, during which the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the TSU failed to win a majority in the new legislature, Lee said, adding that it is inevitable to face difficulties while pursuing a far-reaching goal.

Claiming that the "pan-green camp's" setback in the legislative elections shows that education on Taiwanese identity should be further intensified, Lee disclosed that his school is planning to organize a series of alumni forums aimed at integrating efforts of local civic groups and TSU parliamentarians to help build a strong Taiwanese identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUSHING FOR FTA WITH MALAYSIA: MNNA
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, March 6 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (Taiwan) is pushing for a free trade agreement (FTA) with Malaysia in an attempt to further prop up substantive ties between the two countries, Taiwan's representative to Malaysia was quoted by the Malaysian National News Agency (MNNA) as saying Sunday.

Wu Wen-ya, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia, was quoted by MNNA as saying that two-way trade between Taiwan and Malaysia totaled US$6.5 billion in 2004, marking an increase of 22 percent over the year-earlier level.
Taiwanese investments in Malaysia over the years have exceeded US$9.5 billion, making Taiwan the third-largest source of foreign capital, second only to the United States and Japan, Wu told the MNNA.

In addition, Wu said, the number of Malaysian students seeking to pursue advanced studies in Taiwan has reached 36,000, making the Malaysians the largest foreign student group in Taiwan. Currently, about 3,000 Taiwan students are studying in Malaysia and about 1,200 Malaysians seek to go to Taiwan to study every year.

Meanwhile, Chou Mei-fen, a Malaysian vice minister of women, family and community development who studied in Taiwan, said she will push for closer cooperation between the ministry and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in efforts to allow the Malaysian government to recognize the academic degrees conferred to Malaysian students by institutes from Taiwan.

According to Chou, following the Malaysian government's recognition of degrees from six Taiwan medical schools for Malaysian graduates, the Malaysian Ministry of Health announced recently that Malaysian graduates from the Department of Pharmaceutics in three Taiwan universities can become pharmacists in Malaysia immediately after they return to Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS, CITIZENS RALLY TO OPPOSE BEIJING'S LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: A large number of people, including officials and supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) got together Sunday at a rally in Taipei to say "no" to Beijing's imminent passage of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Premier Frank Hsieh, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, among other officials, delivered speeches at the rally to express opposition to Beijing's attempts to annex Taiwan under the pretext of a Chinese law.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said in his speech that Beijing will soon pass the anti-secession law, which he described as a law that violates the principles of the international law and infringes on the sovereignty of Taiwan.
As the ruling party in Taiwan, the DPP must make its stance clearly known to Beijing and win support from around the world on this concern, Lee said.
He added that although the anti-secession law is a domestic law of China, Beijing is poised to use it to deal with Taiwan, allowing it to use force against Taiwan, another country.

Lee urged the opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party to forgo the so-called "92 consensus" that runs counter to mainstream public opinion in Taiwan and to instead throw their support behind the DPP to jointly say "no" to China.

Other prominent figures that took part in the rally included Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, DPP legislative party whip Lai Ching-teh, DPP Legislator-at-large Tsai Ying-wen and Wu Li-pei, a senior presidential adviser.
A similar street rally was held in the southern port city of Kaoshiung that same day, in which some 50,000 people took to the streets to vent their anger with China's anti-secession legislation.

The rally, titled "Against Beijing's annexation of Taiwan, " was sponsored by the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP. It was led by former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader."

DOC.HEADLINE: UNCERTAIN IF BEIJING WILL USE ANTI-SECESSION LAW AGAINST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, March 5 (CNA) (By C. Chiang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Ambassador to China James Lilley said Saturday that even if China enacts an anti-secession law, it is uncertain that Beijing will take any action against Taiwan in accordance with the law, as "law is what you say, policy is what you do."

Lilley also served as former director of the American Institute on Taiwan's Taipei Office, which has dealt with unofficial relations between Taipei and Washington since Washington shifted its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

Speaking at the annual meeting of the Taiwan-U.S. Science and Technology Industry Association, Lilley noted that China passed a bill in 1992 to include Taiwan and Tiaoyutai in its territory. "But its a law, not policy, " he said, adding that China's current enactment of an anti-secession law is similar to that of the earlier law.

The anti-secession law itself is not a cross-Taiwan Strait problem and only the escalation of tension by both sides of the strait will cause problems, he further said, adding that he neither sees tension in the Taiwan Strait nor any provocation from Taiwan to challenge China. Lilley also said he believes Taipei and Beijing can resolve their differences peacefully.
However, he said the United States does not want to hear the Taiwan government remark that "if China attacks Taiwan, the United States will protect the island."

According to Lilley, Taiwan's economic achievements and democratic development can counter China's attacks, but the island should also take responsibility for its own defense, including the procurement of weapons from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS ON APPLICATIONS FOR INDONESIAN WORKERS LIFTED

TEXT.P: Restrictions over applications for the employment of Indonesian workers will be lifted, effective immediately, an official of the Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training (BEVT) under the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Sunday.

According to the official, the resolution to lift restrictions was adopted at the First Taiwan-Indonesia Labor Committee Meeting jointly presided over by BEVT Director-General Kuo Fang-yu and Gusti Made Arka, director-general of the Overseas Labor Placement Bureau under the Indonesian Manpower and Transmigration Ministry.

Under the resolution, the CLA will begin to accept and handle all applications for employment of Indonesian workers, while controversial cases, if any, will be investigated with the BEVT's help in order to shorten the investigation time and expedite the handling procedure, the official said.

In addition, the official went on, both parties also agreed to set up a channel for "direct employment" to reduce Indonesian laborers' financial burden to unscrupulous labor brokers and enhance workers' physical checkup quality control.
Taiwan lifted a freeze on imports of workers from Indonesia late last year, ending a two-year-and-four-month hiatus, but many restrictions over applications were still imposed.

The CLA imposed an across-the-board ban on the import of Indonesian workers Aug. 1, 2002 in retaliation for Indonesia's failure to cooperate with Taiwan in fixing the high absconding rate of Indonesian workers in Taiwan, as well as unreasonable brokerage fees charged by Indonesian brokers.
Currently, there are about 24,000 Indonesian workers in Taiwan, ranking fourth in terms of the number of foreign laborers working on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGED RETIRED SERVICEMAN RETURNING TO TAIWAN WITH RED CROSS HELP

TEXT.P: An octogenarian retired serviceman from Taiwan, who fell seriously ill after suffering a leg injury while visiting China, was escorted Sunday by representatives of the Red Cross Societies on either side of the Taiwan Strait from Xiamen, Fujian Province, to Kinmen.

The 85-year-old Huang Chao-cheng, who suffers from heart disease and high blood pressure and cannot sit or stand, was transported to Kinmen after personnel from the Kinmen Red Cross Society traveled to Xiamen Saturday to escort him. He was taken by ambulance from his hometown in Hunan Province to Xiamen -- a 16-hour journey -- the day before.
With the assistance of the Xiamen Red Cross Society, personnel from the Kinmen Red Cross Society escorted Huang, who was accompanied by his son, Huang Yu-shen, to Kinmen via ferry.
Huang was admitted to a Kinmen hospital and will take the first flight Monday morning back to Taiwan for medical treatment, according to a Kinmen Red Cross Society official.

Huang's journey from Hunan to Taiwan via Kinmen will mark another humanitarian aid case across the Taiwan Strait made possible with the concerted efforts of the Red Cross Societies on either side of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE RUNNERS WIN TOP SPOTS IN TAIPEI ULTRAMARATHON

TEXT.P: Ryoichi Sekaya and Naomii Fujita of Japan won the men's and women's events, respectively, of the 2005 Soochow University 24-Hour International Ultramarathon, which ended Sunday.

Sekaya, the holder of the Asian record and the world's third-best, defeated his rivals to win first place by finishing 660 laps of the Soochow track, or 264.41 km, in 24 hours. It is the second time he has won the title since 2002.
Fujita, 43, won the top spot in the women's division by completing 223.76 km in the endurance contest.
The two winners each won NT$70,000 (US$2,260), according to the organizers.

Local runner Chen Chin-tsai finished with 222.81 km, ranking sixth in the men's division, while Chiu Shu-jung, who was taking part for the first time, ranked fourth in the women's division with 195.7 km.
This is the sixth year that Soochow University has sponsored the event, which attracts top-notch marathon runners from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN CYCLIST WINS TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL ELIMINATION ROAD RACE

TEXT.P: Jurgen Kotulla, a cyclist from Germany, won the Taipei International Elimination Road Race 2005 held Sunday.

A total of 35 athletes from 14 countries took part in the event, which took place on a circuit of about 1.6 km around the Taipei World Trade Center, coinciding with the 2005 Taipei International Cycle Show.
Kotulla won NT$100,000 (US$3,175) in cash, according to the Chinese Taipei Cycling Association, organizers of the event.
Local cyclist Wu Po-hung came sixth, a record for the host country.

DOC.HEADLINE: T-COMMERCE A NEW CASH COW IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Television commerce, better known as T-commerce, is a new cash cow industry poised to change Taiwan's consumer purchase habits as well as create a new marketing system for traders.

Addressing a symposium on integration of service industries and the inspiration of T-commerce, Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung said that T-commerce generated business worth over NT$30 billion (approximately US$1 billion) in Taiwan last year, an amount exceeding the total yielded by all cable TV channels in Taiwan the same year.
Lin said that T-commerce operators are optimistic that similar business will shoot up to the tune of NT$100 billion in three or five years.

The GIO head, who is the top official in charge of Taiwan's television, broadcasting and related affairs, said that although this new business area deserves support and encouragement, it also needs proper control to prevent it from eventual failure as a result of fighting and competition.

Also addressing the symposium, Gary Wang, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, which is co-sponsoring the symposium, said that "shopless" retail sales such as T-commerce generated a total of NT$61.9 billion in business transactions in Taiwan last year, up 12 percent over that posted in 2002.

Although T-commerce is still relatively a new business in Taiwan, Wang said, its business turnover has grown by leaps and bounds in the last two years to constitute 2.1 percent of the business turnover posted by the entire retail business sector in Taiwan in 2004.

Noting that Taiwan's T-commerce has been growing at a pace faster than that in the United States and Japan, Wang suggested that the government include the T-commerce industry into the "Digital Taiwan Project" that is already underway.
Wang is the CEO of the Eastern T-Commerce Channel, one of the major T-commerce operators in Taiwan, and an affiliate of the Eastern Multimedia Group.
Meanwhile, Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank, another co-sponsor of the symposium, said T-commerce is regarded as a cash-making machine, with profits snowballing.

T-commerce, which has "the disparities of small-amount sales" as a unique characteristic, offers a new niche for small- and medium-sized enterprises in Taiwan seeking business breakthroughs, Chen noted.
He warned, however, that the government should oversee the development of T-commerce properly so as to prevent it from becoming a cartel of business circulation and distribution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL NEVER PROVOKE CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Sunday that Taiwan will "never provoke China" and that China's leaders should be held responsible for any tension in the Taiwan Strait.

Addressing a rally organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in Taipei to express its opposition to Beijing's imminent passage of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Hsieh said that Taiwan should continue to make efforts to show the international community that Taiwan is a peace-loving nation.
The National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, is scheduled to screen the proposed law March 8.

Taiwan is an independent sovereign nation with the official designation of the Republic of China, the premier noted, adding that any change to the country's status quo must be subject to the consent of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Although Beijing is trying to make the so-called Taiwan issue a domestic affair, Taiwan has achieved a great breakthrough in internationalizing the matter in light of a recent joint statement from the U.S.-Japan Security Consultative Committee that lists the peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue as one of their common strategic objectives.

He criticized Beijing's proposed anti-secession law for trying to unilaterally change the status quo of the Taiwan Strait and for trying to purport that the issue is an internal rather than an international affair.
A large number of people, including government officials and DPP supporters got together at the rally to say "no" to Beijing's attempts to annex Taiwan under the pretext of the proposed law.

Other prominent figures that took part in the rally included Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang, DPP legislative party whip Lai Ching-teh, DPP Legislator-at-large Tsai Ying-wen and Wu Li-pei, a senior presidential adviser.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PROMOTE LEGISLATION AGAINST BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will present a draft anti-annexation of Taiwan bill at the Legislative Yuan in retaliation for Beijing's proposed anti-secession law, TSU legislative whip Lo Chih-ming said Sunday.

Given that the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, is scheduled to screen the proposed law, which is believed to target Taiwan, Lo said that his party has elaborated a five-article draft bill on the anti-annexation of Taiwan.

The draft bill clearly defines the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as two separate sovereign nations and that the territories under Taiwan's effective jurisdiction include Taiwan proper, Penghu, Kinmen, Matsu, the Dongsha (Pratas) Islands, the Nansha (Spratly) Islands, Green Island and Orchid Island, Lo revealed.

The draft bill also stipulates that any changes to Taiwan's status quo and other matters related to the country's sovereignty and future must be subject to the consent of the people of Taiwan demonstrated through peaceful means.

Taiwan will never accept any decision on its future that is made through non-peaceful means, including economic sanctions, embargo, unilateral legislation or intervention in Taiwan's internal affairs, it adds.

Both the president and parliament would be authorized to initiate a referendum on measures to be taken by the government should the country face the threat of annexation, invasion or intimidation, it says.

The president should inform the parliament immediately if he decides to take measures against any kind of threat, including suspending all exchanges and communications with China, according to the TSU draft bill.
The content of the draft bill will be increased in tune with the final outcome of Beijing's anti-secession law, Lo said.

Meanwhile, Legislator Ker Chien-ming, chief of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Policy Coordination Committee, said the DPP will adopt a wait-and-see attitude toward Beijing's legislation, as the Legislative Yuan has already issued an official statement to express its opposition to the proposed anti-secession law.
The DPP is the largest party in the 225-member Legislative Yuan with 89 seats, while the TSU controls just 12 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI DEFEATS JAPAN IN DAVIS CUP

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei came from behind to defeat Japan 3: 2 after winning the last two singles matches Sunday in the first round of the Davis Cup 2005 Asia/Oceania Zone Group I held in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.
Chinese Taipei tennis player Lu Yen-hsun beat his Japanese rival, Takao Suzuki 5-7, 6-4, 6-3 and 7-6 (1) , while his teammate Wang Yeu-tzuoo overpowered Guoichi Motomura 7-6(4), 7-5, 4-6 and 7-6(2).
Japan took a leading position of 2: 1 after finishing the first two singles matches and the doubles match in the first two days of tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, March 7, or the 27th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1573: War between Turkey and Venice ends with the Treaty of Constantinople.
1850: Tomas Garrigue Masaryk, the Czechoslovakian politician who served as the first president of independent Czechoslovakia, is born.
1876: Scottish-born American inventor Alexander Graham Bell receives a patent for his invention of the electric voice telegraph, or telephone. Bell also invented the audiometer, an early hearing aid, and improved the phonograph.
1918: The Bolsheviks change their name to the Russian Communist Party.
1932: French Prime Minister Aristide Briand dies at the age of 70. He drew up the Kellogg-Briand Pact and shared the 1926 Nobel Peace Prize as well as pioneered the idea of a United States of Europe.
1936: In contempt of the Versailles Treaty imposed after World War I, German Chancellor Adolf Hitler marches his troops into the demilitarized zone east of the Rhine.
1942: Japanese forces land on New Guinea while other Japanese troops begin to enter the Burmese capital of Rangoon after the British evacuation from the city.
1945: Chinese expeditionary forces recapture Lashio in northern Burma.
1945: Britain's 14th Army enters Mandalay in Burma.
1950: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Cheng as premier.
1951: Iran's Premier Ali Razmara is assassinated by a religious fanatic in a mosque in Tehran.
1957: The Gaza Strip, which was administered by Egypt under the cease-fire agreements following the Arab-Israeli war of 1948, comes under U.N. rule.
1971: Swiss men vote to give women the right to vote and hold federal office.
1973: Forty-two agriculturists from 12 African countries attend the opening of the 14th Agricultural Seminar for African Technicians.
1974: ROC Vice President C.K. Yen leaves for Latin America to attend the inaugurations of President Ernesto Geisel of Brazil and President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela.
1974: The 3rd Pacific Area Travel Association Regional Conference opens in Taipei with more than 20 delegates attending from Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and the ROC.
1974: A Sino-Saudi Arabian trade cooperation agreement is signed in Taipei by Wu Kwan-hsiung, secretary-general of the China External Trade Development Council, and Sand M. Al-Joajil, president of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of the Eastern Provinces of Saudi Arabia.
1978: President Ne Win of Burma is re-elected for a second term.
1989: Communist China declares martial law in Lhasa following three days of rioting in which hundreds of Tibetans were reportedly gunned down by Communist Chinese security forces.
1989: A convicted murderer in South Carolina who successfully appealed against being sent to the electric chair is electrocuted accidentally while sitting on the toilet mending a pair of earphones.
1990: The KMT Central Standing Committee passes a draft revision of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion.
1992: Nicaraguan President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and ROC President Lee Teng-hui sign a join communique in Taipei for stronger bilateral relations.
1996: Three U.S. servicemen are convicted in Japan and sentenced to six-and-a-half to seven years in prison for the abduction and rape of a 12-year-old Okinawa schoolgirl in 1995.
2000: ROC Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen and Palauan State Minister Sabino Anastacio sign a joint statement with the aim of boosting bilateral cooperation in a wide range of areas.
2001: Taiwan's religious community joins in the worldwide chorus of condemnation of the decision by the Taliban, Afghanistan's hardline Islamic regime, to destroy ancient Buddhist statutes in Afghanistan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "An honest man does not want, neither does he profess, esotericism. Men now are earnest in what they profess. Are they really good and wise men? Or are they serious only in appearance? That is what I should like to know."
