DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH IN ELECTION-EVE SHOOTING INVESTIGATIONS: CIB HEAD

TEXT.P: Police reported on Monday progress in the investigations into the mysterious election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, saying that two men who have since died in separate suspected suicides were probably connected with the shooting.

President Chen and Vice President Lu were slightly wounded on March 19, 2004 when two bullets grazed their bodies as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan, a day ahead of the presidential election.

One suspect, identified as Chen Yi-hsiung, was found drowned in Anping in Tainan City on March 28 last year, while another, identified by his family name of Huang, was found dead at his home of a suspected self-inflicted gunshot wound May 26, 2004.

Ho You-yi, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (cib) under the National Police Administration who concurrently serves as deputy convener of the 319 shooting investigative team, was holding a news conference late Monday morning explaining details of progress in the investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL VOICES OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 6 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan official in Chicago urged China Sunday to take Taiwan's positive efforts to maintain cross-Taiwan Strait peace seriously prior to enacting an "anti-secession law" which is expected to upset regional stability.
Ben Shao, director of the Information Division at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago, made the call in a letter to the editor entitled "Disturbing the Peace" in the Chicago Sun-Times.
Shao said China's plan to pass the law is worthy of the world's serious concern.

"Beijing wishes, by making such a law, to unilaterally define and then change the status quo of the Taiwan Strait. When and if matters run out of control, the outcome would require a response from the United States," Shao warned.

Shao expressed his approval of the U.S. government's opposition to the European Union's plan to lift its arms embargo against China, which he said has increased its number of deployed missiles targeting Taiwan to more than 700.

In contrast to the bellicosity of China, Taiwan is a positive player in East Asia which has a pluralistic society with a vibrant democracy and robust economy and which readily gives back the fruits of its success to the international community, Shao said.
He pointed out that maintaining cross-strait peace and security is the desire of the people of the Taiwan and the wish of the international community.
While making a trip to Taipei last week, former U.S. President Bill Clinton called on China and Taiwan to set aside their differences because "our common humanity matters more," Shao noted.
"For Beijing to continue to distort Taiwan's democratization and reject President Chen Shui-bian's repeated offering of the olive branch will lead China nowhere," Shao said.
"For its own good, China should heed the voices of the global village," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IN DALLAS VOICE OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, March 6 (CNA) (By H.Y. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates residing in Dallas held a peaceful demonstration Sunday to voice their opposition to China's proposed anti-secession law and to urge the United States to adopt active measures to oppose the law.

The demonstration was jointly organized by a local Taiwanese expatriate association and other Taiwanese-American organizations in Dallas in front of the monument to former U.S. President John F. Kennedy.

A leading member of the association said that China will officially pass its proposed anti-secession bill into law in the coming few days in order to create a legal excuse to use force against Taiwan.

The Taiwan people should loudly voice their desire before the Chinese National People's Congress votes on the bill, he said, adding that the 23 million people of Taiwan should decide their own future.

An advisor to the association also said that the anti-secession law is in preparation to swallow Taiwan up and that all the freedom and democracy-loving people of the world should stand up to jointly oppose such a law.

Concerned that Taiwanese tourists and businesspeople in China could be arrested if their words violate the anti-secession law, the advisor said that protesting against the law will not only protect Taiwan's security, but will also protect the security of those Taiwanese on the mainland.

Wu Ming-kee, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, a pro-Taiwan organization in the United States, stressed during the demonstration that as U.S. President George W. Bush had said in his inauguration speech that he would stand by free nations forever, Washington should clearly express its opposition to the anti-secession law.

Besides the demonstration held in Dallas, rallies organized by other Chinese-American organizations in the United States have also been held in cities around the country, including Houston, Chicago and Washington, D.C., over the past few days.
The organizations have urged the U.S. Congress to ask the Bush administration to press Beijing not to enact the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOLOGICAL SON OF LATE ROC PRESIDENT TO BEGIN USING SURNAME CHIANG

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Legislator John Chang, an illegitimate son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, confirmed Monday that he will officially begin using the surname Chiang from today to "reflect the truth."
Chang confirmed that the process of officially changing his name to Chiang has been completed. He applied for the name change with the Ministry of the Interior in May 2002.
From Monday, Chang said, he will formally begin going by the name John Chiang, which appears on his new identification card.
"My three adult children support my decision, and they will also follow suit by changing their surname soon, " Chiang said.

Speaking to reporters at the Legislative Yuan, Chiang -- who along with his twin brother Winston Chang were born in Gueilin in the southwestern mainland province of Guangxi in 1941 to parents Chiang Ching-kuo and Chang Ya-juo out of wedlock -- said his name-change is basically a family affair.

"I made the decision after extensive discussions with members of my immediate family and relatives. The change represents a respect for history, a return to the facts, and a realization of my parents' wishes," Chiang said.
Chiang, a former minister of foreign affairs and KMT secretary-general, said that it is no longer a secret that Chiang Ching-kuo is his birth father.
"Not only are the people of Taiwan well aware of this fact, but also a large number of mainland Chinese residents know about it, " he said.
Chiang added that he and his family will travel to the mainland in April to sweep the tombs of the Chiang ancestors.

Chiang and his twin brother, who died of a stroke in Taipei several years ago, were raised by their maternal grandmother after their mother died when they were still infants. Until now, Chiang's ID card had listed his uncle Chang Hau-juo and aunt Chi Chen as his parents.
Chiang, the only surviving son of the late president, is now serving his second term as an opposition KMT lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S VISA WAIVER INAPPLICABLE TO TOP 5 ROC OFFICIALS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top five officials are still required to apply for a visa if they decide to visit Japan during the 2005 World Exposition in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Monday.

According to the minister, Japan's visa exemption privilege for Republic of China citizens during the Aichi world exposition, also known as Aichi Expo, does not apply to the nation's top five officials -- President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i and Tan Sun Chen himself.
Chen made the remarks while presiding over the opening of a diplomatic affairs training camp for volunteer workers in the Nanyuan Ranch in the southern county of Tainan.
As part of its efforts to attract more tourists to the Aichi Expo, the Japanese government has decided to waive visa requirements for ROC passport holders from March 11 through Sept.25.

However, Chen said the Japanese government has imposed certain restrictions, including that the above-mentioned five officials still have to apply for a visa if they want to visit Japan during that period.

For fear of offending China, Japan has traditionally been reluctant to issue visas to senior ROC leaders. The eco-friendly Aichi Expo is scheduled to open March 25 and last through Sept. 25. To attract more foreign visitors, Japan has decided to offer visa-free entry to South Korean and Taiwan tourists between March and September. South Korea is Japan's largest source of foreign tourists, followed by Taiwan.

As Japan does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the Japanese Diet passed special regulations Feb. 16 to allow Taiwan citizens to enter Japan without a visa for a maximum 90-day stay between March 11 and Sept. 25.

Speaking at the diplomatic affairs training camp, Minister Chen said China's diplomatic suppression against Taiwan has not eased since the meeting between President Chen and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.
"The Taiwan people generally feel that the domestic political divisions between the ruling and opposition camps have been tempered following the Feb. 24 Chen-Soong meeting," the minister said.

"Nevertheless, our diplomatic situation remains difficult. Despite the smooth operations of the unprecedented two-way, non-stop charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, China has not slowed its diplomatic offensive against Taiwan in the international arena.China will not hesitate to suppress Taiwan diplomatically simply because of the Chen-Soong meeting, " he added.
Stressing that diplomacy is a symbol of national sovereignty, Chen said the Taiwan people should use every possible means to support and assist in the government's diplomatic work.
With China's rise as a economic powerhouse, Chen said, Beijing has been using its new economic clout to step up its diplomatic squeeze against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Fresh China move to rebuild ties with S'pore.
In another sign of improving relations between China and Singapore, Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing said yesterday that Beijing was ready to further its friendship and cooperation.
The Lianhe Zaobao:The anti-Malaysia mood surged high in the Indonesian.
A dispute between Malaysia and Indonesia over an oil-rich region in the Sulawesi Sea escalated yesterday.
The anti-Malaysia mood surged high in the Indonesian because Malaysia declared Malaysia owns the oil field Ambalat.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WON'T SHOW TAIWAN MERCY: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Tan-sun said Monday in Tainan County that the easing of the crisis between Taiwan and China since the "Chen-Soong meeting" is only a "false, short-term phenomenon, " claiming that China will not show mercy in its efforts to suppress Taiwan.
The minister made the comments while presiding over a ceremony to mark the opening of a diplomatic research camp in the county.

Pointing out that most of the Taiwan people feel the domestic political atmosphere has improved since President Chen Shui-bian met with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Feb. 24, the minister, however, said that the island still faces difficulties and challenges in developing its relations with other countries due to China's continued diplomatic offensive to isolate the country internationally.
Chen and Soong reached an agreement during their meeting on various issues relating to constitutional reform, cross-strait relations and other matters.

Saying that China's economy has vastly improved in recent years and that Taiwanese businesspeople have played a significant role in this development, the minister reminded the Taiwan people not to be misled by China as Beijing will "not show mercy to Taiwan" just because of the holding of a"Chen-Soong meeting."

The Taiwan people should intuitively perceive the difficulties faced by the government in promoting foreign relations and should support the government, he further said, adding that this will become the new thought of Taiwan's future diplomatic work.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Often-Crossed Line in the Sand.
Unprecedented investment in technology and staff has not deterred illegal immigration from Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:
Shakeup at Sony Puts Westerner in Leader's Role
In a rare move for a Japanese company, Sony has named Sir Howard Stringer, a Welshman, its chairman and chief executive.
Wall Street Journal:
Sony, Lagging Behind Rivals, Hands Reins to a Foreigner
In the biggest management upheaval in Sony Corp. 's 59-year history, Chairman and Chief Executive Nobuyuki Idei resigned after a series of stumbles and handed the reins to Welsh-born American Howard Stringer, a former television executive who heads Sony's U.S. operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S., France hit Assad vow of withdrawal as insufficient
The United States and France on Saturday repeated their insistence on a complete Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon, with Washington saying a speech by Syria's President fell short of meeting the demands set by the U.N. Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained 33 points to close at 6,231, with 22,438 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved up 30 points to finish at 6,230, with 612 contracts traded, while June futures gained 35 points to finish at 6,225, with 51 contracts traded.
September futures gained 38 points to finish at 6,148, with 67 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 48 points to close at 6,162, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,198 for March, 6,200 for April, 6,190 for June, 6,110 for September and 6,114 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

March TE futures moved up 0.85 points to close at 234.35, with 2,473 contracts traded, while April TE futures gained 0.55 points to finish at 234.25, with 82 contract transactions. September TE futures gained 1.95 points to close at 234.15, with one contract traded, while December TE futures moved down 3.95 points to finish at 228.05, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June.

March TF futures gained 5.4 points to finish at 1,024, with 3,517 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved up 3.8 points to end at 1,023.2, with 153 contracts traded. June TF futures gained 0.4 points to finish at 1,018, with one contract changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 26.9 points to close at 6,220.52.
The bourse opened at 6,224.44 and fluctuated between 6,257.54 and 6,220.52 during trading. A total of 3.74 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$86.6 billion (US$2.8 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, textile stocks at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 545 to 323, with 136 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.071 to close at NT$30.879.
A total of US$799 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.950 and hit a low of NT$30.780.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATIONS INTO PRESIDENTIAL SHOOTING SHOULD CONTINUE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh recognized Monday the efforts of law enforcement agencies in achieving what they described as a "major breakthrough" in the investigations into the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu last March and said that similar efforts should continue until the truth is uncovered.

The State Public Prosecutor-General's Office under the Supreme Court announced Monday that the police had achieved a major breakthrough in the investigations, naming Chen Yi-hsiung, a resident of the southern city of Tainan, as the major suspect in the shooting, in which two bullets grazed Chen and Lu as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in Tainan City one day ahead of the March 20 presidential election.

The police reported that Chen Yi-hsiung, who was found drowned in a canal in Anping, Tainan City, on March 28 last year, is so far the most likely suspect, based on videotapes of the scene, related evidence and witness accounts.
Hsieh issued the directive that investigations should continue to find if Chen had any accomplices or whether he was manipulated by a crime ring.
Hsieh lauded the law enforcement authorities' endless efforts over nearly a year and claimed that the newly achieved breakthrough will contribute to stabilizing social and political conditions.

The premier added that if necessary, the government should invite Henry Lee, a renowned Chinese-American forensic scientist who led an expert team to Taiwan to conduct forensic investigations into the shooting last April, to make another visit to Taiwan to further deepen the investigations.

Meanwhile, Hou You-yi, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the National Police Administration, who concurrently serves as deputy convener of the 319 shooting investigative team, said during a news conference designed to explain details of the progress of the investigations that now that Chen Yi-hsiung is believed to be the most likely suspect, the police will continue other efforts to crack the case, including the whereabouts of the gun used in the attack.

The investigators will continue to track a man in a grey jacket as well as four other men and one woman that appeared in the "hot zone" of the videotapes showing the scene on the street where the shooting occurred, Hou said.

Hou added that although Chen Yi-hsiung's family claim to have no idea about the gun Chen allegedly used, they said they would help the police find the weapon by offering several possible places that Chen might have hidden it.

Hou said during the press conference that the 319 shooting investigative team has concluded that Chen Yi-hsiung was most likely the shooter based on three major accounts: that he appeared in all three videotapes taken by a jewelry shop near the scene, that he apparently changed his style of attire after March 19, 2004 and according to his wife, his temperament changed drastically after that day, and that his family claim to have met secretly March 30, after Chen had died, to decide to keep silent about Chen. They also burned three copies of a will that they alleged Chen left.

President Chen beat his sole challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, in the presidential election by a slim margin. Lien filed two lawsuits in an attempt to nullify Chen's re-election victory. The Taiwan High Court rejected the re-election annulment suit, but Lien appealed the case to the Supreme Court.
Many opposition politicians and supporters have disseminated outrageous speculation about the shooting, including allegations that it was staged by Chen to sway sympathy votes in his favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE IDENTIFIES SUSPECT IN PRESIDENT'S SHOOTING

TEXT.P: A man who died in a suspected suicide a year ago has been identified as a suspect in last year's election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, police said Monday.

Police traced Chen Yi-hsiung three months after they found the maker of the two home-made bullets used in the shooting of March 19, 2004, according to Hou Yu-ih, commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau and a key member of a special task force probing the shooting.

According to police, Chen had obtained a remodeled gun and bullets from a criminal ring led by Tang Shou-yi and that his image also appears in three videotapes taken near the crime scene at the time of the shooting -- when the president and vice president were greeting well-wishers in an open-topped jeep on the campaign trail in Tainan City.
After checking with Chen's family, police decided that he "could have" committed the shooting to vent his resentment at the political situation, Hou said.

The family told police that Chen appeared rather depressed after police released March 26 the image of a "bald man in a yellow shirt" who they were looking for, and when asked by his wife if he was involved in the shooting, Chen said "I'll take care of the things I did," Hou said.
According to Hou, Chen later had his wife shave off his sideburns and burned the yellow shirt that he wore on the day of the shooting.

On March 28, Chen was found drowned wearing a new suit and shoes in the fishing port of Anping, and the family later destroyed three letters he allegedly left for his wife, daughter and son, Hou said.
However, Wang Wen-chung, head of the Tainan City Police Headquarters, pointed out that the case can only be declared resolved if the letters and the gun used in the shooting are found.
Another suspect in the shooting, identified as Huang Hung-jen, was also found dead at his home of a suspected self-inflicted gunshot wound on May 26, 2004, according to police.
Although the gun used in the president's shooting has yet to be found, the police are sure it was supplied by Tang through forensic examination of the bullets, Hou said.
Police confirmed in December last year that Tang, an underground gunsmith in southern Taiwan, was the maker of the two bullets used in the shooting.
Tang was found to have remodeled a total of 53 guns, 39 of which have been retrieved, Hou said.
Police have "pinpointed the whereabouts" of the other 14, although they have not actually found them, according to Hou. He did not elaborate.
Over the past year, police have screened 4,824 ex-convicts involving in the illegal possession of firearms in addition to carrying out raids on underground gun-remodeling outfits.
Police have also checked on 434 people appearing in videotapes taken at the crime scene, including 46 in a "hot zone" considered to be the most likely spot from where the shooter fired the shots.
Four recognizable people have not been identified, while the images of two other men are unclear and six others are totally unrecognizable, police said.
Meanwhile, in an effort to single out suspicious individuals, police have also examined more than 7.1 million households islandwide.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party has alleged that the shooting, which left President Chen and Vice President Lu slightly injured, was set up by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to give it an advantage in the March 20 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED SHOOTER OF PRESIDENT SAID TO BE 'PAN-BLUE' SUPPORTER

TEXT.P: A Tainan man allegedly responsible for last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu was said by his acquaintances Monday to be a supporter of the opposition "pan-blue alliance."
Chen Yi-hsiung, who was found drowned in a suspected suicide March 28, 2004, was reported by police earlier in the day to be a suspect in the March 19 shooting.
According to workers at a Tainan wrestling association that Chen had headed, he was a silent and honest man who had a deep interest in politics.

A 30-year neighbor of Chen said he was a supporter of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and People First Party and had argued with others in public because of differences in political preferences.
Meanwhile, Chen's neighbors said they were surprised to hear of his drowning, because he was known to be a good swimmer and diver.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE TO CONTINUE TO LOOK INTO 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Police said Monday that they will continue to look into suspicious points surrounding the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian last year, even though they claim to have identified the key suspect in the case.

In what they claimed was a "major breakthrough," police announced that Chen Yi-hsiung, a former head of the Wrestling Commission of the Tainan Training Association, is the key suspect in the shooting that slightly injured the president and Vice President Annette Lu March 19, 2004, when they were canvassing in an open-topped jeep in Tainan, southern Taiwan.

Chen later won by a razor-thin margin of a little more than 25,000 votes against his rival out of more than 13 million votes cast. Despite having no evidence to support their allegations, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" accused the president of staging the shooting to win sympathy votes.

Police said that although the key suspect died March 28, they will continue to look into his connections and the possible locations of the gun he is alleged to have used, and the distribution of the guns sold by the underground gunsmith alleged to have sold him the gun, as well as screening suspicious figures videotaped near the "hot zone" of the shooting scene.
Hou Yu-ih, commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, also attempted to explain why it had taken so long for police to make their breakthrough.
Hou said that Chen Yi-hsiung has long been on a list of suspects, as he was one of the figures who appeared in the videotapes taken at the crime scene.

Hou pointed out that Chen was found drowned and that when his body was recovered the following day, his family is alleged to also have found three suicide notes. The family decided to cremate his body hastily to avoid an autopsy and never to discuss the matter. The alleged notes were also burned by the family and the police did not explain why the family broke its silence.

Meanwhile, Wang Wen-chung, chief of the Tainan Police Bureau, said it is not easy to determine if Chen's family will bear criminal responsibility for failing to come forward, but he pointed out that should Chen one day prove to have been the shooter, the family will not be able to claim the reward of NT$53 million (US$1.72 million) as they did not supply the information voluntarily.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER EXHORTS KINMEN INSTITUTE TO GLOBALIZE
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, March 7 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng exhorted the Kinmen Institute of Technology (KIT) Monday to further globalize its teaching and development so as to make it the locomotive of education in all outlying islands of the Republic of China.

Addressing a ceremony to mark the inauguration of the KIT First Dormitory, Tu said the institute should strive to attract more youths from Kinmen families that have emigrated abroad to return to Kinmen to study.

Should Kinmen, which is known as one of the "hometowns of overseas Chinese, " succeed in attracting more youths from Kinmen families residing abroad, it will also contribute to Kinmen's economic development and investment, as the arrival of students will bring about closer ties and exchanges, Tu said.
Meanwhile, Tu said, the KIT can also be an option for China-based Taiwanese businessmen when they are choosing where to send their children to study.

The KIT, the highest level educational institute in all ROC-held outlying islands, can also be an option for China-based Taiwanese businessmen themselves who intend to pursue advanced studies, such as EMBAs, Tu added.

According to Tu, the KIT became operational in the autumn of 2004. Of the students it received last year, 93 percent were from Taiwan proper while only some 7 percent were from Kinmen and Matsu, another ROC-held outlying island located even closer to the coast of China.

In addition to Tu, a number of officials and local government leaders, including Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, attended the ceremony to inaugurate the dormitory, construction of which carried a price tag of NT$101.86 million (US$3.28 million), fully footed by the Ministry of Education.

Also addressing the ceremony, Lee suggested that the KIT open its door to students from China, making the institute an "experimental point" from which Taiwan democracy can be channeled into China via education.
In response to Lee's suggestion, the education minister said that this idea would involve the country's China policy, which is under the charge of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Segregation could help black pupils, says race chief.
Black boys may have to be taught apart from other children in some subjects to improve their grades, according to Trevor Phillips, the chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality. A row over whether black boys should be segregated at school erupted last night after Mr Phillips said that separate lessons may be needed to overcome years of failure.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TAIWAN FARM PRODUCE RETAIL SHOP OPENS IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A retail store specializing in selling Taiwan's agricultural products opened in the Takashimaya Department Store in Tokyo's Setagaya district Monday, making it the first Taiwan farm produce speciality retail counter in Japan.
The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (Taitra) cooperated with Japan's Tomizawa Co. in setting up the counter to boost sales of Taiwan-grown agricultural products.
Taitra Chairman Hsu Chih-jen and Tomyzawa Co. Chairman Ichiro Tomizawa jointly cut the ribbon to open the new outlet.
Addressing the ceremony, Hsu said Taiwan agricultural products have long been exported to Japan and enjoy a good reputation there for their fine quality.

The opening of the new specialty store will systematically introduce a wide variety of top-grade Taiwan farm produce to Japanese consumers, Hsu said, adding that each kind of product sold at the store has a computer code number to facilitate tracking of its production process.
"We'll focus on the products' quality so that Japanese consumers can feel safe consuming them," Hsu said.
Taitra is scheduled to open a similar store at Mitsukoshi Department Store in Yokohama in mid-May, also in cooperation with Tomizawa Co., Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL INCREASE OF CPI UP BY 1.94 PERCENT IN FEBRUARY: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) rose by 1.94 percent in February, thanks to the Chinese New Year holiday, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Monday.

DGBAS officials said some commodities and certain services, such as babysitters, housemaids, beauty parlors and taxis traditionally impose extra fees during the Chinese New Year holiday, which is why the CPI in February increased by 0.64 percent from January.

As Chinese New Year fell in January last year, the comparison base was comparatively lower, making the CPI annual increase in February surge 1.94 percent when compared with the same period of last year, representing a new high since last October.
The officials said that the annual increase of the wholesale price index (WPI) in February was 2.62 percent mainly because international oil prices were still hovering at a high level.
The WPI in February was down by 0.2 percent from January, mainly because the price of electric parts was down and because of the appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar against the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: 475 AFTERSHOCKS RECORDED SINCE SUNDAY: CWB

TEXT.P: A total of 475 aftershocks had been recorded as of Monday noon since two strong and nearly simultaneous earthquakes rocked Taiwan early Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau's seismology center reported later in the day.
Of those aftershocks, 11 were felt, with one measuring 5 on the Richter scale at 3:16 a.m. Sunday the strongest recorded.
Seismologists said more aftershocks are expected to jolt Taiwan in the coming two weeks.

According to the seismology center, an earthquake measuring 5.9 on the Richter scale shook Taiwan at 3: 06 a.m. Sunday, with its epicenter located 6.2 km north of Suao in the northeastern county of Ilan at a depth of 8.5 km. One minute later, the second quake occurred, with the same magnitude.
The two strong quakes did not cause any casualties, but two terrified residents in Ilan were injured when they fled their homes, according to the emergency rescue center.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI INKS COOPERATIVE ACCORD WITH NETHERLANDS RESEARCH ORGANIZATION

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Netherlands Organization for Applied Scientific Research (TNO) signed a memorandum of understanding Monday to boost research and development cooperation and exchanges between the two institutions.

Under the agreement, which was entered into at a ceremony witnessed by ITRI President Johnsee Lee and TNO Vice President Cees van Duyvendijk, both parties will focus their cooperation on research and development of herbal medicine using systems biological technology in the initial stages.

Speaking at the ceremony, Lee said the TNO is a non-government organization funded by the Netherlands Ministry of Education, Culture and Science as well as the Ministry of National Defense and that its research scope includes life sciences, environmental, information and communication technology, and defense industry technology.

Lee pointed out that TNO and ITRI have already started cooperation in research and development of herbal medicine, adding that several ITRI researchers are stationed in TNO laboratories where they are conducting research.

After completing herbal medicine research and development projects, the two institutions will extend their cooperative ties to other fields, such as nanotechnology, opto-electronics and flat panel displays, Lee said.
For his part, Duyvendijk said that ITRI's achievements in the fields of science and technology are internationally recognized.

Noting that bilateral cooperation will be further expanded with the signing of the agreement, Duyvendijk said his institution will study the feasibility of stationing research personnel in Taiwan to conduct research projects with their ITRI counterparts.
TNO, founded in 1932, is renowned in Europe as an applied scientific research organization. Currently, the institution has about 5,100 employees.

ITRI is a non-profit organization engaging in applied research and technical service. It was founded in 1973 by the Ministry of Economic Affairs to attend to the technological needs of Taiwan's industrial development. Backed by its broad research scope and close industrial ties, ITRI is becoming an increasingly active member in the global industrial R&D community.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO STAGE NATIONWIDE DEMONSTRATION IF BEIJING LAW HURTS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday that if Beijing's proposed anti-secession law tries to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo or hurts the national interests of Taiwan, it will stage a nationwide demonstration to underscore the Taiwan people's determination to vehemently oppose the law.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang issued the statement following remarks made by DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang the previous day.

Su said during a "defend Taiwan, oppose annexation" rally in Taipei that the DPP will mobilize a large-scale demonstration if Beijing passes the proposed law that tramples on Taiwan's dignity and squeezes the rights of the Taiwan people. President Chen Shui-bian, who did not take part in Sunday's rally, will also take to the streets with the people in such a rally, Su assured those present at the rally.

Lee outlined "three ifs" upon which holding a large-scale demonstration will depend: if the anti-secession law stipulates punishment, persecution or extradition of Taiwan people; if it allows sanctions, boycotts or the use of violent methods to change the cross-strait status quo; or if it threatens the existence of the Taiwan people, sabotages the basis of Taiwan's democracy and freedom, or hurts the nation's basic interests.

Lee pointed out that the key tensions in cross-strait relations lies in Beijing's refusal to recognize the independent sovereignty of the nation, its threat of force and deployment of missiles to threaten the peace and security of the Taiwan Strait, and its harsh methods used to squeeze Taiwan.

The legislation of the anti-secession law will only make the problem worse, Lee said, urging Beijing to reflect upon its policy toward Taiwan and not to further hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people.
Tung Li-wen, director of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, also said that the DPP cherishes every opportunity to ease cross-strait relations.

But he strongly questioned the formulation of the anti-secession law, describing it as "a sugar-coated bomb" that will be the beginning of legal warfare and provocation of cross-strait peace on the part of Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO PROMOTE GENDER EQUALITY IN POLICYMAKING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that the government is determined to eliminate gender discrimination and to implement gender equality in political participation and the policy formulation process.
Hsieh made the pledge while attending an activity promoting women's rights on the eve of March 8 International Women's Day.
Noting that women account for half of Taiwan's population, Hsieh said women have contributed greatly to the nation's development over the decades.

"We have had many outstanding career women. In public service, female civil servants are known for their diligence and integrity. There have been few corruption cases involving female civil servants, " Hsieh said, adding that he is convinced women can play an even more important role in the political arena if they are given the opportunity.

Now that it has achieved its economic miracle, Hsieh said, Taiwan should continue to create a "cultural miracle" to deepen Taiwan's values in promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and gender equality.

"We should work together to ensure co-existence and cooperation between the genders, " Hsieh said, adding that he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will give up the arms race and instead compete in promoting women's rights and welfare services.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said women have traditionally assumed more of the burden of duty in caring for elderly family members, child-rearing and household chores than their male counterparts.
"We should pay more heed to women's opinions, give them a greater say in policy making and assist them in resolving the dilema of balancing career and family life," Su said.

During the "Let Women's Dreams Come True" activity, a film was screened introducing the aspirations and dreams of local women in different age groups and at various social levels. The program was also aimed at inviting local people to select a song that can best represent or reflect Taiwan women's merits and virtues.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG UNIVERSITY TO OPEN IEMBA CLASSES IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: National University of Kaohsiung (NUK) is planning to open IEMBA classes in Vietnam to facilitate studies by key employees of Taiwanese-operated companies in that country, NUK President Huang Ying-chung disclosed Monday.
Huang said that he will lead a group of NUK executives on a trip to Vietnam to negotiate with Vietnamese officials over the technical details of the cooperative project.
If everything goes smoothly, Huang said, NUK will begin to solicit students wishing to attend IEMBA classes in May and classes will start in September.
Vietnamese government officials and entrepreneurs will also be welcome to attend the planned IEMBA classes, thus contributing to academic exchanges between the two countries, according to Huang.

Huang further said that NUK is also considering opening EMBA classes in cooperation with the Kinmen county government so that China-based Taiwanese manufacturers can study on the outlying island that lies closer to the Chinese coast than it does to Taiwan.

Managers of Taiwanese-operated companies in China have been keen to take EMBA courses in the past, but now most of them choose to study in Taiwan because diplomas issued by schools in China are not recognized by the Ministry of Education, Huang noted.
To help Taiwanese manufactures save time and money, Huang added, his university will open EMBA classes at the Kinmen Institute of Technology (KIT).
The NUK head said the program will not only enrich Taiwanese manufacturers with advanced business management knowledge but will also boost exchanges among Taiwan, Kinmen and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MARCH 19 DEMONSTRATION TO GO AHEAD AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will stage a large demonstration March 19 on the first anniversary of the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian as scheduled to underscore the damage they claim the incident has done to Taiwan democracy, a KMT spokesman said Monday.

Chang Jung-kung was responding to questions as to whether the demonstration will proceed as scheduled after police announced a major breakthrough earlier that day that they have identified who they think might have been the gunman in the shooting, although the man committed suicide shortly after the shooting and no weapon has been found. The KMT has refused to accept the finding.

According to Chang, March 19 marked a regression of Taiwan's democracy, adding the KMT's belief that "two bullets swayed the result of the presidential election" and that a national referendum was held simultaneously with the March 20 presidential election, which the KMT also disagreed with.

President Chen won the presidential election by a razor-thin margin and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" has accused him of staging the shooting to win sympathy votes, although it has failed to provide evidence to substantiate the claim.

Cheng Li-wen, vice chairperson of KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, said that the KMT, the New Party and the People First Party (PFP), as well as various civic groups, will be invited to take part in the demonstration.

She estimated that between 50,000 and 100,000 will take part in the demonstration. The protestors will start at the Sungshan Tobacco Factory and end on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, Cheng said, adding that KMT Chairman Lien Chan will attend.
Upon hearing the demonstration will go ahead as scheduled, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the KMT to rethink its decision.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said the party respects the views of the experts involved in the investigations and supports their tenacious efforts in solving the shooting.
If the KMT chooses to return to Ketagalan Boulevard as it did in the massive protests following its election defeat last year, it will signify a backpedalling of the party, according to Lee.

"Taiwan has paid a hefty price in the past, " Lee said, adding that now that the confrontational atmosphere has eased, there is no reason to continue to incite feelings of hatred in the people and add further to the rift in society.
Meanwhile, a PFP spokesman said that the party will reflect upon itself March 19 and will not take part in the demonstration.

Hsieh Kung-ping noted that PFP Chairman James Soong led the people to the streets last year over the shooting, but was accused by the KMT as being a "violent and radical" party. Such comments have "totally unnerved us," he said.
The PFP will not take part in the demonstration, although Hsieh said the party still admires the participants for their courage in pursuing the truth of the shooting.
Hsieh's remarks came on the heels of a recent meeting between Chen and Soong in a high-profile Feb. 24 meeting touted as "inter-party reconciliation."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL NAMED AS NEW IWF VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The honorary president of the Chinese Taipei Weightlifting Association said Monday that his election as vice president of the International Weightlifting Federation (IWF) will facilitate Taiwan's exchanges with the world.

Chang Chao-kuo said that the closer exchanges will help upgrade the weightlifting standards of the nation and will increase the chances of Taiwan's bids to sponsor world-class weightlifting competitions.

He made the remarks upon his return from Istanbul, where he defeated strong rivals from Russia and Britain to be elected as one of the six vice presidents of the IWF during the 2005 Electoral Congress March 4. Chang previously served as one of the executive members.

But he also expressed worry that since its losses in the Athens Olympics, the Chinese Taipei Weightlifting Association has still not employed any foreign coaches to prepare for the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY OF INDONESIAN FIRST MATE FOUND

TEXT.P: The body of a first mate who fell overboard from a Panamanian-registered freighter that ran aground off Penghu last week was found and sent to the outlying island Monday.
Coast Guard Administration officials on Penghu received reports from a fishing boat operating near Penghu earlier that day that they had found a body wearing a life vest.
The man was also wearing a backpack in which was found his crewmember licence identifying him as First Mate Manahan Simanjuntak, 47.
The freighter, the Shinko Ocean, was carrying timber from Malaysia to Taichung Harbor, when it lost power and began to drift March 4. The vessel listed badly after running aground near Penghu.

Navy vessels, helicopters and Coast Guard Administration cutters joined the rescue operations and were able to rescue 19 Indonesian crewmen from the freighter, but Simanjuntak fell overboard due to the stormy weather at the time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ADMIRES PROGRESS IN 319 SHOOTING PROBE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed admiration Monday for a special team of prosecutors and police detectives for their efforts in probing the assassination attempt against him on the eve of the March 20 presidential election last year, according to a statement issued through his office.

As the victim of the assassination attempt, the statement says, Chen and Vice President Annette Lu -- who was also wounded in the incident -- respect the findings and hope the team will continue its probe until the whole truth is out.

The statement was issued in the wake of a claim made by the special investigation team earlier in the day that it has identified a key suspect who might have been the person that shot the president. The suspect apparently committed suicide March 28 last year before the police could track down him.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS' FINDINGS IN 319 SHOOTING DRAW PARTISAN RESPONSE

TEXT.P: Political parties reacted along party lines Monday to a special team of investigators' claims that they had identified the the person who might have shot President Chen Shui-bian March 19, 2004.

The March 19 assassination attempt on the president has been at the center of a bitter dispute between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) over the legitimacy of Chen's successful re-election.
The KMT and PFP, which fielded a joint ticket in the presidential race, claim that the assassination was a campaign trick choreographed by Chen's camp to win over voters.
In addition to filing two lawsuits in attempt to deny Chen the presidency, they formed the 319 Truth Investigation Commission to carry out an investigation into the shooting.
The KMT has called for its supporters to take to the streets on March 19, the anniversary of the shooting, to turn up the heat on the government to get to the bottom of the shooting.

However, the government's investigation team consisting of prosecutors and police detectives claimed earlier in the day that they had identified a suspect, who apparently committed suicide March 28 last year.

Lawmaker Lai Chin-teh, the secretary-general of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, welcomed Monday's finding, claiming that it clears the president of suspicion that he staged the assassination to win sympathy in the presidential race.
He expressed thanks to the investigators, saying their findings will promote the ongoing process of reconciliation between the DPP and the opposition parties.
Lai urged the KMT to call off its March 19 demonstration, saying it will only prompt further upheaval rather than finding the truth.

The DPP's political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, shared his view. TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming acknowledged the investigators' hard work and called on the various political parties to respect and affirm their findings and refrain from speculation that will only impede the probe.
Meanwhile, the KMT and PFP unanimously decried the investigators' findings as unconvincing.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan shrugged off journalists' requests for comment on the investigators' findings, but his aides said the KMT chief finds them "ridiculous."
KMT Spokesman Chang Jung-kung said his party is worried that the truth of the case might be buried forever now that the police have pointing the finger at a dead person as the chief suspect.

"If that is the government's final reply to the mysterious shooting, it only shows that the government has no intention of getting to the bottom of the case and the Taiwan people, as well as the international community, will keep questioning the fairness of the 2004 presidential election," Chang claimed.
Citing six questions raised by the 319 Truth Investigation Commission about the shooting, Chang said the government's claims that the suspect has been found fails to address these questions.

PFP Spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping noted that the investigators timed the revelation of their "major breakthrough" just two weeks before the anniversary of the shooting and speculated that the timing is apparently for "political purposes."
"Instead of stopping speculation, pointing to a deceased as the suspect will only fuel the rumors," Hsieh said.
PFP Legislator Lee Yung-ping, who is secretary of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the findings will probably satisfy the authorities but not the general public.

Lee said the investigators' inability to substantiate their claims with evidence also proves the necessity of having the 319 Truth Investigation Commission, which ceased its work Jan. 19, carry on its probe.
Commission spokeswoman Wang Chin-feng said the investigators' findings have raised more questions than they have answered.
She said the investigators never mentioned the findings to her commission during their interviews with the commission workers and therefore there is a shadow of doubt cast over their findings.
However, she went on, her commission has been unable to get to the bottom of the case because of a boycott by the DPP administration.

Noting that the Council of Grand Justices has downgraded the commission to an agency under the Legislative Yuan, which Wang described as the nation's "most cruel political arena, " she said her commission cannot carry out its job "independently" with such a status and is not expected to conduct an investigation "free from political interference."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS TO INTRODUCE RESOLUTION URGING BEIJING TO RELEASE ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: Several legislators from the ruling and opposition parties promised Monday to jointly introduce a resolution at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan urging the Beijing authorities to release all detained pro-democracy activists, including Dr. Wang Bingzhang.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators Lin Cho-shui, Hsiao Bi-khim, Chiu Chuang-chin and Chen Chung-hsin, as well as Wu Chih-yang of the Kuomintang and Kao Szu-po of the People First Party were attending a press conference jointly called by the World Organization for Human Rights, the Chinese Association for Human Rights and the Taiwan Association for Human Rights at the legislature.

Kao said that Wang was jailed on suspicion of collecting information for Taiwan's intelligence agencies, so the people of Taiwan have an obligation to help the pro-democracy activist clear himself of the false accusation.
He called on the Beijing authorities to shake hands with political dissidents and to free Wang.

Lin said giving moral support to Chinese pro-democracy activists will make them more confident in their efforts to promote democracy in China and he voiced the hope that all 1.3 billion Chinese people can one day enjoy the universal value of human rights.
For his part, Timothy Cooper, executive director of the World Organization for Human Rights, thanked the legislators for their support for all Chinese pro-democracy activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP BLASTS CHINA OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu blasted China Monday for its plan to enact a so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, saying that such legislation will upset peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Lu made the remarks while receiving a delegation of the Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs at the Presidential Office.

"China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- will begin to deliberate the so-called anti-secession law March 8, thus making International Women's Day a non-peaceful day, " Lu told her guests.

"Once the proposed anti-secession law is enacted, " Lu said, "Taiwan will face a serious military threat from China as the new law will provide Beijing with a legal basis for using force against the country."

As for current cross-strait relations, Lu went on, the maintenance of the status quo means "no unification, no independence and no use of force." She added it is an undeniable fact that Taiwan is an independent country with sovereignty, no matter what designation it uses.
It is China that is trying to unilaterally change the status quo of the Taiwan Strait because Beijing has constantly enhanced its military intimidation of Taiwan, Lu said.

Although Beijing officials have repeatedly declared that Taiwan is a part of the People's Republic of China based on Resolution No. 2758 adopted by the United Nations in 1971, Lu said the U.N. only granted China's seat to the PRC through the resolution, which mentions nothing about Taiwan.

As for the "one China" principle recognized by the United States in the 1972 Shanghai Comunique, Lu noted that it is still worth discussing whether such a principle is acceptable to the 23 million people of Taiwan who enjoy freedom, democracy and human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE DECREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports and imports amounted to US$10.87 billion and US$11.77 billion in February, down 17.3 percent and 10.8 percent year-on-year, respectively, according to statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
It was the first time that Taiwan's foreign trade posted negative growth in nearly two years, MOF Statistics Department Director Hsu Kuo-chung said.
He attributed the decrease to relatively fewer working days in the month due to the week-long Lunar New Year holiday.
Hsu predicted that the country's foreign trade will return to its growth track in March, with exports moving up by 5.92 percent and imports by 10.67 percent.
He also estimated that Taiwan's exports and imports will grow by 7.44 percent and 11.02 percent, respectively, in the first quarter of this year.
For the first two months of this year, he added, Taiwan's exports and imports expanded by 8.3 percent and 11.2 percent, respectively, leaving a trade deficit of US$700 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL REVIEW POLICY AFTER CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government will review its policy toward China if it enacts an anti-secession law, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.
Calling the bill a show of "remarkable malice" against Taiwan, Wu said this cannot be ignored because of Chinese President Hu Jintao's seemingly gentle remarks about Taiwan March 4.
"The Mainland Affairs Council cares more about what Chinese leaders are doing than what they are saying," he noted.

Although the MAC has no idea what the exact text of the anti-secession law will be, information from various sources points to the fact that the wording of the law has been considerably softened by its author, apparently because of the serious concerns it has raised in the international community and Taiwan.

The United States has played a significant role in the change, Wu said, noting that U.S. officials who disapprove of China's move amid an easing of tension across the Taiwan Strait had pressed China with harsh words to temper the hostility displayed in the decision to enact the law.

Instead of telling his office how to change tack in response to the anti-secession law, the MAC chief said President Chen Shui-bian respects the MAC's authority and has given it a blank check to carry out reviews and adjustment.

Wu, however, refused to reveal what changes will take place should China make the bill into law, saying it depends on the content of the law and that in any case the fundamental principles of seeking peace and development with China will not be changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, March 8, or the 28th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1702: Queen Anne accedes to the British throne after the death of her brother-in-law, William III, in a riding accident.
1765: Britain's House of Lords passes the Stamp Act to tax American colonies.
1874: Millard Fillmore, the 13th president of the United States, dies at the age of 74. He struggled to keep the nation united but lost the support of his Whig Party by attempting to enforce the Fugitive Slave Act in the North.
1879: Otto Hahn, German chemist who won a 1944 Nobel Prize for his work on atomic fission, is born.
1898: The United States refuses to back Britain in its conflict with Russia over a loan to China.
1906: The British government publishes the latest "Blue Book," telling how -- in theory -- it is now possible to travel around the world without leaving the dominion of Great Britain, which now has a population of 400 million people and covers 12 million square miles.
1917: Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin, the German inventor who designed and manufactured the first motorized, rigid-frame dirigible balloon, or airship, dies at the age of 79.
1930: William Howard Taft, the 27th president of the United States, dies at the age of 73. His term was marked by passage of the Payne-Aldrich Tariff Act. He also later served on the U.S. Supreme Court as chief justice of the United States.
1942: Japanese forces capture Java after 100,000 defenders surrendered.
1949: France recognizes Vietnam under the rule of Bao Dai as an independent state within the French Union.
1950: The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan approves the nomination of Gen. Chen Cheng as premier.
1952: The Pentagon announces that even after the end of the Korean War, the United States will continue defending Taiwan and the Philippines, which are listed as being under the protection of the U.S. Pacific Fleet.
1954: The United States signs a mutual defense agreement with Japan.
1965, The United States sends 3,500 Marines, the first batch of American combat forces, to join the Vietnam War.
1969: The Soviet Union puts its Far East Army on alert as a warning to Communist China after a frontier clash on Chen Pao Island in the Ussuri River.
1971: In a historic world heavyweight title fight, Joe Frazier defeats Mohammed Ali in 15 rounds.
1976: The first session of the Sino-Saudi Arabian Permanent Joint Committee on Economic and Technical Cooperation opens with Chang Kwang-shih, ROC economic affairs vice minister, and Mansoor Al-Turki, Saudi Arabian deputy minister of finance and national economy, as co-chairmen.
1981: Twenty-eight people are killed and more than 100 others injured when an express train derails near Touchien River in Hsinchu County.
1989: Communist Chinese troops converge on Lhasa to enforce martial law after three days of rioting in the Tibetan capital.
1993: South Korean President Kim Young Sam fires two key generals in a move to establish civilian control of the army.
1996: Mainland China begins eight days of test-firing surface-to-surface missiles in waters close to major ports in northeastern and southwestern Taiwan, timed to last until the island's first direct presidential election.
1999: New York Yankees baseball legend Joe Dimaggio dies at the age of 84.
1999: A Taiwanese-born scientist, suspected of handing over nuclear missile technology to Beijing in the 1980s, is fired by the U.S. Energy Department.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as Kuomintang chairman, orders the all-out mobilization of party members in support of Vice President Lien Chan, the KMT candidate in the presidential election just 10 days away.
2001: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung unveils an ambitious plan to spend NT$810 billion (US$25 billion) this year to catapult Taiwan into "a new era."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Renounce yourself and conform to the ideal of decency and good sense."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SUPPORTS CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS TO COUNTER BEIJING LAW

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday he will not hesitate to support the proposal to phase out the general provisions of the existing Republic of China Constitution if Beijing passes a law that allows it to attack Taiwan anytime and that makes Taiwan a part of the People's Republic of China.
Hsieh made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Su Chi asked Hsieh about his stance on constitutional amendments.

Hsieh said that each major domestic party has its own fundamental stances on the constitutional amendment issue and that respecting the existing ROC Constitution is a consensus of the ruling and opposition parties.

While the opposition KMT and its "pan-blue alliance" ally -- the People First Party -- think that the existing ROC Constitution is good, Hsieh said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party thinks that the constitution needs to be amended and updated in order to meet current realities.

Hsieh said that he personally supports the proposal to revise certain provisions of the ROC Constitution. As to the extent of the revisions, Hsieh said it will depend on the state of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-JAPAN JOINT STATEMENT NOT LINKED TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland affairs has said the joint statement issued by the United States and Japan in February is a product of China's increasing military power and has nothing to do with Beijing's proposed anti-secession law.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks in an exclusive interview conducted with the Central News Agency Monday.

U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, Japanese Foreign Minister Nobutaka Machimura and Defense Minister Yoshinori Ohno held a security consultation meeting in Washington, D.C., Feb. 19. In a joint statement after the meeting, the U.S. and Japanese officials listed "encouraging a peaceful resolution of issues concerning the Taiwan Strait through dialogue" as part of their common strategic objectives in the Asia-Pacific region.

Wu said that although Washington and Tokyo have voiced their serious concerns about China's proposed anti-secession law, there is no connection between their joint statement and the bill. He noted Washington already had plans in place regarding the U.S.-Japan relationship prior to U.S. President George W. Bush's inauguration for a second term.

The joint statement is relevant to China's military deployments and expansion in recent years, the MAC head said, adding that the mainland's military deployment targeting Taiwan also poses threats to other countries.

Pointing out that the Korean Peninsula and the Taiwan Strait are two areas where a wider East Asian conflict could potentially erupt, Wu said that the United States and Japan both feel that any instability in these regions poses a direct threat to them.

On reports that Japan has recently paid more attention to the Taiwan Strait issues, Wu said that the rapid and increased Chinese military deployment has made Japan feel differently and that there have been delicate changes in the relationship between Japan and China. "China's hostility toward Japan has increased, and China's defense white paper has also put more pressure on Japan," he claimed.

On Taiwan-Japan ties, the MAC head said that the Taiwan government maintains very close unofficial relations with Japan, adding that the two countries can also engage in a security dialogue through an unofficial mechanism and that such dialogue can be strengthened if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY POINTS OF BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW UNVEILED

TEXT.P: China unveiled Tuesday the key points of its proposed anti-secession law, including authorizing the State Council and the Central Military Commission to take "non-peaceful" action against Taiwan in certain situations.

Wang Zhaoguo, a vice chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament -- unveiled the highlights of the controversial draft law in a report at the parliament's ongoing plenary session.
Wang said peaceful reunification and the "one country, two systems" scheme are Beijing's basic approach to achieving "peaceful reunification."
However, he also stressed that China is entitled to use force to check secessionist activities.

"Using non-peaceful means to stop secession in defence of our sovereignty and territorial integrity would be a last resort for us, after all our efforts for a peaceful reunification proved futile, " Wang told mainland lawmakers.

He said the draft legislation, which is expected to be passed next week, provides for the use of force "in the event that the Taiwan independence forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China."
Beijing has yet to publicize the full text of the so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Wang's report focused on explaining the necessity and feasibility of enacting the proposed law, the purpose and the scope of the law, the nature of the so-called Taiwan issue, measures to realize peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and the use of "non-peaceful" means to stop secession activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER WOOS BRITISH INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN BANKS PRIVATIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: London, March 7 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lin Chuan on Monday wooed British investment in the privatization of Taiwan's public banks at an investment seminar in London.
Speaking to nearly 200 executives of British investment and financial agencies at the seminar, Lin urged them to seize the business and cooperation opportunities between the two countries.

Lin said that the Ministry of Finance is slated to release late next year its holdings of government shares of all Taiwan's public banks except for the Bank of Taiwan to allow for a greater degree of foreign ownership of domestic banks in line with a government privatization project.

Stressing that Taiwan is poised to do so to sharpen its banking industry's competitive edge as part of its bid to build Taiwan into a regional financial hub, Lin assured that relevant legislation has been underway to encourage mergers and consolidation among banks.

According to the finance minister, there are currently more than 50 banks in Taiwan, including 12 government-controlled ones that account for more than 60 percent of the domestic banking industry's assets.

However, he pointed out that profits posted by the public banks lag far behind those of private banks and that this is the reason behind the government's decision to launch the privatization plan to increase their profitabilities.

Council for Economic Planning and Development Vice Chairman Hsieh Fa-ta and Financial Supervisory Commission Secretary-General Huang Tien-mu also gave speeches at the seminar explaining Taiwan financial policy and management.
Republic of China Representative to Britain Edgar Lin and Vice Representative Shih Wen-pin also attended the seminar.
At the head of an official delegation, Lin flew to London from New York on a tour to attract foreign investment in Taiwan's state-run banks and enterprises.

Representatives from the Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corporation and seven leading financial holdings companies, including Mega Financial Holdings and Hua Nan Financial Holdings, make up the delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN MINISTER SOLICITS TAIWANESE INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, March 7 (CNA) (By C.C. Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: South African Trade and Industry Minister Mandisi Mpahlwa on Monday called for Taiwanese businesspeople around the world to use South Africa as a springboard for making inroads into other parts of the continent.
The minister made the appeal while addressing an annual meeting held by the board of directors and supervisors of the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce in Johannesburg.

Since South Africa is the largest economy on the continent and has a stable political and economic environment as well as good economic relations with other countries, Taiwanese businesspeople can use it to make inroads into other markets on the continent, he said.

The minister expressed the hope that with economic growth of 4 percent last year and a healthy industrial sector that will strengthen the country's competitiveness, South Africa can lure more investment from Taiwan in the future.

According to the minister, total annual Taiwan-South Africa trade registered a vast increase from US$4.9 billion in 1994 to about US$9 billion in recent years. South Africa's main exports to Taiwan have been metal products, while its major imports from the island have been high-tech goods.

Emphasizing that Pretoria is proud of its successful trade relations with Taiwan and that his country also sees Taiwan as an important trade partner in Asia, the minister said that in order to protect foreign investor's property and capital, South Africa is working on improving its judicial and law-enforcement systems.

Chiang Ping-kun, former ROC minister of economic affairs and chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan, also attended the gathering. Pointing out that Taiwan lacks natural resources but has plenty of manpower, Chiang said he believes that if Mpahlwa is able to visit Taiwan, he will attract more investors from the island.
