DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: In Sri Lanka, a Frustrating Limbo.
Bureaucratic inefficiency and new land-use rules are hindering efforts to rebuild after the Tsunami.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : HDB gives developers a bigger role.
Home-buyers looking to buy a newly- constructed Housing Board flat in Tampines in the next year or two are set for a big surprise.
Instead of arranging the purchase with the HDB, they will find themselves face-to-face with a private developer.
In a bold experiment, the Government announced yesterday that it will allow private developers to design, build, price and sell some HDB flats in Tampines Avenue 6.
The Lianhe Zaobao: HDB to announce 3 new measures.
The public housing sector is up for a makeover, starting with a pilot plan to allow private developers to design, build and sell HDB flats.
National Development Minister Mah Bow Tan also announced other changes in Parliament, like relaxation of rental rules to encourage residents to be more self-reliant.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Sony taps Stringer as CEO
Sony Corp. on Monday named Howard Stringer, head of its U.S. operations as its next group CEO, becoming one of the few major Japanese firms to have a non-Japanese at the top.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 47.18 points to close at 6,173.34.
The bourse opened at 6,250.58 and fluctuated between 6,255.68 and 6,156.98 during trading. A total of 4.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.24 billion (US$3.02 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 2.1 percent, textile stocks at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 719 to 213, with 69 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY DRILLS TO GO ON DESPITE BEIJING ANTI-SECESSION LAW:SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan troops remain combat-ready and will start their annual maneuvers as scheduled despite Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law," Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Liu Chih-chien said Tuesday.

Liu said that the military will begin its annual drills, including the "Hankuang" live-fire exercise, according to a timetable worked out a year ago regardless of the proposed law, which is expected to be enacted next week.

Saying that the Republic of China's military training and deployments have nothing to do with the proposed law, Liu added that the defense ministry will also closely monitor Beijing's military action following the enactment of the controversial law.

The National People's Congress, Beijing's parliament which opened its 10th session last Saturday, is expected to pass "anti-secession" legislation against any moves by Taiwan toward independence in the middle of next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March lost 76 points to close at 6,155, with 37,801 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved down 65 points to finish at 6,165, with 1,568 contracts traded, while June futures lost 67 points to finish at 6,156, with 57 contracts traded.
September futures lost 78 points to finish at 6,070, with 41 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 86 points to close at 6,079, with 11 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,231 for March, 6,230 for April, 6,223 for June, 6,148 for September and 6,165 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

March TE futures moved down 0.85 points to close at 233.5, with 5,738 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 0.75 points to finish at 233.5, with 237 contract transactions. September TE futures gained 2.8 points to close at 236.5, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

March TF futures lost 15.8 points to finish at 1,008.2, with 4,843 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 14.2 points to end at 1,009, with 386 contracts traded. June TF futures lost 7.8 points to finish at 1,010.2, with three contracts changing hands, while September TF futures moved down 10.8 points to close at 1,010.4, with three contract transaction. December TF futures lost 6.2 points to end at 1,010, with one contract changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.004 to close at NT$30.875.
A total of US$694 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.930 and hit a low of NT$30.805.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' EXPOSES CHINA'S INTENT TO INVADE TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) lodged a strong protest Tuesday at what it called China's attempt to use an "anti-secession law" to unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, saying the law has exposed Beijing's intent to take over Taiwan by force.

The MAC issued the statement after China's National People's Congress unveiled the key points of the draft law earlier in the day, which include the use of "non-peaceful" means to check secessionist activities in Taiwan.

"The government hereby expresses its strongest protest at the vicious attempt and brutal means of China to sabotage peace in East Asia and stability across the Taiwan Strait, ignore the will of the Taiwan people, and interfere with the freedom of choice of the Taiwan people," the MAC said.
The MAC said China is attempting to negate the sovereignty of the Republic of China and to change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally by introducing the law.
The move has cause regional tension, which proves that the worries of the international community and Taiwan are not unwarranted, according to the MAC.
It said the law has exposed China's ambition to take over Taiwan by force and to build up regional dominance and has virtually given the Chinese military the permission to attack Taiwan.
The MAC pointed out that the Republic of China is a sovereign state, with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait being independent of each other.

"The people of Taiwan will never accept the arrangement of 'one country, two systems' because the future of Taiwan must be decided by the 23 million people on Taiwan, which is a fact that Chinese authorities must face up to," the MAC said.

It noted that the government has made many efforts to try to improve cross-strait relations over the past five years, which include putting forth a proposal to establish a framework for cross-strait peace and stability.
The "anti-secession law" will impede cross-strait exchanges and the resumption of cross-strait dialogue and disregard the efforts made by Taiwan, it continued.
The MAC urged the international community to pay attention to the hegemonic ambition of China and take concrete actions to help maintain the cross-strait status quo and peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOESN'T SUPPORT 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW': MOFA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The United States's stance on China's plan to enact a so-called "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan is that such legislation will not be beneficial to the situation across the Taiwan Strait, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Victor J. Chin, director-general of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, made the remarks after China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- began to deliberate on the law the same day.

ROC government officials have exchanged views with their U.S. counterparts on Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law" since late January and have explained the eventual impact of the new law on stability and peace across the Taiwan Strait and in the Asia-Pacific area to the U.S. government, Chin said at a news conference.

Chin noted that both the U.S. spokesman and other officials have expressed their viewpoints on the legislation from different angles, adding that Washington has said it is unnecessary for Beijing to enact such a law.
According to Chin, the U.S. government doesn't support and is even opposed to Beijing's move to unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait or to define future cross-strait situation.

Taiwan will continue to keep a close eye on developments of the law by China's National People's Congress while maintaining close contacts with the United States to safeguard regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RULES OUT PRE-CONDITIONS FOR CROSS-STRAIT NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that Beijing should not impose any prerequisites for reopening negotiations between Taiwan and mainland China.

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from People First Party Legislator Lee Ching-an in a legislative interpellation, who enquired about the government's stance on the impending enactment of Beijing's "anti-secession law," which observers say could be aimed at curbing Taiwan independence. The lawmaker suggested the government recognize the "1992 consensus" in its dealings with the mainland.

Hsieh called on Beijing to put aside its sovereignty disputes with Taiwan and forswear any other preconditions to display a greater degree of goodwill for rekindling bilateral negotiations on the grounds that the "bigger should compromise more."

Stressing that peace is the cornerstone of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he said that the government is willing to start two-way talks on direct cargo services based on parity and dignity and even those on direct trade, passenger transport and postal links based on the pattern of the recent Taiwan-mainland charter flights during the lunar new year holidays.

Responding to a question from Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Su Chi about whether President Chen Shui-bian's stated desire to write a new constitution for Taiwan provokes Beijing, the premier said that what matters is its contents.

Since what the president referred to focuses on a streamlining of the legislative and executive branches and will not touch on the nation's official designation or change his "five noes" policy, such contents should not constitute a provocation to Beijing, he said.

While fielding questions from KMT Legislator John Chang on opening regular links across the strait, he also vowed to strive for Taiwan's co-existence with the mainland at a time when Beijing's parliament is anticipated to finish the "anti-secession" legislation next week. He pledged not to give up the goal no matter how difficult the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: YAO WEN-CHIH TO BE NEW GIO CHIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Tuesday named Yao Wen-chih, president of TTV Culture Co., a publishing arm of Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., to serve as director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO).

Hsieh approved the resignation of incumbent GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung earlier in the day. Lin tendered his resignation last week in preparation for seeking the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the year-end mayoral election in the central city of Taichung. Lin's resignation will take effect March 14.

Yao, a protege of Premier Hsieh, once served as Kaohsiung City Government's deputy secretary-general and head of the information department. As TTV Culture Co. president, Yao has been assisting in the planning of an aboriginal TV station.

Yao, 40, has a master's degree in political science from National Chengchi University. He said producing good movies and TV drama series will be one of his priorities after assuming the top GIO post. Yao is expected to outline his vision and work plans at a news conference Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPPOSES CHINA'S ATTEMPT TO USE FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers objected Tuesday to China's proposed "anti-secession law," which will authorize Beijing authorities to use force against Taiwan under certain circumstances.

According to the key points of the draft law unveiled earlier in the day by the National People's Congress of China, Beijing can take "non-peaceful" action "in the event that the Taiwan independence forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China."

Commenting on the legislation, KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh asserted that the Republic of China is an independent, sovereign state and will not tolerate any attempt by Beijing to change or downgrade the status of Taiwan.
He also urged President Chen Shui-bian to avoid provoking China and stop promoting a campaign to draft a new constitution and change the official name of the country.
KMT Legislator Lin Yi-shih said it will be impossible for Taiwan and China to start peace talks unless China renounces the use of force against the island.
Although Beijing is aiming its military action at the pro-independence movement, all people on Taiwan will get hurt should any Chinese missile hit the island, Lin pointed out.
Lin urged Beijing to stop trying to resolve the problem of Taiwan independence by force, because he said this will panic the Taiwan people and hinder the resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
Shuai Hua-min, another KMT legislator, said all people on Taiwan, regardless of their political affiliations, are opposed to China's military intimidation of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S ATTEMPT TO CHANGE STATUS QUO SHOULD BE CONDEMNED: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called on the international community Tuesday to condemn China's plan to enact a so-called "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan, claiming that such legislation will unilaterally challenge and sabotage the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- on Tuesday began to deliberate the much-anticipated "anti-secession law" that will probably provide its military with a legal base for using force against Taiwan.

Resolving all disputes through peaceful talks is a fundamental international practice in the 21st century, Lu said. She added that any attempts to deal with disputes through non-peaceful means will violate this international practice.

"China has expressed explicitly in its presentation of the draft legislation that should Taiwan be reluctant to accept unification with China or the "one China" policy, Beijing will resort to non-peaceful means to solve the issue," Lu pointed out.

Stressing that such a move will infringe upon current international practice, Lu said that Beijing's attempts to upset the peace across the Taiwan Strait should be vehemently condemned and blocked by the international community.
The vice president made the remarks after attending a weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HELPING SME DEVELOPMENT: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government continues to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) develop, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said Tuesday at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting in Taipei.

The APEC Symposium on Industrial Clustering for SMEs is being held at the Taipei International Convention Center. The conference is part of a series of prelude meetings for the 2005 APEC SME Ministerial Meeting, which will take place from Aug. 28 to Sept. 3 in Daegu, South Korea.
In a keynote speech at the symposium, Chen introduced the government's policy regarding industrial clustering.
The economist said industrial clusters have played a key role in the island's successful economic development, citing the formation of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.

Describing the facility in northern Taiwan as the best example of industrial clustering, Chen noted that there are currently more than 300 companies operating in the park, creating a total output value of US$25 billion last year.

Industrial clustering covers a broad range of economic activities, which, beside business gatherings, include market and technology information exchanges, Chen explained, adding that this helps lower production and trading costs while ensuring more efficient resource sharing.

Chen stressed that industrial clustering is an important strategy for a country to boost economic development, while it also plays a key role in SME development. Because of these reasons, the ROC government will continue efforts to construct and develop science-based industrial parks, help build a supply chain for local SMEs, set up an SME contact network, and promote cooperative relations between the industrial, official and academic sectors, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Credit card fraud hits new high despite chip and PIN.
Credit and debit card fraud has soared to a record 500 million despite the introduction of new chip-and-PIN technology, it emerged today. Banks, credit card companies and shop owners hoped that the new technology would reduce fraud because a four-digit personal identification number is harder to reproduce than a signature. But far from deterring fraudsters, the new measures have encouraged criminals to steal more cards. Figures from Apacs (the Association for Payment Clearing Services) show that losses to thieves rose by 20 per cent last year, equivalent to 10 for every adult in Britain. An average of 100,000 credit and debit cards were posted to consumers every day last year. Many were intercepted by criminals, resulting in a 62 per cent rise -- to 73 million -- in "mail non-receipt" fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW WILL NOT CAUSE ECONOMIC DOWNTURN: KMT OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, March 7 (CNA) (By C.C. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An impending anti-secession law by Beijing is not expected to spur an economic downturn in Taiwan, P. K. Chiang, a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said here Monday.

Chiang predicted that the law will not drag down foreign investment in Taiwan or the operations of Taiwan and foreign companies at home. He added that its impact on the political front will depend on to what extent Taiwan reacts.

However, Chiang said he believes the enactment of the anti-secession law will hinder Taiwan investment willingness in mainland China, although he does not expect the law to trigger war between the two sides.

He contended that the effects of the proposed law will not cause negative effects on the Taiwan economy any more than those of Taiwan's own moves to create a new constitution or to change its official designation of the Republic of China -- movements which have proven to be provocative to Beijing.

As Taiwan has over the past few years been at loggerheads with the mainland, a piece of legislation by Beijing in itself will not aggravate the situation across the Taiwan Strait and further trigger an economic dwindling in Taiwan, he claimed.

Chiang said the KMT will fully cooperate with other parties in the legislation of a bill initiated by its ally the People First Party with the aim of boosting cross-strait peace and he called on the government to take substantive measures to serve that end.
Cross-strait peace and domestic political stability are the two fundamentals upon which Taiwan's economic development rests, he said.

According to the KMT vice chairman, the party is slated to send a delegation late this month to China to help pave the way for bilateral talks related to agriculture and direct cargo and passenger flight services.

Chiang, formerly a chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development in the previous KMT-led government, traveled to South Africa at the head of a legislative mission to take part in a board meeting of the World Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce held here earlier the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CALLS FOR 'DEFENSIVE REFERENDUM' TO COUNTER ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Officials of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) called on President Chen Shui-bian Tuesday to initiate a "defensive referendum" to counteract China's proposed anti-secession law against Taiwan.

TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said the law, which will authorize the Beijing authorities to use non-peaceful means to check so-called "secessionist" activities in Taiwan, is evidence of China's intention to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and suppress Taiwan.
He proposed that President Chen launch a "defensive referendum" in accordance with the Referendum Law to exhibit the resolve of the Taiwan people to defend the country's sovereignty and survival.

Lo Chih-ming, convener of the TSU legislative caucus, said the party will propose a referendum to let the people vote on "whether Taiwan is part of China" if the president does not exercise his right.
Also, Lo said, the TSU will release Friday details of its "anti-annexation law" in retaliation for the anti-secession legislation that China is expected to pass next week.
According to Lo, Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China is inconsistent with reality and the cross-strait status quo.

Lo said the China-proposed "one country, two systems" format for unification is unacceptable to the people of Taiwan, because any changes to the status quo must be decided by the people of Taiwan through a democratic process.
The anti-secession law is tantamount to a license for the People's Liberation Army to attack Taiwan and a measure coercing the Taiwan people to accept China's annexation, according to Lo.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANDLING CHINA'S PEACEFUL RISE TOP U.S. PRIORITY: U.S. EX-OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Engaging China and handling its peaceful rise is the top priority of the United States East Asia policy, according to a former U.S. government official.
James A. Kelly, who was assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs from 2001 to 2005, made the remarks recently in an international forum.
"As I look back over the last four years, engaging China and handling its peaceful rise is inevitably the top priority, " Kelly said.
There will be no profound changes in President George Bush's foreign policy in his second term, given that many policy aspects worked reasonably well in Bush's first administration, he noted.

Also, he went on, both Bush and Secretary of State Condeleezza Rice have been intimately involved in every important component of East Asia-Pacific policy over the last several years, while Deputy Secretary of State Robert Zoellick has both affinity for and first-hand experience in Asian political questions as well as the economic issues.

Although there has been an increasing number of issues on which Washington and Beijing cooperate very well, Kelly admitted there are a number of issues over which the two sides have strong disagreements, such as human rights and protection of intellectual property rights.
Noting that China has changed a lot over the last decade, Kelly said the economic growth and improvements in the lives of many Chinese and a rising nationalism shape Beijing's current thinking.
With regard to where China is headed, he said some believe China is headed for a bad end, while others are optimistic given China's movement toward becoming a global power.
There are conflicting possibilities and the United States must be mindful of all of them, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-NICARAGUA FTA TALKS TO BE COMPLETED IN APRIL: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan-Nicaragua consultations on a proposed free trade agreement (FTA) are expected to be completed in April this year at the earliest, an official of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Tuesday.

Chien Liang-chi, director of the MOF's Department of Customs Administration, said that Taiwan and Nicaragua have so far conducted three rounds of bilateral FTA talks and that both parties have reached consensus on several issues, such as anti-dumping duties and countervailing duties.
Nicaragua has expressed its satisfaction with a Taiwan-produced list of Nicaraguan farm and industrial products that will be allowed in, according to Chien.

However, he noted that the Nicaraguan government still has different opinions concerning tariff concessions on several kinds of products. He added that regulations on countries of origin have yet to be discussed.

As a result, Chien said, the two sides agreed to hold a fourth round of consultations in the Nicaraguan capital of Managua April 18- 22, in the hope that the two countries will complete their bilateral consultation talks and enter a formal FTA in the first half of this year. If everything goes smoothly, Nicaragua is expected to become Taiwan's second FTA partner after Panama.
Meanwhile, Chien disclosed that the first round of Taiwan-Guatemala FTA negotiations have also been completed and that a second round of talks is scheduled to be held April 11.

Noting that signing a FTA will be beneficial to economic and trade exchanges between the two signatory countries, Chien said that since the FTA signed between Taiwan and Panama came into force Jan. 1 last year, Taiwan's exports to Panama grew by around 100 percent in 2004, while imports from Panama posted a phenomenal growth of 200 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DELIVERS BROADSIDE AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The leaders of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lambasted China's anti-secession law Tuesday as Beijing's National People's Congress (NPC) was set to pass it, but have not decided whether to organize a large-scale demonstration to protest against it.
The DPP Central Standing Committee professed in a resolution its firm objection to the law, calling it a war-mandating bill that will disrupt the stability across the Taiwan Strait.

The resolution urges China to refrain from enacting the law, saying NPC discussion of the law has already stirred up Taiwan people's opposition and indignation. As the ruling party of Taiwan, the DPP will not sit idly by when Taiwan's status is changed by China unilaterally, the foundation of Taiwan's democracy is undermined, and the fundamental interests of Taiwan are hurt.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said the anti-secession law is a regressive act that provides China with an excuse to invade Taiwan.

He said his party wants to develop a peaceful framework with China to ensure long-term peace across the Taiwan Strait, but China should refrain from hurting the feelings of the Taiwan people and stop disrupting the peace and stability between the two sides.

The DPP secretary-general refused to say whether his party will greet the enactment of the law with a large-scale demonstration, saying that it depends on the text of the law, which has not yet made public.

The DPP has vowed to stage a mass demonstration in three scenarios -- if the anti-secession law imposes penalties on Taiwan people, or leads to changes to the status quo across the strait, or damages Taiwan's basic national interests.

In a related development Tuesday, DPP Legislator Lai Chin-teh, the whip of DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said his caucus would support whatever responses are taken by the DPP leadership and administration, such as amending the Constitution or staging a protest.

Premier Frank Hsieh suggested earlier in the day deleting the General Provisions of the Constitution which provide for the country's official name as the Republic of China should the anti-secession law mandate China to invade Taiwan with force at whatever time it wishes.
Lai said the people of Taiwan will certainly support the premier's suggestion if the scenario he described takes place.

Claiming that China's attempt to enact the law has destabilized the peace in the region, Lai called on the United States and the European Union to weigh in and mediate the disputes between Taiwan and China.

Yen Wan-chin, DPP deputy secretary-general, said the law gives China the option for taking over Taiwan by "non-peaceful means" under certain situations and pointed out that "non-peaceful means" is a euphemism for "use of force."
Therefore, the law is nothing but a war-mandating law, Yen said, adding that some political parties still claim the law is aimed at pro-independence activists in Taiwan.
He urged these parties to forge a common front with the DPP in facing up to China.

Yen said his party would like to encourage exchanges with China, including the start of direct transportation links across the strait, but added that the party has the responsibility to warn local people that Beijing has not given up its designs against Taiwan, a point they should keep in mind when dealing with China.

Legislator Chen Ching-chun, who is the secretary of the DPP caucus at the legislature, criticized China for turning a blind eye to the fact that Taiwan has been a separate state from China for a long time.
The anti-secession law has shown China's failure to realize the political reality and has underlined its aggressive characteristics, Chen said.
Chen said the DPP will not accept China's shameless assumption that it has the right to determine Taiwan's future and will never waver in its determination to defend the sovereignty of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN URGES TAIWAN, CHINA TO HANDLE TIES CALMLY

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong urged Taiwan and China Tuesday to deal with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs with calm and reason to avoid a miscalculation and to facilitate reconciliation.

Soong made the remarks in response to China's proposed anti-secession law, which will authorize the Beijing authorities to use non-peaceful means to check what it describes as "secessionist" activities on Taiwan.
The National People's Congress of China is expected to pass the law next week.

Soong pointed out that the cross-strait deadlock has resulted from the different choices made by Taiwan and China in terms of their economic and political systems, which he said is neither an ethnic problem nor a conflict between two countries.
Soong said that promoting the establishment of a Taiwanese identity is not equal to pushing for independence and that Beijing should respect the desire of the Taiwan people to be their own masters.

According to Soong, maintaining peace and the status quo should be the guiding principle in dealing with cross-strait relations because any unilateral move to change the cross-strait status quo will be unacceptable to the international community and to the people on both sides of the Strait.

He called Beijing's attention to what he said is a change in Taiwan's political situation after a meeting between himself and President Chen Shui-bian two weeks ago, in which Chen promised he will not change the official name of the country or draft a new constitution during his term.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIDOW OF ALLEGED '319' SHOOTER APOLOGIZES

TEXT.P: The widow of a man who police believe shot and slightly wounded President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu March 19, 2004 apologized Tuesday for her late husband's actions.

Speaking on a videotape shown by the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) , the widow of Chen Yi-hsiung said her husband had admitted firing the shots on the eve of the 2004 presidential election, which were widely claimed to have swung the vote in President Chen's favor.

"Concerning the shooting of President Chen, he (my husband) had taken responsibility, " said the woman, who kept her back to the camera. "I am deeply sorry for (the event's) causing harm to society. I apologize to the public and hope the whole thing will end here."
Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, was found dead in Anping harbor in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan March 29 last year -- 10 days after the shooting -- in what police have said was an apparent suicide.
His widow's videotaped apology came a day after police identified Chen Yi-hsiung as the key suspect in the shooting.

CIB Commissioner Hou Yu-ih, a key member of a special task force probing the shooting, said after showing the videotape at a news conference that he hopes the public will adopt a lenient and forgiving attitude toward Chen Yi-hsiung's bereaved family.
According to Hou, Chen Yi-hsiung's family members were "innocent third parties."

"It was understandable and forgivable that his family was reluctant to cooperate in the initial stage of the investigation, but they have finally come to the decision to face up to reality and make an apology for their loved one's action. I hope the public can also rationally face up to the reality and show leniency to Chen's bereaved family to avoid adding up to divisions and confrontation in society," Hou said.

President Chen and Lu were slightly wounded March 19, 2004 when two homemade bullets grazed them as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in Tainan. After the Chen-Lu ticket narrowly won re-election the following day, the sole challenging ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong accused the president of having staged the shooting to win sympathy votes and filed two lawsuits to challenge the election result. The shooting is believed to have gravely aggravated hostility between the ruling and opposition camps.
Hou said the police have devoted enormous amounts of manpower and energy to finally track down Chen Yi-hsiung.

"Throughout the investigation, the team has strictly followed Dr. Henry Lee's directive to track the gunman by tracing the flow of bullets and the gun used in the shooting, " Hou said, adding that the renowned Chinese-American forensic expert has contributed a great deal to the investigation with his comprehensive forensic report on the evidence collected at the crime scene.

Stressing that the breakthrough in the investigation was the hard-won result of concerted efforts of all team members, Hou said the breakthrough was not achieved with information provided by any private informer.
"Therefore, there will be no problem of who is eligible to claim the NT$53 million reward offered by the government for providers of useful clues to uncover the key suspect," Hou said.
According to Hou, the investigative team targeted Chen Yi- hsiung's family for intensive monitoring and repeat visits for at least four months.
"It was no easy task to 'break their psychological defense,'" he said.

"After we came to learn through wiretapping that they were preparing to destroy certain evidence, we decided to separately interrogate each family member. Through such isolated interrogation, we secured a major breakthrough last weekend. The family members underwent lie detection Sunday," Hou added.

Meanwhile, Kuo Chen-ni, a chief prosecutor responsible for the case, said that Chen Yi-hsiung's son, daughter-in-law and youngest daughter have all been listed as defendants because they claim to have burned their father's suicide notes and other evidence.

Nevertheless, Kuo said the trio may not necessarily be indicted because the Criminal Code exempts family members from the duty of reporting their loved ones' criminal activities. She said the family has been subject to maximum-guard protection by the investigative team and he urged the public and the media to refrain from harassing them.

Kuo further said the investigative team has targeted several places for an intensified search of the homemade pistol believed to be used in the shooting. She said Chen Yi-hsiung bought agun from an underground gunsmith through his brother-in-law. Kuo stressed that many witnesses have proved that Chen Yi-hsiung bought the gun prior to last March, but she would not reveal further details.
Premier Frank Hsieh said earlier in the day that the CIB report a day earlier on the major breakthrough does not mark an end to the investigation of the case.

"I personally sanctioned the report with a view to preventing the spread of rumors. After the key suspect's family confessed to his criminal action, the media would very quickly gain information. If the CIB failed to give an authoritative first-hand report, rumors would fly in our free-wheeling pluralistic society," Hsieh said.

The premier, a lawyer-turned-politician, said the investigative team must continue its probe into the whereabouts of the handgun used in the shooting and other evidence to back up its "breakthrough" report.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH NSC TO COPE WITH ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has met with the National Security Council to cope with China's plan to enact an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.
Hsieh told lawmakers during a legislative interpellation session that the president will make a final decision as to what steps the government will adopt in reaction to the legislation.

According to the key points of the draft law unveiled by the National People's Congress of China earlier in the day, the law will authorize the Beijing authorities to use non-peaceful means to check what they call "secessionist" activities on Taiwan.
Hsieh said Chen will still follow his "five noes" commitment regarding national status after the passage of the law by China.

The "five noes" refers to Chen's promise that if Beijing has no intention of using force against Taiwan, he will not declare independence, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum on independence or unification to change the cross-strait status quo and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council.

Hsieh said the government will not make any pro-active moves to amend the Constitution to counter the anti-secession law, but said he supports efforts by the people to change the Constitution based on a national consensus.
As to whether Taiwan and China will still remain in a state of peace after the enactment of the anti-secession law, Hsieh said the Cabinet will respect Chen's interpretation of the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO PONDER PEOPLE'S WELFARE WHILE ENACTING NEW LAW

TEXT.P: Leaders of several domestic industrial and business organizations voiced the hope Tuesday that China will take into consideration the long-term welfare of China and Taiwan residents when dealing with the anti-secession law targeting the island.

The Taiwan government should also seek to hold negotiations with the Beijing authorities so as to turn the crisis into a good opportunity to safeguard the rights and interests of the people of Taiwan, they said.

Wang Tiao-chun, secretary-general of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, and Chen Cheng-yi, spokesman for the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, made the appeals after China unveiled key points of the much-anticipated anti-secession law, including authorizing the State Council and the Central Military Commission to take "non-peaceful" action against Taiwan in certain situations.

Wang, who has been trying to act as a communication bridge between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and was also one of the promoters of the special direct cross-strait chartered flights launched during the Lunar New Year holiday, said that the proposed anti-secession law will certainly be passed by China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress (NPC) due to strong pressure from Beijing's diehard lawmakers.

However, Wang said the Beijing authorities have "softened" the wording of the new law to make a concession to Taiwan. For instance, "non-peaceful means" is used as a substitute for "use of force," Wang noted, adding that according to Beijing's presentation on the draft legislation, should China be forced to take military action against Taiwan, its military will do everything possible to protect the personal safety of the people of Taiwan.

Terming the planned anti-secession law as a stick in a carrot-and-stick approach adopted by the Beijing leadership, Wang said the government should seriously ponder what Taiwan needs at the moment, such as the island's presence in the international arena, and then seek to hold talks with Beijing on such issues.

Sharing Wang's viewpoints, Chen said that although the passage of the anti-secession law will not be blocked, the Beijing leadership should refrain from showing its hostility toward the people of Taiwan so that their feelings are not hurt.

He suggested that China postpone promulgating the anti-secession law or make it a political statement, which he said would make the people of Taiwan more confident of "China's goodwill" toward the island.
Wang Zhaoguo, a vice chairman of the NPC's Standing Committee unveiled the highlights of the controversial draft law in a report at the parliament's ongoing plenary session.

Wang said peaceful unification and the "one country, two systems" scheme are Beijing's basic approaches to achieving "peaceful reunification." However, he also stressed that China considers itself entitled to use force to check secessionist activities on Taiwan.

"Using non-peaceful means to stop secession in defence of our sovereignty and territorial integrity would be a last resort for us, after all our efforts for a peaceful reunification proved futile, " Wang told mainland lawmakers.

He said the draft legislation, which is expected to be passed next week, provides for the use of force "in the event that the Taiwan independence forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China."
Beijing has yet to publicize the full text of the so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PARTICIPATES IN FOODEX JAPAN 2005
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 8 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is participating in the 30th International Food and Beverage Exhibition of Japan with a large delegation of 70 farmers' groups and food companies, officials of Taiwan's representative office in Tokyo said Tuesday.

The Taiwan delegation, jointly organized by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , has established a 1,000-square-meter national pavilion in the exhibition venue to display more than 300 products.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the pavilion, TAITRA Chairman Hsu Chih-jen said Japan is the most important overseas market for Taiwan's agricultural products, absorbing 39 percent of its total exports.

The Taiwan pavilion will hold a series of activities during the exhibition, including the introduction of new products and taste-testing, to promote Taiwan's quality products based on health, safety and tastiness, he added.
The annual trade fair, which opened Tuesday at Makuhari Messe (Nippon Convention Center), will run through March 11.
A total of 450 group and individual exhibitors from 75 countries are taking part in the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MAKES CASE FOR TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGNTY TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian made a strong case for Taiwan's sovereignty in a television interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Tuesday.

In the 25-minute interview, Chen stressed that his country is a sovereign state that has never been ruled by the People's Republic of China (PRC) , therefore the PRC's claim that Taiwan is one of its provinces is groundless. The international community should not let Beijing take over the island and rob Taiwanese of their hard-earned freedom, democracy and rights, he said.

The president reiterated a promise he made in his 2000 inaugural address that he will not flirt with the idea of Taiwan independence during his term and stressed that he will refrain from declaring Taiwan independence as long as China refrains from invading Taiwan.

He expressed regret that Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer ruled out the possibility in Beijing last August that his country would help the United States to defend Taiwan in line with a treaty between Sydney and Washington.

Chen said the Taiwan issue is more than an issue of just Taiwan but is also an issue of the Asia-Pacific region and an issue of the entire world. If Taiwan, which is a strategic hub in the region, were to be annexed by China, the security of all the states in the region would be threatened, he said.
He urged Australia, as well as the United States and New Zealand, to have some empathy with Taiwan and to prevent the island from becoming an "orphan in international society."

In order to conduct the interview, an ABC TV crew flew to Palau and the Solomon Islands to meet with Chen when he visited those two South Pacific allies between Jan. 27-31. They caught glimpses of his trip there and accompanied him on his way back to Taiwan.

They also followed the president during his return to his Tainan home Feb. 9 for Chinese New Year and filmed him worshipping his ancestors, giving out red envelopes to his fellow townsmen, and chatting with the elderly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEALTH AUTHORITIES CONFIRM SAFETY OF CONSUMING U.S. BEEF

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) confirmed Tuesday that consuming U.S. beef is safe and that it will present its conclusion next week to the Executive Yuan.

DOH Food Safety Bureau Director Chen Lu-hung said the department reached the conclusion after holding three meetings of experts from the domestic zoological, veterinary, epidemic, public health and food science fields.
The Executive Yuan will decide if U.S. beef will be allowed to re-enter the Taiwan market after it receives the report, Chen said.

Taiwan suspended beef imports from the United States in December 2003 due to safety concerns over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) , also known as mad cow disease, after the discovery in Washington State of a BSE-infected cow at a ranch there.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS SEE FEW NEW IDEAS IN CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The anti-secession law to be enacted by China is more a declaration than a law with legal effect, Chang Wu-yueh, a professor of the Chinese Study Center at Tamkang University in Tanshui, Taipei County, claimed Tuesday.

The law is a document combining the current China policy toward Taiwan, mainly the eight-point guidelines spelled out by former Chinese President Jiang Zemin in 1995 and the four-point guidelines drawn up by Chinese President Hu Jintao March 4.
However, the disputes between Taiwan and China cannot be settled unilaterally and the prospects that China can settle them through a domestic law are slim, Chang said.

He disputed some local politicians' claims that the "non-peaceful" phrase used in the law means "military force," arguing that there are non-peaceful means short of the use of force, such as economic sanctions and psychological warfare.
In view of the great concern the bill has raised among Taiwan people, Chang urged Beijing not have recourse to the law to avoid alienating the Taiwan people.

Meanwhile, Huang Chieh-cheng, another professor from Tamkang University, said the law is harsher than expected and has ignored Taiwan public opinion. The Taiwan authorities should respond solemnly rather than with emotional criticism, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, March 9, or the 29th day of the first month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1454: Amerigo Vespucci, the Italian navigator who discovered the mouth of the Amazon River and gave his name to America, is born.
1562: In Naples, Italy, kissing in public is made punishable by death.
1796: Twenty-seven-year-old Napoleon Bonaparte, the brilliant young French commander of the Army of the Interior who later became king, weds Josephine, 33, a widow since her first husband the Vicomte de Beauharnais was guillotined in 1794.
1831: The French Foreign Legion is formed by King Louis Philippe, with its headquarters in Algeria, to serve in France's African colonies.
1846: Kashmir is ceded to the British East India Company in the Treaty of Lahore.
1905: Japanese forces defeat the Russians at Shenyang (Mukden) in northern China.
1923: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin suffers a massive stroke and resigns as leader of the Soviet Union.
1932: "Manchukuo," the name given to Japanese-controlled Manchuria, is formally founded at a ceremony held in Changchun, with Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, installed as president.
1933: A strong earthquake rocks California, killing 123 people and injuring more than 4,150 others.
1942: Japan finally takes the Dutch island of Java in Indonesia after the surrender of Allied forces.
1945: A power plant at Taiwan's Sun Moon Lake is bombed and destroyed by Allied planes during World War II.
1945: The U.S. Army captures the German city of Bonn near the end of World War II.
1955: The Commission for Examining Foreign Exchange and Trade under the Executive Yuan decides that the nominal quotation of exchange settlements in Taiwan banks should be US$1 to NT$6.
1959: King Hussein of Jordan arrives in Taipei for an eight-day state visit.
1975: The Honduran Consulate in Taipei reopens.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a certificate to John M. King of Cornell University for his contribution to hog research in Taiwan.
1978: Shih Ming-chen, a crew member on a China Airlines flight from Taipei to Hong Kong, is killed after a failed attempt to hijack the plane to Kwangchow (Canton).
1987: Iraq is accused by Iran of using chemical weapons in the ongoing war between the two countries.
1990: East Germany and West Germany begin preliminary reunification talks.
1991: The Straits Exchange Foundation formally begins operations.
1992: Menachem Begin, former Israeli prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1978 for his part in the Camp David settlement with Egyptian President Anwar Sadat, dies of a heart attack in Tel Aviv at the age of 78.
1995: The United States signs a deal with its allies to supply North Korea with two nuclear reactors.
1996: George Burns, one of America's best loved and most enduring entertainers, dies at the age of 100.
1997: Two astronomical phenomena -- rarely enough occurring on their own -- happen simultaneously. A full solar eclipse occurs at the same time a comet is visible in the atmosphere over the Mo River near Heilungkiang on the Chinese mainland. Such coincidences occur on average once every 2,500 years.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a two-year extension of the Technology Cooperative Agreement between the Republic of China and the Republic of Panama.
2001: The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation celebrates the 10th anniversary of its founding and calls for the early resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If one could only live a moral life, renouncing himself and conforming to the ideal of decency and good sense for one single day, the world would become moral. To be moral, a man depends entirely upon himself and not upon others."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OPPOSES NON-PEACEFUL MEANS ON TAIWAN ISSUE: BOUCHER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 8 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Commenting on China's proposed anti-secession law, a U.S. State Department spokesman said Tuesday that the United States has always opposed any attempt to determine the future of Taiwan by non-peaceful means.

Although the full text of the anti-secession law targeting Taiwan has not actually been released, Wang Zhaoguo, a deputy chairman of the Chinese National People's Congress Standing Committee, described the keys points of the law Tuesday to the nearly 3,000 NPC members gathered at the Great Hall of the People. The law includes the authorization of non-peaceful actions to resolve the Taiwan issue in certain situations.

When asked about this point, U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher quoted a journalist as noting that the anti-secession law calls for non-peaceful means possibly to be directed at Taiwan. "We have always opposed any attempt to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means," Boucher said.
"We've talked about this with people in the PRC as well as people on Taiwan. We've had continuing discussions with both sides and we expect that dialogue and discussion will continue," he added.

Meanwhile, he also said that the anti-secession legislation issue had not come up when Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice talked with her Chinese counterpart, Li Zhaoxing, over telephone the day before.

When asked whether Rice will raise the issue during her meetings with Chinese leaders when she visits Beijing next week, Boucher said that "if eventually I confirm that she's going to make a trip and that China might be part of that trip, then I would expect her to discuss the Taiwan questions in Beijing."

In a written statement issued Tuesday evening, the State Department said that Rice and other members of the U.S. administration have expressed concern to Chinese officials that the anti-secession law "may be counterproductive and is not helpful in the current environment, where there are opportunities for exchanges that could move forward a peaceful resolution of outstanding cross-strait differences."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PACIFIC COMMANDER CALLS ANTI-SECESSION LAW 'DISCONCERTING'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 8 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's proposed anti-secession legislation is disconcerting, the commander of the U.S. Pacific Command said Tuesday.

Adm. William Fallon, who assumed his post in late February, made the remarks at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing during which he was asked to give his general evaluation of Beijing's so-called anti-secession law and the U.S. aircraft carrier deployment in the West Pacific in light of this new development.

"It's disconcerting that this legislation has been put forward, because I think it hardens the line, and it apparently gives them a legal basis of sorts for the potential for military action later on," the admiral said.
Fallon added that he doesn't think the new legislation would be useful in lessening tensions between Taiwan and China.
As to U.S. capabilities in the West Pacific, Fallon said the presence of a carrier strike group in the Far East certainly has been very useful in the past for a number of events.

"This ready capability forward-deployed, I think, is a very good idea, particularly given the vast distances across the Pacific, " he said, adding that "having this much robust power forward-deployed gives us a lot of options for quick response."

"And some of it is certainly to deter potential military actions, but there are other times when it comes in very handy, like the tsunami relief effort, when we happened to have another carrier out there that was nearby and could divert down there and work the issue," Fallon said.
The National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament -- began to screen the so-called anti-secession bill Tuesday and is expected to pass it next week.

The Straits Times: No-smoking areas to be extended from Oct.
Smokers should get ready to stub out-there will be even fewer public places to light up in from Oct 1.
The no-smoking ban will be extended to bus shelters and interchanges, public pools and toilets, community clubs and open-air stadiums, as Singapore intensifies its war against cancer- causing nicotine.
After that, the Government will mount another assault later in the year, at pubs and discos.
Yet another target it is eyeing: hawker centres and coffee shops. A decision will be made by year-end.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 80 PERCENT OF SCHOOLCHILDREN ARE HAPPY: POLL

TEXT.P: Over three-quarters of schoolchildren in Taiwan are happy, according to a poll by the monthly magazine Power.

The survey, conducted on Grade 5 and 6 students in 41 elementary schools around Taiwan, found that 78.5 percent of the schoolchildren respondents said they feel happy. A total of 2,019 valid samples were collected in the survey.
By region, central Taiwan showed the highest percentage of happy children, at 80.2 percent, while northern Taiwan had the lowest, at 75 percent.

Some of the reasons cited by the schoolchildren for their happiness included having a warm family and good friends, and not having to worry about food or clothing. The survey found that performance on school exams and pocket money were not factors determining a child's level of happiness.

The survey also found that only 41 percent of schoolchildren feel that they will be even happier in the future. Interpreting this result, Chai Sung-lin, a national policy adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, and Tsai Wen-tze, a psychiatrist at National Taiwan University Hospital, said it reflects the feeling of uncertainty among schoolchildren.

Meanwhile, the survey also showed that 88.8 percent of the schoolchildren respondents are happy to go to school. Among those who said they are not happy going to school, 58.7 percent cited a heavy school workload as the reason, while 23 percent mentioned punishment by school teachers or feelings of boredom. Chai said this shows that education institutions still have room to improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR CITIZENS ACCOUNT FOR 9% OF TAIWAN'S TOTAL POPULATION

TEXT.P: Senior citizens made up 9 percent of Taiwan's overall population in 2004, higher than the global average of 7 percent, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Wednesday.
Taiwan ranked third in Asia in terms of the ratio of senior citizens to total population, trailing only Japan, at 19 percent, and Hong Kong, at 12 percent.

In 2004, DGBAS officials said, the global aging index, calculated by dividing the number of people aged 65 or over by the number of people aged below 14, stood at 23.3. A higher index indicates a greyer population.

Taiwan became an aging society as defined by the United Nations in 1993 when the ratio of the country's senior citizens reached 7 percent of the total population for the first time. Over the past decade, DGBAS officials said, Taiwan's population has been greying at a rapid pace, with the aging index rising from 28.2 in 1993 to 45 in 2004.
In terms of life expectancy, North American people topped the list in 2004, with an average life span of 78 years, while Africans had the lowest life expectancy, at 52 years.
Asia's average life expectancy was 67 years in 2004, while Taiwan's was 76 years, or the same level as in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER OPPOSES MEMBERSHIP FEE REQUIREMENT FOR KMT CHAIRMAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), voiced opposition Wednesday to a party rule requiring members to pay membership fees to gain the right to vote in the chairmanship election.
Raising the issue at the party's weekly Central Standing Committee meeting, Wang said a majority of KMT members will not be able to participate in the election because of this requirement.

While the KMT has more than one million members, only about 200,000 to 300,000 members, most of whom are elderly, will determine the outcome of the election because of the membership fee requirement, Wang pointed out.
Wang said the KMT must study whether the membership fee requirement is in violation of legal principles and, if it is found to be so, amend the rule.

Wang claimed that the membership fee requirement stipulated in the existing rules governing the chairmanship election is against the party charter which states that party chairman should be elected by all rank-and-file members.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, another KMT vice chairman, said he supports any rules that are fair, reasonable and open.
Ma has announced his bid to run in the next chairmanship election set for May, and Wang is also expected to announce his decision to run for the post soon.
The KMT had originally planned to pass its schedule for the election during the meeting. However, the item was not included in the agenda owing to the dispute over the membership fee issue.

Liao Feng-teh, head of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, said the chairmanship election is being held according to established rules and that amendments will be required if party members disagree with any of these rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP UNWAVERING ON OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW: PARTY WHIP

TEXT.P: China's war-mandating anti-secession law is a heartless piece of legislation that completely disregards the fact that Taiwan is a sovereign state, the whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan said Wednesday.

DPP Legislator Lai Ching-teh, head of the DPP legislative caucus, said that the DPP lawmakers are unwaveringly determined to defend the sovereignty of Taiwan and will fight to the last ditch against the law that gives China the option for taking over Taiwan by "non-peaceful means."

Speaking at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan, Lai quoted former Chinese President Jiang Zemin as saying to the CPC Central Military Commission when he resigned from his post as the head of China's military Tuesday that "the military should prepare itself to take over Taiwan."

"This indicates explicitly that Beijing has been playing a two-handed game -- claiming attempts to push for peaceful unification with Taiwan while enacting a law to give it an excuse to invade Taiwan -- to fool the people of Taiwan," Lai claimed.
Lai said that prior to Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, the former Iraqi president also had a law enacted that claimed that "the Kuwaiti people were looking forward to Iraqi rule of Kuwait."

Describing China's legislation as no different from the Iraqi model, Lai called for the Chinese leaders Hu Jintao and Wen Jiabao not to follow Saddam's path, which will eventually lead the two sides to doomsday.
Lai also called for party leaders from across Taiwan's political spectrum to meet for a summit soon to jointly craft Taiwan's countermeasures against the anti-secession law.

Meanwhile, Kuo Chun-ming, a deputy DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, noted that Beijing kept the "sack" wide open before Hong Kong was returned to China, but tightened the opening gradually after Hong Kong's handover in 1997.
Kuo urged the people of Taiwan to view Hong Kong's situation today, particularly its increasingly depleting democracy, and take the Hong Kong example as a lesson.

Kuo also urged opposition parties to throw their support behind the government in its arms procurement plan, saying that only by beefing up Taiwan's defense capability can the island talk to Beijing from a position of strength.
