DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER OPPOSES CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng expressed opposition Wednesday to China's enactment of an anti-secession law, although he added that it is more appropriate for heads of other relevant government agencies to make remarks in this regard.

Tu made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan session after opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Legislator Lo Chih-ming pressed Tu for an answer on his position regarding Beijing's legislation of the anti-secession law.

Lo said that while the Ministry of Education (MOE) is teaching Taiwan's next generation that the Republic of China is a sovereign state, Beijing is enacting a law stipulating that Taiwan is a part of China, which will not compromise on threats to its territorial integration.
Lo demanded that Tu teach Taiwan's youth that Taiwan is not a part of China.
In response, Tu said the MOE will enhance teaching about the country and further nurture patriotism in students so that they can then make their own judgments about themselves and the country.

Meanwhile, the education minister said that the ministry's policy of subsidizing the education of children of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China -- known in Taiwan as "Taishang" -- will continue.

Noting that Taishang children are also the children of Taiwan, Tu said that if the government does not exert any influence on Taishang children, they will end up receiving Chinese education and being fed Chinese ideology.
Tu continued that the MOE is also planning to allow Taishang children to attend schools ranging from elementary schools to technology institutes in the ROC-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
Tu made the remarks in response to questions raised by TSU Legislator Tseng Tsan-deng, who accused the MOE of inappropriately spending too much money on Taishang childrens' education.

It is unfair that the government should foot the bill of about NT$30,000 for each Taishang child each year while the Taishang pay no taxes in Taiwan under the current taxation laws, Tseng pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OPPOSES BEIJING USE OF FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN: PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) strongly opposes Beijing's use of force against Taiwan and will do its utmost to secure the welfare of the Taiwan people by upholding the Republic of China Constitution, KMT spokesman Cheng Lee-wen said Wednesday.
Cheng was quoting remarks made by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the weekly meeting of the party's policy-deciding Central Standing Committee.

According to Cheng, Lien said that the KMT is opposed to Beijing's threats to launch military action to resolve its disputes with Taiwan and he claimed that Taiwan independence is unnecessary. Lien vowed to protect the benefits and interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait under the framework of the Constitution.

Regarding Beijing's ongoing legislation of an anti-secession law apparently aimed at curbing Taiwan independence, Lien was cited as saying that pro-Taiwan independence activists represent only a small number of people in Taiwan society.
The Taiwan-centric concept is very important but it is not tantamount to Taiwan independence, Lien said, urging Beijing to adequately deal with the ROC and its people.

To safeguard Taiwan, the KMT will not yield to any pro-Taiwan independence movements, such as "one country on either side of the strait, " the "two-state theory, " "writing a new constitution" or "holding a referendum on Taiwan's future" and the "one country, two systems" formula, he noted, insisting that the ROC is an independent and sovereign state.

Under the prerequisite that the cross-strait status quo remains intact, the KMT fervently hopes that Taiwan and China will re-open stalled negotiations as soon as possible to step up bilateral exchanges and avoid confrontation in any form, he said.
The KMT is Taiwan's leading opposition party, controlling 79 seats in the 225-member Legislative Yuan, behind only the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has 89 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC HEAD DOES NOT EXCLUDE POSSIBILITY OF REFERENDUM ON BEIJING LAW

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Wednesday that he does not exclude the possibility of Taiwan holding a nationwide referendum to say "no" to Beijing's anti-secession law legislation.

Chang said it is possible that a nationwide referendum opposing China's anti-secession law could be held simultaneously with the elections for the mission-oriented National Assembly (NA) if an endorsement on the referendum initiative is completed 40 days ahead of the NA elections.
The CEC has set May 14 as the polling day for the National Assembly election.

Noting that the CEC has no right to initiate a referendum, Chang said, however, that it would be relatively difficult for the 23 million people of Taiwan to call for a referendum 40 days ahead of May 14 and noted that it would be easier if the Legislative Yuan or President Chen Shui-bian were to take the initiative to start a nationwide referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained 43 points to close at 6,198, with 21,598 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for April moved up 31 points to finish at 6,196, with 1,843 contract transactions, while June futures increased 25 points to close at 6,181, with 66 contracts traded. September futures gained 15 points to finish at 6,085, with 122 contract transactions, while December futures moved up five points to close at 6,100, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,155 points for March, 6,165 points for April, 6,156 points for June, 6,070 points for September and 6,095 points for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

March TE futures gained 1.45 points to close at 234.95, with 3,105 contracts changing hands, while April TE futures moved up 1.65 points to finish at 235.15, with 203 contract transactions. June TE futures increased 2.8 points to close at 234.9 points, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September and December.

March TF futures increased 4.8 points to finish at 1,013, with 2,697 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures gained 4.8 points to close at 1,013.8, with 241 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened low but closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 39.94 points to close at 6,213.28.

The bourse opened at 6,163.56 points and fluctuated between 6,227.13 and 6,163.56 during trading. A total of 3.57 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$84.01 billion (US$2.71 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving up the most by 1.3 percent, followed by banking and financial stocks by 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics issues by 0.6 percent, cement shares by 0.4 percent and construction stocks by 0.1 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most by 0.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks by 0.5 percent and textile shares by 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 587 to 308, with 107 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION URGED TO MAINTAIN REASON DESPITE DOUBTS OVER 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged the opposition Wednesday to avoid resorting to irrational methods to express their doubts over the investigations into last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Hsieh made the remarks during a Cabinet meeting after a "major breakthrough" recently reported by the police on their investigations into the shooting of March 19, 2004 that left Chen and Lu slightly injured was dismissed by the Kuomintang (KMT) -led opposition as totally implausible.

Police said Monday they had identified a man found drowned in a suspected suicide last year as the alleged shooter by tracing clues left by the two home-made bullets used in the shooting, although the gun has yet to be found. The man was said to be an opposition supporter who allegedly committed the shooting to vent his resentment at Chen's administration.

The KMT, which believes the shooting was set up by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to give it an advantage in the election, is planning to mobilize 100,000 people in a rally in front of the Presidential Office on the anniversary of the shooting next Saturday to press for the "truth."
Commenting on the KMT's move, Hsieh said taking to the streets will not help resolve the problem because the pursuit of truth should be based on mutual trust.
Hsieh promised that the government will continue its investigations into the shooting to answer the many doubts raised by the public.

He pointed out that the shooting has polarized Taiwan society into two camps that believe two extremely different stories and that many people, including the president, vice president, medical workers and security officials, have been hurt in the face of the disbelief and doubts.
Under these circumstances, people tend to reject facts and evidence that are inconsistent with their beliefs, Hsieh said.
Hsieh said he agrees with Chinese-American forensic expert Henry Lee, who called the breakthrough "extraordinary" in light of the lack of direct evidence in the case.
Hsieh said he has requested the police to improve their investigation skills and continue to track down the gun and investigate the cause of the suspect's death.
If necessary, the police can seek the assistance of international experts, he added.
The premier said he understands that finding the truth behind the 319 shooting is the common expectation of the people, even though they may have differing interpretations of the case.
He urged political parties and their leaders to help build up a trustful and rational society that values evidence and facts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL NOT ACCEPT VIOLENT MEANS TO VENT DISCONTENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu are willing to accept criticism and suggestions, but they cannot accept anyone using violent means to vent their dissatisfaction, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

Chen Wen-chung, director of the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office, made the remarks in response to suggestions by the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) that President Chen should apologize to the Taiwan people for his poor performance in office and pardon the family of an alleged gunman who shot the president on the eve of the 2004 presidential election.

The TSU urged President Chen to emulate the approach of "sagacious kings of the past" who would issue an imperial order to blame themselves for poor performance that caused suffering for the people. President Chen should blame himself for the economic downturn and even the March 19 shooting, according to the TSU.
In response, the presidential spokesman said that a task force is still investigating the gunman and truth of the March 19 shooting and that the case is yet to be solved.

"Everyone should respect the professional and independent investigation of the law enforcers and the judicial proceedings in uncovering the truth, " the spokesman said, adding that not even the president or the vice president should intervene in the case.

He said President Chen and Lu have done their best during their past five years in office and are willing to accept criticism and suggestions with humility, although a smooth administration will require the concerted efforts of the ruling and the opposition parties.

"We are unable to accept anyone who uses violent methods, or even shooting, to vent their dissatisfaction, " the spokesman said, adding that such deeds are intolerable in a democratic society and a nation based on human rights.

TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said Wednesday that although there is indirect evidence to show that the alleged gunman, Chen Yi-hsiung, shot the president due to disappointment and discontent over his poor performance, he has since committed suicide and the gun he used has not been found, so that the police have been unable to announce a solution of the case.

TSU officials also said the president owes an apology to the general public and that he should pardon the family of the suspect so as to create an atmosphere conducive to the reconciliation of the people and not just target one party for reconciliation. They were referring to a high-profile meeting between President Chen and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Feb. 24, which was touted as "inter-party reconciliation."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: 'We offered to shoot the killers of McCartney' -- IRA.
The IRA meant to kill when it offered to shoot Provisionals who murdered the Belfast man Robert McCartney, the Northern Ireland chief constable said today. Hugh Orde also confirmed that his detectives know the identities of the gang members suspected of stabbing the father of two to death, but their investigation is being thwarted by witnesses refusing to give evidence. Mr Orde appealed for a return to the rule of law in the wake of the astonishing statement from the Provisional IRA offering to shoot the men blamed for the murder of Robert McCartney. The macabre offer was made to Mr McCartney's family by a Provisional representative following a five-hour meeting between IRA members and Mr McCartney's five sisters and fiancee.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN SHOULD NOT BE PHASED OUT: EX-CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body that supervises government operations, should not be abolished or incorporated into other branches in the future constitutional re-engineering plan, a former Control Yuan chief said Wednesday.
Former Control Yuan President Frederick Chien made the appeal in an acceptance speech delivered after receiving a decoration from President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.

Chen decorated Chien with the Order of Chiang Chung-cheng with Grand Cordon in recognition of Chien's contributions to upgrading the Control Yuan's functions in protecting human rights and enhancing political accountability and transparency, as well as boosting Taiwan's democratic development in a sound and positive direction.

Chien, a career diplomat who once served as minister of foreign affairs and representative to the United States, said the Control Yuan has been a very important organ in the Republic of China's constitutional political system.

"The ROC Constitution devotes six chapters to regulating the powers and functions of the executive branch of the central government. And the number of provisions concerning the Control Yuan is only second to the number of clauses related to the presidency. This indicates that the initiators of our constitution had high expectations of the role of the Control Yuan in the government's operations, " Chien said, adding that more than 100 countries around the world now have organs similar to the Control Yuan.

Some people have suggested that the Control Yuan be abolished and that its powers be incorporated either into the legislative or administrative branch in the government's constitutional re-engineering project.

"My observation is that such proposals would adversely affect the exercise of the Control Yuan powers. The Control Yuan powers must be exercised independently to ensure neutrality and impartiality in supervising government operations," Chien said, adding his hope that Chen will take his views into consideration.

Chien's tenure ended Jan. 31 along with all other Control Yuan members. President Chen has presented a list of nominations for new Control Yuan president, vice president and 27 seats in the watchdog body for the approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan in line with the Constitution. However, the legislature has so far declined to screen the list and has instead asked the president to come up with a new list. Chen has rejected such a demand, saying that the request infringes upon his power of nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION BILL IS PROVOCATIVE: U.S. HOUSE REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: David Wu, the only representative of Taiwanese origin in the U.S. House of Representatives, said Tuesday that China's decision to enact a so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan is a provocative act.
It is regrettable that the People's Republic of China has started to screen an anti-secession bill at a moment when cross-Taiwan Strait relations are improving significantly, said Wu.

In conjunction with several other representatives, Wu (D-Oregon) introduced Resolution No. 70 at the House of Representatives, urging the U.S. government to express opposition to Beijing's proposed anti-secession law.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- began to screen the bill Tuesday, which provides the legal basis for China's use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan in certain situations, and is expected to pass it next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE STAY UP, GET UP LATEST AMONG ASIANS: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, March 9 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan stay up longest and get up the latest compared with other Asians, with 69 percent going to bed after midnight and 26 percent not getting up until after 9 a.m., according to the results of a study released recently by ACNielsen.

The survey on global sleep habits was conducted by the world's leading marketing information provider in October among more than 14,100 consumers in 28 countries across the Asia Pacific region, Europe and the United States.
It was found that 40 percent of people in the Asia Pacific region do not go to sleep until after midnight, which is higher than the 34 percent among Americans and 32 percent among Europeans.
Among the top 10 "night-owl nations" in the world, seven are in Asia, the survey shows.
After Taiwan, the other six countries or areas are South Korea, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia and Thailand.
The Portuguese, however, are the latest sleepers in the world, with 75 percent not going to bed until after midnight.
Meanwhile, 60 percent of Asians and Americans are out of bed by 7 a.m., compared with 50 percent of Europeans.
The Indonesians are the number-one early-rising nation in the world, with 91 percent getting up by 7 a.m.
Among Asia-Pacific nations, the Australians are the earliest sleepers, with 24 percent in bed by 10 p.m., followed by 19 percent of New Zealanders.
The Australians and New Zealanders are also the nations getting the most sleep in the region, with 31 percent and 28 percent, respectively, sleeping more than nine hours a day on average.
Getting the least sleep are the Japanese, with 41 percent sleeping six hours or less.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOICES CONCERN TO U.S. OVER CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has relayed the government's grave concern to Washington over China's proposed anti-secession legislation targeting Taiwan, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Wednesday.
Lu said the MOFA has transmitted Taiwan's stance and concern to Washington and added that the government has noted the remarks made by the U.S. government on the issue.

According to Lu, the MOFA views Washington's remarks as a repeat of its long-standing stance on cross-Taiwan Strait relations -- that it opposes any attempts by either side to change the status quo and that it opposes any non-peaceful means to settle Taiwan's future.

U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher reiterated a call for dialogue between Taiwan and China, pointing out that "passage of legislation is not going to help resolve the problem" across the strait.

Boucher said it has been the long-term U.S. stance to oppose any attempts to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means. He suggested that Beijing reconsider the enactment of the proposed anti-secession law and called on the two sides to be rational and to avoid confrontation.

The National People's Congress (NPC) , Beijing's ceremonial parliament, is currently reviewing the anti-secession provisions aimed at curbing Taiwan independence. It is expected to pass the law next week, the full text of which will be made known by that time.

Wang Zhaoguo, vice chairman of the NPC's Standing Committee, explained the anti-secession law Tuesday, saying that Beijing will do its best to obtain peaceful unification with Taiwan but that it will use non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to protect its sovereignty and territorial integrity should all possibilities for peaceful unification be exhausted.
Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council immediately responded by blasting the law as a blank check for an invasion of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IN AUSTRALIA PROTEST AGAINST BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Taiwan expatriates residing in Australia went to the Chinese embassy in Canberra Wednesday to protest against China's proposed anti-secession law.

The proposed law is now being reviewed by the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament. The law will give Beijing a legal basis to use force against Taiwan should it move toward independence.

Nearly 300 Taiwan expatriates and representatives from Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Canberra and Perth converged on the Chinese embassy to deliver a protest letter and to urge Beijing to address Taiwan public opinion by refraining from enacting the law.

The protesters then went to the U.S., British and Japanese embassies and expressed appreciation to a recently issued joint statement by the U.S. and Japan that Taiwan is a mutual security concern during a Security Cnsultative Committee meeting in Washington D.C.

They also placed advertisements in the Australian, the largest national paper in Australia, urging the Australian government and others to address China's attempts to unilaterally change the status quo of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA STILL HAS MISGIVINGS ABOUT ALLOWING U.S. BEEF INTO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday that it still has misgivings about allowing beef from the United States to enter Taiwan.

Officials from COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine made the remarks in the wake of confirmation the previous day from the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) on the safety of consuming U.S. beef and that the DOH will present its conclusion next week to the Executive Yuan for a final decision.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million-worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before it imposed the ban in December 2003 in the wake of a case of mad cow disease in Washington State. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.
The DOH suggested that when imports of U.S. beef are allowed, only beef that is less than a certain number of months old will be allowed in, and that offal and the bones will still be prohibited.

But bureau officials noted that the United States only started to regulate the registration of cattle last July, and they questioned if the regulations have been fully implemented and monitoring rigorously carried out.
In addition, they said that the methods used to determine the age of the cattle vary and that the results are not necessarily correct.

They further said that Japan, which is an affected area of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, the scientific name for mad cow disease, has expressed safety concerns about reopening its markets to U.S. beef.
"As a non-affected country, Taiwan must act even more cautiously," they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY 68.57% COMPLETE AND SCHEDULED TO OPEN OCT. 31

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-speed railway is on schedule to be opened on Oct. 31 this year, an official of the Bureau of High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Wednesday.
Total construction for the 345 kilometer railway and facilities, including six stations, is 68.57 percent complete, the official noted.
The buildings for the six high-speed rail stations, located in Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi, Tainan and Kaohsiung, are finished and the interiors are 57.98 percent complete.
The actual rail line is 75.16 percent complete, the official said, adding that the headquarters and several maintenance yards were 39.88 percent finished as of the end of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESS MAY SANCTION FIRMS IF E.U. LIFTS ARMS BAN AGAINST CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 8 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Chuck Hagel (R-Neb.) said Tuesday that if the European Union lifts its arms embargo against China, some in Congress might support sanctions against companies in the EU who trade with China.

Hagel said that what the United States worries about is dual-use technology falling into the hands of the wrong people, adding that " ...obviously, sophisticated technology enhances anyone who possesses that technology -- their defense capability, their intelligence capacity."
But he also said, "We have some rather stringent laws in the United States to ensure, as best as we can, that doesn't happen."
Asked whether he thinks Congress will impose sanctions against companies if the embargo is lifted and companies start trading with China, Hagel replied that he didn't know if that would be an option.
"But there are those here in Congress who might well support something like that," Hagel said.
Hagel is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations International Economic Policy, Export and Trade Promotion Subcommittee and the co-chairman of the Congressional-Executive Commission on China.
The EU imposed the arms embargo against China shortly after its bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989. Recently, the EU has been mulling lifting the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Maskhadov Declared Dead in FSB Sweep.
FSB special forces officers killed Chechen rebel leader Aslan Maskhadov in a special operation in the Chechen village Tolstoy-Yurt, Federal Security Service director Nikolai Patrushev told President Vladimir Putin in televised remarks Tuesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Data Is Lacking on Iran's Arms, U.S. Panel Says.
A report due this month will describe U.S. intelligence on Iran's weapons programs as inadequate to allow firm judgments.
Wall Street Journal: Fannie Mae Is Cited for 'Deficiencies'.
Fannie Mae's regulator announced that it has instructed the mortgage company to correct "deficiencies" in its controls over accounting ledgers and other corporate records.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ASKS FOR PERMANENT JAPAN VISA-FREE TREATMENT FOR TAIWANESE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs urged Japan Wednesday to grant permanent visa-free treatment to visitors from Taiwan on the eve of temporary half-year, visa-exemption privileges that begin Friday.

A foreign ministry spokesman called on Japan to continue its visa-free treatment designed for Taiwan tourists visiting the 2005 World Exposition, to be held in Aichi from March 25 to Sept. 25, after the event to help bolster two-way exchanges and to reciprocate Taiwan's treatment of Japanese tourists.
Taiwan has been offering visa-free treatment for Japanese visitors since 1993, the spokesman noted.
The Japanese Cabinet approved the visa-free measures on March 4 to lure Taiwan tourists to the Aichi World Exposition.
In compliance with the set of measures, visitors from Taiwan with valid Republic of China passports will be allowed to enter Japan visa-free from March 11 to Sept. 25 for up to 90 days.

However, the rule is not available for those Taiwan people who plan to work or engage in money-making performances in Japan and the Japanese government is entitled to deny entry to non grata individuals.
The Japanese government also has the power to temporarily and fully or partially suspend the measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO ISSUE EXPLANATORY BOOKLETS ON 319 SHOOTING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) is scheduled to publish explanatory booklets in English to expound on recent developments surrounding the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, outgoing GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung said Monday.

Lin, who tendered his resignation last week in preparation for seeking the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the year-end mayoral election in the central city of Taichung, made the remarks during a meeting with his successor, Yao Wen-chih, president of TTV Culture Co., a publishing arm of Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd.

GIO staff are working hard to compile explanatory booklets in English concerning the incident, Lin said. He added that contents of such pamphlets will include results of the two lawsuits filed by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in an attempt to nullify President Chen's re-election victory in the March 20 election, subsequent developments of a "319 shooting investigation commission" and the latest progress made by the police in the investigation into the mysterious election-eve shooting.

According to Lin, all the explanatory booklets will be offered to foreign media organizations through Republic of China's representative offices so that the international community can gain a better understanding of related developments after the presidential election.

Chen and Lu were slightly wounded in the election-eve shooting when two bullets grazed their bodies as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in the southern city of Tainan. They defeated the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong by a slim margin of less than 30,000 ballots, or 0.228 percent of the 13 million votes cast.

The "pan-blue alliance" insinuated that the shooting was staged to boost the chances of Chen's re-election and filed two lawsuits to appeal for an annulment of Chen's victory and for a new election. Both suits were rejected.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' MARKS STARK VIOLATION OF U.N. CHARTER: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday that Beijing's proposed "anti-secession law" is a brutal piece of legislation to force Taiwan into its fold.

"The proposed legislation reveals China's desire to use the law to unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait. It's an act of provocation and a stark violation of the U.N. Charter, " Lu said.
The outspoken vice president made the comments during an informal meeting with the media a day after Beijing unveiled the draft version of its so-called "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.

Lu said although Beijing claims it will pursue peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, it sets a prerequisite for negotiations that Taiwan must accept its cardinal "one China" principle and its ultimate goal of unification.

"The gist of China's 'anti-secession' bill lies in Beijing's demand that Taiwan unify with China. If Taiwan accepts this, peace could prevail. Otherwise, Beijing could use non-peaceful means against Taiwan. Once the bill is enacted, cross-strait relations will be in an extremely dangerous state, " Lu said.

By clearly stating in the "anti-secession" bill that completing China's unification is a sacred mission for all Chinese people, including Taiwanese residents, Lu said the provision has revealed China's ambition for hegemony.
"Beijing intends to annex Taiwan. Should that be the case, the 23 million people of Taiwan would form 1.8 percent of China's total population. How outrageous is such hegemonic thinking," Lu lamented.

Stressing that the use of "non-peaceful" means prescribed in China's "anti-secession" bill is the use of force in disguise, Lu claimed that the enactment of the bill would unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.
"It's tantamount to an act of provocation and runs against the U.N. Charter and the 1984 U.N. declaration that recognizes people's rights to enjoy permanent peace," Lu said.

Lu, a legal scholar-turned-politician, urged local academics in international law to prudently study how Taiwan can protect its security, dignity and well-being in the face of China's new "legal battle" against Taiwan.

Asked whether the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will organize a large protest march against Beijing's "anti-secession law, " Lu said she will respect President Chen Shui-bian's decision. "Protest can come in various forms. We can resort to soft-tone diplomatic measures to express our indignation and protest," Lu said.
Lu is scheduled to leave Taipei this weekend for a Central America diplomatic tour that will take her to two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in the region -- Guatemala and El Salvador.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER SUPPORTS REFERENDUM ON ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Wednesday he supports the proposal to hold a referendum on the government's long-stalled massive arms procurement project simultaneously with the May 14 National assembly elections.
Lee made the remarks while fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan question-and-answer session.

It marked an about-face in Lee's attitude toward holding a referendum on arms procurement issues. In the past, Lee once said that as arms procrement involved professional judgment, such issues should not be put forth for a referendum.
Lee said as local people have become more supportive of the procurement project, he is convinced that the referendum result will be in favor of the project.

The opposition-controlled legislature has declined to screen a special statute that would authorize the administration to appropriate special funds to purchase three kinds of advanced weapons from the United States -- eight diesel-electric submarines, six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.
Lu said the results of recent public opinion poll show that the number of proponents of the special arms procurement project has been increasing steadily.

During the legislative session, Lee also said if the legislature eventually cuts the budget for the project, the Ministry of National Defense will give the priority to purchasing eight diesel-electric submarines.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA IS BREAKING THROUGH DEFENSIVE ISLAND CHAIN: DEFENSE CHIEF

TEXT.P: Mainland China is breaking through the defense line of Japan, Taiwan and the Philippines, which Minister of National Defense Lee Jye referred to Wednesday as the "first island chain."

Fielding questions from lawmakers during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said Chinese naval ships and submarines have often been spotted recently in waters east of Taiwan and in the Western Pacific, a fact that demonstrates its ability to project its military forces beyond the "first island chain."

The defense chief said China is aggressively acquiring advanced warships in an attempt to control the seas far from its territory, and is stepping up the capabilities of its armed forces for amphibious landings and joint operations of aircraft and ships.

This, coupled with the Kilo-class submarines it is purchasing from Russia, means that Beijing could easily build a cordon of submarines around Taiwan to deprive it for a length of time from obtaining imported materials, Lee said.

Lee said that China's military is capable of attacking Taiwan via an amphibious landing and from the air, and its ballistic missiles deployed across the Taiwan Strait from Taiwan -- estimated to be around 700 -- could saturation bomb the island for 10 hours. Taiwan's armed forces would have a hard time defending itself with its current arsenal, Lee admitted.

The operating range of Beijing's new jet fighters can cover the seas east of Taiwan; this, combined with its long-range precision attack weaponry, poses a serious threat to Taiwan and translates to the entire island of Taiwan being the frontline in the event of war, he said.

The defense minister said he didn't see any imminent danger of invasion from China despite the legislation of its "anti-secession law," which Lee said would set back bilateral ties to the 1950's when the Chinese Communists and the Nationalists were still engaged in a bitter civil war.
However, if Taiwan's political status quo remains unchanged, the minister said, the possibility that Beijing will attack Taiwan is slim.

The defense minister said that the controversial arms purchase package offered by the United States which is under consideration by the legislature in Taiwan will give Taiwan a military superiority at the Taiwan Strait, the island, however, would need help from the U.S. to win an all-out war with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT TO BE PHASED IN: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is planning to phase in direct transport between Taiwan and mainland China, although the cross-Taiwan Strait situation will remain an uncertain factor on the way, an MAC official in charge of the issue said Wednesday.

Chien Chuan, deputy director of the MAC's Economic Affairs Department, made the remarks at a seminar held by a sub-group of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) at the Legislative Yuan. Officials from relevant government agencies, legislators and private-sector executives discussed the pros and cons of the matter.

Claiming that setting up direct Taiwan-mainland transport services is a set government policy, Chien, however, pointed out that an improvement in the fragile cross-strait situation is the key. He added that the MAC is projecting to phase in the links and is trying to seek the mainland's agreement to open talks.

He said that the MAC is currently reviewing the lunar new year charter flights and revealed that it will come up with an initial decision in one month as to whether cross-strait passenger and cargo transport negotiations can be modeled after the charter flights pattern by commissioning the private sector to hold talks.

Lee Chieh-chia, director of the Assistant Chief of the General Staff Office under the Ministry of National Defense, asserted that the military is capable of monitoring plane movements and will deploy adequate ground troops to safeguard Taiwan's security as long as cross-strait airlink routes and schedules are fixed.

Lin Chih-ming, director of the Navigation and Aviation Department under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, made it clear that no technical problems will arise from the issue. But he added that prior negotiations with the mainland side are a must.

Hu Chung-ying, director of the Economic Research Department at the Council for Economic Planning and Development, opined that direct Taiwan-mainland transport is advantageous for Taiwan in its bid to achieve its Asia-Pacific business operations hub dream.
KMT Legislator Ho Chih-huei asked the government to allow exports of Taiwan farm products to the mainland and permit charter passenger and cargo services between the two sides.
KMT Legislator Chu Fong-chih suggested that all Taiwan people be included in future charter flights to help slash operating costs of carriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND WILL GIVE TOP PRIORITY TO BUYING SUBMARINES: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Should the special budget required for the purchase of U.S.-made advanced weapons be cut by the legislature, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will give priority to the procurement of submarines, followed by anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot anti-missile batteries, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Wednesday.
Fielding questions at a meeting of the National Defense Committee under the Legislative Yuan, Lee stressed that the priority for procurement of the proposed weapons will not be adjusted again.

The Cabinet has listed a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for a proposed massive arms procurement package, under which the country plans to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

During the meeting, Legislator Ku Chung-lien of the opposition People First Party said Therese Shaheen, former managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan, has suggested that Taiwan shouldn't buy submarines, so he questioned whether the United States just intends to test Taiwan's loyalty and sincerity through the military procurement proposal.
In response, the defense minister said U.S. officials have told him that the U.S. government will not change its policy of selling arms to Taiwan.

The MND has delivered a new set of publicity material to the Legislative Yuan in a fresh attempt to lobby for lawmakers' support for the proposed arms procurement package. In the 13-page booklet, the ministry uses simple images to illustrate the connection between the arms procurement and national security.

Legislator Lin Chin-hsing of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said at the meeting that the contents of the explanatory pamphlets are too simplistic for DPP lawmakers to defend the government's military procurement plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' EXPOSES BEIJING'S MALINTENTIONS: DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reiterated its opposition Wednesday to China's proposed "anti-secession law, " which it said has exposed Beijing's intent to change unilaterally the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and to disrupt peace in the region.
The DPP China Affairs Department described in a statement the draft law unveiled by China's rubber stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- a day earlier as a war-mandating law.
According to the draft law, the statement noted, Beijing can take "non-peaceful" action against Taiwan under certain circumstances.
It is tantamount to giving Beijing authorities a blank check to use force against Taiwan and will destabilize cross-strait relations, the statement added.
Furthermore, the statement went on, the draft of the law is just like an order during wartime to "protect" the citizens of Taiwan and their property by using force.
The opposition to China's legislation, which is aimed at Taiwan, is to defend Taiwan people's dignity and the Republic of China's status, it stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUPS CALL FOR TAIWANIZATION OF EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Riding on people's anger about the impending enactment of an "anti-secession law" by China, seven pro-independence groups called on the government Wednesday to delete Chinese history, geography and literature from local schools' textbooks.

In a joint statement, the groups led by the Taiwan Association of University Professors said Taiwan is a state separate from China so there is no reason to teach Chinese history, geography or literature in Taiwan schools.
They urged the government to purge the schools' textbooks of any Chinese elements, which would not entail revising the Republic of China Constitution and would be easier to put into practice.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE CALLS FOR PEACEFUL SOLUTION TO TAIWAN-CHINA DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who was a winner of the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1986, called Wednesday for a peaceful solution to the disputes between Taiwan and China.

He told the Legislative Yuan that the Chinese "anti-secession law, " which authorizes Beijing to resort to "non-peaceful" means to take over Taiwan when there is no way to do so peacefully worries him because it virtually gives Beijing the right to attack Taiwan whenever it wishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER'S RECONCILIATION SUPPORTED BY 71 PERCENT OF PEOPLE: POLL

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh's promotion of political reconciliation and a "healthy Taiwan year" won the approval of 71.6 percent of people in an opinion poll released by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan.

The poll conducted March 2-3 also found more than 91.8 percent of those interviewed favor the Executive Yuan's decision to step up police patrols and road checks, bring the police force up to strength, and make stealing and fraud the two top crimes to be checked as part of the government's efforts to maintain peace and social order.

Just over 80 percent of those surveyed support the Executive Yuan's decisions to drop the tax-free privilege given to military personnel and teachers, and to impose a minimum tax on advanced technology companies that are exempted from income tax.

A total of 63 percent of the surveyed approve of the Executive Yuan's decision to raise the premium for people with higher incomes under the National Health Insurance program while keeping intact the premium of others with chronic diseases.
The same percentage approve of the Executive Yuan's decision to reorganize the Executive Yuan's 36 ministries and agencies into 13 ministries, four councils and five independent agencies.
The poll was conducted by phone among adults in Taiwan. It collected 1,082 valid samples, and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, March 10, or the first day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1848: Under the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, the United States becomes a million square miles larger, thanks to the addition of California, New Mexico and parts of Texas, the spoils of victory following the war with Mexico.
1862: The United States issues the "greenback," America's first true paper money, with all bills the same color and size, whatever the denomination ($1 to $1,000).
1910: D.W. Griffith, an American film director who pioneered the use of close-ups, traveling shots and modern editing techniques, discovers a small town called Hollywood in which to shoot his movie "In Old California."
1912: Yuan Shih-kai is installed in Peking (Beijing) as provisional president of the Republic of China.
1922: Mahatma Gandhi is arrested, tried for sedition, and sentenced to six years imprisonment by the British government of India.
1942: Japanese forces capture Rangoon, capital of Burma.
1942: The "Flying Tigers," a group of American volunteer aviators led by Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, becomes the U.S. 14th Air Force, and Chennault is officially appointed its commander.
1945: Three hundred U.S. B-29 bombers devastate Tokyo, killing more than 100,000 people.
1947: The ROC government sends Defense Minister Pai Chung-hsi to Taiwan to handle the aftermath of the Feb. 28 Incident.
1954: The ROC National Assembly votes to impeach Vice President Li Tsung-jen.
1959: Chinese army forces occupy Lhasa as the Dalai Lama, who led a failed rebellion against the communist government, flees to India with more than 10,000 followers.
1969: James Earl Ray pleads guilty to the murder of civil rights leader Martin Luther King and is sentenced to 99 years in prison.
1972: Lon Nol takes over as Cambodian head of state.
1974: Rodolfo Silva Vargas, Costa Rican communications minister, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Ralph P. Davidson, publisher of Time, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1975: Hanoi troops seize most of South Vietnam's provincial capital of Ban Me Thuot in the central highlands.
1976: Minister of Finance K.T. Li and Mahsoun Bajhat Jalal, vice chairman of the Saudi Development Fund, sign an agreement for a US$50 million loan to the ROC.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives Suat Erler, commissioner of the Turkish International Olympics Committee, and Eduardo Hay, commissioner of the Mexican International Olympic Committee.
1976: The Secretariat of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League announces the opening of an office in Taipei. A resolution of the December APACL general meeting transferred the secretariat from Saigon to Taipei.
1976: Chang Kwang-shih, vice minister of economic affairs, and Mansoor Al-Turki, deputy minister of finance and national economy of Saudi Arabia, sign an agreement on Sino-Saudi Arabian economic and technical cooperation.
1985: The principal line of the 53.85-kilometer Seikan Tunnel, the world's longest undersea tunnel, which links Japan's main island of Honshu with the vast northern island Hokkaido, is opened to traffic after 21 years of construction.
1985: Konstantin Chernenko, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, dies after only 13 months in office. He is succeeded by Mikhail Gorbachev.
1993: Indonesia's President Suharto is re-elected for a sixth five-year term of office, becoming one of the longest-serving heads of state in the world.
1999: Six Libyans, including Colonel Muammar al Qaddafi's brother-in-law, are sentenced to life imprisonment by a French court for the 1989 bombing of a French airliner over Africa.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian wins the endorsement of Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee, as the Nobel laureate agrees to serve as his policy adviser if Chen is elected president March 18.
2001: On the 40th anniversary of the Tibetan uprising, Tibet's political and spiritual leader the Dalai Lama throws his weight behind the idea of a free referendum in Tibet as a way to determine its future.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Whatsoever things are contrary to the ideals of decency and good sense, do not look upon them. Whatsoever things are contrary to the ideals of decency and good sense, do not listen to them. Whatsoever things are contrary to the ideals of decency and good sense, do not utter them. Lastly, let nothing in whatsoever things you do, act or move, be contrary to the ideals of decency and good sense."
