DOC.HEADLINE: EU URGED NOT TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 9 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for Germany's ruling party said Wednesday that the European Union should not lift its arms embargo against China at a time when Beijing is reviewing whether to enact an anti-secession law which has escalated tensions in the Taiwan Strait.
The spokesman, who is responsible for foreign affairs of the Social Democratic Party, made the remarks in an exclusive interview recently with the West German Broadcasting Co.
The Chinese government has revealed the key points of the proposed anti-secession law, but it has yet to make public the full text of the law.

Pointing out that the EU has been considering lifting the arms sales ban before June of this year, the spokesman said he thinks it shouldn't lift the ban as it does not want to be seen as supporting the enactment of such a law.

Meanwhile, a senior member of Germany's opposition Christian Democratic Party has warned that if the EU insists on lifting the ban without considering Washington's opposition, then all efforts that might reduce cross-strait distrust and misunderstanding will be undermined.
He also urged the EU to be very cautious in dealing with relevant issues and to first consult with the United States before voicing its stance regarding the lifting of the ban.
A lawmaker from Germany's Green Party also called for the EU to do whatever it can to maintain its arms ban on China due to the new threat posed by Beijing to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 2.6M students take test
Over 2.6-million Grade 6 and high school senior students are expected to take the national assessment test (NAT) today, March 10, in all public schools across the country.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 28 Bohol pupils die of food poisoning
Judy Ann Bosbos and at least 27 other pupils, aged 7 to 13 years old, died while 60 others were hospitalized due to food poisoning at the San Jose Elementary School in Mabini town, Bohol, 104 km northwest of the city. It was the worst reported case of food poisoning in the history of the province.
The Philippine Star: Cassava kills 30 kids in Bohol
Thirty elementary school children died of food poisoning yesterday after eating a native delicacy made from cassava flour at the San Jose Elementary School in Mabini town, Bohol.
The Manila Times: Cassava kills 30 kids
As many as 30 grade school children died Wednesday from apparent food poisoning in a town in Bohol. The pupils from the San Jose Elementary School in Mabini had eaten cassava roots for their mid-morning snack before becoming sick, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : University entry: Activity points out.
Singapore's universities will scrap awarding points during admission to students for taking part in sports and for taking up leadership positions in school activities.
The points system has been given the boot after the Education Ministry received bad feedback about calculating students.
So, from this year, if junior college students want to take up sports or lead the debating team, they will do so because they want to or feel passionately for a particular activity.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 4000 to 8000 people could be infected by HIV in Singapore.
In Singapore, there are 2 to 4 undiagnosed patients possible infected by HIV when diagnosed one patient with AIDS.
There are over 2000 patients with AIDS now in Singapore, so there could be 4000 to 8000 undiagnosed patients with HIV, warned by Dr Balaji Sadasivan, the Senior Minister of State for Health, in Parliament yesterday.
Dr Balaji warned of an AIDS epidemic as the total number of new cases in 2004 reached a high of 311, up 28% compared with 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Top Chechen rebel Maskhadov slain
The leader of Chechen rebel forces was shot and killed Tuesday during a raid by Russian forces, an event that could create as many problems as it solves for Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESS URGED TO OPPOSE ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 9 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission sent a letter Wednesday to the speakers of the two houses of the U.S. Congress to suggest that Congress "immediately and strongly" urge Beijing not to enact the proposed anti-secession law.
The commission said in the letter that enactment of the law can only escalate tensions in the Taiwan Strait and that the law runs directly counter to Washington's one-China policy.
The mandate of the commission, which was set up by Congress in 2000, is to examine the influence of the Sino-American economic relationship on the United States' national security.

In the letter, the commission said that although the text of the anti-secession law has not been released, descriptions of its nature and thrust have been circulated throughout the global international affairs community.

"It is apparent that its passage would needlessly inflame the China -Taiwan situation and complicate the task of maintaining stability in that relationship. The significant U.S. interest in maintaining the peaceful status quo in the region would be adversely affected, " it said.

Noting that China's unilateral action of enacting such a law would unlikely have a practical effect concerning international law or policy, the commission said that its principal impact would be to destabilize the already tenuous cross-strait balance by provoking Taiwanese reaction as well as inflaming Chinese nationalist sentiments and limiting the political maneuvering room for Beijing's leadership to take innovative steps that might lead to a lessening of cross-strait tensions.
The commission also said in the letter that China's intention in enacting the law is "to create a purported legal basis for it to take Taiwan by force."

Claiming that the anti-secession law runs directly counter to the U.S. position that neither side of the Taiwan Strait should try to unilaterally change the status quo, the commission said that it believes Congress should "immediately and strongly" oppose the enactment of the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS LIE IN BEIJING'S ONE-CHINA PRINCIPLE: ROC REP
DOC.DATELINE: London, March 9 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The crisis in the Taiwan Strait lies in Beijing's insistence on its "one-China principle, " the Republic of China representative to Britain said Wednesday.

Edgar Lin made the remarks when the anchorwoman of BBC News 24 TV asked him to comment on the threat to Taiwan posed by Beijing's proposed anti-secession law which authorizes the "use of non-peaceful means" against the island in certain situations. The National People's Congress (NPC), China's rubber stamp parliament, is expected to enact the law before its annual session ends Monday.
Lin pointed out that Taiwan has been a sovereign, independent country for over the past five decades and is not part of the People's Republic of China.
The crisis in the Taiwan Strait lies in Beijing's insistence on its one-China "principle, " Lin said, noting that in fact, other countries have only acknowledged the one-China "policy."

The principle and policy are two different things, Lin explained, noting that a principle cannot change, while policy, which is the decision made by a certain body, can be altered through negotiations. He added that this is the reason why Taiwan keeps urging China to engage in negotiations with the island.
The ROC representative stressed that Taiwan hopes to live with China peacefully because after all, Taiwan is in a disadvantageous position when under military threat from China.
He pointed out that in addition to deploying more than 800 missiles along its coastal provinces targeting Taiwan, Beijing has also relentlessly squeezed Taiwan's maneuvering space internationally.
The proposed anti-secession law is in fact an attempt by Beijing to create an excuse to annex Taiwan, Lin claimed.

Meanwhile, an Amnesty International representative who was interviewed during the same program said that 16 years after the Tiananmen Square Massacre, China's human rights record has yet to improve. He said that many who were detained before the bloody crackdown have still not been released.

Recently, a great number of people in China have been detained for pushing for more human rights, he said, adding that some have even been arrested simply for visiting Web sites advocating more human rights.
The representative from the international human rights group also said that China executes 100,000 people a year, more than the number of people executed in all other countries combined.

Chinese authorities have not relaxed their suppression of political and religious groups, he continued, adding that Amnesty International has not see any signs of improvement in China's human rights record.
He added that if the European Union lifts its arms embargo against China, which it has been considering for the last several months, this will send a weird message to human rights activists in China.

Lin agreed with the Amnesty International representative's remarks on China's human rights record. However, he added that the international community has focused on political suppression, saying that this is only "a drop in the bucket" of Beijing's human rights violations. He added that in looking at China's human rights record, attention should also be paid to its economic exploitation of women, children and minority groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP TAKING PART IN U.N. COMMISSION ON STATUS OF WOMEN SESSION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 9 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A delegation of Taiwan women is taking part in the 49th session of the United Nations' Commission on the Status of Women being held Feb. 28-March 11 in New York.
The 23 Taiwan women are participating in their capacity as members of non-governmental organizations (NGOs).
The delegation, led by Chang Chueh, an associate professor of public health at National Taiwan University, has participated in various round-table discussions, hosting three of them.
In a discussion on "Military Conflict Prevention From a Gender Perspective" held Tuesday, the participants urged the international community to pay attention to women's calls for peace.

According to Chen Jau-hwa, an associate professor of philosophy at Soochow University, there is still much room for improvement in Taiwan regarding the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action for equality, development and peace adopted during the 4th World Conference on Women in 1995.
For example, Chen said, women's participation is lacking in the making of defense policy in Taiwan, and the government is wasting a lot of money on arms procurement despite women's calls for peace.
Chen proposed that an independent organization be set up to monitor the government to ensure that a gender perspective is included in every policy.

Chen said the discussion has facilitated in-depth exchanges between Taiwan representatives and those from other countries and has enhanced participants' understanding of the progress of the international peace movement.
The advocacy for peace by Taiwan women has also won international support, which is expected to further boost the involvement of Taiwan women in the peace movement, Chen added.
On March 1, the Taiwan delegation hosted two discussions on the themes of promoting mental well-being of Asian women and girls education as a key to poverty eradication.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIFTING ARMS BAN AN ENCOURAGEMENT FOR BEIJING TO ATTACK TAIWAN: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that if the European Union lifts its ban on arms sales to China, the move will be tantamount to encouraging a non-democratic, non-peaceful country to use force against democratic Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a delegation from the U.S.-based Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs, a private think tank.

Noting that the European Union imposed the arms ban against China after the 1989 Tiananmen Massacre, where Chinese troops were mobilized to crush a massive pro-democracy demonstration, in an attempt to pressure Beijing to improve its human rights situation, stem arms proliferation and retain the military balance in the Taiwan Strait, Chen said China has since done little to meet the E.U.'s demands.
"Since the reasons that the E.U. arms embargo was imposed in the first place remain as before, I don't see any legitimate reason justifying lifting the ban," Chen said.
Over the past 16 years, Chen went on, China's annual defense budget has been growing at an average rate of 12 percent.

"Worse still, Beijing has never renounced the option of using force against Taiwan and has deployed more than 700 ballistic missiles along its southeastern coast aimed at Taiwan, " Chen said, adding that this poses a grave threat to the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability.

If the E.U. goes ahead and lifts the arms embargo against China, Chen said it will be tantamount to encouraging and supporting an undemocratic, non-peaceful country to use force against Taiwan -- one of the most vibrant democracies in Asia.

Chen further said the joint statement issued at the end of a recent U.S.-Japan security meeting for the first time included the Taiwan Strait issue as one of the two countries' common strategic objectives.
In their joint statement, the United States and Japan also encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to talk and resolve bilateral disputes peacefully.
"It is extremely regrettable that Beijing's proposed 'anti-secession' legislation runs completely against this common strategic goal of maintaining regional peace and stability, " Chen said.

While the United States and Japan have called for peaceful solutions to cross-strait issues through dialogue, Chen said Beijing's new legislation authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" to resolve cross-strait disputes.

During his recent Europe visit, Chen said, U.S. President George W. Bush expressed his concern about the E.U. plan to lift its arms sales ban against China because it could upset the cross-strait military balance.

The U.S. government, Congress and think tanks have also expressed grave concern about Beijing's proposed 'anti-secession' legislation, Chen said, adding that he is very grateful for the support from the U.S. for Taiwan's cause.

Chen also reiterated that Taiwan will consistently serve as a defender of the world order and guardian of democracy. "Democracy and peace are universal values, and peace cannot be achieved without democracy," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Kremlin's Victory May Be Shortlived.
Even though Aslan Maskhadov's death is being touted as a major publicity coup, it is unlikely to offer any long-term benefits for the Kremlin and could backfire if terrorism-bent rebels complete a takeover of the Chechen separatist movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: STARTING JULY 1 NEW ID CARDS WILL HAVE 21 ANTI-FORGERY FEATURES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior will replace existing identification cards with a new forgery-proof version from July 1 this year until June 30, 2006, ministry officials said Thursday.
Starting June 1, local household registration offices will notify people to submit one mug shot to be used on the new cards, the officials said.
The photo must be clear and in color and taken without the subject wearing a hat or sunglasses and have been taken within the last six months, they said.
The name and identification card number of the person in the photo as well as the date when the photo was taken must be written on the back of the photo, they said.
People must pick up their new identification cards in person, while a home delivery service will be provided to those suffering from a serious disease or those who are incapacitated.
The new identification cards will be pale purple and have 21 forgery-proof features. Unlike the existing identification cards whose print is vertical, the writing on the new ones will be horizontal.
Information regarding identification card renewal is available online at www.ris.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened low and closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 20.75 points to close at 6,192.53.

The bourse opened at 6,207.86 points and fluctuated between 6,215.47 and 6,168.76 during trading. A total of 4.04 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.91 billion (US$2.89 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares moving down the most by 1.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks by 1.6 percent, cement issues by 0.8 percent, foodstuff and textile shares by 0.7 percent, banking and financial stocks by 0.6 percent as well as machinery and electronics issues by 0.2 percent, while plastics and chemicals stocks moved up by 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 597 to 315, with 96 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION SAFETY COUNCIL HEAD TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Aviation Safety Council (ASC) Chairman and Managing Director Kay Yong confirmed Thursday his resignation has been approved by the Executive Yuan and will be effective starting April 1.
Yong said he decided to resign from the posts for family reasons and that the resignation was approved on Jan. 18 by former Premier Yu Shyi-kun.
According to Yong, the Cabinet is considering several possible candidates as his replacement.
Yong is the first managing director of ASC, which was established in May 1998. He has served as chairman of the council since May 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING DPP TO HOLD LARGE PROTEST AGAINST 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is slated to hold a large protest March 26 in Taipei in response to Beijing's "anti-secession" legislation targeting Taiwan, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang announced Thursday.

Su said that the DPP plans to call 500,000 people to take to the streets and that he may personally invite political leaders to take part in the demonstration, including Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

Pointing out that he has not reported the plan to President Chen Shui-bian nor has he invited the president to take part, Su said that the president should weigh the issue on his own in his capacity as head of state.

In the face of the impending passage of the law next week crafted to stem Taiwan independence, the 23 million people in Taiwan, regardless of their political affiliations or stances, should unite to counter Beijing's intimidation, he said, adding that it is time that the people of Taiwan show their solidarity to the international community.

Saying that the proposed "anti-secession law" is tantamount to writing a blank check for Beijing to invade Taiwan at any time, the DPP chairman called it clear proof of Beijing's long-term plan to alter the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and to dictate Taiwan's future by force despite the olive branches extended by President Chen in the past.
He stressed that the planned demonstration will be peaceful to underscore the Taiwan people's firm resolve to protect their values and lifestyles.

Meanwhile, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said that Soong will not participate in the protest and urged Taiwan and mainland China to be rational in order not to breach the valuable opportunity to forge rapport now at a time when cross-strait tensions have showed initial signals of improvement.

Hsieh also called on Beijing to treasure Taiwan's middle-road efforts after Chen and Soong issued a 10-point joint statement late last month promising to maintain the name of the Republic of China in view of the fragile cross-strait situation. Both sides of the strait should engage in peace-making for mutual benefits, he urged.
Meanwhile, pro-Taiwan independence groups, such as the TSU and the Human Chain Alliance of Taiwan, said that they will mobilize supporters to take part in the March 26 demonstration with the DPP.

The alliance issued a declaration demanding a name change of Taiwan's official designation, a new constitution, a referendum to decide Taiwan future status and entry into the United Nations as well as insisting that Taiwan is an independent and sovereign state.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March lost 31 points to close at 6,167, with 26,861 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved down 26 points to finish at 6,170, with 2,590 contracts traded, while June futures lost 25 points to finish at 6,156, with 31 contracts traded.
September futures lost 25 points to finish at 6,060, with 138 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 44 points to close at 6,056, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,198 for March, 6,196 for April, 6,181 for June, 6,085 for September and 6,100 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.
March TE futures moved down 0.15 points to close at 234.8, with 4,331 contracts traded, while April TE futures lost 0.45 points to finish at 234.7, with 306 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
March TF futures lost 5.4 points to finish at 1,007.6, with 3,081 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved down 4.2 points to end at 1,009.6, with 478 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: STARTING APRIL 1 SEPARATING GARBAGE FOR PICKUP MANDATORY

TEXT.P: After a three-month grace period accompanied by publicity, the requirement to separate garbage will be fully implemented in 10 cities and counties islandwide beginning April 1, with violators facing fines, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) reported Thursday.

Household garbage or refuse from shops is to be classified into three categories -- ordinary garbage, recyclable garbage and food scraps -- before they are taken out to garbage trucks, EPA officials said.

The 10 cities and counties that are included in the first phase of the islandwide garbage classification program are the cities of Taipei, Kaohsiung, Keelung, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi, and Tainan; and the counties of Ilan, Taichung and Kaohsiung.
Garbage that does not fall into any of the three categories will not be collected in regular pickups. Violators will be issued tickets for fines ranging from NT$1,200 (US$39) to NT$6,000 (US$195).
On Jan. 1 this year the EPA began to educate Taiwan citizens about the garbage classification and recycling program.
The program is scheduled to be expanded to all 25 cites and counties nationwide next year.
Taipei City has been using a similar program for more than two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.029 to close at NT$30.79.
A total of US$1.3 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$30.819 and fluctuated between NT$30.67 of NT$30.82.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUICIDE NOTES BELIEVED TO HAVE EXISTED DESPITE MEDIA REPORTS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A chief investigator of the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on March 19, 2004 said Thursday that five family members had read the suicide notes of the shooting suspect, despite news reports that no notes were left behind.

Legislators Lee Ching-hua and Sun Ta-chien of the opposition People First Party cited media reports that alleged that the suspect's sister and nephew had come forward to say that Chen Yi-hsiung -- the prime suspect in the shooting -- did not leave any suicide notes as claimed by his wife and that police had not followed proper procedures in questioning her.
Hou Yu-ih, commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, said: "As everyone sees the case from different angles, I'll respect their views and shoulder all responsibility for the case,."
The legislators asked if the media reports were true.

Hou said that based on a wiretap, police took Chen Yi-hsiung's wife and children in for questioning because they suspected they might have destroyed evidence. However, they were released in less than 24 hours. Police subsequently questioned them again.
All the questioning was recorded, Hou said, adding that this would show that proper police procedures were followed.

Regarding the suicide notes, which police said were destroyed by Chen Yi-hsiung's wife, Hou said that Chen Yi-hsiung's family said that only five of his closest family members read them, and that Chen Yi-hsiung's family decided in a meeting shortly after he allegedly committed suicide by drowning March 28 that they would not reveal the contents to anyone. They are the only ones who know what was actually contained in the suicide letters, Hou said.

On the location of the gun that was allegedly used to fire shots at President Chen and Vice President Lu, Hou admitted that it would be rather difficult to locate, adding, "This is probably the most difficult case in my life."
Even if the gun is found, police still cannot be 100 percent certain that it is the gun used in the shooting, Hou said.
He stressed that police were correct to identify Chen Yi-hsiung as the prime suspect, although all the evidence need to be substantiated.

Meanwhile, legislators asked if Chen Yi-hsiung's family had been put under house arrest. State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao said this was not the case and that he will convene a meeting to discuss the possibility of making Chen Yi-hsiung's family available to the media and human rights groups, although he said that the wishes of the family must be respected.
Hou said that police obtained prior consent of the family before they were relocated away from their residence on Monday, and that they have complete and unrestricted freedom of movement.
Kuo Jen-ni, chief prosecutor of the Tainan Prosecutor's Office, categorically denied that police have put Chen Yi-hsiung's family under house arrest.

She stressed that the family wanted to be taken away from the dogged pursuit of the media and had asked for police protection. The media shouldn't blame the police because the family wants its privacy.
She said that the family now feels safe and are not all staying in one place.

Police announced Monday that they had identified Chen Yi-hsiung as the key suspect, although he apparently committed suicide off Anping Harbor in Tainan March 28. His body was recovered the following day and hastily cremated. The suicide notes were burned and the gun that he allegedly owned has not been found.

The assassination attempt took place in the southern city of Tainan where the president and the vice president were riding in an open jeep during eleventh-hour campaigning. President Chen won reelection the following day by a razor-thin margin against his rival, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who said the shooting was staged and unfairly swayed the result of the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL ORCHID SHOW TO OPEN MARCH 26 IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan International Orchid Exhibition 2005 is set to open March 26 in Tainan, Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih announced Thursday.
The 16-day event will take place at the Taiwan Orchid Plantation in Houpi township, Tainan County, Su said.

It will bring together exhibitors from more than a dozen countries or areas including the United States, Japan, the Netherlands, South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, South Africa, France, Singapore, Australia and Hong Kong, he said.
There will be three halls with different themes, which include orchid landscaping, an orchid species showcase and an orchid sale, according to Tainan County Government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Withdraws From Death Penalty Protocol.
Bush administration pulls out of international deal that guarantees access to a diplomat when jailed abroad. Deal has been used by death penalty foes.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Battle over terrorist law reaches final showdown.
The Government today gave a tacit signal that it may be prepared to give way to Conservative demands for a "self-destruct" clause on proposed new anti-terror laws. Hazel Blears, the Home Office minister, refused to rule out the introduction of a "sunset clause" - under which the Bill would expire in November - into the Prevention of Terrorism Bill as the watered-down legislation returns to the House of Lords today for another widely-anticipated battering.
Financial Times: EU steps up accounts pressure.
The European Union has formally asked to be given more powers in the body that sets international accounting standards, a move that would go hand in hand with curbing US influence on global reporting rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING UNWISE TO ENACT 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW: ANALYST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 9 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: If the Beijing authorities were wiser, they would refrain from enacting the so-called "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan, Nancy Bernkopf Tucker, a professor of history at Georgetown University, said Wednesday.

Tucker, who specializes in American-East Asian relations, made the remarks the day after China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- began to screen an "anti-secession" bill Tuesday, which will provide a legal basis for China's use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan in certain situations.

"After having waited with great concern about what the "anti-secession" law might say, we can, on the one hand, be relieved that it is fairly mild and allows Beijing to act with flexibility should it wish to do so, " Tucker said. "It imposes no explicit deadlines and doesn't use the term 'one country, two systems, '" she went on.

"On the other hand, there are undesirable portions that can cause future difficulties," Tucker said, adding that it essentially revives a third 'if'; that indefinite delay is unacceptable, leaves vague what is meant by a major incident that would trigger the use of force, and is confusing over what actions by Taipei might be judged as going too far.
"Beijing would have been wiser not to have enacted the law and its likely use to parry the U.S. Taiwan Relations Act probably will no doubt lead to future problems," Tucker said.

The Taiwan Relations Act, passed by the U.S. Congress and signed into law by President Carter in 1979 after Washington switched its diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing, has served to regulate unofficial relations between Taipei and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN SPOUSES TO ENJOY PRENATAL CHECK-UP, CONTRACEPTION SUBSIDIES

TEXT.P: The government will subsidize the costs of prenatal examinations and birth control for foreign spouses who are not covered by the National Health Insurance program, officials said Thursday.

According to Su Shu-chen, head of the Maternal, Infant and Genetic Health Division of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Department of Health, the policy has been approved by the Cabinet, and the date of implementation will be announced by the Ministry of the Interior soon.

In the future, the government will subsidize NT$600 (US$19.49) for each prenatal visit by foreign wives for up to five visits and NT$1,000 for the installation of intra-uterine devices as a means of contraception, Su said.
Meanwhile, foreign husbands will enjoy a subsidy of NT$2,500 for sterilization surgery, Su said.
Su said the policy is aimed at protecting the health of the foreign spouses and their children, many of whom are financially disadvantaged.
The number of foreign wives residing in Taiwan, including those from mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau, totalled 338,000 as of the end of 2004, according to official statistics.
Foreign spouses of Taiwan nationals can only join the National Health Insurance program four months after they enter the country.
The new policy is estimated to cost the government NT$13.5 million a year, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BUYERS SET TO FLOCK TO TAIWAN FOR MACHINERY TOOL SHOW

TEXT.P: Foreign response has been enthusiastic to a Taiwan Machinery Promotion Project (TMP) , as scores of machinery tool distributors from across the world will travel to Taiwan to take part in the 2005 Taipei International Machinery Tool Show set to open March 15, organizers said Thursday.

The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), which is in charge of organizing the annual exhibition, said that foreign buyers from Brazil, Canada, India, Italy, Japan, Germany, Mexico, Poland, South Korea, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates will also participate in a series of seminars from March 14 to March 18 to explain their purchasing policies.

Companies among them include ATLAS and VITOR from Brazil, Gross Machinery Group from Canada, IWEMA from Germany, MIND, VISMAC and UTS from Italy, MEPEPSA from Mexico, BPLANALP from Poland, PHU BINH from Vietnam and LAROSA from the United Arab Emirates, according to TAITRA officials.

In addition, TAITRA officials said that the Korea Machine Tool Manufacturers' Association composed of 11 companies, the Turkey delegation made of 13 companies and the 20-company India mission will hold negotiations with Taiwan counterparts on their own.

Taiwan-made machinery tools have gained increased popularity among foreign buyers thanks to their fine quality and reasonable prices, they said, adding that the TMP plan initiated by TAITRA this year is set to serve as an efficient broker to introduce domestically made products to professional foreign distributors.

The non-profit TAITRA, Taiwan's leading trade promoter and formerly known as the China External Trade Development Council, was set up in 1970 to help Taiwan businesses explore international trade opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE TO CAMPAIGN AGAINST 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 9 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Members of Taiwanese communities in Boston and New England met recently to voice their opposition to Beijing's enactment of an "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan, officials from the Boston Chapter of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace (GADP) said Wednesday.

Members of the Taiwanese and overseas Chinese communities in the United States decided to make phone calls or send e-mails to influential people or media to amplify their opposition to the soon-to-be passed Chinese law that would allow the Chinese military to use "non-peaceful means" should Taiwan move toward independence.

The meeting, jointly sponsored by the GADP -- a democracy-championing arm under the auspices of Taiwan's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission -- the Formosan Association of Public Affairs, the Taiwanese Clan Association in Boston and several Taiwan trade associations in New England, also issued a five-point statement.

The five points are: to oppose the enactment of the "anti-secession" law by the totalitarian government of China; to ask the European Union to retain its arms embargo against China; to urge the Chinese regime to respect the will of the 23 million people on Taiwan; to staunchly support peaceful exchanges between people across the Taiwan Strait; and to safeguard the universal values of democracy, freedom, peace and human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN SUGGESTS U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 10 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman John Culberson (R-Tex) described Taiwan at a hearing Wednesday as "a shining city on a hill" and suggested Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice visit Taiwan during her upcoming visit to Asia.

At a question-and-answer session, Culberson said that he would like to bring the people of Taiwan to Rice's attention, and described Taiwan as who he described as "a shining city on a hill demonstrating to the people of China the benefits of democracy and freedom."

Culberson said to Rice: "I sincerely hope that you, in your visit to Asia, can either visit Taiwan or express in some further tangible form the admiration that the United States holds for the free people of Taiwan and the good work that they have done in building their democracy and freeing up their country, because they truly are a city on a hill, and I hope that we can do something tangible there to encourage them."

Rice apparently dodged this part of Culberson's remarks as she continued to talk about other matters. Noting that time was limited, Rice cut short her comments regarding Culberson's statement and asked the representative's consent to allowing her to supplement her answers in written form. .

DOC.HEADLINE: CONVICTED YUNLIN MAGISTRATE TO BE RELIEVED OF DUTIES

TEXT.P: Yunlin County Magistrate Chang Jung-wei will be relieved of his duties for having been convicted of vote-buying by the Supreme Court, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) said Thursday.

An MOI spokesman made the remarks after the Supreme Court meted out its final verdict earlier in the day that Chang was guilty of buying votes in 1994 when he was vying for reelection as speaker of the Yunlin County Council.
The Supreme Court upheld the Tainan High Court's one-year sentence for Chang, plus a two-year deprivation of his civil rights. The Supreme Court ruling was final.
The ministry has not yet received the Supreme Court's verdict, the spokesman said, adding that it will relieve Chang of his duties once it receives it.
According to current regulations, the MOI must relieve a local government chief of his or her duties if he or she is given a prison term that can neither be suspended nor commuted into a fine.

As the tenure left by Chang is less than two years, the MOI spokesman said no by-election has to be held to elect a successor. Instead, the Cabinet is authorized by law to name a replacement to serve out the remaining term.

In fact, Chang has already been suspended and detained since last December for his alleged involvement in a corrupt scandal. His deputy is now acting as Yunlin county magistrate. However, the MOI spokesman said, the law requires Chang's deputy, a political appointee, to be relieved of his duties along with Chang.
The Supreme Court also upheld the high court's sentence for Chang's wife, Wang Yue-hsia -- an eight-month prison term with three-year suspension.

Fifteen Yunlin County councilors at the time who accepted a free overseas trip from Chang in return for their support for his bid for speaker were each given seven-month jail terms, but the sentences for all but five of them were suspended for two years, according to the Supreme Court verdict.

Chang, who served as speaker of the Yunlin County Council from 1990 to 1997, and from 1999 to 2001, was elected as magistrate in 2001. He was suspected of bribery surrounding the construction of an incinerator in Linnei, Yunlin County during his term as magistrate and was wanted by prosecutors for questioning. He was arrested by police Dec. 10, 2004 for ignoring public prosecutors' subpoenas.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU SUGGESTS LEGAL BATTLE TO COUNTER 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested Thursday that international legal means be used to repel Beijing's "anti- secession" law aimed at quelling Taiwan independence.
Lu made the remarks at the Presidential Office during a meeting with local reporters.

Commenting on a plan by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to organize a large demonstration March 26 in Taipei to protest Beijing's "anti-secession" legislation, Lu contended that "a demonstration must be staged, " but she added that "it is by no means the only way" in the face of Beijing's move to enact a law with the aim of eventual unification with Taiwan.
Lu proposed the government make its case to the international community by launching a legal battle in view of the law's anticipated passage in the middle of next week.
She called for wisdom and solidarity to counter Beijing and urged the government not to dance to the tone of Beijing and refrain from emotional reactions.

The vice president expressed her belief that the international community will respond to Beijing's "anti-secession" legislation on the grounds that the law is counterproductive to international interests and goes against the universal principles of the United Nations.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang announced earlier the same day that the DPP will hold a large protest against Beijing, planning to attract 500,000 people to join forces with the party.

Pro-independence groups, including the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- a political ally of the DPP -- also voiced support for the planned rally and promised to show solidarity with the DPP in the activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INDUSTRIAL PARK IN EL SALVADOR COULD BE REALITY WITHIN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Thursday said she hopes that a proposed "Taiwan Park" for industries to set up shop in El Salvador could be accomplished in the remaining three years of President Chen Shui-bian's term.

Lu will leave Taiwan Saturday at the head of a large delegation to visit El Salvador and Guatemala. She will attend the Democratic Pacific Assembly's American regional meeting in Guatemala and inspect the environment of El Salvador for the possibility of establishing a "Taiwan Park."
Lu said that a high-tech advisory committee under the Presidential Office first broached the idea and President Chen instructed the Executive Yuan to study the project.

After the project was approved, she called El Salvador President Elias Antonio Saca, who was excited and said he would work to make the project a reality, including providing sufficient water and electricity to the park.

She stressed that the project requires El Salvador to provide 200 hectares of national land in the first stage. Taiwan will then help with the introduction of agricultural and livestock concerns and aquaculture and processing industries in the park. The companies can aim to create their own brands to export to all of America.

In comparison with past economic assistance Taiwan offers to the ROC's diplomatic allies, Lu said the project will not only give fish or fishing rods, but will be to "grow fish" together with the allies, adding that the successful experience of Taiwan industries will be able to expand to other allies in Central America.

Noting that President Chen has only a little more than three years left in office, Lu said that if the project is feasible, it will be the first time that the government, working hand in hand with the private sector, will have made such an inroad into Central America, which will contribute to Taiwan businessmen reaching out to the world and help Taiwan's bid to become an observer of the Organization of American States.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, who will concurrently serve as the head of the delegation's inspection team, said that five countries in Central America are now discussing with the United States the signing of a free trade agreement and an American Free Trade Zone covering 34 countries in the region will also be established.
If Taiwan businessmen establish factories in Central America, they will enjoy 30 percent tariff incentives for their textile products, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITY FORGES SISTERHOOD TIES WITH JAPANESE SCHOOL

TEXT.P: The Providence University (PU) in Taichung, central Taiwan, has forged sisterhood ties with Kansai University (KU) in Japan, according to the PU administration.

The sisterhood accord signing ceremony was held Wednesday at PU, in which PU President Yu Min-teh and KU President Kawata Teiichi inked the documents on behalf of their respective universities, PU officials said.
Under the agreement, the two parties will conduct exchanges of students, professors and academic affairs.
Currently, PU has sisterhood ties with more than 50 universities and colleges from around the world, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR 2005 PROJECTED AT 4.5 PERCENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2005 is projected at more than 4.5 percent, but the government will try its best to challenge the goal of 5 percent, according to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Affected by a global economic slowdown, the island's economic growth this year is forecast to move between 4.0 percent and 4.7 percent, the CEPD said in a report delivered Wednesday to the Legislative Yuan.

Among other economic development goals is to have the per capita income hit US$15,000 this year, reach 4 percent for the jobless rate and less than 2.0 percent for the consumer price index growth rate, according to the report.

Although domestic electricity and water rates are expected to be raised, the impact of an increase in the rates on domestic consumer prices will be reduced should such hikes be done in different stages, the CEPD pointed out.

In addition, the CEPD said that the slowdown in international raw material price hikes and the continued appreciation of the local currency against the greenback will help reduce imported commodity prices and wholesale prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: G.O.P. Senators Balk at Tax Cuts in Bush's Budget.
Republican leaders offered a budget for 2006 that would undo more than a fourth of the cuts that President Bush has requested.
Wall Street Journal: Republicans Are Split On Social Security Steps.
With President Bush struggling to get the public and Congress to embrace his top-priority proposal for private accounts within Social Security, fretful Republicans are increasingly critical of White House strategy but divided on how to proceed.

DOC.HEADLINE: RATIO OF ABORIGINES IN FREE TRADE ZONES TO BE CUT TO 1 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The ratio of aboriginal people working in Taiwan's free trade zones will be cut to 1 percent from the 5 percent as currently stated in regulations, the nation's top economic planner said Thursday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), was responding to questions by Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party about the progress of the free trade zones.

According to regulations governing the establishment of the free trade zones, the ratio of aborigines should account for 5 percent of the total workforce in the zone. Enterprises have complained about this figure, saying that the ratio is too high considering the fact that the number of aboriginal people in the proportion of the total population is low.

According to bills to protect the rights of aboriginal peoples, government agencies, public schools and public enterprises in cities and counties other than the outlying islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Lienchiang County, those institutions that employ over 100 people must have at least 1 percent aboriginal people in their workforce
In private schools, groups or private companies whose total workforce surpasses 200, the employment of aboriginal people should no be lower than 0.5 percent of the total workforce.
Judging from the ratio, the requirement of 5 percent seems to be too stringent, Hu noted.

Hu said that the CEPD has coordinated with related government agencies and determined that the ratio for employing aboriginal workers be cut to 1 percent, although the figure will still have to be discussed with the Council of Aboriginal Affairs.

Taichung Harbor will be the country's third free trade zone. The first one was the northern Keelung Harbor, which started operations in October 2004, and the other one was the southern Kaohsiung Harbor, which started operations earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: BE CALM IN THE FACE OF 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW: KMT

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Thursday that the cross-strait situation must be dealt with calmly amid reports that China will soon enact an "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Policy Committee, said that the KMT caucus is against the "anti-secession" law, adding that Taiwan should handle cross-trait situations in a calm and rational fashion.

"We must solve and not create problems, " Tseng said, adding that the proposed "anti-secession" law will only be finalized next Monday and that the KMT will respond properly after seeing the final result.

Noting that legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, have proposed their own draft "anti-annexation laws" to counter Beijing's "anti-secession" law, Tseng said that the KMT has yet to see the draft laws, and will decide whether to support them only after seeing their contents.

DOC.HEADLINE: NY TIMES REPORTER CLARIFIES WORDING ABOUT '319' SHOOTING

TEXT.P: A New York Times reporter who described Taiwan police's identification of a dead man as the key suspect in the mysterious election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian last year as something out of a "one dime novel" has rephrased his wording in a follow-up report, the Government Information Office (GIO) said Thursday.

Keith Bradsher told GIO officials stationed in New York a day earlier that it was not his intention to denigrate Taiwan police and prosecution authorities' efforts at investigations into the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung said.

Bradsher was quoted as having clarified that his "one dime novel" wording in the first place was mainly aimed at highlighting the theatrical nature of the event. He said he already changed the wording to "a sequence of events worthy of a pulp crime novel" in his later article, titled "Suspect in shooting of president identified, " published in the March 8 edition of the International Herald Tribune.

After Bradsher's "one dime novel" report was posted on the New York Times Web site Tuesday, Lin said, it was widely quoted by local opposition politicians and news media and given a negative interpretation, resulting in a distortion of the image of local law enforcement agencies. Therefore, Lin said, the GIO's New York office took the initiative to inform Bradsher of the misunderstandings in Taiwan because of his report.

Since the team investigating the shooting unveiled its latest findings and investigative procedures early this week, Lin said the GIO has translated all relevant data and information into English and presented them to the nation's overseas offices and journalists posted in Taiwan by major international news organizations for reference.
Lin said foreign news media has generally given faithful reports about the professionalism and strenuous efforts shown by local police and prosecution authorities in probing the case.

The special investigative team identified Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, as the key suspect in the March 19 shooting Monday after several months of tracking down numerous clues. Chen Yi-hsiung was found dead in Anping Harbor in the southern city of Tainan March 29 last year -- 10 days after the shooting -- in what police have said was an apparent suicide.

President Chen and Lu were slightly wounded when two homemade bullets grazed them as they campaigned in an open jeep in Tainan. After the Chen-Lu ticket narrowly won reelection the following day, the sole challenging ticket of Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong accused the president of having staged the shooting to win sympathy votes and filed two lawsuits to challenge the election result. The shooting is believed to have gravely aggravated hostility between the ruling and opposition camps.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO RESPECT DEMOCRACY IN HONG KONG AFTER TUNG RETIRES

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official urged the Beijing leadership Thursday to respect the people of Hong Kong and their pursuit of freedom and democracy in the future now that Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa has confirmed that he wishes to step down.
Tung citing health reasons for the move, and hoped that his bosses in Beijing will approve his resignation "as soon as possible."

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Thursday that generally speaking, Hong Kong's freedom and democracy that were developed during British colonial rule, have been oppressed under Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula imposed since Hong Kong was returned to China in 1997.

Beijing authority should respect the people of Hong Kong and their desire for freedom and democracy, Chiu said, adding that hopefully relations between Taiwan and Hong Kong will improve instead of retrogress after a new Hong Kong chief executive is appointed by Beijing.

In a statement announcing his resignation, Tung said that over the past eight years, Hong Kong has successfully showcased the "one country, two systems" initiative, in which the people of Hong Kong govern themselves, enjoy a high degree of autonomy and continue to live in a free and democratic society.
Chiu said that he has no idea why Tung resigned and that it is the MAC's established policy not to comment on personnel changes in Hong Kong.
Chiu would not speculate on who will succeed Tung or the future of Hong Kong, saying only that Taiwan looks forward to closer ties with Hong Kong in the years to come under a new leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 11 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, March 11:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09:30, The Women's Rescue Foundation will hold a news conference on Taiwan "comfort women's" compensation claim against Japan at the Legislative Yuan.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive participants of an international seminar on national communications policies at the Presidential Office.
10: 00, The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union will unveil the contents of a draft bill on "anti-annexation" of Taiwan at the party's headquarters.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
13: 30, A farewell party in honor of outgoing Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Lin Chia-lung will be held at the GIO reception center.
16: 00, The ruling and opposition parties' legislative caucuses will hold a consultation meeting at the Legislative Yuan.
16: 20, The Foreign Exchange Department of Taiwan's Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PACKAGE NEEDED TO MAINTAIN MILITARY BALANCE: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye appealed to opposition lawmakers once again Thursday to support the defense ministry's purchase plan for arms from the United States, saying that if no new purchases are made, the cross-strait military balance will severely tilt in China's favor by 2012.

Noting that China's defense budget is growing at a double-digit pace, Lee said that the cross-strait military balance will seriously favor China if Taiwan fails to secure the weapon systems that it has planned to purchase from the United States since 1996.
Lee was referring to the six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-fueled submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.
By 2012, Lee said, when China's and Taiwan's air and navy combat capabilities are at a prospective ratio of 2.87: 1, the mainland will be sufficiently capable of taking Taiwan by force.

This, of course, does not necessarily mean that China will invade Taiwan in 2012. The truth is that the "red light" may flash in the cross- strait military balance by that year, with Taiwan being on the vulnerable side, if the island continues to lag in procuring advanced weaponry, Lee said.

Lee made the remarks at a news conference after he paid courtesy calls on lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang and the Taiwan Solidarity Union while lobbying for the passage of the budget for the U.S. weapon systems.
Noting that a cut in the budget is acceptable and understandable, Lee said hopefully the cut will be reasonable and not result in having to abandon the purchase plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO BOOST CROSS-STRAIT RAPPROCHEMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Thursday reaffirmed his administration's pragmatic stance of boosting reconciliation and rapprochement with China to secure peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the reaffirmation while addressing an annual Hsieh Nien Fan business dinner organized by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei.

"The major obstacle to cross-strait rapprochement resides in different political systems and Beijing's reluctance to give up using 'non-peaceful means' to resolve disputes between the two sides," Chen said.
He said that Taiwan has sincerity and goodwill in seeking reconciliation with China and that the country will never retreat from its efforts to achieve this goal.
However, the president stressed that his administration will by no means give up its long-standing cause -- safeguarding Taiwan's democratic system -- while seeking cross-strait rapprochement.

The most pragmatic way to deal with cross-strait issues isn't to use "non-democratic, non-peaceful" means, which will make both sides turn away from each other, Chen noted, stressing that only through boosting democracy and freedom can the fruits of cross-strait civilian, economic and trade exchanges be secured.

In his speech, Chen also quoted former U.S. President Bill Clinton and incumbent President George W. Bush as saying that democracy and peace are not only the common languages of Taiwan and the United States but also great incentives for the promotion of bilateral economic and trade exchanges.

Chen reiterated that his administration is willing to join hands with the United States to promote sustainable economic development and co-prosperity and will do everything possible to seek inter-party reconciliation, solidify the democratic system, seek cross-strait peace and participate in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR INCREASING TAIWAN-U.S. ECONOMIC INTERACTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called Thursday for a further increase in Taiwan-U.S. economic interaction, which he said has played the most important role in the development of bilateral ties.

Addressing the annual Hsieh Nien Fan business dinner of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, Chen said that he has been satisfied with the increasing economic exchanges between the two countries in recent years.

Taiwan and the U.S. resumed sub-Cabinet-level trade consultations last November in Washington, D.C. under the bilateral Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) after a six-year hiatus, Chen said.

During the two-day meeting, Chen said, the two sides had constructive talks on the trade of agricultural and pharmaceutical products, telecommunications, government procurement accords and issues related with the new round of talks of the World Trade Organization.

The U.S. delegation to the meeting recognized that Taiwan had made tremendous progress in cracking down on commercial piracy and in IPR protection, he noted, adding that the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) subsequently removed Taiwan from its "Special 301 priority watch list" in January.
The fact shows that Taiwan-U.S. trade and economic ties have been further strengthening, he emphasized.

The president also said that his administration will create more room for Taiwan's substainable development and international cooperation based on the principles of speeding up globalization, easing restrictions regarding certain laws and regulations, increasing infrasctructure construction and improving the cultivation of talented people.
Taiwan is ready to face the rapidly changing era of globalization and its economic transformation, he affirmed.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Kung Jaw-sheng and American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office Director Douglas Paal were also present at the annual event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTED TO ENJOY ENCOURAGING ECONOMIC GROWTH: AMCHAM HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to continue to enjoy sustained economic growth this year, American Chamber of Commerce Chairman (AmCham) Tom Johnson said Thursday.

The island enjoyed strong economic growth in 2004, so its economy is forecast to record good growth this year, especially in the semiconductor and pharmaceutics sectors, Johnson said after an AmCham-organized annual Hsieh Nien Fan business dinner in Taipei.
Johnson said he is happy to hear that President Chen Shui-bian announced Taiwan's plan to resume beef imports from the United States while addressing the dinner party.

The AmCham head also disclosed that his chamber is compiling an annual "white paper, " in which it will come up with constructive proposals on how to further boost economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MILITARY BRASS CONCERNED ABOUT CHINA'S 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 10 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Admiral William Fallon, commander of the U.S. Pacific Command, Thursday said he was concerned about China's "anti-secession" legislation.

Speaking at a full committee hearing on the FY2006 defense budget request at the House Armed Services Committee, Fallon said that the "anti-secession" legislation that contains language that includes other-than-peaceful means as a potential step in dealing with the Taiwan issue is "certainly not something we would like to see."
The U.S. military cannot solve the problem on its own, he noted, suggesting that it needs help from all the agencies of the government and U.S. allies as well.
The first step would be reemphasizing U.S. policy regarding the status quo, emphasizing no unilateral moves by either sides of the Taiwan Strait, he went on.

"We might facilitate efforts to peacefully resolve this by emphasizing those areas of shared interests, particularly between ourselves and China, stability in the Korean peninsula, the tremendous economic benefits that flow today and could continue to grow, the very, very robust cross-strait economic activities, as one example, the reestablished commercial air travel between Taiwan and the mainland," he added.
Fallon pledged that he plans to do the best he can to support a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAKKA AFFAIRS COUNCIL CHAIRMAN STEPS DOWN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh approved the resignation of Hakka Affairs Council Chairman Lo Wen-jia Thursday effective March 14, Cabinet Spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.
Lo decided to quit from his current post to run in the year-end Taipei County magistrate election, he explained.
The premier has also instructed Lo's deputy, Lee Yung-teh, to serve as the council's acting chairman, Cho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, March 11, or the second day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1702: The Daily Courant, the first English daily newspaper, is published in London.
1819: Marius Petipa, French choreographer who created "Swan Lake" and "Sleeping Beauty," is born.
1820: Benjamin West, the first American painter to study art in Italy and who went on to become president of the British Royal Academy, dies at the age of 82. His "Death of General Wolfe" is among the American history and portrait painter's most important works.
1864: A reservoir near Sheffield in the north of England bursts its banks, killing 250 people.
1912: A provisional constitution for the Republic of China is promulgated.
1913: At the invitation of Japan's Asahi Shimbun newspaper, Dr. Sun Yat-sen delivers a speech on Asian affairs at the Youth Association in Osaka, in which he advocates Sino-Japanese cooperation.
1916: Harold Wilson, British Labour prime minister 1964-70 and 1974-76, is born.
1931: Rupert Murdoch, Australian media magnate, is born.
1941: The U.S. Congress approves the Lend-Lease Act, which allows China, Britain, the Soviet Union and other friendly powers to receive tanks, ships, ammunition and other weapons on preferential credit terms.
1945: U.S. Marines land on Mindanao Island in the Philippines, while the vast Krupps factory in Germany is destroyed when 1,000 Allied bombers make the biggest-ever daylight bombing raid of World War II.
1954: The United States admits that its H-bomb test explosion on the Marshall Islands exposed 264 local residents and 28 Americans to radiation.
1954: The second session of the first National Assembly of the ROC approves indefinite extension of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1955: Sir Alexander Fleming, the British bacteriologist who discovered penicillin in 1928 and shared a 1945 Nobel Prize for the achievement, dies at the age of 74.
1982: Chen Wan-fu, speaker of the Taipei County Assembly, is arrested for alleged involvement in vote-buying during the 1981 elections.
1985: Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, 54, takes office in Moscow following the death of Konstantin Chernenko, becoming the youngest leader in the history of the Soviet Union.
1990: Lithuanian Parliament declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1990: Chile turns the page on 17 violent and bitter years of repression under Gen. Augusto Pinochet, welcoming in the democratic era of Patricio Aylwin.
1991: Ma Hsin-yeh, national policy advisor to the ROC president, president of the Chinese Institute of Mass Communications and former chairman of the Board of Directors of the Central News Agency, dies in Taipei at the age of 82.
1996: The trials begin in Seoul of Roh Tae Woo and Chun Doo Hwan, former South Korean presidents charged with carrying out a 1979 coup and killing pro-democracy protesters.
1998: South Korea says it will compensate women who were enslaved in Japanese army brothels in World War II.
1998: President Suharto of Indonesia is inaugurated for a seventh five-year term.
1999: Chi Mei Corp., one of Taiwan's giant plastics producers, obtains a loan of more than NT$7 billion (US$212.12 million) to build a second TFT-LCD factory.
1999: Visiting Macedonian Assembly President Dr. Savo Klimovski signs a joint declaration on parliamentary cooperation with his ROC counterpart Wang Jin-pyng.
2001: A memorial service is held in Taipei to mark the 10th anniversary of the passing away of the late Central News Agency Chairman Ma Hsin-yeh and his wife.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When going out into the world, behave always as if you were at an audience before the Emperor; in dealing with the people, act as if you were at worship before God. Whatever things you do not wish that others should do unto you, do not do unto them. In your public life in the State as well as in your private life in your family, give no one just cause for complaint against you."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHRODER URGED NOT TO SUPPORT LIFTING OF EU ARMS BANS ON CHINA

TEXT.P: Berlin, March 10 CNA) Four members of the European Parliament from various German political parties on Thursday jointly sent a letter to German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder to voice their opposition to a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China.

The parliamentarians who sent the letter are Elmar Brok of the Christian Democratic Party, who is president of the EP's Foreign Affairs Committee, Alexander Lambsdorff of the Liberal Democratic Party, Cem Ozdemir of the Green Party, and another Green Party member.

The Chinese National People's Congress revealed at its current annual plenary session being held in Beijing the key contents of the anti-secession bill. The congress is expected to pass the bill into law before the conclusion of the annual session Monday.

Urging the German chancellor to change his stance of supporting a lifting of the arms sales ban against China, the parliamentarians said in the letter that a lifting of the ban, which was imposed after the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre, would violate the EU's human rights policy, as well as jeopardize the close relations between the EU and the United States.
Schroder had reiterated his support for a lifting of the ban at the U.S.-EU summit meeting held two weeks ago in Brussels.
The German Bundestag is set to discuss at its March 17 session issues regarding the anti-secession law and the lifting of the arms embargo against China.
The EU has been considering lifting the arms sales ban for several months. Both the United States and Taiwan are fiercely opposed to a lifting of the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL INVITES MINNESOTA GOVERNOR TO VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 10 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An official of the Republic of China's mission in Chicago has invited Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty to visit Taiwan during his trip to China and Hong Kong later this year.

Shao Ping-yun, an information official of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago, made the invitation in a letter he sent to the Minneapolis Star Tribune, the largest newspaper in Minnesota.
Pawlenty is scheduled to lead a delegation to visit China and Hong Kong in November mainly to inspect the information technology (IT) industry there.
Noting that Taiwan is geographically close to China and Hong Kong and excels in the IT industry, Shao urged the governor to include Taiwan in his visit to the region.
Shao noted that Taiwan is the 17th largest economic entity in the world, and the United States' eighth largest trading partner, as well as Minnesota's 14th largest export market.

Although China's population is 56 times that of Taiwan, Taiwan people purchased an average of US$940 worth of American products last year, compared with only US$30 purchased on average by mainland citizens, Shao noted.

Taiwan excels in a number of industries, Shao said, noting that it is the third largest IT industry producer. Taiwan is also very industrialized, and has a strong demand for Minnesota's agricultural, environmental protection and other products, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 'COMFORT WOMEN' PROTEST AFTER JAPANESE COURT REJECTS CLAIMS

TEXT.P: Two representatives of former Taiwanese "comfort women" on Friday protested against the Japanese government's "inhumanity" and demanded an apology after their request for compensation was rejected by a Japanese court late last month.

Cheng Chen Tao, 83, accompanied by members of a women's group and a dozen legislators, said that she was forced into sex slavery by the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II while she was still a girl.
"I don't want compensation. I want an apology from the Japanese government. Let the world know this, and I'll be content, " said Cheng, who sells coconuts in Pingtung, southern Taiwan for a living.
Another former comfort woman, Chen Yan, asked for assistance from all quarters in her pursuit of justice.

Liao Yin-chi, chairwoman of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, noted that the Japanese court rejected the compensation claims on the grounds that the 20-year statute of limitations period had expired before the claims were filed and on the grounds that individuals cannot be the main claimants in a suit involving national compensation.
The foundation will sponsor a "Million People Around The World Sign Up" signature gathering campaign at the Tamshui MRT Station Saturday.

In April, the group will join hands with its counterparts in South Korea, Indonesia, and the Philippines -- where women were also forced to serve in Japanese military brothels during WWII -- to appeal their case at the U.N. Human Rights Committee.
Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of filing war compensation claims at the International Criminal Tribunal at The Hague, Liao added.

The women's group also suggested that the topic of comfort women be included in senior high school history textbooks, that a memorial monument at a site in Hualien, believed to have housed a military brothel during WWII when Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule, be established, complete with historical photo exhibition, that pressure be applied to the Japanese government to enact a law to compensate the comfort women, and that a million signatures be collected globally to lend support for the cause of the comfort women.
