DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SOLICITS SUPPORT FOR RALLY AGAINST ANTI-SECCESSION LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) continues to solicit support from all sectors of society around Taiwan to take part in a nationwide demonstration set for March 26 to vehemently oppose Beijing's proposed anti-secession law, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Friday.

Su called for people of all ages and walks of life to take part in the rally to say "no" in a democratic way to the anti-secession law targeting Taiwan. The anti-secession law is expected to be enacted by the Chinese National People's Congress at its ongoing annual session which closes March 14.

Su visited several private groups Friday to try to broaden the support base for the DPP-initiated nationwide rally, in which some 500,000 people, including President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui, are expected to participate.

Among the business executives that Su also visited Friday was Taiwan Federation of Industry Chairman Lee Cheng-chia, who said that members of his federation will throw their support behind the ruling DPP in its efforts to lead the Taiwan people to oppose the law, which allows "non-peaceful means" to be used should Taiwan move toward independence.

Meanwhile, Lai Ching-teh, a DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP caucus will soon initiate an endorsement drive calling for support from leaders of parties from across Taiwan's political spectrum for the March 26 nationwide "Defend Taiwan, Oppose Annexation" rally.

Lai said it is hoped that opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party Chairman James Soong and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang will lead their supporters to take part in the rally to reflect the truth that all the 23 million people in Taiwan are determinedly opposed to the anti-secession law which he said aims to unilaterally change Taiwan's future.

He further said that the DPP legislative caucus will also initiate a resolution soon to ask all party leaders to take part in a leadership summit to jointly craft countermeasures against enactment of the anti-secession law.
The March 26 nationwide demonstration will be the largest-ever that the Taiwan people hold to say "no" to China, Lai added.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang issued a statement earlier this week saying that the rally will be held based on "three ifs, " namely "if the anti-secession law stipulates punishment, persecution or extradition of Taiwan people; if it allows sanctions, boycotts or the use of violent methods to change the cross-strait status quo; or if it threatens the existence of the Taiwan people, sabotages the basis of Taiwan's democracy and freedom, or hurts the nation's basic interests."

Lee pointed out that the tensions in cross-strait relations lie in Beijing's refusal to recognize the sovereignty of Taiwan, its threat of force and deployment of missiles which threaten the peace and security of the Taiwan Strait, and its harsh methods used to squeeze Taiwan.
The anti-secession law will only make the problem worse, Lee said, urging Beijing to reflect upon its policy toward Taiwan and not to further hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people.

Meanwhile, during a session at the Legislative Yuan Friday, TSU legislators called for President Chen to immediately initiate a nationwide referendum to demonstrate the Taiwan people's relentless determination in opposing China's attempts at annexation.

Also responding to DPP lawmakers' appeals, KMT Legislator Kuo Su-chun said that the KMT party members and their supporters would be happy to take part in the March 26 rally if the DPP could prepare 500,000 Republic of China national flags for the people attending the rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOPES TAIWAN CAN ACT WITH RESTRAINT REGARDING ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 10 (CNA) (By Olive Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the U.S. Defense Department said Thursday that he hopes Taiwan can "act with restraint" in responding to China's anti-secession law.
Peter W. Rodman, assistant secretary of defense for international security affairs, made the comments while responding to questions raised by a reporter from Taiwan's CTI TV News Channel.
The Chinese National People's Congress is expected to pass the anti-secession bill into law at its current annual plenary session being held in Beijing.
Rodman also said that the United States does not think that what Beijing has done regarding the law is a "constructive step."
Nevertheless, he expressed the hope that Taiwan will not overreact to the matter. "We hope our friends on Taiwan will act with restraint. We should consult on this," he said.

Meanwhile, U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld declined to respond to Taiwan reporters' questions the same day regarding the anti-secession law, saying that he has not seen the law nor been briefed on the matter and that it is better for the U.S. State Department to talk about the relevant issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAS YET TO DECIDE ON REPLACEMENT OF YUNLIN COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has yet to decide on a replacement to serve out the remainder of Yunlin County Magistrate Chang Jung-wei's term following Chang's conviction in a speakership election bribery case, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Friday.

Cho was commenting on media reports that the central government has contacted former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Su Chih-fen from the southwestern county of Yunlin to ask her whether she is interested in filling the vacancy.

Cho said the report is not true, insisting that Premier Hsieh is unlikely to handle the matter before the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) receives the Supreme Court's final ruling on the vote-buying case.
The Supreme Court handed down its ruling for Chang Thursday, sentencing him to 12 months in jail for his involvement in the 1994 Yunlin County Council speakership election bribery case.
According to current regulations, the MOI must relieve a local government chief of his or her duties if he or she is handed a prison sentence that cannot be suspended or commuted into a fine.

As there are less than two years remaining in Chang's term, no by-election has to be held to elect a successor. Instead, the Cabinet is authorized by law to name a replacement to serve out the remainder of the term.

In fact, Chang has already been suspended and detained since last December for his alleged involvement in the corruption scandal. His deputy is now acting as Yunlin county magistrate. However, the law requires Chang's deputy, a political appointee, to be relieved of his duties along with Chang.

Cho said once the MOI receives the Supreme Court ruling, it will refer a short list of candidates to the premier to choose a preferred replacement. Cho said the replacement will be announced before the end of this month.

Besides Su, two other DPP politicians -- Lin Kuo-hua and Kao Meng-ting -- have also expressed a keen interest in securing the post. Whoever becomes the acting county chief is expected to gain an edge in the year-end magistrate election.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the DPP's "pan-green" ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) -- suggested that TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming, a former legislator, be named acting Yunlin county magistrate.
TSU legislative whip Lo Chih-ming said he has presented the proposal to Premier Hsieh.

Lo quoted Hsieh as having said that so long as DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang and TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang can come to terms on the proposal, he would name Chen to serve out the remainder of Chang's term.
Stressing that Chen is well known throughout the country, Lo said he is a perfect replacement for the post.

"With three DPP hopefuls vying for the post, naming Chen as acting Yunlin magistrate could be the best strategy to prevent the 'pan-green' camp from splitting and guarantee a victory in the year-end election," Lo claimed.
After learning of Lo's statement, Premier Hsieh denied that he has ever promised to have Chen serve in the post.

Hsieh stressed that he has yet to consider the replacement issue and is unlikely to make such a promise as quoted by Lo. "How could I make any promise before the MOI comes up with a comprehensive report about the issue?" he asked.

Chen said he is determined to run for the Yunlin magistrate post in the year-end election regardless of whether Hsieh names him as acting magistrate or not. Chen, a Taipei City resident, said he will move his legal abode to Yunlin County next Tuesday to qualify for running in the year-end election.

There have also been reports that top government authorities prefer to have incumbent Cabinet Secretary-General Lee Ying-yun, a Yunlin County native, named as the acting Yunlin magistrate. Lee said that he is pleased with his current job and that his current priority is assisting the premier in pushing the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to pass five critical bills, including the massive arms procurement package and the government restructuring plan.
While fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan plenary session, Premier Hsieh also said that he will not name Lee as acting Yunlin County chief becasue he badly needs Lee assistance at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO WORK OUT COUNTERMEASURES AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will conduct a comprehensive evaluation of China's anti-secession law and work out countermeasures after the law's expected enactment next week, an official said Friday.

The law, which the National People's Congress of China is expected to pass at its ongoing annual session which ends Monday, will authorize Beijing authorities to adopt "non-peaceful means and other necessary measures" should Taiwan move toward independence.

According to MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san, the so-called "non-peaceful means and other necessary measures" refer not only to military actions, but also blockades, economic sanctions and diplomatic suppression.

In light of the lack of a clear definition of what "other necessary measures" means, the law could seriously impact cross-Taiwan Strait relations and cross-strait trade and economic activities, Chiu said.

Chiu said one possible example of "non-peaceful means" could be the cutting off of water supply to Hong Kong by Beijing, which would disrupt the life and economic activities of the people in Hong Kong.
Meanwhile, Chiu declined to make any comment on the large-scale demonstration being planned by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for March 26 against the enactment of the anti-secession law.
However, Chiu urged China to carefully consider the possible consequences of the law on cross-strait relations and the feelings of the Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' COOPERATION URGED IN YEAR-END LOCAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Several legislators from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) urged cooperation Friday between the two parties as they announced their bids for the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections.
KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin, in announcing his bid for the Taipei magistrate spot, said he will follow the party's procedure in seeking nomination.

Lee said that five or six aspirants within the KMT are also keen on the post and that he had already inquired as to the views of KMT Chairman Lien Chan, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- the latter two who concurrently serve as KMT vice chairmen.
According to Lee, Lien encouraged all the aspirants to make public their intentions and urged cooperation between the KMT and the PFP to ensure maximum victory in the election.
Lee also said he agreed with a proposal by PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei that polls will decide who will come forward to serve as the joint candidate of the KMT and the PFP in Taipei County.
Lee's words came one day after Hakka Affairs Council Chairman Lo Wen-jia tendered his resignation so that he can concentrate on his bid for Taipei magistrate.
A KMT spokesman said the schedule for nominating the party's candidate will remain unchanged and that after it finalize the list, it will coordinate with the PFP.
Meanwhile, Chou claimed that he is the top choice in opinion polls for the position among all the aspirants hoping to run.
The public hope for a younger, healthy person with professional capability to serve the post, he claimed.
He also expressed the hope that the KMT will present a fair nomination mechanism and coordinate with the PFP for one joint candidate.

Chou made the remarks in a PFP press conference in which the party introduced him, as well as legislators Liu Wen-hsiung, Hsu Yao-chang and Chung Shao-he and former Legislator Hsieh Chang-chieh, as the party's candidates for Taipei County, Keelung City, Miaoli County, Kaohsiung County and Changhua County, respectively, in the year-end elections.
Chung said that among the five aspirants, he will run under the greatest pressure, noting that southern Taiwan is traditionally a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HOPES TO DISCUSS CHARTER FLIGHTS FOR TOMBSWEEPING DAY

TEXT.P: China's Civil Aviation Association (CAA)
has expressed hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can start to discuss charter flight services for the Tombsweeping Day period based on the same model used for the Chinese New Year holiday.
CAA Executive Director Pu Zhaozhou sent a letter to Michael Lo, head of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) Friday outlining his desire for talks on the subject.

TAA Secretary-General Su Hsien-jung said the TAA immediately notified the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- the top charter of the nation's China policy -- of the letter and was waiting for the MAC to decide whether it will commission the TAA to discuss the matter with its Beijing counterpart.

Pu and Lo, on behalf of each side of the Taiwan Strait, completed discussions on the charter flights during Chinese New Year holiday in early January, and adopted the model of joint-participation of air carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, as well as two-way flights without stops in Hong Kong or Macau.

Su said that although the New Year charter flights were quite successful, it was an isolated case and that if both sides intend to promote charter flights during the Tombsweeping Day period, new discussions will be needed.
However, the opposition People First Party said it "would be better to slow down" on discussing cross-strait charter flights at this moment.

Chen Chih-ping, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that as China will soon enact an "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan, it would be "a bit strange" for both sides to discuss the charter flights issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA OPPOSES UNILATERAL MOVE THAT COULD CHANGE TAIWAN'S STATUS: FM
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, March 10 (CNA) (By George Wu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Pierre Pettigrew reiterated Thursday that the government of Canada opposes unilateral moves taken by either side of the Taiwan Strait that could change Taiwan's status, build up cross-Taiwan Strait tension and affect political stability and economic prosperity in East Asia.

Answering a question raised at the Canadian Parliament by Don Boudria, a leader of the Canadian Reform Conservative Alliance, who asked Pettigrew whether Canada is taking a similar stance as the United States on Beijing's enactment of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, Pettigrew said that how China's National People's Congress is processing the proposed law is unknown yet, but he added that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will try to gain further understanding of the law once it is passed and publicized.

Boudria, who is also chairman of the parliamentarian Taiwan-Canada Friendship Association, said during an interpellation session that Washington has recently voiced its opposition to Beijing's enactment of the proposed law, which would provide Beijing with a legal basis to adopt "non-peaceful means" to resolve cross-strait problems if it thinks Taiwan is making moves toward independence.

Meanwhile, Stockwell Day, a spokesman for the Canadian Reform Conservative Alliance, said during the interpellation session that the Chinese communist regime's expected enactment of the proposed anti-secession law once again reveals Beijing's attempts to invade Taiwan and its intention of taking Taiwan by force.

Day claimed that when what he described as Taiwan's "allies" such as the United States and Japan, have spoken loudly to express their concerns over a democracy infringed upon by totalitarians, Canada should also render its support to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.7 points to close at 6,204.23.
The bourse opened at 6,225.75 and fluctuated between 6,238.43 and 6,194.14 during trading. A total of 3.44 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.23 billion (US$2.6 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.5 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction issues and cement stocks both at 0.5 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.1 percent.
Foodstuff issues remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 511 to 354, with 142 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU UNVEILS DRAFT OF 'ANTI-ANNEXATION LAW'

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) unveiled Friday a draft of an "anti-annexation law" designed to counter an anti-secession law that China is expected to pass next week.

According to the draft, in the event of the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo being at stake, the government should take steps such as calling a referendum and amending the Constitution to safeguard the sovereignty of Taiwan, and can resort to non-peaceful means to resist China's annexation.

TSU Chairman Shu Chin-chiang pointed out that the anti-secession law, which will authorize the Beijing authorities to use non-peaceful means should Taiwan move toward independence, will pave the way for military action against the island and will jeopardize cross-strait security and peace in the Asia-Pacific region.
Shu urged the United States and Japan to take concrete action against the imminent threat posed by China.

The draft states that Taiwan has existed alongside China since the foundation of the People's Republic of China on Oct. 1, 1949, with the status quo being that the two sides are independent of each other and have no jurisdiction over each other.
Taiwan is already an independent, sovereign state and it is not an issue for Taiwan to declare independence or seek separation from China, the draft says.

It says Taiwan and China must respect the fact of their existing alongside each other and negotiate with each other on an equal footing in order to resolve their differences, adding that the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" format for unification is unacceptable to the people of Taiwan.
Taiwan and China should maintain peace and stability across the strait and respect each other's independence and autonomy in terms of domestic and foreign affairs, it says.

The draft says the two sides should expand their economic and cultural exchanges to enhance mutual understanding and trust, and proposes that a cross-strait military confidence-building mechanism and code of conduct be set up to protect regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BAR ASSOCIATION VOICES OUTCRY OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Bar Association issued a public statement Friday calling for China to pull back on its enactment of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan "before it's too late."

The Taiwan Bar Association, which groups some 4,000 lawyers practicing in Taiwan, urged the Chinese communist regime not to enact the proposed law to avoid undermining an atmosphere that is conducive to accelerating cross-Taiwan Strait engagement and shun actions that will lead both sides of the strait to a mutually destructive doomsday.

The Taiwan lawyers said that after failing to push its "pro-unification, anti-independence" scheme, Beijing authorized its State Council and Central Military Commission to take Taiwan by "non-peaceful means" if it thinks Taiwan is making moves toward independence.

This pre-emptive plot will change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally and also hurts the feelings of the people of Taiwan, the statement says, adding that the law also infringes upon the Taiwan people's rights to survival and autonomy.

Warning that the proposed anti-secession law will curtail Taiwan people's pursuit of democracy, freedom and human rights, the Taiwan Bar Association said it will initiate a petition among all bar associations around Taiwan soon to express their indignation with and disdain for Beijing over the anti-secession legislation.
The association will also seek support from its counterparts in the international community, as well as international human rights bodies, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S VISA WAIVER FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS COMES INTO FORCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan's visa waiver for tourists from Taiwan during the Aichi World Exposition came into force Friday, with the arrival of 151 Taiwan visitors in the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido via a China Airlines charter plane.
They were the first group of Taiwan tourists to enjoy the visa-free privilege.
Japanese public television channel NHK footage showed an arriving Taiwan tourist who said the people of Taiwan generally welcome Japan's visa waiver.

A Taiwan tour guide told an NHK reporter that he believes the visa-free privilege will help boost the number of Taiwan visitors to Japan by 20 percent to 30 percent this year. The number of Taiwan tourists to Japan broke the 1 million mark for the first time last year.

With a view to attracting more foreign visitors to the eco-friendly world exposition to be held in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi March 25-Sept. 25, Japan passed regulations in February to waive the visa requirements for Taiwan tourists between March 11 and Sept. 25.
During the period, Taiwan passport holders can enter Japan without visas for sightseeing purposes for a maximum 90-day stay.
Japanese government officials said they will also consider whether to offer Taiwan citizens permanent visa-free privileges after the Aichi World Exposition.
Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea. Japan began to offer similar visa waivers to South Korean citizens early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORMAL CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER FLIGHTS NEEDS NEGOTIATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that opening of normal charter flights across the Taiwan Strait is "possible in principle" if both sides can shelf their differences and meet for talks.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that although the exchanges of "two-way, non-stop" passenger charter flights across the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese New Year holiday had some shortcomings, they created a favorable basis upon which the two sides could continue to talk about expanding the program to make it available during three other major Chinese festivals -- Tombsweeping Day, Dragon Festival and Moon Festival -- in the following year.

Opposition lawmakers raised the topic of cross-strait charter flights Friday after Pu Zhaozhou, executive director of China's Civil Aviation Association expressed hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can start to discuss charter flight services for the Tombsweeping Day period based on the same model used for the Chinese New Year holiday.
Pu sent a letter to Michael Lo, head of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) Friday outlining his desire for talks on the subject.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.030 to close at NT$30.820.
A total of US$621 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$30.842 and dipped to a low of NT$30.775 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED NOT TO TALK WITH BEIJING ON CHARTER FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Friday that the government should put talks on cross-strait charter flights during the Tombsweeping Day period on hold and should reassess its China policy overall.

Chen Chin-chun, whip of the DPP legislative caucus, made the remarks after Pu Zhaozhou, executive director of China Civil Aviation Association, sent a letter to Michael Lo, head of the Taipei Airlines Association, earlier Friday inviting him to discuss the charter flights during Tombsweeping Day period based on the same model used for the Chinese New Year Holiday.

Pu and Lo, on behalf of each side of the Taiwan Strait, completed discussion on the charter flights during Chinese New Year holiday in early January, in which the model of joint-participation of air carriers on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, as well as two-way flights without stops in Hong Kong or Macau, was adopted.

Chen noted that the successful launch of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday should be conducive to the easing of cross-strait relations, but the good atmosphere has not stopped China from putting aside its legislation of its proposed "anti-secession law" targeting at Taiwan.

He said that China threatens "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan in the proposed law, but the law also stipulates that it will encourage and promote cross-strait economic exchanges and cooperation, establish direct trade, postal and transportation links and closer economic relations for mutual benefits.
Chen described Beijing's talk about charter flights during the Tombsweeping Day period as a "carrot and stick" approach that he said lacks true goodwill.
The opposition parties were also lukewarm about talks on the Tombsweeping charter flights, with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) saying that the government should deal with it with wisdom.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed that Beijing made the offer because its proposed "anti-secession law" has caused revulsion among the Taiwan people and because the DPP has put a hold on the promotion of cross-strait exchanges such as cargo charter flights, so that Beijing has to extend an olive branch.

Chang said the United States was positive about cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday and claimed that if Taiwan cannot agree to such services for Tombsweeping Day, the United States could apply pressure to the DPP government.
The KMT's ally, the People First Party, said it "would be better to slow down" on discussing cross-trait charter flights at present.
Chen Chih-ping, whip of the PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, said that because of the anti-secession law, it would be "a bit strange" for the two sides to discuss the charter flight issue.
The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said it opposes the flights.

Lo Chih-ming, whip of the TSU caucus in the legislature, said the party is opposed to charter flight service on various festive days, claiming that the service is an attempt to accomplish the normalization of direct flights.

In addition, the anti-secession law is like a big stick aimed at Taiwan, and the island should not kowtow to China. Until Beijing responds with goodwill, Taiwan should not be over-enthusiastic, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for March gained 40 points to close at 6,207, with 26,378 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April moved up 33 points to finish at 6,203, with 4,352 contracts traded, while June futures gained 30 points to finish at 6,186, with 66 contracts traded.
September futures gained 28 points to finish at 6,088, with 52 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 12 points to close at 6,081, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,167 for March, 6,170 for April, 6,156 for June, 6,060 for September and 6,069 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

March TE futures moved up 1.8 points to close at 236.6, with 3,172 contracts traded, while April TE futures gained 1.9 points to finish at 236.6, with 490 contract transactions. June TE futures gained 1.4 points to close at 235.3, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

March TF futures gained 4 points to finish at 1,011.6, with 3,551 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures moved up 1.4 points to end at 1,011, with 1,635 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT NOT TO MEET INTERNATIONAL PRESS OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office denied Friday a report claiming that President Chen Shui-bian will host an international press conference in reaction to the expected enactment of an anti-secession law by China.

Earlier in the day, the possibility of the government making its case on the law to the international press was being discussed by the National Security Council (NSC), an advisory panel to the president.
However, Presidential Office staff denied that such a press conference will be hosted by the president, contrary to a report printed in a local evening paper.

According to Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung, both the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan have made all necessary preparations for holding an international press conference and the authorities are assessing the optimum timing for it.
Lin said the government will finalize its statement based on the conclusion reached by the NSC.
The government is also maintaining close contact with the United States and Japan to gather information regarding China's move, Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BACKS IDEA OF COMBINING ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that it is worth considering the idea of combining elections to help save spending and costs.

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Chun-yi at an interpellation session, who raised the question of whether some similar elections should be combined and suggested that the central government assess the issue.

City mayor and county chief elections are slated for the end of this year and polls for city and county councilors will come at the beginning of next year, which will be followed in late 2006 by a vote for township and village chiefs, Lee pointed out.
The premier praised Lee's suggestion and said it would help cut billions of dollars in expenditure every time there is an election. He promised to evaluate the possibility of adopting the measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEFENDS DPP-INITIATED RALLY AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh defended a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) plan to organize a huge rally to protest China's anti-secession law aimed at Taiwan, saying that opposition parties should not give the cold shoulder to the planned rally.

Hsieh made the remarks in response to questions from DPP Legislator Lee Chun-Yi during a general interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan. Lee asked the premier to express his viewpoint on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's recent remarks that the DPP's plan to stage a demonstration against the law is a provocative action. Ma serves concurrently as a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

"It is not Taiwan that is taking the initiative in arousing so much dispute over the so-called anti-secession law, " Hsieh said, adding that now is an opportune chance for the people of Taiwan to let the international community understand that Taiwan is not a "tension-maker."

Claiming that the planned rally will show the international community that Taiwan is a democracy- and peace-loving country, Hsieh said the people of Taiwan will be considered numb if they show no reaction to China's proposed law.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress (NPC) -- began Tuesday to screen the bill, which provides the legal basis for China's use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan in certain situations, and is expected to pass it next week.

In response, the DPP is planning to stage a rally in Taipei March 26. DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang called on all sectors of society Friday to take part in the demonstration to vehemently oppose the legislation. Around 500,000 people, including President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui, are expected to participate.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council have said that the law is tantamount to a "blank check" authorizing the Chinese military to use force against Taiwan, and accused Beijing of jeopardizing peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, Lai Ching-teh, a DPP whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP caucus will soon initiate an endorsement drive calling for support from leaders of parties from across Taiwan's political spectrum for the March 26 anti-annexation rally.

Lai said it is hoped that KMT Chairman Lien Chan, People First Party Chairman James Soong and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang will lead their supporters to take part in the rally to reflect the truth that all the 23 million people in Taiwan are determinedly opposed to the anti-secession law, which he said aims to unilaterally change Taiwan's future.
China still considers the island part of its territory despite their split in 1949 after a civil war. Beijing has repeatedly threatened to use force against Taiwan if the island declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO MAINLAND CHINA FLOCK TO CENTRAL REGION

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports to mainland China are increasingly going to Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces in the central part of the country, with the two provinces accounting for nearly 60 percent of Taiwan's mainland-bound shipments last year, according to government tallies released Friday.

The statistics made public by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that along with rapidly growing Taiwan investment in central mainland China, Taiwan exports to Jiangsu and Zhejiang accounted for 58.3 percent of the country's total outbound shipments to the mainland in 2004.

Last year, 43.3 percent of Taiwan investment went to Jiangsu, while 28.9 percent and 8.5 percent went to Guangdong and Fujian provinces, respectively, BOFT tallies show. Zhejiang Province took 6.6 percent. At the same time, 54.8 percent of Taiwan's total exports to mainland China were shipped to Jiangsu, while 30.9 percent went to Guangdong.
In terms of product category, 85.5 percent of optical exports and 47.3 percent and 27.7 percent of chemical goods exports were shipped to Jiangsu and Zhejiang, respectively.
More than 80 percent of other Taiwan exports bound for the mainland, such as electrical engineering, machinery, rubber, steel, man-made fiber products, were also destined for Jiangsu and Guangdong.

According to BOFT officials, mainland-bound exports from Asian neighbors, including Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines have also increasingly focused on the central region rather than the southern region, with Jiangsu outpacing other provinces.

Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh urged Taiwan businesses to exercise greater caution with regard to their investments in the mainland at a time when Beijing's anti-secession law aimed at Taiwan is expected to be approved next week.
Ho made the remarks Thursday at an economic forum while giving a keynote speech on cross-strait economic development and strategies.

Pointing out that it is undeniable that Taiwan investment in mainland China has benefited Taiwan, Ho nevertheless called on Taiwan companies to take political factors into consideration while weighing investment plans in the mainland.

Ho said her ministry will retain its current mainland China investment rules for the time being until after the national security authorities hammer out an assessment on the fragile cross-Taiwan Strait situation.

A very strict mainland China investment policy is very likely to erode Taiwan companies' competitive edge in other countries, as many of them have relocated to the mainland and are dedicated to export-oriented business, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARTER CARGO FLIGHTS SHOULD TAKE PRECEDENCE OVER PASSENGER LINKS: MAC

TEXT.P: The government will have to assess the value of launching direct charter passenger flights across the Taiwan Strait during the upcoming Tomb-sweeping Day holiday in the face of Beijing's proposed "anti-secession" legislation, an official said Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the remarks after China's Civil Aviation Association (CAA) expressed the hope earlier in the day that both sides of the Taiwan Strait could start discussing the opening of cross-strait charter flight services during the Tomb-sweeping Day period based on the same model used for the just-concluded Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

CAA Executive Director Pu Zhaozhou sent a letter to Michael Lo, head of the Taipei Airlines Association (TAA) Friday outlining his desire for talks on the matter. TAA Secretary-General Su Hsien-jun said Pu's message has been conveyed to the MAC, which charts Taiwan's cross-strait policy.
While Beijing's figurehead parliament is screening the so-called "anti-secession" bill targeting Taiwan, Chiu said it's hypocritical for the CAA to propose talks on the flights now.
As the Tomb-sweeping Day holiday lasts for a couple of days, Chiu said, the opening of direct cross-strait charter flights during the would not contribute any to bilateral commercial exchanges.
In his view, Chiu said, the opening of cross-strait cargo flights would have far more positive effects on economic development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chiu said if Beijing is sincere in promoting constructive cross-strait engagements and maintaining regional stability, it should scrap its "anti-secession" legislation plan and give priority to negotiating the launch of direct cross-strait charter cargo flights to meet market demand.
Tomb-sweeping Day, which falls on April 5, is one of the most important festivals in Chinese society.

Under a landmark deal reached in January, six carriers from each side of the Taiwan Strait were allowed to operate a total of 48 direct, non-stop charter flights between Taipei/Kaohsiung and Shanghai/Guangzhou/Beijing during the Chinese Lunar New Year period to facilitate the return of Taiwan business people operating on the mainland for holiday celebrations.

With Beijing is expected to pass the "anti-secession" law next week, major domestic political parties have urged the government not to discuss any cross-strait charter flight issues for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PURCHASE WILL DETER CHINA'S INVASION OF TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the government's proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms procurement package from the United States will deter a Chinese attack of Taiwan because China "is bound to lose."
However, failure to acquire the weapons will tilt the military balance across the Taiwan Strait in China's favor, Hsieh warned.

Hsieh made the remarks during an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan ahead of the expected enactment of an "anti-secession law" by China, which will authorize the Beijing authorities to use non-peaceful means should Taiwan move towards independence.

The Cabinet has been lobbying the legislature to support an expensive budget proposal for the procurement of six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

According to Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, the side on the offensive will be certain to win if its has three times the strength of the deffense and the result will be uncertain if it has only two times the strength of the defense.
If the ratio between the strenthes is lower than "1.5, " the side on the defensive will be certain to win, Lee said.

While the current ratio of military strength between China and Taiwan is 1.46, the it will increase significantly to 2.87 between 2020 and 2035 if Taiwan does not buy new weapons to maintain its defense capabilities against China's continued military buildup, Lee said.
The arms procurement will slow down the rate of increase and keep the ratio at 1.67, he said.
The minister said China is not going to launch an attack of Taiwan now because the chances of success are meager.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEEK U. S. UNDERSTANDING REGARDING MARCH 26 PROTEST

TEXT.P: The government will make its stance fully known to the United States and other friendly countries regarding a large protest planned by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) against Beijing's "anti-secession" law, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Hsieh made the remarks while fielding questions from DPP lawmaker Julian J. Kuo, who asked the premier whether the government is ready to explain Taiwan's stance to the United States, as Washington has called on both sides to refrain from emotional actions in order not to fuel tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

According to Hsieh, he personally expects all the people in Taiwan to take part in the demonstration set for March 26 in Taipei. Since it is a rally hoped for by the private sector, the government will try to seek understanding and support from the United States and other friendly countries for such an activity to counter Beijing's intimidation.
The DPP hopes that at least 500,000 people will take to the streets.

The National People's Congress, Beijing's ceremonial parliament, is anticipated to pass the "anti-secession" legislation next week to prevent Taiwan from edging toward independence. The law is expected to include provisions to allow Beijing to deal with Taiwan with "non-peaceful" means.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang announced a day earlier that the party will organize a large protest against Beijing in view of its "anti-secession" legislation aimed at Taiwan.
The demonstration will be peaceful to underscore the strong desire of the Taiwan people to protect democratic values and their lifestyles, Su said.

Echoing Su's call, Hsieh urged Beijing later the same day to treasure Taiwan's middle-road efforts after President Chen Shui-bian met People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong late last month and issued a 10-point joint statement pledging to maintain the national moniker of the Republic of China.
Both sides of the strait should engage in peace-making for mutual benefits, he said.
Many pro-independence organizations, including the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a political ally of the DPP, have showed willingness to take part in the activity in a gesture of solidarity with the DPP.

They blasted that the enactment of the law is tantamount to writing a blank check for Beijing to invade Taiwan at any time and called it clear proof of Beijing's plot to change the cross-strait status quo and to dictate Taiwan's future by force despite the olive branches extended by President Chen.

According to a PFP spokesman, Soong will not participate in the March 26 protest. He also urged both Taiwan and mainland China not to breach the good opportunity to forge rapport now at a time when bilateral ties have showed initial signals of improvement in the wake of the lunar new year charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELEGATION FROM U.S. UNIVERSITY VISITS WETLANDS PARK IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: An 11-member delegation from the Shenandoah University in Winchester, Virginia lauded the Kaohsiung city government Friday for its construction of a wetlands park for hundreds of aquatic bird species.

The group, led by Dance Department Acting Director Chen Ting-yu, who is a Taiwanese American, was making a fact-finding trip to the Choutzu Wetlands Park in the southern port city. Chen graduated from Kaohsiung City Tsoying Senior High School.
With explanations from several volunteers, the delegation members observed the ecological environment of the wetlands and were astonished that there were so many species resting there.

John Stevens, a counselor of the Shenandoah University, spoke highly of the Kaohsiung city government's efforts to protect wildlife. Since its inauguration two years ago, the wetlands park has become a habitat for innumerable water birds and insects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO CALL NEWS CONFERENCE ON 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to call an international news conference March 14 to express his opposition to China's "anti-secession" law aimed at Taiwan, a Taipei City Government official said Friday.

Yu Tzu-hsiang, director of the Information Department, said that China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- is expected to pass an "anti-secession" bill next Monday morning to provide the legal basis for China's use of non-peaceful means against the island in certain situations.

All county magistrates and mayors from the ruling and opposition parties will be invited to attend the planned news conference, during which Ma will strongly protest Beijing's "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan, Yu pointed out.

Yu went on to say that all local government chiefs present at the news conference will sign a joint protest letter that will be sent to international media organizations. He said that he hopes that this will help Taiwan obtain support from more foreign countries for the island's opposition to this "anti-secession" law.
Meanwhile, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai called on Ma to take part in a ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated anti-annexation rally slated for March 26.

Chen said that the planned rally offers a good chance for all different ethnic groups and supporters from across the political spectrum to show their determination to defend Taiwan and oppose annexation by China.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council have said that the law is tantamount to a blank check authorizing the Chinese military to use force against Taiwan, and accused Beijing of jeopardizing peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

China still considers the island part of its territory despite their split in 1949 after a civil war. Beijing has repeatedly threatened to use force against Taiwan if the island declares independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-PARTY TALKS ON NEW '319 TRUTH COMMISSION' BREAK DOWN

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties failed to reach agreement Friday on the re-organizing of a special commission to investigate the assassination attempt on President Chen Shui-bian last March, commonly known as the "319 shooting."

The caucuses also failed to come to terms on the opposition People First Party-initiated (PFP) proposal that a new special commission be formed to scrutinize all records documenting the procedures of law enforcement authorities' investigation into the mysterious "319 shooting."

The opposition-controlled fifth Legislative Yuan passed a special statute authorizing the establishment of an independent "319 truth commission" to investigate the case in which President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were shot and slightly wounded. However, the statute was later ruled by the Council of Grand Justices (CGJ) to be unconstitutional. According to the CGJ's interpretation, the commission's tenure expired with the expiration of the fifth legislature at the end of January this year.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the PFP continues to control a slim majority in the current legislature and intends to re-organize the "319 truth commission" to probe the incident.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently heads the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) policy coordination department, said the legislature should give priority to revising the "319" special statute to pave the way for the formation of a viable and legal "319 truth commission."

As to the PFP proposal to form a commission to review records regarding law enforcement units' procedures regarding the "319 shooting" investigations, Ker said it's extremely inappropriate for the legislature to form such a commission at the moment.

"Police and prosecution authorities are still probing the case. It's inappropriate for the legislature to review relevant documents at present because such moves would interfere with the exercise of judicial powers," Ker said.
It remains unclear when legislative caucuses from across the political spectrum will hold inter-party consultations on the issue.

President Chen and Vice President Lu were slightly wounded March 19, 2004 when two homemade bullets grazed them as they campaigned in an open jeep in the southern city of Tainan. After the Chen-Lu ticket narrowly won re-election the following day, the sole challenging ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong accused the president of having staged the shooting to win sympathy votes and filed two lawsuits to challenge the election result. The shooting is believed to have gravely aggravated hostility between the ruling and opposition camps.

The special police team investigating the incident identified Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, as the key suspect in the "319 shooting" Monday after several months of tracking down numerous clues. Chen Yi-hsiung was found dead in Anping Harbor in Tainan March 29 last year -- 10 days after the shooting -- in what police have said was an apparent suicide.

Lin Teh-hua, deputy commissioner of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) , said Friday that pegging Chen Yi-hsiung as the "319" gunman was not "wild speculation" even though the investigative team has so far failed to secure direct evidence proving its assumption.

"The bullets and various prior owners of the gun alleged to have been used in the shooting, the footage of security tapes at the crime scene and testimonies of the man's family members all showed that Chen Yi-hsiung was the most likely suspect," Lin said.

Lin said the team is still working hard in hopes of recovering the homemade pistol used in the shooting. He clarified that the team has never set the upcoming March 19 anniversary as the deadline to solve or close the case as media has reported.
"We'll continue looking into the case regardless of how difficult it may be," Lin said.

Meanwhile, Liu Wei-chung, a Tainan chief prosecutor and a member of the investigative team, reiterated that Chen Yi-hsiung's family members are all free and have not been subject to any restrictions in movement and communications. After one-and-a-half days of dredging in the Anping Harbor where Chen Yi-hsiung's body was found, investigators have failed to find the gun allegedly used by the suspect. Investigators said they will not search the area again unless there are new leads or information. Instead, the team will focus on several other possible locations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NATIONAL CONGRESS SPECIAL SESSION TO START SATURDAY

TEXT.P: An extraordinary session of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) National Congress will be opened Saturday, two days before China's National People's Congress is expected to pass an "anti-secession" law aimed at Taiwan next Monday.

President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech at the session, during which the DPP will pass a draft statute governing the nomination of candidates for the mission-oriented National Assembly elections slated for May 14, a DPP official said.
Premier Frank Hsieh and DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang will also attend and deliver speeches at the session, the main theme of which will be "Persist in Reforms, Defend Taiwan, " the official went on.

Prior to the closing of its national congress special session, the official pointed out, the DPP will issue a statement expressing its strong opposition to Beijing's "anti-secession" law and its determination to safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty and to push for constitutional reforms.

According to a DPP preliminary plan, the party will nominate around 150 candidates for the mission-oriented National Assembly elections. A total of 300 delegates will be elected exclusively for the task of reviewing the constitutional amendment proposals passed by the Legislative Yuan last year.

The legislature passed several constitutional amendment proposals at an extraordinary session last August, including the halving of the number of seats in the current 225-seat legislature, the adoption of a "single seat, two votes" electoral system for the legislature, the abrogation of the National Assembly, and the inclusion of the referendum right into the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR NAMED AS KMT CANDIDATE FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was named by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday as a party candidate for the National Assembly elections in May.
Ma said he was honored by the nomination and promised to do justice to the KMT's choice.

Ma said he is one of 74 candidates named by the KMT for National Assembly members-at-large, and there will be another 76 candidates to be named on the recommendations of the party's local branches around the island.

In response to newspapers' reports that the KMT named him in hopes that his popularity with local voters will help boost support for other KMT candidates, Ma said modestly that he is not confident that his appearance on the KMT ticket will attract more votes for the KMT, but he will do his utmost for his party.
The National Assembly is supposed to work on proposals presented by the Legislative Yuan to amend the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERMENT'S REPORT WARNS OF CHINA'S RAPID INDUSTRIAL UPGRADING

TEXT.P: China is upgrading and adjusting its industrial structure to better its competitiveness, a situation that could find China overtaking Taiwan in eight years or less in manufacturing technologies, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Friday.
The bureau identified the electronics sector as being the most vulnerable.

The IDB research was aimed at forecasting the competitiveness of Taiwan products against those from the mainland in the international market through analysis of U.S., Japanese and European Union statistics on trade, as well as relevant statistics released by the governments of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Through the research, the bureau build an indicator regarding cross-strait industrial development, a system to forecast the export growth rate, and an economic impact indicator.

According to the report, in 2003, Taiwan's largest exports were in the manufacturing sector of electronic parts and components, Accounting for 19.25 percent of all of the country's exports. The second largest export item, at 19.14 percent that year, was from the computer telecommunications and video and audio electronic production sector.

The figures were not very much different from those in 1993, the report said, indicating, however, that the ratio of mainland exports from these two sectors to the whole surged from 6.91 percent to 24.27 percent during the 10-year period, while that regarding the food and textile sectors declined from 20.84 percent to 12.38 percent.
The numbers showed China's electronic sector is expanding at a speed that might threaten Taiwan's industrial competitiveness, an IDB official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RECEIVES WARM WELCOME AT OECD TRADE COMMITTEE MEETING

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation to the Trade Committee meeting of the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has received a warm welcome from many member states, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.
The delegation is being led by Huang Chih-peng, director-general of MOEA's Board of Foreign Trade, at the two-day OECD Trade Committee meeting, which was opened Thursday, according to the official.

The official said that this is Taiwan's first time to participate in a meeting of the OECD Trade Committee since the country became an "ad hoc observer" of the committee in October last year. In addition to the island, Israel and Romania were also invited to attend the meeting as "ad hoc observers."

Chairman of the meeting Crawford Falconer of New Zealand and delegates from other member states, such as Switzerland and Germany, expressed their warm welcome to the Taiwan delegation for its presence at the session, the official said, adding that Taiwan's participation in the meeting will help boost the island's relations with OECD member states.

The official quoted the Taiwan delegation leader as saying that as world's 15th-largest trade country, Taiwan will participate actively in OECD-sponsored activities to make constructive contributions to the organization.
The OECD groups 30 member countries sharing a commitment to democratic government and market economy. Taiwan obtained observer status in the organization's Competition Committee Dec. 20, 2001.

Eight of the terror suspects held at Belmarsh and other prisons for the past three years are expected to be freed on bail by this afternoon, amid growing chaos in Britain's antiterrorism laws.
Early this morning the two Houses of Parliament were still locked in a war of attrition over Charles Clarke's plans for new control orders. All the signs were that both Houses would sit all night as each refused to give way to the other.
After a day of high parliamentary drama the Lords again insisted on a series of changes to the new Bill, including their demand for a "sunset clause" under which it would expire next November.
Financial Times: UK poised to issue 50-year term bond.
The UK and Germany are expected to follow France's lead in issuing 50-year bonds, highlighting the attempts by governments around the world to lock in low interest rates at a time when pension funds and insurers are clamouring for long-term assets.

Europe and the United States have agreed on a joint approach to negotiating with Iran over its nuclear program after months of dispute, with the Bush administration agreeing to offer modest economic incentives and the Europeans agreeing to take the issue to the United Nations Security Council if negotiations fail, senior American officials said Thursday.
Wall Street Journal: Senate Approves Bill to Overhaul Bankruptcy System
The Republican-controlled Senate, brushing aside a flood of last-minute Democratic amendments, approved the most significant overhaul of the bankruptcy system in more than two decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, March 12, or the 3rd day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
641A.D.: Chinese Princess Wen Cheng of the Tang dynasty goes to Tibet to marry the Tibetan ruler.
1799: Austria declares war on France.
1832: Charles C. Boycott, English land agent in Ireland, is born. After he refused to lower rents on his estates in Ireland, tenants refused any further communication with him and his name was adopted to describe this form of protest.
1881: Kemal Ataturk, originally Mustafa Kemal, Turkish national leader and founder of modern Turkey, who served as president of the Turkish Republic from 1923 to 1938, is born.
1913: Canberra is made the capital of Australia.
1925: Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who in 1940 would be posthumously declared the founding father of the Republic of China for his life-long contributions to the revolution, dies of liver cancer in Peking at the age of 59.
1926: A foundation-stone-laying ceremony for the construction of the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Mausoleum is held in Nanking.
1938: Adolf Hitler's troops march into Austria and make the country a German province after the resignation of Austrian Premier Kurt von Schuschnigg.
1945: Anne Frank, German Jewish diarist who fled from Nazi Germany to Amsterdam with her family in 1933 and kept a diary during her years in hiding, dies of typhus in the German concentration camp at Belsen at the age of 16.
1947: U.S. President Harry Truman tells Congress that the United States must support countries fighting communism, a stance that becomes known as the "Truman Doctrine."
1949: The Central Daily News publishes its first issue in Taipei.
1966: Gen. Suharto becomes acting president after the Indonesian Congress stripped Sukarno of his authority.
1967: Svetlana Alliluyeva, daughter of Joseph Stalin, arrives in Switzerland asking for political asylum.
1968: A ground-breaking ceremony is held in Taipei for the construction of the National Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hall.
1972: Britain and Communist China agree to exchange ambassadors, 22 years after London first recognized the Beijing regime.
1985: Yang Kuei, a noted Taiwanese writer during the Japanese rule of Taiwan, dies of illness at the age of 80.
1989: Riot police battle demonstrators in Seoul demanding that President Roh Tae Woo step down.
1990: The Parliament of the Republic of Lithuania declares independence from the USSR, becoming the first Baltic republic to break away from Soviet control.
1990: The Communist Party leadership in Outer Mongolia approves opposition demands for sweeping political reforms.
1993: North Korea suddenly announces its withdrawal from the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, intensifying the already tense situation in Northeast Asia.
1996: Mainland China commences nine days of naval and air military exercises in an area of the Taiwan Straits only 53 kilometers from Kinmen and 70 kilometers from the Penghu Islands.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui echoes the pope's 1999 message for the World Day of Peace, saying that true peace lies in respect for human rights.
1999: The U.S. Senate and House of Representatives introduce a resolution reaffirming U.S. commitment to Taiwan and expressing concern over the mainland Chinese military threat to the island.
2000: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says that if elected, he will not be opposed to peace talks with mainland China.
2000: The Kinmen chapter of the Red Cross Society of the ROC is formally established with the aim of promoting humanitarian activities.
2001: The Ministry of Finance announces that the Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan and the Central Trust of China will merge into a new bank.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of character is one who is sparing with his words. A good and wise man is without anxiety and fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC ALLY SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S OPPOSITION TO 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, March 11 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines firmly supports Taiwan's objection to China's attempt to enact an "anti-secession law, " an official from the Republic of China (ROC) Embassy in the Caribbean country said Friday.

The ROC diplomat told a CNA correspondent in Panama City over the phone that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' Deputy Prime Minister Louis Straker, who doubles as the foreign affairs minister, said in a statement March 10 that his country firmly support the ROC's opposition to enactment of the law which authorizes Beijing to use "non-peaceful means" should Taiwan move toward independence.

Noting that Taiwan has contributed significantly to the development of every sector of the Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' economy since the two countries established diplomatic relations two decades ago, Straker said his country and government support Taiwan's status as an independent country and the Taiwan people's right to decide their own future.

The Japan Times: Livedoor wins injunction against NBS-Fuji TV deal
The Tokyo District Court on Friday blocked an attempt by Nippon Broadcasting System Inc. to issue share warrants to Fuji TV in a bid to keep Internet firm Livedoor Co. from taking over NBS.

FORT DEL PILAR, Baguio City -- President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo will confer the Presidential Saber and the President Gloria Arroyo Achievement Award for Academic Excellence on the valedictorian of the Class 2005 Sanlingan of the Philippine Military Academy (PMA) here today.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Rush to save Tarongoy on
FOR THE second time in eight months, the government scrambled yesterday to try and save a Filipino hostage in Iraq, as the final hours of a deadline set by the captors of Roberto "Bobby" Tarongoy dangerously ticked away.
The Philippine Star: Pesticide poisoning eyed
The cassava sweets that poisoned more than a hundred schoolchildren in Mabini town in Bohol on Wednesday may have been contaminated by pesticide.

The Philippines has pleaded with Iraqi militants not to kill a Filipino they have held hostage for months, stressing it has no soldiers in that country, only civilians, the Department of Foreign Affairs said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : More cash and space for sports enthusiasts.
If you play, you win. Whether you are a professional or just someone who likes to dribble a football at the weekends, you count in the Sports Ministry's game plan.
Sportsmen and sports organisers can dip into a fresh allocation of $300 million to fuel Singapore's ambition to become one of Asia's top 10 sporting nations by 2010.
And everyone will be able to make use of 50 designated school fields at weekends, starting from April 1.
More than 150 plots of vacant state land islandwide will also be made available for sports. Grassroots organisations will be able to apply to upgrade the land to make it suitable, with government financial help.
The Lianhe Zaobao: 50 schools fields open for sports rent.
Fifty school fields will be open for sports rent, and more than 150 plots of vacant state land will also be made avaiable for sports, Community Development, Youth and Sports Minister Vivian Balakrishnan announced yesterday in Parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR RESERVED ABOUT DPP-ORGANIZED RALLY

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday he might not take part in the March 26 rally organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to protest China's "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan.

Ma said he would join the chiefs of various counties and cities from around Taiwan in decrying the law in a news conference for foreign journalists March 14 when the law is expected to be passed by the National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament.

In that news conference, Ma said, he and the local government chiefs will unveil an open letter to worldwide media to protest the law and to appeal for international support for Taiwan in its opposition to the law.
"I think that would be enough to show our stance," Ma said.
Asked whether the news conference would be boycotted by DPP county and city chiefs, Ma said: "I am not worried about it."
The mayor also pointed out that he was one of the first people in Taiwan to speak out against the proposed law, voicing his opposition to it back in December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAT, DOG VACCINES IN SUFFICIENT SUPPLY: COA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday that vaccines for cats and dogs are in sufficient supply and urged owners to take their pets to the veterinarian to receive their regular shots.

Officials from the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine noted that the government lifted late last year the ban on imports from the United States of cat and dog vaccines containing ruminant serum, and that so far, 409,761 doses have been imported

The officials said that in view of the fact that around 70,000 doses on average are used in Taiwan every month, the current supply should be sufficient to meet demand for the first half of the year. Further imports will come later, they added.

They reminded pet owners to take their cats and dogs to veterinarians to receive vaccinations regularly to ensure the health of their pets and to avoid diseases that could be contracted by people also.

Taiwan imposed a ban on cat and dog vaccines that contain ruminant serum in December 2003 in the wake of a case of mad cow disease in Washington State. Taiwan also banned the import of U.S. beef and beef products at that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS IN TORONTO PROTEST AGAINST 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW'
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, March 11 (CNA) (By Chang Chun-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Nearly 300 Taiwanese expatriates residing in Toronto held a rally in the Canadian city Thursday to protest China's plan to enact an "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.

Holding green banners symbolizing Taiwan, the protesters chanted slogans such as "One China, One Taiwan!" "China, Hands Off Taiwan!" "Let Taiwan into the United Nations! " and "Let Taiwan into the World Health Organization! " as they marched to the Chinese Consulate General in Toronto to lodge their protest.
The protesters stressed that the fate of Taiwan should be determined by its people and urged the Canadian government to throw its support behind the island.

According to Huang Ta-tun, a leader of the Taiwanese community in Toronto, Taiwan is a sovereign state independent of the People's Republic of China, and the "anti-secession law" will be inapplicable to Taiwan because it is a domestic law of China.
Huang called on China to resume dialogue with Taiwan based on the principle of equality between sovereign nations and seek to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait differences through peaceful means.

The "anti-seccession law, " which the National People's Congress of China is expected to pass next week, authorizes Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW ABSURD: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) urged Beijing Saturday not to enact its "anti-secession law," calling it an absurd law that has stirred up resentment among the people in Taiwan.

Stressing that Beijing cannot hide or lessen the absurdity of the law no matter how hard it tries, the MAC said in a statement that what matters now for Beijing is to put an end to the legislation in order to secure peace and the status quo in the Taiwan Strait. It added that it would be a great mistake for Beijing to go against the Taiwan people's aspirations for peace.

The MAC made it clear that the law has fully exposed Beijing's hegemonic mindset and paranoid intent to arbitrarily determine Taiwan's future as seen in the provision that authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" in dealing with Taiwan. It pointed out that the provision is proof that Beijing's calls for peace and exchanges across the strait are all a lie.
The Cabinet-level MAC is Taiwan's top agency in charge of mainland policy planning.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Beijing's insistence on enacting the law despite the Taiwan people's disapproval is counterproductive to the fragile cross-strait relations, describing the latest remarks by a ranking Beijing official on the law as "the same old lines."

Chiu said that the international community will not accept Beijing's military action against Taiwan and that it is beyond doubt that Beijing is seeking to unilaterally deny the Republic of China's sovereignty through the "anti-secession law."

Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, repeated late Friday that the "anti-secession" legislation is not aimed at the majority of the Taiwan people, but rather at "a few separatists seeking Taiwan independence."
The National People's Congress, Beijing's ceremonial parliament, is expected to pass the law before the conclusion of its ongoing annual session Monday.

Chen Ching-chun, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), urged leaders of the two sides to sit down and open peace talks. He said that Beijing should give up its "anti-secession" legislation if it really wants peace with Taiwan.

Chen's counterparts in the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union echoed his comments, saying that the law is a scheme by Beijing to downgrade the ROC and make Taiwan surrender and become a part of mainland China.
To counter Beijing's military intimidation, the ruling DPP is planning a large-scale protest for March 26 in Taipei. At least half a million people are expected to take part in the demonstration.
