DOC.HEADLINE: WANG PROMISES PEACEFUL CAMPAIGN IF HE DOES RUN FOR KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday that he still has to assess over the next few days whether to run for the Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship, and that if he does run for the post, the campaign will be rational and peaceful.

The politically-savvy speaker made the remarks while attending a ceremony marking the establishment of the "Friends of Jin-pyng in Kaohsiung County" support group in the southern Taiwan county. A similar group was established in Pingtung County the same day.

Wang earlier said that he wants incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan to continue in the post. Lien has yet to publicly announce his intention to step down, although he has said several times that the party needs a generational transition.
Wang, a legislator for 10 consecutive terms, expressed appreciation to his supporters, saying that the party, after losses in the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections, has faced a number of problems.

Feeling the passion of his hometown supporters, Wang said he will give serious consideration to whether to run for the party's top post. He said he will consider whether he is fit to serve in the post, to continue the reforms started by Lien, to integrate the KMT and its two splinter parties, the New Party and the People First Party (PFP) , to deal with the controversial issue of the party's assets, and to inject new blood into the party and make it "Taiwanese."

As cross-strait relations are crucial to the existence and development of the nation, Wang said, he will consider whether he is capable of handling cross-strait relations and increasing exchanges and cooperation with the international community.

Amid misgivings within the KMT that the chairmanship election, which is set for May, might turn into a battle between Wang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- both of whom are KMT vice chairmen -- and divide the largest opposition party, Wang promised that this wouldn't be the case.

"If I do join the election, the campaign will be rational and peaceful, " Wang said, adding that the public "will have a "different look at the party, " and that it will "by no means splinter the party."
KMT Legislator Lin Yi-shih said that if the KMT wants to flourish in southern Taiwan, it will need a chairman from Kaohsiung County.

PFP Legislator Chung Shao-he said that Wang's running for the party chairmanship will only be the beginning. Looking ahead to the 2008 presidential election, only Wang is capable of integrating the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and the New Party, he added.

Yeh Yao-peng, former Control Yuan ombudsman, said that the "pan-blue alliance" is more popular in northern Taiwan, while the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, has wider support in southern Taiwan. If Wang could serve as KMT head, this would help the "pan-blue alliance" to make gains in the "pan-green" stronghold, he added.
It is generally believed that Wang is supported mainly by party members in the south while Ma is popular among urban citizens, especially those in the north.

DOC.HEADLINE: 66% OF GRADUATING COLLEGE STUDENTS WORRIED ABOUT UNEMPLOYMENT: POLL

TEXT.P: Over 60 percent of Taiwan college students graduating this summer are worried they might have difficulty finding employment after graduation, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

In the survey, conducted by the 1111 Job Bank on 1,104 students between Feb. 26 and March 11, 66 percent of the respondents said they are worried about not being able to find a job after graduation. The survey is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 2.9 percentage points.

Of those surveyed, 62.86 percent said they plan to enter the workforce immediately after graduation, 14.49 percent said they plan to continue their studies, 9.6 percent plan to perform their military service, and 8.33 percent plan to prepare for employment-related examinations.
The average "workplace competitiveness" score of those respondents planning to seek employment immediately upon graduation was only 64.2 points on a 100-point scale.

The top five favored occupations among the respondents were administration and general affairs (27.72 percent) , accounting and finance (22.64 percent), computer hardware and communications (17.93 percent), restaurant, tourism and transportation (14.86 percent), and sales and trade (14.67 percent).
On average, the respondents expect to receive NT$26,804.43 (US$869.7) per month for their first job, or NT$1,600 higher than the figure in a similar survey conducted last year.
Meanwhile, in another survey conducted by the job search Web site between Feb. 23 and March 11 on 725 employers, 74 percent of the respondents said they are willing to hire fresh graduates.

The remaining 26 percent said they are not willing to hire fresh graduates because of the graduates' poor ability to deal with stress, their lack of work experience and professional skills, and their poor work attitude, as well as the high costs involved in training new workers.

Among the respondents who said they are willing to hire fresh graduates, the considerations cited in determining whether to hire one included the graduates' field of specialization, part-time work experience, involvement in extra-curricular activities, reputation of the schools they graduated from, and achievements in competitions as well as whether they served as class leaders.
The qualities that employers are looking for in fresh graduates include a good work attitude, a strong ability to deal with stress, good communication skills, and an enthusiasm for work.

Meanwhile, NT$25,146.82 is the average starting salary that the respondents believe is reasonable for fresh graduates. The figure is NT$2,384 higher than that found in a similar survey conducted last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA TO FORMALLY KICK OFF HIS CAMPAIGN FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP IN APRIL

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that he will formally kick off his campaign for the Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship in April and that the plan won't be changed even if Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng announces his intention to run before that time.

After learning that Wang was on a trip Saturday to his hometown of Kaohsiung to consult with his supporters about the possibility of his entering the race, Ma said he has never expected to run unopposed, adding that having more candidates enter the race is better for the KMT because it means more people are interested in serving the party.

Noting that the KMT would begin candidate registration after March 21, Ma said he would announce his candidacy probably in April at which time he would begin seeking the sponsorship of party members to enter the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ON CROSS-STRAIT POLICY: 'RECONCILIATION, BUT NO CONCESSION'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Saturday the government's pragmatic attitude in the face of Beijing's proposed "anti-secession" legislation, saying that Taiwan will uphold its policy of "reconciliation, but no concession; steadfastness, but no confrontation."
Chen made the reaffirmation during an inspection tour of an Air Force base in suburban Tainan in southern Taiwan.

Noting that China's proposed "anti-secession" law reveals its attempt to use "undemocratic, non-peaceful" means to alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said the government will deal with any evident and urgent threat from the mainland with a pragmatic attitude.
"We'll continue our reconciliatory attitude, but we'll never compromise on our core values and basic stances. While we'll remain steadfast, we'll not be provocative or confrontational," Chen said.

Stressing that peace and democracy are Taiwan's core values, Chen said protecting Taiwan's hard-won freedom and democracy will be the most constructive contribution Taiwan can make to the international community.
Chen further said mainland China's continued military buildup has threatened regional stability and caused serious concern in the international community.

The United States and Japan have for the first time announced in their recent joint security communique that peace in the Taiwan Strait is a common strategic objective, Chen said, adding that the United States has also voiced opposition on many occasions to the European Union's plan to lift its 16-year ban on arms sales to China.
"All these developments spotlight that China's military expansion is no longer just a potential threat and has instead become an evident and even imminent crisis," Chen said.

Pointing out that Taiwan's conviction for peace and democracy has set it far apart from mainland China, Chen said Taiwan is determined to defend its pluralistic, democratic lifestyle as well as the international order.
In the face of China's mounting threat, Chen said the nation's armed forces should understand the necessity and urgency of upgrading their defense capabilities.
Referring to the government's pending massive arms procurement from the United States, Chen said the plan is by no means aimed at engaging in an arms race with China.

"The package is part of our efforts to build up an elite deterrent force to back up the government's goal of setting up a cross-strait military buffer zone and a viable cross-strait military trust and consultative mechanism," Chen explained.

The arms procurement package, which is pending legislative approval, includes eight diesel-electric submarines, six PACIII Patriot anti-missile batteries, and a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft.

This was President Chen's third visit to the Tainan air base. In addition to joining military staff stationed at the base and their dependents in making dough figurines, Chen also reviewed combat facilities and military training exercises during his half-day inspection tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN URGES E.U. NOT TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday urged the European Union not to lift its arms embargo against mainland China before Beijing improves its human rights record and implements genuine democracy.
The president made the appeal while addressing a provisional meeting of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party congress held at the Taipei International Convention Center.

President Chen pointed out that Beijing has refused to address the aspirations of the Taiwan people for democracy and peace, has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan for the purpose of unification, and has dismissed the efforts of the Taiwan people to pursue democratization as unilateral provocation.

Beijing's verbal attacks and military intimidation has continued unabated, Chen said, adding that it is now planning to use "non-peaceful" and undemocratic means to sabotage the fruits of Taiwan's democracy achieved over the past five decades.
With the situation in the Taiwan Strait stable and with the success of the Chinese Lunar New Year cross-strait charter flights, the two sides should move towards a further opening up to each other.
He lamented the fact that Beijing has instead pushed for the enactment of an "anti-secession" law, which he said has raised cross-strait tensions.

The president said that although China's national security has been less threatened over the past decade than at any other period in recent history, Beijing's defense budgets have increased by double-digit figures during the last ten years.

China has deployed 706 missiles targeting Taiwan, and the number is growing at 120 missiles every year, Chen said, adding that this has tilted the military balance in the Taiwan Strait and led the United States and Japan to say that "Taiwan is a mutual security concern" in a joint statement following a Security Consultative Committee meeting in Washington, D.C. late last month.

The president stressed that China's military expansion as well as its unfriendly attitude toward its neighbors have threatened the democracy and security of Taiwan as well as regional peace and stability.
"Before China improves its human rights record and implements genuine democracy, there is no reason for the E.U. to lift its arms embargo, " the president said.

Noting that many E.U. members are founders of the modern democratic movement and that they have defended democracy with blood, Chen said that if they were to allow an "undemocratic and totalitarian" country to invade a free and democratic country, this would be the biggest blemish in the history of democracy.

The president also said recently that if the E.U. were to lift its arms embargo, imposed shortly after the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre, it would be tantamount to "encouraging and supporting" an "undemocratic and non-peaceful country" to use force against a "democratic Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: LG TO PLACE US$1.4 BILLION WORTH OF ORDERS IN TAIWAN FOR 2005

TEXT.P: LG Electronics, the world's leading maker of electronic products, plans to purchase US$1.4 billion worth of electronic parts and components in Taiwan this year, the South Korean company's CEO said Saturday.
In 2004, LG Electronics bought US$500 million worth of Taiwanese products.

Kim Ssang Su held a news conference in Taipei to announce LG's 2005 procurement plan in Taiwan. Asked whether the electronics giant would continue to increase its orders on the island, Kim said that as long as Taiwan maintains its competitiveness, LG will not only continue buying more Taiwanese products, but will also seek cooperation ties with Taiwanese companies.

The CEO told reporters that since the mainland Chinese market for electronic products has been increasingly expanding, LG has forecast that its operational revenue in the greater Chinese market, which covers the mainland, Taiwan, Hong Kong and several Mandarin-speaking areas, will account for 30 percent of the company's total operational revenue in the near future.
In 2004, LG's operational revenue hit US$31 billion, and the figure is expected to surge to US$41 billion this year, Kim said, adding that his company has set the target of US$100 billion by 2010.
LG Electronics has declared its ambition to rank among the top three electronics, information and telecommunication firms in the world by 2010 in a statement posted on its Web site.
Of LG's US$1.4 billion worth of orders from Taiwan for this year, semiconductor products, major electronic parts and LCD TV panels will make up the bulk of the orders, according to Kim.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO TEMPORARILY SUSPEND CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The government should temporarily suspend cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in the face of mainland China's impending passage of an "anti-secession" law, scholars suggested Saturday.

Speaking at a seminar held by the Taiwan New Century Foundation, Chen Ming-tung, a professor at National Taiwan University and a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said that Beijing's aim is to challenge the U.S. role in dictating the cross-strait situation and to try to cross the red line of "no Taiwan independence, no Beijing military action" set by Washington.

The enactment of the law could bring the entire Asia-Pacific region to the dangerous verge of war, and both the United States and Japan could also be drawn into a military conflict against mainland China, he warned.

He predicted that the passage of the law, expected to happen Monday, will hinder cross-strait exchanges and upset the positive atmosphere created by the success of the special lunar new year cross-strait charter flights. In the current situation, it would be very hard to continue two-way exchanges, including opening talks on direct air links, he added.
Su Chin-chiang, chairman of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union and a former national security advisor, urged the government to cut cross-strait interaction for the time being.

Su stressed that Beijing has been trying to use every means, including the "anti-secession" law, to bully Taiwan. The law is by no means aimed at "a few separatists seeking Taiwan independence" as Beijing has claimed, he argued.
Lin Cheng-yi, director of the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University, proposed holding a defensive referendum to counter the "anti-secession" law.
Claiming that the "anti-secession" legislation reflects a "pre-emptive" military strategy being mulled by Beijing against Taiwan, Lin warned that it will eventually push Taiwan further away.

He contended that the "anti-secession" law is a war-mandating law that will provide Beijing with a legal excuse to define the cross-strait status quo and wage war against Taiwan under the conditions that it sets.

To highlight Taiwan's right to say "no" to Beijing internationally, the government should consider holding a referendum to make the world aware of the Taiwan people's desire to safeguard their democratic values and maintain their lifestyle, he said.

He also opined that the government should do its utmost to push through a major military procurement budget as quickly as possible at the Legislative Yuan and that it should step up its lobbying efforts to persuade the European Union not to lift its ban on arms sales to the mainland.
He added that at a time when Beijing is set to enact the "anti-secession" law, the government in Taiwan should display its courage and wisdom to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR ONE MILLION PEOPLE TO JOIN MARCH 26 RALLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday called for "one million people" to participate in a rally set for March 26 against the expected enactment of China's "anti-secession law."

Chen urged the Beijing authorities to respect the free will of the Taiwan people and not to miscalculate the situation, saying the people on this island will not remain silent on China's stubborn move to push through the legislation.

The "anti-secession law," which the National People's Congress of China is expected to pass during its on-going session that ends Monday, empowers Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island moves toward independence.

Addressing the second provisional meeting of the 11th National Congress of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Chen warned that China will further estrange people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait by introducing a unilateral, unreasonable law to try to legitimize the use of force against Taiwan.
"The 'anti-secession law' will allow China to determine the fate of Taiwan unilaterally disregarding the right to free choice and will of the Taiwan people," Chen said.

"The so-called 'non-peaceful means' is also in violation of the international consensus that 'cross-strait differences should be resolved through peaceful dialogue' and will lead to a unilateral change in the cross-strait status quo and seriously hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people," he added.

According to Chen, the people of Taiwan expect continued peace in the Taiwan Strait, and the leaders of China should try to resolve the cross-strait deadlock with wisdom instead of damaging the atmosphere of cross-strait reconciliation.

Not to be outdone by Hong Kong, which saw 500,000 residents take to the streets on July 1, 2003 to protest against a proposed "anti-subversion law, " the DPP will try to draw at least one million people to join the March 26 rally to protest the "anti-secession law," Chen said.

The president urged the people, regardless of their sex, age, political affiliation and occupation, to participate in the rally to demonstrate to the international community their resolve to defend the democracy and peace of Taiwan.
Also during the meeting, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Taiwan is facing an unprecedented crisis with its freedom and democracy being at stake.
As a party that has always stood by the people, the DPP is obliged to exhibit its firm opposition to the enactment of the "anti-secession law," Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PLANTS TREES TO MARK ARBOR DAY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou planted trees on Mount Chinan in a northern suburb of the city Saturday to mark Arbor Day.

The tree-planting activity was held to publicize the city government's achievements in relocating villagers from dangerous landslide prone areas on the mountain and to raise public awareness of the importance of water and soil conservation, according to officials from the Department of Economic Development under Taipei City Government.

The tree-planting activity began with a ceremony during which Mayor Ma bestowed awards on a water conservation association and Shih Chien University for their assistance in making arrangements regarding the tree-planting activity.

While addressing the ceremony, Ma said he hopes that Mount Chinan could become a mountain filled with forests and that everybody could remember the Republic of China founding father well on this day. March 12 was designated as Arbor Day by the government in 1929 to commemorate Dr. Sun Yat-sen who passed away on that date in 1925.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO TAKE PART IN 326 RALLY AGAINST 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW': DPP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to take part in the large-scale rally being organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for March 26 against China's "anti-secession law," a DPP lawmaker said Saturday.
Earlier in the day, Chen called for one million people to take part in the rally to show their resolve to defend Taiwan's peace and democracy.
Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said he believes the president himself will not be absent from the event and will lead the demonstration.
According to Lai, the DPP had originally set the target of 500,000 participants in the rally, and the party now hopes at least one million people will come out to "protect Taiwan."
Lai said the DPP has decided to hold the rally in Taipei, and if the number of participants reaches one million, the party might hold rallies in northern, central and southern parts of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR ROC OFFICIAL ARRIVES IN JAPAN FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Frank Hsieh's chief of staff arrived in Nagoya Saturday for a visit aimed at learning from Japan's experience in organizing the upcoming Aichi World Exposition, also known as Aichi Expo.
Cabinet Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan was the first senior ROC official to take advantage of Japan's new visa-free privilege for Taiwan tourists to visit the country.
Lee said his visit is mainly aimed at touring Aichi Expo facilities and studying the exposition's operational formula for reference in organizing a world exposition in Taiwan in 2008.

Senior officials of the three counties selected to be sites of the planned 2008 Taiwan world exposition -- Taoyuan, Chiayi and Tainan -- are accompanying Lee on his current visit. The officials include Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen, Taoyuan County Deputy Magistrate Huang Min-kung and Tainan County Deputy Yen Chun-tsou.

ROC Representative to Japan Koh Se-kai traveled from Tokyo to Nagoya to greet Lee and other delegation members. The ROC officials will visit Taiwan farm produce sales counters and restaurants selling Taiwan-flavor foods and snacks at Aichi Expo theme park Sunday.
The eco-friendly Aichi Expo is scheduled to open March 25 and last through Sept. 25.
With a view to attracting more foreign visitors to the Aichi Expo, Japan passed regulations in February to waive the visa requirement s for Taiwan tourists between March 11 and Sept. 25.
During the period, Taiwan passport holders can enter Japan without visas for sightseeing purposes for a maximum 90-day stay.
Japanese government officials said they will also consider whether to offer Taiwan citizens permanent visa-free privileges after the Aichi Expo.
Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea. Japan began to offer similar visa waivers to South Korean citizens early this month.
However, Taiwan's top five officials are still required to apply for a visa if they decide to visit Japan during the world exposition in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi.

According to a report by ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen last week, Japan's visa waiver is inapplicable to top five ROC officials -- President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i and Tan Sun Chen himself.
For fear of offending China, Japan has traditionally been reluctant to issue visas to senior ROC leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INVITES OPPOSITION TO PARTICIPATE IN MARCH 26 RALLY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Saturday urged all the Taiwan people, including backers of the opposition parties, to take part in the March 26 rally in Taipei against Beijing's "anti-secession" law.

Hsieh called for opposition supporters to join forces with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in a gesture to show Taiwan's solidarity to the world in the face of the impending enactment of a law aimed at curbing Taiwan's independence.

Despite their different political stances, the people of Taiwan should unite to protect Taiwan and loudly express their opposition to the "anti-secession" law, the premier said, asserting that the "Taiwan first concept" is shared by all the people in their pursuit of making Taiwan into a sound and a great nation.

Meanwhile, the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) voiced its opposition to the law for authorizing the use of "non-peaceful" means in dealing with Taiwan and urged Beijing to rethink its planned enactment of the law set for Monday.

Taiwan identity is not tantamount to Taiwan independence, and Beijing should refrain from non-peaceful means to settle cross-Taiwan Strait disputes, a KMT official said, adding that the KMT will do everything it can to protect the dignity of the Republic of China and maintain peace in the strait.
The DPP forecasts that at least half a million people will take part in the March 26 demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR VISIT TO TWO CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu left Taiwan Saturday for an official visit to El Salvador and Guatemala -- two diplomatic allies of the Republic of China in Central America.
The vice president will also make transit stops in Houston and Miami during the 12-day visit.

Lu, at the head of the 152-member delegation, said prior to her departure at CKS International Airport that the visit is aimed at cementing diplomatic ties and introducing Taiwan's industries to its allies.

The delegation, which in addition to government officials, includes executives of state-owned and private enterprises, the vice president said, hoping to introduce Taiwan's traditional and high-tech industries to its allies and further increase trade exchanges with them.

According to delegation's itinerary, Lu will inspect the possibility of establishing a "Taiwan Park" for industries in El Salvador, in the hopes that the park's construction can be completed and its operations begin within the remaining three years of President Chen Shui-bian's term.

If all goes well, the park project would be the first time that Taiwan's public and private sectors join hands to make inroads into the Central America, which would not only help Taiwan businesspeople to reach out and flex Taiwan's economic and industrial muscle, but would also help the island's bid to become an observer in the Organization of American States.

Lu will also attend a regional meeting of Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America in Guatemala. Not only six Central American allies, but also five non-ally countries in North, Central and South America will attend the meeting, Lu said, adding that this will be a a warm-up to a DPU regional organization that will be established in Taipei August 14.
During the 12-day visit, the vice president will call on Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar and Guatemalan President Oscar Berger.
She will also be decorated by the two governments and will deliver speeches to the parliaments of both countries.

On March 19, the vice president will have a tea party with the media to give a major talk on the first anniversary of the controversial election-eve assassination attempt against herself and President Chen.

The opposition has accused the presidential election-eve shooting as a set-up to win sympathy votes. President Chen won by less than 30,000 votes out of 13 million cast in the March 20, 2004 election. (By Lilian Wu) endiatem/Li

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE TOURISTS TO TAIWAN TOP THE LIST: PROFESSOR

TEXT.P: Japan is Taiwan's top source of foreign tourists, followed by Hong Kong, Macau and the United States, a professor in tourism said Saturday.

Citing statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Yang Ming-chin of the Province University in Taichung, central Taiwan said that between 2001 and 2003, tourists from Japan accounted for 29 percent of all foreign tourists to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN GREEN EXPOSITION KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 2005 Ilan Green Exposition kicked off Saturday at the Wu Lau Ken scenic area in Suao Township, with animals such as lizards, red fire ants, and silkworms serving as attractions at the annual event.

"Discovering Living Greens" is the theme of the sixth Green Expo. Various pavilions have been set up within the scenic area to display a great number of reptiles, insects and shells, according to Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-sheng.

For example, at the "lizard pavilion, " the komodo dragon, the world's largest lizard, is on display, along with other lizards, including chameleons and iguanas, Liu told a CNA reporter at the venue on Saturday.

The county chief also said that fire ants, which have been causing damage to agricultural fields in cities and counties in Taiwan, including Taipei, Taoyuan, Chiayi and Ilan, are on display at the "ant pavilion" in line with a prevention and control program initiated by the government to teach the public how to stamp out the dangerous imported insects.

The event also has a "Korean pavilion" where the cuisine of the various regions in the Northeast Asian country are on display, as well as a "Kavalan pavilion" which features many valuable artifacts related to the eastern Taiwan aboriginal tribe.

The exposition, which will run through May 8, has been organized by the Ilan County Government annually to promote the ideas of nature conservation, environmental protection and folk culture preservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:
Army Details Scale of Abuse of Prisoners in an Afghan Jail
Two prisoners who died in U.S. custody in Afghanistan were beaten by soldiers in sustained assaults that caused their deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO ANNOUNCE 'ANTI-SECESSION LAW' COUNTERMEASURES MONDAY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will hold a news conference Monday to expound the government's staunch opposition and countermeasures to China's so-called "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan, a senior official said Saturday.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Beijing's anti-secession legislation is a mistake which has invited aversion from the people of Taiwan regardless of their party affiliation.

As Beijing's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- is expected to pass the so-called "anti-secession" law March 14, Chiu said, the MAC will hold a news conference at 4 p.m. the same day to make known to the world the government's staunch opposition to that evil piece of legislation.
The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, will also take advantage of the occasion to expound its strategy and measures to counter Beijing's threatening move, Chiu said.
According to the draft version released by Beijing earlier this week, the so-called "anti-secession" law will authorize the use of "non-peaceful means" to solve issues across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PASSES 'PROTECT TAIWAN' DECLARATION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) passed a declaration at a provisional party congress Saturday, reaffirming its commitment to promoting sweeping reform and protecting Taiwan's sovereign status in the face of Beijing's proposed "anti-secession" legislation.

The declaration, titled "Insist on Reform, Protect Taiwan, " slammed Beijing's so-called "anti-secession" law as a piece of legislation aimed at using force or non-peaceful means to alter the present status quo across the Taiwan Strait and sabotage peace in the region.
The proposed law is in violation of the international law and detrimental to stability and security in the Asia-Pacific region, the DPP declaration said.

Stressing that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, the declaration said Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to its 23 million residents and that only the people of Taiwan have a final say on any change to its future.

With an aim to defend the 23 million Taiwan people's rights to determine their own destiny, the declaration said, the DPP will join hands with other domestic political parties and social groups to organize a mass rally March 26 to make known to the world Taiwan people's resolve to defend Taiwan with freedom, democracy and peace.

The declaration also urged the international community to adopt effective common actions to prevent the Beijing government from enacting the so-called "anti-secession" legislation which it said would wreck cross-strait peace and Asia-Pacific stability.
As Taiwan's ruling party, the declaration added, the DPP will staunch protect the 23 million Taiwan people's freedom and right to determine their own destiny.

The declaration also reaffirmed the DPP's support for a constitutional amendments package passed by the Legislative Yuan last August, which will pave the way for Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering project.

The declaration said the DPP will win as many National Assembly seats as possible to facilitate the passage of the constitutional amendments package by the mission-oriented National Assembly to be elected May 14.

The DPP provisional party congress was aimed at discussing nomination rules for selecting its candidates for the May 14 National Assembly elections. A total of 300 seats will be up for grabs and the DPP has decided to nominate 150 candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: STEPHEN M. YOUNG MAY BE NEW DE FACTO U.S. AMBASSADOR TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Stephen M. Young, incumbent U.S. ambassador to the Kyrgyz Republic, is likely to succeed Douglas Paal as the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan, informed sources said Saturday.

Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) -- the United States' unofficial office in Taipei -- is expected to leave his current post in the middle of this year, the sources said, adding that Young is Paal's most likely successor.

Young, a career diplomat, was appointed U.S. ambassador to the Kyrgyz Republic, a former Soviet republic, in April 2003. During his childhood he once lived in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung along with his family for two years. He later twice worked at the AIT, including serving as AIT deputy director from summer of 1998 to summer of 2001.

Before Young's departure from the AIT deputy director post, President Chen Shui-bian decorated him with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon, making him the first AIT official to receive such an honor since the United States switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979.

Young has a Ph.D. in history from the University of Chicago. If he truly becomes the new AIT chief, he will be the first U.S. ambassador ever to transfer to the top AIT post in Taipei. In the past, only AIT chiefs became U.S. ambassadors to other countries after ending up their Taipei tenures.

Paal took over as the unofficial U.S. ambassador to Taiwan in April 2002. U.S. officials said in private that Paal is epxtected to end his Taipei tenure this summer. Paal's wife already returned to the United States in February to take up a federal government post.
U.S. government authorities were not available at the moment to comment or confirm the reports about the exact timing of Paal's departure and his possible successor.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CHIN-YUNG MAY BE NAMED ACTING YUNLIN COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Lee Chin-yung, vice chairman of the Public Construction Commission (PCC) , is very likely to be named acting Yunlin County magistrate following the incumbent county chief's conviction in an election bribery case, political sources said Saturday.

Lee, a lawyer-turned-politician, once served as mayor of the northern port city of Keelung. Lee was quoted as having said that he has keen interest in serving as acting Yunlin county chief because he is familiar with local government affairs.
Before assuming the PCC post in February, Lee had been vice minister of the interior. He also once served as deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

A number of politicians have coveted the Yunlin magistrate post since the Supreme Court handed down its ruling for former county chief Chang Jung-wei Thursday, sentencing him to 12 months in jail for his involvement in the 1994 Yunlin County Council speakership election bribery case.

In addition three former DPP legislators from Yunlin county -- Su Chih-fen, Kao Meng-ting and Lin Kuo-hua, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming have also expressed keen interest in the post.

According to current regulations, the Ministry of the Interior must relieve a local government chief of his or her duties if he or she is handed a prison sentence that cannot be suspended or commuted into a fine.

As there are less than two years remaining in Chang's term, no by-election has to be held to elect a successor. Instead, the Cabinet is authorized by law to name a replacement to serve out the remainder of the term.

In fact, Chang has already been suspended and detained since last December for his alleged involvement in the corruption scandal. His deputy is now acting as Yunlin county magistrate. However, the law requires Chang's deputy, a political appointee, to be relieved of his duties along with Chang.

Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Saturday Premier Frank Hsieh will decide on the replacement of Chang after a comprehensive study of various possible candidates' qualifications. Whoever becomes the acting county chief is believed to gain an edge in the year-end magistrate election.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 13 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, March 13:

10:00, Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.

15:00, Council of Hakka Affairs Chairman Lo Wen-jia will announce his bid to run for Taipei County magistrate post in Panchiao, Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, March 13, or the 4th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1733: Dr. Joseph Priestley, the British chemist noted for his work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen in 1774, is born.
1781: William Herschel, a German-born British organist and amateur stargazer, discovers the planet Georgium Sidus, later renamed Uranus. Sir Herschel later became astronomer to George III and catalogued more than 800 double stars and 2,500 nebulae.
1855: Percival Lowell, the American astronomer whose detection of irregularities in the orbit of Uranus led to the discovery of Pluto, is born. The astronomer also founded the Lowell Observatory in Arizona, where his studies of Mars led him to believe that the planet was inhabited.
1881: Alexander II, the Tsar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is killed by bombs thrown at him by extremists in St. Petersburg on the very day he had finally agreed to implement democratic reforms.
1900: Giorgos Seferiadis, Greek poet and diplomat, is born. He won the 1963 Nobel Prize for literature.
1901: Benjamin Harrison, the 23rd U.S. president during whose administration the first Pan American Conference took place, dies at the age of 68.
1930: Pluto, the planet farthest from the sun, is discovered.
1942: British bombers stage a saturation raid on the German city of Cologne.
1946: Republic of China government forces enter Shenyang (Mukden) following the evacuation of Soviet troops.
1959: Some 300,000 Tibetans revolt against the Communist Chinese regime.
1961: Pablo Picasso, Spanish artist and one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, marries his 37-year-old model, Jacqueline Rocque, in Nice, France at the age of 79.
1967: Peasant rioting is reported in mainland China.
1967: Indira Gandhi is sworn in as the first woman prime minister of India.
1969: The Executive Yuan of the ROC decides to construct an international airport in Taoyuan County by enlarging an existing air force base.
1972: Britain closes its consulate general in Taipei after agreeing to exchange ambassadors with the regime in Beijing.
1974: The Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris is opened.
1978: Moluccan terrorists hold 72 people hostage in government buildings in Essen, Holland, demanding the release of comrades in Dutch jails. The hostages were rescued by the police the next day.
1979: The European Monetary System is officially inaugurated.
1990: The parliament of the Soviet Union votes to end the political monopoly of the Soviet Communist Party after 72 years, to allow for private ownership of factories and for a strong presidency.
1992: A strong earthquake rocks eastern Turkey, killing some 4,000 people.
1992: Mauritius, an island located in the Indian Ocean, becomes a republic, dropping its links with the British crown 24 years after proclaiming its independence.
1998: President Kim Dae Jung grants amnesty to some five million South Korean prisoners, including political prisoners and those convicted on drunk driving charges.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents the keys to the city to his Panamanian counterpart, Juan Carlos Navarro.
2000: Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee says that he will resign in order to accept Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian's invitation to head his national advisory group.
2001: Opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong says that he is extremely disappointed by what he described as the Democratic Progressive Party-ruled government's "fast and rampant corruption."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who can resist the long-continued attempts of others to insinuate prejudice into him, or one who cannot be influenced by a sudden appeal to his own personal safety -- such a man may be considered a man of perspicuity. Indeed, a man who can resist such an influence, or such an appeal, must really be a superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CLOSELY MONITORING PLA ACTIVITIES: MND

TEXT.P: The military is closely monitoring China's military movements after Chinese President Hu Jintao was elected chairman of the CPC Central Military Commission Sunday, replacing Jiang Zemin, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense said Sunday.

Liu Chih-Chian said that the Republic of China military has heightened its alert in response to Hu's succession as China's top military chief. It was reported that prior to Jiang's resignation, he said to Hu that if the People's Liberation Army (PLA) plans to take Taiwan by force, "It had better be sooner than later."

Commenting on news reports that the PLA has been ordered to "make whatever preparations needed" against "possible countermeasures" that Taiwan may adopt in protest against Beijing's enactment of an "anti-secession" law, Liu reiterated that it is the defense ministry's established policy and duty to prevent a war, safeguard the national territory and fight terrorism regardless of the odds.
Liu stressed that the defense ministry has built up effective deterrents and defensive capabilities to address any contingency and the military will react swiftly if necessary.
The draft "anti-secession" law is expected to be ratified by a vote in the Chinese National People's Congress Monday, the last day of its annual session.
The law says China could use "non-peaceful means" to stop Taiwan's secession from China should all efforts for peaceful unification prove futile.

DOC.HEADLINE: MTAC, RDEC HEADS TO BE NAMED AS DPP CANDIDATES FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) Chairman Hsu Chih-hsiung as well as Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) Chairman Yeh Jiunn-rong will be nominated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as candidates for the mission-oriented National Assembly elections in May.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said at a news conference Sunday that both Yeh and Hsu are jurists who have devoted themselves to constitutional research, so they will appear in the DPP's list of candidates for the National Assembly elections slated for May 14.

During an extraordinary national congress held Saturday, the DPP passed a special statute governing the nomination of candidates for the upcoming elections, under which a total of 150 candidates will be nominated by the party.

The top 60 candidates will be selected from among DPP chapter chairmen, prominent experts and scholars as well as the elite of society, while the rest will be recommended by DPP chapters' executive committees, Su pointed out.

Su also announced that the DPP will select two prominent young people from those who were born between Jan. 1, 1980 and May 13, 1982 and include them in the party's list of candidates for the March 14 elections.
Noting that youth should not be absent from Taiwan's sweeping constitutional reforms, Su encouraged young people to take part.

Su said that those wishing to participate in the selection process must meet five requirements: have a strong passion for the soil and people of Taiwan, persist in constitutional reforms, have abundant experience in handling public affairs, share the DPP's political concepts, and satisfy regulations governing National Assembly elections.
Young people who satisfy the requirements are welcome to sign up online at youngguns.iparty.org.tw or www.dpp.org.tw between March 13-17.

According to a recent announcement by the Central Election Commission, 300 delegates will be elected exclusively for the task of reviewing the constitutional amendment proposals passed by the Legislative Yuan last year.

The legislature passed several constitutional amendment proposals at an extraordinary session last August, including the halving of the number of seats in the current 225-seat legislature, the adoption of a "single seat, two votes" electoral system for the legislature, the abrogation of the National Assembly, and the inclusion of the right to hold referendums written into the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON POST CRITICIZES CHINA FOR ITS BRAZEN TACTICS TOWARD TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 12 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tan g)

TEXT.P: The Washington Post on Saturday published an editorial criticizing China for using straddling tactics to deal with its relations with Taiwan and panned the European Union and for its "irresponsible" policy of lifting its arms sales ban on China.

Saying that the Beijing leadership was worried that the world would get the wrong idea from the recent flurry of conciliatory gestures and concessions it has made with the Taiwan government that suggested the possibility of a civilized and peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait rapprochement, the editorial, entitled "Brazen China, " noted that President Hu Jintao has now made it clear that Beijing's policy of openly threatening Taiwan with a war of aggression remains intact.

The centerpiece of the Chinese National People's Congress meeting this month is "anti-secession" legislation that "legally binds China to attack the island if it fails to meet China's political demands, " it said, adding: " Chief among these is that Taiwan's democratically elected president, Chen Shui-bian, drop one of the central planks of his platform, which is reform of Taiwan's Constitution."

Pointing out that Chen has yet taken any steps toward constitutional reforms since suffering a defeat in last December's legislative elections, the editorial said that the president has been reaching out to China and even struck a deal with a pro-Beijing opposition leader in which he pledged to work to relax investment and transportation restrictions and reiterated promises not to seek independence for Taiwan.

It also noted that China's military buildup in recent years has been designed to prepare for an invasion of Taiwan and to repel U.S. forces that might seek to intervene, saying that "hundreds of missiles have been deployed within range of Taiwan, and new surface ships and submarines have been purchased from Russia."

Criticizing the totalitarian Beijing government that has openly renewed its determination to wage war and is working hard to acquire the means to do so, the editorial also said that despite the Bush Administration and Congress's appeals and warnings, the European Union is preparing to lift its arms sales ban on China.

"France and Germany -- fierce opponents of military force when used by the United states against a vicious dictator -- remain eager to sell weapons systems to a regime that has formally committed itself to aggression against a democracy, rather than joining with the United States to help keep the peace in Asia, " it said.
"In effect, the Europeans place their own narrow commercial interests above security cooperation with their NATO ally. It is a grossly irresponsible policy," the editorial also said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED NOT TO SIT IDLY BY ON CHINA'S 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW

TEXT.P: Taipei, March 13 (CAN) Former President Lee Teng-hui called on Japan Sunday to refrain from sitting idly by in the face of China's proposed "anti-secession" law, saying that the Japanese government should take action to block Beijing's legislation.

Lee, who is the so-called "spiritual leader" of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , made the remarks while addressing a seminar held in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, for 70 members of the Association of Lee Teng-hui's Friends in Japan.

In his speech, Lee thanked all association members for their participation in a rally held Feb. 28 in Tokyo to oppose Beijing's plan to enact the "anti-secession" law, which provides the Chinese military with a legal basis to use force against Taiwan in certain situations.
In addition to Taiwanese expatriates, many of Taiwan's friends from Japan and Tibet also took part in the demonstration to protest China's desire for hegemony, Lee said.

Noting that Beijing authorities are seeking to annex Taiwan by enacting the "anti-secession" law, Lee said that Japan should not adopt a wait-and-see attitude but should help the Taiwan government block the possibility of China invading the island.
Should Taiwan and Japan fail to do anything, East Asian countries can expect to face a serious disaster in the foreseeable future, Lee claimed.
Consequently, the outspoken former president urged all democracy- and peace-loving countries to join hands to safeguard stability and peace in the East Asian region.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- is expected to pass an "anti-secession" bill next Monday morning to provide the legal basis for China's use of non-peaceful means against the island in certain situations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESES BUSINESS PEOPLE URGED TO SUPPORT WHA BID
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, March 12 (CNA) (By H.Y. Chang and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Business Association in Europe (TBAE) is planning to call Taiwanese businessmen around the world together to voice their support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) when the WHA holds its 58th annual meeting May 16 in Geneva.
Taiwan has failed to obtain observer status at the WHA, the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization, since 1997 because of China's fierce opposition.

According to the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce in the North Texas area, which is also a member of the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce (WTCC) , its president has invited members of the organization to actively participate in the forthcoming gathering in Geneva.
The TBAE and other Taiwanese organizations around the world have jointly voiced their support for Taiwan's participation in the WHA as an observer during last year's WHA meeting in Geneva.
The TBAE has also decided to hold its 11th annual meeting and the second joint meeting of its board of directors and supervisors May 13-17 in the Swiss city.

In a letter sent to the members of the WTCC to call them to gather in Geneva in May, the TBAE leaders urged Taiwanese business people around world to help Taiwan's bid as well as protect Taiwan people's health and wellbeing.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LAW COUNTER TO TERMS OF TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT: V.P. LU
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Texas, March 12 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that Beijing's draft "anti-secession" law targeting Taiwan runs counter to U.S.-China diplomatic ties mandating that China should resolve the Taiwan issue in a peaceful manner.

Lu, who arrived in Houston Saturday night for a three-day transit stay en route to El Salvador for a state visit, said during her flight to Houston that if the "anti-secession" law were indeed passed and allows the People's Liberation Army to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan, the law would seriously contradict the principles of the "Taiwan Relations Act" -- a U.S. law passed after Washington established formal diplomatic relations with Beijing in 1979 with an important condition that China will resolve the cross-strait issue peacefully.

Vice President Lu departed Taipei Saturday (Taipei time) for an official visit to El Salvador and Guatemala -- two diplomatic allies of the ROC in Central America. She is also scheduled to make transit stops in Houston and Miami during her 12-day trip.
Lu said Beijing's "anti-secession" law is not just a problem for Taiwan, it is a problematic concern for the whole world, particularly the United States.

The vice president added that before departing Taipei, she has exchanged views with President Chen Shui-bian several times over Beijing's enactment of the law. She said she does not need to convey the words of the president to the United States regarding the law since the president maintains "very smooth" channels of communication with America.

Lu was accorded a reception befitted a visitor of her status upon her arrival in Houston, with William Brown, acting chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , and David Lee, Taiwan's top liaison officer in the United States, going aboard Lu's charter flight to welcome her.
The vice president is scheduled to greet Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee and Congressman Solomon Ortiz from the state of Texas Sunday morning via telephone.
Lu is scheduled to eat at a Houston steakhouse that President Chen visited in June 2001 Sunday noon and meet with a group of pro-Taiwan lawmakers in Texas.

In the evening, Lu is scheduled to deliver a speech on the implications of Beijing's enactment of the "anti-secession" law at a dinner with some 300 overseas Taiwanese who will come from around the state of Texas.

Lu is scheduled to visit the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) headquarters Monday morning, making her the first ROC vice president to tour an official U.S. organization such as NASA during a transit stop.

Lu, at the head of a 152-member delegation, said prior to her departure at CKS International Airport that the visit is aimed at cementing diplomatic ties and introducing Taiwan's industries to its allies.

The delegation, which in addition to government officials, includes executives of state-owned and private enterprises, the vice president said, hopes to introduce Taiwan's traditional and high-tech industries to its allies and further increase trade exchanges.

According to the delegation's itinerary, Lu will inspect the possibility of establishing a "Taiwan Park" for industries in El Salvador, in the hopes that the park's construction can be completed and its operations begun within the remaining three years of President Chen's term.

Lu will also attend a regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America in Guatemala. Six Central American allies and five non-allied countries in North, Central and South America will attend the meeting, Lu said, adding that this will be a warm-up to a DPU regional organization to be established in Taipei August 14.
During the 12-day visit, the vice president will call on Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar and Guatemalan President Oscar Berger.
She will also be decorated by the two governments and will deliver speeches to the parliaments of both countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING SHOULD NOT PROVOKE EACH OTHER: U.S. SECRETARY OFSTATE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 12 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Friday that the United States hopes neither side of the Taiwan Strait will provoke the other side and that as the U.S. is continuing to modernize its military, China should realize it will be unable to have a unilateral advantage in the Asia-Pacific region.

The secretary made the remarks while responding to questions raised regarding the rise of China as well as possible tensions and a military imbalance in the Taiwan Strait in an exclusive interview with the Washington Times. The full text of the interview was released by the State Department Saturday.

Saying that China is a rising political and economic influence in terms of its global interests and that China's peacekeeping forces in Haiti is a positive contribution, Rice, who will soon visit several Asian countries, including China, Japan and South Korea, said, however, that such a rise has to be managed in a couple of ways.

"First of all, it's very important to be clear about American policies and interests in the region and that means being very clear about the policies. The second is to be active in making certain that our alliances in the region are as strong as possible. Third is that you have to recognize that China is going to be an influence and so try to steer that influence into positive directions, not negative ones," according to Rice.

Talking about U.S.-Taiwan relations, Rice said that the United States has had and continues to have a "one China" policy and plays the role as a kind of anchor, adding that Washington does not expect "either side to try to exploit the situation or to provoke the other side."

"We've been very clear to the Chinese that we have obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act, " the secretary also said, noting that she already said when she visited China before that arms sales to Taiwan are a matter of record and the United States has already agreed to do this.

Claiming that the United States has a lot of leverage when it comes to dealing with the rise of China, the secretary said, "The American military is going to keep modernizing so that the Chinese should never get the idea that they're going to be able to have a unilateral advantage somehow in the Asia-Pacific region."

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN RESOLVED TO BUILD GIANT PEACE-INSPIRING MOTHER BUDDHA STATUE

TEXT.P: People in Kinmen have resolved to build a giant statue of Mother Buddha, or Avalokitesvara in Sanskrit, to serve as an inspiration for peace across the Taiwan Strait.

The Kinmen residents, including Buddhism followers and people's representatives, as well as local government officials, elected Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng Sunday to chair a committee supervising the building and management of a 36-meter white stone statue of the bodhisattva, better known to Chinese as Guanyin.

The Kinmen people enthusiastically envisage building the former anti-communist bastion into a mecca for Buddhism followers, which will also serve as a "torch of peace" for people across the Taiwan Strait, Lee said after attending the first meeting of the committee.

It was decided by Kinmen-based Buddhism followers last June that the outlying island should build the 36-meter Guanyin statue using white stone from Quanzhou, Fujian province, to make the Mother Buddha a landmark of Kinmen.
In a very short period of time, nearly NT$18 million (US$0.58 million) was raised for the initial spending of the building of the statue.

Participants at Sunday's meeting failed to reach a consensus on where the statue should be established. At least four rural township chiefs lobbied for their places as the "most ideal" location for the giant statue.
Lee decided that the location issue will be discussed again in the committee's next meeting slated for mid-April.
(K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN IN PROTEST AGAINST BEIJING'S 'ANTI-SECESSION' LAW

TEXT.P: Braving a chilly drizzle and wearing only thin vests, a group of women, organized by the Non-war Action Alliance of Taiwan, gathered in front of the Legislative Yuan Sunday in protest against Beijing's soon-to-be-passed "anti-secession" law.

The demonstrators put up posters and chanted "non-war" and "peace" to express their opposition to the legislation that would authorize the Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" in dealing with Taiwan.
Chou Shen-hsin, convener of the alliance, said that almost all wars were initiated by men, and women -- who account for half of the global population -- were always the victims.
The activity was designed to demonstrate not only Taiwan people's resolve in opposing the enactment of Beijing's "anti-secession" law, but also her alliance's pursuit of peace, she claimed.

The Washington Post: Syria Promises to Leave Lebanon.
In talks with a top U.N. envoy, Syria promised yesterday to withdraw one-third of its 15,000 troops and 5,000 intelligence agents in Lebanon by the end of March, as the first stage of an operation that would end its 29-year military presence in that country, according to U.S. and U.N. sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR FREE TRADE ZONE TO SEEK GREATER INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will re-double its efforts to help attract more investment to the Kaohsiung Harbor Free Trade Zone to expand the port's role, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Yu Fang-lai said Sunday.

Yu made the remarks while delivering a report on current operations of the free trade zone at the southern port city during a seminar jointly sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , the Kaohsiung City Government and the Republic of China Chamber of Commerce.

According to Yu, the MOTC will target shipping companies that have leased container wharfs at Kaohsiung Harbor, as well as warehousing and logistics companies while seeking to lure more investment to the free trade zone.
Yu said he hopes that economic benefits of the Kaohsiung Harbor Free Trade Zone will be significantly expanded with investments by domestic business sectors in the near future.

Speaking at the seminar, CEPD Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng disclosed that the government will revise various out-dated regulations in an effort to boost development of the free trade zone, which became operational Jan. 1 this year.

Hu said domestic entrepreneurs have opined that the ratio of aboriginal people working in a free trade zone -- 5 percent of the total workforce -- as stated in the Statute Governing the Establishment of Free Trade Zones will scare away hopeful investors because the ratio is too high in consideration of the fact that the number of aboriginal people in the proportion of the total population is low.

CEPD officials are actively communicating with the Legislative Yuan to revise this regulation to facilitate attracting more investors, Hu said, adding that his council will come up with a set of new measures to help upgrade aboriginal people's employment rate.
Kaohsiung Harbor, along with Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan, are the country's first two ports authorized by the central government to run free trade zones.

In addition, the Executive Yuan has also given the green light to a plan to set up a free trade zone at Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan, which is expected to start operations at the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE OPPOSE NON-PEACEFUL MEANS ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES: POLL

TEXT.P: Ninety-three percent of Taiwan people are opposed to adopting "non-peaceful means" to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait issues, particularly sovereignty issue, results of the latest public opinion poll published Sunday showed.

The poll, authorized by the private think-tank the Institute for National Policy Research, found that 93.4 percent of the respondents disagree with Beijing's use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan when it addresses the cross-strait sovereignty issue.
Nearly 84 percent of the respondents said it is absolutely unacceptable that Beijing's draft "anti-secession" law, which follows part of the PRC Constitution, says that Taiwan is a part of the PRC.

About 71 percent said it is absolutely unacceptable that the "anti-secession" law stipulates that cross-strait disputes are "internal affairs" of the PRC entitled to no "interference" by any foreign country.
Nearly 85 percent said that the last thing they would believe is that the "anti-secession" law would not infringe upon the rights and interests of the Taiwan people.

The poll was conducted by Berkeley BIGC Co. March 9-12 soon after the Chinese National People's Congress began to talk about the enactment of the law targeting Taiwan. The law is expected to be ratified by a vote by the NPC Monday.
The poll of adults selected randomly islandwide, obtained 1,067 valid responses, with a margin of error of 3 percent.

Commenting on the findings of the poll, Huang Wei-feng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that the enactment of the "anti-secession" law revealed China's belligerent and hegemonic nature. It attempts to deny the sovereignty of the Republic of China and change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, tantamount to issuing a "blank check" for the People's Liberation Army to attack Taiwan, Huang said.

He added that while Taiwan as well as the world are watching closely China's enactment of the law, the Beijing leadership is turning a deaf ear to Taiwan people's voices and the concerns from the international community.

Huang stressed that it is imperative that the government review its China policy in the wake of the enactment of the law. Beijing authorities will take full responsibility should the passage of such a law causes any repercussions leading to the retrogression of cross-strait relations, he argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ENHANCE SAFETY TO MAINTAIN NO-ACCIDENT RECORD IN MINES

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Mines (BOM) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will continue to enhance safety measures in mines to continue a zero-accident record set last year, a government official said Sunday.

Since the BOM launched its five-year mining security supervision plan in 2001, the death rate has gradually dropped, the official said, adding that thanks to the mining sector's cooperation and concerted efforts, no fatalities were reported last year.
The official said that the BOM will ask the mining sector to strictly follow safety provisions to avoid mine shaft collapses, poor ventilation and short circuits.
In addition, maintaining the environment and preventing water pollution in mining districts will also be intensified for the sake of sustainable development, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE CENTER FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES OPENS IN CHIAYI
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, Southern Taiwan, March 13 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Chiayi County Government established a service center Sunday for foreign spouses of Taiwan residents.

Addressing the inauguration of the center, Chiayi Deputy Magistrate Huang Kuei-nan said that in addition to offering protection and consultation, the center will hold a wide range of classes, from communication with family members to teaching of domestic languages and children's education.
There are some 9,000 foreign spouses in Chiayi County, Huang said, adding that the center is aimed at helping foreign spouses adapt themselves to their new lives in Taiwan as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MISSION GOES ABROAD TO PROMOTE HEALTHY CITY EXPO 2005

TEXT.P: A Taipei City mission, headed by Deputy Mayor Yeh Chin-chuan, left for Toronto Sunday to start a trip to North American and European cities to promote the Taipei International Healthy City Expo 2005.
Taipei City Government officials said that the mission will proceed to Indianapolis after Toronto where it will also observe city construction projects and their operations for Taipei's reference.
The mission will also visit Copenhagen, Demark and Helsinki, Finland before returning home March 18, they added.
The expo, which brought together the chiefs of 16 international cities in Taipei last year, is expected to attract 40 to 50 city chiefs from around the world this time, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE TO BE FORMED TO ORGANIZE ONE MILLION-PEOPLE RALLY

TEXT.P: An alliance grouping representatives of all walks of life around Taiwan will be established March 16 to organize an one million-people rally against the expected enactment of China's "anti-secession law, " officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Sunday.

Following a call made by President Chen Shui-bian a day earlier to draw at least one million people to join the March 26 rally to protest the "anti-secession law, " DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang convoked a party's working-level meeting and decided to invite all Taiwan people, regardless of their sex, age, political affiliation and occupation, to participate in the rally to demonstrate to the international community their resolve to defend the democracy and peace of Taiwan, the officials said.
The proposed "Alliance to Protect Taiwan with Democracy and Peace" is expected to be inaugurated March 16, they added.
The alliance will be in charge of elaborating activity programs and mobilization plans for the March 26 rally, the officials revealed.

The "anti-secession law," which the National People's Congress of China is expected to pass during its on-going session that ends Monday, empowers Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island moves toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, March 14, or the fifth day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Queen Isabella of Castile orders the 150,000 Jews in Spain to accept Christian baptism or face immediate expulsion.
1793: Eli Whitney, American inventor and manufacturer, patents his cotton gin, revolutionizing the cotton industry. He also established the first factory to assemble muskets with interchangeable parts, marking the advent of modern mass production.
1820: Victor Emmanuel II, the first king of a united Italy, is born.
1879: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a 1921 Nobel Prize for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, is born. His special and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1883: Karl Marx, German philosopher, economist and revolutionary who, with the support of Friedrich Engels, wrote "the Communist Manifesto" and "Das Kapital," dies in London at the age of 65.
1900: President McKinley puts the United States on the Gold Standard.
1917: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Germany after the U.S. government severed its ties with Germany in February 1917 and pressed China to do the same.
1932: The League of Nations' Lytton Commission arrives in China to investigate the Shenyang (Mukden) Incident.
1932: George Eastman, the American inventor and industrialist who invented a dry-plate process of photographic film development, as well as flexible film, the Kodak camera and a process for color photography, commits suicide at the age of 78.
1934: A train explosion in El Salvador claims 200 lives and injures some 1,000 people.
1947: The newly independent Republic of the Philippines leases its military bases to the United States for 99 years under a military cooperation agreement.
1953: The butterfly orchid produced in Taiwan wins first prize in a contest at the international flower exhibition held in California.
1953: Nikita Krushchev becomes first secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1954: The ROC Ministry of the Interior formally names the Atayal, Saisiyat, Bunun, Tsou, Paiwan, Rukai, Puyuma, Ami and Yami as the nine major indigenous tribes of Taiwan Province.
1962: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan declares that the ROC does not recognize Japan's so-called "residual sovereignty" over the Ryukyu Islands.
1964: Dallas nightclub owner Jack Ruby is found guilty of killing Lee Harvey Oswald, the presumed murderer of U.S. President John F. Kennedy.
1979: A Trident aircraft crashes into a factory outside Beijing, mainland China, killing more than 200 people.
1987: More than 12 people are killed in the Philippines in an escalating communist insurgency.
1988: Warships of mainland China and Vietnam exchange fire near the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1991: The Executive Yuan passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which become the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. The long-term goal of the guidelines is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1996: A committee in the U.S. Congress approves a resolution urging the United States to defend Taiwan. But Clinton administration officials say they have received assurances from Beijing that it has no plans to invade.
1996: Wang Luo-pin, noted mainland Chinese folk-song composer, dies of illness in Urumqi, capital of Xinjiang Province, at the age of 83.
2000: In an open statement, Soong Mayling, the widow of late President Chiang Kai-shek, endorses the ruling Kuomintang's presidential candidate Lien Chan.
2001: Honduran President Carlos Flores decorates ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of friendship and military cooperation between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Without the confidence of the people in their rulers, there can be no government."

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW CLEARLY RAISES CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS: RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 13 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Sunday that China's anti-secession law clearly raises tensions in the Taiwan Strait and that it is not necessary nor a good thing to raise tensions.
The secretary, who is set to depart this week on a week-long trip to Asia, which will include a stop in China, made the comments in an interview on ABC's "This Week" program.
The Chinese National People's Congress is expected to pass the anti-secession bill into law Monday -- the last day of its annual session being held in Beijing.

Claiming that the United States has told both sides of the Taiwan Strait that taking unilateral steps that raise tensions in the cross-strait situation is not helpful, Rice said that the anti-secession law clearly raises tensions.

"The United States has been an upright anchor in this dispute for a long time. We have a 'one China' policy. Everybody understands that. The key is that there should be no effort on either side to unilaterally change the status quo, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MUST TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR LAW'S DAMAGE: HSIEH

TEXT.P: Beijing must take responsibility for any damage caused to relations across the Taiwan Strait by its passage of the so-called Anti-Secession Law, Premier Frank Hsieh was quoted as saying Monday.

Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai quoted Hsieh as saying that the law -- passed by the Chinese National People's Congress Monday morning at its closing session -- is a unilateral attempt to change the cross-strait status quo and that the Taiwan people and international community are opposed to it, adding that China must take responsibility for the negative consequences.
Hsieh will give a formal statement on Beijing's passage of the law at around 5 p.m. Monday, the spokesman said.
The statement is expected to include some of the government's response measures to the law, including minor changes in Taiwan's business and trade policy toward the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, TSU CONDEMN BEIJING FOR PASSING ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) condemned Beijing Monday for passing the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, saying the law is causing irreparable damage to the development of cross-strait relations.

In a written statement, the DPP caucus condemned the move as severely infringing upon the freedom, dignity and security of the Taiwan people, and urged the Taiwan people to spare no efforts in denouncing it.

The statement said that the Republic of China is an independent sovereign state belonging to the 23 million people of Taiwan. Any move to change Taiwan's status quo, if not agreed upon by the Taiwan people through a democratic referendum, is unacceptable, it added.

The Republic of China and the People's Republic of China are two separate political entities, it said, adding that the fact that the ROC government exercises exclusive sovereignty in the Taiwan area should be respected by the PRC and the international community as well.

The DPP caucus called for the international community to denounce Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, saying that the law authorizes "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan and is poised to escalate cross-strait tension and undermine stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
The law also goes against the U.N. Charter's aim of safeguarding world peace and runs counter to the universal values of freedom, democracy and human rights, the statement said.

Meanwhile, members of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally party of the ruling DPP, have decided to hold a 24-hour hunger strike beginning 4 p.m. Monday to express their vehement opposition to Beijing's passage of the Anti-Secession Law.

The sit-in -- to be staged by TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang, ranking TSU officials and major party members -- is also aimed at urging President Chen Shui-bian to immediately initiate a nationwide defensive referendum, TSU legislative party whip Lo Chih-ming said.
Lo said that the Executive Yuan should designate March 14 as "Taiwan Anti-Aggression Day" to mark the day that China passed a law to try to legitimatize its suppression of Taiwan's sovereignty.
He added that the government should immediately close all communication channels with China and freeze all exchanges across the Taiwan Strait to prevent Taiwan from "falling into China's trap."
