The Straits Times : Only $8,000 claimed from $60m held by Govt.
The Government owes members of the public a whopping $60 million, but only $8,000 has been claimed since details were put on the website www.unclaimedmonies.gov.sg in November last year, says a Finance Ministry spokesman.
No claims have been made with the Law Ministry, which holds a $50 million chunk. And just 15 claims have been made to the Manpower Ministry, the Singapore Examinations and Assessment Board, and the Supreme Court.
Monies available range from deposit refunds for inactive refuse disposal accounts with the National Environment Agency, to outstanding Supreme Court deposits - one of which is for more than $525,000.
The $60 million is owed by ministries, the Subordinate Courts and the Supreme Court, and excludes unclaimed money held by statutory boards, of which the National University of Singapore (NUS) has the largest number of people who are owed money at more than 500.
An NUS spokesman said the people owed money were mostly students from the past seven years who had about $20 each left in their accounts, and had either closed their Giro accounts or had not left their contact details.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAYORS, MAGISTRATES ISSUE STATEMENT AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Seventeen Taiwan mayors and magistrates issued a joint statement Monday opposing China's newly enacted so-called Anti-Secession Law, saying the "ill-intended" legislation destroys peace in East Asia and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Led by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, the 17 Taiwan local government chiefs said in their joint statement that the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan ignores the sovereignty of the Republic of China, counters the collective will of the people of Taiwan and infringes upon the Taiwan people's freedom of choice.

As the mayor of Taiwan's second largest city, Chen took the initiative to draft the joint statement and asked other local government chiefs to support his drive by signing their names on the document. With a view to making known to the world their opposition to the law, Chen published an English version of the joint statement in the Taipei-based English daily Taipei Times.

Pointing out that the question of who splits from whom does not exist across the Taiwan Strait, the joint statement said the ROC has always been a sovereign and independent nation and that any actions to unilaterally change the status quo or downgrade Taiwan's sovereignty goes against the will of the Taiwan people.

The joint statement, titled "Safeguarding Democracy and Peace, Opposing Military Annexation: An Objection to China's Anti-Secession Law, " said the crux of the problem in cross-strait relations lies in China's refusal to recognize the ROC's sovereignty, its use of its military might and missiles to threaten the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, and its use of aggressive means to sabotage Taiwan's international standing.
As the Anti-Secession Law completely disregards the ROC's sovereignty, the statement warns that the legislation will worsen cross-strait relations.

Stressing that developing cross-strait peace and stability is not only the universal goal of the international community but also the common hope of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the joint statement urged Beijing to be prudent regarding enacting the "ill-intended" legislation.

Besides Chen, other signatories included Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-luan; acting Taipei County Magistrate Lin Hsi-yao; Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng; Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin; Miaoli County Magistrate Fu Hsueh-peng; Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan; Changhua County Magistrate Weng Chin-chu; acting Yunlin County Magistrate Chang Ching-liang, Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen; Chiayi City Mayor Chen Li-jen; Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih; Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tian-tsair; Penghu County Magistrate Lai Fong-wei; Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing; acting Pingtung County Magistrate Wu Ying-wen; and Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BE CLEAR ON ITS STANCE REGARDING NEW LAW: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan should make its position clearly known in the wake of Beijing's passage of the Anti-Secession Law, but Taiwan should also avoid crossing China's "line in the sand, " Professor Byron Weng with National Chi Nan University in Puli, central Taiwan, said Monday.

Analyzing the Chinese National People's Congress' passage of the Anti-Secession Law Monday, Weng, a Hong Kong scholar who has lectured in Taiwan for several years, said it is justifiable and understandable that Taiwan society is indignant and opposes Beijing's Anti- Secession Law, given that the law reflects China's total ignorance of the truth that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state.

Weng said that the March 26 street rally that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is planning with the hope of a turnout in excess of one million people is one way for Taiwan to make clear its stance on the issue.

Clause 8 of the new law states: "If Taiwan independence forces, under any name or by any means, cause secession, a major incident causing Taiwan to split from China occurs, or if possibilities for peaceful unification are exhausted, the state can use non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity."

Passage of the Anti-Secession Law was not a surprise, Weng said, adding that Beijing has "internal conflicts" to settle, prompting it to spell out a clear warning to Taiwan, and China also knew that the law would be for foreign consumption, particularly the United States and Japan, on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

While Weng claimed that the world has denounced the Anti-Secession Law as " irrational, " the authors of the law argue that it is aimed at reflecting the "rational side" of China on the development of cross- strait relations.
However, Weng said that the passage of the law is not the end of the world, and there are always options and possibilities for a change in the situation.
Weng suggested that Taiwan make further efforts to improve its diplomatic and legal projection, and bolster its techniques in psychological warfare to consolidate its position.

If cross-strait relations continue as they are or no solutions suitable to both sides are forthcoming, the situation should remain stable, Weng said, but cautioned that the situation could turn dangerous should one or the other cross the imaginary line in the sand that could trigger the use of the new law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 48.72 points to close at 6,155.51.
The bourse opened at 6,181.83 and fluctuated between 6,193.32 and 6,151.8 during trading. A total of 3.25 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.48 billion (US$2.57 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up at 0.6 percent.

Seven other major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by banking and financial shares and plastics and chemicals shares both at 0.7 percent, paper and pulp issues and cement stocks both at 0.5 percent, textile stocks at 0.4 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 662 to 244, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

The Moscow Times: Moscow Makes Its Case for 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER CONFIRMS HUSBAND WORKING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh confirmed Monday that her husband is working in mainland China with a Japanese company but that this in no way violates any Republic of China regulations.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Ho said that her husband began to work with the Japanese company in China long before she became a minister and she reported the matter to Yu Shyi-kun when he was still premier.

Ho made the explanation in response to Legislator Tu Wen-ching from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who claimed that personnel from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) or their relatives could be in cells of China's "fifth column" of intelligence agents.
Tu asked Ho to check how many relatives of MOEA staff are working in China and even working for the People's Republic of China authorities.

Meanwhile, Ho said that in light of Beijing's passage of the Anti-Secession Law, her ministry would welcome an Executive Yuan move "the sooner the better" to push for an overall review of Taiwan's business and trade policy with China.
Ho said that the move had better be taken within one or two months to lessen the impact of uncertainties on the industrial and business sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI-BASED TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN SAY NEW LAW WILL NOT IMPACT THEM

TEXT.P: Most of the Taiwan businessmen operating in Shanghai declined to talk about the impact of the just-passed Chinese Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan Monday, saying that they only care about the prospects of direct air links across the Taiwan Strait.

The general manager of a Taiwanese real estate company said that he does not feel the heat of the Anti-Secession Law and he speculates that the law will not have any major impact on Taiwanese businesses in China in the long term.

The general manager, who preferred to speak on condition of anonymity, said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been too "political." Instead, he said, the governments of both sides should pay more attention to efforts to stimulate the economy and strengthen development in affairs concerning the people's livelihood and wellbeing.
He suggested that authorities from both sides try to resolve the cross-strait issue from a global perspective, saying that a cross-strait rhetorical tug of war does no one any good.

Meanwhile, Chen Fu-chuan, a Taiwanese president of a Shanghai suit and accessory company, said he does not see a major impact from the Anti-Secession Law on the operations of Taiwan businesses in China.

Noting that cross-strait political bickering is benefiting none of the Taiwanese businesses in China, Chen said that only the opening of direct cross-strait air links would be conducive to constructive development of cross-strait relations.
He lamented, however, that the increasing cross-strait political impasse seems to have curtailed the prospects for the opening of such links.
The president of a Taiwan human resources company based in Shanghai said that as a businessman, he prefers not to talk about politics and he does not care about the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' REGRETS BEIJING'S PASSAGE OF ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) on Monday expressed anger and regret over the passage of the Anti-Secession Law by China's parliament.
The National People's Congress passed the law earlier in the day.

Clause 8 of the new law states: "If Taiwan independence forces, under any name or by any means, cause secession, a major incident causing Taiwan to split from China occurs, or if possibilities for peaceful unification are exhausted, the state can use non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity."
Chen Chieh, KMT caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that China rashly approved the law despite the opposition of all Taiwan and without prior discussion with Taiwan leaders.
"Beijing has not shown any goodwill toward us, and we're angry and regretful," Chen said.
Chen also said that the KMT will have to first see what the nature of the planned March 26 ruling Democratic Progressive Party-sponsored rally against the new law is before committing to joining it.
If the rally turns out to be a forum for pro-independence groups to promote a new constitution, then it only will create conflicts and rivalries, he said.

A KMT spokesman also issued a four-point statement that said that the party will follow the Constitution, oppose Taiwan independence, oppose the use of force and promote cross-strait peace through exchanges.

Chang Jung-kung noted that the Republic of China has been a sovereign and independent country since 1912 and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been under separate rule since 1949 and are not interdependent on each other.

There is no question of Taiwan independence, Chang said, adding that Taiwan independence is not the mainstream view of Taiwan. A majority of Taiwan people want to maintain the status quo and will not allow Taiwan independent advocates to give Beijing an excuse to use force against Taiwan.

The KMT will adamantly oppose the use of force to threaten Taiwan, Chang said, adding that the innocent Taiwan people have no reason to suffer from the consequence of problems created by Taiwan independent advocates.
Meanwhile, the PFP said that it regretted that the passage of the bill into law has caused worries in the international community and made the people of Taiwan nervous.

Chen Chih-ping, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that the best policy of Taiwan is to stick to the 10-point agreement reached between President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman James Soong during their recent meeting, including the reiteration of President Chen's promise of no declaration of Taiwan independence and no change of the official name of the nation,
Chen expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can address cross-strait issues calmly and rationally without radicalism which could heighten cross-strait tensions.
Addressing President Chen Shui-bian's call for one million people to take to the streets to oppose the law on March 26, another PFP legislator was reserved about the idea.

Lee Yung-ping noted that since Beijing has already passed the law, a demonstration by the DPP two weeks after the fact loses the benefit of proper timing if the exercise was to try to stop passage of the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW THREATENS TAIWAN: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law threatens Taiwan's survival and has caused anxiety in local society.

Wang made the remarks after China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress (NPC) -- passed earlier in the day a law giving its military a legal basis to attack Taiwan if the island moves towards independence.

Clause 8 of the new law states: "If Taiwan independence forces, under any name or by any means, cause secession, a major incident causing Taiwan to split from China occurs, or if possibilities for peaceful unification are exhausted, the state can use non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity."
The Republic of China's Legislative Yuan passed a unanimous resolution earlier this month attempting to dissuade China from enacting the ill-intended legislation, Wang said.
"Much to our dismay, the NPC failed to give any goodwill response to our appeal, " Wang said, adding that he feels deep regret over Beijing's new legislation.
Wang said the legislature's cross-strait affairs task force has yet to begin operations.

At this critical moment, Wang said, the ruling and opposition parties must remain calm and conduct a rational and in-depth evaluation of the possible impact of the Anti-Secession Law and then map out responses based on the common interests of all local people.

In his view, Wang said, the government's policy toward relations across the Taiwan Strait should not undergo drastic changes abruptly. Both sides of the Strait should exercise self-restraint and avoid escalating tension and confrontation.
Both Taiwan and China should avoid provoking each other and instead pursue genuine reconciliation.

Asked whether he would take part in a large rally to be organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party March 26 to protest the law, Wang, also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said he has yet to make a final decision. "I need to look into the matter more before making a decision," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICELAND PARLIAMENTARIANS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: A group of parliamentarians from Iceland and their spouses arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day visit.

The visitors include Solveig Petursdottir, chairperson of the parliamentary foreign affairs committee, and her husband; Gunnar Birgission, chairman of the parliamentary committee of educational and cultural affairs, and his wife; as well as Gudlaugur Thor Thordarson, chairman of the parliamentary committee of environment affairs.

During their stay, the influential lawmakers will visit President Chen Shui-bian, deputy Legislative Yuan President Chung Jung-chi, as well as executive officials of various ministries including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the Mainland Affairs Council, the National Science Council, the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the Government Information Office.
They will also tour the National Palace Museum located in suburban Taipei, the Taipei 101 skyscraper, as well as Taroko Gorge National Park in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.

This is the first Taiwan visit for Petursdottir, who has been designated to chair the Iceland Parliament in August, and her two colleagues. They made the trip at the MOFA's invitation to learn about Taiwan's current economic and political states, according to a MOFA news release.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW HURT FEELINGS OF TAIWAN PEOPLE: BUSINESS LEADERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan business leaders said Monday that the Anti-Secession Law passed earlier by China's parliament will not endear the people of Taiwan, but they hoped that leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can exercise wisdom and rationality in handling the matter.
The business leaders made the remarks after the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, passed the law at the end of its meeting in Beijing earlier that day.

Wang Tiao-chun, secretary-general of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, said that one can see from the law that China has done its best to try not to offend the feelings of Taiwan people, to the point that as long as Taiwan does not seek independence, it will be a law without teeth.
Beijing also has proposed consultations in the law that both sides can now engage in, and Taiwan should seize the opportunity to have dialogues with the other side, Wang said.

He said that rationally speaking, there are also voices within Taiwan that oppose the island's independence and he believes that Beijing's enactment of the law has been a response from the pressure within.
Chen Cheng-yi, spokesman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the ROC, also said that Beijing did try to convey goodwill to Taiwan in addition to stating its stance on the law.
However, as the law targets Taiwan, it will inevitably hurt an already democratized island, Chen added.
Moreover, the law is a unilateral discussion about the rights of Taiwan people, which will be unacceptable to Taiwan people who have enjoyed freedom and democracy, he said.
It is only natural that Taiwan is mulling countermeasures regarding the law, he said, adding that Beijing should also understand cross-strait differences.

The law has already hurt the feelings of Taiwan people, Chen said, adding that business groups don't like to see this, and hope that cross-strait relations can return to more positive developments in the wake of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday.

Hsu Sheng-hsiung, president of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association, said that the Anti-Secession Law is related to the cross-strait political situation, and any political questions should be dealt with by political means.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERNATIONAL ANIMATION FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF MAY 20

TEXT.P: The 2005 Taiwan International Animation Festival is slated to run from May 20-29 at the Shin Kong Cineplex in Taipei, screening 43 of the best animation films from around the world.

The organizer of the annual festival, the non-profit Chinese Taipei Film Archive and the Digital Content Institute, has selected films from among 235 works from 29 countries, including "Ryan, " which recently won an Oscar for best short film, and three other Oscar-nominated animated films -- "Birthday Boy, " "Guard Dog" and "Lorenzo."

Thirteen programs have been organized for the event, sponsored by the Government Information Office and the Industrial Development Bureau, to feature the development of the global animated film production industry. Themes of the programs include "Best of the World, ""Focus on Director, " "Beginning of Animation " and "Best of International Student Films, " as well as "Children's Programme."

DOC.HEADLINE: DAA TO STAGE RALLY FOR DEMOCRACY AND PEACE MARCH 19

TEXT.P: The Democratic Action Alliance (DAA) is scheduled to stage a demonstration aimed at pursuing peace and democracy March 19 on the first anniversary of the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Huang Kuang-kuo, one of the DAA initiators, told reporters that persons from all walks of life will be welcomed to take part in the planned rally to help re-build Taiwan's value systems of peace, democracy, justice and veracity.

Pursuing the truth of the 319 shooting will be part of the DAA's appeals during the demonstration, Huang said. Chen and Lu were slightly wounded in the election-eve shooting when two bullets grazed their bodies as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in the southern city of Tainan. They defeated the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong by a slim margin of less than 30,000 ballots, or 0.228 percent of the 13 million votes cast.

According to Huang, DAA initiators will call on leaders of the ruling and opposition parties and ask them to lead their supporters to participate in the rally with the main theme -- "Light up Taiwan's Democracy, Pray for the Island's Peace."

As for President Chen's plan to take part in a ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated (DPP) rally slated for March 26 to protest China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, Huang said that it is really inappropriate for the head of state to participate in the demonstration.
Terming Beijing's Anti-Secession Law as a domestic one, Huang explained that the law is by no means binding on the Republic of China because the ROC is an independent country with sovereignty.
He called on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to use peaceful means to resolve their disputes, stressing that the DAA will strongly oppose Beijing's use of force to deal with cross-strait disputes.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- passed the Anti-Secession Law Monday, which provides the Chinese military with a legal base to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan in certain situations.

In response, the DPP is planning to stage a nationwide rally against China's enactment of the law March 26. Chen called for one million people Saturday to participate in the demonstration to show their determination to defend the island.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council have said that the law is tantamount to a "blank check" authorizing the Chinese military to use force against Taiwan, and accused Beijing of jeopardizing peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
China still considers the island part of its territory despite their split in 1949 after a civil war. Beijing has repeatedly threatened to use force against Taiwan if the island declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOLIDARITY UNION MEMBERS BURN CHINESE FLAG IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang led several TSU party officials in a burning of the flag of People's Republic of China in front of the Legislative Yuan Monday to protest Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, hours after it was passed by Beijing's National People's Congress.
Wearing headbands bearing the words "China invades Taiwan", Su and the other party officials shouted anti-PRC slogans while setting fire to the flag.
Su said the protesters will also stage a 24-hour fast in front of the Legislative Yuan.
Su said his party, which controls 12 seats in the 225-member legislature, will motion to ask the Legislative Yuan to designate March 14 as "anti-invasion day."

Lawmaker Lo Chih-ming, who is the convener of the TSU caucus at the Legislative Yuan, urged President Chen Shui-bian to hold a referendum along with the May 14 elections of National Assembly members on the question: "Do you agree that Taiwan is a part of the People's Republic of China?"

In addition to calling for resolution from the Legislative Yuan tp condemn Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, Lo also called on his colleagues at the Legislative Yuan to approve a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) budget for arms procurements and to support an anti-invasion, peace-promotion bill that will be put forward by his party to the legislature soon.

Before the protest, Su released a statement endorsed by the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader, " former President Lee Teng-hui, condemning the Anti-Secession Law, which provides the legal basis for China to use non-peaceful means to take over Taiwan.

In the statement, the TSU decries the Anti-Secession Law as a law approving war against Taiwan and stresses that Taiwan is a state separate from China and that no one will be allowed to damage its democracy, freedom, peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP URGES U.N. TO CONDEMN BEIJING OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Houston, Texas, March 13 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu urged the United Nations Sunday to stridently condemn China over its enactment of a law authorizing the use of force against Taiwan.

Lu, who arrived in Houston Saturday evening for a three-day transit stay en route to a Central America diplomatic tour that will take her to El Salvador and Guatemala, made the appeal in a speech delivered at a dinner given in her honor by major Taiwanese associations in Texas.

The dinner happened to coincide with the passage of the Anti-Secession Law by China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- in Beijing before the conclusion of its 10-day annual plenary session.

Noting that Article 8 of the law states: "If Taiwan independence forces, under any name or by any means, cause secession, a major incident causing Taiwan to split from China occurs, or if possibilities for peaceful unification are exhausted, the state can use non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity, " Lu said the legislation is actually a "war authorization law" in which China gives itself the rights to legislation, interpretation and sanction.
In her view, Lu said, the law is "not a law, " but rather a political statement aimed at forcing Taiwan to accept its "one China" principle as an ultimate unification term.
By enacting the law, Lu said, Beijing has unequivocally revealed a move to unilaterally alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that such a move is clearly in violation of common global interests, Lu said the international community should condemn Beijing's new legislation. As China is a member of the U.N. Security Council, Lu said, the United Nations should condemn China over its stark violation of the U.N. charter, which bans the use of force in resolving any international disputes.

The outspoken vice president also urged the United States to show moral courage by denouncing the Anti-Secession Law, which Lu said runs against the fundamental U.S. premise of peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes under which it established diplomatic ties with China in 1979.
Lu, a legal scholar-turned-politician, said Taiwan's future -- independence or unification -- is basically a political issue, not a legal one.

"Taiwan is not subject to China's law and the so-called Anti-Secession Law is inapplicable to Taiwan. Even though the cross-strait situation is grim, we need not be panicked by the new Beijing legislation. We should remain calm and redouble our efforts to accelerate our national development and beef up our defense capacity to counter Beijing's ever-mounting military threat," Lu said.

On Sunday, Lu had lunch with a group of pro-Taiwan Texan lawmakers at a Texas-style steakhouse in downtown Houston visited by President Chen in June 2001. She received special gifts of a cowboy hat and a waistcoat. Later in the day, she attended a cowboy festival show at Reliant Park -- the world's largest cowboy showground and American football stadium. Lu was accorded high-level courtesies, circling around the 1.9 million-square- foot stadium aboard an open-topped limousine and being introduced to a full house as "Taiwan's vice president."

Wearing a cowboy hat, Lu waved to the crowd and received a resounding two-minute welcome. Many Taiwan expatriates were surprised and excited by Lu's unexpected appearance. The show was also broadcast live to 52 countries around the world, helping to enhance Taiwan's international visibility.

Meanwhile, China's consulate in Houston mobilized a group of Chinese expatriates and students in Texas to demonstrate outside the restaurant where Lu dined with representatives of the Taiwanese community in the southern U.S. state.

Lu is scheduled to visit the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) headquarters Monday morning, making her the first ROC vice president to tour an official U.S. organization such as NASA during a transit stop. Lu was greeted by William Brown, acting chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), and David Ta-wei Lee, Taiwan's de facto ambassador to the United States, upon her arrival in Houston aboard a charter flight Saturday evening.

Lu and her 152-member entourage will leave for El Salvador Monday to start her two-leg Central America diplomatic tour aimed at cementing ties with the ROC's diplomatic allies and exploring investment opportunities for Taiwan businesses.
According to her itinerary, Lu will look into the possibility of establishing a special industrial park to accommodate Taiwan-invested firms in El Salvador.

She will also attend a regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America in Guatemala. Representatives from six Central American allies and five non-allied countries in North, Central and South America will attend the meeting, which will be a warm-up to a DPU regional organization to be established in Taipei Aug. 14.

During her diplomatic tour, Lu will meet with Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar, as well as Guatemalan President Oscar Berger. She will also deliver speeches at the two countries' parliaments.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S LAW VIOLATES INTERNATIONAL HUMAN RIGHTS AGREEMENTS

TEXT.P: The enactment in China of its Anti-Secession Law violates human rights agreements passed by the United Nations and enshrined in the U.N. Charter, the Taiwan Bar Association (TBA) said Monday.

TBA Secretary-General Su You-cheng said the association urged Beijing to refrain from enacting the law but the latter turned a deaf ear to the opposition of the Taiwan people to the law, which was passed by the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, earlier that day.

Faced with Beijing's high-handed action, the association will take part in a March 26 demonstration initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to express the exasperation and protest of Taiwan lawyers, Su said.

He suggested that the Taiwan public seek petitions to protest against the law and send suitable representatives to the United Nations to deliver the letter of protest and arouse international attention.
Meanwhile, several civic groups said that the sovereignties on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are independent of each other and that there is therefore no question of secession.
The Taipei Secretariat of the Global Partnership for the Prevention of Armed Conflict (GPPAC) , which is comprised of several civic groups, made the remarks shortly after Beijing passed the law.

Chien Hsi-chieh, executive director of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are separate and that only the question of whether to integrate with each other in the future remains.

The enactment of law is even more threatening to Taiwan than Beijing's earlier verbal warnings, Chien said, adding that the approach will only make cross-strait relations regress and further hamper cross-strait negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATEMENT REACHED IN CHEN-SOONG MEETING HELPS COUNTER BEIJING'S LAW

TEXT.P: If President Chen Shui-bian can act upon the statement reached in his recent meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, Taiwan can counter the impact of the passage of Beijing's Anti-Secession Law by China's rubber-stamp parliament, the National People's Congress, Soong said Monday at a press conference.

It is urgent for China and Taiwan to bury the hatchet and emotional confrontation should come to an end right away, Soong said, adding that the Taiwan people should voice their opposition to annexation, independence and war with Beijing. They should also appeal for peace, dignity and an equal basis for dialogue with Beijing, he said.

According to a joint statement released Feb. 24 after the Chen-Soong meeting, the two agreed that the national status of the Republic of China as stated in the Constitution defines the de facto and de jure status quo across the Taiwan Strait, and that this sovereign status of the ROC deserves recognition and respect by both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the international community.

Abiding by the Constitution, maintaining the status quo and maintaining peace should be leading principles for cross-strait ties and Chen pledged that during his term, he will not announce independence for Taiwan, will not change the official designation of the country, will not cover the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not facilitate a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo and will not wipe out the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council, according to the statement.

Chen and Soong agreed that the ruling and opposition parties have to seek consensus on constitutional reforms to beef up the country's competitiveness and the government's efficiency, but that the reforms should not deal with changes to national sovereignty, territory and cross-strait status quo.

To normalize cross-strait relations and establish a framework of peace and stability, the two leaders decided that both sides will work together to institutionalize a mechanism for cross-strait peace.

They agreed that the government should negotiate with China on cross-strait charter cargo flights and the opening of direct cross-strait transportation links. The government should also review and amend restrictions that hamper industrial development and national competitiveness.

Chen and Soong determined that any changes to the cross-strait status quo must have the consent of the 23 million people of Taiwan and that Taiwan will not rule out any possibilities in terms of the future development of its relations with China.

On national security, they agreed that the government will procure armaments necessary to step up the country's defense capabilities under the strategic objectives of maintaining national security, cross-strait stability and regional peace.

They affirmed that Taiwan will not engage in an arms race with China and will seek to establish a cross-strait military buffer zone and military confidence-building mechanism to temper cross-strait tensions.

On the issues of ethic harmony, Chen and Soong agreed that anyone using language or behavior that is abusive and discriminatory against a particular ethnic group should be subject to punishment and that both sides will promote the enactment of a basic law to protect the rights of different ethnic groups and enhance ethnic harmony and equality.
Lastly, they agreed that the government should ensure that different ethnic groups enjoy equal rights and status regarding economic, social, educational, cultural and examination issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GDP GROWTH FORECAST AT 4.21% FOR 2005: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that Taiwan's economic growth rate, or the gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate, is estimated at 4.21 percent for 2005.
Hsieh made the remarks after presiding over a meeting of officials in charge of economic and financial affairs.
The premier said the meeting focused on strategies to cope with the general present economic and financial situations, as well as relevant work agendas.
Given the current global market situation, Hsieh said, Taiwan might be unable to achieve its previously projected economic growth rate for 2005.

"Therefore, the government has decided to adopt a number of stimulus projects, including an emerging market exploration program, a broadband market expansion project, a TFT-LCD promotion project and an NT$80 billion flood control project, to increase job opportunities and stimulate economic growth," Hsieh said.
If all those projects proceed smoothly, Hsieh added, Taiwan's GDP growth could even reach 4.5 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TALKS ON CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES BEFORE MARCH 26: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that the Cabinet will not discuss cross-strait industrial exchanges before March 26, when a mass demonstration initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will be held to protest against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law.
Hsieh was responding to questions about the law targeting Taiwan, which was passed by the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, earlier that day.

The premier noted that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council has conveyed the stance of the government in a statement that the sovereignty of the Republic of China belongs to the 23 million people of Taiwan and will not allow Beijing to infringe upon it by any means.

"Cross-strait relations have been more tense than before and now is the time when Taiwan people feel most revulsion toward China, " he said, citing public polls showing that 93 percent of Taiwan's people have responded negatively to the law.

Asked about the government's policy on facilitation of cross-strait cargo transportation and industrial exchanges, the premier said the Cabinet will not talk about the issues until the Taiwan people have had a chance to express their views freely on March 26.

Cho Jung-tai, spokesman of the Executive Yuan, also said that the administration will not make any substantive responses to cross-strait issues, saying that "with the current cross-strait unfavorable atmosphere, it is obvious we cannot embark on any dialogue on cross-strait exchanges."

Legislators across the party spectrum are expected to focus on the response of the government to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law at Tuesday's general interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan, and the Cabinet will work overnight to set the tone, Cho said.
Meanwhile, the premier said that the easing of the daily fluctuation ceiling of stocks will be eased from the current 7 percent to 15 percent and will be put into practice "in due time."

The premier noted that the weighted price index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange ended 48.72 points down, or 0.8 percent lower, at 6,155.51 Monday despite of the passage of Beijing's new law, which he said shows that the stock market is mature.

Hsieh noted that the measure to ease the daily fluctuation ceiling of stock prices was originally set to be implemented in September, but he added that he has asked the Financial Supervisory Commission to study related measures and then put them into effect, based on considerations of both market development and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES HONG KONG TO OPEN REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government would welcome a decision by the Hong Kong authorities to set up a representative office in Taiwan, a senior official said Monday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu was responding to remarks made by Hong Kong acting Chief Executive Donald Tsang in an interview with the Central News Agency earlier in the day that he is willing to boost economic and cultural exchanges with Taiwan for mutual benefit and that the Hong Kong government is considering opening a trade office in Taipei to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

As the Hong Kong chief executive is not elected by Hong Kong residents but appointed by Hong Kong's rulers in Beijing, Wu said, he is not aware of whether Tsang's "opening representative office" initiative has been approved by Beijing.

If the proposal is endorsed by Beijing and the Hong Kong government really intends to open a representative office in Taipei, Wu said, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward China and handles exchanges with Hong Kong and Macau, will negotiate with the Hong Kong authorities to realize this constructive proposal as early as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH COULD REACH 4.5 PERCENT IN 2005: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday that Taiwan's economic growth this year is initially set at 4.21 percent and could possibly reach 4.5 percent.
Hsieh made the remarks while presiding over the first financial meeting of the Cabinet since he assumed the premiership Feb. 1.
He said it is initially estimated that the economic growth this year will be 4.21 percent, but could well be lower than that.

For this reason, the Cabinet will unveil new emerging market project, a broadband market project and a TFT-LCD project, and will approve an eight-year NT$80 billion (US$2.54 billion) flood prevention project to help raise the economic growth rate to 4.5 percent through public investment and job creation projects.

The premier also said that the privatization of state-owned banks should proceed as scheduled so as to build up momentum for the government's plan to promote mergers among banks as a means of strengthening the competitiveness of Taiwan's financial market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW SAID 'STRATEGIC MISTAKE'

TEXT.P: China's anti-secession legislation is a strategic blunder, a defense strategist said Monday.
Lin Chong-pin, a military strategy professor at Tamkang University who also once served as vice defense minister, said the anti-secession law came at a wrong time.
According to Lin, Beijing has long been planning to enact a law to codify the use of force or non-peaceful means to stop Taiwan's movement toward de jure independence.

However, Lin said, the situation across the Taiwan Strait had in fact eased to some extend after Taiwan's pro-unification opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) won more than half seats in last December's legislative elections and President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman James Soong reached a 10-point agreement on cross-strait relations in February.
Lin said it is regrettable that Beijing's slow-pace political operations failed to keep abreast of the swiftly changing Taiwan political situation.

In his view, Lin added, the anti-secession law came at a wrong time. "Now that pro-independence sentiment has been tempering, it's unwise for Bejing to enact such a law to hurt Taiwan people's feelings," he added.
The new Beijing legislation has not only drawn backlash from Taiwan people but has also invited harsh criticism in the international community, Lin said.
"In Taiwan, not only the pro-independence 'pan-green' camp has voiced scathing opposition and even the pro-unification 'pan-blue' alliance has slammed Beijing's move," Lin said.

Meanwhile, the Taipei Society, a self-proclaimed legislature watchdog, said the anti-secession law would only increase hostility and distrust between the peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and force a retreat in cross-strait relations.

It further said in a press statement that by authorizing the mainland administration and military to use "non-peaceful means" to deal with Taiwan, the anti-secession law is actually a absurd anti-human rights, anti-civilization and anti-democracy law.

Legislator Tsai Ing-wen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who also once served as Mainland Affairs Council chairwoman, said the anti-secession law will restrict mainland leaders' flexibility in handling cross-strait affairs and thus makes it harder in resolving cross-strait disputes.
"As the law allows for the use of 'non-peaceful means' against Taiwan, cross-strait engagements will become riskier and Taiwan people will face more risks while visiting the mainland," Tsai said.

Noting that the anti-secession law will have a profound impact on cross-strait ties, Tsai said, the government must make a comprehensive evaluation and map out long-term strategies to cope with the new challenges ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 15 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, March 15:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09:00, A group of fishermen will protest against the detention of Taiwanese fishing ships by the Japanese authorities in front of the Interchange Association of Japan's Taipei Office.
09:25, The Taiwan Association of University Professors will hold a seminar on opposition to China's Anti-Secession Law at the Civil Service Development Institute in Taipei.
10:00, The 2005 Taipei International Machine Tool Show will open at the Taipei World Trade Center.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the 2005 Taipei International Machine Tool Show at the Taipei World Trade Center.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
14: 00, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will explain Taiwan's stance on China's Anti-Secession Law to members of the foreign diplomatic corps at the ministry's headquarters.
15: 00, A consultation meeting of the ruling and opposition legislative caucuses will be held at the Legislative Yuan.
16: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN CHINA MAY BE SLOWED: MOEA

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Monday that the ministry will slow down the pace at which certain industries are allowed to invest in China and the pace at which bans on certain imports from China are relaxed.
Ho made the remarks at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan after the passage of the Anti-Secession Law by China's National People's Congress, the rubber-stamp parliament.
Although the Cabinet has yet to decide on the direction of cross-strait trade relations following Beijing's enactment of the law, Ho said that cross-strait trade relations will not backpedal.
She said that Taiwan will not shy away from the items that are already permitted in cross-strait trade, but the pace of opening to items still under control will be slowed.
Meanwhile, a ranking official of the nation's top economic planning agency, said Monday that the opening of high-level technology to China will have to take national security into consideration.
Yeh Ming-feng, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks when he attended a finance meeting presided over by Premier Frank Hsieh.

Yeh said that the promotion of trade should be based on the principle of mutual benefit. The unfriendly gesture of Beijing in the enactment of the law has hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people, he added.

He stressed that the government has in recent years adopted an "active opening, effective management" policy regarding cross-strait trade exchanges, showing that apart from a few industries, the government has not restricted manufacturers going to China.
Although Taiwan has shown the maximum goodwill, China has not shown appreciation and has not reciprocated in kind, which has had a bad effect on cross-trait trade activities, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO VOICE STRONG OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Several scholars and experts called on the government Monday to drum up support from the international community for Taiwan's opposition to China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

They made the appeal after China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress (NPC) -- passed the law earlier in the day to provide the Chinese military with a legal basis for using non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence.

Lai Yi-chung, director of the Department of International Affairs of the Taiwan Thinktank, said that the NPC passed the law amid strong opposition from major countries, such as the United States and Japan, so Beijing is expected to show a goodwill gesture toward Taiwan in bilateral economic and trade exchanges in an attempt to reduce criticism from the international community.

However, Lai stressed that China's further boosting of economic and trade exchanges with Taiwan cannot offset the serious impact of the new law on political relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The passage of the law means that Beijing will not accept any options other than unification while dealing with cross-strait political relations, Lai explained. But due to strong pressure from the international community, he predicted, the Beijing leadership will refrain from having a showdown with Taiwan in the short term.

Consequently, the government should prepare for the worst and integrate the efforts of the ruling and opposition parties and the public in general to voice Taiwan's strong opposition to the law, Lai said.

Meanwhile, Huang Chieh-cheng, a former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that the passage of the law has not only undermined the previously created atmosphere of cross-strait detente but has also raised the international community's concern that China will probably resort to the use of force to resolve the Taiwan issue.

Originally, the Beijing authorities intended the law to deter pro-Taiwan independence forces from causing the island to "split" from China, but now the people of Taiwan strongly oppose the law while several major countries have also voiced concern over the issue, Huang pointed out.

Huang further said that in the face of the law, the government should take concrete action to safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty, adding that taking to the streets is a feasible way to make China seriously face the strong opposition of the people of Taiwan.

He also urged the government to seize the opportunity to improve relations with major countries and to send delegations to European countries to lobby against any lifting of the EU arms embargo on China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP LEADER TERMS ROC CONSTITUTION BEST RESPONSE TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party (NP) Chairman Yok Mu-ming called for the government Monday to use the connotation of "one China" as shown in the Republic of China Constitution to respond to Beijing's "one China" principle, saying that only in this way can Clause VIII of China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law be nullified.

Yok made the appeal at a news conference after China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- passed the law earlier in the day to provide the Chinese military with a legal basis for using non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence.

Clause VIII of the new law states: "If Taiwan independence forces, under any name or by any means, cause secession, a major incident causing Taiwan to split from China occurs, or if possibilities for peaceful unification are exhausted, the state can use non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity."

Yok said that only by complying with the Constitution being implemented in Taiwan can the government effectively cope with this clause and allow the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to co-exist peacefully.
He also asked the government to insist that cross-strait unification should be approved by the 23 million people of Taiwan and that Taiwan independence should also be approved by the Chinese people.
In this way, Yok went on, the cross-strait status quo would not be changed unilaterally and both sides could set aside the unification versus independence debate to conduct constructive competition.

In addition, Yok called on the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party not to take part in a ruling Democratic Progressive Party-initiated rally slated for March 26 to protest the Anti-Secession Law.

He reiterated that maintaining the status quo is the mainstream opinion in Taiwan and said he is confident the people of Taiwan will be able to deter pro-Taiwan independence forces from achieving their goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONDEMNATION BEST RESPONSE TO BEIJING'S LAW: MAINLAND AFFAIRS CHIEF

TEXT.P: The best way to counter China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law is to "unite the international society in condemning it bitterly, " Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Monday.

In his first response to the Anti-Secession Law, which provides legal basis for China to take over Taiwan by non-peaceful means, Wu said that "China will bow to the ever-growing condemnation from Taiwan and international society, and will show its remorse in action toward Taiwan."
A referendum on the country's future is not an option being considered by the government, he added.
The MAC, however, will review exchanges with China in light of the newly enacted law but will not stop exchanges altogether, according to Wu.

As to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's plan to stage a mass anti-Beijing protest March 26, he said "it is the people's spontaneous expression of their opinion and the government won't meddle."

Asked to comment the opposition Kuomintang's plan to send a delegation on a tour of China later this month, Wu said it is the party's prerogative to decide whether it is wise to visit China amid the public indignation over Beijing's Anti-Secession Law and that the party should be prepared for a public backlash if it goes ahead with its plan.

He dismissed as "shameless propaganda" Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao's offer earlier in that day for regular direct cross-strait charter flights, saying that Taiwan is interested in direct charter cargo flights but China has not responded to Taiwan's overtures.
He said Wen's proposal in the wake of the Anti-Secession Law is like giving Taiwan a Band-Aid after flogging it. "We can't accept it for the time being," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER UNCOMMITTED ON WHETHER TO PARTICIPATE IN 326 RALLY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh is happy to see any civic activities which promote Taiwan's interests but has not yet decided on whether he will participate in the March 26 protest against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Monday.

Cho said the Executive Yuan is pleased to learn that more than 1 million people are expected to take part in the rally, which is sure to draw international attention to the evil character of Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, but the government plays a different role to that of the private individual and the premier will decide upon his response to it after taking into account reactions at home and abroad.
Meanwhile, officials from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which is organizing the Taipei rally, said more than 150 private groups have signed up to take part.

Given that more than 1 million people could show up on the streets of Taipei on that day, the party is planning to lead the protesters through the streets along 10 different routes, all of which will end at the square before the Presidential Office.
DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang called on the public to attend the rally regardless of their party affiliation and ethnic groups, to show the world their indignation toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CIVIC GROUPS PROTEST BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, March 14 (CNA) (By Jason Lu and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Representatives of more than 10 civic groups in Hong Kong staged a demonstration Monday in front of China's liaison office in the special administrative region in protest against Beijing's just-passed Anti-Secession Law.
The demonstrators put up posters and chanted slogans against the passage of the law earlier that day by China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress (NPC).
They left a letter of protest on the fence of the liaison office before peacefully dispersing, as the office refused to send an official out to receive the petition.

Lee Kwok-keung, chairman of the Hong Kong and Kowloon Trade Union Council, criticized Beijing after attending the protest for hegemonically rushing through the bill regardless of strong opposition from the people of Taiwan and concerns from the international community.
He described the legislation as a dangerous move that he said would not only cause regression in cross-Taiwan Strait ties but will also heighten the Taiwan people's indignation toward China.
Lee suggested the two sides resume cross-strait talks immediately and put an end to the hostility between them.
Leung Hon-wah, a spokesman for a youth service group in the demonstration, also criticized Beijing for repeatedly ignoring Taiwan's democratization and its pluralistic society.

Beijing did not consult the people of Taiwan prior to enacting the law targeting the island, he pointed out, adding that his organization supports increased exchanges and an accelerated pace of negotiations on matters of mutual concern based on the principles of equality and reciprocity.

Noting that neither side should unilaterally change the cross-strait status quo, he called on the Beijing authorities to respect the Taiwan people and recognize the reality of the Republic of China's existence and its sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF INTERNET USERS INCREASES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of Internet users in Taiwan increased to 13.8 million in January, up 9.2 percent from the previous year's level, according to statistics released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The tallies show that the number accounts for 64.1 percent of the country's population aged over 12 years.
By gender, 67.6 percent of males have surfed the Web, higher than the 60 percent of females.
More than 50 percent of the country's household Internet service subscribers are broadband users, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF URGES RESUMPTION OF TAIWAN-CHINA TALKS

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan called on both sides of the Taiwan Strait Monday to return to the 1990's, when Taiwan forsook independence while China renounced the use of force against Taiwan, and resume dialogue.

In a written statement issued after Beijing enacted an Anti-Secession Law to justify the use of force against Taiwan under certain circumstances, Lien said that "we insist that the Taiwan issue should be solved peacefully, and we oppose firmly any recourse to use of force."

Lien, whose party has always warned that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's pro-independence policy will lead the country on a collision course with China, said that the Anti-Secession Law reflects the Beijing leadership's high degree of uncertainty about Taiwan leaders' policy, and local pro-independence activists' ever-increasing push for an independent country has only sharpened their worries.

Noting that conflict is not yet unavoidable even with the passage of the Anti-Secession Law and saying that the issue will remain unresolved even all Taiwan people take to the streets in protest, the statement said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should heed what the KMT has always preached -- stepping up economic cooperation and resuming dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, March 15, or the sixth day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
44 B.C.: Julius Caesar, Roman general, statesman and historian, who invaded Britain, crushed the army of his political enemy Pompey, pursued other enemies to Egypt, where he installed Cleopatra as queen, is stabbed by Marcus Brutus while attending a meeting of the Senate in Pompey's theater. He dies at the age of 56.
1521: Ferdinand Magellan, the Portuguese navigator who sailed across the Pacific Ocean, which he named, discovers the Philippines, where he is killed by native warriors. One of his ships returned to Spain in 1522, thereby completing the first circumnavigation of the globe.
1767: Andrew Jackson, the seventh U.S. president who as a general in the War of 1812 defeated the British at New Orleans and as president opposed the Bank of America and increased the president's powers, is born.
1776: The Congress of the United States decides to ignore the authority of the British Crown.
1874: France establishes a protectorate over Annam (now Vietnam), which breaks off its vassalage to China's Qing imperial court. Controversies with Russia in the northwest and with England and France in the southwest jeopardized the stability of the Qing dynasty. In the latter half of the 19th century, China lost its suzerainty rights over Indo-China and large areas of the northwest.
1943: Japanese warplanes raid Darwin, in northern Australia.
1954: An archaeological team formally begins excavations on Yuanshan in Taipei.
1960: Syngman Rhee is elected president of South Korea for a fourth consecutive term.
1964: The U.S. basketball team the Harlem Globetrotters visit Taipei to show off their skills.
1969: Border fighting breaks out between Communist Chinese and Soviet forces.
1970: The Osaka Expo is opened.
1973: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement condemning the Japanese government for allowing Communist China to occupy the ROC embassy in Japan.
1973: Yu Chun-hsien and Chou Po-lien are elected president and vice president, respectively, of the ROC Control Yuan.
1974: The West German government abolishes the speed limit for cars on its freeways, better known as autobahns.
1975: Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis, who in 1968 married Jacqueline Kennedy, widow of U.S. President John F. Kennedy, dies in Paris at the age of 69.
1976: More than 600 government and civic leaders gather for a breakfast meeting with Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1976: Gen. Ro Jae Hyun, chairman of the South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1980: A tour bus accident near Lishan in central Taiwan kills 17 and injures 15 recent graduates of National Taiwan Normal University.
1990: Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev is sworn in as president of the Soviet Union.
1991: The ROC Central Bank raises the ceiling on the annual amount of capital inflow per individual to US$3 million.
1996: President Lee Teng-hui tells Beijing to stop "nagging" the ROC with its war games. Communist China responds by announcing more exercises, this time much closer to Taiwan.
2000: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs says that it cannot accept a unilateral Philippine decision to immediately suspend direct flight services between the two countries.
2000: The ROC Ministry of National Defense reiterates its firm stance of maintaining administrative neutrality with just three days to go before the presidential election.
2001: President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso arrives in Taipei for a six-day state visit to the ROC at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. OPPOSES USE OF ANY KIND OF MILITARY FORCE IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The European Union issued a statement Monday in the wake of China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law to express its opposition to the use any kind of military force in the Taiwan Strait.
In the statement, the European Union reiterated its one-China policy and said cross-Taiwan Strait differences should be resolved peacefully.

The statement also said that the use of "non-peaceful means, " as authorized in the law which was passed earlier in the day by the Chinese National People's Congress, will undermine the recent signs of rapprochement between the two sides of the strait.

The European Union also requested that Taiwan and China avoid taking any unilateral actions that would escalate tensions in the region, and encouraged the two sides to develop initiatives that can contribute to an engagement in dialogue and a growth in mutual understanding in the spirit of the agreement reached on the special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. VOICES OPPOSITION OVER BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 14 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The U. S. State Department again voiced its concern over Beijing's Anti-Secession Law Monday, calling the law's passage earlier the same day "unfortunate" and reiterating its opposition to the use of force to decide Taiwan's future.

State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said in a regular news briefing that "the decision by the Chinese leaders to have the National People's Congress adopt an anti-secession law is unfortunate. It really does not serve the cause of peace and stability on the Taiwan Strait, and for that reason, we believe it to be unhelpful."
Pointing out that the enactment of the law runs counter to the recent warming trends in cross-strait relations, Boucher said that the law only serves to harden positions.
"We oppose any attempts to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, and will continue to encourage both sides to engage in peaceful dialogue to solve their differences," he added.

When asked if Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will send any constructive message to the Beijing leadership during her trip to mainland China later this week, Boucher said: "We will be talking about it with people in the region. We will be talking about it certainly with the Chinese."

"Our view remains that they need to move in the direction of peaceful dialogue. She will encourage them to do that and look forward to hearing from them as to how they might be willing to move in that direction," he said.

Commenting on the impact of the law on the U. S. discussions with the European Union regarding the latter's possible lifting of its arms embargo against the mainland, Boucher said: "Certainly the prospect that China would use non-peaceful means to try to resolve differences with Taiwan should be as disserving to the Europeans as it is to us."

On the large-scale rally being organized by Taiwan for or March 26 to protest the Anti-Secession Law, Boucher said: "We don't have any particular view of a demonstration or a counterreaction, as hypothetical as it is right now, " adding that: "We have encouraged both sides to look for opportunities for dialogue and to avoid any step to try to define unilaterally some kind of resolution to their differences."
"Neither side is going to get anywhere with unilateral steps," he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.P. COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN CRITICIZES ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 14 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A leader of the European Parliament on Monday criticized China's Anti-Secession Law passed earlier in the day, saying that the law has provided Beijing with a legal basis to use force against Taiwan.
Elmar Brok, chairman of the E.P.'s Committee on Foreign Affairs, made the criticism in an interview with Berlin Public Broadcasting News.
He also warned China that it should realize that the law "equals opposition with Western countries."

Brok, a member of the E.P.'s largest political group -- the Group of the European People's Party and European Democrats (EPP-ED) -- also said that establishing a legal basis for the use of force can develop at anytime into the actual use of force which he said could lead to a catastrophe for the whole region.

On the European Union's ban on arms sales to China, the chairman said that although most E.U. members agree that the ban should eventually be lifted, the E.P. still considers that it is not the right time to do so as China has demonstrated a poor human rights record. He added that with the passage of the Anti-Secession Law, the E.U. has even more reason not to export weapons to China.

Brok had joined three other E.P. members from various German political parties to send a letter to German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder March 10 to voice their opposition to a lifting of the arms embargo against China.

Meanwhile, Buro Georg Javzembowski, a E.P. member and spokesman of the EPP-ED for Chinese affairs, said in a statement issued following passage of the Anti-Secession Law that the 23 million people of Taiwan have the right to decide their own future, whether it be reuniting with China or maintaining their sovereignty.

Pointing out that the law has established a legal basis for China to threaten Taiwan by force and possibly take military action against the island, Javzembowski said that this fundamentally violates international law.

Taiwan is a democratic country, Javzembowski said, adding that Western countries should make clear that they will protect democracy and human rights. He also said that the E.P. will firmly oppose interference in Taiwan's internal affairs with the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND CHEN-SOONG MEETING CURRENTLY NOT IN THE WORKS: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office doesn't rule out the possibility of arranging a second meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, an official said Tuesday.
The Presidential Office staff member was responding to media reports that President Chen will meet with Soong again in the near future.

The official said no plans for a second Chen-Soong meeting are in the works at the moment. However, if it becomes necessary or if an opportunity presents itself, the Presidential Office doesn't rule out the possibility of holding such a meeting in the future, he added.

Commenting on media reports that Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun telephoned PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng Monday to discuss a possible Chen-Soong meeting, the official said the Yu-Chin telephone conversation didn't touch on the topic.

After China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress passed its so-called "anti-secession law" Monday morning, Soong publicly urged President Chen to faithfully implement the 10-point consensus reached at their Feb. 24 meeting to avert the possibility of China using "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan as mandated by the new Beijing law.

"In response to Soong's public appeal, Yu phoned Chin to reaffirm Chen's commitment to substantiating the 10 conclusions reached at the first Chen-Soong meeting. Yu also exchanged views with Chin on the 'anti-secession' law's possible impact on Taiwan's domestic political situation. But Yu and Chin didn't discuss any proposal regarding a second Chen-Soong meeting," the official explained.

In the 10-point agreement, President Chen reaffirms that his "five noes" pledge will remain good during his tenure as president, that the country's name is the Republic of China as stated in the Constitution, and that the rewriting of the Constitution will not upset the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU EXTENDS SIT-IN PROTEST AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Tuesday extended its 24-hour hunger-strike protest against passage of China's Anti-Secession Law.

Chen Chien-ming, TSU secretary-general, said that as supporters in southern Taiwan want to join the sit-in protest in front of the Legislative Yuan building, it has been extended to 30 hours and will end at 10 p.m. Tuesday.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang, party officials and legislators began the sit-in at 4 p.m. Monday after the National People's Congress -- China's rubber-stamp parliament -- passed the Anti-Secession Law which authorizes the use of force against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

Wearing a surgical mask and donning a headband which read "China Invades Taiwan, " Su shouted the slogan "Oppose Aggression, Protect Taiwan" while burning the national flag of the People's Republic of China.

At 10 a.m. Tuesday, effigies of mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao, Premier Wen Jiabao and former President Jiang Zemin were decapitated by supporters of the sit-in to show their resentment toward the three for advocating the Anti-Secession Law and to demonstrate Taiwan's determination in fighting against the new law.

Two Cabinet officials -- Lee Ying-yuan, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, and Cho Jung-tai, spokesman of the Executive Yun -- also went to the site of the sit-in to lend support to the TSU officials.
Fifty Japanese fans of former President Lee Teng-hui who are visiting Taiwan also showed up to give support to the protestors. Lee is TSU's spiritual leader.

Meanwhile, the TSU is planning to initiate a defensive referendum targeting Beijing's new law. The TSU said that Article 17 of the Referendum Law empowers the president to initiate a "defensive referendum" on national security issues should the nation come under the threat of external force. The party also plans to present a petition with signatures to President Chen Shui-bian to hold such a referendum.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said that there has been no discussion within the Presidential Office on whether the current situation meets the conditions stated in Article 17 for holding a defensive referendum.
Yu said that he is not clear about the contents of TSU's petition to the president, adding that all related matters must await his meeting with TSU Chairman Su later Tuesday.
President Chen initiated the island's first ever "defensive referendum" on March 20, 2004, the same day as the last presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

The bourse opened at 6,155.49 and fluctuated between 6,169.52 and 6,028.17 during trading. A total of 3.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$85.37 billion (US$2.75 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 3.1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 2.1 percent, textile stocks, paper and pulp issues and cement stocks all at 1.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.9 percent and plastics and chemicals shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 832 to 105, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF SEEKS GLOBAL BACKING AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu urged the international community to join forces with Taiwan in its bid to counter Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, which he said seriously threatens peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Wu renewed the call Monday night in an interview with Singapore-based CNBC and ASIA radio stations. The National People's Congress, Beijing's figurehead parliament, approved the law earlier the same day with the aim of warding off Taiwan independence at any time.

Stressing that any use of non-peaceful means to settle cross-strait disputes would be a violation of the United Nations charter. Wu said that Beijing coming out with such measures in its legislation has had a very negative impact in Taiwan.
Beijing's scheme to take Taiwan by force has not only aroused conspicuous international concern but has also prompted different political parties in Taiwan to protest against the law, he said.

He appealed the international community to express stronger opposition to Beijing's serious provocation that is set to roil cross-strait stability and claimed that fiercer international criticisms may lead Beijing to rethink and employ peaceful and democratic means in dealing with issues related to Taiwan.
The people of Taiwan strongly object to the law, as Beijing has never ruled Taiwan for a single day over the past 56 years since the two sides of the Strait split in 1949, he argued.

According to the MAC chief, Beijing has got it wrong about Taiwan's democratization and its constitutional re-engineering task, which he reaffirmed has nothing to do with the sovereignty issue and will not alter the cross-strait status quo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER POSITIVE ABOUT MARKING MARCH 14 REMEMBRANCE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that it is a good idea to set March 14 as a special day to mark the passage of the Anti-Secession Law in China.

Hsieh made the remarks when he was asked by Legislator Cho Po-yuan of the opposition Kuomintang about the approval of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to set March 14 as "anti-annexation day."
The premier said that he was not aware of the event, but that it sounded like a good idea, adding that what exactly to call the day can be worked out later.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said earlier that to galvanize the will of the people of Taiwan, the party will suggest marking the day that the National People's Congress, China's ceremonial parliament, passed the law as "anti-invasion day" so that the people will remember it.

Su made the remarks while attending a seminar on "Believe in Taiwan and Say No to China" sponsored by the DPP, the Taiwan Association of University Professors, the Taiwan Teachers' Alliance and the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association.

Su said that Taiwan has shown goodwill to the mainland for a long time, hoping to maintain peace, but Beijing has stubbornly passed the law, and the party, to galvanize the people's will, will suggest to the government to mark the day as "anti-invasion day."

He said that the Anti-Secession Law sees Taiwan as a part of China, and authorizes non-peaceful means -- military force -- against a "free and democratic Taiwan, " in total disregard of the fact that peace and human rights are mainstream values around the world.
Asked if President Chen will take part in a protest rally launched by the DPP on the Anti-Secession Law, Su said: Wait and see whether Chen will appear in front of the protest rally."

He urged all people in Taiwan not to condone the law tacitly, but come forward to take part in the rally irrespective of their party affiliation. They should show the true voice of Taiwan people whom Beijing has said on whom it "pins its hopes."
