DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IN EAST CANADA ISSUE STATEMENT AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, March 14 (CNA) (By S. K. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chapters of the Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace in Ottawa, Montreal and Toronto issued a joint statement Monday condemning Beijing's "anti-secession" legislation targeting Taiwan.

Beijing has no right to meddle in Taiwan's internal affairs because the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China have been independent and sovereign states under separate rule since 1949, the statement said, adding that the so-called Anti-Secession Law is totally unacceptable to Taiwanese expatriates.

It called the law a plot by Beijing to unilaterally alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and to legalize an invasion of Taiwan under the conditions it sets, the statement said, claiming that Beijing must be fully held accountable for the tension it fans in the region.

The law has seriously hurt the sentiments of the people in Taiwan and will extensively cast a shadow over cross-strait exchanges and undermine detente in the wake of the special lunar new year charter flights, it said, appealing to the Canadian government and the international community to prevent Beijing from upsetting security in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS CALLS FOR OPPOSITION SUPPORT FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT PACKAGE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged opposition parties Tuesday to support a long-stalled arms procurement bill in the wake of China's enactment of what it called an "ill-intention" law targeting Taiwan.

DPP legislative whip Lai Ching-teh made the appeal a day after China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress (NPC) passed almost unanimously the so-called Anti-Secession Law that authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" to stop Taiwan from moving toward independence.

In addition to passing the "bullying legislation," Lai said the ceremonial NPC also passed China's 2005 military budget, which amounts to US$29.5 billion (NT$1 trillion). If its hidden defense budget is calculated, Lai said, China's total annual military spending could reach NT$3 trillion.

"China has more than 700 ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan and its submarines have stalked Taiwan's eastern coast from time to time. Now it has enacted the Anti-Secession Law. The passage of the war bill-like law has changed the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, " Lai lamented.

In the face of Beijing's ever-mounting saber-rattling, Lai said Taiwan badly needs to beef up its defense capabilities. However, Lai said, the government's plan to purchase a package of advanced weapons from the United States, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft, has been pending legislative approval for more than a year.

"The package requires an outlay of less than NT$600 billion over a 15-year period, a negligent portion in comparison to China's astronomical defense budget, " Lai said, adding that the opposition-controlled legislature should stop boycotts of the package and accelerate screening of the bill to facilitate upgrading of the nation's defense capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO DISCUSS PUTTING OFF PARTY CHAIRMAN ELECTION UNTIL JULY

TEXT.P: A proposal to postpone the election of the chairman of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), for two months until July will be discussed at the KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, a KMT official said Tuesday.
Lin Feng-cheng, KMT secretary-general, confirmed that the proposal was made by a party think tank.
The think tank suggested that the party chairman election be put off to avoid conflicting with the election of a mission-oriented National Assembly, which has been set for May 14, Lin said.

The move is also related to the year-end city and county elections, which will require time to coordinate with the party's allies in the "pan-blue alliance, " which also includes the People First Party and the New Party.
Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that he supported the idea of putting off the party chairmanship election.

Wang, also a KMT vice chairman, said that by doing so the party can focus on the election of representatives to the mission-oriented National Assembly, which will be established for the purpose of approving a series of constitutional amendments made last August.
The nomination of the party's candidates for the year-end city and magistrate elections will also begin at that time, and the party does not want the party chairmanship election to interfere.
But Wang said that he would announce his candidacy for chairman Friday as scheduled, and that his campaign will continue despite the postponement of the election.

With Wang soon to join the party chairmanship election, a KMT official expressed concern that Wang and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- who has also announced his intention to run -- might divide the party since they both carry equal political weight.
Huang Chao-shun, vice executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee, said that rank-and-file members are worried that the competition between the two could further split and weaken the party.
She urged current KMT Chairman Lien Chan to mediate between the two, saying that he has the duty and obligation to do this to ensure a smooth transition.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WILL PONDER LAW'S IMPACT WHILE EVALUATING CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Tuesday that the government will take into account the impact of China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law on Taiwan and reaction of the public in general to the law while evaluating new measures on boosting civilian, economic and trade exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chiu made the remarks at a Taipei symposium on Beijing's Anti-Secession Law targeting the island jointly sponsored by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and several local civil groups, including the Taiwan Association of University Professors.

The MAC, the top government agency in charge of drafting Taiwan's policies toward China, will conduct an overall evaluation on the new cross-strait situation and future exchanges in various fields after China's National People's Congress passed the Anti-Secession Law Monday to provide the Chinese authorities with a legal basis for using non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence, Chiu said.

Touching on cross-strait economic and trade exchanges, Chiu said that in principle, those exchanges which are beneficial to Taiwan will remain in place while those not being in favor of the island will be suspended. For instance, Chiu added, no ban will be put on exports of Taiwan farm products to the mainland.
Chiu also said the Anti-Secession Law has demonstrated that China is a dictatorial and bellicose regime, adding that many countries have voiced their opposition to the law.

Noting that China's enactment of the law has triggered concern in the international community that Beijing will probably resort to the use of force to resolve cross-strait disputes, Chiu said that the government will closely cooperate with the international community not only in coping with the law but also regarding other issues.

The DPP has decided to stage a nationwide rally against the law March 26. President Chen Shui-bian called for one million people Saturday to participate in the demonstration to show their determination to defend the island.
China still considers the island part of its territory despite their split in 1949 after a civil war. Beijing has repeatedly threatened to use force against Taiwan if the island declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VISITS TAIPEI MACHINE TOOL SHOW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hailed the machine tool industry Tuesday as the "mother of all other industries, "saying that the government is planning to make central Taiwan a hub for the domestic industry, which is forecast to have an annual output of NT$300 billion (US$9.68 billion).
Chen made the remarks while giving a speech at the opening of the 2005 Taipei International Machine Tool Show, which opened March 15 and will run through March 20 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

A record of more than 600 companies are exhibiting their advanced items at a new high of 2,588 booths in the world's third-largest show of its kind. More than 60,000 people are expected to visit the show, including 3,000 foreign buyers.
He said that the government attaches a high degree of importance to the industry and promised that it will do its utmost to help in its upgrading.

He elaborated that the government's mid- and long-term project is to turn the central part of Taiwan into a hub for the precision machinery, nano-tech and bio-tech industries, taking advantage of the Taichung area's air and sea traffic facilities to reach further internationally.

According to the president, the domestic machine infrastructure based in central Taiwan will be able to create a production value of NT$300 billion by 2007, with an addition of nearly NT$20 million coming from royalties.
Taiwan's machine tool industry ranks as the world's fourth-largest in terms of export amounts, lagging Germany, Japan and Italy but ahead of Switzerland, Britain and the United States.
The country's outbound shipments totaled US$12.3 billion for 2004, up by 21 percent over the 2003 level -- the largest increase in history.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR'S SECOND TYPHOON NO THREAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: This year's second typhoon has formed in the Pacific but poses no threat to Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau said Tuesday.

Typhoon Roke is well southwest of the Philippines and moving westward at 32 kilometers per hour. Roke has a radius of 100 kilometers and is packing maximum sustained winds of up to 20 meters per second.
Roke is expected to pass through the central Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE ASKS PRESIDENT TO HOLD 'DEFENSIVE REFERENDUM'

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan adopted a non-binding motion Tuesday urging President Chen Shui-bian to initiate a "defensive referendum" in reaction to China's Anti-Secession Law that authorizes Beijing to use force against Taiwan under certain circumstances.

The "defensive referendum" refers to a right enshrined in the Referendum Law in which the president can call a referendum, after obtaining the Cabinet's approval, on issues of "national security concern" in the event of a foreign threat that places national sovereignty at stake.

The motion put forth by the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) also urged the Cabinet to revise related regulations to make March 14 "Taiwan Anti-Invasion Day" and freeze all dialogue and exchanges with China, which include cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights.
Meanwhile, the motion suggested that the legislature pass a resolution to express its position towards the Anti-Secession Law and pass an "anti-invasion and peace law" as soon as possible.

According to a draft resolution entitled "uniting Taiwan, resisting invasion and upholding freedom" put forth by the TSU, legislators across party lines were unanimous in uniting the nation and all freedom and peace-loving people around the world to halt the vicious, aggressive conspiracy by a minority warlike syndicate within China and safeguard peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and in the Asia-Pacific region.

The draft notes that freedom and democracy are universal values pursued by all mankind, adding that the people of Taiwan have walked out of the shadows of the Kuomintang-Communist civil war and Cold War over the past decades and are committed to seeking freedom, peace, democracy and economic development to become a prosperous, democratic and free modern nation.

The minority warlike syndicate of China is attempting to change the peaceful cross-strait status quo unilaterally by enacting the Anti-Secession Law, which can include "non-peaceful means" of unifying Taiwan and China that have been disdained by the international community as an attempt to try to invade and annex a democratic country, the draft says.

It states that the announcement of the termination of the "period of national mobilization for suppression of the Communist Rebellion" by Taiwan in 1991 marked the end of the civil war between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party and the start of cross-strait interaction on an equal footing.

Over the past decades, Taiwan has repeatedly shown its goodwill to cooperate sincerely with China and has assisted with China's economic development with capital and technology, but this goodwill has not been reciprocated, it says.

It points out that the people of Taiwan and China have never used force against each other and that Taiwan has become the greatest moving force behind China's economic development and will be a major catalyst allowing the Chinese people to enjoy freedom and democracy in the future.
It urges the Chinese authorities to prioritize the well-being of its people and not to become a" sinner" who damages cross-strait peace and prosperity.
It says that Taiwan and China are independent of each other and that the Anti-Secession Law is an invasion of Taiwan's freedom and democracy.
The text of the resolution will be finalized through inter-party consultations, according to Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker David J.C. Chung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ATTEND ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK MEETING ON TSUNAMI AID

TEXT.P: Taiwan will sent a delegation to Manila on March 18 to attend the Asian Development Bank's (ADB) meeting to assess the progress in rehabilitating areas in South Asia devastated by tsunamis on Dec. 26 last year, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

Chie Wen-chi, deputy director general of the ministry's Department of International Organization, made the announcement at a news conference. He also noted the delegation will be headed by Republic of China Representative to the Philippines Wu Hsin-hsing.
The ADB has set up a US$600 million trust fund for aid to tsunami-affected Asian countries, Chie said, adding that the Manila meeting will discuss ways to offer more help.

In addition to ADB member states, the tsunami-affected countries and relevant international organizations like the United Nations, the World Health Organization, as well as other major non-governmental organizations, have been invited to take part in the meeting, ministry officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OISTAT SECRETARIAT WILL BE MOVED TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, March 14 (CNA) (By Ku Lan-ying and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: The International Organization of Scenographers, Theatre Architects and Technicians (OISTAT) has resolved to move its secretariat from the Netherlands to Taiwan.
The resolution was adopted Monday at an annual OISTAT world congress, which is being held in Toronto.
During Monday's session, Taiwan's delegate to the world congress -- Chang Wei-wen -- was elected one of the new members of the OISTAT Executive Commission.
According to Chang, the OISTAT's decision to move its secretariat to Taiwan shows its recognition of the contributions made by the island's scenographers, theatre architects and technicians.
Meanwhile, the non-governmental organization also hopes to use Taiwan as a foothold to expand its development in Asia, Chang said.

Taiwan is a member state of the OISTAT, subsidized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). A joint meeting of the OISTAT Management Commission and Theatre Architects Evaluation Commission took place in Taiwan between Sept. 30 and Oct. 4 last year.

OISTAT is a cooperative, non-governmental organization and operates under the auspices of UNESCO. OISTAT's main purpose is to foster opportunities for cooperation between and among theatre organizations. Since 2001, there are opportunities for individual members in countries where no OISTAT center exists to take part in the activities of the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESPONDS WISELY TO BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: U.S. EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 14 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An American expert on cross-Taiwan Strait issues said Monday that Taiwan's top China policy charter has responded wisely to the Anti-Secession Law passed by the National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament.

Alan D. Romberg, director of the East Asia Program of the Henry L. Stimson Center, a think tank in Washington, D.C., made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency in which he commented on the new law.

Romberg said Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council expressed the opposition and indignation of the government and people of Taiwan regarding the passage of the Anti-Secession Law, underscoring Taipei's resolve to act responsibility.

Moreover, instead of reacting directly in response to the wording of the law, the MAC wisely reserved any decisions on a concrete response until after it sees what action Beijing might take to implement the law, he said.
He also lauded Beijing for trying its best in the law's wording to give some flexibility during the enactment of the law.
He cited Article 2 of the law that reads: "both the mainland and Taiwan belong to one China, " instead of the original text of "Taiwan is part of China."

In Article 8, Beijing says it will resort to non-peaceful means and other necessary measures, in a situation in which the "possibility, " instead of the original "conditions" for peaceful unification have been exhausted, he continued.
Beijing also wants to make clear that the law is designed to block steps that would formalize independence and totally close the door to unification, he added.

Meanwhile, a senior associate of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, another Washington-based think tank, said the law can set in motion a series of steps by Taiwan that could lead to a negative action-reaction cycle in cross-strait relations.
Bonnie Glaser termed this as "unfortunate, even if understandable."

Noting that "the interests of the people on both sides of the strait would be best served by the pursuit of positive initiatives by both sides that promote cross-strait interaction and dialogue, " she expressed the hope that Beijing will put forward goodwill gestures to Taipei to limit the negative consequences of this law and help to calm Taiwan's fears.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM PITCHES FOR U.N. ACTION AGAINST CHINA'S NEW LAW

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday that the United Nations should take concrete action against China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with foreign mission chiefs in Taipei to expound upon the government's stance on the Anti-Secession Law.
The meeting came a day after China's rubber-stamp legislature approved the law that authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" to stop Taiwan from moving toward formal independence.
During the meeting, Chen stridently condemned Beijing's new law, saying it reveals China's "bullying and hegemonic" nature.
Chen said he hopes the international community can realize that China has become ever-more menacing by enacting the law.

Since Beijing unveiled its legislative plan and key points of the draft bill a few months ago, Chen said, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has instructed the ROC's overseas missions to explain to their host countries the negative effects of the legislation.
Through their responses, Chen went on, he is fully aware that the international community is unanimously opposed to China using "non-peaceful means" to resolve disputes.

In the past, Chen said, China has accused Taiwan of being a "troublemaker" in its international publicity campaigns and has smeared Taiwan's referendum and constitutional re-engineering projects as acts designed to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law has exposed Beijing's true nature, Chen said the United Nations should not sit idly by and should instead take concrete action to invalidate the law, which he said is in stark violation of the U.N. charter.
Chen stressed that the 23 million people of Taiwan love peace and are "neither likely nor willing" to provoke China.
The minister further said the international community should not hesitate to lend support to Taiwan or think that it is only Taiwan that will fall victim to Beijing's new legislation.
"The world should never forget the historical lessons of World War II, when international appeasement of Hitler eventually led to a global war," Chen said.

Commenting on Beijing's citing of America's civil war lesson to lobby the Bush administration not to oppose its anti-secession legislation, Chen said Beijing misquoted former U.S. President Abraham Lincoln's adage.

In his view, Chen said, Lincoln's famous maxim "United we stand, Divided we fall" is more inspiring to Taiwan. In the face of China's mounting missile threat, he said, the people of Taiwan should stand united regardless of their party affiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS TO STAGE DEMONSTRATION AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: University students in the southern Taiwan area launched a campaign Tuesday against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law with a protest slated for March 20.

A large number of students in universities in southern Taiwan, including National Pingtung Normal University, National Pingtung University of Science and Technology, the National University of Kaohsiung, National Kaohsiung Normal University and Southern Taiwan University of Technology, have signed up to attend the rally initiated by Hsu I-chung, a student of National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology.

Hsu said that he and his friends studying in universities in southern Taiwan have decided to set up a student alliance for peace and organize the rally to express their strong protest over the passage of the law.

The planned rally will take place at the Kaohsiung City Cultural Center and the protesters will march toward City Hall, where they will present a pledge to the authorities stating their intention to defend Taiwan, Hsu added, noting that the sign-up for the demonstration remains open.
The newly formed student alliance for peace also released Tuesday a statement titled "Loving Peace, No Fear of War, " which says that Taiwan will never compromise on China's threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW MARKS TURNING POINT FOR TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Tuesday that China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan is not only a crisis but also a turning point for the nation.

Hsieh made the remarks in response to questions on the Anti-Secession Law from ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tang Bi-a during a general interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan.
No country in the world has enacted any law to legalize its eventual use of force in the way China has done, Hsieh said, adding that pursuing peace and co-existence is a current international trend.

Hsieh said the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law has not only infringed upon international trends but has also let the international community see that China is a bellicose regime while Taiwan is a peace-loving country.

The premier called on the people of Taiwan to keep calm in the face of Beijing's newly enacted law, saying that many friendly countries have voiced their opposition to China's use of non-peaceful means to resolve the Taiwan issue.
During her interpellation, Tang invited Hsieh to sound a "peace bell" to mark the common desire of the people of Taiwan for a permanent peace.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- passed the Anti-Secession Law Monday to provide the legal basis for China's use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council have said that the law is tantamount to a "blank check" authorizing the Chinese military to use force against Taiwan, and accused Beijing of jeopardizing peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
China still considers the island part of its territory despite their split in 1949 after a civil war. Beijing has repeatedly threatened to use force against Taiwan if the island declare independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECULATION RIFE ON WHETHER PRESIDENT WILL JOIN ANTI-BEIJING PROTEST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian kept the public guessing Tuesday about whether he will join the March 26 street march initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to protest Beijing's Anti-Secession Law.

His chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, hedged when asked whether his boss would be in attendance. Yu was leaving a meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee Tuesday, and played down the significance of Chen's participation.
He said the protest is aimed at airing the public's indignation with the law which empowers Beijing authorities to use force against Taiwan in certain situations.
"Therefore, the president's appearance at the protest isn't that important, " Yu said, without confirming a report that Chen has decided to lead the protest.

Noting that a consensus is beginning to coalesce among people at home and abroad that the Anti-Secession Law is unwelcome and should be condemned, Yu said the protest is sure to accomplish the goal of bringing the situation to the attention of the international community.
Meanwhile, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang hinted strongly that Chen would indeed be at the protest.
Citing the fact that Chen has encouraged everyone to take to the streets, Su said: "You can guess whether the president will attend himself.

"Although former President Lee Teng-hui has kindly suggested that Chen absent himself from the protest to give the public a free hand to express their opinion, the president, who has always stood in front of the people and given them leadership, is sure to stand at the best position at the protest," Su said.

Chen is not the only government leader who is keeping his own counsel. Premier Frank Hsieh told the Legislative Yuan the previous day that he was still weighing the pros and cons of taking part in the demonstration, noting that the role of government officials is different from that of private individuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESS URGED TO CONDEMN CHINA OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 14 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), an overseas Taiwanese pro-independence group, urged the U.S. Congress Monday to condemn China over the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law that authorizes the use of force against Taiwan under certain circumstances.

FAPA said in a statement that the law, which unilaterally defines Taiwan as being subordinate to China, is absurd and inconsistent with the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and is in violation of the Taiwan policy of the United States.
FAPA pointed out that Washington "acknowledges" China's sovereignty claim towards Taiwan but has never formally recognized this claim.

The Anti-Secession Law provides China with the legal basis to change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally and legitimizes China's attempt to "compel Taiwan into accepting unification by the use of force," according to the group.

Citing Carnegie Endowment for International Peace Senior Associate Robert Kagan, FAPA said the three conditions set down in the law under which "non-peaceful means" are applicable against Taiwan mean that China can attack Taiwan merely because the island "refuses to be absorbed by China by a timely manner," even if no move toward independence is made.
This is against the long-standing policy of the United States and has seriously jeopardized U.S. interests in the East Asia region, it said.
According to FAPA President Wu Ming-chi, the group has started lobbying U.S. Congress members to hold a press conference to openly deplore China's move.

The group has also proposed that the U.S. Congress pass a resolution to express its support for Taiwan's thriving democracy and to reiterate the U.S. commitment towards Taiwan's security and its policy that the future of Taiwan should be determined through peaceful means and with the approval of the 23 million people of Taiwan, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP ARRIVES IN EL SALVADOR FOR OFFICIAL VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, March 14 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu arrived in San Salvador Monday after a three-day transit stop in Houston, Texas.

Lu received a red-carpet welcome complete with full military honors upon her arrival in the capital city of El Salvador for an official visit aimed at cementing diplomatic relations with the Central American ally and boosting bilateral trade and economic exchanges.
ROC Ambassador Hou Ching-shan, Salvadoran Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Eduardo Calix and many other officials greeted Lu and her 152-member entourage at the airport.

During a dinner with Taiwan expatriates in El Salvador, Lu said she is hopeful that Taiwan businessmen at home and in El Salvador can join forces to build an industrial park in El Salvador to accommodate Taiwan-funded firms, facilitating bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

"The planned park should meet what she called the 'Three P' goals, namely, the park should be productive, environmentally protective and have perspective, " Lu said, adding that the park is expected to begin operation before the end of President Chen Shui-bian's presidential term in May 2008.
Lu will attend a meeting Tuesday to discuss details regarding the planned park with Salvadoran officials and business representatives, as well as inspect the planned site of the park.

On the last day of her transit stop in Houston, Lu paid a visit to NASA headquarters, where she received courteous treatment befitting a visitor of her status. She was granted the privilege of entering the Mission Control Center -- NASA's nerve center.

NASA sent a Taiwanese-American astronaut, Edward Tsang Lu, to guide Lu on a tour of Mission Control. Lu was also welcomed onto the flight deck of a space shuttle to get a rare glimpse into the interior of the spacecraft. The vice president also invited Edward Tsang Lu to visit Taiwan to help inspire local youths' interest in space technology.

Aboard the charter flight from Houston to San Salvador, Lu was interviewed by the Central News Agency, in which she said she had yet to decide on whether to take part in a large street parade to be organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party March 26 to protest China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

"It depends on the development of the situation across the Taiwan Strait. At the moment, the most important thing is to calm down and consolidate domestic unity. We should refrain from excessively emotion-charged reaction and instead pool our wisdom to work out appropriate response measures," Lu said.
China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress (NPC) on Monday passed the Anti-Secession Law that authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" to stop Taiwan from seeking formal independence.

Noting that the law is in stark violation of the United Nations charter, the United Nations declaration on world peace and human rights and the United States' Taiwan Relations Act, Lu said the international community should now come to understand that China is a real troublemaker.

Major countries around the world, including the United States, Japan and the European Union, have voiced opposition to China's new law, Lu said, adding that she believes Beijing will have to pay a heavy price for its "ill-intentioned" legislation.
El Salvador is the first leg of Lu's current Central America diplomatic tour that will also take her to Guatemala.

According to Lu's itinerary, Lu will attend a regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America in Guatemala. Representatives from six Central American allies and five non-allied countries in North, Central and South America will attend the meeting, which will be a warm-up to a DPU regional organization to be established in Taipei Aug. 14.

During her diplomatic tour, Lu will meet with Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar, as well as Guatemalan President Oscar Berger. She will also deliver speeches at the two countries' parliaments.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ORDERS PARTY MEMBERS TO ATTEND ANTI-BEIJING PROTEST

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ordered all of its party members Tuesday to attend a party- initiated March 26 protest to show Taiwan's resentment of Beijing's Anti-Secession Law.

As a part of its all-out efforts to ensure a good turnout at the protest, the party's Central Standing Committee brought out a most urgent party decree to make sure that all its members show up and stand alongside the rest of the public in the protest.
In order to meet the party's goal of mobilizing at least 200,000 of its people March 26, the decree assigns party lawmakers a quota of demonstrators they are supposed to bring to the protest.

The quota varies according to the distances of the lawmakers' constituencies from Taipei where the protest will be held. For each lawmaker elected from Taipei County and Taipei City, the quota is 2,025 people, for lawmakers from northern Taiwan, it is 1,350 people, and for lawmakers from Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan, it is 900 people.
Together with members of other private organizations that have signed up to join the protest, the organizers predicted a record 1 million people will be brought together for the protest.
The DPP Central Standing Committee also unveiled TV and radio commercials that will be played on local TV and radio stations in the lead-up to March 26 to encourage people to join the protest.

The commercials are compilations of films of Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing's bitter criticism of Taiwan, Hong Kong's march for democracy July 1, 2004, and a human chain formed in Taiwan as a symbol of its defense Feb. 28, 2004.

The theme of the protest is defined as "peace and democracy, " which are universal values. Other political calls, such as renaming the country, are not included, according to DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang.
The protesters will be led through downtown Taipei along 10 different routes and will converge in the square in front of the Presidential Office, according to the DPP.
A DPP official said his party will meet with other sponsors of the protest, all private groups, on Wednesday to work out further details.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS REGRET PASSAGE OF ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers expressed Tuesday their regret and worry that China has "willfully" enacted the Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan despite objections by Taiwan politicians across party lines.

A statement released under the name of the KMT legislative caucus said that cross-Taiwan Strait peace and prosperity is the expectation of people in the Asia-Pacific region and on both sides of the strait and that the caucus firmly opposes any military threat against Taiwan, a cross-strait arms race and the use of force.
The caucus pointed out that cross-strait confrontation and conflict could intensify tension between the two sides, which it said is in violation of the interests of the people on both sides.

Taiwan and China should instead interact based on goodwill, resume dialogue, promote economic, sports and agricultural exchanges and work to open direct cross-strait transportation links, the caucus proposed.

Saying that Taiwan people are not equal to pro-independence activists and that the Taiwanese consciousness does not equal independence consciousness, the caucus urged the Democratic Progressive Party government to pay attention to what it claimed is a mainstream "anti-independence" public opinion in Taiwan.

It asked the government to stop any provocative move such as promoting a referendum on a new constitution and a campaign to change the official name of the country from Republic of China to "Republic of Taiwan" so as not to create any excuse for China to invade.
It said the government should abide by the Constitution and uphold the sovereignty of the ROC to safeguard the well-being of the country and its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PARTICIPATE IN KOREA STUDENT FAIR

TEXT.P: A Taiwan higher education delegation composed of representatives from 26 universities will leave for Seoul March 24 to participate in the Korea Student Fair 2005, Ministry of Education officials said Tuesday.
Vice Minister of Education Lu Mu-lin will head the delegation to the fair, which will be held March 26-27 at the Seoul Convention and Exhibition Center, the officials said.
The delegation will introduce Taiwan's education policies and facilities, particularly in higher education, in an effort to lure Korean students to conduct advanced studies in Taiwan, they added.
During their stay in Korea, Lu and his delegation will also visit various Korean universities and will exchange education experiences with their Korean counterparts, the officials revealed.
More than 9,000 Korean students studied in Taiwan last year, of whom 80 percent came to learn Mandarin, according to statistics compiled by the Education Ministry.

The fair is the biggest study abroad exhibition in Korea and is the focal point of attention of Korean students eager to obtain first-hand information and professional, career-related advice from experienced Korean and foreign educators, according to the organizers.
A total of 274 exhibitors from 20 countries took part in last year's fall fair, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE EXPATS IN JAPAN PROTEST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 15 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-ming and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese expatriates in western Japan issued a joint declaration Tuesday to protest against China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law.
The declaration was released during a seminar attended by more than 70 members of the Taiwanese community in the region.
The declaration states that the Republic of China is a sovereign state that is committed to maintaining peace and security across the Taiwan Strait and pursuing economic development.

The enactment of the Anti-Secession Law has trampled on the rights and public opinion of the people of Taiwan and is a despotic move that has jeopardized security and peace across the strait and in the entire Asia-Pacific region, the declaration says.
It says the law has also placed the property and lives of more than one million China-based Taiwanese businessmen at stake.
It points out that Taiwan has become a true democracy after the transition of power in 2000 and that public opinion in Taiwan does not want to merge with a totalitarian China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MIGHT PUT OFF PARTY CHAIRMAN ELECTION TO JULY 23

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) passed a draft program Tuesday on the election of the party's new chairman, under which the election date might be postponed from the originally set May 28 to July 23.
The draft program, adopted at an extraordinary KMT central working-level meeting, is expected to be approved by the party's Central Standing Committee at its weekly meeting Wednesday.

According to KMT officials, the preliminary program on the elections of the party's new chairman and delegates was drafted based upon a proposal made by Tsai Hsun-hsiung, executive director of a party think tank,
Tsai suggested that the election of KMT chairman be put off to avoid conflicting with the election of a mission-oriented National Assembly slated for May 14.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who serves concurrently as a KMT vice chairman, has announced his intention to run for the chairmanship, while Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT vice chairman, is scheduled to announce his candidacy Friday.

Both Ma and Wang also supported the idea of putting off the party chairmanship election so that the party can focus on the election of delegates to the mission-oriented National Assembly, which will be established exclusively for the task of approving a series of constitutional amendments adopted by the legislature last August, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS URGED TO DEFEND TAIWAN IN FACE OF CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: An elderly farmer called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Taitung County Chapter Tuesday to summon local farmers to form a "salvation team" with the aim of saving the country in the wake of China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

Sixty-nine-year-old Liu Chin-yu said that he will invite his counterparts from the eastern county to join the team and ask them to refrain from investing in China, even though the Beijing authorities are set to give Taiwan's agricultural sector greater access to the China market.

Saying that there has been one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait since the former Kuomintang government fled to Taiwan following its civil war defeat in 1949, Liu said that the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by Beijing has fully exposed China's hegemony.

Liu also called for local farmers to take part in a DPP-initiated nationwide rally slated for March 26 to protest the law, which provides the Chinese authorities with a legal basis for using non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW HELPS ENHANCE TAIWAN IDENTITY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law means both a crisis and an opportunity for Taiwan.
Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session, Hsieh said the anti-secession legislation targeting Taiwan exposes the true nature of China's bellicosity.

"The enactment of the Anti-Secession Law has made China the only country in the world to codify war as a means of resolving disputes," Hsieh said, adding that the act runs against the mainstream world trends of pursuing peace, reconciliation and co-existence.
China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress passed almost unanimously the law that authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" to stop Taiwan from seeking formal independence.

"Such an ill-intentioned piece of legislation will only make the world understand that China's conviction that power comes from the barrel of a gun has not changed, " Hsieh said, adding that Beijing has invited criticism from all over the world for enacting the controversial law.
In contrast, he went on, Taiwan has invariably committed itself to safeguarding peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and has consistently sided with the democratic camp.

Meanwhile, he said, the Anti-Secession Law has helped enhance local people's consciousness of Taiwan's separate identity from that of China, citing the results of the latest opinions polls that show more than 90 percent of the respondents voiced opposition to China's new legislation.
"Although we are all very angry at Beijing's ill-motivated legislation, we must remain calm and refrain from any irrational extreme reaction," Hsieh said.

The lawyer-turned-politician further said Beijing's new law has actually altered the peaceful status quo across the Taiwan Strait and that the present situation meets the requirement for Taiwan to hold a defensive referendum to protect its sovereign status.

Nevertheless, he continued, the nation should exercise self-restraint to let the world understand that Taiwan is a peace-loving country that is determined to make every possible effort to protect cross-strait peace.

Asked if he will take part in a March 26 street parade to be organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to protest the new law, Hsieh said: "As a Taiwanese I want to join but now I'm also the premier and I have to consider (the consequences) . My presence might give the impression that the activity is organized by the government."
Meanwhile, Hsieh said that President Chen Shui-bian and the National Security Council (NSC) are weighing the law's possible impact on Taiwan from a broad perspective.

"The NSC will monitor international reaction as well as the sentiments and feelings of the people on both sides of the strait until the end of this month, " Hsieh said, adding that the government will then decide whether and how to revise its cross-strait policy.
Before the deadline, Hsieh said the government will not consider any proposal about the opening of cross-strait charter flights or personnel and commercial exchange programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS INT'L SUPPORT IN DISPUTE WITH CHINA: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan has successfully exposed Beijing's threat against regional security and is winning increasing support from major powers in its dispute with Beijing, according to a report presented to the Legislative Yuan by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday.

Bracing for Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, the ministry said in its report that it sent out delegations to the United States, Japan and European Union member states in January to brief them of Taiwan's opinion that the proposed law is "undesirable, unnecessary, unconstructive and stupid."

These delegations also reiterated Taiwan's stance on its disputes with Beijing, namely that it should be settled peacefully through dialogue and that neither side should alter the status quo in terms of their relationship to each other.

The efforts paid off, the report said, citing White House Press Secretary Scott McClellan as saying March 9 that Beijing's legislation of the Anti-Secession Law runs counter to the recent trends toward a warming in cross-strait relations, and urging Beijing to reconsider passage of the law.

The European Union also believes that the Taiwan issue should be solved peacefully through dialogue between Taiwan and China, and that neither side should take action that could increase the tension between them, according to the report.

Japanese Minister of Foreign Affairs Nobutaka Machimura told Beijing Feb. 23 about his country's strong desire for a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue and about Japan's great concerns about the negative impact of Beijing's law.

Taiwan's security also become a cause for concern of the United States and Japan, with a joint statement Feb. 19 saying that the Taiwan Strait is one of their common strategic objectives, the report said.

Beijing's military buildup is also being questioned, said the report, citing the Japanese government's latest Outline for National Defense Plan, which says China's military modernization and its increasing naval presence deserve Japanese notice.

Also, the report said, Porter J. Goss, director of the Central Intelligence Agency of the United States, told the Senate Feb. 16 that China's military modernization is tilting the military balance across the Taiwan Strait and is posing a threat to the U.S. armed forces in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER CALLS FOR PEACEFUL SOLUTION OF TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 15 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi told Japan's parliament Tuesday that his government opposes the resolution of Taiwan issues by any method other than peaceful means, the Kyodo News Agency reported Tuesday.
Koizumi was reported as telling the parliament that his government would like to see a resolution worked out by both sides of the Taiwan Strait through direct dialogue.
He also said Tokyo is not contemplating a possible military response to the Taiwan-China dispute and is not considering working with Washington in any U.S. military action related to the dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER URGES E.U. NOT TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO ON CHINA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen urged the European Union Tuesday not to lift its arms embargo on China before the human rights situation is improved and a democratic system is implemented there.
In a statement issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Chen thanked the E.U. on behalf of the Republic of China government for its concern about the Taiwan Strait issue.

The ROC government welcomes the statement issued by the E.U. Monday in the wake of China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law that expresses its opposition to the use of any kind of military force in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen called on the E.U. to uphold the universal values of democracy, justice and human rights and not to lift the arms embargo it has imposed since the Tiananmen massacre of 1989.
The lifting of the arms embargo will jeopardize the stability and peace of the Asia-Pacific region, he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, March 16, or the seventh day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1527: Babar, a Muslim ruler from central Asia who established the Mogul Empire in 1526, defeats the Hindu Confederacy at Kanwanha. Babar later conquered India.
1751: James Madison, the fourth president of the United States, who supported ratification of the Constitution, is born. He was the first and only president to exercise his rank as commander-in-chief in an actual battle.
1787: Georg Simon Ohm, German physicist noted for his contributions to mathematics, acoustics and the measurement of electrical resistance, is born.
1802: The U.S. Military Academy at West Point, New York, is established.
1815: William of Orange is made King of the United Netherlands and crowned William I.
1900: Sir Arthur Evans, British archaeologist, unearths at Knossos, on the Greek island of Crete, remnants of a Bronze Age civilization that he named Minoan, after the legendary King Minos.
1906: Japan nationalizes its railways.
1914: Madame Caillaux, wife of the French finance minister, shoots dead the editor of the newspaper Le Figaro to protect her husband against libel.
1925: An earthquake rocks Kunming, Dali in Yunnan Province, killing more than 4,000 people and damaging numerous houses.
1926: Robert Hutchings Goddard launches the first successful liquid-fueled rocket which he developed at Auburn, Massachusetts.
1926: Jerry Lewis, American film star famous for his zany roles and partnership with singer-actor Dean Martin, is born.
1935: German Chancellor Adolph Hitler renounces the terms of the Treaty of Versailles that ended World War I and induces conscription in preparation for armed aggression.
1937: Joseph Austen Chamberlain, British politician who helped establish the Locarno Pact and won the 1925 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 74.
1945: U.S. forces recapture the Pacific island of Iwo Jima during World War II after meeting strong Japanese resistance.
1955: The U.S. State Department makes public all documents related to the Yalta Secret Agreement, which was concluded by the three allied leaders, Winston Churchill, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Joseph Stalin, at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta on Feb. 11, 1945. The three agreed, among other things, that the USSR would enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights in China plundered by Japan in 1904 would be restored.
1968: U.S. troops kill more than 100 civilians during an operation in the South Vietnamese village of My Lai.
1973: British monarch Queen Elizabeth II opens the new London Bridge.
1974: John K. Tabor, U.S. under-secretary of commerce, arrives to participate in the dedication of the Taipei U.S. Trade Center.
1976: The Asian indoor handball Olympic qualifying tournament opens in Taipei with teams from South Korea, Japan and the ROC taking part.
1977: A delegation of government officials headed by Economic Vice Minister Chang Kwang-shih leaves for Riyadh to attend a Sino-Saudi Arabian meeting on economic and technical cooperation.
1979: The Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction is reorganized and renamed as the Council for Agricultural Planning and Development.
1985: The Tsukuba Expo is opened.
2000: Chen Chin-hsing, formerly Taiwan's most-wanted fugitive, is ordered to pay NT$171.3 million (US$5.19 million) in damages to well-known TV entertainer Pai Ping-ping for kidnapping and murdering Pai's daughter Pai Hsiao-yen.
2000: Two aging destroyers, the Tangyang and Laiyang, are decommissioned at a military port near Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan after more than 25 years of service in the ROC Navy.
2001: New Party Legislator Elmer Feng files a lawsuit against presidential advisor Chin Mai-ling (Alice King) for committing "improper" deeds that he said "endangers the internal security of Taiwan."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "You wish to live and hate to die. But while clinging to life, you yet hanker after those things which can only shorten life: that is a great delusion in life."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LAW CONTRADICTS BASIC SPIRIT OF DEMOCRACY: PREMIER HSIEH

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law goes against the fundamental spirit of democracy.

Hsieh said that from the remarks and statements made by the Chinese leadership over the last few days on the new law targeting Taiwan, he has come to realize that the Chinese communists do not have any sense of the principle of democracy.
"Our system is one which we chose freely, and our freedom of choice cannot be deprived by any group of people with any 'non-peaceful means,'" Hsieh reiterated.

Speaking during an Executive Yuan meeting to weigh the Anti-Secession Law's impact on Taiwan, the premier said that most of the people in Taiwan are angry with the new law and that the international community has also voiced its explicit opposition to the law.
Noting that peace is a universal value, Hsieh stressed that the Taiwan people and the international community will not stand for Beijing's codifying of war as a means of resolving disputes.

Hsieh said that Beijing's renewed threats are helping to further consolidate the people of Taiwan. "At this crucial juncture, only unity will make us strong, and the whole country should make explicitly known our consciousness of Taiwan's separate identity from that of China," he said.
"We must, however, express our consciousness of identity in a peaceful manner, and nobody should resort to anything other than peaceful means under any circumstances in this regard," he added.
Hsieh stressed that despite Beijing's mounting suppression and provocation of Taiwan, the government is resolute in continuing to push for reforms and national development.
Meanwhile, the premier also said that the raising of the maximum allowed daily fluctuation in the stock market from the current 7 percent to 15 percent will be put into effect "in due time."

He noted that the measure was originally set to be implemented this September but that he has asked the Financial Supervisory Commission to study related measures and put them into effect based on considerations of both market development and stability.

Hsieh also pointed out that since Beijing's passage of the controversial Anti-Secession Law Monday, Taiwan's bourse has continued to perform within the normal range, indicating that the island's economic development is mature and that investors are confident about the country's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN REITERATES ONLY TAIWAN PEOPLE CAN DECIDE THEIR FUTURE

The president made the remarks when he received participants of a workshop for Global Alliance for Democracy ad Peace regional chapter leaders at the Presidential Office.
The National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, passed the law Monday, authorizing the use of "non-peaceful means' against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNILATERAL MOVES NOT HELPFUL TO CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 15 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Unilateral moves are not helpful to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Tuesday.
Rice made the comments aboard her flight to India -- the first stop of her six-nation Asian tour that will also take her to Pakistan, Afghanistan, Japan, South Korea and China.

The United States "has a kind of upright anchor position, " Rice said, adding that "it is our responsibility to say to both the parties of China and Taiwan that unilateral moves that increase tensions are really not helpful and that the Anti-Secession Law is not helpful in reducing cross-strait tensions."
"And, therefore, we have said to the Chinese that we would have hoped that this (enactment of the law) would not have been done, " she said.

However, Rice added that enactment of the Anti-Secession Law doesn't mean that China and Taiwan can't continue to try to improve cross-strait relations and that talks shouldn't continue on the links between the two sides.

"I'm sure that investment continues, and it's important that we recognize that they need to continue to pursue these positive goals. We'll encourage both sides to continue to pursue the positive goals," Rice continued.

"But our 'one China' policy and the three communiques and the responsibilities under the Taiwan Relations Act really demand that the United States make clear to both parties that unilateral moves are just not helpful," she reiterated.

On whether Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law will have any effect on a possible lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China, Rice said that "it's obvious that the Europeans are examining this issue. They know very well our views on the arms embargo, that this is not a time to end the arms embargo."

"It's a time when Asia is in transition, when the military balance needs to be maintained. It's a time when human rights concerns continue coming out of Tiananmen, which was the original reason for the arms embargo. But I would hope that it would at least remind the Europeans that there are still serious security issues in the region and in the Taiwan Strait in particular," she said.

Meanwhile, U.S. Ambassador to South Korea Christopher Hill, who is expected to be named an assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said Tuesday during a hearing at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that any other than peaceful means should not be adopted to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

While responding to Sen. Lisa Murkowski's question about Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, Hill said that "this type of measure, this type of law, is a unilateral approach. We have to insist to both sides not to resort to unilateral approaches."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 8.88 points to close at 6,072.36.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CALLS FOR BEIJING TO GIVE TAIWAN ROOM

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen called for the Beijing authorities Wednesday to make room for Taiwan in the international community and to allow Taiwan greater access to global activities.

Commenting on speculation that Beijing will probably make some concessions on the diplomatic front as a form of compensation to Taiwan after passing its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, Chen said that if China is sincere in wanting to mend fences with Taiwan, it should help Taiwan improve its living space in the international community and allow Taiwan to take part in activities of more global organizations than just the World Health Assembly.
Chen made the remarks at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee.
He said he had not been informed about the speculation through "normal channels."

Opposition People First Party Legislator Sun Ta-chian asked Chen whether Taiwan would accept China's help in taking part in the World Health Assembly and its activities under a title that is acceptable to Taiwan.

Chen answered that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs would welcome such an initiative, but added that if Beijing is sincere in wanting to improve its relations with Taiwan, it should not restrict its "goodwill" to one case involving only the WHA and related activities.
He added that his office has learned that the United States, like last year, will continue to throw its support behind Taiwan this year in its bid to enter the WHA as an observer.

Meanwhile, Chen said he considers the south Pacific nation of Vanuatu to no longer be a diplomatic ally after a flip-flop on bilateral ties since he and Vanuatu Prime Minister Serge Vohor signed a communique in Taipei Nov. 2, 2004 to establish formal diplomatic relations.

Although Vohor was ousted by the Vanuatu parliament in mid-December and Beijing claimed that Vanuatu would repeal all accords and consensuses reached with Taiwan, the MOFA has not been formally informed by Vanuatu that the ties are null and void, Chen noted.
As of today, the number of countries that maintain formal diplomatic relations with the ROC is 25, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMANSHIP ELECTION SET FOR JULY 16

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) decided Wednesday to hold its next chairmanship election July 16 instead of the originally scheduled May date.

According to a schedule finalized by the party's Central Standing Committee, the party will publish details of the election May 16 and accept registration from interested candidates from May 25 to June 8.

Meanwhile, the KMT is expected to consider next week a proposal to lift a party rule that prohibits party members who have not paid their membership fees from running and voting in the chairmanship election, according to KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen.
Cheng said the party decided to hold the ballot in July because there are already a number of other political events on the agenda between March and June.

While the party is set to hold its preliminary for the year-end magistrate and mayoral elections during the period, the election for the ad hoc National Assembly is scheduled for May 14, Cheng pointed out.
According to Cheng, KMT Chairman Lien Chan pledged during the committee meeting that the next chairmanship election will be open and fair.

Lien said the election should not be held in a hurried manner and that people interested in running for the post should be given ample opportunity to communicate with fellow party members face to face.
The KMT had originally planned to hold the election May 28 but later changed its plan and came up with a proposal to hold the ballot July 23.
The date was finally set at July 16 in the wake of criticism that it would facilitate candidates to recruit new members into the party to boost their chances of winning if the date set was July 23.
According to KMT rules, members gain the right to vote in the chairmanship election after they have been party members for four months.

There was also speculation that Lien favors Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng as his successor and that putting off the election from May to July would give Wang an advantage over Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou in the chairmanship race.
Wang and Ma, who both serve as vice chairmen of the KMT, are expected to run for the chairmanship.
Earlier in the day, Wang urged the public to stop making such speculation, saying that the date of the election was always subject to change before it was finalized by the Central Standing Committee.

Reiterating his claim that all party members should be allowed to vote in the election regardless of whether they have paid their membership fees, Wang said a chairman who is elected by all 1.09 million members will naturally enjoy a broader mandate than one who is elected by only 200,000 to 300,000 paid-up members.
Meanwhile, Ma said he is against postponing the chairmanship election to July because it would spark a lot of unwarranted speculation and damage the party's reputation.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY FOG CLOSES CKS INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
