DOC.HEADLINE: COA HOPES TALKS LEAD TO EXPORTS OF TAIWAN FARM PRODUCE TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of agricultural affairs welcomed Wednesday recent news reports that China is prepared to allow Taiwan farm produce to make inroads into the Chinese market, but suggested that the two sides build up channels for communication and consultation first.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Lee Chin-long, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that the council has worked out preliminary guidelines to oversee Taiwan farm produce exports to China.

Under these guidelines, the COA will invite Taiwan's intermediary body, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to hold talks and communication with the Chinese authorities to facilitate the exports, Lee said.
If the SEF cannot take up this mission, he went on, then the SEF can recommend qualified organizations from the private sector to conduct the talks on the Taiwan side.
"Negotiations and consultations are essential before the agricultural products can head toward China," Lee added.
He noted, however, that Beijing's passage of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan Monday has landed a blow on efforts to warm up bilateral exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that the Anti-Secession Law has hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people, Lee told the legislators that the COA will "wait and see" how the situation unfolds before making a prudent judgment on its export policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY TAIWAN PEOPLE CAN DECIDE NATION'S FUTURE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: In his first public response to the passage of China's Anti-Secession Law, President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that only the 23 million people of Taiwan can decide the island's future and that Beijing has no say in the matter.
The president made the remarks at the Presidential Office when he received participants in a workshop for Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace regional chapter leaders.

The National People's Congress, China's rubber-stamp parliament, passed almost unanimously the Anti-Secession Law Monday, authorizing the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.
The president reminded the public that Beijing is used to a double-handed, carrot-and-stick approach and that they should not be fooled by it.

One million Taiwan people are expected to take to the streets March 26 to say that "more than 2,000 delegates of China's National People's Congress cannot decide the fate of the 23 million people of Taiwan, and that only the great Taiwan people can decide Taiwan's future with freedom, democracy and peace," the president said.
In a six-point statement, Chen expressed his grave concerns and regret over the newly passed law on behalf of the government.

He reiterated that the Republic of China is a sovereign and independent country and that 90 percent of the people believe that only the people of Taiwan have the right to decide on the country's future.

If Beijing leaders really "pin hopes on Taiwan people" as they claimed, they should listen to the voice of the majority of Taiwan people, accept the fact of the existence of the Republic of China and respect the choice of Taiwan people in free will.

Beijing's enactment of the law has shown the stark differences in the systems on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, but the resolution of the differences will not be achieved by the Anti-Secession Law, he said.

He reiterated that "both sides should solve bilateral differences through dialogue based on the principles of democracy, freedom and peace, " and that "any undemocratic or non-peaceful means, no matter under what pretenses, will not be condoned by the international community and will only further divide cross-strait relations and cause the peoples on both sides to drift further apart."

The president noted that despite the international community's overwhelming opposition to the law and repeated appeals not to enact the law, Beijing has turned a deaf ear and went ahead with the legislation.

He stressed that "any laws that advocate the use of force, no matter for what reasons or excuses, are a smear of the universal values of freedom, democracy and human rights and a regression of human civilization."

The president said the Taiwan people love peace and are determined to safeguard the country's democratic system. Although he is happy to see the emergence of China, he said Beijing has continued to engage in military expansion for a long time, increased its missile deployments targeting Taiwan.
Chen again appealed to the European Union not to lift a 16-year-old arms embargo against a potential invader before Beijing guarantees peace and renounces "non-peaceful means" to take Taiwan.

He said the law is Beijing's attempt to unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, which has resulted in a most grave negative impact on cross-strait relations, which were eased somewhat in the wake of cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday.
He said Taiwan is willing to share its development experience with China, saying that Taiwan can offer its "democratic system, complete freedom and human rights protection."
Finally, the president appealed for public participation in a protest march March 26, saying that as the international community opposes the law, the Taiwan people must not remain silent.
The march will be the "most peaceful, rational and humble" voice of Taiwan people to say "no" to the law, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEATTLE-BASED PRODIGY TO RETURN TO TAIWAN ON EDUCATION PROMOTION TOUR

TEXT.P: Andrew D. Hsu, a 13-year-old prodigy university student in Seattle, Washington, is scheduled to come to Taiwan this Friday to raise funds for his World Children Organization activities aimed at providing poor children with English learning materials.

Hsu, currently a student at the University of Washington and expected to obtain a bachelor of science degree next year, has been working on the compilation of a 130-volume series of basic English-learning books in the hope that initially, 10,000 sets can be printed to be distributed to poor children worldwide who have no access to education, according to Hsu's grandfather, who still lives in Taipei after his son and daughter-in-law emigrated to Seattle when the child was a baby.

Hsu and his younger brother Patrick jointly established the World Children Organization in 2002, committed to consolidating global resources and strengths to help poor children without access to education, food or shelter.

Hsu, who received admission from the University of Washington at 10 but delayed his enrollment until he was 12, said in a videotape that some charitable organizations provide poor children with food, clothes, clean water and medical care, and some help build schools for them, but almost no organization provides basic education to needy children to allow them to learn by themselves.
The World Children Organization English books will help the needy children to learn English on a self-taught basis, even if they have no class to attend and no teacher to listen to, said Hsu.
Hsu is scheduled to stay in Taiwan for one week and is expected to call on Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and leaders of several public-interest organizations.
In addition to raising funds for his books, he is also expected to pick up some tips in Taiwan on how to establish and operate a foundation of funds, according to his grandfather.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES PROPOSED ARMS PROCUREMENT STATUTE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved during its weekly meeting Wednesday a proposed "statute for major arms procurement" put forth for the second time by the Ministry of National Defense.

A similar bill regarding the government's latest plan to buy six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States was passed by the Cabinet and sent to the previous legislature for consideration last year.

However, the proposed statute, together with a proposed budget for the procurement, was shelved by the legislature owing to objections from the majority "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party. With the proposed statute and budget technically killed at the end of the last legislative term in January this year, the Cabinet had to submit them again to the new legislature that started Feb. 1.

The ceiling for the procurement package was marked down from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.48 billion) in the new proposal because a plan to make the submarines in Taiwan was dropped, while the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. dollar, officials said.
During the meeting, Premier Frank Hsieh urged the Legislative Yuan to pass the proposed statute as soon as possible to maintain the government's credibility and the country's defense capabilities.
Hsieh also ordered the relevant authorities to step up communication with the public and lawmakers to win their support for the important statute and budget.
According to Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai, the government will not be able to go ahead with the procurement unless the statute is passed by the legislature.
Cho said the government is under intense time pressure, as the agreed amount and items of the procurement might change if there are further delays.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH URGED TO VOICE GRAVE CONCERN OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A group of U. S. congressmen jointly introduced a resolution Monday urging President George W. Bush to voice the grave concern on the adoption of the Anti- Secession Law by Beijing earlier that day.

The resolution, initiated by Henry Hyde, chairman of the International Relations Committee under the House of Representatives, asks Bush to express the U. S. government's opposition to the law and its worry that the law might unilaterally change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait by non-peaceful means on Beijing's part.

Citing a report in 2004 by the Department of Defense on China's military power, the resolution points out that Beijing had deployed about 500 short-range ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan and that the arms buildup of missiles and other offensive weapons by Beijing in the areas adjacent to the Taiwan Strait poses threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific.

The Taiwan Relations Act, enacted in 1979, makes it clear that Washington's decision to set up diplomatic relations with Beijing rested upon the expectation that the future of Taiwan should be determined by peaceful means with the consent of the people in Taiwan, the resolution says.

It is Washington's policy to maintain the capacity of the United States to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security or the social or economic system of the people in Taiwan, it says.
The resolution puts forward the following four key points:

2. the president should direct all appropriate United States government officials to reflect the grave concern with which the United States views the adoption of the Anti-Secession Law in particular, and the growing Chinese military threat to Taiwan in general, to their counterpart officials in the government of the People's Republic of China;
3. the government of the United States should reaffirm its policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan; and
4. the government of the United States should continue to encourage dialogue between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China.
The resolution is expected to be approved Wednesday by the House, sources from the Congress said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA BOOSTS EFFORTS TO PROMOTE TRADE WITH SPAIN
DOC.DATELINE: Madrid, March 15 (CNA) (By T.L. Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has listed Spain as one of its key trade targets with efforts being made to boost Taiwan-Spain economic and trade relations.

Walter M.S. Yeh, vice president of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), was scheduled to sign an agreement with Madrid Chamber of Commerce (MCC) General Director Jose Maria Isardo Wednesday at the MCC headquarters to boost the council's cooperative relations with the Spanish business group, an economics official at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Madrid said Tuesday.

Chen Ming-shih, chief of the office's economic division, pointed out that under the agreement, the existing business information service to businesses of the two countries will be reinforced, while the TAITRA and MCC will make joint efforts to organize trade fairs and exchange visits.

Chen said that following the signing ceremony, Yeh will deliver a speech to introduce the investment environment and trade opportunities in Taiwan. Chen will then inform Spanish participants in the event of Taiwan's official statistics concerning bilateral cooperative ties in trade and investment.

Meanwhile, TAITRA has decided to open a branch office in Barcelona to promote Taiwan-Spain trade and investment relations, preparations for which are already being made, according to the group, which is Taiwan's foremost non-profit trade promotion organization.

According to the economic division's statistics, in 2004 Taiwan exports to Spain reached US$970.5 million, posting a growth of 20.9 percent over the level of the previous year, while imports from Spain amounted to 370.1 million euros, representing a growth 16.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION AFFIRMS PRESIDENT'S RESPONSE TO BEIJING'S LAW

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), the two major opposition parties that are often at odds with President Chen Shui-bian on political issues, unanimously affirmed Chen's restrained response to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law Wednesday.

Legislator Chen Chie, the whip of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the president, as head of state, should voice the people's rejection of and resentment toward Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, which provides China with a legal basis for using force against Taiwan.

However, Taiwan's dispute with China cannot be solved through confrontation and the leaders of the two sides should use their wisdom to steer their countries clear of the fruitless political struggle, Chen Chie said.
Their attention would be better used to address problems concerning their people's daily lives, the KMT lawmaker said.

He refused to comment on a March 26 protest initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, saying that the individual members of the public can decide for themselves whether or not to participate.

Legislator Chen Chih-ping, the convener of the PFP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the president made a good point when he told visiting foreign dignities earlier in the day that Taiwan 's future should be determined by its 23 million people rather than by the 2,000-odd members of Beijing's National People's Congress.

The PFP legislator, however, claimed that the president knows better than to take part in the March 26 protest, as doing so would indicate that he is at the end of his tether in terms of countering Beijing's intimidation.
"As head of state, Chen better keep a cool head in the face of Beijing's provocation and he should not drop any hints that might make Beijing think he feels forced into a corner," the lawmaker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Italy Planning to Start Pullout of Iraq Troops.
Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Tuesday that he aimed to begin withdrawing Italy's 3,000 troops from Iraq by September, in a signal that the domestic cost of loyalty to the United States over the war was growing too high.
Wall Street Journal: Ebbers Is Convicted In Massive Fraud.
Former WorldCom Chief Executive Bernard J. Ebbers was convicted of participating in the largest accounting fraud in U.S. history, handing the government a landmark victory in its prosecution of an unprecedented spate of corporate scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HELP EL SALVADOR CREATE REGIONAL BUSINESS OPERATION HUB
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, March 15 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that she wishes to share Taiwan's experience with El Salvador to make the Central American country a regional business operation center.

Lu made the remarks while attending a seminar on the Taiwan-El Salvador industrial park project on the second day of her three-day visit to the country. Also in attendance were El Salvador Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar; Patricia Figueroa, head of the national investment promotion board; and Sandra de Barraza from the National Development Committee.
Lu said that this was her third visit to El Salvador, and that she came with friendship the first time, with best wishes the second time, and this time with Taiwan's "experience and dreams" to share.
ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long also spoke on plans to build the industrial park.
The industrial park will mark the first time government and the private sector will have joined forces to build an industrial park in El Salvador, Chen said.
The park is initially planned at 200 hectares and will introduce agriculture and livestock technology, aquaculture, manufacturing and processing, warehousing and transportation, Chen said.

Taiwan and El Salvador will soon set up a committee to hammer out the details of the project, Chen said, expressing the hope that the government of El Salvador will provide tax incentives, low-interest loans, and establish a fast clearing system in airports and harbors to lure Taiwan companies to set up shop in the park.
He also urged El Salvador to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with Taiwan to upgrade bilateral trade exchanges.

Vice President Escobar said that El Salvador, at the center of America, has signed an FTA with neighboring countries, such as the United States and Canada, which will help Taiwan businessmen make inroads into the North American market.
She promised that her country will provide all necessary assistance to the investment project.
Lu and her entourage then traveled to the site of the projected park near Comalapa International Airport.
Afterwards, Lu attended a luncheon hosted by Escobar.

Lu spoke at the luncheon of her childhood, studies, having been diagnosed with cancer as well as her life in jail after the "Kaohsiung Incident, " a peaceful rally to mark international human rights day that turned violent in 1979.
In the afternoon, Lu was bestowed with an honorary doctorate at Dr. Jose Matias Delgado University and delivered a speech there.
Lu also announced that Taiwan will offer full scholarships to three students from the school every year to study in Taiwan for their master's degree.

The vice president noted that both countries are similar in size and populations, and both face the threat of communism, although the threat to El Salvador comes from civil war, while the threat to Taiwan comes from China across the Taiwan Strait.
Lu is scheduled to meet with El Salvador President Elias Antonio Saca Wednesday and will then hold a news conference. She will also deliver a speech to the El Salvador Parliament later that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL QUIET ON THE CHINESE FRONT: ROC DEFENSE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Nothing militarily out of the ordinary is happening in China and the Republic of China Ministry of National Defense has not upgraded its combat readiness, an ministry official said Wednesday.

Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Min-shieh said that there is no need to upgrade combat readiness at the moment. Tsai's comment at the National Defense Committee at the Legislative Yuan came one day after Premier Frank Hsieh said during a legislative interpellation that with the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by China, there are "risks of war" in the Taiwan Strait.
Tsai said that the defense ministry is watching the People's Liberation Army of China around the clock and has so far seen no unusual activities.
Asked when the military might upgrade its combat readiness, Tsai said that the defense ministry will follow set procedures should the need arise.
On what attitude the United States will adopt in dealing with the situation in the Taiwan Strait, Tsai only said that Taiwan and the U.S. have open and clear channels for communications.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP URGES CAUTION OF THOSE IN RANKING POSITIONS
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, March 15 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that those who are in ranking positions should "guard against their own words and deeds."

Lu's comments came after Premier Frank Hsieh said that the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by China Monday has changed the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, and that there are risks of war and that the situation has met the conditions to initiate a "defensive" referendum. Lu, currently visiting El Salvador on her two-nation visit of Central America, which will also take her to Guatemala, cautioned that now that the Democratic Progressive Party has been in power, and that it is no longer an opposition party, it should have a different approach in handling things.
Lu said that "President Chen Shui-bian's response over the days have been very cautious."

She said that sometimes a crisis could be a turning point, and the most important thing is timing. Now that Taiwan has become the focus of the world because of Beijing's new law, it needs to deal with the situation with wisdom, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES FOR QUICK REVIEW OF PROPOSED ARMS PROCUREMENT STATUTE

TEXT.P: A leading ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Wednesday expressed the hope that the opposition-controlled legislature will start reviewing the Cabinet-proposed "statute for major arms procurement" soon.

Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said he hopes the proposed statute can be included in the agenda of Legislative Yuan for March 25 and passed on to a legislative committee for review.

The proposed statute regarding a plan to buy six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States was approved by the Cabinet earlier in the day.
Briefing the DPP caucus on the arms procurement, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye stressed that the three kinds of weapons are most needed by the Republic of China military.

Lee explained that the amount of the procurement has been reduced from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.48 billion) because the government has dropped a plan to make the submarines in Taiwan, while the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. dollar.
Lee said the procurement needs to be covered by a special budget since the government will have a difficult time including such a large amount in its regular budget.

A similar proposed statute, together with a proposed special budget for the procurement, was shelved and technically killed by the previous legislature owing to objections from the majority "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP), which thought the package was too expensive.
Lai Hsin-yuan, a leader of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus, said her party will definitely support the arms procurement.
However, Lai said NT$480 billion is still an exorbitant amount and she urged the Ministry of National Defense to bargain with the United States.
Meanwhile, PFP legislative caucus convener Chen Chih-pin said his party insists that any arms procurement must be covered by the government's regular budget instead of a special budget.

Lin Yu-fang, a PFP legislator who serves as a convener of the National Defense Committee, said the arms procurement will do little help to defending Taiwan against the imminent threat from China because the submarines will only be delivered to Taiwan nine to 15 years after an order is placed.

Holding a similar view with the PFP, KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh said adjusting the amount of the arms procurement does not mean the actual prices of the weapons have become less and that the party still insists that the procurement be included in the government's regular budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CALLS FOR PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR MARCH 26 RALLY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) called Wednesday for public support for the March 26 protest in Taipei against Beijing's adoption of the Anti-Secession Law aimed at quelling Taiwan independence.

Lo Chih-ming, a TSU whip at the Legislative Yuan, issued the call echoing President Chen Shui-bian's appeal earlier the same day that "Taiwan's future must be determined by its 23 million people and Taiwan people should speak out loudly their desire for freedom, democracy and peace by taking part in the demonstration."

Voicing the TSU's full agreement with the president's stance, Lo said that all the people in Taiwan should throw their backing behind the president to help him better deter Beijing's threats. He suggested amending the Referendum Law to allow the people to directly express their viewpoints on Taiwan's future.

Former President Lee Teng-hui, spiritual leader of the independence-minded TSU, has publicly showed his willingness to participate in the large-scale protest in a display of solidarity with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang announced last week that the party would organize a massive rally and he claimed that at least one million people would take to the streets to show their fierce objection to the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAN ENVOY INTERESTED IN MIAOLI INTERNATIONAL MASK FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Honduran Ambassador Marlene Villela visited Miaoli County Magsitrate Fu Hsueh-peng Wednesday and discussed with him the details of the 2005 Miaoli International Mask Festival to be held March 26 to May 29.
The festival will center around the old civilizations of Central and South America including Aztec, Inca and Maya cultures.

Villela said she was interested to see that the incorporation of locally crafted wooden frames would be used during the show, evidence of how the integration of the two forms could enhance the entire exhibition and further develop tourism.

Masks from Honduras will be on display at the show, Villela said, adding that her country's cultural affairs department will send two artists to Taiwan to tape the festival for reference should Honduras decide to put on a similar show.
Aside from a large variety of masks to be displayed, the event will include many festive activities including a lion dance, magic and variety shows, drama performances and folk dances.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW NOT IN FORM ACCEPTABLE TO BOTH SIDES: WANG DAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, March 15 (CNA) (By Laurence Chiu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Democracy, rather than a law, is the key to Beijing's desire for unification with Taiwan, Wang Dan, a prominent former student leader at the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement in Beijing, said Tuesday in Los Angeles.

Speaking at a meeting with the Chinese-language media, Wang said that mainland China's democratization is the best remedy for Beijing to achieve eventual unification with Taiwan. He said that its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan independence is not in a form acceptable to both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to Wang, eventual Taiwan-mainland unification must be accomplished in a way that is acceptable to both sides. Only mainland China's democratization will keep Taiwan under its wing, he commented, adding that "the sooner this happens, the better."

He also termed the Anti-Secession Law as unwise at a time when cross-strait relations have shown signs of warming after the special lunar new year charter flights and Taiwan's legislative elections late last year.
Wang, now in exile in the United States, studies at Harvard University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REITERATES OFFER OF PEACEFUL RESOLUTION TO CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Wednesday that Taiwan is willing to resolve disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait through dialogue.

Receiving a visiting Iceland parliamentary delegation at the Presidential Office, Chen told his guests that the international community should not agree with Beijing's intention of using "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan as stipulated in its recently passed Anti-Recession Law.

Democracy, freedom and protection of human rights are three of Taiwan's characteristics that the people on China have not yet enjoyed, Chen noted, adding that he hopes the democratic achievements made by Taiwan can serve as a beacon for China.

Criticizing the recent passage of China's Anti-Secession Law by its rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- that authorizes Beijing authorities to resort to "non--peaceful means" against Taiwan, Chen emphasized that no foreign countries' parliaments can decide the future of Taiwan and only the 23 million people of Taiwan can do this.

He also criticized the exclusion of Taiwan from the United Nations and the World Health Organization, claiming that this violates the U.N. principle of universality, the spirit of health without boundaries and the Taiwan people's rights to enjoy the best health care available.

Noting that the international community should not discriminate against the people of Taiwan, Chen pledged that his government will continue to seek international support for and recognition of the Taiwan people's rights and interests.

Chen expressed his appreciation and support for a proposal by Solveig Petursdottir, chairperson of the Iceland Parliament Foreign Affairs Committee and head of the delegation, to establish a liaison office in Taiwan.
Chen told his guests that he hopes the proposal can be made a reality as soon as possible.
The five-member Iceland parliamentary delegation and their spouses arrived in Taipei Monday for a six-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ATTRACTS MORE EUROPEAN TOURISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 15 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of European tourists visiting Taiwan has been increasing in recent years since the government launched a promotion drive in 2001, a Taiwan tourism official said Tuesday.

Lai Seh-jen, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and honorary president of the Taiwan delegation to the International Tourism Exchange ITB Berlin 2005 trade fair, said that more than 140,000 European tourists visited Taiwan last year and that the government has set a target of attracting 180,000 European tourists this year.
Participating in the Berlin trade fair is part of the government's efforts in promoting Taiwan in Europe, she added.

Europeans have been interested in Taiwan's culture and scenery, while some of them have expressed great interest in folk art, hot spring activities and mountaineering, said Chang Wei-ting, director of the Taipei Tourism Office in Frankfurt.

The trade fair that opened March 11 and ended Tuesday was attended by 10,400 travel businesses from 181 countries around the world, with some 84,000 professional visitors attending, a 12 percent growth over last year, according to the fair organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDER IN CHINA PROMPTS CALL FOR BETTER PROTECTION OF ROC CITIZENS

TEXT.P: Beijing should honor its pledge to protect the personal safety and business interests of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, an Republic of China government official said Wednesday in light of a recent murder of a Taiwan citizen in China.

Speaking in an interview with the Central News Agency, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san urged relevant mainland authorities to live up to their promise and provide full protection to the many Taiwan business people operating in China.
Chiu made the remarks after learning that a business woman from Taiwan, Chen Yu-mei, was killed by a taxi driver March 11 in Guangzhou after returning from a business trip to Jakarta.
Chen, 47, was murdered by the cab driver on the way from the airport to her toy factory in Dongguang. She was hit in the head with a metal tool and then strangled to death.
The taxi was intercepted by public security officers as the driver was driving to a nearby mountainous area where he apparently planned to drop the victim's body.
Chen's family in Changhua, central Taiwan was informed of her death March 12 and her remains were sent back to Taiwan March 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, March 17:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan committees will start their sessions for the day.
09:45, Premier Frank Hsieh will inspect the construction projects of the Yuanshantse sluice on the Keelung River.
10:30, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will hold a news conference at Sheraton Hotel Taipei to announce his decision to run for the opposition Kuomintang chairmanship.

15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive president and board members of the JCI Taiwan at the Presidential Office.

16:00, The Chinese National Federation of Industries will hold a joint meeting of its boards of directors and supervisors at the Taipei World Trade Center Club.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE GROUP DENOUNCES BEIJING'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: An overseas Chinese group threw its weight behind Taiwan in its disagreement with China over Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, which permits an attack on Taiwan under certain circumstances.

The Global Alliance for Democracy and Peace, which was organized in 2002 by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission under the Executive Yuan, said in a statement issued in Taipei that the Republic of China is an independent country owned by its 23 million people. It is separate from China and any alternation to its current status should be based on the consent of its people.

It said that the Anti-Secession Law is just another piece of evidence showing China's ignorance of the political reality prevailing across the Taiwan Strait. It also shows China's abject carelessness about how the people of Taiwan feel and the international community's concerns.

In light of the current international trend of solving disputes through peaceful means, the statement said, China's unveiled attempts to use force against Taiwan are doomed to be condemned by the whole world.

Noting that the United States and Japan have expressed disapproval of the Anti-Secession Law and have made it clear that their defence alliance would apply to the Taiwan Strait and the area around it, the statement said China is threatening stability in the region by falling afoul of its neighboring states.
The statement urged major powers in the Asian-Pacific region to allow Taiwan to take part in their group security system to improve the peace and stability in the region.
It also called on Chinese the world over to understand the evil character of the Communist Chinese regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY KEEPS GROWING

TEXT.P: The production of Taiwan's semiconductor industry increased to NT$282.1 billion (US$9.1 billion) in the fourth quarter of last year, up 20 percent over the previous year's level, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA).
The figure brought the industry's annual output to a record high of NT$1.009 trillion, TSIA officials said.

The TSIA estimated that the industry's output for the first quarter of this year will amount to NT$264.3 billion, an increase of 8.8 percent year-on-year and that annual production will top NT$1.172 trillion for the whole year, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTIES CHIEFS AND COUNCILORS TO BE ELECTED AT SAME TIME IN 2009

TEXT.P: Chiefs and councilors for counties and cities will be elected simultaneously in 2009, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Wednesday.
In an interview with CNA, Su said the decision was made in line with former Premier Yu Shyi-kun's instruction to cut down the number of elections held in the counties.

According to Yu, the national elections, such as those for the president and legislators, and local elections, such as those for county/city chiefs and councilors, would best be held alternately every two years.
As the terms of the chiefs and the councilors are the same -- four years -- it would be relatively easier to have them elected at the same time, Su said.

However, since the chiefs of counties and cities are set to be elected in December this year, while the councilors are due for election next March, Su said it would be too hasty to move the councilor's elections ahead to the same time as the elections for the city/county chiefs now.
That means they will be held together in 2009 at the earliest, Su said.

As to the synchronization of national elections, the minister said, it entails the revision of certain laws and his ministry is still working on the revisions; hopefully, they will be approved by the Legislative Yuan before the next national elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA DRAWS AVALANCHE OF INTERNATIONAL CRITICISM: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: China has drawn an avalanche of criticism ever since its enactment of the controversial Anti-Secession Law which permits it to attack Taiwan under certain circumstances, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday.

Citing statistics compiled by the Government Information Office, Wu said there have been more than 1,700 overseas stories which cast the law in a negative light and have brought enormous pressure on Beijing.

The MAC chief said major global powers such as the United States, Japan, the European Union, Australia, Canada and others have expressed, in very strong words, their disapproval of China's legislation and the numbers are increasing rapidly.

Stunned by the huge backlash, Wu said, China is scrambling to control the damage by trying to reach out to Taiwan, but all its proposals, such as an open market to Taiwan agricultural products, are insignificant.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, March 17, or the eighth day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1190: Some 500 Jews are massacred in York, England.
1766: Britain's Parliament votes to repeal the controversial Stamp Act, a hated colonial tax that fueled a climate of rebellion in the American colonies.
1776: The British are forced by American revolutionaries under George Washington to evacuate Boston.
1853: Christian Johann Doppler, the Austrian physicist and mathematician who first enunciated the principle known as the Doppler Effect, which has an important influence on radar, navigation and astronomy, dies at the age of 50.
1886: Vincent van Gogh, the 33-year-old Dutch post-impressionist painter who had been studying at an art gallery in Antwerp, comes to Paris to further his training. His works were to include "The Potato Eaters" and "Starry Night," but his long struggle with depression was to end in suicide at the age of only 37.
1888: Britain sets up a protectorate over Sarawak on Borneo.
1906: A strong earthquake rocks the area between Chiayi and Toulio, killing more than 1,100, injuring nearly 2,000 and destroying some 6,700 houses.
1939: British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain accuses Adolf Hitler of breaking his word after German forces cross the Czech frontier.
1942: American Gen. Douglas MacAthur arrives in Australia and sets up headquarters in Melbourne.
1946: Tai Li, director of the Investigation and Statistics Bureau under the National Military Council, is killed when a plane flying from Tsingtao to Nanking crashes. He was 50.
1959: Skate, a U.S. submarine, surfaces at the North Pole after completing a historic voyage under ice to reach its destination.
1959: People in Tibet launch a major uprising against mainland Chinese rule as the Dalai Lama flees Lasha in disguise.
1963: Mount Agung on the Indonesian island of Bali erupts, killing more than 11,000 people.
1969: Golda Meir, a 70-year-old grandmother, takes office as Israel's first female prime minister.
1973: More than six million eligible voters go to the polls in Taiwan to elect county and city councilors, mayors and township chiefs for terms of four years.
1973: Yu Chin-hsien and Chou Po-lien are sworn in as president and vice president of the Control Yuan.
1973: Henry Kearns, president of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, signs loan agreements with the Taiwan Railway Administration and the Taiwan Fertilizer Corporation.
1974: Dr. Harrison S. Brown, vice president of the international Council of Scientific Union and foreign secretary of the U.S. Academy of Science, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1974: Leo G. de Grijs, senior vice president of the Continental Bankof Chicago, arrived in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: The U.S. Trade Center is opened in Taipei. Premier Chiang Ching-kuo attended the opening ceremony at which U.S. Undersecretary of Commerce John Tabor presided.
1975: Chu Fu-sung, ambassador to the Republic of Korea, presents his credentials to President Park Chung Hee.
1975: Maj. Gen. Carl W. Hoffman, commander of the U.S. Third Marine Amphibious Force, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Y. S. Sun, minister of economic affairs, tells the Taipei American Chamber of Commerce that foreign investment is still welcome in Taiwan.
1978: The tanker Amoco Cardiz runs aground off the coast of Brittany, France, and then splits in two, releasing its massive cargo of crude oil.
1990: Thousands of university students stage a sit-down protest at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to express opposition to the National Assembly's attempt to expand its authority.
1997: Madame Chiang Kai-shek celebrates her 100th birthday.
1998: Zhu Rongji is elected mainland China's premier with a mandate to overhaul ailing banks and crumbling state industries.
2000: Lee Ching-hua, head of the New Party's national election and development committee, announces that he is quitting his post as convenor of the party and withdrawing his party membership in support of independent presidential candidate James Soong.
2001: The World Taiwanese Congress, an umbrella organization of 60-odd pro-Taiwan indpendence groups that was founded in December 2000, opens its first annual meeting in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "While sitting in court (as chief justice), in deciding upon the suits that come before me, I am no better than other men. But what I always try to do is to make even the suits unnecessary."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE EXPRESSES GRAVE CONCERN ABOUT ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution by a vote of 424-4 Wednesday condemning China's newly enacted so-called "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.
The resolution demands that the Bush administration express its grave concern about the new Beijing legislation which authorizes the use of force against Taiwan.
The resolution also urges the administration to reaffirm the U.S. policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS NEEDED TO SPEED UP TUNNEL CONSTRUCTION: MOTC

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) hopes to import 200 foreign workers to help speed up construction of the Shueishan Tunnel, the centerpiece of the Peiyi Freeway project, an official said Thursday.

An average of 1,500 workers are now working on the Shueishan Tunnel project, the official said, adding that more workers are needed to ensure smooth completion of the freeway before the end of this year as scheduled.
Because of the tough working conditions, the official said, local people have been reluctant to work on the construction project.

"We have long faced a serious labor shortage problem, " the official said, adding that the MOTC hopes the Council of Labor Affairs can allow the ministry to import some 200 foreign workers for the project on a special case-by-case basis.

Boring on the Shueishan Tunnel, also known as a "tunnel beneath troubled waters" for its engineering difficulties, began 13 years ago. After many twists and turns, the earth boring work of the 12.9-km tunnel was finally completed last September.
The Shueishan Tunnel has been called one of the most challenging road construction projects in the world. It is the longest highway tunnel in Asia and the fifth longest in the world.

Construction has long been delayed because of the special geological formation of Shueishan (Mount Snow) through which the tunnel passes. Construction on the 31-km Peiyi Freeway which links Taipei to Ilan began in 1991. Boring work has often been halted due to the frequent welling up of water at the construction site as well as mud slides.

Because of the engineering difficulties, no insurance company has been willing to provide safety coverage for the project. MOTC Minister Lin Ling-san once said that whoever manages to bear through to the completion of the Shueishan Tunnel will secure a place in Taiwan's engineering history.
When the freeway is completed by the end of 2005, driving from Taipei to Ilan will take only 40 minutes, compared to the two hours required at present.

The remains of the 22 suspected members of the Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG), who were killed by policemen in the Tuesday assault at the Metro Manila District Jail (MMDJ) in Bicutan, Taguig City were buried yesterday at the Muslim Cemetery also in Taguig.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: 22 Abus buried as 'martyrs'
TO MANY, the 22 were plain bandits. To their relatives, they were martyrs and buried them as such. Two of them had been accused of beheading hostages in the days when they terrorized civilian communities. One was linked to the torching of a town in Zamboanga del Sur province in which more than 50 people were killed.
The Philippine Star: Sayyaf victims shed no tears
Victims of the Abu Sayyaf are happy that some of its most notorious leaders have been put out of business. The family of former Abu Sayyaf hostage Gracia Burnham expressed relief yesterday at the outcome of the standoff between Philippine government forces and rioting detainees at Camp Bagong Diwa in Taguig City that led to the killing of three notorious bandit leaders.

The country's run down prisons are conducive to escape, officials admitted Wednesday, noting the failed jailbreak by Abu Sayyaf militants that ended in a bloody prison uprising, leaving close to 30 dead.

The Straits Times : Many more S'poreans are obese.
Many more Singaporeans are overweight and at risk of fat-related diseases such as stroke and diabetes than was previously thought.
The conclusion follows the Government's revision yesterday of its guidelines on the ideal ratio of weight to height, measured by the widely-used international measure called body mass index, or BMI.
With the change, which comes about after studies showed Asians have 4 to 5 per cent more body fat than similarly-built Caucasians, half the population will now be classified as overweight or obese.
This up from 30 per cent before.

Increased enforcement was behind the increase. Last year, 1131 roadblocks were set up, compared to 1040 in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER ANNOUNCES BID FOR KMT CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng announced Thursday his bid for the chairmanship of the opposition Kuomintang, whose election is set for July 16.
In a press conference, Wang expounded his ideals for party reforms following the party's consecutive losses in the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections.
Wang said that the Legislative Yuan will play a pivotal role in the reforms and will play the role of a checks-and-balances force.
The party will also make efforts to try to win elections at all levels in the hopes of building a solid basis for regaining the presidency.

On the controversial issue of the KMT's assets, Wang said that he will handle the issue properly if elected so that it won't be a persistent burden to the party. At the same time, he vowed to protect the rights and livelihood of current and retired party workers amid recent reports that the party is trying to streamline due to financial problems.

On concerns that the race for party chairmanship between himself and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, both of whom are KMT vice chairmen, might turn into a confrontation between the two and in turn divide the party, Wang said: "Actually, there will only be cooperation, not confrontation, between us."

Although the person who wins the KMT chairmanship is widely expected to have a strong advantage in vying to be the "pan-blue alliance" candidate in the 2008 presidential election, Wang said that he would have the national interests in mind when considering whether to run in the presidential election and that everything would depend on the "public will."
"As long as the ideal of regaining ruling power can be realized, I'll devote myself to accomplishing the historical task, although success will not depend on myself alone," he said.

He noted that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its two splinter parties, the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party, have to unite and cooperate in response to the aspirations of the voters.

If there is no cooperation among the three parties, there will be no possibility of winning the 2008 presidential election, Wang said, adding that "this is the destiny of the trio, and the leaders of the three parties have to face it honestly."
Wang also said that if elected as party chairman, he will stick to the official names of the party as well as the nation and that the Constitution of the Republic of China will not be abrogated.

More than 60 incumbent KMT legislators and 60 former legislators attended the press conference, showing the immense popularity of the 10-term legislator. Two of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's supporters, namely KMT Legislator Wu Yu-sheng, who formerly served as a Taipei City Government spokesman, and New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, also attended on Ma's behalf.
Meanwhile, Mayor Ma, pointing to Wang's background and style, expressed confidence that the race for the KMT chairmanship will be a "battle between two gentlemen."
As Thursday was Wang's 65th birthday, Ma also sent a birthday cake and flowers to him to express his best wishes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S SUBMARINES IN STRAIT MEAN MORE THAN BLOCKADE: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Thursday that China's submarine deployment in the Taiwan Strait indicates a "higher strategic ambition" than blockading Taiwan.
Wu urged the international community to take the situation seriously and take measures to deal with the problem.
Wu told the legislature's Home and Nations Committee that three shipbuilders on China are currently rushing submarine construction orders placed by the Chinese military.

In addition to the Ming-class, Song-class and Yuan-class submarines, China is equipped with Type-093 and Type-094 nuclear-powered attack submarines and has purchased a total of 12 Kilo-class submarines from Russia, Wu pointed out.
Wu said blockading the Taiwan Strait does not require such a large number of submarines and China obviously has a "higher strategic ambition" than that.

On the government's plan to promote cross-strait charter cargo flights, Wu said the special cross-strait charter flight service provided during this year's Chinese Lunar New Year holiday could be a model for the government to follow while arranging charter cargo flights.

However, after the recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by Beijing, the ROC government will have to assess the changes in cross-strait relations to decide when and how cross-strait talks on the charter cargo flights will be conducted, Wu said.
He said the government will protect the interests of the country and its people while carrying out the policy.

Meanwhile, in a report to the legislature's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said China's Anti-Secession Law is aimed at declaring to the international community that the Taiwan issue is an internal affair and is a confrontation of the United States' Taiwan Relations Act.

Chiu said the Anti-Secession Law dictates unification as the only option for the ultimate development of cross-strait relations and defines a legal basis for China to annex Taiwan by force, which he said is tantamount to unilaterally proclaiming a change in the cross-strait status quo.

Beijing's law contradicts the cross-strait reality in which Taiwan and China are independent of each other and increases the uncertainties across the Taiwan Strait and in the Asia-Pacific region, Chiu said.
By enacting the law, Beijing is also trying to temper nationalist sentiments on China and deal a blow to the pro-independence movement in Taiwan, according to Chiu.
He said the law symbolizes that China's cross-strait policy has shifted from "promoting unification" politically to "compelling unification" legally.
He warned the development will increase Taiwan people's resentment towards China, intensify cross-strait confrontation and hinder cross-strait exchanges and the resumption of dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO END FLOODING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday that the Cabinet will introduce an eight-year, NT$80 billion (US$2.58 billion) flood-prevention project in an attempt to end flooding in Taiwan.
Hsieh made the remarks while inspecting the construction of the Yuanshantzu flood-prevention sluice along the Keelung River.

With the construction work having been delayed after the half-completed facility was used to help drain flood water from the Keelung River during typhoon season last year, Hsieh ordered that the construction be completed by May.
Calling flooding a symbol of backwardness, Hsieh said the problem should not be allowed to continue in a country where people enjoy an average per capita income of nearly US$15,000.

According to Hsieh, the Cabinet currently only earmarks NT$1 billion every year to subsidize the flood-control projects for local governments, which would take more than 80 years to resolve the flooding problem.
Under these circumstances, the Cabinet plans to funnel NT$80 billion over eight years into a comprehensive project to resolve the problem 70 years early, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INCAPABLE OF LAUNCHING FULL ATTACK ON TAIWAN AT PRESENT: MND

TEXT.P: China's military is currently incapable of launching a full attack on Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Thursday.

However, if Taiwan doesn't purchase from the United States the package of six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, Beijing will be able to attack Taiwan between 2020 and 2035, Lee said.
Lee made the remarks while reporting on a special budget for arms procurement to the National Defense Committee at the Legislative Yuan.

Lee said the Anti-Secession Law shows China's intention to invade Taiwan. This, coupled with its military expansion and various of drills and exercises every year, points to the fact that Beijing is actively preparing to wage war against Taiwan.

Noting that the establishment of missile defenses and the capability to repel an attempt at blockading the island are the most urgent tasks for the ministry, Taiwan definitely needs the U.S. arms package, he said.

He also said that the amount of the procurement has been marked down from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$475.9 billion (US$15.48 billion) because the government has dropped a plan to make the submarines in Taiwan, while the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. dollar.

Legislator Tang Huo-sheng of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the passage of the Anti-Secession Law by Beijing has created a degree of uncertainty, and wondered if more weaponry should be acquired.
Lee said that the ministry has estimated what weaponry is required using computer models, and the present package should meet current needs.

Independent Legislator Li Ao pointed out that U.S. officials recently expressed to James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, during the latter's visit to the United States, that even if Taiwan buys the U. S. package, Taiwan cannot protect itself, and can only show that the island has the determination and sincerity to safeguard itself.
