DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW NOT A LAW OF PEACE: ROC DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's Anti-Secession Law is by no means a law of peace because it cuts short mainland China's decision-making process for war, and threatens cross-Taiwan Strait relations and stability in the region, Republic of China Representative to the United States David Lee said Wednesday.

Lee made the remarks while giving a speech on the law's impact on the cross-strait situation to a group of Taiwan Congress Caucus members under the House of Representatives at the Rayburn Office Building.

He said that Beijing's adoption of the law has taken the Taiwan authorities and its people by surprise and stirred up deep concern among them at a time of detente evidenced in a series of events that have helped bilateral ties, such as the historic direct lunar new year charter flights and a joint statement issued by President Chen Shui-bian and People First Party Chairman James Soong vowing not to change the national title of the ROC.

Stressing that the law is not in any form a law of peace as Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao claimed, he said that by delegating power to the State Council and the Central Military Committee to decide on and execute non-peaceful means and other necessary measures, it enables Beijing to initiate hostilities in circumvention of even their own existing checks and balances and aggravates its military threat against Taiwan.
Moreover, the law defies the key element of the U.S. policy toward Taiwan -- no unilateral change of the status quo across the strait and a peaceful resolution of disputes, he said.

Furthermore, he added that the law is a direct challenge to the Taiwan Relations Act, which states that "any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means is...a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area and of grave concern to the United States." Peace and stability in the region are vital to U.S. interests.
According to the ROC de-facto ambassador to the United States, the law is not only detrimental to cross-strait relations but also poses great harm to the world order.

Citing results of recent polls, Lee pointed out that 93 percent of the Taiwan people are against the Anti-Secession Law, while 91 percent want to have their own say on the future of Taiwan. More than 80 percent prefer the status quo to Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification formula, he added.

Urging the United States and the international community not to underestimate its seriousness and to continue to take a firm and principled position as remedies for the law, he reaffirmed that Taiwan will stand firm on its commitment to boosting peace, democracy and prosperity in the region and the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GRATEFUL FOR U.S. HOUSE RESOLUTION AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Mach 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is grateful for all the support and concern shown by the international community for Taiwan in the wake of China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, a Presidential Office spokesman said Thursday.

Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, made the remarks a day after the U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution by a vote of 424-4 condemning China's newly enacted law targeting Taiwan.
"We appreciate the U.S. congressional resolution expressing grave concern about Beijing's ill-intentioned piece of legislation, " Chen said.

Noting that China's "anti-secession" legislation codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, Chen said he is convinced that no government or individuals who value freedom, democracy and peace could accept such an act or sit idly by.
Since Beijing's rubber-stamp National People's Congress passed its Anti-Secession Law March 14, Chen said many countries around the world have voiced concern and support for Taiwan.
"The Presidential Office is very grateful for the warmth and friendship shown by the international community toward us at this critical moment," Chen said.

The U.S. House resolution demands that the Bush administration voice its grave concern about Beijing's provocative action in enacting a law authorizing the use of force to stop Taiwan from seeking formal independence.
The resolution also urges the administration to reaffirm the U.S. policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.

The resolution was introduced by Chairman of the House International Relations Committee Henry Hyde and the Committee's ranking member Tom Lantos along with a handful committee members, including Chris Smith, Dan Burton, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Dana Rohrabacher, Steve Chabot, Darrell Issa, Jo Ann Davis, Joe Wilson and Connie Mack.
The resolution concludes that: (1) The Anti-Secession Law of the People's Republic of China
provides a legal justification for the use of force against
Taiwan, altering the status quo in the region, and thus is of
grave concern to the United States; (2) The president of the United States should direct all appropriate
officials of the United States Government to reflect the grave
concern with which the United States views the passage of China's
Anti-Secession Law in particular, and the growing Chinese
military threats to Taiwan in general, to their counterpart
officials in the Government of the People's Republic of China; (3) The government of the United States should reaffirm its policy
that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means
and with the consent of the people of Taiwan;
(4) The government of the United States should continue to encourage
dialogue between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KFC SAYS TAIWAN OUTLETS DO NOT USE SUSPECTED CANCER AGENT SUDAN 1 DYE

TEXT.P: Taiwan management of the U.S. fast food restaurant franchise Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) said Thursday that all dishes offered in its restaurants around Taiwan are safe and free from the suspected cancer-causing dye Sudan 1.

Taiwan KFC Managing Director Olga Wu told the media that suppliers of Taiwan KFC and those in China are different and all the food materials and ingredients provided in Taiwan have been monitored strictly to ensure their quality and safety.

Taiwan KFC contacted the media Thursday after KFC China pulled two chicken dishes off its menu across the country Wednesday after discovering they contained Sudan 1 dye, a synthetic industrial chemical banned from use in food. Sudan 1 dye was found in red pepper powder used as an ingredient in the KFC restaurants' New Orleans wings and drumstick burgers.
Noting that the ingredients used in the KFC restaurants around China were locally-sourced, Wu said that the red pepper powder used in Taiwan's KFC restaurants is imported from Spain.
Besides, Wu reiterated, use of dyes like Sudan 1, 2, 3 and 4 are strictly controlled in Taiwan.

As of noon Thursday, news reports from mainland China said that Sudan 1 -- used in petrol and shoe polish but banned from food because it heightens the risk of cancer -- was distributed by a Guangzhou-based factory to suppliers in nine provinces across China for use in foods.

Sudan 1 triggered a food scare across much of Europe last month. In Britain, for example, hundreds of sauces, soups and ready-made meals have been taken off supermarket shelves since the discovery of the chemical in food on Feb. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE RESOLUTION EXPRESSES GRAVE CONCERN ABOUT NEW BEIJING LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 16 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution by a vote of 424-4 Wednesday expressing the grave concern of the Congress regarding China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
The resolution demands that the Bush administration voice its grave concern about Beijing's provocative action in enacting a law authorizing the use of force against Taiwan.
It also urges the administration to reaffirm the U.S. policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.

The resolution was initiated by House International Relations Committee Chairman Henry Hyde and the Committee's ranking member Tom Lantos along with a handful committee members, including Chris Smith, Dan Burton, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Dana Rohrabacher, Steve Chabot, Darrell Issa, Jo Ann Davis, Joe Wilson and Connie Mack.

Noting that President George W. Bush stated Dec. 9, 2003 that it is the U.S. policy to oppose any unilateral decision, by either China or Taiwan, to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, the resolution says the passage of the Anti-Secession Law by China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress March 14, 2005 constitutes an unilateral change to the cross-strait status quo.

Citing a report in 2004 by the Department of Defense on China's military power, the resolution points out that Beijing had deployed about 500 short-range ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan and that the arms buildup of missiles and other offensive weapons by Beijing in the areas adjacent to the Taiwan Strait poses threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific.

The resolution further says that the Taiwan Relations Act, enacted in 1979, makes it clear that Washington's decision to set up diplomatic relations with Beijing rested upon the expectation that the future of Taiwan should be determined by peaceful means with the consent of the people in Taiwan.

It is Washington's policy to maintain the capacity of the United States to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security or the social or economic system of the people in Taiwan, the resolution says.
The resolution concludes that: (1) The Anti-Secession Law of the People's Republic of China provides
a legal justification for the use of force against Taiwan,
altering the status quo in the region, and thus is of grave
concern to the United States; (2) The president of the United States should direct all appropriate
officials of the United States Government to reflect the grave
concern with which the United States views the passage of China's
Anti-Secession Law in particular, and the growing Chinese
military threats to Taiwan in general, to their counterpart
officials in the Government of the People's Republic of China; (3) The government of the United States should reaffirm its policy
that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means
and with the consent of the people of Taiwan;
(4) The government of the United States should continue to encourage
dialogue between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES TO HAVE 500,000 WOMEN TAKING PART IN PROTEST MARCH

TEXT.P: Chairman Su Tseng-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party expressed the hope Thursday that at least half a million women will take part in a march scheduled for March 26 to protest against China's newly passed Anti-Secession Law.

Su made the remarks as he called on the National Union of Taiwan Women's Association, Rotary Club Taiwan District 3480 and the Taiwan Medical Association to solicit their support in mobilizing members to take part in the march to send a strong message to the international community.
Su said that the march was planned on short notice and urged the civic groups to mobilize as many people as possible.

He said that Taiwan should unite on March 26 to show clearly that it opposes the law, adding that the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union have been invited to take part in the protest march, which could attract one million participants.

Presidential adviser Lee Yuan-chen also said the Anti-Secession Law has underscored the hegemonic and paternal thoughts of China. Taiwan women must come out in droves to voice their aspirations for peace and democracy internationally.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR PLEDGES TO CONTINUE TO BOOST FILM INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai pledged Thursday to continue to encourage filmmakers to shoot their films in the port city by offering them various incentives.
Chen said he hopes to turn Kaohsiung into a city similar to Nantes or Cannes in France.

Chen made the remarks while presenting a NT$10 million (US$322,581) prize to film director Tsai Ming-liang for his latest film, The Wayward Cloud, which won a Silver Bear at the Berlin International Film Festival last month.

Chen noted that Kaohsiung is the first city in Taiwan to have put forth a film policy, offering cash prizes to support the domestic film industry and encourage filmmakers to shoot their films in the city.

Chen said the city government will in the future study the possibility of expanding the policy to the television industry and provide more resources, assistance and tax deductions to filmmakers to develop Kaohsiung into a city of digital imaging.
Expressing his gratitude for the city government, Tsai said he will soon return to Kaohsiung to shoot a new film.
Tsai praised the city government's efforts to develop Kaohsiung into an international cosmopolitan city in recent years, saying the city is more beautiful than seven or eight years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO LAUNCH PUBLICITY DRIVE AGAINST CHINA

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will launch a publicity drive to counter China's series of campaigns against Taiwan and to underscore Taiwan's own identity, GIO Director-General Yao Wen-chih said Thursday.

In a report to the Education and Culture Committee at the Legislative Yuan, Yao pointed out that Beijing has waged war on Taiwan using public opinion, legal and psychological forces and its parliament has just passed the Anti-Secession Law to unilaterally redefine the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
Beijing is also attempting to use its "one China" myth to squeeze the maneuvering space of Taiwan internationally, he said.

Yao said that to break the myth and reveal the anti-democratic nature and hegemonic mentality of Beijing, the GIO has asked the nation's overseas missions to strike back through such activities as video conferences, seminars, press conferences, interviews or sending letters to media organizations, hoping that major world media will report on news about Taiwan and present the island in a positive light.

He also said that to enhance the international understanding of Taiwan so that the world lends support to the democratic island, the GIO is also engaging in a national image program. The publicity drive will vary in content in different countries, although the purpose will all be to underscore the identity of the nation and to avoid being confused with the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

He cited the examples of the GIO running national image ads at the Athens Olympics last year under the name of Chinese Taipei or Taiwan, while ranking government officials use Republic of China (Taiwan) as the nation's name to avoid confusion with the People's Republic of China, which is the official name of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG WILL WITHDRAW KMT CHAIRMANSHIP BID IF LIEN SEEKS RE-ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that should opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan decide to seek re-election, he will withdraw his candidacy for the party's chairmanship.
Wang, who formally announced his bid the same day for the KMT leadership at a news conference, made the remarks after his meeting with Lien.

Terming Lien as the most suitable candidate to lead the KMT, Wang said if Lien is willing to continue to shoulder the future of the party, he will immediately end his campaign and fully support Lien's re-election.

Even though Wang, who serves concurrently as a KMT vice chairman, has announced his decision to vie for the party's chairmanship, he has maintained his attitude of "respecting Lien" while seeking support from party members.

Wang is scheduled to head for the United States April 4 to take part in a series of volunteer fire fighters activities in his capacity as chairman of the Republic of China National Volunteer Fire Fighters Association. He will also meet with U.S. congressmen and take advantage of the trip to drum up support from overseas KMT members for his chairmanship bid.

Seventy incumbent KMT legislators, 60 former lawmakers as well 15 county and city council speakers or deputy speakers attended Wang's news conference, showing the immense popularity of the 10-term legislator from the southern county of Kaohsiung. He was re-elected legislative speaker of the new legislature in February.

Legislator Chiu Yi of the opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Liu Kuan-ping of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, as well as three lawmakers from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union -- Yen Ching-piao, Lin Ping-kun and Chang Li-shan -- also appeared at the news conference to wish Wang luck.

Speaking at the press conference, Wang noted that if elected as party chairman, he will stick to the official names of the party as well as the nation and that the Constitution of the Republic of China will not be abrogated.
He also said that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its two splinter parties -- the PFP and the New Party -- have to unite and cooperate in response to the aspirations of the voters.

If there is no cooperation among the three parties, there will be no possibility of winning the 2008 presidential election, Wang said, adding that "this is the destiny of the trio, and the leaders of the three parties have to face it honestly."

Wang's announcement followed that of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, also a KMT vice chairman, who made public his candidacy for the party's leadership last month. The election of a new KMT chairman is set for July 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Wolfowitz Gets Bush Nomination for World Bank.
President Bush said Wednesday that he planned to nominate Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputysecretary of defense and one of the admini stration's earliest and most outspoken advocates of using American influence to spread democracy around the globe, to become the next president of the World Bank.
Wall Street Journal: KKR Group to Buy All of Toys 'R' Us For $5.7 Billion.
A seven-month long auction to sell a division of Toys "R" Us Inc. ended late Wednesday night with a sale of the entire company for about $5.7 billion to a consortium consisting of two private-equity firms, Bain Capital and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., and Vornado Realty Trust, according to people familiar with the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Brown courts grey vote in his memorial Budget.
Gordon Brown handed pensioners 200 off their council tax and free bus travel yesterday as he wooed the elderly, families, motorists and first-time buyers with sweeteners funded by a 1 billion raid on oil company profits. The Chancellor pitched for the grey vote in an electioneering Budget containing carefully targeted tax cuts worth 1.5 billion in the coming year and 1.1 billion the following year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT 'DOMESTIC ROUTE' OF CHINA IN OLYMPIC TORCH RELAY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan enjoys equal status as that of China in the International Olympic Committee and will not accept Beijing's plan to make Taiwan one of the destinations in a "domestic route" for the torch relay for the 2008 Olympic Games, an official said Thursday.

Chu Shou-chien, vice chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, said it is still too early to react to the issue because the plan is not yet final and the Games are still three years away.
Liu Qi, president of the Beijing Organizing Committee for the Games of the 29th Olympiad, said recently that the "domestic route" of the torch relay will include Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA EXPRESSES GRATITUDE TO U.S. HOUSE FOR DENOUNCING BEIJING LAW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed deep gratitude Thursday to the U.S. House of Representatives for passing a resolution to voice its grave concern over Beijing's recent passage of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The U.S. House of Representatives passed the resolution introduced by Chairman of the House International Relations Committee Henry Hyde (R.-Il) by a vote of 424-4 Wednesday, demanding that the Bush administration voice its grave concern about China's provocative action in enacting a law codifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should Taiwan seek formal independence.
The resolution also urges the administration to reaffirm the U.S. policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.
The original co-sponsors of the resolution are: Chris Smith, Dan Burton, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Dana Rohrabacher, Steve Chabot, Darrell Issa, Jo Ann Davis, Joe Wilson and Connie Mack.
The resolution concludes that: (1) The Anti-Secession Law of the People's Republic of China
provides legal justification for the use of force against
Taiwan, altering the status quo in the region and thus being of
grave concern to the United States; (2) The President of the United States should direct all appropriate
officials of the United States government to reflect the grave
concern with which the United States views the passage of China's
Anti-Secession Law in particular, and the growing Chinese
military threat to Taiwan in general, to their counterpart
officials in the government of the People's Republic of China; (3) The government of the United States should reaffirm its policy
that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means
and with the consent of the people of Taiwan; and (4) The government of the United States should continue to encourage
dialogue between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China.
According to MOFA officials, only four congress representatives -- Betty McCollum (D-Mn), Jim McDermott (D-Wa), James Oberstar (D-Mn) and Ron Paul (R-Tx) -- cast "no" votes to the resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO SAFEGUARD RULE OF LAW, JUDICIAL INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said the government will make every effort to safeguard judicial independence and the rule of law, and that no one should doubt the judiciary's impartiality.
The president made the remarks in an article posted on his personal Web site Thursday.

The article came at a time when the supporters of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) are planning to hold a rally Saturday to mark the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen on March 19, 2004.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party said the shooting was set up to win sympathy votes for President Chen in his re-election bid. Chen won by a little more than 25,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast. The "pan-blue alliance" filed two lawsuits against the election and the result of the election, but both suits were rejected.

The president said that he has fought all his life for the ideal of "everyone is equal before the law, " and that to carry out the ideal, the government will safeguard the "independent judicial system" and the rule of law.

He stressed that no one should ever think that a judicial verdict was made in Taiwan out of self interest; otherwise, social order will break down, and "justice and righteousness will fall," adding that only through a respect of the judicial system can the democracy in Taiwan mature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, GERMANY INK ACADEMIC LINKS AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Representatives of higher education from Taiwan and Germany inked a Taiwanese-German Academic Links Agreement Thursday, boosting two-way interactions.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng witnessed the signing by Dr. Stefan Hormuth, vice president of the German Rectors' Conference and Giessen University rector, and his Taiwan counterparts, including Cheng Jei-cheng, president of the Association of National Universities of Taiwan, and Mu Tzung-tsanne, president of the Association of Private Universities of Taiwan.

Tu said that the accord will help attract more German college students to study in Taiwan and effectively encourage a large number of Taiwan students to pursue advanced academic degrees in Germany and promised to do his utmost to push for globalization at Taiwan's institutions of higher learning.

The agreement will lay a sound foundation and provide references for college and universities in both countries to verify students's entrance qualifications and compare academic credits and grant diplomas, particularly in the fields of law, fine arts, medicine and music, officials of the education ministry said.
Traveling at the head of a seven-member delegation of the German Rectors' Conference, Hormuth arrived in Taiwan March 13 for six days.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS STAUNCH SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, March 16 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: El Salvador President Elias Antonio Saca reaffirmed his country's staunch support for the Republic of China Wednesday in the wake of China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
Saca made the reaffirmation while meeting with visiting ROC Vice President Annette Lu, who is currently on a three-day official visit to the Central American country.

China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress passed almost unanimously its Anti-Secession Law March 14 that authorizes the use of non-peaceful means to stop Taiwan from seeking formal independence.
Commenting on China's provocative act, Saca said his government's support for Taiwan's cause will never waver.
During their hour-long talk, Saca also exchanged views with Lu on a bilateral cooperative project to build a special industrial park in El Salvador to attract Taiwan investment.
The project will mark the first time the ROC government has joined forces with the private sector to set up an industrial park in El Salvador.

Lu arrived in the Salvadoran capital of San Salvador Monday at the head of a 152-member delegation for a visit aimed at cementing bilateral diplomatic ties and boosting trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 TAIWAN EXPO HOPES TO ATTRACT 5.5 MILLION VISITORS

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Expo slated to be held in Taoyuan, Tainan and Chiayi from May to September 2008 is expected to attract 5.5 million visitors, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials said Thursday.

The purpose of the national exposition, to be organized by the ministry, is to make the country a world-class technology hub by attracting visitors from home and abroad and to secure the country's international status as a base for supplying technological products worldwide so that the country can attract foreign investment that will allow the nation's economy to develop, the officials said.

The exposition venue in Taoyuan will be dedicated to high technology, with topics including digitized operations at home, mobile life, biotechnology and nanotechnology. In Tainan, the event will center around sustainable ecology and environmental protection, while in Chiayi, it will revolve around history and culture, with subjects including visual art, performance art and animated film art, they said.
Thus far, the ministry has cultivated a total of 5,500 professionals that will take part in the exposition, they said, adding that it is expected to create 41,000 jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EXPORT PINEAPPLES TO JAPAN IN APRIL

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung and Chianan branches of the Taiwan Fruit Marketing Cooperative (TFMC) will export pineapples to Japan in April under an agreement entered into Thursday between the cooperative and its Japanese counterpart.
The export price for each 10-kg carton will be US$8.5, according to a TFMC Kaohsiung branch official.
The official said that his branch will procure pineapples from local growers at a price of NT$15 (US$0.49) per kilo, adding that the shipment will take place from late April.
The exports will help stabilize domestic market prices, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BE WARY OF INFLUX OF FARM PRODUCE FROM CHINA: PINGTUNG OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: In the wake of China's offer to allow imports of Taiwan agricultural produce, officials of the Pingtung county government have warned of an influx of Chinese farm products and subsequent complications they might cause.

Huang Chen-lung, head of the Agriculture Bureau, suggested that the central government should weigh the issue comprehensively by asking what its policy will be should China demand that Taiwan also open its market to Chinese produce.

Huang said Chinese agricultural goods might outperform domestic produce in the domestic market thanks to their cheaper prices, but he warned of the risk of disease from Chinese products due to lax quarantine.

Tsao Chi-hung, formerly a legislator from the southern Taiwan county, pointed out that China will only allow certain kinds of Taiwan fruit to enter its market, such as papayas, star fruit, bell fruit and guavas, which are difficult to cultivate in China.
According to Tsao, many Chinese agricultural products have already entered the domestic market, dealing a heavy blow to local produce.

If China demands that Taiwan import agricultural products under the framework of the World Trade Organization, it will do great harm to domestic agriculture, Tsao warned, urging the central government to be cautious when mulling the issue, especially at a time when many Taiwan fruit growers have relocated to China and are reshipping their produce back to Taiwan.

For instance, many mango growers from Taiwan have successfully planted the tropical fruit in China, and Taiwan's Council of Agriculture has come under pressure to accept shipments of mangoes from these farmers, he pointed out.

Huang Juei-chi, an official at the Pingtung County Farmers Association who visited China last year to negotiate agricultural exports, said that the officials they met promised to grant market access to 12 kinds of Taiwan agricultural goods at low customs tariffs and with easy customs procedures.
According to Huang, they expressed their hope that the Chinese authorities will live up to their promise not to demand that Taiwan open its market to Chinese products in return.

Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao said March 14 following Beijing's adoption of the Anti-Secession Law that China is willing to allow more agricultural products to enter its market, especially those from southern Taiwan, in a gesture to play down the law's threat against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP ADDRESSES SALVADORAN PARLIAMENT
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, March 16 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Wednesday thaT the people of Taiwan will never yield to China's threats or saber-rattling.
Lu, who is currently on a three-day official visit to El Salvador, made the remarks in a speech delivered at the Salvadoran parliament.
Over the past 50-plus years, Lu said, China has used all sorts of coercion and tricks in attempts to compel Taiwan to surrender to its unification terms.
On March 14, Lu said, China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress even passed almost unanimously its Anti-Secession Law to codify the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.

"Beijing has 710 ballistic missiles pointed at Taiwan. Now its ceremonial parliament has adopted the so-called Anti-Secession Law to authorize the use of force to annex Taiwan, " Lu said, adding that the international community should not sit idly by and should instead take concrete action to condemn Beijing's ill-intentioned legislation.

Noting that the United Nations will celebrate its 60th anniversary this year, Lu said the ROC used to be a U.N. founding member. However, the ROC has been shut out of the world body since 1971, when the United Nations gave the China seat to Beijing.

Despite China's diplomatic suppression and military threats, Lu said, the ROC will never give in and will instead make every possible effort to safeguard its freedom, democracy, national dignity and sovereignty.
Earlier in the day, Lu paid a visit to Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca to exchange views on a range of topics of mutual concern, including Beijing's provocative anti-secession legislation.
During the meeting, Saca reaffirmed his country's staunch support for Taiwan, saying his administration's support for Taiwan's cause will never waver.
Lu presented pictures featuring the Salvadoran capital of San Salvador taken by the ROC satellite Formosa II.

During their hour-long talk, Saca and Lu also discussed a proposed bilateral cooperative project to build a special industrial park in El Salvador to attract investment from Taiwan businesses as well as Salvadoran entrepreneurs in the United States.
The project will mark the first time the ROC government has joined forces with the private sector to set up an industrial park in El Salvador.

In the afternoon, Lu met with Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar. On behalf of the government, Lu decorated Escobar with a medal in recognition of her contributions to the promotion of bilateral relations. In return, Escobar conferred upon Lu a medal on behalf of the Salvadoran government.

Escobar denounced Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, saying that any dispute should be resolved by peaceful means and that the use of force should never be legalized. In addition to offering diplomatic support for the ROC, Escobar said El Salvador will urge other Central American countries to lend support to Taiwan's cause.
Later, they held a joint news conference to brief the press on key points regarding the proposed "Taiwan Park" project.

In response to press inquiries about Taiwan's aid for its diplomatic allies and the issue of alleged political contributions, Lu said the ROC has consistently conducted comprehensive feasibility studies before finalizing specific aid projects.

Lu said recipients of aid should formulate effective supervisory mechanisms to oversee the implementation of aid projects and the use of the funds. The ROC can do little to supervise the flow of funds after their appropriation to the recipient country, she explained.

Lu arrived in San Salvador Monday at the head of a 152-member delegation for a visit aimed at cementing bilateral diplomatic ties and boosting trade and economic cooperation. She will also visit Guatemala before ending her two-leg diplomatic tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD LAUNCHES CRACKDOWN ON CHINESE POACHERS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Administration mobilized forces in central Taiwan Thursday to disperse Chinese fishing boats poaching in Taiwan waters.

Nine patrol ships, a squadron of four helicopters and 80 coast guard officers took part in the operation to disperse the vessels that were operating illegally in off-limits and restricted waters off various central Taiwan counties, including Taichung, Miaoli and Changhua.
The crackdown was aimed at maintaining security in the region as well as protecting fishery and maritime resources, coast guard authorities said.

Under current regulations, the government can confiscate fishing gear and catches aboard intruding Chinese fishing boats and can remove heavy equipment mounted on the boats to prevent them from returning to poach in Taiwan's territorial waters or exclusive economic zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR MARCH 26 RALLY VITAL FOR DEMOCRACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the public Thursday to take part in a March 26 rally to protest China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, saying that their passion and support for the demonstration will be a pivotal cornerstone for the nation's democracy, freedom and progress.
Chen made the remarks while receiving a group of representatives from the Taiwan Junior Chamber at the Presidential Office.

Over 200 civic groups have so far expressed support for the nationwide rally against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, which provides the Chinese authorities with a legal basis for using non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence, Chen said.

Chen expressed his heartfelt thanks to four international organizations -- the Taiwan Junior Chamber, the Taiwan District of Kiwanis International, the Taiwan Chapter of Lions Clubs International and Rotary International Taiwan -- for joining hands with the ruling Democratic Progress Party to initiate the rally.
The president said he hopes that people from all walks of life will enthusiastically participate in the demonstration to show their solid support and strong desire for freedom, democracy and peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA PLANS TO SET UP 10 MORE OVERSEAS POSTS THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , a non-profit trade promotion entity, plans to establish 10 more overseas posts this year, TAITRA Secretary-General Chao Yung-chuan said Thursday.
Chao did not reveal exactly where the 10 projected overseas posts will be established, saying only that they will be in Asia, Eastern Europe and the Americas.
The new offices will bear the name "Taiwan Trade Office" if possible, he added.

Given that many of TAITRA's overseas posts were established during the era of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) before it was renamed TAITRA, Taiwan's largest trade promoter has been conducting a drive since 1999 to change all the names into "Taiwan Trade Center" with the aim of avoiding confusion with Chinese organizations, Chao explained.
The name-changing movement has been going smoothly thus far, with all 35 TAITRA overseas offices re-designated as "Taiwan Trade Center" except those in Moscow, Mexico, Hong Kong and India, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE RESOLUTION FAVORABLY RECEIVED BY TAIWAN POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: All parties across Taiwan's political spectrum expressed welcome Thursday to a U.S. House of Representatives resolution denouncing Beijing's recent passage of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The U.S. House of Representatives passed the resolution by an overwhelming vote of 424-4 Wednesday, demanding that the Bush administration voice its grave concern about China's provocative action in enacting a law codifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should Taiwan seek formal independence.
The resolution also urges the U.S. administration to reaffirm the U.S. policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.

Responding to the passage of the resolution, Chen Chin-chun, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said the U.S. lawmakers voiced their strong support for Taiwan by almost unanimously passing the resolution.

However, by comparison, Chen claimed, Taiwan's lawmakers lack any esprit de corps in the wake of China's enactment of the ill-intentioned legislation, consequently resulting in a failure to pass a similar resolution introduced by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally party of the DPP with just 12 seats in the 225-seat legislature, several days ago.

Chen called for the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party to demonstrate unity and consolidation by explicitly voicing Taiwan's opposition to the law and by jointly passing the TSU-introduced resolution entitled "unite Taiwan, resist invasion and uphold freedom."
Chen also urged the people of Taiwan to come out March 26 in a nationwide rally aimed at saying "no" to China.

Expressing welcome to the U.S. House of Representatives' passage of the resolution Wednesday, TSU party whip Lo Chih-ming said that people's standards of seeking freedom, democracy and human rights are identical in the United States and Taiwan.

Lo claimed that the Anti-Secession Law passed by the Chinese rubber stamp National People's Congress March 14 violates the Taiwan Relations Act, a U.S. law that stipulates that no non-peaceful means should be used to undermine peace across the Taiwan Strait.
The Anti-Secession Law has also stepped on the U.S. "red light zone" regarding cross-strait relations, Lo added.

Meanwhile, Chen Chieh, a legislative whip of the opposition Kuomintang, offered his appreciation for the U.S. House of Representatives for its support for Taiwan and for its opposition to China's military threats against Taiwan.

Noting that the cross-strait issue is a thorny one, Chen Chieh called for the leaders on both sides of the strait to use wisdom and patience in jointly resolving cross-strait differences in a peaceful manner.
As important trade partners, the two sides should further enhance exchanges and allow political differences to be resolved through peaceful negotiations and consultations, Chen Chieh added.
Chen Chih-ping, a PFP legislative whip, attributed the U.S. House of Representatives resolution to the success of Taiwan's expressions of indignation at China.

The outcry of the Taiwan people over the Anti-Secession Law has gained support and sympathy from the international community, Chen Chih-ping said, adding that the government should continue to expand Taiwan's diplomatic front to secure broader global support.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 18 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, March 18:
09:00, President Chen Shui-bian will attend the opening ceremony of an international seminar marking the 10th anniversary of the National Health Insurance program at the Howard International House.
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09:00, The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research will hold a seminar on Taiwan's development strategy at the institution's headquarters.
09: 30, A rally to call for public participation in the March 26 manifesto in protest against China's Anti-Secession Law will be held at the Taipei Youth Activity Center.
10:00, The Democratic Action Alliance will hold a news conference in front of the Taipei Guest House on the March 19 manifesto.
10: 00, The opposition Kuomintang legislative caucus will hold a news conference at the caucus' office.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
10: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus will hold a news conference at the caucus' office.
14: 00, A forum on the prospects of the four so-called BRIC nations will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
14:00, The organizers of the 2005 Taipei Film Festival will hold a news conference at the Taipei House SPOT.
14: 00, A rally in promotion of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations will be held at the office of the National Union of Taiwan Women Associations.
16: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive members of the Council for Asia Liberal Democrats Executive Committee at the Presidential Office.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 30, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet the media at the Taipei City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WORKS TO PUT ANTI-SECESSION LAW DISPUTE TO U.N. DEBATE

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday that the his ministry is working on strategies aimed at putting China's controversial Anti-Secession Law up for debate at the United Nations through Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

Chen said that Beijing has called on allied pro-China countries to push for a publicity drive on its enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, a piece of legislation which he said has triggered a "tidal wave" of opposition and concern worldwide.

To counter Beijing's lobbying efforts, Chen said, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has worked out several strategies of its own, including sending Taiwan publicity groups to important and influential countries to make Taiwan's stance more clearly known, distributing President Chen Shui-bian's position papers through Taiwan's diplomatic missions overseas and enabling the cross-Taiwan Strait disputes derived from the enactment of the law to reach the U.N. Assembly for debate through Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

On allegations that Beijing will probably make some concessions on the diplomatic front as a form of compensation to Taiwan after passing the ill-intentioned law targeting Taiwan, Chen described this as wishful thinking.
He added that if China is sincere in wanting to mend fences with Taiwan, it should help Taiwan improve its living space in the international community instead of tossing Taiwan some "tiny favors."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO PRESSURE BEIJING OVER ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The government is hopeful that the United States will continue to put pressure upon China over its newly enacted Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan, Executive Yuan Spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.

Cho made the remarks after the U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution to voice its great concern over the passage of the Anti-Secession Law by China's National People's Congress Monday, as it provides the legal basis for the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the nation moves toward formal independence.
According to Cho, the U.S. House of Representatives stresses in its resolution that the future of Taiwan should be decided by the 23 million people of Taiwan.

Noting that this is a very important concept, Cho voiced the hope that the U.S. government will continuously express its grave concern over the Anti-Secession Law and press for the Beijing authorities to resolve all disputes triggered by the law.

As for an upcoming visit to China by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Cho said she is expected to bring the international community's concern over the issue to the Beijing leadership and that the government will keep a close eye on related developments.

As for the question of whether China will show goodwill toward Taiwan's presence in the international arena following the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, Cho said that Taiwan will seek to participate in international organization on its own and will never soften its solid stance due to any "insignificant favor" from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 2004 EXPORTS TO CHINA HIT US$61.6 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to China amounted to US$61.6 billion for the whole of 2004, up 33.1 percent from the previous year's level, according to government statistics released Thursday.

The ratio of Taiwan's dependence on China in terms of exports climbed to an all-time high of 25.8 percent in 2004, up 1.3 percentage points from the 24.5 percent of 2003, an official of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan said.

If shipments to Hong Kong are excluded, exports to China hit US$45 billion last year, posting an annual growth rate of 27.2 percent, the official said, adding that machinery and related spare parts ranked first in terms of export value (US$14 billion), followed by optical instruments and spare parts (US$5.7 billion) and machine tools and spare parts (US$5.6 billion).

Meanwhile, Taiwan's imports from China totaled US$16.7 billion in 2004, up 52.2 percent from the previous year's level. The top three import items were machinery, machine tools and steel, reaching US$4.7 billion, US$3.3 billion and US$1.5 billion, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ENACTMENT OF ANTI-SECESSION LAW MAY BENEFIT TAIWAN: MINISTER

TEXT.P: China's recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law will benefit Taiwan if the nation handles repercussions of the legislation prudently, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday.

The United States House of Representatives approved a resolution by an overwhelming vote of 424-4 Wednesday urging President George Bush's administration to voice grave concern about China's provocative action in enacting the law, in which Beijing gives itself the authority to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan, Chen noted.
The U.S. Senate is expected to pass a similar resolution in a few days, he added.
Washington may reconsider a proposal by Taiwan to amend the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) to enhance Taiwan's security in the wake of China's legislation, the minister went on.

The TRA has been in effect for more than 25 years and the U.S. rejected a similar proposal several years ago in light of the fact that it is a U.S. internal law and that China's reaction might have made the situation more complicated, Chen pointed out.

The U.S. and Japan, which listed the Taiwan Strait issue as one of their common strategic objectives in a joint statement issued after concluding their Security Consultative Committee meeting Feb. 19 in Washington, might further realize the importance of protecting the area's security after China's ill-intended legislation, he continued.

Also, he said, the European Union, which is mulling the lifting of an arms embargo on China by the end of June, might reconsider its intent in the face of increasing pressure from the United States and the international community following Beijing's enactment of the controversial law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, March 18, or the ninth day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1455: Fra Angelico, also known as Giovanni da Fiesole, an Italian Dominican friar and religious painter of the Florentine school, dies at the age of 55.
1662: The first public bus service is inaugurated in Paris, France.
1745: Robert Walpole, English politician who as first Lord of the Treasury and Chancellor of the Exchequer led the Whig administration. Walpole is regarded as Britain's first prime minister, although the office was not officially recognized until 1905, dies at the age of 69.
1858: Rudolf Diesel, German engineer and pioneer of the modern car engine, is born.
1869: Neville Chamberlain: British politician and prime minister from 1937 to 1940 who advocated a policy of appeasement toward the fascist regimes of Europe, is born.
1890: Otto von Bismarck, the Germany chancellor who governed Prussia and later Germany with a policy of "blood and iron" since 1862, is dismissed from his post by Kaiser Wilhelm II.
1922: India's Mahatma Gandhi is sentenced to six years in jail for his civil disobedience campaign.
1926: Guard units under the orders of Tuan Chi-jui, provisional chief executive of the Peking-based government, open fire at citizens and students who went to Tien An Men to make a petition, killing 47 and injuring 160. The incident becomes known as "March 18 Tragedy". Tuan resigned on April 9, 1926.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek becomes chairman of the National Military Council and concurrently chief of the general staff.
1936: F. W. de Klerk, South African president who initiated the reforms which led to the end of apartheid and co-winner of 1993 Nobel Peace Prize, is born.
1940: Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini meet at the Brenner Pass in the Alps, agreeing that Italy would eventually join the war.
1949: The United States and Western European countries establish the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1962: Chi Ju-shan, a great master of Peking opera, dies of a heart attack in Taipei at the age of 86.
1965: Soviet cosmonaut Aleksei Leonov becomes the first man to float in space as he leaves his orbiting spacecraft and dances and somersaults in orbit hundreds of miles above the earth, secured only by a slender lifeline.
1967: Soviet Union expels two Beijing diplomats from Moscow, charging them with anti-Soviet activity.
1969: American President Richard Nixon orders a secret bombing campaign of Cambodia.
1970: Prince Norodom Sihanouk is deposed as chief of state of Cambodia while on a visit to Moscow.
1990: East German holds its first democratic elections, paving the way for the unification of Germany.
1996: The Chinese mainland begins eight days of war games involving ground, air, and naval forces in seas 85 kilometers northwest of Taiwan proper.
1997: Former chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff General Colin L. Powell visits the ROC.
2000: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party ticket of Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu wins the Republic of China's second direct presidential-vice presidential election, ending 55 years of Kuomintang rule in Taiwan.
2003: China's National People's Congress approves the appointment of Hu Jintao as president of the country and the appointment of Wen Jiabao as premier, while Jiang Zemin retains his post as chief of the Central Military Commission.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be patient in maturing your plans and then carry them out with conscientiousness."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS CALLS FOR OPPOSITION PARTIES TO HELP SHOW TAIWAN'S UNITY

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged its opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (FPF) counterparts Friday to jointly denounce Beijing's enactment of the so-called "anti-secession law" targeting Taiwan.

Lai Ching-teh, a DPP legislative whip, said that members of the U.S. House of Representatives voiced their strong support for Taiwan by passing a resolution almost unanimously Wednesday that urges the Bush administration to voice grave concern about China's provocative action in enacting the law, in which Beijing gives itself the authority to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.
The resolution also urges the U.S. administration to reaffirm the U.S. policy that the future of Taiwan should be resolved by peaceful means and with the consent of the people of Taiwan.
The U.S. Senate is expected to pass a similar resolution in a few days, according to Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen.

In contrast, Lai claimed, Taiwan's lawmakers have lacked unity in the wake of China's enactment of the "ill-intentioned" legislation, resulting in a failure to pass a similar resolution introduced several days ago by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally party of the DPP.

Lai said that inter-party efforts to oppose the anti-secession legislation, through which he claims Beijing aims to unilaterally determine Taiwan's future, have so far been non-existent because the KMT and the PFP have closed the door to any negotiations after their attempts to resume the "truth investigation mechanism" on the March 19, 2004 presidential election eve shooting failed.

Lai called for the KMT and PFP to demonstrate Taiwan's unity and consolidation by joining the DPP in explicitly voicing the country's opposition to the Beijing law and passing a resolution of Taiwan's own.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES POLICE COMMAND DENIES PRESENCE OF WIRETAPPING CENTER

TEXT.P: The Armed Forces Police Command (AFPC) has categorically denied the presence of any wiretapping center in the basement of its headquarters in Taipei as reported by the local news media.

Media reports said that in addition to the wiretapping center at the Military Intelligence Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense, military intelligence authorities have another electronic eavesdropping stronghold which has never been exposed before.
According to the reports, the maximum-guarded wiretapping center is located in the basement of the AFPC's Taipei headquarters.
"The reports are not true, " the AFPC said in a press statement, adding that the command has never installed a so-called wiretapping center in its history.

The statement said a group of lawmakers from the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee made an inspection tour of the AFPC last year to check whether the command had a wiretapping center and found that it did not, the statement added.

The AFPC 's statement came a day after ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Chien-hui complained about what he called local prosecutors' abuse of their power to authorize wiretaps at a meeting of the legislature's Judicial Committee.
Quoting official tallies, Huang said local prosecution authorities approved more than 19,000 wiretap applications in 2004, almost two times the number authorized in the United States.

"Is this reasonable? " Huang asked. "The United States has a population of more than 200 million, while Taiwan has only 23 million people. It seems to me that the number of our authorized wiretaps has gone out of proportion to our population and indicates that our prosecution authorities do not respect local people's privacy and human rights," Huang claimed.
Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin and State Public Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao said they share Huang's view that the number of authorized wiretaps is "too high."

Both Shih and Wu promised to demand that prosecutors tighten screening of wiretap requests in the future. They also promised to study the feasibility of delegating the power of wiretap authorization to judges. Prosecutors currently have the power to authorize wiretaps.

According to statistics compiled by the State Public Prosecutor General's Office, a total of 19,485 wiretap applications were approved in 2004, marking a whopping increase from about 3,000 recorded in 2000.

More than 70 percent of the authorized wiretaps were related to drug trafficking and firearm trading investigations, and less than 10 percent were related to corruption probes, Wu said, adding that the wiretapping periods for some cases lasted more than a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS TO HOLD PROTEST RALLY IN D.C. AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 17 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates in the United States are scheduled to stage a demonstration in the U.S. capital on March 26 against China's Anti-Secession Law, organizers said Thursday.

The members from at least 13 Taiwanese groups led by the pro-independence Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) will protest to the Chinese embassy in Washington, D.C. and gather on Capitol Hill to express their opposition to the law, which legalizes the use of force against Taiwan, FAPA officials said.
They said the protesters will also urge the European Union not to lift its arms embargo against China in light of Beijing's military threat against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN KFC FOOD CONTAINS NO CANCER-CAUSING SUDAN 1 DYE: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Friday that no suspected cancer-causing dye Sudan 1 has been found in ingredients used in Taiwan's Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) restaurants.

According to Hsiao Tong-ming, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, Taiwan management of the U.S. fast food restaurant franchise KFC submitted their documents to the food sanitation bureau for examination Thursday proving that the ingredients used in its restaurants islandwide are safe and free from Sudan 1 dye.

The Bureau of Food Sanitation carried out a surprise inspection of a KFC ingredient preparation factory located on Roosevelt Road, Taipei City, Thursday night and discovered that the company's ingredients, especially red pepper powder, contained no synthetic dye Sudan 1, which has triggered a food scare over the past several days in mainland China.

Sudan 1, a synthetic chemical used in petrol and shoe polish but banned from use in food products because it is suspected of increasing the risk of cancer, was found to have been used in two KFC dishes in China. The chemical was illegally used in food because it is light-resistant and helps retain red pepper powder's fresh color, said Hsiao.

Taiwan KFC Managing Director Olga Wu told media that suppliers of Taiwan KFC and those in China are different and all the food materials and ingredients provided in Taiwan have been monitored strictly to ensure their quality and safety.

Taiwan KFC contacted the media Thursday after KFC China pulled two chicken dishes off its menu across the country Wednesday after discovering that they contained Sudan 1 dye. Sudan 1 dye was found in red pepper powder used as an ingredient in the KFC restaurants' New Orleans wings and drumstick burgers.
Noting that the ingredients used in the KFC restaurants around China are locally-sourced, Wu said that the red pepper powder used in Taiwan's KFC restaurants is imported from Spain.
Besides, Wu reiterated, use of dyes like Sudan 1, 2, 3 and 4 are strictly controlled in Taiwan.
News reports from mainland China Thursday said that a Guangzhou-based factory was supplying Sudan 1 to distributors in nine provinces across China for use in food products.

Sudan 1 triggered a food scare across much of Europe last month. In Britain, for example, hundreds of sauces, soups and ready-made meals have been taken off supermarket shelves since the discovery of the chemical in food products on Feb. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROMISES NO CHANGE TO ROC'S OFFICIAL DESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that he will conform to the Republic of China Constitution and will not change the nation's official designation during his term before the Constitution has been amended.
Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from opposition People First Party lawmakers Cheng Chin-ling and Chung Shao-ho during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

The premier pledged not to alter the nation's official title or push for a new constitution while serving in the post, but he pointed out that the "one China" framework presented in the current Constitution could be amended as long as a national consensus is forged and reactions from the international community and Beijing are weighed across the board.

At a time when Beijing has passed its Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan, the people in Taiwan, regardless of their political affiliations, should unite to counter Beijing's threats and strongly voice their objections to the international community, he said.

Hsieh also said that the government will exercise extreme caution when handling cross-Taiwan Strait relations based on the strong public desire for peace and democracy, which he said are universally recognized values and the largest common ground shared by the people in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE STUDENTS JOIN SIT-IN AGAINST BEIJING LAW

TEXT.P: Lecturers and students from National Taiwan University continued a sit-in Friday to vehemently express their opposition to Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The sit-in began March 15 at noon, one day after China's rubber stamp National People's Congress passed the Anti-Secession Law, in which Beijing gives itself the authority to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island seek formal independence.
NTU students and some lecturers have been taking turns to sit in front of the NTU campus on Roosevelt Road in Taipei, to make known their opposition to the law.
As their sit-in proceeded into its fourth day, more students from National Chengchi University joined the group.

According to Yeh Hung-ling, a graduate student at the NTU Institute of Political Science, the sit-in will go on until March 26 when a nationwide rally is expected to be staged with 1 million people coming out to express strong protest against China's hegemony and belligerence toward Taiwan.
Meanwhile, university students in southern Taiwan are planning for a similar protest slated for March 20 at the Kaohsiung City Cultural Center, to be followed with a street rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ESTIMATES 100,000 WILL TAKE PART IN 319 MARCH

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) estimated Friday that 100,000 people will take part in a march Saturday to mark the first anniversary of the March 19 presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan and New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming, as well as two KMT vice chairmen -- Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou -- will take part in the march, which will start at 1: 30 p.m. at the Sungshan Tobacco Factory and end on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

The activity at Ketagalan Boulevard will start at 3:20 p.m. Wang, Ma as well as lawyer Wang Ching-feng will deliver speeches. Lien will give the last speech and participants will sing "Tomorrow will be a Better Day" before ending the activity at 7 p.m.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen estimated that 100,000 will take part in the rally. The KMT will mobilize supporters living north of Miaoli, estimated at 50,000, while the rest will come voluntarily.
Chen Chieh, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, said that to pursue "truth" for the sake of Taiwan democracy, he believes many KMT members will take part in the march voluntarily.
Chen said that the march was launched by "Democratic Action Alliance, " a group comprised of academic, social movement and cultural figures, and that the KMT identifies with its ideals.
Chen also said that the truth of the shooting is still unanswered, and claimed that this has caused a lot of damage to Taiwan's democracy.
James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), will not take part in the rally.
PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei said that the PFP members can decide for themselves whether they want to take part, but he predicted that many party members will want to attend.

Lien and Soong, who represented the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP in the 2004 presidential election, claimed that the shooting, which slightly injured the president, was staged to win sympathy votes for Chen's second bid for the presidency. Chen won by a little more than 25,000 votes out of more than 13 million cast in the election. Lien and Soong filed two lawsuits against the election and the result of the election, both of which were later rejected by the courts.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Solidarity Union said Friday that the contention revolving around the shooting is a judicial issue and should not be the subject of protest marches.
The TSU urged the KMT to exercise self-restraint and act rationally or face its responsibility in history.

Legislator Lo Chih-ming, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, also said that Ma is the highest official in charge of the social order of the capital city and should not take part in Saturday's march so as to avoid being "a player and a referee at the same time."

DOC.HEADLINE: SKIT PREFORMED TO WARM UP FOR 319 MARCH

TEXT.P: Opposition legislators and a civic group staged a skit in downtown Taipei as a warmup to a protest rally to mark Saturday's first anniversary of the March 19 presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian.

Cheng Li-wen, spokeswoman of the opposition Kuomintang, KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, People First Party (PFP) Legislator Sun Ta-chien and five other people donned white costumes to display the words "there would be peace if there weren't bullets" in a skit performed in front of the Taipei Guest House.

Chang Ya-chung, founder of the 319 Action Committee, claimed that the two bullets fired March 19 last year "smashed values and democracy in Taiwan" and that the public's hopes for the truth had been illegally squeezed and unreasonably suffocated. The 319 Action Committee was formed by the Democratic Action Alliance, a group of academic, social movement and literary figures.

The public can only use the simplest method of taking their protest to the streets, using their shouts to express their demand that the president provide truth so as to free them from being "duped" and so that Taiwan will have "genuine justice and democracy," Chang said.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP claimed that the shooting, which slightly injured President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu, was staged to win sympathy votes for Chen's second bid for the presidency. Chen won by a razor-thin margin against his rival KMT Chairman Lien Chan. The KMT and the PFP filed two lawsuits against the election and the result of the election, both of which were later rejected by the courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.48 points to close at 6,043.95.
The bourse opened at 6,039.23 and fluctuated between 6,054.75 and 6,018.63 during trading. A total of 2.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$56.6 billion (US$1.81 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 0.1 percent and plastics and chemicals shares gaining 1.4 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues and banking and financial shares both at 0.4 percent, textile stocks and construction issues both at 0.3 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 439 to 408, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA OPPOSES BEIJING USE OF FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Costa Rican Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement Thursday calling for maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and urging dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China to resolve disputes peacefully.

As a peace-loving country, Costa Rica opposes any use of force unilaterally adopted by one side against the other, putting cross-strait peace at stake, the statement says, adding that it is the common position of all the world's peace-loving countries regarding the cross-strait situation.

Costa Rica, like all other countries in the world, hopes that Taiwan and China can boost their mutual understanding and communications and conduct negotiations to mend their differences based on the principles of peace, friendship and respect for the people's free will, it says.
Peace and stability in the strait and Southeast Asia must not be undone by either side through non-peaceful means, it stresses.
The National People's Congress, Beijing's ceremonial parliament, passed the Anti-Secession Law March 14 with an aim of fending off Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY TO SPONSOR YACHT VOYAGE TO PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government is sponsoring a yacht voyage crossing the Bashi Channel to the Philippines to offer Taiwan's aboriginal people and Kaohsiung citizens an opportunity to get a better understanding of the ocean and Austronesian culture.

The trip, slated for April 2-8, will be overseen by the city's Commission for Native Taiwanese Affairs, with Liu Ning-sheng, a veteran yachtsman who skippered an 877-day round-the-world voyage that ended in 2001, providing consultations during the trip, said Taibang Lesale, executive director of the commission.

Even though Taiwan is an island country, few people here know much about the culture of the ocean or have the disposition of magnanimity and toleration that the ocean demonstrates, according to Taibang Lesale.

For the April yachting voyage, the 10 participants will embark from the southern port city of Kaohsiung to Batan Island, the northernmost island in the Philippines, to experience an ocean voyage that was taken by the ancestors of Taiwan's aboriginal people hundreds or thousands years ago, Taibang Lesale said.

He added that people in the Batan island group speak almost exactly the same language as that spoken by the aboriginal people of Tao on Taiwan's Orchid Island. The two peoples also look very alike, share the same dietary habits and live in the same kind of dwellings.

The Kaohsiung city government organized a cultural exchange between Orchid Island and Batan in 1998, kicking off exchanges between peoples from the two sides. In 2002, Taiwan and the Philippines signed an agreement to further bolster agricultural, fishing, cultural and leisure exchanges and cooperation between the two countries, Taibang Lesale said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMBERSHIP FEES BECOME ISSUE IN KMT CHAIRMAN ELECTION

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that whether members of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) who have not paid their membership fees will be allowed to take part in the KMT chairman election will be decided by a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting next week.

Wang, who announced his bid to run for the party's top post the previous day, made the remarks as the seemingly trivial issue popped up with he and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou joining the race, since both are considered to be of equal weight politically.
It is generally believed that Wang favors allowing non-paid up members to take part in the vote.

Wang said that whether to allow such members to take part in the party chairman election will be decided in a vote by the KMT Central Standing Committee members if coordination on the matter fail to achieve a result.

Asked about reports citing Wang as saying that even if Ma fails in the KMT chairman election, Ma will still be a potential presidential candidate in 2008, Wang said only that if he is elected KMT chairman, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" will nominate the presidential and vice presidential candidates with the best chance of winning.
Meanwhile, Ma said that the membership fee issue should be viewed from the angle of the party system.
Ma said that while the KMT claims it has 1.09 million members, "everyone knows" that the figure is a far cry from the actual figure.

He said that the party should first do a census to check the exact number and ascertain how many have paid membership fees. It can then assess the membership fee system and the advantages and disadvantages of whether to keep the system before making a "more comprehensive" decision.
He noted that the KMT's Organization and Development Committee is now doing a census of the party members, which is expected to be completed by the end of April.
