DOC.HEADLINE: ALL PARTIES WELCOME AT 326 RALLY AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the March 26 rally organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) against China's Anti-Secession Law will be a non-partisan event.

Hsieh said during a legislative interpellation session that members of all political parties are welcome to join the rally and that participants are free to bring along national flags or their party flags.
Hsieh said the government will encourage people to take part in the rally, even though it is not organizing the event, and that he will announce Sunday or Monday whether he himself will participate.

He said the Anti-Secession Law infringes on the right of the Taiwan people to choose their future and that the rally will stick to the theme of peace and democracy to fight for the best interests of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan said members of a DPP-led "democracy and peace" alliance supporting the rally will visit the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party and Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, as well as Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, to invite them to take part.
Cheng said the alliance is opposed to China's use of non-peaceful means to threaten Taiwan's democracy and cross-Taiwan Strait peace.
While protecting Taiwan is a consensus between the "pan-blue" and "pan-green" camps, the DPP welcomes all parties to take part in the rally, Cheng said.
Cheng called on opposition leaders to put aside political differences and join the DPP in participating in the rally to exhibit the public opinion of Taiwan and jointly protect the island.
Also Friday, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang attended an event held by several Hakka women's groups to promote the rally, which hopes to attract 1 million participants.
According to Su, a large number of people from around the island have signed up for the rally over the past week and the alliance is currently tallying the number of participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST 2007 ASIA-PACIFIC LIFE INSURANCE CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Genting Highlands, Malaysia, March 18 (CNA) (By Lin Huei-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will actively prepare for the next Asia and Pacific Life Insurance Conference in 2007, an official from Taiwan said here Friday.

Tsai Chin-cheng, president of the Insurance and Financial Practitioners Association in Taiwan, made the remarks while taking part in the 8th Asia and Pacific Life Insurance Conference that opened here Friday.
To attract other member countries to take part in the Taiwan conference, his association has set up a pavilion at the present conference to provide information and registration services.

The conference will air a 10-minute film to introduce Taiwan Saturday and there will also be an aboriginal dance performance to promote Taiwan, while a"Taiwan night" dinner party will be held that night.

The Asia and Pacific Life Insurance Conference is held every two years. Around 10,000 members from Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Singapore, India and China are attending the March 18-20 conference in Genting Highlands, Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-GUATEMALA TIES REMAIN STEADFAST: VP LU
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, March 16 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's attempts to lure Guatemala to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing has failed as relations between the Republic of China and Guatemala have remained steadfast, visiting ROC Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday.

Lu, heading a 152-member delegation of government officials and senior business executives, arrived in the Guatemalan capital of Guatemala City in the morning on the second leg of her current Central America diplomatic tour that already took her to El Salvador.

As Lu came on the heels of the departure of a large Chinese trade mission, many journalists asked Lu whether Taiwan's diplomatic relations with Guatemala would be affected by China's lobby with lucrative trade and investment deals.

Despite China's strenuous lobby campaign, Lu said ROC-Guatemalan relations have remained unchanged and steadfast. Lu said Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo is scheduled to visit Taiwan in August to attend the inaugural ceremony of the Democratic Pacific Union.

In an effort to show his staunch support for Taiwan, Lu said, Berger has ordered a Guatemalan commercial and industrial delegation to cancel its planned market inspection visit to China. The group was originally scheduled to visit the mainland next month, Lu said.

As to reports that Guatemala is unhappy with Taiwan's plan to build a special industrial park in El Salvador to attract investment from Taiwan and ethnic Salvadoran entrepreneurs in the United States, Lu said each country has its own unique business environment.
To the best of her understanding, Lu said the Guatemalan government has not been dissatisfied with the "Taiwan park" project in El Salvador.

"With opportunities presenting themselves, El Salvador took the lead in coming up with the 'Taiwan park' project. The ROC government doesn't rule out the possibility of launching similar projects in other countries, including Guatemala, " Lu said, adding that one purpose of her current visit is to explore Guatemala's investment environment.

Since the Democratic Progressive Party administration took power in Taiwan, Lu said, it has consistently attached great importance on cementing relations with the ROC's diplomatic allies. In the future, Lu said the government will continue making every possible effort to boost trade and economic cooperation with Guatemala.

Lu received a red-carpet welcome complete with full military honor upon her arrival at the Guatemala City airport. Guatemalan Vice President Eduardo Stein and many other senior officials as well as ROC Ambassador Ou Hong-lien greeted Lu and her entourage at the airport.

Shortly afterwards, Lu paid a visit to the Guatemalan parliament where she was granted the highest-level courteous treatment. Jorge Mendez Herbruger, speaker of the Guatemalan parliament, decorated Lu with a medal in recognition of her contribution to boosting bilateral ties.
Lu then delivered a speech to Guatemalan lawmakers, urging them to pass a resolution to protest China's enactment of its so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

"I admire your country's courage in aligning with the ROC based on its conviction of peace, humanity and justice. We are grateful that Guatemala has not been daunted by China's threat and has consistently support Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations," Lu said.
Noting that Beijing's anti-secession law legalizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan, Lu said the international community should condemn such a provocative act.

"As Taiwan is facing mounting threat from China, we need your support. I hope the Guatemalan parliament can take a concrete action to support our cause by passing a resolution condemning China's ill-intentioned legislation," Lu said.
In the evening, Lu hosted a dinner in honor of her counterparts from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua.

Lu is scheduled to hold an informal leadership meeting with Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma de Escobar, Guatemalan Vice President Eduardo Stein, Honduran Vice President Armida de Lopez and Nicaraguan Vice President Jose Rizo Friday.

The informal summit meeting will take place at the sidelines of a regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America. Representatives from six Central American allies and five non-allied countries in North, Central and South America will attend the meeting, which will be a warm-up to a DPU regional organization to be established in Taipei Aug. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, ROC TOP CHOICES FOR U.N. NAME

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the Republic of China are "top priority choices" for the name under which Taiwan should bid for its re-entry into the United Nations, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

Hsieh made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan when Legislator Huang Hsih-cho of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union asked if it is possible for the government to make its bid under the name of "Taiwan" after past bids under the name of the "Republic of China" have failed for 12 consecutive years.

The premier said that both "Taiwan" and the "ROC" are top priority choices, adding that the name does not necessarily have to conform with the official name. As long as it "benefits the Taiwan people, " the name of "Taiwan" can be used to join international organizations, while other names are equally acceptable if difficulties are encountered.
"Active participation in international organizations is the goal," he pointed out.

Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen also said it will be very difficult for the government to promote a return to the U.N. under the name of the Republic of China and said it is mulling a new mindset to promote the bid, although the name issue is yet to be finalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST SUGGESTS CONTINUED CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES TO THAW TIES

TEXT.P: The government should keep a cool head in gauging the complications of Beijing's Anti-Secession Law and should continue trade and economic exchanges to thaw ties between Taiwan and mainland China, a leading domestic economist said Friday.

Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research President Vincent Siew made the call in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency. Siew, a seasoned technocrat, served as premier in the previous Kuomintang-led government from 1998 to 2000.

Siew agreed that the government should lodge a strong protest against Beijing's Anti-Secession law targeting Taiwan, but advised it to maintain sound economic and trade exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Siew said that cross-strait economic activities might be affected in the short term by the Anti-Secession Law, but urged the government to adopt an opening policy to allow for continued interaction between the two sides to offset the law's impact on Taiwan.

Citing government statistics to buttress his argument that market forces always prevail over government rules, he said that Taiwan's trade reliance on the China market has surged to a historic high of more then 25 percent at present despite various attempts by the government to stem bilateral exchanges in the past.

In view of the situation, he said, the ratio will keep on growing amid close and frequent two-way exchanges, and he urged the government to be aware of the fact that policies that go against market trends are doomed.

As the government still needs to resolve various thorny issues, such as permitting Taiwan hi-tech investment in China and setting up direct transport links, he proposed that the government follow market trends as means of improving the fragile cross-strait relations.

Increased economic interaction should be helpful in improving bilateral relations, he said, admitting that political dialogue between Taiwan and China is still far off due to a lack of mutual trust and understanding. Economic dialogue should be a remedy to this situation, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTING OF CHINA-BOUND TRAVELERS REQUIRED BY LAW: MAC

TEXT.P: Airline companies and travel agencies are required by law to report China-bound travelers to the immigration authorities, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.
Chiu noted that the requirement is included in the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area during an amendment in 2003.

According to Chiu, keeping China-bound travelers on file is necessary in light of the continuing outbreaks of infectious diseases such as severe acute respiratory syndrome, avian flu and cerebrospinal meningitis in China.
In addition, the government needs to get an accurate account of the number of people traveling to China for reference in its policy-making process, Chiu said.

Chiu made the remarks in the wake of a local media report that the Immigration Office under the National Police Agency has recently asked airline companies and travel agencies to provide the names, passport numbers and birthdates of China-bound travelers on a daily basis.
According to the report, the airline companies and travel agencies are unhappy with the measure and have criticized it as one that invaded the privacy of travelers.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. LIFTS ANTI-DUMPING TAX ON TAIWAN POLYESTER STAPLE FIBERS

TEXT.P: The European Union has announced the lifting of an anti-dumping tax on polyester staple fibers from Taiwan starting March 18, Bureau of Foreign Trade officials said Friday.
The E.U. decided to lift the tax, which was imposed Dec. 16, 1988, after the dumping margin of Taiwanese exporters dropped below 2 percent, the officials said.
According to official statistics, Taiwan exported polyester staple fiber products worth US$90 million to E.U. nations in 2004, accounting for 0.38 percent of Taiwan's total exports.
The officials said the lifting of the anti-dumping tax will help enhance the competitiveness of Taiwan's polyester staple fiber products in the E.U. market.

While sparing Taiwan, the E.U. has decided to continue to impose anti-dumping taxes of between 5.7 percent and 10.6 percent on polyester staple fibers from South Korea, between 4.9 percent and 49.7 percent on those from China and 20.9 percent on those from Saudi Arabia, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Sizable Cut in U.S. Forces in Iraq Called Possible in '06.
An Army general said that the number of American troops in Iraq would probably drop to around 105,000 from 150,000.
Wall Street Journal: Oil Companies Reap Cash Windfall From Price Surge.
The surge in oil prices over the past year is generating an immense cascade of cash that is flooding the coffers of oil companies, raising pressure on their bosses to pursue acquisitions, further boost spending on production or give more of the gains to shareholders.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Chubais Survives Roadside Ambush.
A view of the armored BMW sedan that Chubais was riding in Thursday. A bomb was detonated near the car, and assailants opened fire with automatic rifles. Anatoly Chubais survived a roadside ambush Thursday when a bomb went off near a black armored BMW carrying him to work and attackers opened fire with automatic weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP TO MEET CENTRAL AMERICAN COUNTERPARTS FOR LEADERSHIP SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, March 17 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu is scheduled to meet her counterparts from four Central American countries Friday for an informal leadership summit on Pacific Rim regional cooperation.

Lu, who is currently on a three-day official visit to Guatemala at the head of a 152-member Taiwan delegation, is scheduled to meet with El Salvador Vice President Ana Vilma de Escobar, Guatemalan Vice President Eduardo Stein, Honduran Vice President Armida de Lopez and Nicaraguan Vice President Jose Rizo at the summit.
Guatemalan President Oscar Berger will deliver a keynote speech at the meeting, according to Lu.

The summit will take place on the sidelines of a regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America in Guatemala. Representatives from six Central American allies and five non-allied countries in North, Central and South America will attend the meeting, which will be a warm-up to the DPU inauguration slated for Aug. 14 in Taipei.

Representatives of the organization's more than 20 founding member nations, including vice presidents of countries that maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan and senior parliamentarians and lawmakers from countries that are friendly toward Taiwan, are expected to attend the inaugural ceremony, Lu said.

Lu and her 152-member entourage arrived in the El Salvador capital of San Salvador March 14 for an official visit aimed at cementing diplomatic relations with the Central American ally and boosting bilateral trade and economic exchanges.

During a dinner with Taiwan expatriates there, Lu said she is hopeful that Taiwan businessmen at home and in El Salvador can join forces to build an industrial park in El Salvador to accommodate Taiwan-funded firms, facilitating bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

"The planned park should meet what she called the 'Three P' goals, namely, the park should be productive, environmentally protective and have perspective, " Lu said, adding that the park is expected to begin operation before the end of President Chen Shui-bian's presidential term in May 2008.
During her visit to El Salvador, Lu met with Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca and Vice President De Escobar. She also delivered aspeech at the parliament.
Speaking to the press Thursday, Lu said that the primary goal of her visit to El Salvador and Guatemala is to pave the way for Taiwan business and industrial sectors for their global expansion.

Taiwan investors can find their investment niches in Central America not necessarily from high-technology industries, Lu said, adding that they can help the Latin American countries develop high value-added textiles and garments using Taiwan's nanotechnology and they can also help them produce Taiwanese-style foods and delicacies for export to the United States.
Lu has met with Berger and will also deliver a speech at the Guatemalan parliament before wrapping up her 12-day tour which will also include a transit stay in Miami.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER FORMS PREPARATORY GROUP FOR ASIAN FESTIVAL IN AMERICA

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party Lawmaker Lin Cheng-erh formed a preparatory group Friday for Taiwan's participation in an Asian festival that will take place in Los Angeles and San Francisco in May.

Lin, who is a lawmaker for Taiwan's aborigines, said the United States set May aside as Asian Month in America in 1998. Many U.S. cities such as Los Angeles and San Francisco have since celebrated in May Asian cultural traditions, promoted the understanding of Asia and Asian communities in America, and established a strong bond between the Asian and non-Asian communities.

Taiwan has been allowed to send a team of performers to the festival since 1998, and was absent from the activities only in 2003 because of the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, Lin said.

As the United Nations is going to celebrate its 60th anniversary this year, Lin said, the organizers of the Asian Festival are adopting the U.N. anniversary as the theme of this year's festival, and more spectators are expected to be attracted, making it a good opportunity for Taiwan to enhance its international profile by sending a large team, Lin said.
Several aboriginal and folk dancing troupes have signed up to join the Taiwan team this year, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIA CHIEF SEES POTENTIAL FOR CHINESE ATTACK AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Washington believes that Beijing is prepared to respond with various levels of force if it decides that Taiwan is taking steps toward permanent separation that exceed its tolerance, Central Intelligence Agency chief Porter Goss said Thursday.

At a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Goss said that on March 14 Beijing enacted an Anti-Secession Law which Taipei characterizes as a "war-authorizing law." Taipei's National Assembly will vote this summer on constitutional reforms that Beijing has said it considers to be part of a timeline for independence.

Goss also said that Washington should be concerned that Beijing's military modernization and buildup pose new questions for the U.S. and that these improved capabilities could well threaten U.S. forces in the region.

He noted that in 2004, Beijing increased its ballistic missile forces deployed across from Taiwan and christened several new submarines. Also, it continues to develop more robust and harder-to-intercept nuclear-tipped missiles as well as conventional weaponry for use in a regional conflict.
This is tilting the balance of power in the Taiwan Strait, and threatens U.S. forces in the region, Goss said.

Along with this military buildup, Goss went on, Beijing is increasingly confident and active on the international stage, trying to ensure that it has a voice on major international issues and secure access to natural resources. China also hopes to counter what it sees as U. S. efforts to contain it.

However, Goss said, Beijing's new leadership under President Hu Jintao will face many challenges in 2005, such as the potential for a resurgence in inflation, increased dependence on exports, growing economic inequalities, increased awareness of individual rights, and popular expectations for the new leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG INTERNATIONAL DIRECTOR AWARD ADDED TO 2005 TAIPEI FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: An award for best young international director will be added to the competition category of the 2005 Taipei Film Festival, which will be held June 25 to July 9.

Liao Hsien-hao, director of the Cultural Affairs Bureau of the Taipei City Government, Taiwan Film Culture Association Executive Director Huang Wen-ying, as well as the top coordinator of the film festival, Huang Chien-yeh, made the announcement Friday.

The cash awards of the film festival total NT$3.35 million (US$108,060) . The new talent competition award will be worth NT$650,000. Thirty-five films from 15 countries have so far entered for this award with the final total expected to reach 60 by the April 10 deadline.

South Korean Director Daniel H. Byun will submit his 2004 work "The Scarlet Letter." Lee Eun-Joo, an actress also popular in Taiwan and who played a gloomy mistress in the film recently committed suicide at the age of 25.
Qualified entrants in this category will be judged on their first two films.

In addition to the young international director's category, the film festival will continue to highlight different cities through cinema as it has done for the past three years. This year, the focus will be on two Russian cities -- Moscow and St. Petersburg.

DOC.HEADLINE: USE WTO FRAMEWORK FOR CROSS-STRAIT PRODUCE TRADE: TAINAN MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: In light of Beijing's proposal to allow agricultural imports from Taiwan, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-dji suggested Friday that a framework under the World Trade Organization (WTO) be used to conduct two-way negotiations.

Su said that he backs the idea of applying WTO rules to regulate agricultural exports between the two sides. The magistrate of the southern Taiwan county also advocated that Taiwan impose strict quarantine measures on products from China out of serious concerns over food safety of Chinese goods.

Su made the remarks at a news conference after returning to Taiwan a day earlier from a trip to France, where he sought to seek Taiwan's sponsorship for a world orchid exhibition slated for 2011. Singapore won the sponsorship.

A recent offer by Beijing to open its markets to Taiwan's agricultural imports has worried local farmers, predominantly those in southern counties that rely heavily on agriculture, that the mainland side may demand that Taiwan open its markets in return.
Pingtung County officials warned a few days ago of an influx of Chinese farm products into the domestic market and called attention to possible subsequent complications.

They urged the central government to study the issue comprehensively, particularly at a time when many Taiwan farmers and fruit growers have relocated to China and are shipping their produce back to Taiwan.

Taiwan's Council of Agriculture has come under pressure to accept shipments by those people, they said, pointing out that domestic goods will be further harmed should more mainland produce be allowed to enter the Taiwan market.

Mainland Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao said on March 14 following Beijing's adoption of the Anti-Secession Law that China is willing to open its markets to Taiwan's farm produce, in particular those from southern Taiwan, in an apparent effort to mitigate the law's perceived damage to cross-strait relations.
Beijing has repeatedly said that the law was enacted to prevent Taiwan independence and is not aimed at the people on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN TENDERS RESIGNATION TO PREPARE FOR MAGISTRATE RACE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh confirmed Friday that Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san has offered to resign to seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) nomination to run in the year-end magistrate election in the central county of Taichung.

Hsieh made the confirmation while fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition People First Party Legislator Cheng Chin-ling asked the premier about Cabinet personnel issues.
Hsieh said Chiu tendered his resignation earlier in the day because of his determination to vie for the DPP candidacy to run in the year-end Taichung County magistrate race.
Later in the day, Chiu said he will formally announce his candidacy next Monday.
Asked whether You Ying-lung, vice president of the Ketagalan Institute, will fill the vacancy, Chiu said he was not in a position to answer.
"It must be decided by President Chen Shui-bian, the premier and MAC Chairman Joseph Wu, " said Chiu, who once served as a prosecutor and a legislator.
The Ketagalan Institute is an independent, non-partisan educational institution founded by President Chen in March 2003 to promote civic values through education, policy research and public forums.
You is an academic-turned-politician who once served as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ATTENDS ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK MEETING IN MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, March 18 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation attended an Asian Development Bank (ADB) meeting Friday held in the Philippine capital to assess the progress in rehabilitating Asian countries affected by last year's tsunami disaster.
Wu Hsin-hsing, the Republic of China's representative to the Philippines, said Taiwan, as a member of the international community, will do its part to help with rehabilitation work.
Wu pointed out that the ROC government dispatched medical and rescue teams to the disaster areas and donated US$50 million in relief funds immediately after the disaster occurred on Dec. 26, 2004.
Taiwan's private sector also contributed US$100 million and 355 tons of medical and relief supplies, Wu added.
The meeting was attended by 200 representatives from 28 countries and 10 international organizations.
According to data provided by the ADB, rehabilitation in hard-hit India, Indonesia, the Maldives and Sri Lanka will cost a total of US$7.764 billion, with US$5.25 billion yet to be raised.
The ADB has set up a US$600 million trust fund for aid to tsunami-hit Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ECONOMICS MINISTER TO BE NEW ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO WTO

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu will succeed Yen Ching-chang as the Republic of China's representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO), Cabinet sources said Friday.
Yen will retire from public service after stepping down from the WTO post, the sources said.

Lin, 63, joined public service after graduating from National Chengchi University's statistics and accounting department. Between 1972 and 1990, he worked at various ROC overseas trade offices, including those in Australia, the Philippines, Thailand and Canada.
Lin was not retained as economic affairs minister when the Cabinet was reshuffled Feb. 1. At that time, Premier Frank Hsieh said he would be given other assignment.
Meanwhile, Cabinet sources said You Ying-lung, vice president of the Ketagalan Institute, will succeed Chiu Tai-san as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Chiu tendered his resignation earlier in the day to prepare to run as a candidate for Taichung magistrate.

You, 49, an academic-turned-politician, had been deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission before becoming Ketagalan Institute vice president.

The Ketagalan Institute is an independent, non-partisan educational institution founded by President Chen Shui-bian in March 2003 to promote civic values through education, policy research and public forums.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO KEEP HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM AFLOAT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday the government will do its utmost to bolster the cash-strapped national health insurance program.

Chen made the pledge while addressing the opening of an international seminar on health insurance issues, which was organized by the Cabinet-level Department of Health to mark the 10th anniversary of the country's universal health insurance program.

Praising the national health insurance program as "Taiwan's national treasure," Chen said that over the past decade, the program has benefited local people, particularly those with serious diseases, chronic ailments or critical injuries.

Noting that sustainable development of the health insurance program is the government's promise to local people, Chen said his administration will spare no effort to prevent the system from going bankrupt.

Chen said the Cabinet is working on a package of measures, including raising the ceiling on the index insurance premium and increasing taxes on cigarettes and liquors, to improve the program's financial status.
"With confidence, creativity and strenuous efforts, I'm confident that we'll succeed in keeping our health insurance program afloat, " Chen said.
Scores of health insurance experts from the United States, Britain, Japan, South Korea and several other countries are attending the seminar in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INVESTMENT IN CHINA DROPPED IN JAN.-FEB. FROM 2004

TEXT.P: Fewer investments in China were approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in the first two months of this year than the same period last year, according to statistics prepared by the MOEA's Investment Commission.

There were 159 approved mainland Chinese investment projects in January and February with a combined capital of US$692 million, a 60.84 percent drop in the number of projects and a 11.53 percent decrease in capital over the same period of last year.
The tallies showed that there were 67 approved investments in February, with a combined capital of US$196.9 million.
Most of the investments during the two-month period went to Jiangsu province, accounting for 54.76 percent, followed by Guangdong province at 24.55 percent, and Zhejiang province at 6.53 percent.

By industry, electronics and electrical appliance manufacturing made up the lion's share of 42.45 percent, followed by chemical manufacturing at 8.97 percent, precision equipment manufacturing at 7.43 percent, basic metal manufacturing at 6.98 percent, and non-metal manufacturing at 6.14 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BE ASIA'S DESIGN CENTER IN 10 YEARS: DANISH DESIGNER

TEXT.P: Prestigious Danish designer Frederick Rickmann said Friday that he expects Taiwan will become Asia's design center by 2015 because of the continued advancement of investments and education in the field of design.

The chief executive and design director of Denmark's forefront design company, Designnord, made the comment while calling at Johnsee Lee, president of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).
Rickmann is visiting the island at the invitation of the ITRI to lecture at a three-day ITRI seminar titled "Methods for Innovated Design with Modern Thoughts," which will begin March 24.
The experienced and well-traveled designer said he thinks China's design capability and product innovation is weak, while Singapore and Hong Kong are good at trading, not designing.

South Korea was seen as having significant improvement in industrial design, especially in the manufacture of vehicles, mobile phones and 3C products -- consumer electronics products, computers and communications, Rickmann said, adding he found that in Taiwan, more and more money is being spent on investments and education in design.

Lee noted that he feels that non-technical, cultural abilities will play an increasingly important role in the nation's development. Because of this, more and more people skilled in the arts and culture are working at the ITRI now than in the past, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CHIN-YUNG TO TAKE OVER AS ACTING YUNLIN COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday he has decided to name Lee Chin-yung, vice chairman of the Public Construction Commission (PCC), as acting Yunlin County magistrate.
"I already informed Lee of his new assignment, " Hsieh told reporters after attending a Legislative Yuan interpellation session.

Lee, a lawyer-turned-politician, once served as mayor of the northern port city of Keelung. Lee was quoted as having said that he has keen interest in serving as acting Yunlin county chief because he is familiar with local government affairs.
Before assuming the PCC post in February, Lee had been vice minister of the interior. He also once served as deputy secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Lee, a Yunlin County native, is scheduled to assume his new post Monday.
Lee will take over as acting Yunlin County magistrate following the conviction of the incumbent county chief Cahng Jung-wei's conviction in an election bribery case.

The Supreme Court handed down its ruling for former county chief Chang Jung-wei earlier this month, sentencing him to 12 months in jail for his involvement in the 1994 Yunlin County Council speakership election bribery case.

According to current regulations, the Ministry of the Interior must relieve a local government chief of his or her duties if he or she is handed a prison sentence that cannot be suspended or commuted into a fine.

As there are less than two years remaining in Chang's term, no by-election has to be held to elect a successor. Instead, the Cabinet is authorized by law to name a replacement to serve out the remainder of the term.

In fact, Chang has already been suspended and detained since last December for his alleged involvement in the corruption scandal. His deputy is now acting as Yunlin county magistrate. However, the law requires Chang's deputy, a political appointee, to be relieved of his duties along with Chang.
