15: 30, A "March 19 manifesto" organized by the opposition Kuomintang will be held at Ketagalan Avenue, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS KMT TO CALL OFF PROTEST ON ANNIVERSARY OF 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday to call off its planned protest on Saturday, noting that the administration is sympathetic toward their desire to know all the facts surrounding the assassination attempt of President Chen Shui-bian on March 19 last year and is working hard to provide answers.

In an apparently futile effort to dissuade the KMT from leading their supporters to protest what they consider the government's foot-dragging in investigating the case, the premier told the Legislative Yuan that law enforcement is doing everything humanly possible to get to the bottom of the shooting.
"It is not necessary to push them to accelerate their investigation by holding a public protest," Hsieh said.

In an attempt to preempt the protest, a group of law enforcement officials investigating the shooting disclosed on March 7 what they called a major breakthrough in the case, identifying a man who drown last March 28 as the suspected shooter.
The investigators said the man committed suicide after the shooting and that his body has been cremated.

Instead of dissipating critics' suspicions that the shooting was staged to help President Chen win re-election, the investigators' new findings have prompted more questions because no hard evidence has been found to corroborate investigators' claims.

At the Legislative Yuan Friday, the premier stopped short of affirming that the investigators had found the correct suspect, saying only that he personally believed the deceased man in question was involved in the shooting, but being aware that questions still linger, has asked investigators to continue their probe until the whole truth is uncovered.
In order to bring public pressure to bear on the government, the KMT is calling on its supporters to take to the street in Taipei Saturday, one year to the day after the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO DO UTMOST TO DEFEND TAIWAN'S INTERESTS IN WTO

TEXT.P: The government will do its utmost to defend Taiwan's interests in the World Trade Organization (WTO) , including protecting its official designation, officials of the Executive Yuan said Friday.

Commenting on reports that the WTO Secretariat is to change the designation of Taiwan's representative office in the organization's correspondence directory to be issued in April under strong pressure from China, the officials said that similar speculations have been circulating for a long time.
The Executive Yuan has instructed Taiwan's representative office and diplomatic agency to keep a close watch on the issue and do their utmost to defend the nation's interest.
It would be an important matter if the representative office's designation were changed, they added.
According to Taiwan's terms of WTO admission, its representative office at the WTO is the "Permanent Mission of the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES MILLIONS TO PROTEST AGAINST BEIJING ON MARCH 26

TEXT.P: In order to show Taiwan's resentment toward Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, President Chen Shui-bian urged Taiwan people to respond to a call by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and join the protest march in force on March 26.

While receiving members of the Executive Committee of the Council of Asian Liberals and Democrats (CALD), the president said Beijing is trying to alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait by enacting the Anti-Secession Law, which permits it to attack Taiwan under certain circumstances.

"China's attempts to solve the Taiwan issue through non-peaceful means runs counter to the international trend of solving disputes through dialogue and would never be accepted by the international community," the president told his visitors.

"Taiwan's future should be determined by the great 23 million people of Taiwan, rather than the 2,000-odd members of China's National People's Congress, which enacted this Anti-Secession Law, " Chen said.

The people on this island will show the world their common aspirations for democracy and peace, and their collective resentment towards hegemony and violence in the March 26 protest, the president said.
The CALD Executive Committee will meet Saturday and Sunday in Taipei.
Founded in 1993, the CALD consists of Asian political parties that believe in democracy and freedom.
The CALD Executive Committee is expected to pass a resolution in its meeting condemning China for enacting the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY APPRECIATE US SENATE'S RESOLUTION IN TAIWAN'S FAVOR

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Friday that it appreciates a U.S. Senate resolution on Thursday urging the European Union to leave in place its arms embargo against China.

The ministry said in a statement that this resolution, coupled with one from Congress the previous day which aired the House of Representatives' concerns about China's Anti-Secession Law, has shown the importance the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives has attached to peace across the Taiwan Strait, saying: "We appreciate it very much."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, March 19, or the 10th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
721 B.C.: The Babylonians make the first-ever record of an eclipse of the sun.
1711: War breaks out between Turkey and Russia.
1813: David Livingstone, the Scottish missionary and African explorer who discovered the Zambezi River and Victoria Falls, is born.
1834: Six farm workers from southern England are sentenced to seven years' banishment to a penal colony in Australia for trying to set up a rural trade union. The convicts are called the Tolpuddle Martyrs after the name of their Dorset village.
1853: During the Taiping Rebellion in China, Taiping troops led by their leader, Hung Hsiu-chuan, capture Nanking.
1858: Kang Yu-wei, the Chinese thinker who, together with Liang Chi-chao, in 1898 initiated a reform movement that came to an inglorious end after only 100 days and who later formed the China Reform Association in exile in Canada, is born.
1920: The U.S. Senate votes against the United States joining the League of Nations.
1929: Rabindranath Tagore -- the Indian poet who won the 1913 Nobel Prize in literature and who was known especially for his poetry collection "Gitanjali," which is based on traditional Hindu themes -- arrives in Shanghai for a visit.
1930: Arthur Balfour, the British prime minister who promised British support for a national homeland for Jews in Palestine provided that the rights of existing communities would be safeguarded, dies at the age of 82.
1932: The Sydney Harbor Bridge, the world's longest single-span arched bridge, is opened in New South Wales, Australia. The bridge has a 503-meter span, four rail tracks, a 17-meter wide road and two footpaths.
1933: Benito Mussolini, Italian dictator, proposes a pact with Britain, France and Germany.
1944: German troops cross the border into Hungary during World War II.
1947: Republic of China government troops capture Yenan.
1950: Edgar Rice Burroughs, the American novelist who created "Tarzan of the Apes" and sold more than 100 million copies of his 70 novels in 56 languages, dies at the age of 75.
1960: The third session of the first National Assembly decides to set up a committee to study the exercise of initiatives and referendums by the National Assembly.
1964: The Great St. Bernard Tunnel under the Alps between Italy and Switzerland is formally opened to traffic.
1987: American TV evangelist Jim Bakker is forced to resign from his "Praise the Lord" religious network in the southern United States after confessing to a string of sexual adventures. In addition, Bakker is placed under investigation for allegedly having pocketed church funds donated by supporters.
1996: A discotheque fire kills more than 150 and injures 105 others in Manila in one of the worst fire-related disasters ever in the Philippines.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou says that he is willing to push for the formation of a ticket between Vice President Lien Chan and former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong in Taiwan's 2000 presidential race.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton congratulates Chen Shui-bian on his victory in the Republic of China's presidential election and promises to maintain close unofficial ties with Taiwan under the "one-China" policy, while again urging Taipei and Beijing to resolve their differences peacefully through dialogue.
2000: Thousands of furious protesters, including members of the Kuomintang, whose candidate lost in the previous day's presidential election, surround the KMT headquarters to demand that President Lee Teng-hui step down from his post as party chairman.
2001: ROC President Chen Shui-bian reaffirms his commitment to adopting a new "middle-of-the-road" policy in dealing with relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2003: The U.S.-led military offensive aimed at ousting the regime of Saddam Hussein in Iraq got underway. The first strike occurred after dark, when about 40 Tomahawk cruise missiles descended on targets in Baghdad.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who studies extensively the arts and literature, and directs his studies with judgment and taste, is not likely to get into a wrong track."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times: Gambling Website ran by Pingtung councillor cracked down by police.
The United Daily News: Four security dealers forced to refund investors NT$781 million for unwittingly selling them shares of a shell company.
The Liberty Times: Changhua County Goverment ordered to pay tens of million dollars in damage to a local fish farmer.
The Taiwan Daily: US Senate urges EU to leave in place arms embargo against China.
The Central Daily News: 319 Protest to be staged to press government to probe shooting of President Chen.
The China Post: 100,000 expected for 'pan-blue' rally marking shooting.
The Taiwan News: Chen pledges to preserve NHI system.
The Taipei Times: Two involved in sand sales probe.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: No indiscriminate raids -- Lomibao
Director General Arturo C. Lomibao, chief of the Philippine National Police (PNP) , yesterday assured leaders of Muslim communities in the country, particularly those in Metro Manila, that there will be no indiscriminate raids against Muslim residents as a result of the police assault operations following a foiled escape attempt of Abu Sayyaf suspects in a jail in Taguig City.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Holy Week plot real -- PNP CHIEF Supt. Ismael Rafanan, head of the Philippine National Police's Intelligence Group, said Abu Sayyaf leader Abu Solaiman "reiterated" his call to his followers to immediately bomb key cities, particularly in Metro Manila, after the killing of three of the group's top leaders at Camp Bagong Diwa on Tuesday.
The Philippine Star: RP needs'shame campaign'to fight corruption -- expert
All the Philippines needs is an unrelenting "shame campaign" to stamp out corruption in the bureaucracy, the former head of Hong Kong 's Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) has suggested.
The Manila Times: Al-Qaeda trainer nabbed at airport
A suspected member of Osama bin Laden's militant al-Qaeda network has been arrested as he arrived at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport Wednesday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Malaysia to hire 100,000 Pakistani workers.
Malaysia plans to recruit 100,000 Pakistani workers to relieve a severe labour shortage that is threatening to damage its economy.
The move follows a crackdown on illegal labour that has purged more than 400,000 mostly Indonesian illegal immigrants from the country since the beginning of this month.
Many construction sites, factories, plantations and even restaurants have virtually shut down since the end of an amnesty period nearly three weeks ago when illegal immigrants were sent home.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Temasek Holdings has been invited to participate in the reform of Chinese state-owned enterprises.
Chinese State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council (SASAC) invited Singapore Temasek Holdings to paticipate in the reform of Chinese state-owned enterpises, including the board establishment and attracting the talented person.
The work group will be established in Beijing recently.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Military Recruitment Affected by Iraq War.
Reenlistment rates remain high, but military recruiters find it increasingly hard to meet goals for new soldiers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY SENDS IMPORTANT MESSAGE: U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Friday that Taiwan's democratic development is an important message indicating that traditional or political culture should not hamper further political openness in China.

"It's yet further evidence that the notion that was in fashion somehow back in the 1980s and early 90s that democracy was not an 'Asian value' is simply crumbling across the entire region, " Rice said.
"And in this regard, the further development of an open Chinese political system clearly should not be a matter of traditional or political culture as people sometimes want to make it," she added.

Rice made the remarks during a flight to Tokyo when asked by reporters what message she will give Beijing about Taiwan. Rice is scheduled to arrive in Beijing on Sunday as one of her stops on her on-going Asian tour.

Rice said Washington's message to both China and Taiwan is that the United States maintains a one China policy and does not expect either side to try to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo unilaterally.
She noted that neither China nor Taiwan will be able to resolve the cross-strait problem unilaterally.
"What we've been encouraging instead is that they engage each other on ways to reduce cross-strait tensions, not engage in unilateral actions that actually add to cross-strait tensions, " Rice said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Players Balk on Steroid Use.
Putting the integrity of the national pastime under a harsh spotlight, a House committee questioned a panel of superstars about steroids in baseball, eliciting sharp denials from several--and in the case of retired home run legend Mark McGwire, an emotion-choked acknowledgment of baseball's doping problem followed by repeated refusal to answer questions about his own possible involvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR ROC ALLIES URGE PEACEFUL MEANS TO RESOLVE CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, March 18 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Vice President met with her counterparts from four Central American countries Friday during which they expressed their staunch support for the ROC and urged that cross-Taiwan Strait differences be solved by peaceful means.

Lu, who is currently on a three-day official visit to Guatemala at the head of a 152-member Taiwan delegation, attended the regional meeting of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in America, which was held Friday.

Representatives from 11 countries in the region, including Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma de Escobar, Guatemalan Vice President Eduardo Stein, Honduran Vice President Armida de Lopez and Nicaraguan Vice President Jose Rizo, attended the meeting.
The five vice presidents held an informal roundtable meeting after the opening ceremony.

Stein pointed out that the charter of the Organization of the Central American States stipulates that all governments are committed to solving disputes by peaceful means. Guatemala supports the ROC government and people and the notion that all cross-strait disputes be solved through peaceful means, he said.

He noted that Central America suffered from civil wars for many years and has paid a hefty price for this, adding that these wars "did not solve any problems, and have only brought more misery to the people."
Rizo also said that Central America has long been a staunch ally of Taiwan and that his country supports Taiwan's bid to join international organizations.

Meanwhile, Escobar said that the DPU aims to cement democracy, adding that before a country can cement its democracy, it must develop its economy. She said she is appreciative of Taiwan for stepping up trade exchanges with all countries in the region so that Central America can develop its economy with the help of Taiwan's experience.
Lopez invited Lu to attend a forum for vice presidents of Central American countries.

She said that the agricultural and traditional sectors of many countries in central America have suffered the greatest impact of the globalization trend, adding that she hopes that they can learn from Taiwan in this respect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST SPEAK OUT AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan must bravely voice their opposition to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law in order to protect their freedom, former President Lee Teng-hui said Saturday.

Speaking at an international academic seminar held at National Taiwan Normal University, Lee said that the Taiwan people will never accept the law and that they should stand up against it and make their voice heard in the international community.

Lee also appealed for greater global backing for Taiwan's fight against Beijing's hegemonic designs and urged the Taiwan people to go on striving for the country's course based on a Taiwan identity and a Taiwan-centric concept.

As citizens of a democratic nation, the people of Taiwan must be cognizant of the fact that democracy does not only mean voting, Lee said, adding that in the face of Beijing's obvious scheme to swallow Taiwan up, the people of the island must unite regardless of their ethnicity or region of residence.

He praised the recent steps toward reconciliation made by the ruling and opposition camps for the sake of Taiwan's future, but he also added that the Taiwan identity must be an indispensable prerequisite among the parties of different political stances in their efforts to build a consensus in order to serve the people of the nation.
The National People's Congress, Beijing's ceremonial parliament, passed the Anti-Secession Law on March 14 with an aim of stemming Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SUPPORTS REGISTRATION REQUIREMENT FOR CHINA-BOUND TRAVELERS

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) weighed in the dispute between the government and air carriers and travel agencies by urging the latter to abide by the government's regulation and provide to the Immigration Office under the Ministry of the Interior lists of their mainland-bound travelers.

Legislator William Lai, secretary of the DPP caucus, said the registration is intended to keep the government informed of local people's mainland trips and enable it to help Taiwan visitors when they are involved in accidents on the mainland.
This information is also important for the government to formulate appropriate policy toward mainland China, Lai claimed.

Noting that the registration is required under a law revised in 2004, Lai denied that the measure is part of a government plan to curtail exchanges with the mainland in the wake of Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

Lai said that air carriers, which always keep lists of their passengers, could easily transfer this information to the Immigration Office through their computers at little cost. He disputed the tour industry's claim that this would violate travelers' privacy rights, arguing that it is permitted by law.
Even the current law governing electronic data allows the government to gather personal information when needed, Lai said.

In addition to confirming his caucus' support for the government's measures, Lai urged the Mainland Affairs Council to help the tour industry comply with the rules by providing them with a computer program to allow the easy transfer of the travelers' lists to the Immigration Office.

The dispute arose at the beginning of February when the Immigration Office asked local travel agencies and air carriers to provide them with lists on a daily basis of their travelers bound for the mainland.
The office cited as the legal basis for the requirement an article which had not been used before in the statute governing the relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China.

The new requirement has caused an uproar among those in the tour industry. They have questioned the legality, as well as the necessity of the requirement, not to mention the extra cost it will bring to them.

Hsu Kao-ching, president of the Republic of China Association of Travel Agents, said Friday that the travel agencies are entrusted by their customers to arrange their mainland tours and are not supposed to give out their customers' personal information.

If the government wants to have the mainland-bound travelers registered, the Immigration Office can oblige these travelers to sign their names at the airport when they leave or arrive in the country, Hsu argued.

Furthermore, Hsu said, not every travel agency has computers which are programmed to transfer their information to the Immigration Office. These agencies will therefore have difficulty complying with the requirement, he added.

For all the trouble it causes, Hsu said, the new regulation doesn't achieve the government's goal of keeping track of the exact number of Taiwan people who have traveled to mainland China because it can't prevent them from visiting the mainland via a third location.

The Board of Airline Representatives in Taiwan joined in the chorus of criticism Friday, arguing that the Immigration Office should issue a formal decree to require them to follow this practice which might infringe on their customers' privacy.
Even with such a decree, foreign airlines which operate in Taiwan claim they will still need the approval of their own countries to comply with the controversial regulation.
An executive of one foreign airline said Friday that he really doubts that the authorities in his country would ever allow his airline to give out passengers' personal information.
In the worst case scenario, the executive said, the foreign airlines might be forced to withdraw from the Taiwan market, which he said would not serve the interests of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW UNTIMELY: TAIWAN OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 18 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: It was untimely and unnecessary for China to enact the Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan when signs of cross-Taiwan Strait relations improving were becoming apparent, a Taiwan official based in the United States said Friday.
Andrew L.Y. Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, made the comment on the CNN news show "Diplomatic License."

Hsia pointed out that the launch of special cross-strait charter flights during this year's Lunar New Year holiday as well as President Chen Shui-bian's and Premier Frank Hsieh's recent remarks on cross-strait relations all indicated Taiwan's intention to improve its relations with China.

Hsia said it was unnecessary for Beijing to pass the Anti-Secession Law to try to change the cross-strait status quo at this point and he urged the international community, especially the United Nations, to pay attention to this development.
The law enacted by Beijing early this week authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

On Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, Hsia said the support voiced by the international community for Taiwan after the passage of the law indicates that Taiwan has a lot of friends internationally.

He admitted that Taiwan will face a lot of difficulties while trying to gain membership in the United Nations, but he added that the bid must be continued because the right of the 23 million people in Taiwan to join the world organization should not be ignored.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS MONASTERY, ORPHANAGE ON ANNIVERSARY OF 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited a Buddhist monastery and an orphanage in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan Saturday on the first anniversary of the presidential election-eve assassination attempt against himself and Vice President Annette Lu.

The president first paid a visit to Fuoguangshan Temple where he was warmly greeted by Buddhist masters and followers. The president burned incense at the major temple of the complex and exchanged gifts with the new director, Master Hsin Pei, before leaving for Lioukuei Nursery.

Meanwhile, a march launched by the "319 Action Alliance" was held in Taipei, northern Taiwan to demand the "truth" behind the shooting on March 19, 2004, in which the president and vice president were slightly injured.
Officials of the Presidential Office pointed out that President Chen has urged the public several times to have faith in the country's judicial system.
The president will mark the day in a warm and peaceful manner, in contrast to the Kuomintang's (KMT's) approach of taking to the streets, the officials said.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan, as well as Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, both of whom are KMT vice chairmen, took part in the march.
Vice President Annette Lu, who is currently leading a 152-member delegation on an official visit in Guatemala also spoke about her feelings regarding last year's shooting.
Lu said that she is fully recovered and that she plans to climb Mount Hsueh (Snow Mountain) on May 20, or the first inauguration of her second term as the vice president.

Police recently announced a "major breakthrough" in the case, saying however that the prime suspect had committed suicide 10 days after the shooting and that the alleged weapon used in the shooting was not found.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" alleged the shooting was staged to win sympathy votes in President Chen's bid for re-election. After Chen won by a razor-thin margin, the alliance filed two lawsuits to challenge the election and the election result. Both lawsuits were rejected by the court.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR UNITY ON 319 SHOOTING ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang urged the opposition Saturday to put aside political strife in order to unite the nation against the threat posed by China.

Su made the call ahead of a rally held by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to demand the "truth" on the anniversary of last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
The KMT alleges that the shooting, which left Chen and Lu slightly injured, was set up by the DPP to give it an advantage in the election.

While making a trip to Hsinchu County to promote a large-scale DPP-organized rally set for March 26 against China's Anti-Secession Law, Su noted that opinion polls show that up to 90 percent of the people in Taiwan are opposed to the law and more than 50 percent of the people support an open demonstration of their objections.
At this moment, the nation should stop all internal strife and work closely together against China so as to show the world a united Taiwan, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OFFER SCHOLARSHIPS TO STUDENTS FROM DPU MEMBER NATIONS: VP
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, March 18 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu announced Friday that the ROC government will offer a total of 60 full scholarships each year to students from member nations of the proposed Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) to support their graduate studies in Taiwan.

Lu made the announcement while addressing the opening ceremony of a DPU American regional meeting in Guatemala. Representatives from six ROC allies in Central America and five non-allied countries in the Americas attended the meeting, which was a prelude to the inauguration of the DPU slated for Aug. 14 in Taipei.

High-profile participants included Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma de Escobar, Guatemalan Vice President Eduardo Stein, Honduran Vice President Armida de Lopez, and Nicaraguan Vice President Jose Rizo.

In her address, Lu, the initiator of the DPU, reiterated the goals of the union of Pacific Rim democracies, which are to advocate democratic development, protect marine resources, and promote industrial and economic cooperation among international organizations.

After the American meeting, Lu indicated, an Asian meeting will be held in Tokyo, Japan and a South Pacific meeting will be opened in Australia. Lu also said Taiwan will hold a "Discovering Taiwan" activity in August for all DPU members to engage in an in-depth study of the island.
Many conclusions were reached in the one-day meeting, including that Taiwan will play a key role in leading free trade and investment in the American region.

Lu, at the head of a 152-member delegation, is currently on a three-day official visit in Guatemala. On the sidelines of the DPU meeting, she also held an informal leadership meeting with her four counterparts from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua.
Before coming to Guatemala, Lu and her entourage made an official visit to El Salvador from March 14-17.

DOC.HEADLINE: 319 MARCH HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH PURSUING 'TRUTH': DPP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Saturday that the "319 March" held by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) had nothing to do with pursuing the "truth" behind last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
DPP and TSU officials were referring to the march calling for "truth, democracy and peace" which was held in Taipei Saturday afternoon to mark the first anniversary of the shooting.
William C.T. Lai, DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that the march had nothing to do with the pursuit of truth, but more about drumming up support for the KMT.

At a critical time when Taiwan should be displaying national unity in the face of China's recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan, the KMT has instead insisted on staging the march despite all appeals, Lai said.
What's more surprising is that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, both of whom are KMT vice chairmen, took part in the march, Lai said.

The march was an extension of the 2004 presidential election, Lai claimed, adding that Wang and Ma, both of whom are vying for the KMT chairmanship, are warming up for their bids to run in the 2008 presidential election.
Lo Chih-ming, TSU caucus whip in the Legislature, said that the truth behind the shooting must be left to police investigation, adding that a march will not solve the problem.
Lo also expressed affirmation for People First Party Chairman (PFP) James Soong's decision not to attend the march.

Prior to the march, Premier Frank Hsieh said that it is the right of the people to express their views, but he urged the participants in the march to exercise self-restrain and avoid clashes less they undermine the message they want to drive home.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang also urged the various parties to set aside their differences and rally behind the nation to show the island's unity to the whole world.
Su made the remarks in Hsinchu County to solicit support for a DPP-sponsored march scheduled for March 26 to protest against mainland China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law.

The "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP alleged the election-eve shooting was staged to win sympathy votes for President Chen's bid for re-election. After Chen won by a little more than 25,000 votes out of more than 13 million ballots cast, the alliance filed two lawsuits to challenge the election and the result of the election. Both lawsuits were rejected by the court.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS WARN AGAINST LIFTING OF E.U. ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA

TEXT.P: A lifting of the European Union's ban on weapons sales to mainland China would help fuel Beijing's hegemonic designs, posing a serious threat to security in East Asia and the West Pacific, scholars said Saturday at a seminar in Taipei.

In the seminar sponsored by the Taiwan New Century Foundation to express Taiwan's opposition to a possible removal of the E.U.'s ban, foundation chairman Chen Lung-chih said that the issue is of great significance to the safety and livelihood of the people in Taiwan and to peace and security in the entire Asia-Pacific region.

The international community must make Beijing realize that its Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan not only constitutes a violation of the United Nations' Charter, but also poses a threat to world peace, Chen said.

Chen suggested that the government launch a publicity campaign against the law in Europe and increase the country's international visibility to relay the strong desire of the Taiwan people for peace and democracy to the whole world, and to help the E.U. face up to the serious consequences that a lifting of the arms sales ban would have in the Taiwan Strait and the rest of the world.

Wu Chih-chung, a professor at the Taipei-based Soochow University, contended that it is just a matter of time before the E. U. lifts its ban and that Taiwan won't necessarily be a loser if it does so, pointing out that the lifting of the ban might bring about a new turning point for Taiwan to step up its strategic partnership with the United States and Japan.

According to Wu, it is worth noting whether a lifting of the arms ban will further fan disagreement between what he calls two polarized geopolitical and strategic blocs that are increasingly taking shape in East Asia -- one of the United States, Japan and Taiwan, and the other composed of mainland China, Russia, France and Germany.

Chang Yang-pei, a senior researcher at the Taiwan Research Institute, opined that it is very possible that the E. U. will make a decision on removing or maintaining the ban this year. He warned of a serious threat to peace and stability in East Asia and the West Pacific that may be arising with a better armed China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE' MARKS 1ST ANNIVERSARY OF 319 SHOOTING WITH MARCH

TEXT.P: Supporters of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) took to the streets in Taipei Saturday afternoon on the first anniversary of the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu to demand the "truth" behind the shooting.
The protesters, estimated by police at more than 30,000, gathered at the now-defunct Taipei Tobacco Plant and then marched to the square in front of the Presidential Office.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, as well as Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, both of whom are KMT vice chairmen, New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming, lawmakers of the Pan Blue Alliance formed by the KMT, PFP and New Party, and 319 Truth Investigation Commission spokeswoman Wang Ching-feng were among the participants in the march.
Notably absent from the march was PFP Chairman James Soong, who teamed up with Lien to form the "pan-blue alliance" ticket in the 2004 presidential election which they lost to Chen and Lu.
Lien, Ma, Wang and Yok took turns in addressing the rally participants in front of the Presidential Square, lambasting the government for what they called foot-dragging in probing the shooting.

The election-eve shooting has been alleged by the "pan-blue alliance" to have been staged in order to gain sympathy votes in Chen's re-election bid. After Chen won the election, the alliance filed two lawsuits in an attempt to have the election and the election result nullified. The two lawsuits were later be rejected by the courts. Alliance supporters also staged a sit-in in front of the Presidential Office for several days after the election.
Police were out in force to ensure order in Saturday's march, which turned out to be much more peaceful than the protests immediately following last year's elections.
Meanwhile, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has drawn fire from his political rivals for taking part in the rally. They claimed that as the mayor, he should not take part in protest rallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOURNALISTS CALL FOR FREEDOM OF PRESS TO BE ENSHRINED IN CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The Association of Taiwan Journalists on Saturday called for freedom of the press to be enshrined in the Constitution.
In a statement marking its 10th anniversary, the association said that freedom of the press cannot be ensured unless it is clearly listed in the Constitution.

The association also called for the enactment of an open information law, establishment of a national communication commission free of political influence, and enactment of a law prohibiting political figures from hosting TV talk shows.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES 319 PROTESTERS TO EXERCISE SELF-RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Saturday urged participants in an opposition rally demanding the "truth" behind last year's presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian to exercise self-restraint to prevent an outbreak of violence.

Hsieh, who made the appeal during an inspection tour to Hsinchu County ahead of the rally in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the shooting, said that people have the right to express their opinions but should exercise restraint in doing so.
Major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) figures including party chairman Lien Chan, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou took part in the rally.
The KMT alleges that the shooting was set up by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to give it an advantage in the election.
On the large-scale DPP-organized rally set for March 26 against China's Anti-Secession Law, Hsieh said he will make a decision on Sunday on whether to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT ACCEPTS INVITATION TO VISIT TAIWAN IN AUGUST
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala, March 18 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Oscar Berger on Friday accepted an invitation from visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu to visit Taiwan in August.

Lu, who is currently on a three-day visit in Guatemala, called on Berger Friday and presented him with a satellite photo of Guatemala City, capital of the Central American country, taken by the ROC satellite ROCSAT-II.

Lu extended an invitation to Berger to visit Taiwan to attend the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) on Aug. 14. Lu and her counterparts from El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua earlier attended a DPU regional meeting in Guatemala. The DPU, the brainchild of the vice president, will be comprised of representatives of the Pacific democracies to create a new alliance in the Pacific region to advance democracy, peace and prosperity.
Berger accepted the invitation and expressed the hope that the two countries could sign a free trade agreement (FTA) by then.
Lu then signed a letter of intent to cooperate with Guatemala to preserve the historical sites of Antigua, promising to provide assistance to repair and renovate a museum and a monastery.

The vice president said that the budgets for the two renovation projects will be finalized after discussions by an ad hoc team upon her return to Taiwan. She added that she hopes the renovation work can be completed within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MEET APEC 'PAPERFREE' TRADE TARGET THIS YEAR: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is working to upgrade facilities in foreign trade in an effort to coordinate the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's promotion of "paperfree" trading, an official from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Saturday.

Vice CEPD Chairman Thomas M.F. Yeh indicated that the upgrading is expected to be completed by the end of this year, noting that by then, most of the operations concerning importing and exporting, from import and export permit applications to customs clearance and shipping affairs, can be completed on the Internet.

"Paperfree" operations will not only help decrease the costs of trading, but will also boost the global operational power of the businesses operating in Taiwan, Yeh said, noting the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and Ministry of Finance have all joined in the drive to build a "One Input for All" trading system.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN GROUP ADOPTS RESOLUTION AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The Council of Asian Liberals and Democrats (CALD) passed a resolution Saturday to express its regret at China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
The council urged Beijing to make itself responsible for regional peace and resume dialogue with Taiwan to resolve their differences.

The resolution was adopted during a CALD Executive Committee meeting held in Taipei and hosted by CALD Secretary-General Hsiao Bi-khim, who is also a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
It was attended by political representatives from the Philippines, Thailand, Cambodia, Myanmar, Malaysia, Singapore and Sri Lanka.

According to the resolution, democracy is a longstanding principle upheld by the CALD, and the use of non-peaceful means, as authorized in the Anti-Secession Law, is against the interests and principles of CALD members.
It said the CALD has noticed that the United States, Japan, the European Union and Australia have expressed their opposition to the use of force to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait political differences.

During a meeting with Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian on Friday, Philippine legislator and CALD member Nereus Acosta said on behalf of the participants of the meeting that the cross-strait situation is related to the regional security in East Asia and that no country in Asia wishes to see a war break out across the strait.
Acosta said cross-strait differences should be resolved through peaceful means. He urged Beijing to respect the wish of the Taiwan people for peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Wal-Mart to Pay U.S. $11 Million in Lawsuit on Illegal Workers.
Federal prosecutors and immigration officials announced yesterday that Wal-Mart Stores had agreed to pay a record $11 million to settle accusations that it used hundreds of illegal immigrants to clean its stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD SET SIGHTS ON 'BRICS': VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: With the expected rise of Brazil, Russia, India and China as the major driving force in the world economy by mid-century, Taiwan should jockey for position in these "BRIC" markets in advance through greater investment, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said.

Wu, who made the call in a speech given at a forum held Friday by Business Weekly, proposed signing agreements to protect Taiwan business interests in the four rising economies which have been forecast to replace the present-day developed countries to become the engine of global economic growth by 2050 due to their huge populations and significant industrial and technological skills and resources.

Apart from mainland China, where Taiwan investments accounted for 46 percent of all foreign capital that flowed into the country in 2003, Wu said that Taiwan should further enhance economic ties with the three other countries and urged efforts to foster foreign trade personnel with language abilities, particularly the Portuguese and Russian languages.
In recent years, Taiwan's annual trade volume with Russia has grown at a rapid pace of about 16.7 percent per year, he noted.

However, Wu was somewhat reserved concerning some of these countries' determination to advocate a free economy. Pointing to mainland China as an example, the vice premier claimed that it is difficult to craft a good policy to couple with an opening market due to its political system.

Yuwa Hedrick-Wong, a leading economic advisor in charge of Asia-Pacific markets at the MasterCard International, Roopa Purushothaman, an analyst at the Goldman Sachs investment bank who first made a report on the "BRICs, " and Paulo A. P. Pinto, director of the Brazil Business Center in Taipei, also attended the forum.
Roopa said that the key to the "BRICs" becoming the major driving force in the world economy is for them to continue implementing trade liberalization policies and opening measures.

Hedrick-Wong expressed great optimism about the mainland Chinese economy, saying that a globalized society and economy will push China to continue opening up, as evidenced by the fact that the country lowered its customs duties twice over the past two years.

Meanwhile, Pinto said Brazil is a lucrative market for Taiwan businesses, especially in the tourist and motorcycle industries. He claimed that Brazil is rife with trade and investment opportunities for Taiwan companies at a time when his country is poised to push for an integration plan in Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SUPPORTS CONSTITUTIONAL COMMISSION TO LOOK INTO 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bain said Saturday that he supports the formation of a commission that is constitutional to look into the presidential election-eve shooting of himself and Vice President Annette Lu last year.
The president made the remarks after he visited Liuokuei Nursery, an orphanage in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, on the first anniversary of the shooting incident.
Chen earlier visited Fuoguangshan Monastery, also in Kaohsiung, hoping to use a"warm and peaceful" approach to mark the day, according to officials from the Presidential Office.

President Chen said that he supports coordination between the ruling and opposition parties to form the commission, adding that Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance," could serve as conveners or could nominate a convener.

"I will cooperate fully with the investigation work of the commission, " Chen said, stressing that as he hadn't rigged the election, he had no fear of the vote-recount demanded by the "pan-blue alliance." The grueling full recount later confirmed Chen won the election, but only by a margin of a little more than 25,000 votes, instead of the original figure of 29,518 votes, out of more than 13 million cast.

Chen said that he eagerly wants to know who pulled the trigger on March 19, 2004, but added that he has no right to tell an ad hoc investigation team formed to probe the case what to do. He added that he admired their tenacious work in trying to crack the case in a situation like "looking for a needle in a haystack."

He also expressed his "admiration" for the recent announcement by the police of a "major breakthrough" in identifying the prime suspect, although the suspect committed suicide 10 days after the shooting and the weapon he allegedly used has not been found.

On the opposition's promotion of a second commission to look into the truth of the shooting, the president said that he has never opposed the forming of such a group, just as he had not opposed or feared a vote recount after the election.
"As long as the commission is formed in line with the Constitution, I'll give it my full support," he said.

A similar "319 truth investigation commission" was formed last October under a statute passed by the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan, but the commission never got anywhere because it encountered heavy resistance from every government agency that members visited and couldn't obtain needed information it requested after the Council of Grand Justices decided that the all-powerful commission was unconstitutional and wouldn't cooperate.

President Chen also made clarification to try to dispel some persistent doubts and misgivings about the shooting, such as why he didn't wear a bullet-proof vest while campaigning in the open-topped jeep.

Chen said that he had only worn a bullet-proof vest after being elected Taipei mayor and after the first time he was elected president in 2000. He said he never wore the vest while campaigning for re-election because it never occurred to him that someone might want to shoot the president.
He also said that former President Lee Teng-hui told him that he had not worn a bullet-proof vest at any time during the presidential campaign in 1996.
"There is nothing special in the fact that I didn't wear the bullet-proof vest on March 19, 2004," the president said.

Chen also recalled the situation after being shot that day. He said that before the campaigning in Tainan, southern Taiwan, he reminded Vice President Annette Lu that the voters in his hometown were especially passionate and that she should be wary of the ear-deafening firecrackers in the streets along which they would be campaigning.

Chen recalled that he was in hyped mood with the enthusiastic supporters lining the streets and that therefore didn't feel any pain initially when he was shot and insisted on walking into the hospital himself.

The "pan-blue alliance" claimed that the shooting and the ensuing activation of a national security mechanism which barred many police and military servicemen, traditionally supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" parties, from leaving their posts unfairly swayed the election in Chen's favor. The alliance filed two lawsuits to challenge the election and the result of the election, but both were later rejected by the court.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CALLS FOR SETTING UP 2ND 319 TRUTH INVESTIGATION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan urged his party's lawmakers Saturday to accelerate legislation for establishing a special investigation commission to find out the truth behind the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu last year.

Addressing a rally in front of the Presidential Office to mark the first anniversary of the shooting, Lien said that there will be no political reconciliation or peace in Taiwan without an unveiling of the truth behind the shooting because it is the essence of Taiwan's new democratic movement and the foundation of democracy to pursue the truth.
"The 'pan-blue alliance' of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) can be cheated, " Lien criticized, "but the nation and the people of Taiwan should not lose."

More than 30,000 "pan-blue alliance" supporters took part in Saturday's march, according to police estimates. The participants first gathered at the now-defunct Taipei Tobacco Plant and then marched to the square in front of the Presidential Office.

The "pan-blue alliance's" ticket of Lien and PFP Chairman James Soong narrowly lost last year's presidential election. The alliance alleges that the election-eve shooting was staged in order to gain sympathy votes in Chen's re-election bid.
After Chen won the election, the alliance filed two lawsuits in an attempt to have the election and the election result nullified. The two lawsuits were later rejected by the courts.
A commission was formed on Oct. 4, 2004, according to a controversial statute crafted on the "pan-blue alliance's" terms to look into the March 19 shooting.
The Council of Grand Justices ruled on Dec. 15 that the commission was partly unconstitutional.

The commission, however, issued a report Jan. 19 before deciding to dissolve itself, claiming that the shooting was a campaign scheme aimed at influencing the outcome of the presidential election and that the president should be recalled for trampling on the Constitution and the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, March 20, or the 11th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1602: The Dutch East India Company receives a charter granting it a monopoly on all trade between Holland and the lands lying between the Cape of Good Hope and the Straits of Magellan.
1727: Sir Isaac Newton, the English mathematician and scientist who invented differential calculus and formulated the theories of universal gravitation, terrestrial mechanics and color, dies at the age of 85.
1792: The French Legislative Assembly approves the use of the guillotine as a means of capital punishment.
1815: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte returns to Paris as a hero after putting behind him a dreary year of exile on the Mediterranean island of Elba.
1896: The Ching court's first modern post office begins operations, turning a new leaf in the history of China's postal service. The ROC Ministry of Transportation and Communications in 1947 formally fixed March 20 as Postal Service Day.
1913: Soong Chiau-jen, acting chairman of the ROC's Kuomintang (Nationalist Party), is gunned down by assassins and severely injured at the northern railway station in Shanghai. He died two days later at the age of 33.
1934: Radar is first demonstrated in Kiel Harbor, Germany, by Dr. Rudolph Kuenhold.
1949: The S.S. Chungking, a cruiser which had earlier defected to Communist China from the Republic of China, is sunk by ROC Air Force warplanes off Hulu Peninsula in Liaoning Province.
1959: Tibetans stage a large-scale armed revolt in their capital of Lhasa against the Chinese communists.
1965: A car accident on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei kills 29 people and injures 71 others, most of them fourth-grade students and their teachers from Yoong-An Primary School in Hsinwoo Village, Taoyuan County.
1974: Princess Anne, the daughter of Britain's Queen Elizabeth II, escapes unhurt after an armed man tries to kidnap her in The Mall, London.
1976: A newly invented Chinese character computer, the "Fu Hsi 4674 Chinese Character Data Procession System," goes on display.
1990: Imelda Marcos, wife of Ferdinand Marcos, ex-president of the Philippines, stands trial in New York for fraud.
1990: The Republic of Namibia gains independence after 75 years of military occupation by South Africa.
1994: Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, former president of the Soviet Union, accompanied by his wife, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1995: A nerve gas attack in a Tokyo subway station by the Japanese Aum Shinri Kyo religious cult kills 10 and injures more than 5,500.
1995: Sheu Yuan-dong replaces Liang Kuo-shu as governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China.
1996: The British government acknowledges that mad cow disease could probably be transmitted to humans.
1997: The ROC Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan confirms that an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease among the nation's pigs has caused economic losses of more than NT$100 billion.
1999: U.S. Rep. Tom Campbell (R-Calif.) introduces a concurrent resolution in the House of Representatives seeking to express the feeling that all Chinese people, including those in Taiwan, deserve to be represented in international institutions.
2002: Minister of Economic Affairs Christine Tsung resigns abruptly 48 days after her ascent to the office, making her the shortest-serving minister in the Republic of China's history.
2004: President Chen Shui-bian wins re-election by a slim margin. The defeated contestant in the race, Lien Chan, and his running mate James Soong question the outcome of the election and lead their supporters to protest in front of the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good and wise man encourages men to develop the good qualities in their nature; whereas, a bad man and a fool does the very opposite."
