DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO STABILIZE POLITICS TO HELP INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh vowed Sunday to stabilize Taiwan's politics to provide a favorable environment for industrial development.

Addressing a ceremony marking the establishment of a sub-group of the Legislative Yuan, the Legislative Alliance for Science and Technology, Hsieh noted that stabilizing the domestic political situation will be the top priority of his administration in the coming years while accelerating efforts to push for legislation to facilitate industrial development, particularly that relevant to high-technology industries.

Hsieh said that while Taiwan has been ranked exceptionally high overall by the World Competitiveness Scoreboard published by IMD, a Switzerland-based business school, as well as the World Economic Forum Global Competitiveness Report, the country was ranked relatively poorly in terms of government efficiency and far behind -- below 50th place -- in political stability.
He said that an unstable political situation affects not only a country's global competitiveness ranking but also adversely impacts a country's overall industrial development.

The premier said he attaches great importance to the Legislative Alliance for Science and Technology and hopes that the group will become a bridge between the administration and the legislature in efforts to accelerate legislation to cope the fast-growing and fast-changing high technology industry.

Meanwhile, Hsieh said that the Cabinet will cooperate fully with the investigation work of a proposed new commission to look into the presidential election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, so long as the commission is established legally and constitutionally.
"None of the Cabinet members and agencies will resist investigations to be conducted by the commission should the commission is constitutional and approved by the Grand Justices, " Hsieh added.

Hsieh was echoing President Chen Shui-bian, who said a day earlier that he supports the formation of a constitutional commission to look into the presidential election-eve shootings of March 19, 2004.

Chen said he supports coordination between the ruling and opposition parties to form the commission, adding that Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong, leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " could serve as conveners or could nominate a convener.

"I will cooperate fully with the investigation work of the commission, " Chen said, stressing that as he did not rig the election, he had no fear of the vote-recount demanded by the "pan-blue alliance." The grueling full recount later confirmed that Chen won the election, but only by a margin of a little more than 25,000 votes, instead of the original figure of 29,518 votes, out of more than 13 million ballots cast.

Chen said that he eagerly wants to know who pulled the trigger on March 19 last year, but added that he has no right to tell an ad hoc investigation team formed to probe the case what to do. He added that he admires their tenacious work in trying to crack the case in a situation that is like looking for a needle in a haystack.
"As long as the commission is formed in line with the Constitution, I'll give it my full support," he said.

A similar "319 truth investigation commission" was formed last October under a statute passed by the opposition-dominated Legislative Yuan, but the commission got nowhere because it encountered heavy resistance from every government agency that the members tried to question and could not obtain information it requested after the Council of Grand Justices ruled the all-powerful commission unconstitutional and refused to cooperate.

The "pan-blue alliance" claimed that the shooting and the ensuing activation of a national security mechanism it claims barred "many" police and military servicemen -- traditionally supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" -- from leaving their posts, unfairly swayed the election in Chen's favor. The alliance filed two lawsuits to challenge the election and the result of the election, both of which were thrown out by the courts because the plaintiffs failed to provide any evidence to support their allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE SEIZE RECORD NUMBER OF GUNS

TEXT.P: Police seized a total of 4,354 contraband guns last year, up a whopping 64.74 percent from the number uncovered in 2003, according to official tallies released Sunday.

The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said both the number of seized factory-made guns and those of home-made or modified guns set new records. Of the seizures, 2,687 were home-made or modified pistols and the remainder were standard manufactured rifles or handguns.
Among the 2004 seizures, 276 were powerful rifles, up from 108 in 2001.
Over the past four years, CIB officials said the number of seized illegal firearms has continued to rise, indicating that the gun smuggling issue has become more serious.
As the Cabinet has made crime-fighting a top priority, the officials said police forces around the nation will step up a crackdown on firearms smuggling to prevent the issue from further worsening.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNILATERAL MEASURES NOT HELPFUL TO RESOLVING CROSS-STRAIT PROBLEMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taking unilateral measures that can only escalate tension is not helpful to resolving cross-Taiwan Strait problems, U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Saturday.

She made the remarks while touching on China's anti-secession law in an interview with a Japanese TV station during a visit to Tokyo. The U.S. State Department released the contents of the interview the same day.

Saying that neither side of the Taiwan Strait can resolve the cross-strait problem on its own, Rice noted that "unilateral measures that only increase tension rather than reducing them are simply not helpful."

Talking about China's human rights issue and the European Union's intention to lift its arms sales ban on China, Rice said that despite the fact that the United States has decided not to seek a human rights resolution at the U.N. Commission on Human rights this year, the resolution is "something that comes up every year, " adding, however, that "the removal of arms embargo doesn't come up every year and once it's removed, it's removed."

"The other thing is that we've made a very clear point that this is not just human rights, although that's important, but this is also about the message that it sends about Europe's view of the strategic balance in the Pacific," she said.

Pointing out that the lifting of the arms embargo has been a source of concern because of China's rising military strength in the region, Rice said: "After all, particularly for the United States, which plays the role of guarantor of stability in that region, it simply sends the wrong message at a time of rising Chinese military expenditure to lift the arms embargo."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STICKS TO OBLIGATION UNDER TRA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice reiterated in Tokyo Saturday that Washington will continue to stick to its obligation under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
She also said that the United States will maintain its one-China policy and oppose any unilateral change to the status quo by either side of the Taiwan Strait.
Rice, who is visiting Japan, made the comments in an address at Sophia University in Tokyo. The full text of her speech was released by the State Department the same day.

Pointing out that the United States has reason to welcome the rise of China as a confident, peaceful and prosperous country, Rice said that Washington also wants China as " a global partner, able and willing to match its growing capabilities to its international responsibilities."
However, she admitted that some issues, particularly Taiwan, have complicated relations between China and the United States.
"Our one-China policy is clear and unchanged. We oppose unilateral changes to the status quo, whether by word or deed by either party, " Rice said.

Saying that Taipei and Beijing must realize that neither side can solve the problem alone and should continue to expand recent steps toward a more productive relationship, Rice reiterated that "in the interest of peace and stability we stand by our obligations under the TRA."
She also said that the United States can assure basic security as well as reach out to achieve other goals in the Pacific community because it knows economic and political openness works.

"The ultimate direction of contemporary trends is clear. Openness is the vanguard of success. Time and again we have seen that economic and political openness cannot long be separated. Even China must eventually embrace some form of open, genuinely representative government if it is to reap the benefits and meet the challenges of a globalizing world," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW TO INCREASE TENSION IN TAIWAN STRAIT: SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, March 19 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Several scholars from various countries around the world panned China Saturday for the enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, saying that it will escalate tension in the region.

The scholars made the criticism at a seminar held by the Canadian Association for the Studies of International Development to discuss issues relating to "Taiwan and the International Ccommunity: Between NGOs, Development Agencies and the United Nations." It was presided over by Scott Simon, an associate professor from Ottawa University.

Stephane Corcuff, a professor from Leon University in France, who served previously as a press officer of the French Institute in Taipei and has long studied Taiwan issues, said that both China and the international community have dealt with Taiwan issues unfairly and that peace should be established on the basis of fairness and justice.
In the conclusion, almost all the participants agreed that China and Taiwan should engage in peaceful dialogue to reduce tension in the Taiwan Strait.
Canadian congressmen David Kilgour and Meili Faille, Taiwan's Representative to Canada Thomas Chen, and other staff of his office also attended the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP LAUNCHES 'CULTURAL DIPLOMACY' IN GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, March 19 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu signed a letter of intent with her Guatemalan counterpart Friday, promising Taiwan aid to help restore and preserve buildings and historical sites there that have been repeatedly damaged by earthquakes.

Unlike all other economic and technological aid programs that Taiwan has engaged in with its allied countries, this marks the first "cultural diplomacy" launched by any political leader from Taiwan to help preserve historical sites and enhance bilateral cultural ties with a diplomatic ally, she said.

According to preliminary plans, Taiwan will help restore and renovate Museum Pilar de Zaragoza and Monastery Sor Juana located in Antigua City, a monumental city founded in 1543 with strong Spanish colonial influence.

Restoration and renovation of the two historical sites are expected to be completed in two years, with a budget of around US$700,000, said Wu Ching-fa, vice chairman of the Council of Cultural Affairs, who is among Lu's 152-member entourage.
Lu signed the letter of intent with Guatemalan Vice President Eduardo Stein Friday in a ceremony witnessed by President Oscar Berger.
Lu and her group toured the city of Antigua Saturday with Antigua Mayor Antonio Siliezar Portillo. At the same time, Lu and Siliezar jointly announced the restoration and renovation project.

Throughout its history, the city now known as Antigua Guatemala, or La Antigua, has been repeatedly damaged by earthquakes, and always the Antiguan-style buildings have been rebuilt. But on July 29, 1773, earthquakes wrought such destruction that officials petitioned the King of Spain to allow them to move the capital to safer ground, which led to the founding in 1776 of present-day Guatemala City.

Antigua was left to rusticate, largely but never completely abandoned. Today, its monumental bougainvillea-draped ruins and its preserved and carefully restored Spanish colonial public buildings and private mansions form a city of charm and romance unequaled in the Americas. In 1979, UNESCO recognized Antigua Guatemala as a Cultural Heritage of Mankind site.

Touring the city, Lu said that Guatemala is a country blessed with rich cultural heritage. She said she was moved deeply by Guatemala's historical and architectural magnificence the first time she visited the country nine months ago.
The first thing she did after returning to Taiwan was to meet officials and scholars to work out a plan to help Guatemala preserve its cultural heritage, Lu said.
Lu also gave Siliezar a satellite photo of Antigua City taken by the ROC satellite ROCSAT-II and invited Siliezar to visit Taiwan in the near future.

The vice president also expressed hope that Antigua City will give seedlings of Guatemala's national flower and national tree to Taiwan as a gift so that a beautiful Latin garden can be nurtured in Taipei City.

For his part, Siliezar offered his deep gratitude to Taiwan, saying that Taiwan's unselfish compassion shown to Guatemala is especially respectable at a time when Taiwan is under military threat from China.

According to Wu, the museum and monastery restoration project is a highly rewarding program, earning the appreciation and respect from the Guatemalan people on one hand and helping Taiwan further broaden its support base overseas on the other.

Professor Chang Po-shuo from National Cheng Kung University (NCKU), one of the scholars on the team in charge of the restoration project, said that the project will be jointly planned and undertaken by people from NCKU and Guatemala's San Carlos University. The two schools will also knot sisterhood ties because of the project, he added.
Lu and her entourage are scheduled to wrap up their three-day visit to Guatemala Sunday and will return to Taiwan, making a transit stay in Miami.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUB-GROUP ESTABLISHED TO PUSH FOR LEGISLATION ON SCI-TECH DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: A sub-group of the Legislative Yuan, the Legislative Alliance for Science and Technology (LAST), was formally established Sunday to push for legislation to cope with the fast-growing and fast-changing high technology industry.

Addressing a ceremony marking the establishment of the LAST, Premier Frank Hsieh said he attaches great importance to the alliance and hopes that the group will help bridge differences between the administration and the legislature in efforts to accelerate legislation on affairs pertaining to sci-tech industrial development.

The LAST was jointly established by 20 lawmakers from across the political spectrum, with Lee Yung-ping, a legislator from the opposition People First Party named as the convener and Legislator Kuo Cheng-liang from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and legislators Lee Chi-chu and Wu Chih-yang from the opposition Kuomintang as deputy conveners.
The LAST is open to all legislators interested in pushing for legislation governing sci-tech industrial development and related affairs, Lee said.

Noting that government operations and laws and regulations have always lagged behind the development of high technology, Lee said that the LAST is committed to filling the gap and helping bolster interaction and understanding among the government, the legislature and the industry.

To function as a communication platform for the administration, legislature and industry, the LAST will initially focus its attention on legislation on affairs pertaining to digitalization of information and communication industries, the digital-content business, intellectual property rights, radio frequency ID systems, the biotechnology industry and the competitiveness of Taiwan's sci-tech industries, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP URGED NOT TO BOYCOTT PROPOSED ARMS PROCUREMENT STATUTE

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator called on the legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) Sunday to refrain from boycotting the inclusion of a statute governing major arms procurements in the agenda of the Legislative Yuan.

Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, made the appeal after the PFP legislative caucus said at a recent news conference that it will be against the inclusion of the Cabinet-proposed "statute for major arms procurements" on the agenda of the legislature.

The proposed statute regarding a plan to buy six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States was approved by the Cabinet last Wednesday and presented immediately to the legislature for discussion.

The ceiling for the procurement package was marked down from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.48 billion) in the new proposal because a plan to build the submarines in Taiwan was dropped, while the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. currency.

Lai said that the DPP legislative caucus will take the initiative to negotiate the issue with its PFP counterpart in the hope that the proposed statute can be included on the legislature's agenda for March 25 and passed on to a legislative committee for review.

Terming the draft statute a major indicator of reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, Lai said that both President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman James Soong also voiced their support for the proposal in a 10-point declaration issued in the wake of their Feb. 24 meeting.

Should the PFP legislative caucus block the draft statute from being included on the legislative agenda, it will trigger misgivings among the public about the Chen-Soong meeting, Lai explained, adding that neither party wants to see this.

A similar proposed statute, together with a proposed special budget for the procurement, was shelved and blocked by the previous legislature owing to objections from the majority "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and PFP, which thought the package was too expensive.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% OF TAIWAN PEOPLE OPPOSE CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Over 90 percent of the people of the Republic of China are opposed to China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan, ROC representative to Malaysia Wu Wen-ya said Sunday, quoting the results of a recent public opinion survey.

As many as 93 percent of the respondents said they do not support the Anti-Secession Law because it will not only hurt the people of Taiwan but will also sabotage relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wu said.

According to the survey, Wu went on, more than 90 percent of those polled expressed support for maintaining the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and using peaceful means to resolve disputes between the two sides.

Wu made the remarks during a meeting with reporters in Malaysia. Also present at the meeting were Hung Jung-min, a member of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and Chiu Chi, director of the Press Division under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia.

Hung said that the unification versus independence debate should be resolved by plebiscite, adding that should cross-strait political leaders resolve the issue based upon the results of a referendum exclusively for the people of Taiwan, it would be acceptable for the Taiwan public.
He proposed that the authorities on either side of the Taiwan Strait set aside the unification versus independence debate and concentrate on stepping up bilateral economic and cultural exchanges.

Meanwhile, Lee Fang-hsin, chairman of the Malaysia-based Association of Taiwanese Manufacturers, said amajority of China-based Taiwanese businessmen are afraid of Beijing's Anti-Secession Law and that some of them are considering relocating their investments elsewhere.
According to Lee, people have the right to be free of terror.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN CHINA ON CONTINUOUS RISE: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan investment in China has increased by leaps and bounds over the past five years, officials from the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Sunday.

Having surged in both scale and scope, the amount of China-bound investments constituted an alarmingly high 67.24 percent of the entire investment that Taiwan made overseas in 2004, commission officials said.
According to tallies compiled by the Investment Commission, Taiwan businessmen channeled some US$41.94 billion into China in 33,314 investment projects between January 1991 and February 2005.

However, according to figures released by the Chinese authorities, Taiwan businessmen had committed some US$77.37 billion for 63,616 projects in China as of September 2004, although only US$39.37 billion was actually implemented.
Taiwan's China-bound investment also soared proportionally in terms of ratio of investment in China and Taiwan's overall investment overseas, commission officials said.

Investment Commission statistics show that China-bound investment constituted 33.93 percent of Taiwan's entire investment overseas in 2000, gradually climbing to 38.8 percent in 2001, 53.38 percent in 2002, 53.66 percent in 2003 and 67.24 percent in 2004.
China has not only become the top absorber of Taiwan investment, the proportion has also increased to surpass two-thirds, the officials said.

By industry, they added, the electronics industry has remained the largest investor over the past five years, making up 41 percent of the entire Taiwan investment in China. In 2000, Taiwan's electronics industry invested US$1.5 billion in China, a figure that had shot up to US$3 billion by 2004.
The metal industry followed, constituting 9 percent, followed by the chemical and plastics industries with 7 percent, and non-metal industries with 5 percent.

Taiwan investment in China's service sector has also grown considerably to reach 4.04 percent, or US$1.065 billion, of the entire Taiwan investment in China over the past five years, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH VOWS TO HALVE TAIWAN'S TUBERCULOSIS INCIDENCE RATE IN 10 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will join forces with the private sector to halve the domestic tuberculosis (TB) incidence and death rate in 10 years, a senior official said Sunday.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Center for Disease Control, made the remarks at an award-presentation ceremony honoring those who have contributed to local TB prevention as part of the activities to mark the March 24 World Tuberculosis Day.
Quoting DOH tallies, Lin said about 15,000 new TB cases are reported in Taiwan each year and that an average of 1,300 local people succumb to the disease annually.

"Although tuberculosis is an old disease, it is the most serious statutory communicable disease in Taiwan, " Lin said, adding that the TB death rate is the highest among all communicable illnesses in Taiwan.
Lin said Taiwan's TB incidence rate is 13 times that of the United States.
"In the United States, the TB incidence rate is 5.1 people out of every 100,000, compared to 66.67 people in Taiwan and 24.8 people in Japan," Lin said.
In terms of the TB death rate, Lin said, the ratio is 0.3 people out of every 100,000 in the United States, 1.9 people in Japan and 5.8 people in Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan still has ample room to improve TB prevention and control, Lin said the DOH hopes to join forces with the private sector to lower the disease's incidence and death rate by 50 percent in the coming 10 years.

He acknowledged that it will not be easy to realize these goals. "Strenuous efforts and close coordination between medical and public health personnel will be necessary to realize our goals," he added.
As far as TB prevention is concerned, Lin said identification of TB patients is a very important and difficult task.

"We cannot just rely on chest X-rays. Examination of sputum is equally important. The DOH has designated nine sputum examination centers around the island with a view to identifying TB patients in the shortest possible period of time," Lin said.

Thanks to the establishment of a comprehensive negative-pressure quarantine ward system during the fight against the severe acute respiratory syndrome epidemic in 2003, Lin said those well-equipped quarantine wards have become an important resource in the fight against TB.

Lin further said a particular problem in the TB-fighting campaign lies in the fact that more than half of the patients are over 65 years of age and have often stopped taking medication, hindering the treatment of the disease and enhancing the risk of spread.
According to Lin, TB patients can fully recover so long as they take prescription drugs regularly for six to nine months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR MARCH 26 RALLY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on the public Sunday to take part in a March 26 rally to protest China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, claiming that popular force is the best weapon to safeguard the nation.
Chen made the remarks while offering his respects to the spirit of the late Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Huang Hsin-chieh in front of his tomb at a public cemetery in Taipei County.

In the face of China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law, the president said, the people of Taiwan should take courage and participate in the DPP-initiated demonstration to voice discontent with the law.

Chen spoke highly of Huang and several pro-democracy activists during Taiwan's martial law era, such as Yin Hai-kuang, Fu Cheng and Lei Chen, for their courage in challenging the former Kuomintang government while facing injustice, saying the pro-democracy seniors used their precious lives to demonstrate that "as long as we are on the right side of history, we will never feel lonely."
Noting that Beijing has been doing everything possible to annex Taiwan, Chen said the Taiwan public should join together to safeguard the nation.

He further said that over 200 civic groups have decided to take part the March 26 demonstration to show their love for Taiwan, democracy and peace. He did not say whether he will take part in the demonstration.

China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- passed the Anti-Secession Law last Monday to provide the Beijing authorities with a legal basis for using non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the island moves toward independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE URGED TO PASS NATIONAL ASSEMBLY BILL

TEXT.P: A private constitutional amendment supervision group called on the Legislative Yuan Sunday to pass a draft bill on the exercise of power by the mission-oriented National Assembly as soon as possible to facilitate its task of reviewing a package of sweeping constitutional amendment proposals.

The Cheng Hsin (Sincere and Credible) Constitutional Amendment Supervision Alliance, formed by several civic organizations such as the Judicial Reform Foundation, the Alliance for Parliamentary Reform Actions (APRA) and the Taipei Society, made the appeal during a press conference.

APRA Convener Lu Hsiu-chu said that members of the constitutional amendment supervision organization will call on the legislative caucuses of the ruling and opposition parties and push for them to support the early passage of the draft bill.

The alliance will not rule out adopting radical steps, including mobilizing its members to surround the legislature and stage hunger strikes in an attempt to force the legislature to pass the draft bill as soon as it can, Lu said, adding that the organization will also consider fielding its candidates for the National Assembly elections to be held in May.

According to Taipei Society President Hung Yu-hung, the alliance insists that delegates to the mission-oriented National Assembly will only be responsible for voting on various constitutional amendment proposals adopted by the legislature at an extraordinary session last August. Consequently, Hung stressed, the voting procedures should be simplified and the meeting should have to last for only three days.

He also said that the threshold for a second-round vote on the constitutional amendment proposals should be based upon approval by a half of the delegates instead of three quarters, adding that the latter is too high and is against the spirit of a second-round vote as stated in the Constitution.

Among the constitutional amendment proposals passed by the legislature are halving of the number of seats in the 225-seat legislature, the adoption of a "single seat, two votes" electoral system for the legislature, the abrogation of the National Assembly, and the inclusion of the right to hold referendums written into the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-DEMOCRACY ACTIVISTS LAUNCH 'QUITTING CCP' CAMPAIGN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 19 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of exiled mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists staged a rally on the Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. Saturday to call for support for a "quitting the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)" campaign.

Among the demonstrators was Wei Jinsheng, a renowned exiled mainland political dissident. Wei joined his fellow mainland pro-democracy activists in singing a Taiwan-originating Mandarin pop song "Wake Up When Dream Goes By" with adapted lyrics to accentuate their aversion to the Chinese Communist Party.
The demonstrators carried English posters bearing words "Say bye-for-good to CCP." Some posters were written in Chinese with words standing for "CCP is moving toward collapse in an unique way."

Organizers said the rally was also aimed at celebrating the warm response to the "quitting the CCP" campaign. They said since the campaign was launched last December, more than 377,000 CCP members around the world have renounced their membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFERS CHEAPER PRICE FOR PATRIOT PAC III: MND REPORT

TEXT.P: The United States has offered a cheaper price for the Patriot PAC III anti-missile system to be sold to Taiwan, according to a Ministry of National Defense (MND) report sent to the Legislative Yuan Sunday.
The report said the U.S. military has agreed to deduct the research and development cost from the Patriot PAC III price to be offered to Taiwan.
According to the report, each Patriot PAC III missile to be sold to Taiwan carries a price tag of about US$3.01 million, lower than the US$3.2 million price offered to the Netherlands and Japan.
In the face of China's ever mounting missile threat, the MND report said Taiwan badly needs to purchase the Patriot anti-missile defense system.
"As China has pointed hundreds of tactical missiles at Taiwan, we urgently need to purchase anti-missile defense system to safeguard our national security," the report said.
At present, the report said, the military's anti-missile system can only protect northern Taiwan.

Noting that the Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries can be flexibly deployed and fired by a remote-controlled system, the report said the planned procurement of six Patriot PAC IIIs is aimed at beefing up the nation's anti-missile defense capabilities.

"Once we acquire the new anti-missile defense system, we'll be able to protect major cities in northern, central and southern parts of the island as well as major strategic locations from China's missile attacks," the report said, adding that the new batteries are expected to offer protection for 70 percent of local population and more than 60 percent of industrial production facilities.

The six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries are part of a package of advanced weapons Taiwan intends to buy from the UNited States. The package also includes eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 Orion P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

The Cabinet already approved the MND's proposal to mark down the budget ceiling for the procurement package from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.48 billion) after a plan to build the submarines in Taiwan was dropped and the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. currency in recent months.

The revised procurement proposal will soon be referred to the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan for screening and approval. The MND report about the Patriot PAC III's performance and price tag was part of the ministry's efforts to seek legislative support for the bill.

The arms procurement package has been stalled for a long time. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus urged the opposition camp Sunday to stop boycotting the package for the sake of national interests.

DPP legislative whip Lai Ching-teh said he keenly hopes the opposition People First Party (PFP) can agree to include the package into the March 25 legislative screening agenda to allow for rational debate on the arms procurement issue.

Lai said that the DPP legislative caucus will take the initiative to negotiate the issue with its PFP counterpart in the hope that the proposed statute can be included on the legislature's agenda for the March 25 session and passed on to a legislative committee for further review.

Terming the package as a major measurement of reconciliation and cooperation between the ruling and opposition parties, Lai said that both President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman James Soong have voiced their support for the proposal in a 10-point joint statement issued at the end of their high-profile Feb. 24 meeting.

Should the PFP legislative caucus block the package from being included on the legislative agenda, it will trigger misgivings among the public about the significance of the Chen-Soong meeting, Lai explained, adding that neither party wants to see this.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S RISE MEANS BOTH CRISIS AND OPPORTUNITY FOR TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday China's rise as a regional military power means both a crisis and an opportunity for Taiwan.
Hsieh made the remarks while attending an annual meeting of an association of students who had pursued advanced studies in Japan.
Hsieh, who once did advanced study in law at Kyoto University in the Japanese ancient capital of Kyoto, said China's military expansion and bellicosity pose a threat to Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Hsieh said, China's rise a regional military power has alarmed many free and democratic countries. For instance, the United States and Japan have for the first time included the Taiwan Strait security as one of their common strategic objective in their recent joint defense statement.
In his view, Hsieh said, the development offers an opportunity for Taiwan to strengthen substantive exchanges with Japan.
It has not been easy to expand Taiwan-Japan relations, Hsieh said, adding that Taiwan should grasp the new opportunity to develop closer ties with Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DELEGATION VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: A Japanese delegation, headed by Tokuichiro Tamazawa, a member of the lower house of the Japanese Diet, toured Taiwan's frontline island of Kinmen Sunday.

The delegation visited the Shuitou port where a Kinmen ferry boat was carrying Taiwan passengers back to Kinmen from mainland China's Xiamen port and a mainland ferry boat was waiting for taking Kinmen passengers to Xiamen.
Tamazawa said he was impressed by such direct shipping services across the Taiwan Strait, also known as the "mini three links."

The "mini three links" refer to direct shipping, mail and trade links between Taiwan-held Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/Mawei in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian. Direct cross-strait transportation links have been suspended for more than five decades, but Taiwan has opened Kinmen and Matsu for direct shipping links with Fujian as part of its efforts to promote cross-strait rapprochement. Kinmen and Matsu lie closer to Fujian than to Taiwan. Tamazawa said he believes that the opening of the "mini three links" will contribute to cross-strait peace and stability in East Asia.

Tamazawa said he hopes Taiwan's government authorities will allow foreign citizens to travel from Kinmen directly to Xiamen by ship in the future. "I'm interested in making such a direct voyage, " he added.

The delegation is composed of Japanese Diet members and other elected representatives and senior executives of several pro-Taiwan civic groups. Tamazawa and delegation members met with Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng in the morning and also toured major Kinmen tourist attractions. The delegation arrived in Taiwan Friday for a goodwill visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH 26 MARCH AIMED AT ACCENTUATING TAIWAN'S DESIRE FOR PEACE

TEXT.P: The planned March 26 march in Taipei against China's anti-secession law is aimed at accentuating Taiwan's aspirations for peace, democracy and security, a former top mainland policy planner said Sunday.

Legislator Tsai Ing-wen, who had been Mainland Affairs Council chairwoman before becoming a lawmaker, said the upcoming march against China's newly enacted law targeting Taiwan is of great significance.

"The protest march is very important. It will inspire Taiwan people to reflect on the crisis across the Taiwan Strait as well as let the world understand local people's resolve to pursue democracy, peace and security," Tsai said.

Stressing that brute force or non-peaceful means should never be an option in maintaining any form of relationship, Tsai said China's so-called anti-secession law violates this basic principle of a civilized society.

"The March 26 protest march will caution the international community that China's anti-secession law is a potential threat not only to Taiwan but also to the whole world, " Tsai said, adding that the street parade is an expression of Taiwan people's feelings and aspirations. Tsai made the remarks at a news conference held by the Democracy, Peace, Protect Taiwan Alliance which is organizing the March 26 protest march.
Representatives of major social groups who will mobilize their members to join the street parade through major streets in Taipei also spoke at the news conference.

Taipei Society President Hung Yu-hung said the society will for the first time in more than 10 years join the street parade to tell the world that no other country can decide on the future of the people of Taiwan and to show Taiwan people's resolve to protect their present democratic way of life and their self-determination right.
Many ruling Democratic Progressive Party officials and lawmakers also attended the news conference to introduce the signs, slogans, commemorative badges to be used in the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, March 21, or the 12th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1685: Johann Sebastian Bach, German composer and organist who is considered to be among the greatest composers in history, is born.
1804: A new civil code, the Code Napoleon, comes into force in France.
1829: An earthquake rocks Spain, killing some 6,000 people.
1908: French aviator Henri Farman flies over Paris with the first air passenger.
1927: The Northward Expeditionary Forces led by Commander in Chief Chiang Kai-shek take the city of Shanghai.
1939: Wang Ching-wei, who fled from Chungking to Hanoi, Vietnam, escapes an assassination attempt in his residence in the early morning, but his secretary, Tseng Chung-min, dies of a gunshot wound. Wang later established a puppet regime in Nanking on March 29, 1940.
1940: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is posthumously declared the Founding Father of the Republic of China for his life-long contributions to the revolution. The decision was made at a meeting of the Kuomintang Central Standing Committee.
1950: President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Chiang Ching-kuo chief of the General Headquarters, Political Warfare Department under the Ministry of National Defense.
1953: Nikita Khrushchev is appointed first secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, succeeding Georgi Malenkov who becomes Soviet premier.
1966: The National Assembly elects President Chiang Kai-shek to a fourth term as president of the Republic of China.
1972: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected to a fifth six-year term.
1973: An Asian small- and medium-size enterprise league is inaugurated in Taipei.
1975: Kao Cheng is named minister and charge d'affaires of the Chinese Embassy in Tonga.
1975: Dr. Albert M.J. Parisis, deputy speaker of the Belgian House of Representatives, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1975: Republic of China officials stationed in Phnom Penh return to Taipei.
1977: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi resigns after losing her seat in India's parliamentary elections.
1978: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected by the National Assembly as president for the sixth constitutional presidential term of the Republic of China.
1984: President Chiang Ching-kuo is reelected for a second six-year term.
1989: Beijing's leaders announce new controls and taxes on private business, rural factories and free-market farming.
1990: Lee Teng-hui wins 641 votes out of the 668 votes in the National Assembly and is elected as the eighth-term president of the Republic of China.
1993: Republic of Nauru President Bernard Dowiyogo visits Taipei.
1996: India successfully launches its domestically produced one-ton class satellite into orbit.
1998: King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia grants a royal pardon to his son, Norodom Ranariddh.
2000: U.S. Reform Party presidential candidate Patrick Buchanan praises the people of Taiwan for their courage in defying Beijing's bullying tactics and threats by electing opposition politician Chen Shui-bian as the ROC's next president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In your government, why should you think it necessary to depend upon capital punishment? Wish for honesty, and the people will be honest. The moral power of rulers is as the wind, and that of the people is as the grass. Whithersoever the wind blows, the grass is sure to bend."

DOC.HEADLINE: DECISION ON WHETHER U.S. DEFENDS TAIWAN UP TO PRESIDENT: U.S. GENERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 20 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: It's up to the U.S. president to decide whether the United States will defend Taiwan if China attacks the island, a top U.S. military official said Sunday.
Gen. Richard Myers, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, made the comments while responding to questions in an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press" program.

Asked whether the United States would defend Taiwan if Beijing deemed it necessary to use "non-pacific means" against Taiwan as is authorized in China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law, Myers said: "Obviously, the president makes that policy and makes those decisions, and the military will do what we have to do."

Pointing to the fact that President George W. Bush has stated that there should be no change in the Taiwan Strait status quo by force by either side, the general said: "Clearly, its not in anybody's interest to settle this by force."

The program also showed a videotape of President Bush's previous remarks relating to the U.S. stance on defending Taiwan. The president said in 2001 that the United States has an obligation to defend Taiwan and that it would do "whatever it took to help Taiwan defend herself, that's our policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP ARRIVES IN MIAMI FOR TRANSIT STOP
DOC.DATELINE: Miami, Florida, March 20 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu arrived in Miami Sunday for a transit stop on her way back to Taipei after concluding a two-leg Central America diplomatic tour that took her to El Salvador and Guatemala.

Lu was greeted by William Brown, acting chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan -- the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties -- and David Ta-wei Lee, the ROC representative to the United States, upon her arrival at Miami International Airport from Guatemala aboard a charter flight.
Lu dined with Taiwan expatriates in the Miami region in the evening. She is scheduled to visit the U.S. National Hurricane Center and the Fort Lauderdale city government and harbor facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Congress Gives Parents a Voice in Schiavo Case. With the clock running down on how much longer Terri Schiavo can remain alive, congressional leaders announced an unprecedented agreement that would allow Schiavo's parents to petition the federal courts to have a feeding tube replaced for their brain-damaged daughter.

The Straits Times : Cholesterol drug - health alert for Asians.
Researchers here have raised the alarm over acholesterol-lowering drug which a landmark study indicates has potentially more harmful side-effects in Asians than in Caucasians.
The study found that the concentration of the popular drug Crestor (rosuvastation) that lingered in Chinese people was twice that in Caucaians, despite both talking the same dosage of the medicine.

The Washington Post: House Debates Schiavo Bill Passed by Senate.
Legislation from weekend session would give federal courts jurisdiction over Fla. woman's case.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MUST CLARIFY ANTI-SECESSION LAW TO RICE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Beijing authorities must clarify to visiting U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice the "non-peaceful means" clause of China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, a top Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Monday.

Outgoing MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san also said that Rice is expected to stress Washington's firm stance to Beijing that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should engage in constructive exchanges and resume peaceful dialogue to resolve their differences.

Rice arrived in Beijing Sunday for a two-day visit on the last leg of her six-nation Asian tour. She met with Chinese President Hu Jintao and Premier Wen Jiabao on her first day and is scheduled to meet with Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing on Monday.

Speaking at his last press conference as MAC vice chairman, Chiu said that major nations around the world have expressed their concerns about the enactment of the law which he said has raised tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

Chiu, who has resigned to run for the magistrate seat in the central county of Taichung, also said that Rice is expected to express the U.S. position that any unilateral moves that increases tensions are not helpful and that the Anti-Secession Law is not helpful in reducing cross-strait tensions,

Chiu added that Beijing has not clarified to the international community under what conditions exactly it would be authorized by the law to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan, saying that this has caused great concern around the globe.

Meanwhile, Lai Ching-teh, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that the DPP caucus salutes Rice's determination in maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and the way she has conveyed U.S. opposition to a possible lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China.
Lai said that prior to arriving in Beijing, Rice had expressed her concerns in Japan and South Korea over China's growing defense budgets and military buildup.
Rice also reiterated the U.S. position of opposing any unilateral moves to change the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, Lai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE SECRETARY-GENERAL PREDICTS 2ND CHEN-SOONG MEETING

TEXT.P: Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Monday that he believes there will certainly be a second meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong.

Nevertheless, Yu said while meeting with reporters that currently, he and PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng have no plans to meet with each other to make preparations for a second Chen-Soong meeting.
In their meeting Feb. 24, Chen and Soong reached consensus on various issues relating to constitutional reform, cross-strait relations and other matters.
In response to recent media reports that the president would meet with Soong again, Yu said it wouldn't be a surprise as the two had said that their Feb. 24 meeting was just the first meeting.
Asked when the second Chen-Soong meeting would take place, Yu said that it's up to the staff of the two camps to work out a plan.
Meanwhile, on behalf of the president, Yu on Sunday offered his condolences to Chin and his family for the death of Chin's father.
It is expected that President Chen will visit Chin and his family Monday afternoon to express his sympathy.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE URGES CHINA TO COOL CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS CAUSED BY NEW LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, March 21 (CNA) (By Liao Chen-yi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Visiting U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice urged Beijing at a news conference Monday to take steps to cool tensions that have flared across the Taiwan Strait since the passage of the Anti-Secession Law, describing the law as an unwelcome piece of legislation.

Noting that cross-Taiwan Strait issues should be resolved by the two sides themselves in a peaceful manner, Rice said that any unilateral moves that increase tensions are not helpful and that the Anti-Secession Law is not helpful in reducing cross-strait tensions.

Earlier in the day, Rice met with Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing for a talk. Rice reportedly said to Li that the United States' "one China" policy and its commitment to the Three Communiques remain unchanged, but the obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act demand that the United States make clear to both parties that unilateral moves are not helpful.
Reiterating Washington's concerns over the development of cross-strait relations, Rice stressed that cross-strait differences must be resolved peacefully.

Rice focused on the common interest of a more peaceful and secure Asia-Pacific region. She also pushed China to improve its human rights while warning that the North Korea nuclear standoff cannot go on forever.

For his part, Li told Rice that the Taiwan issue remains the biggest challenge in Beijing-Washington relations and whether this issue can be properly handled will directly affect how U.S.-China relations unfold.
Rice was to leave the Chinese capital later Monday at the end of her six-nation Asian tour that has also taken her to India, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Japan and South Korea.

The Washington Post: House Joins Senate in Approving Schiavo Bill.
President Bush signs measure that gives federal courts jurisdiction over.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORT ABOUT FORMING 400-MEMBER SPECIAL FORCE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense Monday denied the existence of any plan to organize an additional elite unit for counter-terrorism or to guard against a "decapitation strike" from China as reported by local media.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Defense Committee meeting, both Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh and Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chu Kai-sheng said the media report about a plan to form a "400-member special force" was only speculation.
According to the media report, the ROC Army is planning to organize a 400-member elite unit to cope with possible terrorist attacks and China's "decapitation attack" against Taiwan.

Decapitation strategies short-circuit command and control systems, wipe out nationwide nerve centers and leave the opponent hopelessly immobilized. Many military observers say the mainland is very likely to use this strategy to invade Taiwan by seizing the island's center of power, the capital and its top leaders.

Under the Cabinet's counter-terrorism action plan, Huo said, the military is tasked with offering necessary support. Against this backdrop, Huo said, the military is determined to beef up its special forces' combat capabilities.
Nevertheless, Huo stressed that the military has no plan to organize a new 400-member elite unit.

Huo also denied a media report about the defense ministry having a plan to spend a large sum of money to open special production lines to manufacture equipment or weapons needed by the existing special forces.
"The report is not true," Huo said, adding that while some of the weapons or equipment needed by the special forces are produced at home, many other items are procured from abroad.

As the number of each item needed by the special forces is not large, Huo said the military has traditionally not needed a special production line to produce a specific item to meet the demand of special forces.
Speaking on the same occasion, Army Commander-in-Chief Chu Kai-sheng said the Iraq War shows that modern warfare mainly features combined services attacks.

"As a result, special forces will play a critical role in future warfare. We must beef up our combat capabilities and equipment used by special forces, " Chu said. But he added that the ROC Army has no plan to form an elite "counter-terrorism" or special force to counter an attempted decapitation strike.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Churches unite to demand an election pledge on abortion.
Abortion was propelled to the centre of the election campaign yesterday as the Church of England threw its weight behind demands for a thorough review of legislation.
The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr Rowan Williams, who declared that there was a "groundswell of distaste" at the way the current law works, was backed by senior Anglican clergy who not only questioned the current 24-week time limit, but also the whole of the 38-year-old Abortion Act.
Financial Times: US-EU trade talks in crisis.
European Union finance ministers on Sunday night agreed on sweeping plans to rewrite the EU's stability and growth pact, clearing the way for flexible new fiscal rules to be agreed at a summit on Tuesday.
Under a breakthrough compromise deal, Germany would be able to cite the costs of its reunification as an excuse for breaking the European Union's stability and growth pact.
