DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Suspect Is Detained in Chubais Attack.
Police detained a highly decorated former special forces commando, who is a neighbor of Anatoly Chubais and whose wife's car was spotted at the scene of Thursday's ambush of the Unified Energy Systems chief. But questions were raised about why an explosives expert and Afghan war veteran would give investigators such an obvious lead.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 13 points to close at 6,040, with 20,102 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 18 points to finish at 6,042, with 120 contract transactions, while June futures increased 3 points to close at 6,018, with 33 contracts traded. September futures lost 4 points to finish at 5,915, with 55 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 22 points to close at 5,940, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 6,027 points for April, 6,024 points for May, 6,015 points for June, 5,919 points for September and 5,918 points for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also mixed.
April TE futures gained 0.9 points to close at 228.35, with 2,465 contracts changing hands, while May TE futures moved up 1.25 points to finish at 228.30, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures increased 2.2 points to finish at 990.8, with 2,222 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gave up 0.4 points to close at 988, with 14 contracts traded.
June TF futures surged 1.6 points to close at 990, with one contract traded and September TF futures fell 1.2 points to finish at 985.2, with only one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREIGN EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.142 to close at the day's high of NT$31.294.
A total of US$949 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$31.181 and slid to a low of NT$31.173 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 15.01 points to close at 6,058.96.
The bourse opened at 6,056.10 and fluctuated between 6,051.53 and 6,077.94 during trading. A total of 3.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.61 billion (US$2.03 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories moved up, with construction issues gaining the most of 2.0 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks and foodstuff stocks both at 0.2 percent.
Paper and pulp issues gave up 0.7 percent.
Plastic and chemical shares and banking and financial shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 430 to 420, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DON'T TURN ANTI-SECESSION LAW PROTEST INTO PRO-INDEPENDENCE RALLY: KMT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on Monday cautioned against turning the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-sponsored March 26 protest march into a pro-independence rally.

Chen Chieh, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, said that if the march, aimed at showing the people's displeasure with China's Anti-Secession Law, turns into a pro-independence rally, it will confuse the focus of the event and bring other adverse effects.
The KMT is asking that all participants be rational, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC CASE WILL BE HANDLED FAIRLY: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The court case involving United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) will be handled impartially, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.

UMC, the world's second-largest chip foundry after Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., has been charged with unlawfully passing on capital and technology to Chinese-based He Jian Technology Co. in Suzhou. UMC headquarters and factories in Taipei and Hsinchu were searched by prosecutors Feb. 15 and as of Monday, 25 current and former UMC employees have been investigated.

UMC Chairman Robert Tsao ran an advertisement in major newspapers Monday - - the second time he has done this -- saying that UMC helped He Jian, who in turn paid for the assistance with 15 percent of its stock, worth some US$110 million.

Tsao also said UMC wrote a letter to the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs March 18 to ask for administrative guidance so that the stocks could be smoothly transferred to UMC.
Noting that all transfers of corporate stocks involve the issue of investment, Ho said that the UMC case will be dealt with impartially.
Since the UMC-He Jian stock transfer is an investment issue, Ho said, it should not have been carried out without prior government approval.

In addition, Ho said, UMC's "help" to He Jian involved technical cooperation, something that also needed government permission. Ho said that the economics ministry will find out whether UMC's technical assistance to He Jian occurred before the Statue Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area was amended or afterward.

Should the "technical cooperation" have occurred before the statute was amended, then UMC will only be fined up to NT$25 million (US$800,000) . If it occurred after the statute was amended, UMC employees involved could face jail terms, Ho said.
The Republic of China government bans individuals or companies from investing in wafer plants in China without government permission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATRIATES PROTEST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: About 10,000 overseas Taiwanese in 54 countries have shown their displeasure with China's Anti-Secession Law by marching on Chinese embassies and writing letters to the lawmakers of the countries where they live, Overseas Chinese Commission Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei said Monday.
Chang made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

China's rubber-stamp parliament, the National People's Congress, approved the law March 14, authorizing the Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

According to the People's Daily newspaper in China, Article 8 of the Anti- Secession Law states: "If the Taiwan independence secessionist forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China, or that major incidents entailing Taiwan's secession from China should occur, or that possibilities for a peaceful reunification should be exhausted, the state shall employ non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to protect China's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The State Council and the Central Military Commission shall decide on and execute the non-peaceful means and other necessary measures and report to the National People's Congress Standing Committee."

DOC.HEADLINE: HACKING IS NO GAME FOR ACCUSED SOUTH KOREAN CYBER GAME ENGINEER

TEXT.P: An engineer with a South Korean company that makes cyber games was arrested Monday for allegedly breaking into the computer system of a Taiwanese competitor and stealing vital business information, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported.

The South Korean computer engineer, surnamed Lee, was accused by Taiwan's cyber game company INSREA of penetrating the company's Internet firewall and stealing business intelligence and deleting vital corporate uplink data, CIB investigators said.
Lee, who was assigned to Taipei by his South Korean company Webzen, was arrested at his Taipei County home and was handed over to the Taipei Prosecutors' Office for further questioning.
According to CIB investigators, INSREA and Webzen were business partners until they had a falling out in recent months due to competition and conflicts of interest.

After examining and cross-comparing computer data provided by INSREA, CIB investigators concluded that Lee was the one who hacked into INSREA's system and destroyed information after the two companies ended their partnership last August.

During Monday's questioning, Lee said that INSREA was the sole agent of Webzen products in the Taiwan area. After it established its own branch office in Taipei, Webzen wanted to retrieve part of the operational business rights for some of the games in Taiwan, so he was assigned to Taipei.

Lee denied the hacking accusation, claiming that for the convenience of data transfer, he was authorized by INSREA to use that company's Internet protocol (IP) and he changed some relevant information while INSREA staff looked on.

But the INSREA people said, according to the CIB investigators, that Lee continued to intrude into INSREA's core systems after the companies ended the relationship last August, resulting in huge losses for INSREA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN ANNOUNCES BID FOR TAICHUNG COUNTY MAGISTRATE

TEXT.P: Outgoing Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san formally announced his candidacy Monday for magistrate of the central Taiwan county of Taichung.

Chiu told a news conference that after careful consideration and with encouragement from people in his home county, he decided to seek the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) nomination to run in the year-end magistrate election.
As a Taichung County native, Chiu said he aspires to win the magistrate post to accelerate the county's development in various fields.

Noting that the central government has planned many ambitious development projects for the county, including the central Taiwan high-tech industrial park, the Taichung Harbor free trade port zone and the Chingchuankang International Airport, Chiu said the realization of these projects requires the close cooperation of the Taichung County Government.

Taichung County has traditionally been a stronghold of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party. Chiu said he hopes his magistrate candidacy will mark the beginning of the county's administrative reform.
"I'll bring vision and hope to the county, one of the island's most populous and spacious constituencies," Chiu said.
Chiu tendered his resignation from his current MAC post last Friday. Premier Frank Hsieh has approved his resignation, which will take effect April 2.

Two former senior officials -- former Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Luo Wen-chia and former Vice Minister of Civil Service Lee Chun-yi -- as well as several incumbent DPP legislators attended the news conference to lend their support for Chiu's bid.
Former DPP Legislator Lin Feng-hsi has long made known his resolve to seek the party's nomination to run for the county's top administrative post.

Chiu said the DPP has a well-designed intra-party primary mechanism to decide its candidate for the year-end election in each constituency. "I'll compete with Lin strictly in line with our party rules. Both of us will engage in a 'gentlemen's race.' Whoever wins the candidacy will certainly have the best wishes and support from the loser," Chiu said.
Chiu had been a prosecutor and a legislator before assuming his current MAC post.

The post to be vacated by Chiu will be filled by You Ying-lung, vice president of the Ketagalan Institute, an independent, non-partisan educational institution founded by President Chen Shui-bian in March 2003 to promote civic values through education, policy research and public forums.

You, 49, an academic-turned-politician, had been DPP deputy secretary-general and vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission before becoming Ketagalan Institute vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: FSC PREDICTS UP TO US$40 B. TO ENTER TAIWAN SECURITIES MARKET

TEXT.P: US$10 billion to US$40 billion will enter the island's securities market with a more liberalized investment environment, a government financial official said Monday.
Kong Jaw-sheng, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, (FSC) made the remarks when he was reporting to the Finance Committee at the Legislative Yuan.

He noted that Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) raised its weighting of Taiwan stocks, increasing Taiwan's Limited Investability Factor (LIF) from 0.55 to 0.75 last year, and that it will increase Taiwan's LIF from 0.75 to 1 at the end of this May.

In addition, the FTSE Group, a joint venture between the Financial Times and the London Stock Exchange, announced in September 2004 that Taiwan had officially been added to its Watch List and would be reviewed for a possible upgrading to developed market status in September.

Looking ahead, he said that his commission will work toward accelerating the merger of financial institutions, the planning of an international board for capital markets, promoting of the listing of securitization products, stepping up cracking down on financial crimes, and the launching of the Taiwan Government bond index by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR REVIEW OF TAX INCENTIVE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the government should establish an efficient incentive system to encourage technological innovations and upgrade the nation's overall competitiveness.
Chen made the remarks after presiding over a meeting of the presidential economic advisory group.

"The administration should inspire industrial upgrading based on the principle of encouraging the creation of new values, " Chen said, adding that by so doing, the nation's overall competitiveness can be enhanced.
Against this backdrop, Chen said, the existing tax incentive mechanism should be subject to an overall review in order to ensure that national resources are wisely and efficiently used.

"Academic institutes, government-funded research bodies and the private sector should pool their resources in technological research and development (R&D) to enhance operational efficiency," Chen said.

In response to criticism that the government has offered too many tax incentives for high-tech industries, Chen said the government may have to set a timeframe or conditions for ending R&D tax privileges, commonly known as "sunset clauses, " to prevent abuse of the relevant tax incentives.

Chen further said all new science-based industrial parks now under construction should give priority to accommodating companies devoted to production of high-end or high value-added products and services.

"Invention and innovation will be core values for our technological development, " Chen said, adding that he has directed the Cabinet to come up with a comprehensive report on relaxation of restrictions on high-tech development and investment.
The report will be unveiled at the presidential economic advisory group's next meeting, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Congress Passes and Bush Signs Legislation on Schiavo Case.
The approval and signing of the measure allows a federal court to intervene in the case of a brain-damaged woman in Florida.
The Wall Street Journal: Diller's IAC Nears Deal for Jeeves.
Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp last night was near a deal to purchase the fifth-largest Web- search service, Ask Jeeves Inc., for around $2 billion in stock, according to people familiar with the matter, marking an aggressive move by the electronic-commerce company into the Internet's most competitive arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTO PARTS TRADE MISSION TO VISIT U.S. IN JUNE

TEXT.P: An auto parts trade mission jointly organized by the Taiwan Foreign Trade Development Council (TAITRA) and domestic leading manufacturers will visit the United States in June, TAITRA officials said Monday.

The mission is scheduled to arrive in Detroit June 5 for the tour in which members of the mission will visit the three main U.S. carmakers -- GM, Daimler Chrysler and Ford -- as well as other leading auto parts manufacturers, to seek opportunities for strategic cooperation, the officials disclosed.
The mission will be composed of representatives from Yulon Motor, Yulon Nissan Motor, China Motor and 15 other OEMs, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MAINTAINS STANCE ON ANTI-SECESSION LAW: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The United States has clearly expressed its stance on China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, and U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to China has not moved away from that position, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Monday.
Cho Jung-tai made the remarks when he was asked whether Rice weakened the U.S. position on the newly passed law during her visit to China.

Rice said in a press conference in Beijing earlier that day that the U.S. hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait will not take unilateral action to change the status quo or raise cross-strait tension and that China will use peaceful means to resolve cross-strait disputes.
Cho stressed that the U.S. State Department said March 14 that the passage of the law was "unfortunate" and that "it really does not serve the cause of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait."
Cho said that Rice's remarks in Beijing have not been any more conservative or stronger that those expressed in the past.
He said that the U.S. stance is clear, that Taiwan has also clearly stated its position and that it now remains to be seen whether or not the Beijing authorities understand this.
Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) also said Rice's remarks have not veered away from the basic U.S. stance.
Michel Lu also said that the ministry appreciates Rice's remarks that the legislation of the new law is "not a welcome development."

DOC.HEADLINE: 43.7% OF FOREIGN SPOUSES IN TAIPEI COUNTY NOWHERE TO CONTACT

TEXT.P: Nearly 44 percent of foreign spouses and brides from China in Taipei County cannot be traced, Taipei county government officials said Monday.

Over the past six months, an official said, the county government has assigned contract staff to interview 47,191 foreign and Chinese citizens who have been allowed to enter Taiwan and take residence in the county by marriage.

"Much to our dismay, only slightly more than half of them could be contacted smoothly, while up to 43.7 percent were nowhere to be found, " the official said, adding that the county government is worried about the whereabouts of those "missing" spouses.
Further probes found that 10,211 of the "missing" spouses did not reside at their formally stated addresses, 6,933 had left Taiwan and 3,502 were divorced.
"We are worried that the missing spouses came to Taiwan through marriages of convenience," the official said.
According to the official, the county government has been cooperating with police authorities in addressing the problem.
"It's like looking for a needle in a haystack to locate those 'missing' spouses," the official said.

With more and more local men tying the knot with Southeast Asian women and women from China, about 340,000 foreign and Chinese spouses have taken up residence in Taiwan. Among all counties and cities around the island, Taipei County boasts the largest number of such spouses.
Because of language barriers and different cultural backgrounds and values, the official said, many of the women have had difficulty adapting to the local lifestyle and need assistance.

According to the survey results, the official said, 55 percent of the spouses interviewed said they most need assistance in landing jobs, receiving vocational training and securing protection for their work rights.

Many respondents also expressed keen interest in studying Mandarin and Taiwanese, and some of them said they want to learn about Taiwan's social welfare service regulations, get motorcycle licenses and obtain information about the national health insurance program.

The official said the county government has drawn up a comprehensive educational and guidance program for these women, including offering language courses at various elementary schools around the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILL JOIN MARCH 26 PROTEST

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will join the March 26 protest to show Taiwan's anger about Beijing 's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Monday.
Cho said the premier wants to express his solidarity with his countrymen when the country is facing an unprecedented threat from China.

He quoted Hsieh as saying that the protest will demonstrate to the world Taiwan's determination to pursue peace and to defend itself, and will show that Beijing's threat only helps the Taiwan people to close their ranks even tighter.

The protest, organized by the so-called Alliance to Defend Taiwan with Democracy and Peace, will also demonstrate to Beijing the powerful will of the people, which would be smothered under an authoritarian regime such as that of China, the premier was quoted as saying.

Cho said the premier urges the public to join the protest, noting that the more of them who show up March 26, the more international publicity the protest will generate and the more the international community will understand Beijing's threat to Taiwan.

As a citizen of Taiwan, Cho quoted the premier as saying, he cannot be absent from the protest when the world's major powers such as the United States, Japan and the European Union are speaking out against China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO LEAD 100,000 PEOPLE IN MARCH 26 PROTEST

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Monday that it will lead 100,000 supporters in a March 26 protest called to vent the island's wrath with China's newly enacted Anti-Secession Law.

The party said that in order to ensure a large turnout, its Central Executive Committee asked party members and party officials Monday to show up at the protest and to bring their followers with them.

TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said the party has charted a train March 26 to ferry its followers in northern Taiwan to the Taipei City district of Wanhua, from where they will march toward downtown Taipei.
TSU supporters in central and southern Taiwan will be brought to Taipei on tour buses, Chen said.

Although the protest is intended to show the people's opposition to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, Chen said his party will take advantage of the event to press its demand to change the official name of the country from Republic of China to Taiwan.

Chen said the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader, " former President Lee Teng-hui, will deliver a speech to the demonstrators when they converge in the square in front of the Presidential Office at the end of the protest but will not join them on the march.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENDS CLEAR MESSAGE OF OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW: DPP

TEXT.P: The United States has sent a clear message of its opposition to China's Anti-Secession Law, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.
William C.T. Lai was responding to U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's remarks in Beijing earlier that day after concluding her two-day visit there.

Rice said the passage of the Anti-Secession law, which authorizes Beijing to adopt "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence, makes it harder for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in dialogue and that in the wake of the passage of the law, the U.S. hopes China will take measures to "demonstrate a willingness to reduce tension in the cross-strait environment."

Lai noted that Rice expressed concern about the growth of Beijing's military expenses and upgrading of its military might during her visit to Japan and South Korea prior to her visit to China. She also reaffirmed that the United States opposes either side of the Taiwan Strait doing anything unilaterally to either try to change the status quo or anything that increases the tension.

Lai also noted that the U.S. House of Representatives recently passed a resolution 424-four to express grave concern over the Anti-Secession Law and that U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher also said that the passage of the law is "unfortunate."

He said that as the United States, Japan and the European Union have expressed concern over the law, the people of Taiwan should take part in a protest march March 26 to show that the law has not only affected the rights of the Taiwan people but has also affected the peace and security of the Asia-Pacific region and that the international community should intervene to protect regional security.

Meanwhile, Chen Chieh, legislative caucus whip of the opposition Kuomintang, said that Rice's visit will not necessarily solve the cross-strait differences over the Anti-Secession Law and that an easing of tension will depend on the wisdom of leaders across the Taiwan Strait.
An opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator said Rice's remarks about Beijing taking measures to reduce cross-strait tension are only a reaffirmation of Washington's long-standing position.

But Lee Yung-ping, the PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that the aspirations of the pro-Taiwan independence activists that cross-strait tension will be raised and that the United States will be forced to pressure Beijing "will fall through."

Chen Chien-ming, caucus whip of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union in the legislature, said that Rice's remarks are so far the strongest protest against China and he urged Washington to be more active and to use a more substantive approach to support Taiwan's democracy and freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND ACCENTUATES NEED TO PROCURE PATRIOT PAC III

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh accentuated Monday the need for Taiwan to procure the U.S.-made Patriot PAC III anti-missile system, saying if the procurement plan is dropped, Taiwan will be unable to defend itself from China's missile attacks.
Huo made the remarks while fielding questions from opposition lawmakers at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.

In an attempt to persuade opposition lawmakers to support the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) long-stalled arms procurement package, Huo said if the plan to purchase six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries is killed, Taiwan will not have any anti-missile capability in the foreseeable future.

According to an MND written report presented to the legislative defense committee earlier in the day, Patriot PAC IIIs are the U.S. military's latest anti-missile system in active service. They are also the world's only batterfield-tested missile defense system.
Quoting data provided by the U.S. miltiary, the report said, the chances of a Patriot PAC III interceptor hitting its target reaches 90 percent.

During the 2003 Iraq War, the report said, the U.S. military deployed Patriot PAC II and PAC III anti-missile batteries in the batterfield. Iraq fired a total of 19 tactical missiles, with 10 falling in areas outside the Patriot's range and nine falling within the range. All of the nine Iraqi missiles entering the Patriot range were successfully intercepted, the report said.

According to a Pentagon report released in September 2004, the Patriot PAC III has completed batterfield tests and been deployed. In test-firings conducted in March, September and November 2004, the Patriot PAC III interceptors all could directly hit the incoming targets.

The MND report further said if its plan to purchase six Patriot PAC III batteries can clear the legislature smoothly, 70 percent of Taiwan's population and more than 60 percent of its industrial production facilities will be under the theater missile defense system's protection.
Meanwhile, the report said the United States has offered a cheaper price for the Patriot PAC III batteries to be sold to Taiwan.

As the U.S. military has agreed to deduct the research and development cost from the Patriot PAC III price to be offered to Taiwan, the report said, each interceptor will carry a price tag of about US$3.01 million, lower than the US$3.2 million price offered to the Netherlands and Japan.
In the face of China's ever mounting missile threat, the MND report said Taiwan badly needs to purchase the Patriot anti-missile defense system.
"As China has pointed hundreds of tactical missiles at Taiwan, we urgently need to purchase anti-missile defense system to safeguard our national security," the report said.
At present, the report said, the military's anti-missile system can only protect northern Taiwan.

Noting that the Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries can be flexibly deployed and fired by a remote-controlled system, the report said the planned procurement of six Patriot PAC IIIs is aimed at beefing up the nation's anti-missile defense capabilities.

"Once we acquire the new anti-missile defense system, we'll be able to protect major cities in northern, central and southern parts of the island as well as major strategic locations from China's missile attacks," the report said, adding that the new batteries are expected to offer protection for 70 percent of local population and more than 60 percent of industrial production facilities.

The six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries are part of a package of advanced weapons Taiwan intends to buy from the UNited States. The package also includes eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 Orion P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

The Cabinet already approved the MND's proposal to mark down the budget ceiling for the procurement package from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.48 billion) after a plan to build the submarines in Taiwan was dropped and the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. currency in recent months.

The revised procurement proposal will soon be referred to the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan for screening and approval. The MND report about the Patriot PAC III's performance and price tag was part of the ministry's efforts to seek legislative support for the bill.

The arms procurement package has been stalled for a long time. The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus urged the opposition camp Sunday to stop boycotting the package for the sake of national interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY HALF OF LABORERS GET TWO DAYS OFF PER WEEK: CLA POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the nation's laborers are now working five days a week, showing that the five-day workweek has become the mainstream work pattern, according to the results of a poll conducted by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) and released Monday.

Nearly 50 percent of laborers have two days off a week. In terms of businesses, 36.2 percent of businesses work five days a week, compared with 28.2 percent that work six days and 8.1 percent that work five-and-a-half days.
The number of laborers working five days a week was down 1.5 percent in 2004 from a year earlier, which the CLA attributed to the dramatic adjustment of working hours in the medical care sector.
In contrast, the number of those working flexitime on Saturday increased slightly by 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING INTENDS TO USE NON-PEACEFUL MEANS AGAINST TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: The recent enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law shows that Beijing intends to use non-peaceful means to solve the cross-Taiwan Strait dispute, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.

In a news release, Taiwan's top China policy formulating agency explained that the law describes abstract and ambiguous situations under which the Beijing authorities are allowed to resort to non-peaceful means against Taiwan, which is tantamount to a "blank check" for attack.
The move has triggered serious concern from the international community because it threatens the peace and stability of the East Asian region, the council went on.
The MAC also expressed appreciation for the United States, Japan, the European Union, Canada, Australia and many other countries for their open opposition to the law.

According to the People's Daily newspaper in China, Article 8 of the Anti- Secession Law states: "If the Taiwan independence secessionist forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China, or that major incidents entailing Taiwan's secession from China should occur, or that possibilities for a peaceful reunification should be exhausted, the state shall employ non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to protect China's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The State Council and the Central Military Commission shall decide on and execute the non-peaceful means and other necessary measures and report to the National People's Congress Standing Committee."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPRECIATES JAPAN'S OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed his appreciation Monday for Japan's speaking out against China's Anti-Secession Law, under which China gives itself the legal basis to attack Taiwan.

Chen told Japanese Dietman Tamazawa Tokuichiro, who is visiting Taiwan as the head of a pro-Taiwan group in Japan, that Beijing's threat to resort to force in settling its disputes with Taiwan is a setback to civilization, which favors the peaceful settlement of differences.
The president also expressed his concerns about the earthquake that rattled Fukuoka, Japan the previous day, causing mild casualties and damage.

He lauded Tokuichiro for helping to persuade the Japanese government to announce Feb. 19 that peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue is one of the strategic objectives shared by Tokyo and Washington.

The president said Tokuichiro and his group have also contributed significantly to Japan's support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and its decision to extend visa-free privileges to Taiwan tourists during the period of Expo 2005 Aichi, which will run from March 25 to September 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ADVISOR RECOMMENDS TAX INCENTIVES FOR NEW TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The government should encourage the development of new technology and new applications of old technology through offering grants or tax breaks, an economic advisor to President Chen Shui-bian recommended Monday.

In a report to the president, the chief economic advisor to the president, Shi Chin-tai, who is also the dean of the School of Science and Technology Management at National Tsin Hua University in Hsinchu, said the recipe for upgrading industry has been changed from "improving efficiency" to "developing new technology."
The job of upgrading well-developed technology should be left to the private sector, according to Shi.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, March 22, or the 13th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe -- German writer, scientist, master of poetry, drama and the novel, and one of the greatest thinkers of his age -- dies at the age of 82.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai, who declared himself emperor Dec. 12, 1915, is forced to cancel his imperial reign after 83 days and calls himself "president" again. He also appoints Hsu Shih-chang as premier.
1917: The United States becomes the first country to recognize the new provisional government in Russia after the collapse of the monarchy.
1927: The first troops of the National Revolutionary Army, under the leadership of Commander in Chief Chiang Kai-shek, enter Shanghai during a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1935: The first television service is inaugurated in Berlin, Germany.
1935: Persia changes its name to Iran.
1945: Jordan gains its independence.
1945: The Arab League is established in Cairo by seven Middle Eastern countries in order to coordinate political action and safeguard their sovereignty. The member countries are Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, Jordan and Yemen.
1954: Chiang Kai-shek is re-elected president of the Republic of China for a second six-year term.
1960: Chiang Kai-shek is reelected to a third term as president, while Chen Cheng is reelected for a second term as vice president.
1966: The National Assembly elects Premier Yen Chia-kan as the third vice president of the Republic of China.
1966: Relations between Beijing and Moscow deteriorate further when the Communist Chinese refuse to attend the 23rd national congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
1966: President Chiang Kai-shek signs into law and makes public the "Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion" amended by the National Assembly on March 19, 1966.
1972: Vice President C.K. Yen is elected to a second six-year term.
1973: President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Kiding Wang as the ROC ambassador to the Central African Republic.
1974: Y.T. Wong, director of the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, leaves for Rio de Janeiro to negotiate the purchase of soybeans.
1975: Tang Ching-hsuan, the new ROC ambassador to Honduras, and Konsin C. Shah, ROC consular-general in New York, leave Taiwan to take up their respective posts.
1976: A Sino-American seminar on biochemistry opens with 21 Chinese and American delegates, including U.S. Nobel laureate Stanford Moore, attending.
1983: Pu Nai-fu, a noted mainland Chinese writer with the pen name "Mr. Anonymous," arrives in Taipei from Hong Kong and issues a statement against the Communist Chinese.
1984: Lee Teng-hui is elected by the National Assembly as the seventh-term vice president of the Republic of China.
1990: Li Yuan-zu is elected vice president of the Republic of China.
1992: The Democratic Party in Albania scores a landslide victory in elections, ending Communist Party rule.
1997: Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama arrives in the Republic of China on Taiwan for a six-day visit.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian vows that he will do his best to ensure Taiwan's stable political and economic order and to set a good example for a peaceful power transition by cooperating with all political forces.
2001: The 2001 Taiwan International Orchid Exhibition opens in Taipei with more than 20,000 potted orchids of various kinds on display.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Now a man who is really a man of distinction is one who stands upon his own integrity and loves what is right: who forms a correct judgment of men by observing how they look as well as by regarding what they say. Reflection makes him humble in his estimate of himself as compared with other men. Such a man, whether he be in public life or in private life, will be a distinguished man."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA OPPOSES ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, March 21 (CNA) (By H.G. Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Canada has expressed clearly its opposition to China's recently passed Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Pierre Pettigrew said Monday.

Pettigrew made the remarks while responding to questions by Don Boudria, a member of the Canadian Parliament who heads the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group, during a question-and-answer session in the House of Commons.

Pettigrew reaffirmed that Canada is very concerned about the passage of the Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence. China's rubber-stamp parliament, the National People's Congress, passed the law March 14.
Canada is especially concerned about the "non-peaceful means" which it fears will lead to tensions in Taiwan and Southeast Asia, the minister said.

He said that Canada has unequivocally told the Chinese embassy in Ottawa and Beijing officials that Canada is opposed to the new law, and is opposed to either side of the Taiwan Strait taking unilateral actions, including the use of force, to change the status quo in the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO PLACE FAMILY ASSETS INTO BLIND TRUST

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday he will put his family assets into a blind trust to accentuate the government's sincerity and resolve in promoting clean politics.

Hsieh made the pledge during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wang Yu-ting asked the premier whether the government is sincere about establishing clean politics and stamping out official corruption.

Stressing that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has been committed to substantiating clean politics, Hsieh said he is willing to set an example for other politicians to follow by putting his family assets into a blind trust.
Hsieh said he has been discussing his asset trust plan with a professional accountant.
"A final deal on entrusting my family assets to professional managers can be struck soon," Hsieh said.

He further said the DPP administration will push for the establishment of an independent anti-corruption agency in the future to substantiate the goals of various "sunshine bills, " which have been enacted in the past few years, such as the Political Contribution Law, to prevent corruption and promote clean politics and transparency.

The government will also refer to practices adopted by foreign countries to revise existing laws and legislate new ones to facilitate probes into cases involving government employees suspected of acquiring assets illegally during their terms of office.

Current Taiwan laws do not require senior officials to put their assets into a blind trust. But President Chen Shui-bian entrusted his family assets to professional managers shortly after he won a second presidential term last May.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KMT CHAIRMAN ASPIRANTS AT LOGGERHEADS OVER MEMBERSHIP FEES ISSUE

TEXT.P: Two opposition Kuomintang vice chairmen who are vying for the party's top post are still at loggerheads over whether to allow KMT members who have not paid membership fees to vote in the party chairmanship election, and the issue may have to be resolved through a vote at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday.

Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is in favor of only allowing those who have paid their membership fees to vote in the election scheduled for July 16, said that it is simply "unreasonable" to have two different sets of rules for elections for party posts and elections for government posts.

Ma said that if those who have not paid their membership fees are allowed to vote in a party election while only those who have paid the fees are allowed to vote in elections for government positions, then the electorate for these two types of elections will be different and the election results "distorted."

A more reasonable approach would be to allow party members to make up for any unpaid fees, Ma said, adding that the amount can be discussed further. He said the figure should not exceed NT$900 (about US$28).

The other aspirant for the KMT chairmanship, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, also pointed out that the makeup of voters for party elections and elections for government positions are different because of the different rules regarding membership fees.

Wang said that at present, about 700,000 of the some 1 million KMT members are unwilling to pay membership fees, which he said demonstrates that they have "deviated from the party." If these members are allowed to vote, it will bring them back into the party fold, he said.

On media reports that the other KMT vice chairmen favor only allowing those who have paid their membership fees to vote in the chairmanship election, Wang said that they are voicing their "own opinions" and that the issue will be decided in a vote during the KMT Central Standing Committee in its regular meeting Wednesday.

The disagreement on the membership issue, a seemly trivial question that suddenly props up because of two strong contenders have entered the race instead of the one-man election in the past, between Ma and Wang can also be witnessed between their respective supporters.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, who supports Ma, said that if those who have not paid their membership fees are allowed to vote, then the precedent could be applied to the KMT primaries in the city and county elections, which he said would have a tremendous impact on the party system, adding that the KMT must therefore "think about it carefully."

Meanwhile, Legislator Ho Tsai-feng, who supports Wang, said that the Wang camp is confident that a vote on the issue in the KMT Central Standing Committee meeting will be in favor of allowing those who have not paid their membership fees to vote in the party chairmanship election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IN SAN FRANCISCO, CANADA TO RALLY AGAINST BEIJING LAW
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, March 21 (CNA) (By Chiang Chun, S.K. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An action committee representing the overseas Taiwanese community in San Francisco urged Taiwan expatriates Monday to participate in a rally March 26 in front of the Chinese consulate general to protest Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan.

The action committee called on Republic of China nationals, regardless of their political affiliations or ethnicity, to take part in the protest to safeguard Taiwan's security, which it said has come under greater military threat from China due to the adoption of the law which provides a legal basis to deal with Taiwan through "non-peaceful means."

It also issued a statement objecting to the law and stressing that other countries have no right to decide Taiwan's fate. Only the 23 million people of Taiwan are entitled to determine the country's future course, and Beijing must be cognizant of this fact and respect the will of the Taiwan people, it said.

Accusing Beijing of plotting to deny the ROC's sovereignty and to unilaterally alter the status quo in the Taiwan Strait with the law, the action committee said that the scheme has violated the U.N. Charter, undermined the international order and raised tensions in the region.
The law is tantamount to writing a blank check for Beijing to launch an attack against Taiwan at any time, the statement said.

The "ill-intentioned" law not only poses a huge threat to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the rest of East Asia, it also abuses the rights and free will of the Taiwan people, the committee said, adding that a strong protest must be lodged to condemn Beijing's actions.
It called on all overseas ROC nationals and the international community to back the Taiwan people's democracy and freedom.

Meanwhile, various Taiwanese organizations in eastern Canada are slated to stage a rally March 24 in Ottawa to protest the Anti-Secession Law enacted by Beijing March 14. Participants will gather on Parliament Hill before marching to the People's Republic of China Embassy to voice their protest. Several members of the Canadian Parliament are also expected to speak at the rally.

The Taiwan Compatriots Association in Ottawa said that the People's Republic of China, since its founding in 1949, has never for one day ruled Taiwan, and that the ROC is an independent and sovereign state.
With its "fabricated" one China policy and more than 700 missiles targeting Taiwan, Beijing poses a serious threat to the livelihood of the 23 million people of Taiwan, the association said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY WELCOMES RICE'S COMMENTS ON ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's recent comments in Beijing about the unhelpfulness of the Anti-Secession Law was a welcome development, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.
Lu made the comments at a news conference at the ministry's headquarters in Taipei.

According to Lu, Rice's talks in Beijing fully reflect the interests and values commonly shared and upheld by Taiwan and the U.S. Rice also reiterated that the U.S. hopes that democracy, peace and prosperity in the Taiwan Strait and the rest of the Asia-Pacific region is maintained.
Rice said Monday during her two-day visit to Beijing that Beijing's adoption of its Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan is not welcome and unhelpful to delicate cross-strait relations.

"The Anti-Secession Law was not a welcome development because anything that is unilateral that increases tensions, which clearly, the Anti-Secession Law did increase tensions, is not good," Rice said following meetings with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao, Premier Wen Jiabao and Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing.

"I did talk to my Chinese counterparts about hopefully taking measures in the wake of this Anti-Secession Law, taking measures that would demonstrate a willingness to reduce tensions in the cross-strait environment, " Rice told reporters. "We are not pleased when either side does anything unilaterally to either try to change the status quo or that increases tensions."

Rice paid her first visit as Secretary of State to Beijing after mainland China's National People's Congress overwhelmingly approved the law March 14 to fend off Taiwan independence through non-peaceful means, if necessary.

Beijing has never denounced the use of force against Taiwan despite the fact that the two sides of the strait split in the wake of a civil war in 1949. Taiwan and the mainland have been under separate governments since that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Camilla will be Queen unless MPs change law.
Camilla Parker Bowles will become Queen unless Parliament legislates to strip her of the right to the title, it was confirmed yesterday. The admission by the Department for Constitutional Affairs contradicts repeated assertions by Clarence House that she will be known only as Princess Consort on her husband's succession, and not Queen. Any change to her status may also have to be approved by the 17 parliaments in countries where the new King will be head of state. However, that runs the risk that some countries, such as Australia, Canada and New Zealand, may vote instead to become republics because they could not accept a"Queen Camilla".
Financial Times: Brown fears new pact could stop UK joining euro.
Gordon Brown indicated yesterday that the UK may face a new obstacle to euro entry, after EU finance ministers agreed on sweeping plans to rewrite its Stability and Growth Pact. As governments digested the implications of a new set of EU fiscal rules agreed at the weekend, the chancellor said he had ensured that a new medium-term deficit target would only apply to the 12 states within the eurozone, not those, like the UK, outside the euro. But speaking on his return from a Brussels summit of EU finance ministers, Mr Brown indicated that the new target - under which members must keep borrowing below 1 percent of national income over the medium term - would make it even harder for a Labour government to join the euro whilst retaining key domestic policy objectives.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY CANDIDACY REGISTRATION TO START MARCH 26

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Tuesday it will begin to accept candidacy registration for the May 14 National Assembly election this weekend.

Only political parties or private alliances composed of more than 20 members are eligible to register their individual candidates with the CEC because seats in the nation's first-ever and probably last mission-oriented National Assembly will be allotted to political parties or groups in proportion to the ballots they garner in the upcoming popular vote.

According to the National Assembly election rules, political parties or groups must deposit NT$100,000 in guaranty for each candidate they intend to nominate while registering their candidacy with the CEC. The money will not be refunded if the parties or groups fail to obtain a specified minimum number of votes in the election.

The candidacy registration will start at 8 a.m. March 26 and last through 5: 30 p.m. March 30, CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said, adding that the daily work hours are from 8 a.m. to noon and from 1:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m.

Candidates for the National Assembly seats must not be younger than 23. Election staff, military personnel in active service, conscripts on alternative services and cadets at military academies are banned from running in the election. But according to the newly revised Public Officials Election and Recall Law, students at civilian educational institutions and policemen will be eligible to vie for the National Assembly seats.

Teng said political parties or alliances must fill out candidacy application forms and produce their lists of individual candidates as well as other relevant documents and articles, including the candidates' mug shots and agreements to serve as a specific party's representatives in the National Assembly, while registering with the CEC at its headquarters in downtown Taipei.
Registration forms can be downloaded from the CEC's Web site at www.cec.gov.tw, Teng added.

The mission-oriented National Assembly will be tasked to screen a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last August, including changing the legislative electoral system to a "single seat, two ballots" system and phasing out the National Assembly to allow for holding a referendum on future constitutional amemdment proposals.
