DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April lost 32 points to close at 6,008, with 32,667 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved down 32 points to finish at 6,010, with 278 contracts traded, while June futures lost 29 points to finish at 6,000, with 53 contracts traded.
September futures lost 23 points to finish at 5,898, with 145 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 21 points to close at 5,900, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,040 for April, 6,042 for May, 6,029 for June, 5,921 for September and 5,921 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

April TE futures moved down 1.05 points to close at 227.3, with 3,359 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 0.9 points to finish at 227.5, with eight contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 1.6 points to close at 228.65, with one contract traded, while September TE futures moved down 0.55 points to close at 225.9, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures lost 8.8 points to finish at 982, with 3,539 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved down 7.6 points to end at 982, with 30 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down seven points to finish at 982, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures lost 12.8 points to end at 975.2, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN TO VISIT CHINA IN LATE MARCH

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang is slated to visit mainland China later this month in an effort to help forge rapport in cross-Taiwan Strait ties, a spokesman for the main opposition party said Tuesday.
Chiang will visit China from March 28 to April 1 at the head of a KMT delegation, but his itinerary has yet to be decided, the spokesman said.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan announced in late February that Chiang would travel to China this month and pay tribute at the mausoleum of Republic of China founding father Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing and at the tomb of the 72 martyrs who sacrificed their lives in a KMT-led revolution against China's last empire, the Ching Dynasty, in Guangzhou, southern Guangdong province.
The death of the 72 martyrs on March 29, 1911 is designated as the ROC's national Youth Day.

Chiang's trip will come after a large demonstration set for March 26 in Taipei by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in conjunction with its pro-Taiwan independence ally, Taiwan Solidarity Union, to protest the Anti-Secession Law adopted March 14 by Beijing with an eye to warding off Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS NO 'RASH' HIKES IN WATER, POWER RATES DURING HIS TERM

TEXT.P: In the face of a new surge in oil prices on the global market that are expected to push up consumer prices at home, Premier Frank Hsieh pledged Tuesday not to "rashly" raise water and electricity rates during his term.
Hsieh made the promise while fielding questions from opposition Kuomintang Legislator Wang Yu-ting during a question and answer session at the Legislative Yuan.

The premier admitted that rate increases have been in the works for some time, but he pointed out that he favors a proposal to temporarily freeze any hikes in public utility fares "if bank interest rates and workers' salary increases do not pick up."

However, he claimed that he cannot promise that water and power rates will stay fixed during his term due to international factors and added that users' rights and interests will be fully taken into account before the government makes a final decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY ASKED TO REVIEW NAVY FLEET'S FLOP IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday there is still room for the Ministry of National Defense to improve its visit arrangement for the ROC Navy's "Fleet of Friendship" after the team was recently barred from making a port call in Singapore due to pressure from China.

Hsieh told lawmakers during a legislative interpellation session that the ministry should have anticipated the many problems that were likely to occur when the fleet was to visit a country with no diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
Without a definite commitment from the destination country, it would have been better for the fleet to avoid the country in the first place, Hsieh said.

A local daily reported Tuesday that because of pressure from Beijing, Singapore decided without prior notice to prohibit the fleet from berthing when the vessels arrived at the city-state for refueling early this month. Singapore is the first stop on the itinerary of the fleet's round-the-world cruise this year.
The fleet was later allowed to anchor offshore, according to the report.
Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Taiwan and Singapore had a secret agreement to allow a port call by the fleet but a media leak of the arrangement put Singapore under heavy pressure.
Lee promised no similar incidents would occur during the rest of the fleet's voyage because all the remaining destinations are diplomatic allies of Taiwan.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen noted that Singapore is very mindful of China's reaction, which he said is evident in the remarks made by Singapore's national leaders, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
Chen said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has relayed the government's position on the matter to Singapore through diplomatic means.

Meanwhile, foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu said the ministry will continue its efforts to expand the country's participation in the international community despite Beijing's continued suppression.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATUTE FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT FAILS TO REACH AGENDA AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A Cabinet-proposed "statute for major arms procurement" failed to be put on the agenda for review at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday because of the opposition from the majority "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP).

The KMT and the PFP caucuses of the legislature said that there are still disputes over the arms procurement proposal, and that the Cabinet should not list the arms procurement package for six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States under a special budget.

This was the first time the statute was blocked since the Cabinet marked down the ceiling price for the procurement package from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.38 billion) because a plan to make the submarines in Taiwan was dropped, and because the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. dollar.

During the discussions, KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming proposed that the arms procurement proposal be postponed from being put on the agenda, and his words led to verbal sparring among the ruling and the opposition legislators.

Legislator William C. D. Lai, caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the legislature, said that as long as the prepared information is complete, all bills should be put on the agenda.
Lai also took the chance to criticize KMT and PFP legislators for themselves proposing "money-pit" bills.

Lee Yung-ping, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that most of the KMT and the PFP legislators were opposed to the arms procurement during the legislative elections late last year. Judging from the fact that the "pan-blue alliance" legislators won over half the seats in the 225-member legislature, the public is opposed to paying an exorbitant price for the major arms purchase and opposed to the listing the purchase under a special budget, Lee said.

The Cabinet proposed a similar bill last year, but it, together with a proposed special budget for the procurement, was shelved by the legislature owing to objections from the majority "pan-blue alliance."
After the proposed statute and budget were killed at the end of the last legislative term in January this year, the Cabinet had to re-submit them in the new legislature that started Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH PREMIUM TO BE RAISED APRIL 1 FOR SELECT GROUPS

TEXT.P: Health insurance premiums for government employees, public school teachers, military personnel and those in high-income brackets will be raised by varying amounts next month, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) announced Tuesday.
Starting from April 1, the ceiling on the index health insurance premium will be raised to NT$131,700 from the current NT$87,600.
As a result, each high-income wage earner will have to pay an additional health insurance premium per month of NT$61 to NT$602.
"Some 300,000 high-income wage earners will be affected by this measure," said Hung Pi-lan, head of the DOH's task force in charge of health insurance premium adjustments.

After the adjustments, the gap between the highest and lowest index insurance premiums will be widened to 8.3 times, conforming to the social justice principle of wealthier people paying more to bolster the universal health insurance program.

Meanwhile, Hung said, the insured amount of the nation's 760,000 government employees, teachers and military personnel will also be raised from the current 82.42 percent of their monthly salary to 87.04 percent from April.
"The ratio adjustment means that each public functionary, teacher or military serviceman will pay an additional NT$61 to NT$307 per month," Hung said.
The two adjustments will affect some one million people in the system while helping increase the health insurance premium revenues by NT$3.5 billion annually, Hung said.
According to Hung, the adjustments are part of the DOH's efforts to prevent the cash-strapped national health insurance program from going bankrupt.

Hung said the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) has worked out other proposals aimed at keeping the insurance program afloat, including raising the taxes on cigarettes and liquors, funneling air pollution fines into the BNHI coffers and implementing a number of austerity programs to cut medical and health care costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND FINANCIAL REFORM TO BRING TAIWAN IN LINE WITH THE WORLD: CHEN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is undergoing a second financial reform to open the country's financial markets completely to the outside world, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

Receiving a group of executives from insurance companies from across Asia, Chen said the second financial reform will bring the island's insurance practices in line with those of developed countries and will make it easier for foreign insurance operators to venture into local markets.

Chen said that Taiwan has great potential and is keeping in step with globalization, pointing to the fact that 17 out of the 57 insurance companies operating in Taiwan are from overseas, and that the insurance sector's combined assets accounted for 16 percent of the country's financial industry as a whole in 2004.

The president said the insurance sector's total premiums income accounted for 14 percent of the country's gross national product in 2004, ranking it 15th in the world and fourth in Asia, adding that this income is growing by 10 percent to 12 percent annually.

Chen said the country has been gradually opening its markets to international players since its entry into the World Trade Organization in 2002 and this second financial reform being engineered by his administration is part of a program to integrate the island's markets with global markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP MAINTAINS BUSY SCHEDULE DURING FLORIDA TRANSIT STOP
DOC.DATELINE: Miami, Florida, March 21 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu toured the U.S. National Hurricane Center in Florida Monday on the second day of her transit stop on her way back to Taipei after a Central America diplomatic tour that took her to El Salvador and Guatemala.
Lu received a warm welcome from the center's Chinese-descent director, Dr. Jiann-Gwo Jiing, when she arrived together with her 152-member entourage.

Jiing briefed Lu and her entourage on the center's functions and its various facilities for observing, forecasting and analyzing hurricanes to facilitate activation of the disaster prevention mechanism.

Later in the day, Lu visited Florida International University, where she attended a tea part hosted by the school's president, Dr. Modesto A. Maidique, in her honor. Lu said she hopes the school will increase exchanges with Taiwan's academic and educational institutions.

She also toured Fort Lauderdale. In the company of Fort Lauderdale Mayor Jim Naugle, Lu toured the city's new landmark building River House to see for herself Fort Lauderdale's new urban development projects. She also took an amusement ride aboard a Taiwan-made "water taxi" along the city's scenic river.

In the evening, Lu dined with Taiwan expatriates living in the Florida area. Speaking on the occasion, Lu said she hopes Taiwan people at home and abroad can work hand-in-hand to realize the nation's bid to join the Organization of American States as an observer.

Touching on China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, Lu said Beijing's ill-intentioned legislation has made the international community understand that it is China that is the troublemaker in the Taiwan Strait, not Taiwan.

"Taiwan is by no means a troublemaker. Instead, we are a peacemaker. We love peace, freedom and democracy. Over the past more than five decades, we have lived under China' military threat and diplomatic isolation. But we have not been daunted. We have successfully developed Taiwan into one of Asia's most prosperous and vibrant democracies," Lu said, adding that she thinks Taiwan deserves a Nobel peace prize.
Before her departure for home, Lu will visit a Jewish senior citizens' nursing center, attend a tea party to be hosted by Coral Gables City Mayor Don Slesnick and visit the University of Miami.

After her official visits to El Salvador and Guatemala, Lu arrived in Miami Sunday to a warm welcome from William Brown, acting chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, and ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STICKS TO CROSS-STRAIT 'CO-EXISTENCE AND RECONCILIATION'

TEXT.P: China has damaged Taiwan's security by enacting the Anti-Secession Law and Taiwan should respond duly, although the response should be appropriate lest the two sides become forever anathematic to each other, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.
The premier made the remarks during a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu of the opposition Kuomintang asked Hsieh if he still sticks to his ideas on cross-strait "co-existence and reconciliation" after China's rubber-stamp parliament, the National People's Congress, passed an Anti-Secession Law on March 14, authorizing "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

The premier said that in the long term, both sides have to "co-exist." Geographically, Taiwan is close to the mainland, and instead of whining about being near a rogue neighbor, it is better to think in terms of the advantages of being near the mainland, as Taiwan will be able to influence its democratization.

He also reaffirmed his new mindset for Taiwan, saying that Taiwan cannot be marginalized as China rises, and that as both sides of the Taiwan Strait become even closer economically, Taiwan cannot sit on the sidelines and must grow stronger by riding on the coattails of the economic boom on the mainland.
Taiwan shouldn't consider itself a pariah, Hsieh said, adding that both sides must co-exist and prosper together.
The premier also reaffirmed that he will take part in a planned march this Saturday to protest Beijing's newly passed law.
The march is being sponsored by a civic group, the Alliance to Defend Taiwan with Democracy and Peace, which he said is significant in the sense that it will galvanize the people of Taiwan.
Hsieh said that he took many things into consideration before deciding to take part in the march, adding that he will also encourage civil servants to join the demonstration.

As for whether President Chen Shui-bian should take part in the march, he said that he will leave that for the president to decide, although he said the president will have to take other things into consideration, such as international relations and the future ties with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DETECTS NO ABNORMAL CHINESE MILITARY ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: The People's Liberation Army has not conducted abnormal military activities or maneuvering since China's enactment of its so-called Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, a senior Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Tuesday.

Hu Chen-pu, director of the MND's POlitical Warfare Department, said China's ill-intentioned legislation, which authorizes the use of force or "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan, has gravely threatened Taiwan's national security and peace and stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region.
Even though China's People's Liberation Army has so far not taken any abnormal military activities, Hu said, Taiwan must upgrade its defense capabilities to safeguard its national security.

"I hope local people and lawmakers can support the MND's new arms procurement project to meet the antion's defense demand," Hu said, referring to its plan to procure six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEBRUARY JOBLESS RATE UP TO 4.28 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate was 4.28 percent in February, up 0.22 percentage points from the previous month, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

DGBAS officials said February's figure represents the first rise in nearly six months. They attributed the reasons mainly to the increase of those who quit their jobs to look for new ones after the Chinese New Year holiday, and the end of temporary jobs offered by the government's public service expansion program.

The officials said that the number of the employed was 9.87 million in February, while the number of the jobless in the same month was 441,000, up 22,000 from the previous month. Among the 22,000, the number of those who lost their jobs because of the closure or the scaling down at the work place and the end of temporary jobs offered by the government under a job-creation project increased by 14,000, while the number of those who quit their jobs because of dissatisfaction with their work increased by 6,000.

In addition, the economic growth this year was slower than the previous year. The number of the jobless in the construction sector in February increased by 18,000 from the previous month alone, contributing to the rise in the jobless rate in February.

The jobless rate of those between 45 and 64 was 3.22 percent, up 0.32 percentage points from the previous month. Whether this was related to a new pension system for laborers, which will be put into practice in July this year and which will affect those laborers who have worked long years, the officials said that they will still have to look at the figures in March and April to make a more accurate assessment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDYING FURTHER ACTION AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 21 (CNA) (By Weng Tsui-ping and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei's representative office in the United States is consulting with foreign countries about the possibility of taking further action against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan after the United Nations failed to make any move on the matter, a Taiwan official based in New York said Monday.

Andrew L. Y. Hsia, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said the situation is due to the fact that Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations, whose decisions, however, can affect the island.

For example, the implementation of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora and the Kyoto Protocol aimed at cutting back on greenhouse gas emissions have subject certain Taiwan exports to international trade sanctions, Hsia pointed out.
Hsia made the remarks while receiving a group of 34 undergraduates from Taiwan, who are scheduled to attend a simulated U.N. meeting to be held Tuesday in New York.

Asserting that it is Taiwan's basic right to join the United Nations, Hsia said because Taiwan is not a member of the world organization, the people of Taiwan are not able to be involved in the international community and the international community also dares not accept donations from Taiwan.

He said the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should the island move towards independence, is another example that has highlighted the island's need to join the United Nations.

Usually, the U.N. Security Council will meet immediately for a resolution and ask concerned parties to sit down for peace talks in the event of a country enacting a law to pave the way for an invasion of another country, but the United Nations has done nothing in this case so far, Hsia noted.
He said China will create unnecessary regional tensions by changing the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo unilaterally through the law.

After Japan, the European Union and Canada have stated their opposition to the enactment of the law, Taiwan will continue to make its case to the international community to try to win more international support, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE AROUND TAIWAN SUMMONED TO 326 PROTEST MARCH

TEXT.P: Facing China's reinforced threat with the passage of its Anti-Secession Law, young people, women and children around Taiwan were urged Tuesday to attend a protest march slated for March 26 in Taipei.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's department of women's affairs, along with several private women's organizations, initiated Tuesday a "Mammies, Babies Loving Peace, Protecting Taiwan" campaign, while kicking off a recruiting drive for 706 children aged between three and six who will symbolically bare their buttocks to Beijing and its Anti-Secession Law in the planned march.

The children will have their buttocks pasted with "anti-missile" posters on March 26, while pregnant women are also wanted for the campaign aimed at "voicing Taiwan's love for peace with sounds of tenderness" during the demonstration, Hsu Chia-chin, director of the department, said at a news conference.

Besides the women's action, taxi drivers were also urged to voice their support for the "anti-Anti Secession Law" drive organized by the "Alliance to Protect Taiwan with Democracy and Peace, " which carried out a publicity stunt Tuesday by arranging hundreds of yellow cabs to form the word "peace" in front of Taipei County Hall.

The alliance chief executive Lee Yi-yang also pasted "326 March" stickers on the taxis. Lee said the cars are mobile broadcasting stations that could summon more people to take to the streets March 26.

Meanwhile, in Taichung City, a group of students and young people in the central Taiwan area were planning a trip to Taipei for the March 26 protest by a so-called "magic train of democracy" with the support of former Government Information Office Director-General Lin Chia-lung.

At a news conference to promote the train trip, Lin, who has been named to serve as "train master" for the trip, noted that China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law is a big threat to Taiwan and said all the people on the island, regardless of their political links, should stand out to fight against the attempt to annex Taiwan.

The train will be painted in colors supposed to show themes adopted from the popular "Harry Potter" series of novels by J.K. Rowling, according to the organizers, who did not explain the significance of this.

The "magic train" is scheduled to set off at 9: 40 a.m. March 26 from the Taichung Railway Station for Taipei, and will return later that day, the organizers said, adding that about 800 people are expected to board the train.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE TO DISCUSS EDUCATION OF CHILDREN FROM MIXED MARRIAGES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education is scheduled to hold a conference March 23-24 in central Taiwan to seek measures to improve the education of children from international marriages, officials said Tuesday.

Although the learning ability of these students differs little from that of other children, their learning efficiency may differ owing to their parents' socio-economic background, according to the officials.
The conference will bring together educators that will share their teaching experience and discuss problems they face in teaching children born to a foreign mother or father, they said.
The ministry will also hold a similar conference in northern Taiwan in May.

According to ministry statistics, a total of 47,196 elementary and junior high school students around Taiwan were born to a foreign parent in the 2004-2005 academic year, with 41,591 in elementary schools and 5,605 in junior high schools.
The top three localities where these students are attending school are Taipei County, Taoyuan County and Taipei City.
On the nationalities of the foreign parents, those from China, Hong Kong and Macau total 16,034, with 11,687 from an Indonesian mother or father and 5,289 with a Vietnamese parent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING TO BE PRIVATIZED AS SCHEDULED

TEXT.P: The state-run China Shipbuilding Corporation (CSBC) will complete privatization by the end of 2005 as scheduled, a company official said Tuesday.
According to CSBC President Fan Kuang-nan, the company will hold an investment conference at the end of April and start inviting investment in May.
Fan said several potential investors from the United States, Japan and Indonesia have expressed interest in the privatization project.
However, the total number of shares held by foreign investors cannot exceed 45 percent after the company is privatized, Fan noted.
He said the company posted sales of NT$2.66 billion (US$84.74 million) in the first two months of this year, with accumulated profits amounting to NT$72 million.
The company currently has 52 shipbuilding orders in hand, which is expected to keep its production lines busy up to early 2009, he added.
CSBC saw an accumulated surplus of about NT$711 million in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA KNOWS BETTER THAN TO BOYCOTT TAIWAN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: China knows better than to apply economic sanctions against Taiwan, as it would also hurt itself, Premier Frank Hsieh claimed Tuesday.

Fielding an opposition lawmaker's question about how his administration would respond to Beijing's economic sanctions against Taiwan, which is one of the non-peaceful options threatened by Beijing after passing its Anti-Secession Law, the premier said that neither side of the Taiwan Strait will benefit in such a senario, although he admitted that Taiwan "might suffer more" as it enjoys a huge trade surplus with China.
China and Taiwan will flourish if they can live peacefully alongside each other and cooperate, Hsieh said.

In order to prevent China from resorting to sanctions that would be harmful to both sides, the premier said his administration is working with major powers to limit China's leeway in using non-peaceful means against Taiwan. He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LIFTS ANTI-DUMPING TAX ON JAPANESE H-BEAMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance announced Tuesday that it had lifted an anti-dumping tax on Japanese H-beams with immediate effect.

Tsan Kuang-ruey, deputy director-general of the Department of Customs Administration under the Ministry of Finance (MOF), said that the government decided to lift the punitive tax following a series of investigations by the MOF and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The investigations found that imports of Japanese H-beams would not damage the domestic steel industry's development.
The government imposed the anti-dumping tax Dec. 10, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA CALLS FOR CONTINUITY OF NATIONAL SCIENCE COUNCIL

TEXT.P: Forty-four members of Academia Sinica, led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, urged the Executive Yuan Tuesday to enlarge the National Science Council (NSC) into a full ministry instead of eliminating it as envisioned in the Executive Yuan's reorganization plan.

In a public letter to the Executive Yuan, the scholars said the country's intelligentsia has aired its opposition to the proposal to eliminate the NSC, but has elicited no reply from the Executive Yuan.

Expressing regret that their opinions have been overlooked, the letter says its signatories are uneasy with the government's plan to do away with the NSC, which has contributed a great deal to the country's science and technology development and has played a significant role in producing the "Taiwan miracle, " referring to the country's amazing economic development.

Eliminating the NSC and transferring its business to other government agencies is certain to damage the country's scientific research because the absence of an agency exclusively charged with the development of science will blunt Taiwan's competitiveness.

Instead of abolishing it, the NSC, which can only coordinate science-related policies among various government ministries for the time being, should be enlarged into a ministry with the authority to map out, execute and supervise the country's science policy, the letter says.
The country's intelligentsia will be disappointed and the government's goal of sharpening the country's competitiveness will be hampered if the NSC is abolished, the letter warns.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA APPRECIATES EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT'S OPPOSITION TO CHINA'S LAW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed its appreciation Tuesday for the European Parliament's opposition to China's recently passed Anti-Secession Law.

The Foreign Relations Committee of the European Parliament approved a resolution March 16 to express its concern over the law, which it said will intensify the cross-Taiwan Strait tension, according to the MOFA.
The resolution also urged the European Union Commission not to lift the arms embargo on China that it has imposed since 1989.
The MOFA called on the international community to keep the European Parliament's resolution in mind and to urge the E.U. to maintain its arms ban on China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL DO ITS BEST TO GET INTO WHA: HEALTH MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not let up on its effort to join the World Health Assembly despite a Beijing official's assertion that China will make every attempt to block it, Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou said Tuesday.

In a response to Beijing Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing's statement that it is impossible for Taiwan to join the WHA as an observer this year, Hou said it is regrettable that China hurts the feelings of Taiwan people by subordinating their health to Chinese political interest.

However, Taiwan's efforts to join the WHA will not abate. Rather, it will aggressively join international rescue operations sponsored by the World Health Organization, of which the WHA is the assembly, and scrupulously follow the World Health Regulations crafted by the WHO.

Hou said Taiwan's participation in the international rescue operation in the wake of the disaster caused by the Dec. 26 tsunami in South Asia and Southeast Asia last year has won the country an international reputation for generosity that will be helpful for Taiwan's WHA bids.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, March 23, or the 14th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Patrick Henry, U.S. statesman, makes a plea for American freedom from Britain, declaring: "Give me liberty or give me death."
1910: The British government removes its consulate in Anping, southern Taiwan.
1912: Wernher von Braun, a German-born rocket expert who designed the V1 and V2 rockets and later worked for NASA, is born.
1913: Fire engulfs the Taipei Post Office.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai, who declared himself Hung Hsien emperor on Dec. 12, 1915, gives up his throne.
1918: Lithuania proclaims its independence.
1919: A group of disillusioned former socialists and Italian war veterans, led by Benito Mussolini, form the Fascist Party (Fasci di Combattimento) in Milan.
1935: The Soviet Union sells its interest in the Chinese Eastern Railway to Japan.
1942: The U.S. government begins moving Japanese-Americans from their homes on the U.S. West Coast to inland detention camps.
1956: Pakistan becomes an Islamic republic, with Maj. Gen. Iskander Mirza as its first provisional president.
1959: Communist Chinese troops capture Lhasa, capital of Tibet, and engage in large-scale suppression of rebelling Tibetans.
1962: Sixteen Communist Chinese MiG jet fighters fly over the Republic of China-controlled island of Kinmen, with one of them being shot and partly damaged by anti-aircraft fire.
1962: The Savannah, the world's first nuclear merchant ship, is launched in New Jersey.
1973: Gen. Yin Chun, commander in chief of the Taiwan Garrison Command, leaves for Manila for a four-day visit.
1974: A ceremony to honor the 2,346th anniversary of the birth of Mencius is held in Taipei.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan dubs the Soviet Union "an evil empire" and proposes a "Star Wars" defense system.
1992: The first-ever meeting between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait convenes in Peking to discuss issues related to document verification and indirect registered postal services.
1994: The Legislative Yuan increases the annual quota of permanent residency permits for mainland spouses of ROC citizens from 300 to 600.
1995: The Regulations Governing the Management and Compensation for Victims of the Feb. 28, 1947 Incident are passed by the Legislative Yuan. The regulations provide for the establishment of a foundation to manage relevant affairs and for the designation of Feb. 28 as a day of national commemoration.
1995: A two-day convention of secretary-generals of the Olympic Council of Asian member nations opens in Kaohsiung. Following international practice, the convention hoists the flags of all OCA members -- including the five-star flag of mainland China.
1996: Four pairs of candidates compete in the first-ever direct election of the ROC president and vice president. Lee Teng-hui and his running mate Lien Chan win with 54 percent of the vote. At the same time, 334 members of the Third National Assembly are also elected.
1998: Russia's President Boris Yeltsin fires his prime minister and the entire Cabinet.
2000: Newly appointed Republic of Sao Tome & Principe Ambassador to the ROC Ovidio Manuel Barb Osa Pequeno presents a copy of his credentials to Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian meets with Defense Minister Tang Fei and the chief of the General Staff, Tang Yao-ming.
2001: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung admits that his administration thus far is a failure, only to recant the statement later and dismiss its as a slip of the tongue.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it a rule to work for something before you accept anything as your own: that is, perhaps, the best way to elevate the moral sentiment. Make it a habit to assail your own vices and failings before you assail the vices and failings of others: that is, perhaps, the best way to discover the secret vices of your innermost mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN A STRATEGIC PARTNER OF DEMOCRATIC WORLD: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: London, March 22 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has always been a strategic partner of the democratic world, the new Republic of China representative to Britain said Tuesday.

Edgar Lin said that as Taiwan's strategic position is of major significance in terms of global peace and security, the United States is determined to defend this part of the world. He added that Japan also firmly believes that Taiwan's security is inextricably linked to Japan's security and that of other neighboring countries.
Lin made the remarks while addressing a welcome party held in his honor by the British-Taiwanese All-Party Parliamentary Group.

Lin, who assumed his current post only two months ago, said that Beijing's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes the "use of non-peaceful means" against the island in certain situations, has not only deprived the 23 million people of Taiwan of their autonomous rights, it also threatens peace and security in East Asia and will eventually result in a "conflict of civilizations between the West and the East."

This "ill-intentioned" law, if coupled with a lifting of the European Union ban on arms sales to China, which the union has been considering for the last several months, will undoubtedly accelerate China's military expansion, posing a huge threat to many countries in the world, Lin warned.
The new ROC envoy expressed his appreciation to the British parliamentarians for their support for Taiwan and his admiration for their far-reaching vision on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.
Lin also said that he was extremely pleased to hear British Secretary of Foreign Affairs Jack Straw on Monday voice his opposition to a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China.
He further said that Taiwan has been a sovereign, independent country for over the past five decades and that it is not a part of the People's Republic of China.

There is no such thing as the so-called "Taiwan issue, " he claimed, adding that there is only a "China issue" since China insists on maintaining the option of force to annex Taiwan, which he said has caused cross-strait tensions to continue to escalate.
Lin added that he has noticed that the British government has recently reiterated its stance that Taiwan's future should be resolved peacefully through dialogue, which he said he fully supports.

Formerly chairman of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration and a Republic of China ambassador to Gambia, Lin quoted a Chinese foreign affairs expert as saying recently that if China were to fail to secure Taiwan, it would never become a great maritime power. This indicates the Chinese military's ambitions regarding Taiwan, he added.

He said that the best option to prevent cross-strait conflicts from erupting is to speed up the democratization of Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland, with democratic Taiwan working in concert with Western countries to maintain peace and security in East Asia and the rest of the world.

Speaking prior to Lin's speech, Lord Richard Faulkner of Worcester, vice chairman of the British-Taiwanese All-Party Parliamentary Group, said at the cocktail party that his group will continue to strongly voice support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization.

Faulkner criticized the European Union for considering lifting its arms embargo against China before Beijing improves its human rights record, referring to it as "scandalous" and saying no responsible government should do that sort of thing.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S CONCERN OVER TAIWAN INCREASINGLY EXPLICIT: ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Japan's concern over Taiwan in terms of security as a result of Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law has become increasingly explicit, the Republic of China representative to Japan said Wednesday.
Koh Se-kai said Japan's stance on the cross-Taiwan Strait issue has become clearer as the country increasingly feels the threat posed by China in the Asia-Pacific region.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee, Koh noted that the Japanese government has expressed its intention to "demonstrate grave concern" and "conduct a possible intervention" in the event of incidents that may undermine cross-strait peace.

Koh said Japan is not legally allowed to organize its own military forces prior to its amending of Article 9 of its Constitution. But if cross-strait conflict erupts after the Japanese Constitution is amended, it will positively demonstrate its serious concern toward such conflict, Koh added.

Should cross-strait conflict occur prior to the Japanese constitutional amendment, Koh said, Japan can only throw its support, such as logistic support, behind the U.S. military in the event that the United States comes to Taiwan's rescue militarily should a cross-strait war erupt.

Discounting criticism by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Su Chi, who claimed that Taiwan's diplomacy toward Japan is nothing but "kowtow, independence and senility" diplomacy, Koh said he has done his utmost in efforts to maintain Taiwan's dignity while securing engagement with Japan.

Koh promised to look further into the issue that Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan soared by 50 percent to reach US$56.83 billion last year, saying that he will see to it that certain measures are adjusted.

Despite the fact that he is pro-Taiwan independence and that the establishment of a "Republic of Taiwan" is his personal ideal, Koh said that as a government functionary, his priority is to fulfill his governmental obligations.

"I know what I'm doing," Koh responded to opposition People First Party Legislator Sun Ta-chian, adding that he agrees with Sun that the best common ground for Taiwan for the time being is maintaining the Republic of China and securing the cross-strait status quo.

Meanwhile, Koh said, Japan will continue to support Taiwan in its bid to participate in the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision-making body of the World Health Organization, this year, marking the third consecutive year that Japan has openly thrown its support behind Taiwan in this regard.

The Japanese government has promised that "what has been achieved will not be degraded," Koh said, adding that his office will continue to push for Japanese officials to voice support for Taiwan at the WHA.
In addition, he said, a number of ROC health officials are scheduled to visit Japan in April to enhance Taiwan's WHA lobby.
Also at the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee session, Koh said that Taiwan has been invited to take part in the Japanese expo, Expo 2005 Aichi.
On display at the Aichi Expo will mainly be Taiwan delicacies and snacks, as well as unique Taiwan agricultural products, Koh added.
Sidelining the expo, several Taiwan performance groups, including the Cloud Gate Theatre and the Lanyang Dance Troupe, will stage five days of performances and concerts in June and July, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO DECIDE WHETHER TO TAKE PART IN MARCH THURSDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will decide Thursday whether to take part in a protest march scheduled for this Saturday, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday.

Su made the remarks when he unveiled the so-called "spiritual bastion" of the march -- a white pearl inscribed with the word "peace" to symbolize Taiwan and a red ovoid spiked ball representing China -- at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall.

Su said the 20-meter high beacon will be placed on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, which will be the destination of Saturday's march, to underscore the marchers' anger over China's Anti-Secession Law.
Likening the red ball to a sea urchin, Su said every spike on the ball represents Chinese missiles that will sabotage peace and makes other countries uncomfortable.
He also sent out text massages via computer to party officials and the media, urging them to mobilize more people to take part in the protest rally.
Su and other officials then deflated balloons representing Chinese missiles to demonstrate Taiwan's determination to pursue peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: P-3C AIRCRAFT TO BOOST MILITARY'S UNDERSEA SURVEILLANCE SCOPE: MND

TEXT.P: The procurement of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States will meet the military's minimum combat demand and expand its undersea surveillance scope by more than 10-fold, according to a report presented Wednesday to the legislature by the Ministry of National Defense.
While seven of the planes are expected to be delivered to Taiwan in 2009, the other five will be delivered in 2011, the report says.

It says the ministry originally reserved NT$53.04 billion (US$1.7 billion) in a special budget proposal for the 12 aircraft, but the amount has recently been adjusted to NT$45.04 billion following changes in the exchange rate and cutbacks in spending and coverage of some of the amount by the government's regular budget.

It points out that the military's existing S-2T anti-submarine planes, which have been in service for more than 40 years, are no longer capable of meeting the military's combat demands and that the military needs to replace the planes to enhance its three-dimensional anti-submarine capabilities.
China has in recent years developed the Song-class submarine and nuclear-powered submarines and has also purchased Kilo-class submarines from Russia, the report notes.
In the event of a Chinese blockade of Taiwan, the nation's economy and security will be seriously jeopardized, it says.

Lin Chin-ching, head of the ministry's Integrated Assessment Office, predicted that China will have the ability to build aircraft carriers in 2008 and to form an aircraft carrier battle group in 2015 to gain sea dominance in the Taiwan Strait.
Also in 2015, the submarines developed by China will be equipped with the ability to launch an undersea blockade, attack and nuclear retaliation, Lin added.
Lin said the number of new frigates owned by the Chinese navy and its combat capabilities will significantly surpass those of Taiwan in 2012, which he said will pose a great challenge.

The 12 P-3C aircraft are one of the items in the government's NT$480 billion proposed arms procurement package from the United States. Also on the shopping list are six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and eight diesel-electric submarines.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS TAKING PART IN U.N. SIMULATION CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 22 (CNA) (By T.P. Weng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A total of 34 Taiwan students are taking part in the 2005 National Model United Nations (NMUN) Conference that opened at the U.N. headquarters Tuesday.

The students, led by Chiang Chia-hsiung, an associate professor at National Chengchi University, attended the opening ceremony of the 2005 NMUN Conference, marking the second time that Taiwan college students have entered the U.N. building after the Republic of China lost its seat in the world body to China more than 30 years ago.
The NMUN Conference, the world's largest university-level simulation of the United Nations, is being held under the auspices of the National Collegiate Conference Association.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Dr. Michael Ignatieff from Harvard University quoted U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan as espousing recently that the U.N. Security Council should be enlarged in scale to help facilitate U.N. reforms.

The inefficient U.N. Human Rights Committee, which has been dominated by undemocratic, totalitarian countries, should also be reorganized into a U.N. Human Rights Council to allow reform-minded and genuine human rights-championing countries to participate, Ignatieff said.
Ignatieff called for the world to help poor countries, saying that about 2 billion people go to bed hungry every night with a per capita daily income of less than US$1.
It is shameful that Americans spent US$35 billion on pets last year, an amount larger than the United States spent on aid to poor countries that year, he added.

Ignatieff welcomed the 3,000-odd students from around the world to the conference, saying that they are bringing new hope to the United Nations. It is hoped that in some five or 10 years, some of the students will represent their countries at the United Nations and achieve the tasks that the current generation has failed to achieve, tasks that include arms controls and limits on execution of force.

The Taiwan students will take part in debate sessions with 18 out of 24 U.N. committees over three days. They are also expected to take part in the closing ceremony of the conference slated for March 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained two points to close at 6,010, with 30,170 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved down two points to finish at 6,008, with 117 contracts traded, while June futures also lost two points to end at 5,998, with 33 contracts traded.
September futures lost seven points to finish at 5,891, with 63 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 34 points to close at 5,866, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 6,008 for April, 6,010 for May, 6,000 for June, 5,898 for September and 5,900 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

April TE futures moved up 0.4 points to close at 227.7, with 3,217 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 0.35 points to finish at 227.65, with 12 contract transactions. June TE futures slid 0.5 points to close at 228.15, with one contract traded, while September TE futures moved down 0.55 points to close at 225.4, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures lost 5.2 points to finish at 976.8, with 3,925 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved down six points to end at 976, with 32 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down 5.8 points to finish at 974.2, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S DRY EYE SYNDROME RELAPSES IN MIAMI
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, March 22 (CNA) (By Yang Chia-hui and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suffered a relapse of dry eye syndrome Monday during a transit stop in Miami on her way back to Taiwan after concluding a trip to Central America.
She recovered after medical treatment.
She is scheduled to return to Taiwan Thursday (Taipei time).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 0.7 points to close at 6,019.49.
The bourse opened at 6,005.36 and fluctuated between 5,970.2 and 6,023.76 during trading. A total of 2.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.86 billion (US$2 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.8 percent, banking and financial issues at 0.4 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.

The other four stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues and construction issues rising the most at 0.7 percent each, followed by machinery and electronics shares and paper and pulp issues at 0.4 percent each.
Losers outnumbered gainers 442 to 405, with 170 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO ENHANCE INTERNATIONAL PUBLIC RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 23 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Natale Bellocchi said Tuesday that Taiwan's achievement in democratization is its best vehicle for winning international support.

Speaking at a symposium on the impact of Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, Bellocchi said Taiwan should bolster its public relations work in the international community and should refrain from what he described as "clinging to the United States for everything."
The United States is too busy to render comprehensive help to Taiwan, the former AIT chairman and managing director said.

Taiwan's democratization is the most efficient weapon to deter China's guns and missiles, and also the best bargaining chip in efforts to win sympathy and support from the world, according to the former official.

Taiwan has been doing a good job in terms of lobbying in the United States, but the problem is that America is too busy with fighting terrorism at home, the Iraq issue and the new efforts to push for democracy in the Middle East to enable it to help Taiwan fully, Bellocchi said.

He added that Taiwan should direct its energy from lobbying in the United States to addressing the international community, in order to allow more countries to understand Taiwan's democracy, which will show in sharp contrast to China's totalitarianism.
The symposium was organized by the Formosan Association of Public Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar fell against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.021 to close at NT$31.369.
A total of US$755 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.491 and fluctuated between NT$31.491 and NT$31.33.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO LAUNCH NEW NT$500, NT$1,000 BILLS JULY 20

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) is scheduled to launch new NT$500 and NT$1,000 bills July 20 featuring strengthened anti-forgery functions, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said Wednesday.
Perng made the remarks at the Finance Committee in the Legislative Yuan during an interpellation session.
Legislator Lo Ming-tsai said that the color and size of the NT$100 and NT$500 bills are similar and he claimed that this confuses a lot of people.
Legislator Hsieh Ming-yuan also said that the NT$2,000 bills are rarely used and asked if anyone present had one, upon which Perng produced one from his pocket.
Perng also said that the circulation rate of the NT$2,000 is 2.8 percent and will continue to be circulated.
He also said the CBC will continue to improve the design of the bills so as to strengthen the anti-forgery functions and step up a campaign to tell the public how to discern genuine from bogus bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO REMAIN NEUTRAL IN MARCH 26 PROTEST: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh encouraged public servants Wednesday to take part in a March 26 protest in Taipei against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, but stressed that the government will maintain neutrality in the activity, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said after a weekly Cabinet meeting.
According to Cho, Hsieh urged public functionaries to participate in the protest but made it clear that the government will not obligate them to do so.

The premier said that public servants are part of Taiwan society and that everyone in Taiwan should show their solidarity to the world at a time when the country's peace and democracy are under increased threats, Cho added.
Hsieh himself will take part in the protest.
William C. D. Lai, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was optimistic about keen public response to the rally.
Basing his optimism on survey results, he estimated that more than 2 million people will take part in the demonstration, higher than the DPP's original target of 1 million.
DPP Legislator Lin Cho-hsui said high ranking government officials should not take part.

Saying that the government should craft an adequate policy to deal with the situation rather than take to the streets, Lin said that the government should not get involved in the demonstration in order to make sure that it remains an activity purely for the public to express their anger about the law.
He suggested the government set up a task force to study countermeasures to the law through legal means.

Meanwhile, Legislator Su Chi of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said he supports participation by KMT backers, but voiced his opposition to the DPP's strategy of using public mandate as a pretext to help break the stalemate facing President Chen Shui-bian after Beijing enacted the law March 14 with an eye to quelling Taiwan independence.
Su claimed that the real purpose behind the demonstration is to find a way out of the deadlock for Chen.

Su, formerly a chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council in the previous KMT-led government, made the comments while giving a report at a weekly Central Standing Committee meeting of the main opposition party.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ENCOURAGE INVESTMENT IN SWAZILAND: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that he will encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest in Swaziland.
Chen made the remarks when he received new Swaziland Ambassador Njabuliso Busisiwe Gwebu, who came to the Presidential Office to present her credentials.

The president said that Swaziland, in a superb geographic location in Africa and with stable politics and good social order, is an ideal place for investors. He said he will encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest in the southern African country so as to promote employment and assist in the nation's economic development.
Chen also said Taiwan is willing to contribute to Swaziland's program to fight AIDS.
He noted that the countries have enjoyed diplomatic relations for 37 years and that the two sides maintain close and friendly relations.

He expressed appreciation for Swaziland's assistance in Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization, as well as its speaking up for Taiwan's bid to join other international organizations and its support for Taiwan's bid to become an observer in the World Health Assembly, the policy-making organ of the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAME-CHANGE TO COST CHINA SHIPBUILDING NT$140 MILLION

TEXT.P: State-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) President Fan Kuang-nan said Wednesday that a plan to change the company's name will cost an estimated NT$140 million (US$4.46 million).
Fan told the legislature's Sci-Tech and Information Committee that the company submitted its name-change proposal to the Ministry of Economic Affairs in late January.

The company is considering changing its name to "Central Shipbuilding Corp." or "Chungchuan Shipbuilding Corp." and will maintain its Chinese and English abbreviations to lessen the impact on its brand value, Fan said.
According to Fan, the CSBC is a reputable company in the international shipbuilding industry, with a brand value estimated at over NT$1 billion.
The government has put forth a plan to change the names of state-run enterprises that bear the word "China" or "Chinese" to avoid confusion with those in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER ESTIMATES 2 MILLION PEOPLE WILL TURN OUT FOR 326 PROTEST

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator William Lai estimated Wednesday that more than 2 million people will join the March 26 protest to show their anger against Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law.

Lai, who is the secretary of the DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan, predicted that Taipei -- the venue for the protest -- will be bursting at the seams March 26 with so many protesters flocking to the capital to take part.

Citing his own experience as an example, Lai said the DPP asked him to solicit at least 1,000 protesters from his home city of Tainan, and promised to provide him with 20 buses to ferry them to Taipei.

Lai said he ran commercials on a Tainan radio station and gave out leaflets to seek protesters, eliciting a response so overwhelming that the number of people asking to join the protest surpasses his 1,000 quota by far, so that many of them will have to travel on buses assigned to other DPP lawmakers in Tainan.

According to a poll conducted by the DPP, Lai said, 15 percent of those interviewed said they will join the protest and 11 percent said they will not miss it for anything, which means that about 2 million people can be expected to take to the streets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PRINTED CIRCUIT BOARD OUTPUT TOPS NT$167.8 BILLION IN 2004

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's printed circuit boards (PCBs) amounted to NT$167.8 billion (US$5.36 billion) in 2004, according to a report released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.
The figure represents a rise of 13.8 percent from 2003, a four-year high, the report says.
Taiwan exported PCBs worth NT$133.7 billion in 2004, 44 percent of which went to China and Hong Kong.

China has replaced the United States to become the major export market for Taiwan's PCBs since 2002 owing to increased demand in China and Taiwan's liberalization policy that allows notebook computer manufacturers to establish operations in China, according to the report.
Meanwhile, Taiwan imported PCBs worth NT$18.6 billion in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRRELEVANT WHETHER PRESIDENT TAKES PART IN 326 MARCH: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu, Oliver Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Whether President Chen Shui-bian should take part in a March 26 protest to express anger over China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law is beside the point, a U.S. China expert said Tuesday.

John Tkacik, a research fellow in China Policy at the Heritage Foundation, made the remarks in a seminar sponsored by the pro-Taiwan independence Formosan Association for Public Affairs in Washington, D.C.

According to Tkacik, Beijing has "irrationally" enacted the Anti-Secession Law and Taiwan has no need to counter it by adopting an anti-annexation law, making irrational moves to even the score, or by mobilizing a government-led protest march.
But if it were the private sector mobilizing a 1-million protest march on its own, it would underscore the will of the Taiwan people to the international community.

Bonnie Glaser, another China hand who is currently a senior associate at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, noted that according to media reports Chen will not march but will deliver a speech when the participants reach the end at Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

She pointed out that Chen has been seeking an appropriate way to respond to Beijing's newly passed law -- which authorizes "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence -- without further raising cross-strait tension. His speech, should he deliver it, will be a major indication of whether he will stick to that course, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS DOWN SLIGHTLY TO US$16.19 BILLION IN FEBRUARY

TEXT.P: Export orders were down slightly to US$16.19 billion in February due to decreased working days because of the weeklong Chinese New Year holiday, the Statistics Department of the Ministry of the Economic Affairs said Wednesday.

The figure represents an annual increase of 7.68 percent, officials said. Export orders amounted to US$34.61 billion in the first two months of this year, or an increase of 19.47 percent from the same period last year.

Among the major export items, the increase of electronics products by US$320 million in February from the same month last year contributed the most to an increase in export orders, mainly because of continuing strong foreign demand for consumer electronics.

Electronics products were followed by export orders for information and communications products, which increased by US$160 million from the same month last year, and by export orders for precision instruments, which increased by US$140 million from the same month last year.
The officials estimated that export orders will grow steadily, and should show an increase of around 10 percent in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL CARGO TRANSPORTATION SERVICE RANKED WORLD'S SECOND BEST

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Airlines (CAL) recently won an award of excellence from Air Cargo World, a U.S.-based magazine. It was the first time CAL had won the award.
In an Air Cargo World survey, CAL was ranked second best among 50 international carriers in terms of air cargo transportation services, following Virgin Atlantic Airlines of the United Kingdom.
Survey respondents were asked to evaluate each company by rating four areas: customer service, performance, value and information technology, according to a CAL official.

In the terms of customer service, carriers were graded on their ability to handle claims with expedience and solve problems in a prompt and courteous manner. In performance, the ability to fulfill promises and contractual agreements and to meet scheduled transit times were considered.

Value examined competitive fees, rates commensurate with service levels required by customers, and value-added programs. Information technology was defined as the ability to track and trace shipments, and Internet and electronic commerce abilities, the CAL official said.
CAL owns the world's largest B747-400F all-cargo fleet with 16 planes, according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Appeals Court Refuses to Order Schiavo's Feeding Reinstated.
A federal appeals court said Terri Schiavo's parents "failed to demonstrate a substantial case on the merits of any of their claims." The parents plan another appeal.
The Wall Street Journal: Federal Appeals Court Denies Reinsertion Of Schiavo Feeding Tube.
A U.S. federal appeals court refused early Wednesday to order the reinsertion of Terri Schiavo's feeding tube, denying an emergency request by the parents of the brain-damaged woman to keep her alive and backing Tuesday's ruling by a U.S. district court judge in Florida.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI LABORER NABBED FOR SELLING AMPHETAMINES TO OTHER THAI WORKERS

TEXT.P: A Thai worker was taken into custody by police Wednesday in Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan, for selling amphetamines to other Thai workers.
The man, Buransarn Theeraphon, was stopped in Taoyuan by police for questioning for behaving suspiciously. He confessed to selling the drug.
Police searched his Taoyuan residence and found 30 grams of amphetamines.
Taoyuan County has the most Thai workers in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW MAY BE HELPFUL TO TAIWAN: U. S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D. C., March 22 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's passage of the controversial Anti-Secession Law might be a good thing for Taiwan, as it has explicitly exposed Beijing's plot to swallow Taiwan, a political analyst said Tuesday.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan independence-leaning Formosan Association for Public Affairs, John J. Tkacik, Jr., a senior researcher at the Heritage Foundation, claimed that the law regarding Taiwan has shown Beijing's true colors to the entire world.

Saying that Beijing should feel ashamed because of the limited backing for the law from just a few countries such as North Korea, Russia and Zimbabwe, Tkacik pointed out that the decision of the European Union to postpone lifting its arms exports ban on mainland China is another side effect of the law.
Against this backdrop, a measured response from Taiwan should help gain greater international support for the island, he contended.
In addition, he said, remarks made recently by U. S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice in Beijing also reflect Washington's discontentment with the law.

Rice said Monday following meetings with Chinese President Hu Jintao, Premier Wen Jiabao and Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing that the Anti-Secession Law is neither welcome nor helpful to thawing ties between Taiwan and China.

She urged Beijing to "take measures that would demonstrate a willingness to reduce tensions in the cross-strait environment, " and reiterated the position of the U. S. to help defend Taiwan in compliance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

Tkacik called the Anti-Secession Law a "war-mandating bill, " which he said will accelerate insecurity in East Asia and totally disqualify Beijing from acquiring advanced weapons under the terms provided by the E.U.

Under E.U. rules, its member states are not allowed to sell weapons to countries that pose a threat in an adjacent region or those notorious for their lack of good human rights records, he said, adding that China fails both tests.
The National People's Congress, Beijing's ceremonial parliament, approved the Anti-Secession Law March 14 to stem moves toward Taiwan independence through non-peaceful means, if necessary.

In response, Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party is organizing a large protest on March 26 to allow the people in Taiwan to show Beijing their outrage. More than one million people are expected to take to the streets in Taipei this Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS GROUP URGES BEIJING TO ANNUL ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 23 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: The Frankfurt-based International Society for Human Rights (ISHR) has urged China to unconditionally rescind its recently enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

In an open letter signed by ISHR Chairman Karl Hafen March 21, the organization described the law as a "war-authorizing bill" against Taiwan and called on European nations not to overlook Beijing's military intimidation and threat.

Beijing authorities have continuously oppressed dissidents, minorities and religious believers and have carried out the world's most executions, it noted, adding that Beijing's claim that the Anti-Secession Law is aimed at pursuing peaceful reunification of Taiwan and China is not credible.
All countries around the world should ask China in the United Nations to quash the controversial law, it went on.
The open letter also urged the European Union to abandon its plan to lift its arms embargo against China.
It said that whether or not Taiwan and China unite, and if so when and how, is a matter that must be decided by the people of Taiwan, who have enjoyed freedom and the protection of human rights.

China's rubber-stamp parliament, the National People's Congress, approved the law March 14, authorizing the Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.
Founded in 1972, the ISHR is an international non-governmental organization that bases its work on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights proclaimed by the United Nations on Dec. 10, 1948.

It seeks to promote international understanding and tolerance in all areas of culture and society and acts according to the philosophy that the realization of human rights and the improvement of social conditions cannot be pursued by the use of force.
