DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN COULD SUPPORT U.S. IN FIGHT FOR TAIWAN: REP TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Japan is forbidden by its constitution from having an army or navy and is thereby incapable of engaging in a war; however, it could extend logistical support to the United States should the U.S. go to war over Taiwan, Republic of China's representative to Japan said in Taipei Wednesday.

Koh Se-kai told the Legislative Yuan that Japan has been reluctant to take sides in the confrontation between the United States and China over the Taiwan issue because it needs Chinese support in its bid to join the United Nations Security Council.

But Tokyo has shed its reluctance since the end of last year by airing its concerns over Taiwan's security more assertively because of its realization that China is a potential threat to the region, Koh said.
Taiwan was relieved when Japan said in February that the peaceful solution of the Taiwan issue is a strategic objective shared by it and the United States, Koh said.

Although Japan has extended visa-free privileges to Taiwan tourists during the period of its Expo 2005 Aichi, Taiwan's five top leaders, namely the president, vice president, premier, defense minister and foreign minister have yet to receive approval from Tokyo to visit Japan, Koh said.

Also exempt from the visa-free program are 48 senior government officials and the first lady, Wu Shu-jen, who will have to give Japanese authorities 10 days' advance notice before visiting, Koh explained.
Koh said he didn't think there would be any problem for the first lady to visit Expo 2005 Aichi, if she wishes.
He made the comments in response to a recent report that Wu was interested in visiting Expo 2005 Aichi, but was worried that her visit might cause embarrassment to the host country.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WANT TAIWAN TO COMMIT ON ANTI-SUBMARINE AIRCRAFT BY MAY 1

TEXT.P: The United States has asked Taiwan to decide before May whether it intends to buy 12 U.S.-made P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, an Naval official told the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.
Navy General Staff Vice Admiral Lee Hai-tung said the U.S. might withdraw its offer to sell the planes if Taiwan fails to commit to the deal before May 1.

He said he did not agree with an opposition lawmaker's sarcastic claim that Taiwan is America's watchdog in the Taiwan Strait, but he admitted that Taiwan would share with the United States information gathered by its anti-submarine aircraft.

In a briefing to the legislature, Lee said the 12 P-3Cs offered by the United States are the same model currently in use by the U.S. and would therefore make exchanging information on the planes with the U.S. easy.

Lee said the 12 P-3Cs are the minimum Taiwan requires to shield itself from underwater attacks, and after being retrofitted, they would replace the country's aging anti-submarine fleet of 26 S-2Ts. They may also be used in combination with forces on and beneath the water to expand the current area patrolled by a factor of 10.

Given the fact that P-3Cs are in service in at least 16 countries around the world, the U.S. is eager to know whether Taiwan will accept its offer as orders from other countries are piling up, Lee claimed.

The P-3Cs are part of a proposed arms purchase from the U.S. The package was originally budgeted at NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) , but is now being considered at NT$480 billion due to currency changes and a decision not to build submarines included in the deal in Taiwan.
The budget for the purchase has been stuck in the legislature because of opposition parties who think that the weapons are overpriced and will not approve the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCOMPANYING LAWS EXPECTED TO STEP UP CHINA'S THREAT TO TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Beijing is expected to enact ancillary laws and refine its Anti-Secession Law to intensify its intimidation of Taiwan, according to a report submitted by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to the legislature Wednesday.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu will outline the report Thursday at the Legislative Yuan on the government's countermeasures to tackle the latest development across the Taiwan Strait after Beijing's enactment of the law last week.

Pointing out that Beijing has been using a "carrot and stick" approach to cross-strait affairs while turning a blind eye to Taiwan's opposition, Wu said in the report that Beijing is likely to continue promoting interactions in an effort to create a friendly image and diminish criticisms from the international community.

The report goes on to say that the Chinese foreign ministry has been trying to gain international backing for the Anti-Secession Law by sending ranking officials for visits abroad and maintaining close links with Chinese-language media around the world.

Beijing is expected to introduce complementary laws, such as "emergency state decrees" or a "military mobilization law" to further cement its legal basis to define its "one China" principle and the status quo in the strait in terms of sovereignty disputes with Taiwan, the report says.

To protect Taiwan's overall interests and national security in cases of irrational actions by Beijing, the MAC will comprehensively assess ensuing complications of the Anti-Secession Law as a gauge of how to conduct cross-strait exchanges, despite the fact that peace and development remain the two central themes in government policy regarding China.
The People's National Congress, China's parliament, approved the Anti-Secession Law March 14 in view of a mounting pro-independence movement in Taiwan.
Although President Chen Shui-bian has repeatedly claimed that he will not declare Taiwan independence during his term, Beijing remains highly wary of an independence-minded Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION DECREASES IN FEBRUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index stood at 103.41 for February, down 13.26 percent from the previous year's level and down 17.3 percent month-to-month, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The decrease brought the country's accumulated industrial output in the first two months to a negative annual growth of 1.45 percent, Chang Yaw-tzong, director of the MOEA statistics department said.
Chang also expressed his concern that industrial production may suffer another setback in March given that international oil prices continue to surge and global economic growth is slowing.

The appreciation of Taiwan's currency against the U.S. dollar and the number of working days in February being less than the previous year due to the weeklong Chinese New Year holiday were other factors attributing to the decrease, he went on.
Taiwan's industrial output index posted 124.75 for January, an annual expansion of 13 percent but a 4.65 percent fall from the December 2004 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EXPENDITURE IN ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION INCREASES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's expenditure in environmental protection amounted to NT$107.3 billion (US$3.44 billion) in 2003, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
The figure represents a per capita expenditure of NT$4,753 in 2003, EPA officials said.

Taiwan has been spending more money in the research and development of environmental protection facilities and operations, the officials said, citing the fact that the R&D expenditure increased to NT$5 billion in 2003 from NT$800 million in 2001 as an example.
The spending on operations and maintenance of the country's environmental protection facilities also increased to NT$29.85 billion from NT$19.05 billion during the three-year period, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MOVES UP TWO NOTCHES IN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has moved up two notches in the Global Information Technology Report compiled by the World Economic Forum and releaded earlier this month in Geneva, an official said in Taipei Wednesday.
Minister without Portfolio Lin Ferng-ching said the 2004-2005 report, which assesses the network readiness of 104 economies around the world, placed Taiwan 15th, comparing to 17th last year.
The Networked Readiness Index prepared by the report measures the degree of preparation of a nation or community to participate in and benefit from information and communication technology (ICT).

The index is composed of three component indexes which assess the environment for ICT offered by a given country or community; the readiness of the community's key stakeholders; and the usage of ICT among these stakeholders.

Lin said Taiwan moved up from 17th the previous year to fourth this year in terms of readiness, from 22nd the previous year to 11th this year in terms of usage, but dropped from eighth place last year to 23rd this year in terms of environment.
He blamed the drop in the ranking of environment on the poor scores Taiwan got in the effectiveness of law, the independence of its judiciary, and the protection of intellectual property.
However, Lin said the country's move up in the overall ranking indicates that the government's programs to promote the development and use of information technology is beginning to bear fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN THAILAND DENOUNCES ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Thailand, March 23 (CNA) (By Wu Hsieh-chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Fifteen Taiwan Chambers of Commerce in Thailand denounced Beijing's Anti-Secession Law Wednesday, saying it only further alienates Taiwan people from those in China.
In a joint statement, the groups said they firmly support the Republic of China and oppose any attempt to change the status of Taiwan without the assent of its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, March 24, or the 15th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1401: Tamerlane, or Tamburlaine, the Mongolian ruler who led his hordes from their capital of Samarkand in central Asia to overrun vast areas of Persia, Turkey, Russia and India, conquers Damascus.
1603: Elizabeth I, Queen of England and Ireland who succeeded the Catholic Mary I and reestablished Protestantism in England, dies at the age of 70. Her reign was marked by the execution of Mary Queen of Scots, the defeat of the Spanish Armada, and domestic prosperity and literary achievement.
1783: Spain recognizes the independence of the United States.
1882: Robert Koch, the German bacteriologist who discovered the cholera bacillus and the bacterial cause of anthrax, announces the isolation of tuberculosis germs. He later won a 1905 Nobel Prize for developing tuberculin.
1839: Ching Dynasty Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu closes down 13 guilds in Kwangtung after foreign merchants such as Lancelot Dent refused to yield all the opium stored on Lingting Island. The foreign merchants finally gave in and handed over 22,830 chests of opium to Lin who, to the dismay of the drug dealers, promptly burned them.
1911: Denmark abolishes capital punishment.
1921: The first Women's Olympic Games are held in Monte Carlo, Monaco.
1927: The Chinese communists seize Nanking.
1938: British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain admits that he will not oppose German Chancellor Adolf Hitler's annexation of Czechoslovakia, in the interests of avoiding war between Britain and Germany.
1951: American General Douglas MacArthur issues a statement advocating that Allied forces fighting in Korea should push the war to the Chinese mainland.
1954: Chen Cheng is elected by the National Assembly as the vice president of the Republic of China for a six-year term.
1959: More than 10,000 monks in Lhasa join the Tibetan revolt against the communists when new fighting erupts between the two sides.
1974: Henry Kerns, former chairman and president of the U.S. Export-Import Bank, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1975: Vice Adm. George P. Steele, commander of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives at Keelung aboard his flagship USS Oklahoma for a three-day visit.
1976: Charles Sperck, president of U.S. National Semiconductor Corp., arrives in Taipei on a business trip.
1976: Argentinian President Isabel Peron, third wife of former President Juan Peron, is deposed by the army in a bloodless coup. She was succeeded by Gen. Jorgi Videla.
1976: U.S. Chase Manhattan Bank and Continental Illinois National Bank jointly loan US$15 million to Taiwan Fertilizer Corp.
1984: Taiwan's first liver transplant surgery is completed at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
1988: The Government Information Office and the Ministry of National Defense reiterate that the Republic of China has never engaged in the development of nuclear weapons. This is confirmed by the U.S. government.
1989: Stanley Pons of the University of Utah and Martin Fleischmann of the University of Souththampton publish a paper in which they claim to have unlocked the secret of cold nuclear fusion.
1994: The ROC Legislative Yuan increases the annual maximum number of permanent residency permits for mainland spouses from 300 to 600.
1995: Beijing Premier Li Peng signs a declaration announcing a five-day work week.
1998: The European Union declares 11 nations eligible to issue the euro, the currency that will eventually replace their respective national currencies.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, who concurrently served as the Kuomintang's chairman, steps down from the party chairmanship to assume political responsibility for the party's defeat in the presidential election. Lee's presidential tenure will end May 20.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man allows himself to lose his temper and forget himself of a morning, in such a way as to become careless for the safety of his own person and for the safety of his parents and friends -- is that not a case of a great delusion in life?"

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM DIPLOMATIC TOUR

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu arrived back in Taiwan Thursday after a two-leg diplomatic tour to El Salvador and Guatemala to cement bilateral diplomatic relations.

In addition to helping consolidate relations with two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America, Lu said, her 12-day overseas visit also laid the groundwork for local entrepreneurs to launch new investment projects in the region.
Lu made transit stops in Houston and Miami en route to and from Central America.
Due to her hectic schedule, Lu developed acute inflammation of her left eye. Doctors said her eye will soon get better.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY, PEACE BEST CURE FOR AUTOCRACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan expects China to use rational, democratic and peaceful methods, not "non-peaceful means," in its rise as a regional power.
Chen made the remarks at the annual congress of the Association of Asian Election Authorities which is being held in Taipei.

Noting that China's quick rise has led to both expectations and concerns in the international community, Chen said he is worried about failure by Beijing to recognize that an attempt to use "non-peaceful means" to deal with relations across the Taiwan Strait could cause cross-strait tension and regional instability.
In his view, Chen went on, peace and democracy are the best cure for autocracy and military force. "We look forward to China's early democratization," Chen added.

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Council tax bills increase by twice rate of inflation
Council tax bills will rise by more than twice the rate of inflation next month, with even bigger increases predicted for the next two years.
Opposition parties gave warning yesterday that householders faced soaring bills after the general election when homes will be revalued.
The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats pointed out that the average council tax bill had risen above 1,000 for the first time after increases of more than 74 per cent since Labour came to power in 1997.
Financial Times: Chirac demands end to rebate.
Jacques Chirac, French president, on Wednesday embarked on a campaign to scrap Britain's rebate from the European Union budget, blowing a hole in the fragile unity shown at a two-day EU summit in Brussels.
Mr Chirac foreshadowed a potentially explosive clash over money in Europe, warning that the British rebate - worth an average ?4.6bn a year - could "no longer be justified".

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Jakarta bars new budget flights to 4 key cities.
Indonesia is closing its doors to foreign budget airlines applying to fly to four key cities - Jakarta, Medan, Surabaya and Denpasar - in a bid to protect its fledgling air transport industry.
Transoprtation Minister Hatta Rajasa also said that, for now, applications to fly to Yogyakarta and Semarang in Central Java would not be approved either.
Singapore's Transport Ministry said that if Indonesia feels low-cost carriers should not be encouraged on the affected routes, the policy should apply to airlines of both countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO JOIN MARCH 26 RALLY AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Thursday his decision to take part in a large-scale rally set for March 26 against China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
However, Chen said he will not give any speech or play the leading role in the rally.
"I can't and won't be absent on March 26 and will take my whole family to participate in this sacred moment of history, walking and standing by the Taiwan people," Chen said.
"I'll shout together with everybody to the other side of the Taiwan Strait that 'we want democracy, we love peace,'" he added.
The president made the announcement when meeting representatives of the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led group that is organizing the rally.
The group has set the goal of attracting at least one million people to participate in the "326 March for Democracy and Peace" event.

Chen said he has heard the outrage and resentment of the people toward Beijing's wilful decision to enact the Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan in certain situations, disregarding the objections of the vast majority of the people in Taiwan and widespread condemnation from the international community.

The people on this island know very well that Taiwan's achievements in terms of democratic and economic development are likely to be destroyed by such undemocratic and non-peaceful means adopted by China, Chen noted.

He recalled that more than two million Taiwan people held their hands on Feb. 28 last year to form "the Great Wall of Taiwan democracy" and exhibit to the world the collective resolve of the Taiwan people against China's missile threat.

"Two days from now, one million Taiwan people will take to the streets in the most rational, democratic and humble manner to again express the true voice of Taiwan for 'democracy, peace and security,'" he said.

According to Chen, one million people will say in one voice to China and to the world that the passage of the Anti-Secession Law has damaged the peaceful status quo across the strait, posed a serious threat to the universal values of freedom, democracy and human rights, and marked the regression of human civilization.
The president said he is convinced that democracy and peace are not only the best remedy for dictatorship and force but also the most powerful asset Taiwan has to win international support.
"Eventually, the 1.3 billion people in mainland China will stand on the side of democracy and peace," Chen predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Schiavo's Parents Appeal to the Supreme Court on Feeding Tube.
Gov. Jeb Bush also succeeded in getting a Florida court to hear new motions in the case of a brain-damaged woman.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL:
MCI to Resume Talks With Qwest
MCI Inc.'s board decided to resume merger discussions with Qwest Communications International Inc. until March 29, buying itself more time to consider whether to go through with its planned acquisition by Verizon Communications Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS TO KEEP LOW PROFILE IN MARCH 26 RALLY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Ranking government officials will be "in the second line" in the large protest Saturday in Taipei against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, Premier Frank Hsieh said Thursday.

Hsieh said that government officials will not be "in the frontline" and will not give any speeches. The move is to play down the government's role in the demonstration initiated by a private organization, he added.

The premier called on government functionaries to actively take part in the rally and urged the public not to criticize those who don't participate in it. In a democracy, all sorts of opinions are acceptable, he pointed out.

Hsieh himself will participate in the protest. President Chen Shui-bian announced earlier the same day that he will take part in the demonstration along with his family, but will not deliver any speech on the occasion.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party said it is optimistic that more than one million people from across Taiwan will take part in Saturday's rally in Taipei to express their opposition to Beijing's recent passage of the law, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

Despite President Chen's reiteration that he will not change the official title of the Republic of China and will not declare Taiwan independence during his term, Beijing remains highly wary of a what it sees as an independence-minded Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: VARIOUS FACTORS USED TO ASSESS RESUMPTION OF CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges could return to normal after several events take place, with the election of the representatives for the mission-oriented National Assembly on May 14 being just one of them, the nation's top China policy planner said Thursday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks while answering questions by Legislator John Chiang of the opposition Kuomintang at the Legislative Yuan.

Chiang claimed that Wu had said privately that cross-strait exchanges that have stalled in the wake of China's recent enactment of an Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan would get back on track after the election of the representatives to the ad hoc National Assembly.
Wu, however, made it clear that the government usually assesses whether to tighten or relax cross-strait interactions based on a number of things.
The election is only one factor in determining how future relations will play out, Wu said.

He said that the election of the ad hoc National Assembly is significant in that it will highlight the new mandate of the people. For cross-strait exchanges to get back on a normal footing, however, the MAC will cautiously weigh domestic political factors as well as the international situation and the atmosphere across the Strait, he added.

Wu added emphatically that proposed direct cross-strait charter passenger flights for Tomb-sweeping Day, which falls on April 5, would "not be feasible, " adding that the government has never said it wants to promote direct cross-strait charter passenger flights on holidays, and especially with this upcoming holiday which is only days away. Moreover, the atmosphere has been soured by the enactment of Beijing's new law.

Meanwhile, commenting on an article by Richard Bush, a former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, to the China Times, a major Chinese daily in Taiwan, Wu said that Bush is encouraging Taiwan to adopt a responsible approach -- as it is now doing -- in dealing with the law.

Bush said in his article that Taiwan can of course protest to express its opposition to the Anti-Secession Law, but he also urged Taiwan to protect its own interests and the status quo by not overreacting.
Wu said self-restraint by Taiwan is present government policy.

Legislator Chiang urged the government "not to misread the message sent by the U.S." He interpreted the former AIT chairman as worrying that President Chen Shui-bian's participation in an upcoming protest march against Beijing's law will exacerbate cross-strait tensions.

Wu said that he didn't feel that the U.S. was concerned about whether or not the president takes part in the Saturday protest, adding that the U.S. "has never said that it is better that President Chen not take to the streets."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT TO TAKE PART IN MARCH 26 RALLY

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui will join his successor, Chen Shui-bian, and Premier Frank Hsieh in participating in a large rally set for March 26 in Taipei against China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, organizers said Thursday.
However, Lee will only walk part of the way and will not give a speech, the organizers said.
Also on March 26, the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will hold a sit-in in Kaohsiung City against what it terms China's aggressive legislation.

According to TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming and Kaohsiung City Councilor Chao Tien-lin, participants at the demonstration will be encouraged to bring along their notebook computers or PDAs to send out protest letters to the rest of the world.

To set an example, the two politicians and a group of young people on Thursday sent e-mails to U.S. President George W. Bush, the United Nations and China's Taiwan Affairs Office to express the objections of the people of Taiwan toward the Anti-Secession Law.
The letters stressed that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state and that any decision concerning Taiwan will have to be approved by the 23 million people on the island.
It said China has no right to determine the fate of Taiwan unilaterally and it should scrap its Anti-Secession Law immediately.

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators on Thursday called on people, regardless of their ethnic background, to come out and take part in the March 26 rally to "protect Taiwan."
Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said Taiwan should not be fractured by ethnic differences.

Regardless where they are from, what language they speak and whether they are Republic of China nationals, people should reject China's annexation as long as they identify with Taiwan's sovereignty, democracy and freedom, Lai said.
The "326 March for Democracy and Peace" is being organized by the DPP-led Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, with a goal of attracting at least one million participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Refinery Blast in Texas Kills 14.
Cause of the explosion, which injured more than 100 people, is unknown.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Protests Move to the Kyrgyz Capital.

Kyrgyzstan's new hard-line interior minister warned on Wednesday that force could be used to restore order, and riot police violently broke up an opposition rally in the capital, Bishkek, sending a signal that authorities were determined to prevent protests from spreading north.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY PERSONNEL TO AVOID MARCH 26 PROTEST: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: It is improper for military personnel to take part in Saturday's protest in Taipei given that the purpose of the demonstration does not conform to the military's mission, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Thursday.
Lee made the remarks while answering questions from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers Ting Shou-chung and Lu Shiow-yen in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Despite the fact that a large demonstration is being organized for this weekend to protest Beijing's Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan, Lee said he believes that all military members are fully aware of relevant regulations, and that none of them will participate in the rally.
As for non-military personnel within the Ministry of National Defense, Lee said that it is up to their own discretion whether or not to participate.

Lee also said that the military has no plan to step up its combat preparedness that same day, as no abnormal activities of the Chinese military have been detected in recent days. The defense minister added that he himself will keep a close tab on military movements on the other side of the Taiwan Strait Saturday.

President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh have both announced that they will take part in the demonstration, which organizers said is expected to draw at least one million people from across the country.
Beijing enacted the law on March 14 to stem moves toward Taiwan independence through non-peaceful means under conditions that it sets.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.095 to close at NT$31.464.
A total of US$966 million changed hands during the trading session.
The greenback opened at NT$31.460 and fluctuated between NT$30.412 and NT$31.515.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Shares prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 18.49 points to close at 6,001.00.

The bourse opened at 6,029.74 points and fluctuated between 6,054.65 and 6,001.00 during trading. A total of 2.90 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.17 billion (US$2.31 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile shares moving down the most by 1.0 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals and construction stocks by 0.9 percent, banking and financial issues by 0.6 percent as well as cement shares by 0.4 percent.

Three other major stock categories gained ground with foodstuff issues moving up the most by 0.2 percent, followed by machinery and electronics as well as paper and pulp stocks by 0.1 percent, respectively.
Losers outnumbered gainers 497 to 353, with 166 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICA VISIT FRUITFUL: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday her just-concluded two-leg diplomatic tour to El Salvador and Guatemala was a success.
Lu made the remarks after her arrival back at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

In addition to helping consolidate relations with two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America, Lu said, her 12-day overseas visit also laid the groundwork for local entrepreneurs to launch new investment projects in the region.

During her visit, Lu said, she and her entourage received a warm welcome from the top leaders and senior officials of the two host countries. Lu was also invited to deliver speeches at the Salvadoran and Guatemalan parliaments and their noted universities.

Lu said the presidents and parliamentarians of the two Central American allies all voiced their opposition to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan and extended their staunch support for Taiwan's cause.

"The Guatemalan parliamentary speaker has promised to join with his counterparts in other Central American countries that maintain diplomatic ties with us in issuing a joint statement against China's Anti-Secession Law and in support of our national stance after the Easter holiday, " Lu said, adding that all these moves point to the success of her visit in cementing bilateral diplomatic relations.

On the promotion of bilateral economic cooperation, Lu said 18 possible cooperative projects have been worked out by the 100-plus members of the delegation that accompanied her on her two-leg Central America visit.

"The mission members from government agencies, the academic community and the business circles made field studies and held numerous rounds of talks with their Salvadoran and Guatemalan counterparts to flesh out 18 feasible cooperative projects in agricultural and industrial fields, " Lu said, adding that she will host a news conference Friday to unveil details of those proposed cooperative projects.

She further said Guatemalan President Oscar Berger Perdomo, and Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma De Escobar, are to visit Taipei later this year to sign free trade agreements or attend the inaugural ceremony of the Pacific Democratic Union.
Moreover, Lu said, Taiwan's decision to finance an historical relics restoration and renovation project in Guatemala has received wide acclaim and recognition from the United States.

During her stay in Guatemala City, Lu signed a letter of intent with her Guatemalan counterpart on Taiwan's participation in the cultural relics restoration project. According to preliminary plans, Taiwan will help restore and renovate Museum Pilar de Zaragoza and Monastery Sor Juana located in Antigua City, a monumental city founded in 1543 with strong Spanish colonial influence.
Restoration and renovation of the two historical sites are expected to be completed in two years, with a budget of around US$700,000, Lu said.
Turning to domestic affairs, Lu urged local people to join a huge protest march in Taipei this weekend to voice their opposition to Beijing's so-called anti-secession law.

"The people of Taiwan should take to the streets to defend our national dignity and sovereignty in a peaceful and rational manner, " Lu said, adding she is hopeful that all would-be demonstrators refrain from irrational or extremist actions.

Asked whether she will take part in the protest march, Lu said she has yet to make a decision. "I'll discuss with President Chen Shui-bian and then make a decision in terms of the general situation and my health," Lu said.
Because of her hectic schedule, Lu developed an acute inflammation of her left eye. Doctors said her eye will soon get better.
Lu made transit stops in Houston and Miami en route to and from Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained two points to close at 6,012, with 23,312 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved up two points to finish at 6,010, with 130 contracts traded, while June futures lost three points to finish at 5,995, with 72 contracts traded.
September futures gained three points to finish at 5,894, with 67 contracts traded, while December futures moved down six points to close at 5,885, with six contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 6,010 for April, 6,008 for May, 5,998 for June, 5,891 for September and 5,891 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

April TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 229, with 3,911 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 1.05 points to finish at 228.5, with 21 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 0.65 points to close at 227, with one contract traded, while December TE futures moved up 2.1 points to close at 228.9, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June.

April TF futures lost 2.8 points to finish at 974, with 2,941 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved down 2.0 points to end at 974, with 25 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down 2.2 points to finish at 974, with four contract transactions, while September TF futures lost 4.6 points to end at 970, with three contracts traded. December TF futures moved down seven points to end at 965.4, with six contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO RESIST CHINA'S AGGRESSION WITH DEMOCRACY: DPP

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang Thursday called on people to take an active part in the March 26 rally against China's Anti-Secession Law, saying Taiwan must resist the aggressive legislation with democracy.
Su said more than 500 civic groups have signed up for the event and that opinion polls also show that more than 1.4 million people have decided to participate.

Su made the remarks at a news conference hosted by the DPP-led Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, the organizer of the "326 March for Democracy and Peace" to be held in Taipei. The group has set a goal of attracting at least one million participants.

According to Su, the 23 million peace-loving people in Taiwan have never tried to provoke anyone, but China has turned a blind eye to Taiwan's goodwill and its efforts to maintain cross-Taiwan Strait peace and stability.

While Taiwan has built up an open and democratic society after decades of hard work, undemocratic China is now using the Anti-Secession Law that authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan's 23 million people, Su said.

He said the parade will be an unprecedented one that was initiated spontaneously by the private sector, with one million people demonstrating their firm resolve to protect Taiwan's sovereignty, democracy and freedom.
President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh and former President Lee Teng-hui have all decided to take part in the rally.
The protesters will be divided into 10 groups, who will set off from 10 different places in Taipei and march to the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office, according to the alliance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BAR ASSOCIATION MEMBERS TO JOIN 326 MARCH

TEXT.P: Members of the Taiwan Bar Association will take part in the "326 March for Democracy and Peace" Saturday to protest Beijing's enactment of an Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, an association official said Thursday.

Lawyer Su You-chen, secretary-general of the Taiwan Bar Association, which groups some 4,000 lawyers practicing in Taiwan, called for all members of the association to participate in the rally to be held in Taipei to protest the Beijing law, which authorizes China's People's Liberation Army to take Taiwan by "non-peaceful means" if it thinks Taiwan is making moves toward independence.
The Taiwan Bar Association will also issue a petition with signatures of lawyers from the organization Saturday to say "no" to China's aggression, Su said.
Su claimed that the Anti-Secession Law violates the United Nations charter of protecting "racial autonomy" and people's rights pledged by the U.N. Declaration of Human Rights.

This pre-emptive Anti-Secession Law is changing the cross-strait status quo unilaterally and bringing the people across the Strait to the brink of war, Su claimed, adding that the law also infringes on the Taiwan people's rights to survival and autonomy.

Stressing "no to war, aggression and annexation; yes to peace, freedom and democracy, " the bar association will also seek support from its counterparts in the international community, as well as international human rights bodies, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS AS USUAL FOR ECONOMICS MINISTER AFTER PREMIER'S HARSH WORDS

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Thursday that an apparent "dressing down" by Premier Frank Hsieh the previous day did not bother her and that there was nothing in the air about her having to change jobs.
Ho made the remarks when she was reporting on the budget of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) for 2005 to the Economics and Energy Committee in the Legislative Yuan.

Legislators instead were more concerned about how the premier took her to task in a Cabinet floor meeting the previous day for not keeping him informed about the price hikes of petroleum products of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. and Taiwan Fertilizer's investment project in mainland China. The premier said that those in the Ministry of Economic Affairs should think deeply about their actions.

Reports said that sour relations between Ho and Hsieh could be traced to the time when the former was vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the latter was former Kaohsiung mayor. The reports also said that Ho could see her post change in the second-wave of Cabinet appointments in August.
Hsieh's Cabinet retained most of the members from the previous one with only minor changes when he assumed the premiership on Feb. 1.

Ho said that prices for petroleum products are subject to the free market, and recent surges in oil prices have forced the adjustment of petroleum prices in Taiwan. The premier is concerned about changes to the public's lifestyle due to the change in oil and consumer prices, so he had asked her to inform him prior to price hikes. She didn't feel that the premier was "scolding her."
Ho said that the Executive Yuan had made no such requests before, and the ministry will from now on follow instructions. "My feelings are not affected," she added.

On the reports that she might be shifted to a different position, Ho said that the premier had said before that there would be a accommodation period between himself and Cabinet members, and it would be reasonable for a Cabinet reshuffle in August, although she was not aware of any impending changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TO PAY LESS IN HEALTH INSURANCE PREMIUMS UNDER DOH'S NEW PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has re-engineered the National Health Insurance system so that 74 percent of those covered will pay less in premiums, DOH Minister Ho Sheng-mao said Thursday.
Ho gave the outline of the "second-generation program, " at the Legislative Yuan. The health department is banking of the success of the new system to salvage the cash-strapped program.
Ho said a great majority of the people will not necessarily pay more in health insurance premiums under the new system, but premiums for high-income people will definitely increase.

Six categories of the insured will be scrapped, and the premium payment will be changed from being based on individual incomes to household incomes, and the government and employers will also shoulder the premium payments according to a set formula.

Lee Cheng-hua, vice president of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, said that the revenue of the national health insurance premium is expected to increase by 1.2 percent under the second-generation health insurance program.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REOPEN IMPORTS OF U.S. BEEF NEXT MONTH: HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan will conditionally allow U.S. beef back into the local market beginning April 16 following the suspension of imports in 2003 due to the discovery of a case of mad cow disease, a Department of Health official said Thursday.

U.S. beef and beef products, that is, beef cattle under 2.5 years old, clear of specific risk materials, including bones, offal, brain, trigeminal ganglia, dorsal root ganglia and spinal marrow, and with certificates issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), will be allowed to be imported into Taiwan from April 16, said Chen Lu-hung, director of the health department's Bureau of Food Safety.

The bureau will also ask the USDA to provide Taiwan with a list of the names of legal, contracted U.S. slaughterhouses to be used as a reference to make sure that all the beef reintroduced into Taiwan are from these companies, Chen said.
The health department will also consult with the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture for other details pertaining to the imports, Chen added.

Taiwan suspended beef imports from the United States in December 2003 due to safety concerns over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease, after the discovery in the U.S. state of Washington of a single BSE case at a cattle ranch.

Taiwan health and agriculture officials have traveled to the U.S. to conduct on-site inspections of the implementation of the U.S. safeguards against mad cow disease and have recently completed the reviews necessary for resuming the beef trade.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before Taiwan imposed the ban in December 2003. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, have imposed embargoes against U.S. beef, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year. Big names in the beef export trade, including Tyson Foods, Inc. and Cargill, Inc., have exerted great pressure on the USDA for the early resumption of exports to these former importing countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOB-CREATION PROJECT HELPS LOWER 2004 JOBLESS RATE

TEXT.P: The overall unemployment rate for 2004 dropped by 0.55 percent from the previous year's level to 4.44 percent thanks to a government program aimed at creating short-term jobs for underprivileged groups, a government official said Thursday.

The government began to carry out a project of expanding employment in the public service sector in 2003 to help curb the growing jobless rate, said the official with the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The official pointed out that the job creation program ended earlier this year, with the total outlay reaching NT$28.5 billion (US$0.91 billion) , adding that a total of 8,200 job opportunities were created during the 2003-2004 period.

As for the backgrounds of those hired for public services under the program, the official said that people aged 50-65 accounted for 50 percent of the total and that those having an education level lower than junior high school made up 44 percent.
Fifty-six percent of those hired said that the employment-boosting program was of much help to them while 89 percent expressed satisfaction with the project, the official went on.
Meanwhile, the government has also implemented a public construction expansion project since December 2002 to create employment opportunities for jobless people.

The official said that around 100 local construction programs which require an outlay of NT$57.7 billion, including communications, flood prevention and living environment improvement, have been launched, thereby creating 40,000 jobs.

The budget execution rate for the expanding public construction project stood at 96 percent, while the project contributed with 0.16 percentage points and 0.23 percentage points to the nation's 2003 and 2004 economic growth rate, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUPS IN NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY CONDEMN ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: New York, March 23 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng, Chiang Ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Leaders of Taiwanese groups and associations in New York and New Jersey on Wednesday strongly condemned China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
More than a dozen Taiwanese associations, including the Taiwan Compatriot Association in Greater New York, issued a three-point statement after a meeting in Flushing, New York, Wednesday night.

Noting that the law authorizes "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence, the leaders said that the status quo of the Republic of China is its independent sovereignty, and that Chinese authorities should not invade it by any means.
They also said that peace is the only option to solve cross-strait issues, and that they oppose Beijing using the pretext of anti-secession to invade Taiwan.
Thirdly, they said the authoritarian system in China is the greatest threat to stability in Asia and the Pacific, and that China should engage in democratic reforms as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, two dozen Taiwanese associations in northern California will stage a "326 March for Democracy and Peace" in tandem with the activity sponsored by the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace in Taipei.
More than 300 Taiwan expatriates are expected to take part in the march and protest against the passage of the Anti-Secession Law in front of China's general consulate in San Francisco.

An action committee to protest against China's Anti-Secession Law also said that the ROC is a sovereign, independent country and is independent to the People's Republic of China, and that Taiwan's future will hinge on the consent of its 23 million people and no other countries have the right to decide its fate unilaterally.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR DEMOCRACY, PEACE TO REPLACE AUTOCRACY, FORCE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan expects China to use rational, democratic and peaceful methods, not "non-peaceful means," in its rise as a regional power.
Chen made the remarks at the annual congress of the Association of Asian Election Authorities (AAEA), which is being held in Taipei.

Noting that China's quick rise has led to both expectations and concerns in the international community, Chen said he is worried about failure by Beijing to recognize that an attempt to use "non-peaceful means" to deal with relations across the Taiwan Strait could cause cross-strait tension and regional instability.
In his view, Chen went on, peace and democracy are the best cure for autocracy and military force. "We look forward to China's early democratization," Chen added.

The AAEA was founded in Manila in 1998 to provide a non-partisan forum for the exchange of information among election authorities to discuss and act on ways to promote open and transparent elections with the objective of supporting good governance and democracy. Similar associations have also been set up in the Caribbean, Central and Eastern Europe and Sub-Saharan Africa.

Chen said one of the toughest challenges facing Asia's democratic countries lies in pushing and assisting undemocratic countries in the region to peacefully and smoothly transform themselves into democracies.

Over the past two years, Chen said, residents in the authoritarian China-ruled Hong Kong Special Administrative Region have continued to campaign for democratic reform and an end to authoritarian rule.

Now that Taiwan has emerged as a strong force in the Asian democratic community, Chen said, he hopes that core democratic values, such as regular democratic elections, fair inter-party competition, peaceful power transition and de-linking of the military from politics, can become realities in China someday.
Chen further said 2004 could be described as the "year of elections in Asia" with many Asian countries, including Taiwan, holding general elections during the year.
"Although the electoral proceedings were not impeccable in various Asian countries, the elections embodied two precious values of democracy -- freedom of choice and fair competition," Chen said.

As a model of Asia's emerging democracies, Chen said, the Republic of China held its third direct presidential election last year. The people of Taiwan used "love" and democratic votes to elect him to a second term, Chen said, adding that the ROC government made strenuous efforts to prevent vote-buying and violence in the process.
Despite some controversies, Chen went on, Taiwan's judicial authorities have proved that the 2004 presidential election was open, fair, just and impartial.

Simultaneous with the 2004 presidential election, Chen said, Taiwan also held its first-ever nationwide referendum to show the world by a democratic method that only peaceful talks on an equal footing can forge a stable cross-strait relationship. The referendum also indicated that Taiwan must beef up its self-defense capability to protect Taiwan's hard-won democracy from being sabotaged by China through non-peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. INFORMED OF PRESIDENT'S DECISION TO JOIN 326 RALLY: MOFA

TEXT.P: The United States maintains close contact with Taiwan and is undoubtedly aware of President Chen Shui-bian's decision to take part in the March 26 rally against China's Anti-Secession Law, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.
Chen announced earlier in the day that he will participate in the demonstration to be held in Taipei but will not give a speech or play the leading role.

According to MOFA spokesman Michel Lu at a regular news briefing, Washington has said explicitly that the law, which virtually authorizes war against Taiwan, is unwelcome and has urged Taiwan to deal with the situation rationally, but it has not told Taiwan what not to do.

When the international media has paid much attention to the rally, all people of Taiwan, regardless of their political affiliations, should unite together against China and make Taiwan's position known to the international community, Lu said.
Lu said Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will also take part in the rally, while staff of the ministry are free to decide whether to participate or not.

Also on Thursday, National Security Bureau official Liu Shuo-tzung told the legislature's Judiciary Committee that the bureau will make full preparations to protect President Chen's security during the rally to prevent a repeat of last year's presidential election-eve shooting of the president and Vice President Annette Lu.
National Police Agency Deputy Director-General Hung Sheng-kun said the police will closely monitor the rally to decide how many policemen will be dispatched to maintain order.
Usually, the ratio will be 1,000 policemen to every 100,000 participants, Hung said.

The organizer of the "326 March for Democracy and Peace" is expecting at least one million participants. In addition to President Chen, Premier Frank Hsieh and former President Lee Teng-hui have also decided to participate.

However, Chen's and Hsieh's decision met with strong challenges from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) , which believe it is inappropriate for national leaders to take to the streets.
According to KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh, the government should deal with cross-Taiwan Strait issues with wisdom, not emotion.
Chen Chieh said the president's move is making the public confused as to which direction he is leading the country.
He claimed that the country's economic development, rather than such political mobilization, is what the people are concerned about.

Lee Yung-ping, a leader of the PFP legislative caucus, said President Chen, by taking part in the demonstration to pacify the resentment of pro-independence hardliners, will give the international community the wrong impression that the Republic of China is subordinate to the People's Republic of China.

Also expressing his disapproval of Chen's decision, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Cho-shui said staging a demonstration against China should be the job of the people, not government officials.

In response to the criticism, Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said although Chen is the head of state, he is still a member of the 23 million people on Taiwan who are obliged to come out to express their objections to the Anti-Secession Law.
Lai claimed President Chen's participation is not out of proportion because he will avoid giving a speech in the rally to play down his role as the president.
Meanwhile, Chen Chien-ming, secretary-general of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union, said his party will respect the decision of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ORCHID PRODUCTION TO GROW 10-FOLD IN FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's annual orchid production has exceeded US$100 million and is expected to grow by 10-fold in five years, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said Thursday.
Su made the remarks on the eve of the opening of the 2005 Taiwan International Orchid Trade Fair at the Taiwan Orchid Biotechnology Park in Houpi township in the southern county of Tainan.
President Chen Shui-bian will preside over the opening ceremony, Su said.
Noting that the orchid biotechnology park can offer one-stop orchid shopping, Su said foreign traders are welcome to visit the annual trade fair.
According to Su, Taiwan's orchid exports have been growing at an annual rate of more than 50 percent.
"I hope the biotechnology park can help our orchid farmers to further improve their competitive edge in the global market, " Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER DEFENDS URGENT NEED TO PURCHASE SUBMARINES

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Jye defended Thursday a clear need to acquire submarines to safeguard Taiwan, warning that China's navy is building a force with a long range war capability that will pose a serious threat to Taiwan by 2020.

Lee made the remarks while giving a keynote report on a proposal by his ministry on its submarine purchase, part of a major procurement plan worth billions of dollars of military equipment from the United States that also includes six PAC III Patriot anti-missile batteries and 12 P-3C Orion anti-submarine aircraft.

Saying that it is urgent and vital to purchase submarines to protect the country, Lee said that by 2020, the Chinese navy will be capable of reaching regions including the Taiwan Strait, the South China Sea and the Strait of Malacca.

At that time, it will generate a huge threat to Taiwan's economy and security, as the country totally relies on shipping to transport military and daily consumption materials through sea lanes in these regions, he warned, adding that with more than 80 submarines, the Chinese navy will be able to enforce a blockade against Taiwan.

To effectively deter such a possible attack, Taiwan has to own at least 10 submarines before 2020, which is the reason behind the ministry's plan to buy advanced diesel-electric subs equipped with sophisticated missiles from the United States that would help the Taiwan navy upgrade its surveillance abilities five-fold and tremendously sharpen its attack capabilities, he said.

He went on to say that his ministry has slashed its budget for eight subs to NT$297 billion (US$9.42 billion) from the previous level of NT$412 billion after taking into account a stronger new Taiwan dollar and a business strategy ruling out constructing the ships at home due to a lack of expertise.

In the face of discontent from various lawmakers of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) over what they describe "a high quotation" from the United States, the minister claimed that the high cost is due to the need for the United States to find a builder in a third country or reopen its own production lines to build the subs, a cost that has to be borne by Taiwan.

Speaking on the same occasion, ministry officials said Taiwan will be entitled to take over the blueprint and manufacturing facilities for the subs after the eight vessels have been built. They added that the ministry will seek cooperation opportunities from the United States in follow-up maintenance and repairs and promised to continue negotiations on a cheaper price offer.

The ministry's budget allocation for the eight submarines is the most disputed section of the arms procurement plan, which has triggered a partisan strife at the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

Lawmakers of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the People First Party and the New Party are strongly opposed to the arms procurement deal, calling it no more than pork barrel politics that will leave Taiwan's younger generations strapped with huge debt.

DOC.HEADLINE: 326 MARCH TO KICK OFF FROM 10 LOCATIONS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 326 March for Democracy and Peace against Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law is scheduled to kick off from 10 locations in Taipei at around 2:30 p.m. Saturday, the Taipei Municipal Police Department reported Thursday.

Protesters are expected to converge from around noon at the 10 locations, in preparation for walking a variety of routes around the city from 2: 30 p.m. to the Gongyuan-Ketagalan Plaza in front of the Presidential Office, according to a spokesman for the police department.

The 10 locations are: the Zhongshan Stadium; Taiping Elementary School on Chongqing North Road; the Rongxing Garden; Mingsheng East Road, Sec. 2; Tunhua Elementary School on Tunhua South Road; the Songshan Tobacco Factory; Taan Forest Park; National Taiwan University; the Mengjia Boulevard and Wanda Street Intersection; and the Zhongxing Bridge.
The police have no clue yet how long the marchers will take to reach the plaza, given the uncertainty in the number of people expected to turn out.

The marchers, who will include President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh and former President Lee Teng-hui, will meet at the plaza for a short period before the march ends there, according to the police.

Meanwhile, the Taipei police said that some 3,000 tourist buses are expected to enter Taipei City Saturday from around the island and that the number of people taking part in the march may far exceed 100,000, the official number that rally organizers have given to the police department.
Traffic controls will be in place in areas adjacent to the Presidential Office from 2 p.m. Saturday, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PUSH FOR TARIFF LOWERING AT WTO NAMA TALKS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plan to push for lowered customs tariffs on eight industrial products has received support and recognition from several World Trade Organization (WTO) member states, an official with the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Thursday.

BOFT Deputy Director-General Wu Hsin-hua said that on the sidelines of a recent WTO conference on non-agricultural market access (NAMA) , Taiwan delegates held talks with their counterparts from the United States, Canada, Japan, South Korea and Switzerland over a proposal to lower tariffs on garments, hand tools, timepieces, bicycles, dyestuffs, sporting goods, musical instruments and jewelry.

Representatives from these WTO member countries threw their support behind the proposal, aimed at boosting development of the global trade, and pledged to cooperate with Taiwan on relevant issues during future WTO talks, said Wu, who was also present at the conference.

According to Wu, the NAMA talks involved the lowering of tariffs on industrial, fishery and forest products and is one of the issues of the WTO Doha Round of trade negotiations that has drawn great attention from many member states.

Delegates from WTO member economies have held five rounds of NAMA talks since the so-called "July Package" was unveiled last year, but no real negotiations on tariff lowering formulas and complementary measures took place until the March 14-18 meeting, Wu said.

Wu added that formulaic tariff reductions will help reach the goal of lowering tariffs, but said the measure should target specific sectors because the tariffs structures of WTO member states are different.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO TIGHTENING WIRETAPPING AUTHORIZATION

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin reaffirmed Thursday the government's resolve to transfer the authority to order wiretaps from prosecutors to judges.

Shih made the reaffirmation at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session in which lawmakers from across the political spectrum lambasted what they said is the abuse of wiretap authorization by law enforcement authorities.

Shih said even though police authorities remain opposed to the proposal to delegate wiretap authorization to judges instead of prosecutors in the future, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is determined to uphold this new policy line.
At present, prosecutors' offices at various levels are tasked with the job of screening and authorizing wiretap applications.

Shih assured the lawmakers that the MOJ will come up with a draft package of revisions to the existing law as soon as possible to pave the way for transferring the wiretap authorization. The draft bill will then be referred to the legislature for approval, Shih added.
According to statistics compiled by the State Public Prosecutor-General's Office, a total of 19,485 wiretap applications were approved in 2004, a whopping increase from about 3,000 recorded in 2000.

More than 70 percent of the authorized wiretaps were related to drug trafficking and firearm trading investigations, and less than 10 percent were related to corruption probes. The wiretaps in some cases lasted for more than a year.

In comparison, the number of authorized wiretaps in Taiwan was almost double the number authorized in the United States in 2004. Lawmakers said the phenomenon was unreasonable given the population gap between the two countries.

"The United States has a population of more than 200 million, while Taiwan has only 23 million people. It seems to me that the number of our authorized wiretaps has grown out of proportion to our population and indicates that our prosecution authorities do not respect people's privacy and human rights, " Legislator Peng Shao-chin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORT BAN ON U.S. LIVE CATTLE TO REMAIN IN PLACE

TEXT.P: An import ban on live cattle from the United States will remain in place after U.S. beef is allowed to enter the Taiwan market again next month, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

The council made the announcement after the Department of Health (DOH) declared earlier in the day that the ban on U.S. beef imports will be conditionally lifted April 16, ending a more-than one-year import ban over concerns about bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease.

COA officials said the lifting of the import ban will be applicable strictly to items clearly listed by the DOH. The import ban on live cattle and related products will remain in place in line with regulations set forth by the World Animal Health Organization, the officials said.

According to the DOH announcement, U.S. beef and beef products, that is beef cattle under 2.5 years old, clear of specific risk materials, including bones, offal, brain, trigeminal ganglia, dorsal root ganglia and spinal marrow, and with certificates issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), will be allowed to enter the Taiwan market from April 16.
Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in the U.S. state of Washington of a single BSE case.
Taiwan had been the sixth-largest market for U.S. beef before the import ban was imposed in late 2003. Australia has since then dominated the Taiwan beef market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS URGED TO DIVERSIFY INVESTMENT LOCATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's business and industrial sectors were urged Thursday to diversify their investment locations overseas to prevent the investments from centering on Asia.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Liu Yi-ru, who was in Vice President Annette Lu's entourage during a recent official visit to Taiwan's Central American diplomatic allies of El Salvador and Guatemala, called for Taiwan businessmen to direct their overseas investment away from Asia, particularly China, to Latin America.
Liu, a finance professor-turned-legislator, said that nearly 80 percent of Taiwan's investments abroad are centered in Asia, leading to great investment risks.
He suggested that the administration provide Taiwan investors with useful information on Latin America to help them make decisions when they plan investments.

Bolstering investment in Central and South America will not only be mutually beneficial economically for Taiwan and the target countries, it will also help cement bilateral ties diplomatically, Liu noted.

Liu quoted Lu as saying that people in Taiwan should also try to develop interest in countries on the South American Continent instead of focusing their interest only on Asian countries such as Japan and South Korea.

Meanwhile, Legislator Yu Ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, who was also in Lu's 152-member entourage, said that Beijing passed its Anti-Secession Law exactly during the time when the Taiwan delegation under Lu's leadership was visiting Central America.

"We spared no efforts to win support in El Salvador, Guatemala and the United States, where the delegation made transit stays in two cities, for Taiwan's efforts to oppose the Beijing law, which authorizes it to use 'non-peaceful means' against Taiwan should it decide Taiwan is moving toward independence," Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO EMULATE TAIWAN CUSTOMS' SNIFFER DOG PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Japan is to send officials to Taiwan to learn from the country's experiences in using sniffer dogs at customs offices to prevent illegal animals and plants from being smuggled into Taiwan, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

The Japanese government, which has decided to follow Australia and the United States in using sniffer dogs as a means of strengthening quarantine defense at customs and immigration offices, will make use of Taiwan's experience, given that Taiwan is located near Japan and the two countries share some common ground in culture and other matters, according to COA officials.

Officials from Japan's Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries are expected to come to Taiwan in early April to learn from Taiwan's experience in using sniffer dogs, in addition to gaining an understanding of other affairs pertaining to quarantine work, COA officials said.
According to the COA Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, Taiwan began to use three groups of sniffer dogs for quarantine work at customs and immigration offices in 2002.
Today, there are eight groups of such dogs being worked at international airports and seaports islandwide, bureau officials said.

Altogether, the sniffer dogs searched a total of 12,232 arriving aircraft and vessels between 2001 and February this year, discovering 7.9 metric tons of illegal animals and animal products, as well as 11.4 metric tons of illegal plants and plant products, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNTY PLANNING TO BUILD BELT RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government is planning to build a rapid transit system connecting satellite cities around the Taipei metropolitan area, acting Taipei County Magistrate Lin Shyi-yaw said Thursday.
The first phase of the project, which will link the Hsintien, Chungho, Panchiao and Hsinchuang areas is scheduled to be completed in 2011, Lin noted.

It is estimated that the belt will have a capacity of transporting 270,000 people per day upon completion and will link with the existing five lines of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit System, Lin added.

The construction will cost about NT$49.7 billion (US$1.58 billion), of which NT$25.6 billion will come from the private sector, while the remaining NT$24.1 billion will be provided by the government, he went on.
The construction will be carried out under the build-operate-transfer (BOT) formula as part of the government's efforts to promote private participation in public construction projects, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY MAN `RUNNING FOR TAIWAN PEACE' FROM OLUANPI TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An elderly man who began running the 460 km from Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi March 20 as a protest against China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan arrived at the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chapter offices in Miaoli County Thursday.
Liu Chin-cheng, 64, continued his northward run after taking a break at the offices and is scheduled to arrive at the Presidential Office Saturday to take part in a large-scale protest over the law.

Prior to his departure, Liu, who has participated in similar demonstrations many times, said he will show the Hakka people's spirit of enduring hardship in order to arrive at the Presidential Office as scheduled.
An official with the DPP's Miaoli County chapter said that many locals have signed up to take part in the March 26 protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO HELP NARROW TAIWAN'S TRADE IMBALANCE WITH SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will continue with a series of sales promotion activities aimed at helping improve Taiwan's trade imbalance with South Korea, a TAITRA official said Thursday.

Taiwan recorded a deficit of US$6 billion in its trade exchanges with South Korea last year, so TAITRA and the Ministry of Economic Affairs will concentrate their efforts on narrowing the island's trade imbalance this year, according to the official.

A Taiwan delegation led by TAITRA officials took part in an international exposition of automated equipment in Seoul, the official went on, adding that several delegation members forged agreements with South Korean agents to promote their products there.

During the first quarter of this year, the number of South Korean buyers that came to Taiwan to visit the Taipei International Cycle Show and the Taipei International Machine Tools Show at TAITRA's invitation was higher than in the previous year, the official said. While in Taipei, they also held trade talks with local manufacturers.

The official said that during the second quarter of this year, several delegations organized by the Korean International Trade Association (KITA) and the Korean Importers Association (KOIMA) will arrive in Taiwan to hold trade talks with local manufacturers of electronic and textile products, machinery and auto parts and accessories.
Meanwhile, TAITRA will organize three delegations to participate in consumer goods and food shows to be held in April and May in South Korea to explore more trade opportunities.

The official suggested that Taiwan manufacturers wishing to display their products in the upcoming Korean expositions should prepare their catalogs in the Korean language if they want to win more orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, March 25, or the 16th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1306: Robert the Bruce, the eighth Earl of Carrick who defied Edward I of England, is crowned King of Scotland at Scone, becoming Robert I. He later won Scottish independence from England at the battle of Bannockburn in 1314.
1799: At the Battle of Stockach, 60,000 Austrians led by Archduke Charles defeat 40,000 French under Jourdan near Baden.
1807: Influenced by the philanthropic Member of Parliament William Wilberforce, the British Parliament abolishes the slave trade.
1815: Austria, Britain, Prussia and Russia form a new alliance against Napoleon Bonaparte of France.
1867: Arturo Toscanini, the Italian conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and many other orchestras worldwide, is born. He refused to conduct in Italy or Germany when they were ruled by the Fascists and the Nazis, respectively.
1936: Britain, France and the United States sign the London Naval Convention.
1937: Chiang Ching-kuo of the Republic of China leaves Moscow for home, ending a 12-year stay in the Soviet Union.
1941: Yugoslavia joins the Berlin-Rome-Tokyo Alliance, or Axis.
1950: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek issues a written order to posthumously commend Lien Heng, a noted historian.
1957: Six European nations -- France, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg -- take a historic step toward guaranteeing a future of peace and prosperity for their continent by signing the treaties for the European Economic Community and Euratom.
1971: The Penghu Cross-Sea Bridge, which has a 2,160-meter span between Paisha Island and Hsiyu in Taiwan's offshore county of Penghu, is opened to traffic.
1973: The Chinese National Ethics and Science Education Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Second Museum Conference of the ASPAC Cultural and Social Center opens in Taipei, with over 20 museum experts from six nations participating.
1975: Saudi Arabia's King Faisal is murdered at the age of 70 by his nephew Prince Faisal during a ceremony at the palace in Riyadh celebrating the birthday of the Prophet Mohammed.
1986: Construction of Taipei's Feitsui Reservoir is completed in the ROC.
1990: Hungary's first multiparty elections since 1949 are held, with the Hungarian Democratic Forum -- a non-communist party -- winning a majority.
1993: Jiang Zemin becomes president of Communist China.
1994: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait hold talks in Beijing on fishery disputes and the repatriation of illegal immigrants and hijackers.
1996: The United States, France and Britain sign the South Pacific Nuclear-Free Zone Treaty.
1996: Due to concerns over the possible spread of mad cow disease, officials from 15 European Union states agree to recommend a ban on exports of British beef products.
1997: Australia's parliament votes to overturn the world's only law allowing terminally ill patients to commit suicide with the help of a doctor.
1999: The Republic of China and Costa Rica sign agreements to boost bilateral economic and sports exchanges.
1999: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs informs 13 embassies in Taipei that the ROC has increased measures to protect embassy officials and staff members after death threats were received at the embassies.
2001: The host Chinese Taipei team wins the title in the 21st Asian Baseball Championship.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over an official welcoming ceremony for visiting Dominican President Hipolito Mejia in northeastern Taiwan's Ilan County.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral life of a man consists of loving men. Understanding consists of understanding men. Uphold the cause of the just, and put down every cause that is unjust in such a way that the unjust will be made just."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THOROUGHLY UNDERSTANDS FREEDOM, DEMOCRACY RIGHTS: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 24 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to the United States David Lee said Thursday that the United States thoroughly understands the rights of democracy and freedom.

Lee made the remarks while responding to media questions regarding Washington's opinion about ROC President Chen Shui-bian's decision to participate in a rally to be held in Taipei Saturday to voice the Taiwan people's opposition to China's anti-secession law.

Noting that the Republic of China is a free and democratic country whose people have the right to freely express their opinions, the representative said that the United States as a free and democratic country itself understands this clearly.
Meanwhile, U.S. State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli declined to comment at a press briefing the same day on Chen's announcement that he will participate in the rally.

"What I would tell you is that our position is to encourage both sides to look for opportunities for dialogue. And we continue to encourage both sides to avoid steps that could be seen as being unilateral or trying to resolve their differences in any way other than through dialogue," he said.

Terri Schiavo's parents went to the U.S. Supreme Court late Wedneday in a desperate attempt to keep their daughter alive, after a day in which a federal court in Atlanta turned away their appeals and Florida lawmakers decided not to intervene.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Softbank unit given NBS Fuji TV stake
A Softbank Corp. affiliate rescued Fuji Television Network Inc. from the specter of being taken over by Internet firm Livedoor Co. on Thursday by suddenly becoming the largest shareholderin the embattled TC broadcaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION TO VISIT U.S. WITHIN TWO WEEKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 24 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China legislative delegation will visit the United States within the next two weeks, ROC Representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee confirmed Thursday.
