Lee said that now is good time for the delegation to visit the United States, noting that the international community has turned to support Taiwan in the wake of China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

Asked if the United States has talked with the ROC representative office about Taiwan's arms procurement plan, Lee only said that the proposed procurement of six Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine jetfighters from the United States is major issue, and that he has exchanged views with U.S. officials regularly since he assumed office last year.
The arms procurement bill recently failed to be put on the Legislative Yuan's agenda because of objections from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" which holds a slight majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: O'SEAS CHINESE, TAIWAN EXPATS IN DENMARK CONDEMN ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 24 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Seven leading overseas Chinese and Taiwanese organizations in Denmark issued a joint statement Thursday condemning China's enactment of its so-called anti-secession law.
They said in the statement that since the law provides Beijing with a legal basis to invade Taiwan by force, the international community should condemn it.

The purpose of enacting such a law is to deprive the Taiwan people of the right to determine their own future, the statement said, adding that by doing so, China wants to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.
It criticized the use of the anti-secession law to deal with the de facto separation between the island and the mainland over the last 55 years as "unfit and ridiculous."

The United States, Japan and the European Union have voiced their concerns about the law and urged Beijing to engage in dialogue with Taiwan to solve cross-strait differences, the organizations said in the statement, adding that they would also request that China use peaceful means to resolve cross-strait differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN COMPANIES OPTIMISTIC ABOUT BUSINESS PROSPECTS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: More Taiwan companies have become optimistic about their business prospects for the next half year mainly as a result of the atmosphere of reconciliation that has emerged in Taiwan's politics since the beginning of this year, an economic think-tank reported Friday.

In a survey conducted at the end of February on members of Taiwan's industrial sector, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) found that 54.6 percent of the respondents said they believe that their business prospects will turn for the better in the following six months, marking a steep rise from 26.9 percent in the think tank's January survey.

In the February survey, 22 percent of the companies surveyed said their business was "good" in that month, down from 25.8 percent in January, and 41.3 percent said business was somewhat "unchanged, " down from 52.8 percent the previous month, while 36.7 percent said business turned for the worse, compared with only 21.4 percent in January.

Meanwhile, 36.9 percent of the respondents said they see their business prospects remaining unchanged over the next six months, down from 54.9 percent in January, while those who believe business will slide in the next six months dropped to 8.5 percent from January's 18.2 percent, the TIER survey found.

Acting TIER President Hung Teh-sheng attributed the industrial sector's optimism to several factors, including the emerging atmosphere of reconciliation in Taiwan's politics, as witnessed by the meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong on Feb. 24. After the meeting, the two announced a 10-point consensus on several issues, including efforts to promote cross-strait peace, national security and ethnic reconciliation.

Also, Frank Hsieh's comments after being sworn in as the new premier Feb. 1 that the new Cabinet would make consultations and coexistence the cornerstone of its policies was another major reason for the industrial sector's increased optimism, Hung said.

Hung added that the better-than-expected performance of the economies of the United States and mainland China, the two major markets for Taiwan's exports, also contributed to the Taiwan industrial sector's increased confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE IN EASTERN CANADA MARCH AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, March 24 (CNA) (By S.K. Wu, Eric Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese groups and associations in eastern Canada staged a protest march in the Canadian capital of Ottawa Thursday against China's recent enactment of its so-called anti-secession law.
More than 250 Taiwanese expatriates first gathered in the square in front of the Parliament Hill buildings, where Chen Wen-lung, president of aTaiwanese professors association, delivered a speech.

Chen said that the passage of the law provides China with a legal basis to attack Taiwan. He also said that Beijing has deployed more than 700 missiles in its southeast coastal provinces against Taiwan and that the march is aimed at voicing serious protest against Beijing's passage of the law and its "intentions to annex Taiwan."
Several Canadian parliamentarians were also on hand to lend their support for the cause.

The participants then marched toward the Chinese Embassy to deliver a protest letter, which was accepted by a Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer to hand over to the embassy as the embassy had shut its doors.
Meanwhile, Taiwanese associations in the greater New York area are planning a protest march Saturday in line with the large-scale "326 March for Democracy and Peace" activity in Taipei.
The organizers of the march said that participants would first gather in front of the U.N. headquarters at 10: 30 a.m. and then march toward the Chinese general consulate in New York to protest.
They said some 500 people are expected to take part in the march, which will go through Times Square in Manhattan in order to attract the attention of New Yorkers and tourists there.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSENSUS ESSENTIAL ON COUNTERING BEIJING LAW: ROC PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that public consensus is essential on whether to enact a law to counter China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

Hsieh made the remarks during a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in which Legislator Yeh Yi-jin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party asked whether the government has any substantive measures, such as a legislation, to counter Beijing's Anti-Secession Law which authorizes "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

Hsieh said that legislation will require a national consensus, adding that for now, the Cabinet will call international attention to the threat posed to Taiwan by the law and try to make China feel the heat from the international community and Taiwan.

Hsieh noted that through the law, China can arbitrarily decide if Taiwan "has crossed the red line" and take action in response. However, if the international community applies pressure to Beijing, the latter will then be more careful in deciding when and if Taiwan has crossed the line, he said.

Asked about government employees taking part in Saturday's "326 March for Democracy and Peace, " the premier said that he has urged all Taiwan people to take part in the march, including government employees. He added, however, that they are free to decide for themselves whether they will participate.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT WELCOMES TAIWAN DECISION TO REOPEN TO U.S. BEEF IMPORTS

TEXT.P: The United States welcomes Taiwan's announcement Thursday that it will reopen its market to U.S. boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age starting April 16, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said in a news bulletin Friday.

The Republic of China Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday that Taiwan will conditionally allow U.S. beef back into the local market beginning April 16 following the suspension of imports in 2003 due to the discovery of a case of mad cow disease.

U.S. beef and beef products, that is, beef cattle under 2.5 years old, clear of bones, offal and specific risk materials including brain, trigeminal ganglia, dorsal root ganglia and spinal marrow, and with certificates issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), will be allowed to be imported into Taiwan from April 16, said Chen Lu-hung, director of the health department's Bureau of Food Safety.
Ground beef will not be included in the opening list, Chen added.
The AIT is a quasi-official organization authorized by Washington to handle U.S. exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

In the news bulletin, the AIT Kaohsiung Office said that the DOH decision was made after completing a meticulous and long-term assessment on the U.S. system for deterring any further spread of mad cow disease.

The AIT Kaohsiung Office said that the United States is studying the details of the DOH announcement about the reopening policy. The office said it expects the governments of the two countries to work together to help implement the decision.

The DOH Bureau of Food Safety will ask the USDA to provide Taiwan with a list of the names of legal, contracted U.S. slaughterhouses to be used as a reference to make sure that all the beef introduced into Taiwan is from these companies, Chen said.
The health department will also consult with the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) for other details pertaining to the imports, Chen added.
COA officials said later Thursday that an import ban on live cattle from the United States will remain in place after U.S. beef is allowed to enter the Taiwan market again next month.

The officials said that the lifting of the import ban will be applicable strictly to items clearly listed by the DOH. The import ban on live cattle and related products will remain in place in line with regulations set forth by the World Animal Health Organization, they said.

Taiwan suspended beef imports from the United States in December 2003 due to safety concerns over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease, after the discovery of a single case of mad cow disease on a ranch in the U.S. state of Washington.

Taiwan health and agriculture officials have traveled to the U.S. to conduct on-site inspections of the implementation of the U.S. safeguards against mad cow disease and have recently completed the reviews necessary for resuming the beef trade.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before Taiwan imposed the ban in December 2003. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U.S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, have imposed bans on U.S. beef, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year. Big names in the beef export trade, including Tyson Foods Inc. and Cargill Inc., have exerted great pressure on the USDA for the early resumption of exports to these countries.
The AIT had also been contacting relevant Taiwan officials in an effort to speed up the paperwork so that U.S. beef can reenter the Taiwan market at an earlier date.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO LEAD ONE MILLION PEOPLE TO SING 'WE SHALL OVERCOME'

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to lead one million participants to sing the U.S. civil rights movement key anthem, "We Shall Overcome, " during Saturday's rally against China's Anti-Secession Law, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Friday.
DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan pointed out that the song represents the pursuit of an equal and democratic society, which he said perfectly matches the theme of the demonstration.

In addition to "We Shall Overcome, " Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka and aboriginal songs that represent the four main ethnic groups in Taiwan have been selected for the participants to sing in chorus at the rally, Cheng said.

The "326 March for Democracy and Peace," organized by the DPP-led Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, will see at least one million people set off from 10 different places in Taipei and march toward the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office for a huge gathering, the organizers said.
President Chen announced a day earlier that he will take part in the event but will not give a speech or play the leading role.
According to Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, President Chen's decision is aimed at highlighting his identity as a member of the 23 million population in Taiwan.
Yu said that the country's diplomatic allies have been informed of the president's decision and that they have expressed no opinion on the matter.

He said national security authorities have not finalized as to which route the president and the first family will take because there are a number of security issues that must be taken into consideration.
Also on Friday, legislators from the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union held a press conference to urge all people of Taiwan to join the rally to voice their protest to China.

The legislators gulped down foods and beverages named after current and former Chinese leaders in front of the media to express their anger at the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

Meanwhile, with all legislators from the DPP expected to participate in the rally, a group of female DPP legislators announced Friday that they will give away "peace candy" and "happiness cake" to the participants to wish them peace and happiness.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERY SEMINAR TO EXPLORE DEEP-SEA FISHING MANPOWER PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: A seminar on deep-sea fishing manpower issues will be held Monday as part of the government's efforts to formulate new policy and strategies for sustainable fishery industry development, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

The seminar, to be organized by the COA's Fishery Administration, will focus on the supply and demand of fishing manpower, upgrading the quality of the fishery workforce and improvement of the shipboard working environment, the official said.

The one-day seminar will bring together officials from city and county governments, representatives of local fishing industry associations, scholars and experts to explore manpower-related problems faced by local fishing boat owners and feasible measures to resolve them, the official said.

According to the official, the seminar will be the first of a series of forums to be held this year to tackle fishing industry issues with a view to opening up new opportunities for the local fishing industry.

In recent years, the official said, Taiwan's fishing industry has encountered many problems, including manpower shortages, a coastal fishery resources drain and increasing global competition in deep-sea fishing.

Besides manpower issues, the official said, other seminars to be held later this year will tackle issues regarding the sustainable management of coastal fishery resources, coastal law and offshore fishing industry development, the most suitable scale and management of the deep-sea fishing industry and core values of fishermen's associations.
"All the findings and conclusions from the planned series of seminars will serve as reference for the formulation of our future fishery development policies and strategies," the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TO TAKE PART IN MARCH 26 PROTEST

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that she will take part in some of the activities in Saturday's demonstration against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, but added that she has not yet decided on whether to join the massive march that will take place.

Lu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters following a news conference she called after returning to Taiwan a day earlier from a 12-day diplomatic tour to two Central American allies -- El Salvador and Guatemala.

Saying she was still considering whether or not to take part in the protest march together with an estimated crowd of at least 1 million people due to concern over security and her physical condition, Lu encouraged the public to bravely speak out their objections to Beijing by participating in the demonstration.
The vice president suffered an eye infection during her Central American tour and is still receiving treatment.

The 326 March for Democracy and Peace, organized by the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace in Taipei, is expected to draw more than 1 million protesters from across Taiwan to express their rage about the law targeting Taiwan.
President Chen Shui-bian, former President Lee Teng-hui and their families will also participate.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DISAGREE ON GOVERNMENT INVESTMENT IN HIGH SPEED RAIL

TEXT.P: Legislators reacted along party lines at a public hearing in the Legislative Yuan Friday on whether the government should continue to invest in Taiwan's first high speed rail project.

At the hearing sponsored by a sub-group in the legislature to promote financial bills, legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said the high speed rail is a national infrastructure project in which the government should continue to invest.

Legislators from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), however, said the cost-overrun project should try other means to secure capital or borrow from the government. They advised against continued investment in the project lest it create too much risk for the government.

Ho Nuan-hsuan, director-general of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail, and Liu Kuo-chi, president of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), also said in the hearing that the project, which links Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south, is a major infrastructure project that the government originally planned to build itself, but the Legislative Yuan later passed a resolution that it would be done according to the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model, they said.
The government investment should be seen in the light that the government supports its own policy, they added.

PFP legislators Christina Y. Liu and Chou Hsi-wei said the government's investment in the project has high "moral" risk and claimed that the political price has become the priority concern of the government,

In addition, they claimed that the government took on too much risk when signing the contract with the THSRC in the first place. The company should have used other means to solicit investment, they said.
But DPP legislators Julian Kuo, Kao Chi-peng and Huang Wei-tze noted that the project is still under construction and that it is mere speculation to conclude that it will lose money.

The legislature should let state-owned enterprises decide on their own whether to invest in the project and state-controlled banks' investment in the project should not be seen as government subsidies, they said.
Ho and Liu expressed the hope that the government will continue to invest in the project so that the 345-km railway can become operational this October as scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REMAINS SUPPORTIVE OF TAIWAN'S WHO BID: TAIWAN OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 24 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi, Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States, which explicitly expressed its support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) last year, will remain supportive of the cause this year, Republic of China representative to the United States David Ta-wei Lee said Thursday.

Lee made the remarks in response to reports suggesting that Washington intends to "punish" China for enacting the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan and to "make up for" Taiwan by supporting its WHO bid.

In a regular news briefing with the Chinese-language media in Washington, Lee said U.S. government officials have never mentioned the word "punish" during his consultations with the administration of President George W. Bush on the Anti-Secession Law.
Lee would not disclose details of the consultations but said Washington is very concerned about the enactment of the law and has taken a tough and firm stand toward China's move.
Lee said the United States will continue to throw its support behind Taiwan's bid to enter the WHO this year like it did last year.
According to Lee, Washington has expressed its approval of President Chen Shui-bian's 10-point agreement reached with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Feb. 24.

In the agreement, Chen reaffirmed his "five-noes" commitment that during his term he will not declare independence for Taiwan, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" theory in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council.
Lee said he has sensed an obvious change in the United States' attitude toward Taiwan since December last year.

While Washington is very unhappy with China's wilful move to enact the Anti-Secession Law to change the cross-strait status quo unilaterally, it has commended the rational manner that Taiwan has adopted in dealing with the situation, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Options Dwindle for Keeping Schiavo Alive.
Supreme Court declined to hear parents' appeal. Pinellas County judge blocked Fla. Gov. Jeb Bush from taking custody of brain-damaged woman.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Top-level renewal in civil service.
As part of an ongoing process of renewal at the top rungs of the civil service, Mr. Lim Siong Guan will step aside as head of civil service on April 1 to make way for Mr. Peter Ho.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Bishkek Falls to Opposition, Akayev Vanishes.

An angry crowd stormed the Kyrgyz government headquarters and the national television station Thursday in a violent uprising that left dozens injured as opposition leaders claimed to have taken control of the government. By nightfall, President Askar Akayev's whereabouts were unknown, while unconfirmed reports said he had resigned and fled the country, as looting and chaos reigned in the capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear the Schiavo Case.
A state judge also rejected Gov. Jeb Bush's attempt to intervene, prompting a last-ditch legal scramble by Terri Schiavo's parents.
The Wall Street Journal: Boeing Plans to Resume Offering Commercial Rocket.
Hoping to re-establish itself as a major player in commercial-space programs, Boeing Co. said it intends to resume offering its top-of-the line rocket to launch corporate telecommunications satellites by the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE POET TO SPEAK AT COLLOQUIUM IN TAINAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan City, southern Taiwan, March 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: West Indian dramatist and poet Derek Walcott, winner of the 1992 Nobel Prize in Literature, is expected to appear at a colloquium to be held in Tainan City Sunday, the National Museum of Taiwanese Literature reported Friday.

Walcott, who was born in Castries, St. Lucia in 1930 to a British father and a West Indian mother, will attend the colloquium titled: Poetry, Language and Identity, to be sponsored by the National Museum of Taiwanese Literature with various local poets, academics and literati also taking part.

It is hoped that Walcott, who skillfully fuses folk island culture with the classical and avant-garde in his poems, will be inspirational to Taiwan's literary circles at a time when Taiwan is enthusiastically promoting maritime culture, a museum spokesman said.
Walcott, who from the age of eight envisaged becoming a poet, published his first poem at 14 and had his first verse collection printed by the time he was 18.

Walcott, who divides his time between the United States and Trinidad, exalts in the English language with his meticulously honed poems and evocative dramas, while also using a rich mix of Latin, French and Trinidadian patois.

In addition to poems and verse, Walcott also writes plays and epic poems. His 1990 epic poem Omeros, which echoes Homer's Iliad and Odyssey as it examines the Caribbean's colonial past and complex present, won him the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1992.

Often focusing on West Indian folk traditions, Walcott's plays include Dream on Monkey Mountain (1970), The Joker of Seville (1975), A Branch of the Blue Nile (1986), while his verse collections include In a Green Night (1962), the autobiographical Another Life (1973), Sea Grapes (1976) and Midsummer (1984).

Prof. Xi Mi from the University of California in Los Angeles will be the host of the colloquium, while Taiwan poets Lee Kuei-hsien and Lee Min-yung, as well as professor Tseng Chen-chen of National Dong Hwa University and Lin Jui-ming, director of the National Museum of Taiwanese Literature, will conduct dialogues with Walcott, according to the museum spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 64.91 points to close at 6,065.91.
The bourse opened at 6,018.79 and fluctuated between 6,065.91 and 6,016.48 during trading. A total of 2.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.65 billion (US$1.86 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 675 to 211, with 128 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERY MARCHER COUNTS IN 326 PROTEST: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that every marcher counts in Saturday's demonstration against China's Anti-Secession Law.

Hsieh made the remarks as he answered questions during a general interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan in which Yang Li-huang of the opposition Kuomintang questioned the approach of Hsieh and other government officials taking to the streets.

Hsieh, who has over the last few days been urging government employees to take part in the 326 March for Democracy and Peace sponsored by the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, said that his own participation is to be with the people, adding that he has no intention of leading the march or walking at the front.

But he said that as a member of Taiwan society, he believes that the more people who take part, the more weight will be lent to the activity, which will translate into additional effect internationally.

He said that a more galvanized people's will will allow foreign countries to see that the Taiwan people really care about the threat posed by China and that their resolve to pursue democracy and peace is a model for the world.

Responding to Yang's sarcastic remark that if marching was so effective, the government might as well appropriate budget to have marches all year round, the premier said that the world does not pay attention to Taiwan or listen to what it says all year round.
The premier stressed that not all activities should be protests, saying that government officials should not take to the streets over such issues as internal problems.

Claiming that Taiwan has been talking without people listening for years, the premier said that "now that the passage of China's Anti-Session Law has aroused world attention and provides a rare forum for Taiwan to speak out, the country should seize the opportunity March 26."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PINS HIGH HOPES TO TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged Taiwan's agriculture sector Friday to engage in innovation and sustainable progress to "help the country reach further into the international community and bring Taiwan to the world."
Chen made the remarks while addressing the opening ceremony of the 2005 Taiwan International Orchid Exhibition that will run through April 10 at an orchid bio-tech park in southern Tainan County.

Chen expressed the hope that Taiwan's fine quality orchids will break into more foreign markets and he revealed that the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has reached an agreement with China Airlines to decorate the cabins of its new passenger planes with orchid prints as means of presenting the flowers to the rest of the world.

Although many are concerned about future developments in Taiwan's agriculture since the country entered the World Trade Organization in January 2002, Chen said there is clear proof that although the industry has sustained difficulties, it is heading into a brighter future.

For instance, the industry yielded NT$377 billion (about US$12 billion) in production value last year, up by 7 percent over the 2003 level. Export values amounted to US$3.52 billion, an increase of 11.7 percent year on year, he said.
More than 20,000 pots of orchids are on display at the exhibition, with international seminars and a world competition on the sidelines.

Participants from 16 countries and areas, including Australia, France, Indonesia, Holland, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand and the United States will vie for the top prize in the competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE TO DETERMINE THEIR FUTURE: PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 25 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that a large-scale rally scheduled for Saturday in Taiwan against China's Anti-Secession Law will show the world that "it is the people of Taiwan who will determine their future, not the unelected leaders in Beijing."

"The demonstrators will mobilize to oppose the idea that China has a 'right' to use force to subjugate the people of Taiwan -- and they will protest the notion that some 2,900 unelected and unaccountable Chinese 'parliamentarians' have the right to determine the future of the 23 million people of Taiwan, " Hsieh says in an article titled "Taiwan's Right to Freedom" printed in the Washington Post.

At least 1 million people are expected to turn out for the 326 March for Democracy and Peace to be held Saturday in Taipei. President Chen Shui-bian and Hsieh have both decided to participate in the demonstration.
According to Hsieh, it is perplexing that China has passed a law that authorizes the use of force against Taiwan after cross-Taiwan Strait relations were improving.
Furthermore, Hsieh says, the process by which the Anti-Secession Law was passed reflects the sharp contrast between China's dictatorship and Taiwan's vibrant democracy.
Beijing was making a "flawed" analogy when it tried to justify the law by claiming a parallel to the U.S. Civil War and Abraham Lincoln's effort to forcibly preserve the Union, Hsieh says.

"It refers to a Taiwan that has never been a part of, or under the sovereign control of, the People's Republic of China. And it ignores the most basic point: Lincoln wanted to preserve the Union in the name of freedom, not to deny it," he says.

While remarkable progress has been seen in the democratic development in East Asia over the past two decades, the region's two remaining one-party dictatorships -- China and North Korea -- pose a serious threat to regional security, he points out.

The premier calls the international community's attention to the fact that China "continues to stifle the democratic aspirations of its own people and to threaten Taiwan's democracy with military force."
"Unless the great democracies of the world say this behavior is not tolerable, we will only be inviting Beijing to believe it is," he concludes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 38 points to close at 6,050, with 18,475 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 38 points to finish at 6,048, with 112 contracts traded, while June futures gained 41 points to finish at 6,036, with 38 contracts traded.
September futures gained 31 points to finish at 5,925, with 84 contracts traded, while December futures moved up six points to close at 5,900, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,012 for April, 6,010 for May, 5,995 for June, 5,894 for September and 5,894 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures moved up 2.25 points to close at 231.25, with 3,017 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 2.25 points to finish at 231.25, with 20 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 2.7 points to close at 230.5, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

April TF futures gained 3.4 points to finish at 977.4, with 3,098 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved up 4.8 points to end at 978.8, with 23 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up 4.6 points to finish at 977.8, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.036 to close at NT$31.500.
A total of US$668 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.464 and fluctuated between NT$31.462 and NT$31.505.

DOC.HEADLINE: POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS FRUIT JELLY SHOULD BE BANNED: FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Domestically produced mini-fruit jellies under the brand name of Sheng Hsiang Chen that choked a child to death in the United States a couple of years ago and another recently in Shanghai, should be banned completely, the Consumers' Foundation of Taiwan said Friday.

Foundation Chairman Huang Yi-teng said the government should ensure that Sheng Hsiang Chen fruit jelly -- which is already banned in the United States and the European Union -- is also recalled from stores in Taiwan.
Several days ago, the 18-month-old son of a Taiwan businessman in Shanghai died after choking on a Sheng Hsiang Chen fruit jelly.
Huang said that while many countries have barred the sale of the dangerous product, the Taiwan authorities should follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP SPONSORS RECYCLING DAY ON 326

TEXT.P: While the countdown to the much-publicized 326 March for Democracy and Peace against Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law is under way, an environmental group expressed Friday a different way to show love and respect for the country.

The Earth, Ecology and Environment Nursing Foundation will sponsor a resources recycling gala in Sanchung City, Taipei County, Saturday to show people how waste and garbage can be turned into wealth while helping conserve the environment through correct recycling, said foundation Chairman Pan Chien-lung.

The first step to save the Earth is to cut the amount of garbage generated, Pan said, adding that everyone, including children, should learn how to recycle waste and garbage so as to prevent overtaxing and overextending the Earth.
The gala, to be held at the Sanchung Stadium, will feature garbage recycling lessons, games, a quiz and a prize draw.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NOT CONCERNED IF PRESIDENT JOINS PROTEST MARCH: MAC

TEXT.P: The United States is not concerned whether President Chen Shui-bian or other government officials take part in a large-scale protest march against China's Anti-Secession Law, the nation's top mainland China policy charter said Friday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks in response to questions during a general interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan.

Chen announced Thursday that he will take part in the 326 March for Democracy and Peace Saturday following media reports that he had sounded out the U.S. response beforehand and had learned that the U.S. did not oppose his participation, although it expressed hope that he will refrain from making provocative remarks.

During the legislation process of Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, Taiwan maintained communication with the United States and the government knows clearly the U.S. stance on the Anti-Secession Law, including remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice during her recent visit to China in which she criticized the passage of the new law as an unwelcome development.
Wu noted that Washington thinks taking to the streets is a method of free expression in a democratic society.

Meanwhile, Hsueh Shih-ming, head of the National Security Bureau, will attend Saturday's march, organized by the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, where he will be in charge of President Chen's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN OFFICE EMPLOYEES WILL NOT ATTEND VIOLENT PROTESTS: POLL

TEXT.P: More than 80 percent of Taiwan's office employees would not take part in "violent protests" that involve such things as hunger strikes or "pushing back and forth, " according to the results of a recent survey made public Friday.

The poll conducted by the executive search Web site www. 1111. com. tw shows that nearly 89 percent of the office workers surveyed said they would refuse to participate in such demonstrations, which they described as violent, while only about 11 percent said they would.

Asked if they would ask for leave from their companies to take part in demonstrations, around 54 percent said "no, " ahead of 37 percent who said "it depends." Only 8.3 percent claimed that they would do so.

Around 64 percent of the respondents agreed to the idea that joining a protest march is a way of expressing public opinion, with more than half of them viewing a protest march as a display of "discontent, concern and support" over issues in that order, the poll found. Some 46 percent of them admitted to having taken part in a protest in the past.
The poll was conducted via the Internet from March 16-28, recovering 1,089 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 2.9 percent.
Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that there were a total of 5,464 protests in 2004 around the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL ECONOMY WILL NOT SLOW DOWN DESPITE SURGING OIL PRICES: TIER

TEXT.P: Rising oil prices are not expected to cause a global economic recession because the economic development of most countries around the world is supported by the service industry, researchers of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) said Friday.

However, international oil prices, which have been estimated to stay at a high range of US$45-US$55 per barrel this year, are not expected to fall much since global oil demand has grown faster than expected due to increasing economic growth in China and the United States, as well as global weather changes, according to TIER.

The report cites an International Energy Agency decision March 11 to enlarge its assessment of the world's annual crude oil demand by 2.2 percent. It also mentions the fact that oil suppliers will not dump stockpiles in the market since there are only limited oil reserves.

In the latest trading in New York, the price of light sweet crude oil for delivery in May soared US$1.03 to US$54.84 per barrel after a fatal blast at the British Petroleum Company's biggest oil refinery in the United States, which took lives of at least 15 people and injured some 100.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has assessed that if crude oil prices stay at the level of US$50 per barrel, the global economic growth rate will be lower by 0.5 percentage points.
A similar assessment by the International Monetary Fund also shows that every US$5-per-barrel growth in international oil prices will bring down the global economic growth by 0.3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES OPPOSE CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: VP

TEXT.P: Now that El Salvador and Guatemala have spoken out against China's Anti-Secession Law, the parliamentary speakers of Taiwan's other Central American allies are expected to release a joint statement against the law during their next meeting in April, Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

Lu, who returned a day earlier from an official visit to El Salvador and Guatemala, said her trip has consolidated the country's friendship with its two allies, has upheld justice for Taiwan, has expanded opportunities for Taiwan industries and has highlighted what she described as the "soft emergence" of Taiwan. She did not elaborate.
Lu noted that China has continued its diplomatic suppression of Taiwan and has tried to lure away the island's allies in Central America.
The trip successfully "stopped" the financial temptation offered by Beijing to Taiwan's allies, Lu claimed.

In what Lu called the other two achievements of her trip, Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma de Escobar will visit Taiwan in April to discuss details of setting up a "Taiwan Park" in her country, while Guatemalan President Oscar Berger will visit in August to sign a Free Trade Agreement with Taiwan and attend the inauguration of the Democratic Pacific Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY OFFICIALS DISCIPLINED OVER 319 SHOOTING

TEXT.P: Seven senior security officials, including Tsai Chao-ming, the former chief of the National Security Bureau (NSB) and Maj. Gen. Chen Tsai-fu, the former chief-de-camp of President Chen Shui-bian, were disciplined Friday for failing to protect him in last year's March 19 shooting.

Tsai was given a warning, the lightest kind of discipline, while Chen was dismissed from his job and prohibited for one year from serving as government employee, according to a decision of the Committee on the Discipline of Public Functionaries which metes out punishment to government employees who fail in their duty.
Meanwhile, Shen Tsai-tien, former vice chief-de-camp for Chen, was demoted two ranks, while the police chief of Tainan City where the shooting took place was demoted by one rank.
Three other NSC officials who were in charge of the president's personal security were reprimanded twice.

They were seven of eight security officials referred to the discipline committee for possible punishment by the Control Yuan in July 2004 for failing to provide proper security for the president. Chen was grazed in the attempted assassination on the eve of the presidential election.
The only one spared by the committee is a senior police officer from the National Police Administration.

The Control Yuan said the officials failed to ask the president to wear a bullet-proof vest during a campaign parade before the shooting took place, and failed to surround the president's motorcade with bodyguards during the campaign parade, resulting in the bodyguards being unable to react quickly to the shooting.
Tsai Chao-ming, Chen Tsai-fu and Shen Tsai-tien were removed from their jobs after the shooting, pending the investigation.
The shooting has been at the center of a lingering political dispute between Chen and his political rivals, who claim that it was staged to help Chen win re-election.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY APPROVES 20 RESEARCH PROJECTS BY SMALL BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs approved 20 research projects Friday proposed by local small- and medium-sized businesses, officials said.

The ministry will subsidize a total of NT$45 million (US$1.43 million) for these projects as an incentive to encourage small- and medium-sized businesses to enhance their research and development capabilities, the officials said.
At the same time, the businesses will funnel another NT$82 million into the projects, they said.
The winners of the subsidy funds include Allis Communications Co., Innovative & Superior Technology Inc., Coventive Corp., Yun Teh Industrial Co. and MFC Sealing Technology Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES PUBLIC TO SPEAK OUT AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that oppressed people should speak out in a democratic, peaceful manner to remind the world not to pamper oppressors.
Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at the opening of the 2005 World Poetry Festival in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
His call for "speaking out" came on the eve of a planned massive rally in Taipei to protest China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

Chen read a poem written in 1945 by local poet Chi Hsuen that features relations between sound and existence to accentuate the need to speak out against Beijing's legislation that codifies the use of force against Taiwan should the island pursue formal independence.

"Just as the poem says that sound proves existence, those who are oppressed or mistreated should speak out and remind the world of the perils of coddling oppressors. If we keep silence or sit idly by, the oppressors will become ever stronger and more aggressive," Chen said.

Noting that the 326 March for Democracy and Peace is aimed at voicing opposition to the idea that China has a "right" to use force to subjugate the people of Taiwan and protesting the notion that some 2,900 unelected and unaccountable Chinese "parliamentarians" have the right to determine the future of the 23 million people of Taiwan, Chen urged local people to join the parade to make Taiwan's voice heard around the world.

He also expressed his gratitude for more than 100 poets from 17 countries on six continents who have made the long journey to Kaohsiung to take part in the poetry festival and share their literary achievements with local people.
Praising poetry as beautiful sound from the depth of the human soul, Chen said poetry is a beautiful language shared by all human beings without the constraints of borders or ethnicity.
Chen further said Taiwan has diverse ethnic groups who have created a myriad of poems and lyrical songs in different styles over the centuries.

"We welcome with great modesty the arrival of noted poets from around the world to offer their poetic visions, lyrical perspectives and aesthetic experiences, " Chen said, adding he believes that the ongoing World Poetry Festival will bring rich inspiration to local poets and add to the diversity of Taiwan's literary creations.
With a theme of "Sea and Land in Harmony, Poetic Minds in Interflow, " the 2005 World Poetry Festival in Kaohsiung will run through March 27.
During the three-day period, poets from home and abroad will exchange their insights and creative experiences as well as recite their own poems and discuss topics related to literary developments.

Among the participants is Derek Walcott, a Saint Lucia dramatist and poet who won the 1992 Nobel Prize in literature. Other participants come from India, Bangladesh, Mexico, Nigeria, Mongolia, Romania, the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY TWO OUT OF 100 TAIWAN SCHOOL CHILDREN BORN OF MIXED MARRIAGES

TEXT.P: An average of 1.6 out of every 100 students at Taiwan's elementary and junior high schools are born out of mixed marriages, according to recent government statistics.

A total of 46,411 children born to mixed marriages received primary and secondary education in Taiwan last year, a jump of 54.5 percent over the 2003 level, tallies made public by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show.
There were 40,907 such children at primary schools and 5,504 at senior high schools, marking a growth of 53.6 percent and 61.3 percent, respectively, year on year.

Nearly half of them, 20,084, lived in northern Taiwan, followed by 12,556 in the south, and 11,667 in central regions. A total of 1,045 resided in eastern Taiwan, while 339 lived on the remote islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

The outlying Matsu Island had the highest ratio of 10.6 percent of children born to mixed marriages at its schools. Kinmen Island came second with 4 percent, followed by Penghu Island with 3.6 percent at third, Pingtung County with 2.9 percent at fourth and Yunlin County with 2.8 percent at fifth.

Some 34 percent of these children's father or mother came from mainland China (including Hong Kong and Macau) , followed by 24.8 percent from Indonesia and 15.4 percent from Vietnam, the DGBAS tallies show.
Most the 300,000 foreign spouses of Taiwan citizens are from China (including Hong Kong and Macau) and countries in Southeast Asia, such as Cambodia, Indonesia and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF SEES NO IMMINENT CRISIS OF CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY CONFLICT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, March 25 (CNA) (By Lu Chien-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The possibility of a military conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait breaking out in the near future is nil, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said in a recent interview with a Hong Kong daily published Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said in the interview with the Hong Kong Economic Journal that the Republic of China's armed forces have consistently kept a close watch on military activities on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

Since China's ceremonial legislature, the National People's Congress, passed the Anti-Secession Law March 14, Wu said, the People's Liberation Army has not conducted any abnormal activities. Against this backdrop, Wu said, he sees no immediate potential for a cross-strait military conflict.

Nevertheless, Wu said, the possibility continues to grow because of Beijing's deployment of more than 700 ballistic missiles along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan. Worse still, he added, the number of China's missiles targeting Taiwan will further increase to 800 by the end of next year.

Asked why Taiwan has reacted strongly to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law that codifies the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan, Wu said Taiwan's rage lies in China's erroneous premise for using brute force.

Stressing that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been independent of each other since 1949, Wu said the term "anti-secession" seemingly implies that the two sides are united at present and, therefore, China could "punish" Taiwan at will.
China's ill-intentioned and arbitrary legislation is unacceptable to democratic and pluralistic Taiwan because it is tantamount to restricting Taiwan people's freedom of choice.

By authorizing its Central Military Commission to use non-peaceful means to stop Taiwan from declaring independence, Wu went on, the legislation is actually a war bill that completely runs against the United Nations charter.
As for Taiwan's response measures, Wu said ultimately, national interests are the top concern and formulating guidelines for counter- strategies.

According to Wu, the ROC government will not promote the legislation of an anti-invasion bill or an anti-aggression bill. The government will also refrain from launching a "defensive referendum" to counter Beijing's legislation.

"We must exercise self-restraint and be a responsible member of the international community, " Wu said, adding that world news media has so far published more than 2,000 articles, editorials and commentaries in support of Taiwan.
In addition, Wu said, more than one million Taiwan people will take to the streets to voice their strong opposition to the Anti-Secession Law.
Wu said the ROC government will adopt a cautious and prudent attitude to cope with the situation in the wake of Beijing's new legislation.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE STUDENTS GO ONLINE TO SUPPORT PROTEST IN TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 25 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Elizabeth)

TEXT.P: A group formed by overseas Taiwanese students over the Internet will participate remotely in the March 26 rally in Taiwan against China's Anti-Secession Law.

According to the European Taiwanese Association for Peace and Anti-Invasion (ETAPA) , the cooperation was initiated by Taiwanese students in Britain, France and Belgium. Then, those studying or living in Germany, Sweden, Holland and Spain gave their support to the protest through online contacts, an ETAPA member said Friday.

On March 26, "anti-invasion" protest rallies will be held in European capital cities like London, Brussels and Amsterdam, with protesters in Britain gathering in front of the Chinese Embassy in London to oppose Beijing's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan and to call for the European Union not to lift its arms ban on China.

In France, five demonstrations will be held that day at the same time in Paris, Nantes, Lyon, Strasbourg and Potier, while in Germany, a two-hour planned rally will be held at the Marienplatz in the heart of Munich, according to the organizer.
The alliance will also release a joint statement of its promotion of peace and against invasion in Chinese, English, French, German, Dutch, Swedish and Spanish.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADS ASIAN ELECTION ASSOCIATION

TEXT.P: Central Election Commission Chairman Chang Chen-hsiung was named Friday to chair the Association of Asian Election Authorities (AAEA) in the association's annual meeting held March 24-25 in Taipei, a CEC official said.
It is Taiwan's first chairmanship in an international organization, the official noted, adding Chang was elected during the AAEA annual meeting from

The AAEA was founded in 1998 to promote and institutionalize open and transparent elections, independent election authorities, professional election administration, citizen participation in the electoral and civic process, information sharing, and to develop information resources, according to the CEC.
Chang said that during his tenure as AAEA chairman, he will try to get more Asian countries to join the association, which has at present 12 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WILL CONTINUE TO PROMOTE DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORT

TEXT.P: The government will continue to promote the opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.
Fielding questions raised by lawmakers at an interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that the government has completed an assessment on the cross-strait transport links.

Basically, he said, it is necessary to hold consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the opening of the direct cross-strait transport links, which he said should be based on the cross-strait charter flight services for this past year's lunar new year holiday.

The premier noted, however, that the government should take Taiwan people's feeling into consideration when dealing with the cross-strait issue in the wake of China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

This is the reason why there were no cross-strait talks on the issue recently, he explained, adding that the government will continue to promote faster and more convenient cross-strait transportation in the long run.

Hsieh feels that the two sides should hold peaceful talks on matters of mutual concern and should increase bilateral exchanges, making China's development positive and beneficial for Taiwan, while making experiences of Taiwan's democratization part of the Chinese people's lifestyle and contributive to their progress.

Given that the two sides have been becoming more interdependent economically, Hsieh stressed that Taiwan should not make the other side of the Strait an enemy, although it has to protest against China's moves that hurt Taiwan's rights and interests.
Taiwan should use its geographic advantages of being located near China to participate in regional development and to avoid being marginalized, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF TO JOIN MARCH AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday he will take part in the "326" March for Democracy and Peace in Taipei Saturday to protest China's so-called anti-secession law against Taiwan.
The nation's top mainland policy planner said he will be present throughout the whole event. Nevertheless, he will not reveal which parade route he will take.

"Premier Frank Hsieh said earlier this week that government employees can join the March 26 street parade against the anti-secession law, but should keep a low profile. Therefore, I decide to mingle with ordinary citizens and take part in this democratic extravaganza at a suitable location," Wu said.

He further said the significance of the "326" march lies in the fact that the event provides the people of Taiwan an opportunity to show the world their opposition to Beijing's ill-intentioned law that authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan as well as their aspiration for peace and democracy.

"Democracy and peace are the ultimate goal of the march," Wu said, adding that if the march can really draw the participation of 1 million people, the international community then can fully understand Taiwan people's true desires.
More than 1 million people are expected to march toward the square in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei from 10 different locations in Taipei City and Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: POETS SIGN JOINT DECLARATION AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: More than 70 local and foreign poets who are attending the 2005 World Poetry Festival in the southern port city of Kaohsiung signed a joint statement against China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The statement, written by Lee Min-yung, a noted Taiwan poet, stressed the civilized values of freedom, democracy, love and peace. The statement said all the signatories hope to use "poetic roses to cover China's guns aimed at Taiwan."

Lee said he was pleased to win the endorsement of more than 70 local and foreign poets to use this poetic way to voice opposition to Beijing's Anti-Secession Law that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.
With a theme of "Sea and Land in Harmony, Poetic Minds in Interflow, " the 2005 World Poetry Festival in Kaohsiung will run through March 27.
During the three-day event, poets from home and abroad will exchange their insights and creative experiences as well as recite their own poems and discuss topics related to literary developments.

Among the participants is Derek Walcott, a Saint Lucia dramatist and poet who won the 1992 Nobel Prize in literature. Other participants come from India, Bangladesh, Mexico, Nigeria, Mongolia, Romania, the United States and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 26 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, March 26:
10:00, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will attend the opening ceremony of the 2005 Taipei International Chain and Franchise Stores Fair at the Taipei World Trade Center.
13: 30, Demonstrators of the 326 March for Democracy and Peace will converge at 10 different locations in Taipei to march toward the plaza in front of the Presidential Office.
14:00, Author Yeh Shih-tao will meet Nobel laureate Derek Walcott at the Kaohsiung Municipal Cultural Center.
15: 00, A sit-in protest against China's Anti-Secession Law organized by the Taiwan Solidarity Union will be held at Kaohsiung Municipal Cultural Center.
18: 30, An alliance to protect Taiwan will organize speeches on Taiwan-U.S. relations at the Howard International House in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BRACES FOR PROTEST WITH EXPECTED RECORD TURNOUT

TEXT.P: With more than one million people expected to turn out in Taiwan for Saturday's protest against China's Anti-Secession Law, organizers are taking pains Friday to ensure the event is a success.

The Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, which is organizing the protest, is an umbrella group consists of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and others. It said Friday that more than 5,000 tour buses will pull into Taipei from around the island Saturday, raising the possibility of traffic jams and parking problems.

The buses will drop off their passengers at 30 different locations around the city, and then drive to parking lots near the square in front of the Presidential Office where the marchers will eventually meet up.
In order to minimize air pollution, the city's environmental protection officials asked the drivers Friday not to keep their buses running while they are parked.
The protesters will march toward the square in front of the Presidential Office following 10 different routes. The routes have a combined length of more than 40 kilometers.
In order to monitor the speed of the marchers, each route will be led by a car equipped with a global positioning system.
President Chen Shui-bian and his family will join the march at some point, ensuring that security details will have their hands full.

News reports Friday said that seven security officials were disciplined for allowing the president and vice president to be shot last year the day before the presidential election. Punishments were said to have been meted out to the former National Security Bureau chief and the president's former aide-de-camp, among others.

Adding to the security headache is the fact that many other high-ranking government officials will also march Saturday, from Premier Frank Hsieh on down. With so many routes and so many people involved, officials say that keeping the high-profile marchers safe will be a challenge, even for experienced security officials.
To keep things running smoothly, the organizers have recruited an army of volunteers to help ensure that everything proceeds in a peaceful manner.

Sixteen supply stations will be set up along the 10 routes to provide protestors with bottled water, small flags, and badges. Twenty thousand bottles of water have been ordered by the organizers -- one bottle for every five people expected to march.
The organizer will also have 1,500 mobile toilets for the expected one million protesters, or one toilet for every 666 persons.

Instead of listening to politicians' speeches as in the past, the protesters will sing several songs at the square in front of the Presidential Office, and break up at about 5 p.m. How a million people will disperse without gridlock is something that organizers say will work itself out.
Organizers will have big posters pointing the way to tour buses, and they said that they hoped that the last protesters will leave the square for home an hour and a half after the end of the march.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO ACCENTUATE NAME-CHANGE APPEAL IN '326' MARCH

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) will accentuate its appeal for rectifying the nation's name and writing a new constitution in the 326 March for Democracy and Peace this weekend, a spokesman said Friday.
More than one million Taiwan citizens from all walks of life are expected to take to the streets in Taipei Saturday to protest China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
The demonstrators will march toward the square in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei from 10 different locations in Taipei City and Taipei County.
Legislator Lo Chih-ming, the TSU legislative whip, said like-minded demonstrators are welcome to join the TSU squad, also known as the anti-annexation squad or the ninth squad, in the parade.

"The TSU squad will take the ninth parade route from Wanhua railway station to the Presidential Office square, " Lo said, adding that the party has designed a number of activities, slogans and souvenirs to highlight its goals of promoting the rectification of the nation's name from the Republic of China to Taiwan and writing a new constitution that suits Taiwan's political reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY, PEACE AND SECURITY ARE COMMON DESIRE OF TAIWAN PEOPLE: CHEN

TEXT.P: Democracy, peace and security of Taiwan -- the theme of a protest to be staged on March 26 -- are the common desires of the people in Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.

Receiving South Korean scholar Kim Young-oak, founder of the Institute of History of Korean Thoughts, Chen said Taiwan doesn't have ethnic problems, what it has is the problem that some people don't consider this island as their homeland.
Chen said Taiwan is a diversified society with people of different origins. Except for the aborigines, Taiwanese immigrated to the island from different places at different times.
No matter when they arrived in Taiwan, no matter whether they call it the Republic of China or Taiwan, Chen said, they had a common compassion for the island.
All the differences among them notwithstanding, Chen said democracy, peace and security is their common desire, which unites them closely together.
Chen said he believes that this will also be the desire for the Chinese people on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER JOINS `FLASH MOB' TO SHOW ANGER AT ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh set a precedent Friday by joining a "flash mob" to demonstrate displeasure over China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law.
At about 10: 55 p.m., the premier showed up in front of National Taiwan University (NTU) accompanied by Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai and Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao.

They were responding to the creative way of around 70 young people to express their opposition to the passage of the law, which provides Beijing with a legal basis to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan if it deems the nation to be moving toward independence.
One of the flash mobbers sent the premier an e-mail Thursday inviting him to join the activity.
The youngster said the main task of the flash mob was to distribute brochures to passers-by to express their views on opposing the law.
The premier gladly accepted the invitation, describing it as a "significant" activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, March 26, or the 17th day of the leap second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1827: German composer Ludwig van Beethoven, considered the greatest composer of his day, dies in Vienna at the age of 57. His music, which formed a transition from classical to romantic composition, includes nine symphonies, five piano concertos, a violin concerto, 32 piano sonatas, several other sonatas, two masses and an opera.
1875: Syngman Rhee, South Korea's first president, is born. His rule ended in 1960 when he was forced out of office and into exile.
1895: Japan occupies the Penghu Islands located in the Taiwan Strait.
1902: Cecil John Rhodes, the British financier and colonizer who became prime minister of Cape Colony in 1890, dies in Cape Town at the age of 48. He amassed a huge fortune in the South African mining boom of the 1870s and 1880s, eventually gaining control of 90 percent of the world's diamond production.
1941: Ernest Miller Hemingway, the American writer who won the 1954 Nobel Prize in literature, interviews Gen. Yu Han-mou, commander of the seventh war zone, in Chukiang, Kiangsi Province, during the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1948: A total of 81 experts and scholars, including Wu Ta-you, Chen Sheng-shen and Hu Shih, are elected as members of Academia Sinica in the first elections held by the Republic of China's top research institute.
1949: The Chinese communists announce that peace negotiations with the Kuomintang will open in April in Beijing.
1953: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk announces the development of the first effective dead-virus vaccine against polio.
1953: Burma files a complaint at the United Nations against the ROC's support of guerrilla troops on the Sino-Burmese border.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek, in a special message to the Tibetan people, pledges that "the government will assist the Tibetan people in realizing their own aspirations in accordance with the principle of self-determination."
1966: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the ROC's opposition to U.S. recognition of Outer Mongolia.
1971: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman declares that the former country of East Pakistan is now the independent republic of Bangladesh.
1971: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Kuwait.
1975: Lien Chan, the new ROC ambassador to El Salvador, leaves Taipei to assume his post.
1976: Lin Yu-tang, one of the best-known Chinese writers in English, dies of a heart attack in Hong Kong at the age of 80.
1976: Taiwan's Chinese Federation of Labor opens its first national conference, with 118 delegates taking part.
1976: The ROC Executive Yuan nominates Chien Chun, deputy director of the Central Bank of China, as director of the International Monetary Fund.
1977: The ROC research vessel Hai Kung returns to Keelung after a 115-day exploratory expedition to Antarctica.
1979: In the presence of U.S. President Jimmy Carter, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar Sadat of Egypt sign a peace treaty ending 30 years of war between the two nations.
1985: Wang Hsi-ling, Hu Yi-min and Chen Hu-men are indicted for involvement in the murder of Liu Yu-liang, a noted writer with the pen-name Chiang Nan.
1993: In an interview with CNN, President Lee Teng-hui stresses the ROC's willingness to form a regional collective security system with other Asia-Pacific countries.
1996: The IMF agrees to offer a loan of US$10.2 billion to Russia over the next three years to help Russians transform their economy.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first high-speed rail system kicks off in the southern county of Kaohsiung.
1999: Visiting Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez makes history as he becomes the first incumbent foreign head of state to deliver a speech at the Republic of China's Legislative Yuan since its establishment at its current location.
2001: The Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation, initiated by former Premier Vincent Siew and 20 others, is formally established.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious in what you say to a friend. Lead him gently to what you would have him be; if you cannot do that, stop. Do not quarrel with him only to get an insult."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times:
A million people to protest against China's Anti-Secession Law.
The United Daily News:
Former chief-de-camp of President Chen Shui-bian disciplined over 319 shooting.
The Liberty Times:
A million people expected to take part in protest march.
The Taiwan Daily:
A million people say 'No" to China in protest rally.
The Central Daily News:
Former chief guard of president dismissed from job over 319 shooting.
The China Post:
MAC urges China to halt further anti-secession law.
The Taiwan News:
Chen calls on Taiwanese to stand up.
The Taipei Times:
France, don't mess up Asia: Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Supreme Court Rebuffs Appeal in Schiavo Case.
The U.S. Supreme Court turned aside the case of TerriSchiavo, dimming her parents' hope of keeping her alive, while religious activists made a final appeal to Gov. Jeb Bush to defy the courts and intervene.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Japan and HK sound holiday terror warnings.
THE chorus of warnings over an increased risk of terrorist attack in Indonesia and the Philippines has grown louder.
Japan has warned its citizens in Indonesia to avoid crowded places there, while Hong Kong's Security Bureau has issued a statement advising residents to take care if travelling to the Philippines.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Man trying to retrieve shoe hit by train in subway station.
A Man, who was on his way to Geylang to buy wedding decorations for his customary marriage, went down to an MRT track to retrieve his shoe died after he was hit by a train at Buona Vista station yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES PARTICIPATION IN MARCH IRRESPECTIVE OF PARTY AFFILIATION

TEXT.P: Everyone should come out in support of Taiwan against China's Anti-Secession Law regardless of party affiliation, a legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Saturday.
William C. D. Lai, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that different parties can have different views at home, but they should stand united when representing Taiwan to the foreign community.

"With the recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law in China, which stipulates that Taiwan is a part of the People's Republic of China, Beijing could use non-peaceful means against the island if Taiwan does not agree," Lai said.
He regretted that the opposition parties have been unwilling to take part in the march, especially since it is a critical time to take concerted action against China.

Chen Chieh, KMT caucus whip in the legislature of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), said Saturday that the march falls into China's trap and he knows of no KMT legislators who will take part in the march.
Chen said that Taiwan is a sovereign, independent state, and China's enactment of any law is irrelevant to Taiwan.

He said that the participation of President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh in the march will require thousands of military and policemen for their protection, which is "a squandering of national resources."
In response to Chen's remarks, Lai said that it is baffling for the KMT to use the pretext of China bullying Taiwan to explain their reasons for not participating.

Lai said he never suspected to see the KMT in league with the Chinese authorities, noting that KMT Chairman Lien Chan said before that the Anti-Secession Law is targeting a few pro-independent activists, and now the KMT is saying that it doesn't matter that Beijing passed the law.
The "326 March for Democracy and Peace" was organized by the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, an umbrella group consists of the DPP, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and others.
All 89 DPP legislators have pulled out all stops to mobilize the people, and the party estimates that at least 200,000 people from around the island will come to Taipei, Lai said.

But they will only form the basis of the participants in the afternoon, Lai said, adding that he is confident that one million will turn out to speak out for Taiwan and convey their will that they are vehemently opposed to the Anti-Secession Law.
To make the march take on the flair of a peaceful carnival, the DPP legislators have taken pains to be creative.

Lai has prepared a lot of Taiwan fruits, including bananas and guavas, and will perform skits during the march to satirize China for taking a two-pronged approach -- approved the Anti-Secession Law on the one hand and saying that it supports Taiwan fruits for export to the mainland on the other.

Several female DPP legislators will distribute candy and cookies along the marching routes, while Legislator Tang Pi-er will dress in a costume printed with slogans in various languages to underscore their opposition to the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF TAIPEI POLICEMEN SENT FOR 326 RALLY

TEXT.P: More than 4,700 policemen were dispatched to maintain order for Saturday's rally against China's Anti-Secession Law in the capital city, police said.
This is the largest number ever deployed by the Taipei City Police Department for a single assembly, with 56.4 percent of the city's police force on duty.

At least one million people are expected to turn out for the 326 March for Democracy and Peace. The marchers will set off from 10 different places in Taipei and head to the boulevard in front of the Presidential Office for a huge gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU STARTS SIGNATURE DRIVE FOR REFERENDUM ON ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) launched a signature drive in southern Tainan County on Saturday for a proposal to hold a referendum on China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The party proposed that a referendum be held on May 14 alongside the elections for the ad hoc National Assembly to let the people vote on "whether Taiwan agrees or disagrees with the Anti-Secession Law."

According to Tseng Hsin-chao, head of the TSU's Tainan County branch, a lot of people in southern Taiwan are not able to participate in the large-scale 326 March for Democracy and Peace being held in Taipei because of transportation problems, and the signature drive was organized to allow them to voice their protest at the aggressive legislation.
Tseng said more than 1,000 people have signed to endorse the proposed referendum as of Saturday noon.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: U.S. Is Set to Sell Jets to Pakistan; India Is Critical.
The U.S. will sell F-16 jet fighters to Pakistan in a deal that the State Department said would improve regional security.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIOANL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush: U.S. to Sell F-16s to Pakistan.
President Bush rewarded a key ally in the war on terrorism Friday by authorizing the sale of F-16 fighter jets to Pakistan, a move that reversed 15 years of policy begun under his father and that India warned would destabilize the volatile region, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TAKES TO THE STREETS AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian joined hundreds of thousands of people in a huge demonstration Saturday in the capital city against China's Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes the use of force against Taiwan in certain circumstances.
Escorted by security officers, the president and the first family showed up at around 3 p.m. at one of the 10 routes heading toward the boulevard in the front of the Presidential Office.

An estimated one million participants of the 326 March for Democracy and Peace set off from 10 different places in Taipei at around 2:30 p.m. and are expected to reach the boulevard at 4:30 p.m. for a large rally.

The president is not going to give a speech at the rally but will lead a ceremony declaring Taiwan's aspirations for "democracy, peace and security" and lead protesters in singing songs before the rally is dismissed.
Four songs representing the four main ethnic groups in Taiwan and the U.S. civil rights movement key anthem, "We Shall Overcome, " will be sung.
In addition to President Chen, his predecessor, Lee Teng-hui, and Premier Frank Hsieh also participated in the march.
Vice President Annette Lu will only take part in the assembly in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATRIATES IN JAPAN PROTEST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang, Y. S. Lo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Representatives from Taiwan groups and associations in Japan went to the Chinese Embassy in Tokyo Saturday to express their indignation at China's recent enactment of an Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
More than a dozen representatives took part in the protest, with Lin Yao-nan, who serves as an adviser to Taipei's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, reading a protest letter.

Lin said that Taiwan has established a nation through democratization with its president popularly elected.
