China's law is nothing more than an excuse to try to swallow Taiwan, he said, adding that the law has been met with derision from the people on Taiwan and has been condemned by the international community.
In addition to the protest, more than 30 Taiwanese-Japanese groups met in Tokyo Saturday afternoon to pass a resolution condemning China over the law.
Meanwhile, Taiwanese expatriates in Europe will meet in downtown Brussels Saturday to protest the law.

He Chang-hsien, president of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Belgium, said that posters will be displayed and there will be singing and speeches at the gathering, at which more than 100 people are expected to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Authorizes U.S. to Sell F-16s to Pakistan.
Policy reversal, decried by India, is coupled with fighter-jet promise to New Delhi. Critics assail deal as fueling regional arms race.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS IN U.S. TO TAKE MESSAGE TO THE STREETS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 25 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi, Chu Lu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Members of over a dozen Taiwanese groups in the great Washington, D.C. area will protest in front of the Chinese Embassy Saturday against Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

Gaines Ho, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs' D.C. Chapter, said on Friday that Taiwan expatriates in the United States are expressing their opposition to the passage of the law, which provides China with a legal basis to use "non- peaceful means" against Taiwan if it deems the nation to be moving toward independence.

The planned march in Washington, D.C. will take demonstrators first to Capitol Hill, where they will speak about the rights of the Taiwanese people and that Taiwan's future should be decided by the people living in Taiwan, instead of the authoritarians in Beijing, in a peaceful manner, according to the organizer.
Then, the demonstrators will head toward the Chinese Embassy on Connecticut Avenue to protest against Beijing's attempt to annex Taiwan, Ho said.
Fourteen groups of Taiwan expatriates from the East Coast have signed up for the march, which coincides with the massive March 26 protest rally in Taipei.

Meanwhile, on the West Coast, more than 800 Taiwan expatriates in Los Angeles, Orange County, Riverside and San Diego in California gathered at a square in front of Los Angeles City Hall Friday, where they began an "anti-Anti-Secession Law" march around the downtown area.

The demonstrators waved national flags of the Republic of China and the United States, as well as flags of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, raised banners reading "Anti-Secession is a Bad Law, " "Taiwan, China; One Country, One Side, " and "Anti-Aggression, Protect Taiwan, " and shouted other slogans. They urged people in the U.S. to condemn the "war-oriented" law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW THREATENS CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that Taiwan is a peace-loving country and is opposed to China's Anti-Secession Law, which he said has jeopardized peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Hsieh made the remarks while participating in the 326 March for Democracy and Peace in Taipei, which attracted an estimated one million participants.
The law, enacted by Beijing earlier this month, authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan under certain circumstances.
Hsieh said he was very happy to take part in the demonstration to make the voices of the Taiwan people heard by the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DRAW BLOOD TO SHOW LOVE FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: People in Yunlin, southern Taiwan have taken a different approach to show their love for Taiwan, in contrast with a large march in Taipei, northern Taiwan to protest against China's recent Anti-Secession Law targeting the island.

The opposition Kuomintang, working with other groups, launched a blood donation drive in front of the Touliou Railway Station, while the Disabled Women's Association also sponsored a charity auction, which received a good response.
The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union sponsored a signature drive in front of the railway station, and they also set off firecrackers to vent their displeasure over the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. OPPOSES CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 26 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China's Anti-Secession Law, which threatens the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, is in violation of the European Union's long-standing position that cross-Taiwan Strait differences should be resolved through dialogue, an E.U. official has said.
Javier Solana, secretary-general of the E.U. General Affairs and External Relations Council, made the remarks in an interview with Germany's Bild am Sonntag weekly magazine for its March 27 issue.
Solana said the enactment of the law is worrying to the E.U., which is currently working to lift its arms embargo against China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 326 MARCH NOT TO HAVE LONG-TERM EFFECT ON TAIWAN SHARES: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: The massive march protest Saturday in Taipei against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law -- the largest in Taiwan's history -- should not have a negative impact on Taiwan shares over the long term, market analysts said Saturday.

Market observers said share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) should not be too much affected Monday, as the peaceful protest marks an end of a string of complications to Beijing's enactment of the law March 14 against Taiwan independence.

Rather than political factors, recent oil price surges on the global market and fluctuating currency exchange rates will create more effects on the market's performance at a time when the U.S. again lifted its interest rates Tuesday and when U.S. stocks have been at relatively low levels in recent days, they pointed out.

As foreign hot money has showed signs of flowing to the United States from Taiwan due to the U.S. Federal Reserve recent rate hikes, they predicted that Taiwan stocks may come under increased selling pressure over the short term.

Although room will be limited for the TAIEX to perform extraordinarily for the coming low season in the second quarter, they are confident that the market will eventually return to look to economic fundamentals on the grounds that political elements are usually passing phenomenon.

They opined that the Saturday protest will not have a long-term impact on the domestic bourse and flow-on effects should be fully and quickly digested in the wake of the event owing to a political reconciliation atmosphere in Taiwan.
Investors can temporarily sit on the sidelines, but they do not have to be wholly pessimistic about Taiwan shares, they suggested.

However, in the face of rising oil costs, shares of energy-intensive traditional businesses, such as plastics, synthetic rubber, steel and metal industries, will be hit harder over the mid- and long-term, they said, adding that the present situation will be harder for small businesses to sustain than large companies.

Continued soaring oil prices will increase production costs for businesses and fuel product prices, a development that may force consumers to cut spending and could drag down economic growth, they warned.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , in conjunction with the Bureau of Foreign Trade and Taiwan External Trade Development Council, has formed an overseas purchase group to help minimize operating pressure on Taiwan's small businesses in light of rising raw-material prices, taking advantage of a stronger new Taiwan dollar.
Initially, the MOEA is planning to send the mission to South Africa, Brazil, Russia and Ukraine to procure prime raw materials to meet local demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN DISAPPROVES OF 326 RALLY

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan expressed his disapproval of Saturday's large demonstration co-organized by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) against China's Anti-Secession Law.

During a meeting with local KMT politicians in central Taichung City, Lien said the DPP, which controls lots of administrative resources, could have done something more meaningful to express its unhappiness with the law than mobilizing people to take to the streets.
According to Lien, ensuring the peace and stability of Taiwan should be the top priority no matter what methods are adopted to show the country's objections to the law.
The organizers of the 326 March for Democracy and Peace had previously invited Lien and other opposition leaders to join the demonstration, but the invitations were turned down.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIAOLI INTERNATIONAL MASK FESTIVAL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 2005 Miaoli International Mask Festival kicked off Saturday with a carnival and exotic atmosphere at the Shan Grira Paradise recreation park in Chaochiao township of Miaoli County, northern Taiwan.
To open the festival, County Magistrate Fu Hsuen-peng switched on a symbolic "light of the god of the sun, " as was once revered in ancient civilizations in South and Central America.
The festival has been held five times in the past seven years.

With Latin American mask art a special focus for the 2005 event, many exquisite, historic and valuable hand-crafted masks featuring mysterious ancient civilizations of the Incas, Mayans and Aztecs are on display during the festival that will run through May 29.

Besides mask exhibitions on five different themes, including Taiwanese mask art, there will also be a series of music and dance performances prepared by local and folk art troupes from Brazil, Mexico, Peru and Malawi during the 65-day activity organized by the Miaoli County Government, according to the organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS JOIN 326 RALLY IN SUPPORT OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: As hundreds of thousands of Taiwan people marched down Taipei streets to protest against China's Anti-Secession Law on Saturday, a number of foreigners living on the island also turned out for the demonstration to show their support for Taiwan.
Pablo Mark, an American teaching English in Taichung City, appeared among the protesters in a T-shirt printed with the Chinese characters meaning "Taiwan spirit."
Calling China a bully, Pablo said Beijing has caused tensions across the Taiwan Strait by enacting a law to threaten the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.

Eddy, a lecturer of French at Taitung University, who has lived in Taiwan for 16 years, said China should respect the right of the people of Taiwan to make their own decisions while the rest of the world should also listen to their voices.
Malcom Vergas, another American who has lived here for 20 years, said Taiwan is his home and that he will stand on the side of the Taiwan people.

Meanwhile, a group of Japanese students studying Mandarin in Taiwan also formed a team to support Taiwan's democracy and protest against China's hegemonistic move, saying they will "protect Taiwan, protect Japan, protect Asia."

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH SECTOR WANTS CROSS-STRAIT RAPPORT TO BOLSTER EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Companies based in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) in northern Taiwan called Saturday for rapport with mainland China, saying that it is vital for both sides to upgrade their technologies.

Tung Chao-chin, chairman of a federation composed of companies based in the hi-tech park, said that peace and security across the Taiwan Strait is a conduit for continued hi-tech development on both sides.

Both sides of the Strait will be hurt if tensions continue to mount, he said, adding that Taiwan hi-tech businesses long for sound government policy and goodwill from both sides to maintain peace in the region.
That China has become one of the world's economic powerhouses is clear and more and more foreign enterprises are seeking to expand into its market, he said.

Chen Hsi-meng, chairman of an IC design company operating in the park, viewed cross-strait peace as the key gauge for Taiwan companies wishing to draw up their next-step market deployment strategies and as a major reference for foreign businesses to assess long-term investment potential in Taiwan.

Should cross-strait stability become uncertain, the pace of Taiwan companies "going west" will diminish and foreign enterprises could begin to worry, Chen said. On the other hand, a peaceful cross-strait relationship will help attract a much greater amount of foreign capital to Taiwan, he added.
Their remarks came shortly before a large demonstration later the same day in Taipei to protest Beijing's Anti-Secession Law aimed at curbing Taiwan independence.
The HSIP, Taiwan's most representative facility of its kind, houses only hi-tech companies.

Cross-strait ties have remained fragile for some time since late last year after perceptions that Taiwan was leaning toward independence by making such moves as wanting to change the official title of the Republic of China to Taiwan and writing a new constitution.

The situation became even more sensitive recently for the high-tech sector after United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) was charged by prosecutors last month with illegally investing in He Jian Technology -- a mainland-based wafer plant in Suzhou.
Taiwan-based UMC is the world's second-largest chipmaker on a contract basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IN PANAMA OPPOSE CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, March 26 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Representatives of overseas Chinese and Taiwanese groups issued a joint statement Friday in Panama to express their opposition to China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
The statement pointed out that China's legislation is trying to change unilaterally the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo and to provide Beijing authorities a legal basis for invading Taiwan by force.
Noting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been two different countries since 1949, it argued, cross-strait issues are absolutely not China's internal affair.
The future of the Republic of China should not be decided by any individuals or political parties, but all own citizens, it stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE IN HONG KONG SHOW SOLIDARITY WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, march 26 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: About 200 Hong Kong people marched from Victoria Park in Causeway Bay to China's joint liaison office in Hong Kong Friday to protest Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law.
The protest was timed to coincide with a similar protest in Taipei, Taiwan to show Hong Kong people's solidarity with the Taiwan people, said an organizer.
He said the protesters oppose the Anti-Secession Law because it threatens to use force against Taiwan, which runs counter to the international trend of solving disputes by peaceful means.

The protestors had no sympathy for Taiwan independence but believed the opinion of Taiwan people should be respected when it comes to the unification of the mainland and Taiwan, the organizer went on.
The marchers waved posters and shouted slogans opposing the Anti-Secession Law along the way to China's liaison office.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMONSTRATION ENDS WITH PRAYER FOR PEACE ACROSS THE TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: More than one million protesters who gathered in Taipei to show their resentment towards Beijing's Anti-Secession Law topped their protest off with a prayer for peace.

The prayer, which was read out by an emcee through the public address system at the end of the protest, said the protesters gathered had one common desire: to safeguard democracy, ensure peace and protect Taiwan.

The prayer read, "We treasure democracy and thereby oppose China's interference with Taiwan's internal affairs, which is the opposite of democracy. We treasure peace and thereby oppose Chinese military threats against Taiwan, which is the opposite of peace."
"China should learn what democracy and peace are -- universal values. China should also listen to the voices of the people of Taiwan"

Noting that their ancestors braved dangers to move to the island for freedom and had forged an epirit de corps through common suffering and hardships, the prayer said Taiwanese will be helped by their ancestors in their fight to preserve democracy and peace.
"We have just broken free from the shackles of an authoritarian regime, we will never allow ourselves to be shackled by another authoritarian regime."
"We will never give up the right to determine our own future, it is a right neither we nor our offspring will give up.

"Today we pray for not only peace for Taiwan, but also peace for the world. We hope the 1.3 billion friendly people of China can enjoy the same democracy, liberty and freedom from fear as we do. We hate war, we love peace; this is the 23 million Taiwan people's enthusiastic desire. We hope people with like minds will join us in our pray. May God bless Taiwan, both its people and its land, " the prayer ended.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CALLS FOR RATIONAL HANDLING OF CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) officials Saturday urged the government to put aside emotions and deal with cross-Taiwan Strait issues in a peaceful, rational and neutral manner after the large demonstration against China's Anti-Secession Law was over.
According to the party's spokesman, Hsieh Kung-ping, PFP Chairman James Soong was fully aware of the details of the demonstration but he had no comment on the matter.
No PFP member was to have taken part in the rally asking for democracy and peace, which was organized by an alliance led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
Among the protesters were President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh and a number of other government officials.
Chen Chih-pin, convener of the PFP's legislative caucus, said it was inappropriate and unhelpful to cross-strait peace for the president and government officials to take to the streets.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE OPPOSED TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW: DPP

TEXT.P: The large turn out at Saturday's demonstration showed the common resolve of the people of Taiwan against China's Anti-Secession Law, an executive member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said.
The law, enacted by Beijing earlier this month, authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan under certain circumstances.

Chen Wen-chan, director of the DPP department of culture and information, said that Taiwan is a society with democracy and freedoms. In the face of the threat inherent in the new law, hundreds of thousands of Taiwan people took to the streets to voice their determination to defend their democracy and freedom, adding this is the mainstream opinion of the public in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, senior advisor to the president Yeh Chu-lan reiterated that the people of Taiwan will not compromise their stance on defending their homeland.

No threat can force Taiwan to give up the fruits of its efforts to promote a democratic system and seek freedom, Yeh said in her address aimed at the four major ethnic groups on the island -- Australoid, Hakka, early settlers from southern China, and indigenous peoples.
During the rally, a Hakka citizen from Hsinchu, Chen Yung-hung, raised a sign with the characters for "Taiwan is no longer a colony of any other country; Peace is the only road for Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTEST UNLIKELY TO HALT ANTI-SECESSION LEGISLATION: OBSERVERS

TEXT.P: Despite a large protest in Taipei against China's Anti-Secession Law, Beijing is unlikely to halt its legislation process to iron out more by-laws to step up its threats against Taiwan, political observers said Saturday.

Byron S. J. Weng, a national policy advisor to President Chen Shui-bian and professor at National Chi Nan University, opined, however, that Beijing should be more concerned about follow-up reactions from the United States and European countries in the wake of the March 26 protest in Taipei.

Weng told CNA that it is still too early to talk about possible effects of the march for Beijing, and he contented that it is unlikely that Beijing will stop its legislation moves to further oppress Taiwan. But he said that support from the U. S. and the European Union (E. U.) should push Beijing to review its hegemonic attitude toward Taiwan.

Lin Chong-pin, a former vice minister of national defense and a vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, echoed Weng by saying that it is hard to judge whether the protest march would exact a price in bilateral ties and claimed that Beijing would care more about ensuing responses from the U. S. and the E. U. because Beijing is dealing with the Taiwan issue through a global strategic viewpoint.
Lin said that he does not think that Beijing would overreact to the protest march in the near term, as protesters showed restraint.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILLION-PERSON MARCH ENDS PEACEFULLY WITH CARNIVAL ATMOSPHERE

TEXT.P: A million-person march to protest China's Anti-Secession Law concluded peacefully in Taipei with the singing of songs instead of emotionally charged rhetoric by political figures.

President Chen Shui-bian showed up in front of the Presidential Office at around 5: 15 p.m. as the giant mass of people surrounded him with air batons banging and shouts of "protect democracy, love peace and safeguard Taiwan."

The president later activated a "peace" ceremony in which a laser beam that originated from a 20- meter tall balloon representing the "pearl of democracy," which hit a red "sea urchin" -- another balloon with numerous spikes representing the approximately 700 missiles Beijing has deployed along its coastal provinces targeting Taiwan -- to show that the "beam of democracy can crush military might."
The president then led the crowd to join arms to symbolize national solidarity. The laser beam also projected the words "democracy, peace and safeguard Taiwan" on the Presidential Office building.
The march ended after the president led the participants in singing "She's Our Baby, " symbolizing that Taiwan is like the child of all its inhabitants.
The "326 March for Democracy and Peace, " attracted the participation of more than 500 civic groups and hundreds of thousands of people from around the island.

The people, coming from every city and county and even from the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, started to converge on Taipei in the morning. The march began at around 2: 30 p.m. at 10 different locations, and ended at a boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

President Chen, dressed casually, led his family through the throng at 3:11 p.m. while some people struggled with security personnel around the first family to try to shake hands with the president. The president's two-year-old grandson, with demonstration stickers on his cheeks, was also a big attraction. Chen and his family arrived at Ketagalan Boulavard at around 3: 30 p.m.

Former President Lee Teng-hui led a large contingent from Daan Forest Park. Accompanying him were such pro-independence activists as former Presidential Office senior adviser Koo Kuan-min, former Presidential Office advisers Huang Chao-tang and Kim Mei-lin, and Huang Chu-wen, former head of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), of which Lee serves as its spiritual leader.
Several TSU legislators also stamped on pictures of the leaders in Beijing to vent their anger with the new law.
Premier Frank Hsieh, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and other ranking government officials were also on hand.

To vent their indignation at China for the passage of the Anti-Secession Law March 14, some tried to burn the national flag of the People's Republic of China, but security guards quickly doused their enthusiasm with fire extinguishers. Protesters had to settle for jumping up and down on the makeshift paper flags
Woman legislators from the DPP distributed "peace candy" and "happiness cookies" along the march routes to wish the participants peace and happiness.
Some tried more creative ways to underscore the cause by decorating their dogs with flags and stickers and taking them along the routes.

Another group comprised mostly of women's groups and TV talk show hosts and hostess commandeered 706 kindergarten children, who were made to put on paper fake bare buttocks with the words "leave" and "peace" on them to symbolically moon China.

Ketagalan Boulevard took on a carnival-like atmosphere with a band playing and several local performers singing songs about Taiwan shortly after the first contingent arrived at around 3: 25 p.m. Music took the place of political speeches ubiquitous in past rallies.
A representative of the Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, an umbrella group consisting of the DPP, TSU and others, who sponsored the march, then read an article on the goal of the march.

The sea of people then sang four songs symbolizing the four major ethnic groups in Taiwan -- "Friends, " "She's Our Baby, " "The Nature of the Hakka, " and "We're of a Family, " as well as a U.S. civil rights movement key anthem, "We Shall Overcome."

DPP Chairman Su and the convener of Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace then pushed five giant balloons symbolizing "opposition" into the crowd. Vice President Annette Lu then hung banners symbolizing prayers for peace on balloons that were then released into the air.

DOC.HEADLINE: IF BEIJING STILL CAN'T HEAR TAIWAN, THEN IT'S BEING CALLOUS: TSU

TEXT.P: If the leaders in Beijing still cannot hear the voice of the people of Taiwan after Saturday's march, then they are indeed insensitive to the level of being callous, a legislator from the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Saturday.

Lo Chi-ming, TSU caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks after hundreds of thousands from around the island and outlying islands joined the march in Taipei to vent their anger at China's passage of the Anti-Secession Law on March 14, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan under certain circumstances.

Given that Taiwan people have attempted to make their feelings on the issue known to the international community via the march, and let the world hear the true voice of Taiwan, if Beijing leaders still cannot hear this, then they are indeed insensitive, Lo said.
The TSU agreed that it was appropriate that President Chen Shui-bian participate in the march, although it "regretted and felt it is a pity," that he didn't give a speech.
"This is because a lot of people around the island couldn't join the march, and they wanted to hear the president speak, " Lo explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROGRAMS TO ENCOURAGE PRIVATE INVESTMENT IN PUBLIC PROJECTS MULLED

TEXT.P: Several programs to boost private investment in public projects are in the pipeline and soft loans to private investors are being serious considered, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Saturday.

Answering journalists' questions on the sideline of the March 26 protest against China, the economist-turned vice premier said several primary programs aimed at encouraging the private sector to chip in with investments in public projects have been worked out after Premier Frank Hsieh asked economic officials to do their utmost to keep the economy growing at more than 4 percent, and keep the unemployment rate below 4 percent in 2005.
As these programs have yet to be approved by the Cabinet, Wu said it is not time to reveal them, but offering soft loans to private investors is possible.

09:00, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will attend the activities held by the District 3460 of Rotary International at the campus of National Chunghsin University in Taichung, central Taiwan, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Rotary International.
09: 30, The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.
10: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will be interviewed by the Chinese Television System (CTS) at the CTS studio.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, March 27, or the 18th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: Spain agrees to cede Gibraltar and Minorca to Britain.
1794: The United States establishes its Navy.
1802: France and Britain sign the Peace of Amiens, creating a short pause in the Napoleonic Wars.
1914: The first successful blood transfusion is performed in a Brussels hospital.
1917: Cyrus Vance, American politician and secretary of state from 1977 to 1980, is born.
1926: Construction of a railroad linking Taitung and Hualien in eastern Taiwan is completed.
1933: Japan withdraws from the League of Nations after the organization refuses to recognize "Manchukuo."
1945: Argentina declares war on Japan and Germany.
1953: The Republic of China Ministry of Education approves the establishment of Tunghai University by a Christian organization.
1958: Nikita Kruschev ousts Soviet Prime Minister Marshal Nikolai Bulganin in a Kremlin power struggle.
1968: Soviet astronaut Yuri Gagarin, the first man to orbit the earth, dies in a plane crash near Moscow.
1969: The North Vietnamese delegate to the Paris peace talks rejects South Vietnamese President Nguyen van Thieu's proposal for direct and secret negotiations.
1973: Paul Cardinal Yupin leaves Taipei for the United States en route to the Vatican to attend a meeting.
1974: Vice President C. K. Yen returns from a 20-day visit to South America. He attended the inaugurations of President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela and President Ernesto Geisel of Brazil.
1974: Retired Lt. Gen. James H. Doolittle of the U.S. Air Force, who led the first American air raid over Tokyo, Osaka and Kobe during World War II, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Madame Yen Chia-kan awards Golden Phoenix Statues to the 10 outstanding young women (under 40) of 1975-76.
1976: Taipei Mayor Chang Feng-shu is decorated by Dr. Jose A. Quezada Tajeda, administrative secretary of the Presidential Office of the Dominican Republic.
1977: A KLM jetliner and a Pan Am jetliner collide on the runway in Tenerife in the Canary Islands, claiming 575 lives.
1981: Urged by union leader Lech Walesa, millions of Polish workers stage a general strike to protest police harassment of activists belonging to the trade union Solidarity.
1989: The Central Bank of China of the ROC announces the cancellation of limits on the daily fluctuation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, effective April 3.
1990: The eighth plenum of the ROC National Assembly passes a motion to force members who failed to attend the plenary session to retire by the end of July 1990.
1991: Chen Charng-ven, secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, flies to the Chinese mainland to discuss the release of three security policemen taken across the Strait by mainland fishermen. The four would be returned to Taipei on April 3.
1992: The ROC and Bulgaria agree to establish direct air links between Taipei and Sofia.
1994: The Eurofighter, a high-tech fighter jet developed under a four-nation project, makes its successful maiden flight.
1995: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council of the ROC adopts a regulation governing the participation of mainland Chinese people in economic and trade activities in Taiwan.
2000: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng assumes the post of secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee.
2000: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Canadian Nobel laureate Robert Mundell to exchange views on Asian financial problems, Taiwan's economic development and global economic trends.
2001: John Chang, former secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang, registers to run for a seat in the Legislature in the year-end elections.
2003: The Executive Yuan declares severe acute respiratory syndrome a statutory infectious disease and set up special clinics in major hospitals to deal with people suffering from the disease.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who can recite three hundred pieces of poetry by heart, but who, when the conduct of the affairs of a nation is entrusted to him, can do nothing; and who, when sent on a public mission to a foreign country, has nothing to say for himself -- although such a man has much learning, of what use is it?"

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTS AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW HELD IN GERMANY
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, March 26 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese expatriates and students in Germany held various activities Saturday to protest against China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, urging the German government and people to pay attention to China's threat to Taiwan.
The Anti-Secession Law adopted March 14 gives the Beijing regime the so-called "right" to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan.
The activities, including sit-ins, petitions and speeches, were held in Berlin, Frankfurt, Munich and Tubingen.

In Berlin, members of nine local Taiwanese organizations gathered at the square of Emperor William's Memorial Church to wave banners saying "anti-annexation, protect Taiwan" and to hand out leaflets to drum up support for the nation. According to the organizations, about 850 German people gave their names and addresses to show their support.
In Munich, Taiwanese students collected signatures from about 300 Germans.
Meanwhile, members of the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce, as well as the Taiwan Association and the Taiwan Women's Association in Frankfurt also held a petition drive.
In Tubingen, some 50 Taiwanese students from local universities and universities in Heidelberg and Freiboug also gave speeches in front of a church to criticize the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS DEMONSTRATE AGAINST ANTI-SECESSION LAW IN LONDON
DOC.DATELINE: London, March 26 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: About 200 Taiwanese expatriates in the United Kingdom gathered Saturday in front of the Chinese Embassy in London to demonstrate against China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, which threatens to use non-peaceful means to resolve the Taiwan issue.

During the protest, the demonstrators, who came from six local Taiwanese organizations and various cities, unfurled Republic of China national flags and banners, and chanted slogans to protest against China's newly enacted law.

They also gave an English-language statement to passers-by that not only reminds the British government of China's 12 percent increase in its military budget for this year and the more-than 700 missiles targeting Taiwan, but also notes that Beijing has enacted the Anti-Secession Law threatening Taiwan.
The statement also requests that the British people urge their government not to support the European Union's plan to lift an arms embargo on China.
Taiwan is a sovereign and independent state as well as a free and democratic country, it also says, adding that the future of the island must be decided by its 23 million people.

Pointing out that maintaining the current stability and status quo in the Taiwan Strait is the consensus of the international community, it further says that the Anti-Secession Law has unilaterally changed the status quo and will endanger security and peace in East Asia and the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO PREVENT 'AVALANCHE EFFECT' AMONG TAISHANG

TEXT.P: The government was urged Sunday to hammer out countermeasures to protect the rights and interests of Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "Taishang, " who are predicted to bear the brunt of Beijing's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Chai called for the government to work out policies to prevent the Taishang from being pushed to alienate Taiwan in business considerations under the threat of the Anti-Secession Law.

Chai warned that an open letter issued Friday by Hsu Wen-lung, founder and former chairman of Chi Mei Optoelectronics, saying that he supports the Anti-Secession Law, might trigger an "avalanche effect" among the Taishang community in China who will do anything to protect their money-making in China.

In the open letter marking his formal retirement from the Chi Mei leadership, Hsu expressed his anti-Taiwan independence stance, claiming that both Taiwan and China are parts of "one China" and that any move to seek Taiwan independence will lead the nation to war.

Hsu's letter represents a dramatic turnabout in his political attitude, as he was previously regarded as an ally of President Chen Shui-bian. Because of that, the People's Daily -- the mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party -- named Hsu last June as an example that Beijing does not welcome Taiwan businessmen who make cash in China and funnel the money back to the independence movement in Taiwan.

Noting that Beijing has incessantly spooked "green businessmen, " a term referring to DPP supporters in the business world, Chai said that the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law has enabled Beijing to exert unlimited pressure on Taishang.

Chai quoted intelligence from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) as indicating that as long as the Taishang are labeled by Beijing as "pro-independent" or "pro-Taiwan, " they can be sure of having "irrational" taxes levied by the Chinese authorities or of having their factories or companies investigated by tax officials without warning.
The Chinese authorities can easily accuse Taishang of violating the Anti-Secession Law, Chai added.

Chai said that if the government fails to craft efficient solutions soon, the Taishang will face a life-or-death crisis, which will in turn cause Taiwan's economy to "collapse, " he claimed, given that Beijing's grip on the Taishang has tightened, making the 1 million-strong Taiwanese businessmen in China scapegoats for China's so-called "united front."

Chi Mei Optoelectronics, one of the leading TFT-LCD flat panel manufacturers in Taiwan, has several manufacturing operations in China, although some new investment projects have hit snags as a result of political implications.

Meanwhile, officials from the MAC, the top government agency in charge of Taiwan's China policy, said Sunday that they are gaining an understanding of why Hsu wrote his open letter and the motives behind his publication of the letter on the eve of the largest protest in Taiwan history Saturday against the Anti-Secession Law.

According to Chi Mei spokesman Hsu Chun-hua, Hsu Wen-lung retired from the Chi Mei chairmanship late last year. His open letter was aimed at leaving a "blank paper" to his successor, Liao Chin-hsiang, to allow him a free hand to run the conglomerate, which has relentlessly sought expansion in China, said the spokesman.
Hsu Chun-hua said that all the Chi Mei staff feel comfortable with the former chairman's open letter, which claims that Chi Mei is a neutral business group that will stay out of politics.
It is also hoped that the Chinese authorities will appreciate the intent of the letter, the spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, Liao left for China Sunday, mainly to inspect progress in the building of a new flat panel plant in Ningpo, eastern China, and the expansion of a petrochemical plant in Zhenjiang, also in eastern China.
Liao said late last year that he has always believed business should be kept separate from politics. He added that he would rather keep aloof from politics for "at least fifty years."

Claiming that he visits China one or twice every year and maintains good connections with the authorities there, Liao said he does not think his group has been discriminated against since the People's Daily's lambasting of Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUARANTEE BEFORE LIFTING ARMS BAN ON CHINA: GERMAN CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of the ruling Social Democrat Caucus in the German parliament, Gernot Erler, demanded Saturday that Beijing must give a responsible guarantee in dealing with the Taiwan issue before the European Union lifts its arms embargo on China.
German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has insisted on the lifting of the E.U.'s arms embargo on China since the E.U. leaders held a summit meeting March 23.

The E.U. had planned to lift the embargo before the end of June, but China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan has created a difficult political environment for the E.U. to remove the ban.
The E.U. imposed the embargo in 1989 after the Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing.
According to Erler, the E.U. cannot give others the impression that it has approved China's offensive policy toward Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Javier Solana, the E.U.'s foreign policy representative, said in an interview that the E.U. has reservations about the Anti-Secession Law.
"The threat of the use of non peaceful means to resolve the Taiwan issue contradicts the European position, which is that the one-China policy must be pursued only through dialogue," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAR EAST AIR PILOT DIES AFTER ATTACK IN CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, March 27 (CNA) (By C.H. Jen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A pilot from Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. was reportedly killed after he and another pilot from the same company were assaulted Saturday at their guest house in Zhuhai City, in China's Guangdong Province.
Chien Sheng-chang was found dead, while his colleague Hsieh Cheng-wei suffered serious head injuries. Both were stabbed in their room in a guest house run by Southern China Air.
Chien, in his 30s and Hsieh, 48, were two of three Far East Air pilots who were sent by the carrier to Zhuhai March 19 for a Boeing 757-200 flight simulator training program.
The Guangdong authorities have been silent over the incident, while workers at the Zhuhai guest house have also kept tight-lipped about the murder.
The official Xinhua news agency reported the incident briefly, quoting "local police" as saying that "the crime occurred during a dispute over counterfeit money, " but did not provide details.
Another unconfirmed source said that the two pilots were attacked in their sleep by assailants who sneaked into their room to steal their belongings.

The Far East Air authority in Taipei contacted the intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) for help after being informed of the murder and wrote to the SEF's counterpart in Beijing, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) , as well as China's public security authorities, demanding that they find the killer.
Meanwhile, Far East Air officials are accompanying relatives of Chien and Hsieh to Zhuhai.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE IN WAKE OF PROTEST MARCH

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Sunday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume dialogue and work together for mutual benefit.

Lien made the remarks while meeting with members of a KMT delegation on the eve of their departure for a visit to China. The delegation will be headed by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang who is also a KMT legislator-at large. Chiang's mission will be the KMT's first official delegation to visit the mainland.

Analysts said the KMT risks being labelled as pro-China sympathizers -- or even traitors -- as the visit will come just two days after huge crowds of Taiwan people marched in Taipei against Beijing's anti-secession law.
However, Lien dismissed the allegation that the KMT is trying to mend fences with an old enemy, saying that the KMT is mainly aimed at reducing cross-strait tension.

Claiming that cross-strait relations are at a critical juncture, Lien said the KMT, as Taiwan's largest opposition party, cannot sit idly by and has to instead provide other choices and vision than those offered by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Lien said the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, 2000, opposes both the DPP administration's "one country on each side" of the Taiwan Strait stance and Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme.

"The KMT is committed to defending the Republic of China's national dignity and constitutional system. We don't think that Taiwan should declare independence. Nor do we think that the Chinese mainland should use force against Taiwan," Lien said, adding that "no Taiwan independence and no mainland attack" is the KMT's ultimate cross-strait policy.
In his view, Lien said, the two sides should shelve their political disputes and work together for their common interests.
"There are many things that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can do together for mutual benefit, and resumption of the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue should be the top priority, " he said.
Touching on Chiang's mission, Lien claimed that the delegation's visit is of "great historical significance."

The KMT delegation will visit the cemetery of Dr. Sun Yat-sen -- the ROC's national founding father -- in Nanjing and the cemetery of the martyrs who died in the Hwanghuagang Uprising in Guangzhou in the southern mainland province of Guangdong.

"This year marks the 80th anniversary of ROC national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen's death and the 94th anniversary of the Hwanghuagang Uprising. Without the revolution led by Sun and the Hwanghuagang Uprising, there would not have been the birth of the ROC. Those events have sacred meanings to the KMT. Therefore, the delegation's upcoming visit bears profound historical significance, " Lien said.

The KMT, which once ruled all of China, has kept a low profile because the visit comes at a sensitive time when many Taiwan citizens are angry at China's so-called anti-secession law which codifies Beijing's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it pursue separate statehood.
The delegation will leave Taipei for the mainland Monday, just two days after a massive protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's ill-intentioned legislation.
Chiang claimed that the visit is aimed at averting escalation of cross-strait tension in the wake of Beijing's anti-secession law.

In addition to visiting Guangzhou and Nanjing, the KMT delegation will also travel to Beijing, but its itinerary in Beijing has not been revealed. Political observers said the delegation may help pave the way for Lien to visit the mainland before he steps down as KMT chairman in August this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT YOUTHS CITED AS TAIWAN'S 'SELF-STRENGTHENING' HEROES

TEXT.P: Eight youths from poor or broken families were cited Sunday as young "self-strengthening" heroes for their courage demonstrated in the face of adversity.

The non-profit Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) presented "self-strengthening" awards to the eight youths, ranging in age from 12 to 16, in recognition of their vitality and endurance in the face of challenges and hardships that their counterparts from normal families could never imagine.
The youths were selected from among 35,000 children and teenagers nationwide who are on a TFCF list of recipients of some kind of aid.

According to TFCF Chairman Peng Ming-tsung, 12-year-old Chang Teng-chieh from Nantou, central Taiwan, has received nine operations over the past two years after a car accident, but has never shed a tear in front of his mother.
Sustaining traumatic pain from the operations and walking with artificial limbs, Chang often cheered up his counterparts many years his senior who could not face being handicapped.

Tsao Huan-chen from the offshore county of Penghu has a broken, financially constrained family, with a father who ran out when Tsao was a baby, a mother who suffers depression after sustaining brain injuries in a car accident and a senile grandmother.

Despite all his hardships, Tsao has studied hard and made himself a scholarship recipient every year, as well as winning various awards and prizes, including an educational award from President Chen Shui-bian.

TFCF -- a Taiwan version of the U.S. Christian Children's Fund (CCF) -- has been lauded by Chen as "a driving force enabling the government to try strenuously and undauntedly to administer the country" for the unconditional care it provides for children from underprivileged backgrounds.
The TFCF Web site can be found at www.ccf.org.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL PRICE HIKES EXPECTED TO HAVE LIMITED IMPACT ON TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Sunday that rising international oil prices are not expected to have a significant impact on Taiwan's economic development because the nation's dependence on imported oil has been dropping gradually.

Wu, who served as president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) before assuming his current post, made the remarks while delivering a speech on the domestic and global economic situations at an annual meeting of the Rotary International Taiwan District 3460.

The momentum of the global economic growth is expected to slow down due to continued hikes in international oil prices, a lower-than-expected growth of the economy of industrialized nations such as Germany, France and Japan, and a tightened monetary policy to be adopted by the United States and China, Wu said, quoting the latest report issued by Global Insight Corp.

Global Insight has forecast that the global economic growth will drop from 2004's 4.1 percent to 3.3 percent in 2005 and that the growth rate of the international trade volume for the whole of 2005 will slide from 2004's 8.9 percent to 4.2 percent, Wu pointed out

As for the domestic economic situation, Wu said that a yellow-red light has been signalled for Taiwan's economy for five consecutive months since December 2003, while a red light was recorded in May 2004.

The island's economy was rated yellow-red again during the June-September period and green between October and December 2004 and in January 2005, meaning that the domestic economy has been growing steadily, Wu went on. In the government-devised five-color rating system, a red light signifies an overheated economy, yellow-red indicates a heating-up economy, green reflects steady growth, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue represents recession.

Despite the surging international oil prices, Wu said the value of Taiwan's imported oil made up 25 percent of the country's total import value in 1980 and that the ratio dropped to 8.3 percent in 2003, while the proportion of the total value of imported oil as a ratio of the gross national product (GNP) fell from 12 percent in 1980 to 3.7 percent in 2003.
Wu further said that the production value of industries closely related to imported oil accounted for 37 percent of the GNP in 1980 and that the figure dropped to 27 percent in 2003.
Consequently, continued hikes in international oil prices are forecast to have a limited impact on Taiwan's overall economy, Wu added.

However, the vice premier stressed that due to Taiwan's limited national resources, the government will adopt concrete measures to develop substantive energy and upgrade energy efficiency to face the challenge from high oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS TO PUSH FOR 'ANTI-INVASION' BILL

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) vowed Sunday to push for the early passage of an "anti-invasion bill" after the March 26 mass rally against China's Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan.

Lo Chih-ming, chief convener of the TSU legislative caucus, noted that the 326 March for Democracy and Peace ended peacefully Saturday in Taipei, with the people of Taiwan showing their strong determination to fight against Beijing's hegemony.
However, he stressed that the TSU will continue to push for the legislation of an "anti-invasion peace law" in the Legislative Yuan.

Calling on the ruling and opposition parties to support the draft bill, Lo said the legislation will not only highlight the Taiwan people's stance against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law but will also provide a legal basis for a cross-Taiwan Strait peace mechanism.
Lo further said that the TSU caucus will maintain close contacts with its counterparts of other parties to strictly supervise the government's policies toward China.

Meanwhile, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming called on the government to adopt concrete and feasible policies aimed at safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty and highlighting the nation's international position.
Following the March 26 demonstration, the government should take concrete action to defend the country's sovereignty in line with mainstream public opinion, Chen said at a press conference.

Noting that the people of Taiwan have shown their firm determination again and again to fight against Beijing's hegemony from the "one-million-people-hand-in-hand" human chain rally held Feb. 28, 2004 to the 326 March for Democracy and Peace, Chen demanded to know what the government will do for the people in the wake of the protest.

Hundreds of thousands of Taiwanese marched down 10 major streets Saturday in Taipei, symbolizing the 10 clauses of China's Anti-Secession Law, and congregated for a carnival-like rally at the square in front of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TAIWANESE STUDENTS IN FRANCE OPPOSE ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, March 26 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Over 100 Taiwanese students pursuing advanced studies in France gathered at the Paris Human Rights Square Saturday to express their opposition to China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The students, who came from all over France after a week of online organizing, delivered speeches in French to express their discontent with the Anti-Secession Law, in which China gives itself the so-called "legal right" to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan if it decides the nation is moving toward independence.

Accusing the Beijing leadership of sabotaging peace across the Taiwan Strait, they called on the European Union to refrain from lifting an arms embargo against China, especially after the enactment of the law.

Another group of Taiwanese students also took to the streets in Lyon in central France in support of a mass rally held in Taiwan that same day to defend democracy and peace, while Taiwanese studying in Strasbourg also staged demonstrations against the law.

Meanwhile, France's main newspaper Le Monde covered Taiwan's 326 March for Democracy and Peace on its front page, claiming that "nearly 1 million people" took part in the demonstration to show their love for democracy and peace under the sponsorship of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and 500 civic groups.
The report also quoted the results of a public opinion survey conducted by the English-language Taipei Times as saying that 40 percent of those polled identified themselves as Taiwanese, not Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MISSION TO HEAD FOR CHINA MONDAY

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) delegation to be headed by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang is scheduled to embark on a five-day visit to the mainland Monday, marking the party's first official delegation to visit China, KMT sources said Sunday.

Chiang, who is also a KMT legislator-at large, and the 27-member delegation, are scheduled to first pay tribute at the cemetery of 72 martyrs who sacrificed their lives in the KMT-led Huanghuagang Uprising against China's last empire, the Ching Dynasty, in Guangzhou, southern Guangdong Province, Tuesday, or March 29. The death of the 72 martyrs March 29, 1911 is designated as the Republic of China's National Youth Day.
The group will then pay tribute at the mausoleum of ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing Wednesday before heading north to Beijing later in the day.
The KMT leadership declined to make known the group's itinerary in Beijing, but said that meetings with key officials should be expected.

It is widely speculated that Chiang's mission could mark a stepping stone to a landmark visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the near future, given that both Ting Yuan-chao, director of Lien's office and Chang Jung-kung, the KMT spokesman, are among the 27 delegation members.

Chang released the results of an opinion poll conducted recently by the KMT that indicates that about half of the respondents support the notion that the KMT should organize an influential delegation to China to forge rapport, while some 30 percent of the respondents said it is unnecessary.

The poll finds that most of the respondents do not want to see cross-Taiwan Strait relations continue to deteriorate but would be pleased to see the KMT help resolve the cross-strait stalemate and help rekindle exchanges, Chang added.

Lien said earlier that "this year marks the 80th anniversary of the death of ROC founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen and the 94th anniversary of the Hwanghuagang Uprising. Without the revolution led by Sun and the uprising, there would not have been the birth of the ROC. Those events have sacred meaning to the KMT. Therefore, the delegation's visit bears profound historical significance, " Lien said.
Lien also said Sunday that the KMT, as the dominant opposition party in Taiwan, should strive to provide the people with other options and a great vision.

Claiming that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led government is leading Taiwan "nowhere, " Lien said that both sides should seek to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue for mutual benefit.

According to Chiang, the KMT delegation members will also meet with China-based Taiwan businessmen for talks in Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing to gain a better understanding of their situation regarding operating in China.
Chiang's delegation will include nine KMT officials, 11 elected KMT representatives and seven pro-KMT business and industrial leaders.

The KMT, which once ruled all of China, has kept a low profile because the visit comes at a sensitive time when many Taiwan citizens are angry at China's Anti-Secession Law, which codifies Beijing's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if Beijing decides it is pursuing separate statehood.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES TAISHANG TO HAVE SECOND THOUGHTS ON INVESTING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " should review their China-bound investment projects and refrain from "blindly" expanding their investments there.

Lu made the appeal a day after a noted local business tycoon published an open letter supporting Beijing's "one China" policy and praising its newly enacted anti-secession law that codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it decides the democratic island pushes for separate statehood.

Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chimei Group, said in his letter carried in a local newspaper Saturday that he felt "comfortable" with the anti-secession law because independence will only push Taiwan toward war and bring disaster to the people.

Hsu's statement came as a surprise and an embarrassment for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration because he was one of President Chen Shui-bian's big supporters during Chen's presidential bid in 2000. Hsu's support for Chen made his China business a target of retaliation by the Beijing authorities. The publication of Hsu's letter coincided with a "million person" protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's ill-intentioned law.
Speaking in a television interview, Lu said she believes the publication of Hsu's letter Saturday was part of a Beijing countermeasure against Taiwan's unprecedentedly massive protest march.
Lu further said she is convinced that the letter was not conceived by Hsu himself, but was rather a Beijing-dictated "deposition" signed by Hsu.

Recalling that she was forced to sign a Kuomintang government-dictated "deposition" when she was imprisoned for the pro-democracy Kaohsiung Incident during Taiwan's martial law era, Lu said she was sympathetic to Hsu's plight and would not blame him.

Lu said she takes pity on what has happened to Hsu, saying that Hsu issued the letter at the expense of his own reputation and for the sake of a large number of people working for him in China because he "did not have any other choice."
The outspoken vice president reminded taishang that among the 190-plus countries around the world, the People's Republic of China is the only one that is hostile toward Taiwan.
Since China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress passed its so-called anti-secession law March 14, Lu said, relations across the Taiwan Strait have reached a critical juncture.

"At this crucial moment, local businessmen should exercise extreme prudence before venturing into the mainland market. Those who have already invested in China should also review their future operations and investment strategies to reduce risks," Lu said.

She further said her just-concluded diplomatic tour to El Salvador and Guatemala was part of her efforts to help local entrepreneurs adjust their investment strategies and foster new business opportunities in Central America, Taiwan's major diplomatic stronghold.
Lu said the delegation she headed has worked out several feasible cooperative projects in El Salvador and Guatemala. Details of those projects will be unveiled soon, she said.

"In the past, our businesses have focused on exploring the China market and setting up footholds there. In the future, I hope our entrepreneurs can look eastward for investment opportunities in Central America, where we have many diplomatic allies and have good business prospects," Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE EXPATS IN U.S. OPPOSE CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 26 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Luis Huang)

TEXT.P: Nearly 1,000 members from 17 Taiwanese associations in North America congregated at Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. Saturday to protest China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The demonstration was jointly organized by the World Federation of Taiwanese Associations (WFTA) and the Taiwanese Association of America in support of a mass rally held in Taiwan that same day to defend the nation's democracy and peace.

WFTA Chief Coordinator Kuo Chung-kuo told the demonstrators that the Taiwanese Associations in Washington, New York, Houston, Seattle and Canada had mobilized their members to throw their support behind the 326 March for Democracy and Peace held in Taiwan.

During the rally, some of the demonstrators presented a satirical play on China's enactment of its "bullying and irrational" law, which gives China the so-called "legal right" to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan if the country moves toward independence.
The protesters, divided into several groups, marched down the street to the Chinese Embassy to protest the controversial law, shouting "Democracy, Peace, Defend Taiwan."
The rally attracted many reporters, while John J. Tkacik, a U.S. Heritage Foundation senior researcher familiar with cross-Taiwan Strait affairs, also expressed his support for Taiwan's protest.
Meanwhile, over 800 Taiwanese expatriates and students gathered in the square in front of United Nations Headquarters in New York to voice their opposition to the law.
The protesters shouted "Shame on China, " "Peace for Taiwan, " "China Hands off Taiwan Now, " and "Anti-Secession, China Aggression."

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO OPEN CHAPTER IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, March 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation from the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) is scheduled to arrive in Tokyo April 2 to attend a ceremony marking the inauguration of the party's chapter in Japan, political sources said Sunday.
The 10-member delegation, to be headed by TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang, will be composed of TSU incumbent and former lawmakers and TSU strategists, the sources said.
Lin Chien-liang, vice president of the World Taiwanese Congress, will serve as the top representative of the TSU's Japan chapter. Lin said the TSU Japan chapter will also set up a branch in Osaka.
According to Lin, the TSU Japan chapter will focus on promoting the party's exchanges and cooperation with major Japanese political parties and boosting substantive Taiwan-Japanese relations.
Lin said the TSU Japan chapter will also serve as a channel for contacts between former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's spiritual leader, and Japan's political and academic circles.
During its four-day visit, the TSU delegation will also attend an annual meeting of the Japanese Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association and meet with influential Japanese politicians, Lin added.

In Taiwan's political arena, the TSU is an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the two parties are commonly known as the "pan-green" camp which pursues a Taiwan identity separate from that of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT CALLS FOR OVERHAUL OF CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui urged the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration Sunday to overhaul its policy toward China and stop its "active openness" attitude toward China-bound investment.

Lee made the call at a seminar on new thinking for cross-strait exchanges in the wake of China's enactment of its so-called anti-secession law that codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it decides the democratic island pushes for separate statehood.

Noting that the anti-secession law has posed a new challenge to Taiwan, Lee said that in the future, if China faces internal instability, its rulers can use the law as a pretext to attack Taiwan and thus sway Chinese people's attention from their domestic problems.
Nevertheless, Lee acknowledged that the law also offers new opportunities for Taiwan.

Lee said the ill-intentioned law reveals Beijing's ambition to become a regional power by force. Against this backdrop, Lee said, the United States and Japan have recently declared that the Taiwan Strait security is one of their common strategic objectives. In his view, Lee said the joint U.S.-Japan statement implies a favorable international climate for Taiwan to break the constraints of the anti-secession law and pursue its ultimate goal of becoming a normal country.
In recent years, Lee went on, the DPP administration has adopted an "active open" policy toward China-bound investment under pressure from some people.

"They argue that such a policy could ease cross-strait tension. However, China mainly treats cross-strait economic ties as a 'united front' tactic with an ultimate goal of annex Taiwan, " Lee said, adding that the "Hsu Wen-long" incident was the best example.

Lee was referring to an open letter published by Hsu Wen-long, founder of Chimei Group, in a local newspaper Saturday which throws support behind Beijing's "one China" policy and its anti-secession law.

Hsu's statement came as a surprise and an embarrassment for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration because he was one of President Chen Shui-bian's big supporters during Chen's presidential bid in 2000. Hsu's support for Chen made his China business a target of retaliation by the Beijing authorities. The publication of Hsu's letter coincided with a "million person" protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's ill-intentioned law.
Lee said Hsu's dramatic about-face embodies the failure of the DPP administration's "active opening, effective management" policy on china-bound investment.

"While easing restrictions on cross-strait investment, the DPP administration has failed to effectively manage China-bound investments. The lax management has resulted in a gradual loss of Taiwan's economic clout vis-a-vis China," Lee lamented.

With the anti-secession law escalating cross-strait tension, Lee said, now is the time for Taiwan to make a complete overhaul of its cross-strait economic policy and reinstate the previous "no haste, be patient" cross-strait policy.

The "no haste, be patient" policy was implemented during Lee's presidency. The policy was aimed at dissuading local businessmen from blindly venturing into the mainland market or setting up production facilities there.

DOC.HEADLINE: '326 MARCH' EMBODIES MATURITY OF TAIWAN'S DEMOCRATIZATION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday the smooth and peaceful conclusion of the unprecedentedly massive march in downtown Taipei a day earlier clearly manifests maturity of Taiwan's democratization.
Hsieh made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Taipei Fine Arts Museum where an exhibition especially organized for visually impaired people is being held.

An estimated 1 million people from around the island took to the streets in Taipei Saturday to voice their strong opposition to China's newly enacted anti-secession law that codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it decides the democratic island works to make its present de facto independence permanent.

"While the scale of the protest march was unprecedentedly huge, the event proceeded smoothly in a carnival style to accentuate our love for peace and democracy," Hsieh said, adding that the event serves as yet another indicator that democracy has taken root in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES LEGISLATURE TO SCREEN CONTROL YUAN NOMINATION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will ask the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan to include confirmation of the Control Yuan nominations into its work agenda, a party whip said Sunday.

DPP whip Lai Ching-teh said the DPP caucus will come up with a proposal Monday which will ask the legislature's procedures committee to place the confirmation of the President Chen Shui-bian-initiated Control Yuan nominations on to the legislature's work agenda at its Tuesday meeting.

The opposition-controlled legislature has been reluctant to screen the Control Yuan nominations on the excuse that President Chen had not consulted with the opposition before finalizing the nomination list.
Lai said the legislature can disapprove the nomination list, but is not entitled to infringe upon the president's power of candidates nomination authorized by the nation's Constitution.

The president referred the list to the legislature late last year. As the tenure of the previous legislature expired in January this year, the new legislature, which was inaugurated Feb. 1, has asked the president to send a new list.
As a concession, Lai said, the DPP caucus would not oppose that the legislature sends a letter to the Presidential Office asking the president to re-send the list.

"The president can respond by informing the legislature that the nominations will remain same as those named in the previously sent list, " Lai said, adding that he hopes the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party can accept this proposal to resolve this deadlocked issue.
The Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body that supervises government operations, has stopped operations since the tenure of previous Control Yuan members expired Jan. 31 this year.

President Chen has presented a list of nominations for new Control Yuan president, vice president and 27 seats in the watchdog body for the approval of the legislature in line with the Constitution. However, the legislature has so far declined to screen the list and has instead asked the president to come up with a new list. Chen has rejected such a demand, saying that the request violates the constitutional provisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPATS IN BRITAIN DEMONSTRATE AT CHINESE EMBASSY
DOC.DATELINE: London, March 26 (CNA) (By N. K. Han and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: More than 200 Taiwanese expatriates in Great Britain rallied in front of the Chinese Embassy in London Saturday to protest China's recent enactment of its so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

The demonstrators, including businessmen, students and individual Taiwan expatriates residing in Britain, expressed their strong opposition to China's anti-secession law that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan if it decides the democratic island pursues separate statehood.

Responding to an online notice of the planned peaceful demonstrations in major European countries, many Taiwan students traveled from various British cities to London to lend their support for the event.

The demonstrators, regardless of their party affiliations, waved the Republic of China's national flags, banners and posters as well as chanted English slogans to protest China's ill-intentioned legislation.

They distributed leaflets to passers-by. The leaflets remind the British government that China has raised its military spending by 12 percent this year and has pointed more than 700 ballistic missiles at Taiwan.

And now China enacts a so-called anti-secession law to codifies its longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it decides Taiwan moves toward formal independence, the leaflets said, adding that the British government should not support the proposal that the European Union lift its arms ban against China.
Stressing that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state as well as a liberal democracy, the leaflets said Taiwan's future should be decided by its 23 million people, not anybody else.
The two-hour demonstration was jointly organized by major Taiwanese associations in Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGED TO WORK OUT MEASURES TO PROTECT 'TAISHANG'

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) should worked out new measures to protect Taiwan businessmen operating in China, locally known as "taishang, " in the wake of China's enactment of the so-called anti-secession law, a lawmaker said Sunday.

Lai Ching-teh, who concurrently serves as the legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said the "Hsu Wen-long" incident indicates that China has stepped up pressuring "taishang" to change their political stance after the enactment of its anti-secession law.

Lai was referring to an open letter published by Hsu Wen-long, founder of Chimei Group, in a local newspaper Saturday which throws support behind Beijing's "one China" policy and its anti-secession law.

Hsu's statement came as a surprise and an embarrassment for the DPP administration because he was one of President Chen Shui-bian's big supporters during Chen's presidential bid in 2000. Hsu's support for Chen made his China business a target of retaliation by the Beijing authorities. The publication of Hsu's letter coincided with a "million person" protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's ill-intentioned law.
Lai said the MAC, the nation's mainland policy planning agency, should hammer out new strategies to cope with the post-anti-secession law situation.

A military tribunal determined last fall that Murat Kurnaz, a German national seized in Pakistan in 2001, was a member of al Qaeda and an enemy combatant whom the government could detain indefinitely at the U.S. military prison at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. In fact, the evidence upon which the ruling was based, recently declassified and obtained by The Washington Post, shows that U.S. military intelligence and German law enforcement authorities had largely concluded there was no information that linked Kurnaz to al Qaeda, any other terrorist organization or terrorist activities., the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, March 28, or the 19th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1483: Raphael, originally Raffaello Sanzio, great Italian Renaissance painter, is born. His works, including frescoes and portraits of religious subjects, exemplify the ideals of the High Renaissance.
1844: Mexico breaks off relations with the United States over the disputed territory of Texas.
1910: The first seaplane, designed by Frenchman Henri Fabre, successfully takes off near the French port of Marseilles.
1911: Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in China in 1898, arrives in Keelung from Kobe for a two-week visit.
1920: Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford, known to millions as the King and Queen of Hollywood, get married while surrounded by friends.
1930: Constantinople and Angora are renamed Istanbul and Ankara respectively in Turkey.
1938: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement denouncing the "Reform Government of China," a puppet regime established by the Japanese in Nanking.
1939: Adolf Hitler renounces Germany's 1934 non-aggression pact with Poland.
1939: Gen. Francisco Franco leads his army to take Madrid, ending the three-year Spanish civil war.
1941: Britain's Royal Navy sinks seven Italian warships without suffering any losses itself at the battle of Matapan, off the Greek island of Crete.
1945: Nazi Germany mounts its last V2 rocket attack against Britain.
1950: Nationalist troops retreat from Hsichang, in mainland China's Hsikang Province, marking the total fall of mainland China to communist forces.
1959: Mainland Chinese troops invade Tibet to quell an anti-Communist Chinese rebellion, forcing the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, to flee into exile in India.
1969: Former U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower dies of heart disease at the age of 79.
1969: Massive anti-Soviet demonstrations take place in Prague.
1969: Bishop Paul Yupin is appointed Cardinal.
1970: A disastrous magnitude 7.5 earthquake jolts western Turkey, killing more than 2,000, injuring over 4,000, and leaving more than 90,000 homeless.
1973: Marlon Brando, American film actor, refuses to accept his Oscar award for his role in "The Godfather" because of Hollywood's abuses of the American Indians.
1979: In the United States, the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant's reactor leaks radiation.
1985: Devan Nair resigns as president of Singapore on health grounds.
1994: The ROC and the Central African Republic sign a joint communique pledging further cooperation.
1996: After eight years of construction, the Mucha Line of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit System in Taiwan formally begins operations.
1999: NATO aircraft widen their strikes against Yugoslavia, targeting ground forces in Kosovo that are forcing tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians from their homes.
2000: The ROC-Canada Biotechnology Development Fund is formally established and is poised to become a prime mover behind a new round of development of Taiwan's biotechnology industry.
2000: Taiwan decides to ban imports of live cloven-hoofed animals and related products from Japan and South Korea after cattle in the two countries were found to be infected with foot-and-mouth disease.
2001: Liberian President Charles Taylor and his wife arrive in Taipei for a seven-day state visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man is in order in his personal conduct, he will be served even without taking the trouble to give orders. But if a man is not in order in his personal conduct, he may give orders, but his orders will not be obeyed."
