DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT TO HOLD WTO DISPUTE SETTLEMENT MECHANISM SEMINAR APRIL 8

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a seminar April 8 to introduce the World Trade Organization (WTO) Dispute Settlement Mechanism (DSM) to local industry, a BOFT official said Monday.
According to the WTO, the dispute settlement mechanism is the central pillar of the multilateral trading system and the world trade body's unique contribution to the stability of the global economy.

"A dispute arises when one country adopts a trade policy measure or takes some actions that one or more fellow-WTO members consider to be breaking WTO agreements, or to be a failure to live up to obligations," also according to the WTO.
The official said that more and more WTO members are using the dispute settlement mechanism to protect their rights and interests and to resolve trade quarrels.

BOFT Director-General Huang Chih-peng obtained a good result in the preliminary stage of an anti-dumping consultation meeting he held last month with his Indian counterpart in accordance with the WTO's dispute settlement procedures, the official said.

It is expected that several BOFT officials will explain during the seminar how to appropriately use the WTO dispute settlement mechanism to expand overseas markets, as well as share their experiences with the local industrial and trade sectors to jointly work on the removal of trade barriers against Taiwan products.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TASK FORCE SHOULD BE SET UP AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE: WANG

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng on Monday called for the accelerated establishment of the special task force to be made up of legislators from across the political spectrum to address cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Wang said that legislators from the various parties have agreed to create the task force with the principle of representation according to the ratio of political parties' presence in the legislature, adding that members of the group should be chosen without further delay.
The task force will be made up of the legislative speaker, vice speaker and 23 legislators, according to Wang.
The top priority of the task force will be organizing a cross-party delegation of lawmakers to travel to mainland China to bolster bilateral exchanges, Wang said.
He said that it is imperative that the legislators visit the mainland as one of the means to seek breakthroughs in the development of cross-strait relations.

The legislative speaker said it is hoped that all future cross-strait activities and relations will be included under the operations of the legislative cross-strait affairs task force, which he said he believes will allow Taiwan to get on better terms with the mainland eventually.

However, Lai Chin-teh, caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, cautioned earlier this month that matters relating to cross-strait ties are the responsibility of the president according to the Constitution.
Lai urged respect for the Constitution, adding that if the cross-strait task force affects the purview of the president, then this will undermine the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SUPPORTS FORMOSA PLASTIC GROUP'S STEEL MILL PLAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) supports Formosa Plastics Group's plan to build an integrated steel mill in the Yunlin offshore industrial park in southwestern Taiwan, a senior official said Monday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh was responding to a media report that Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) , one of Taiwan's largest private business groups, has decided to invest NT$135 billion in building an integrated steel plant in the Yunlin offshore industrial zone.
According to the media report, the new FPG plant -- the second of its kind in Taiwan after Kaohsiung-based China Steel Corp.'s -- will be able to produce 7.5 million tons of crude steel annually.
Asked about her views on the FPG's new investment plan, Ho said the MOEA has consistently supported the FPG's steel mill project because it is important to the development of Taiwan's steel industry.
Ho said the MOEA welcomes business groups from home and abroad to launch investment projects in Taiwan.

Under current domestic investment regulations, an environmental impact assessment must be carried out prior to the construction of a steel mill. Ho said the MOEA is now preparing for this work for the FPG project.
If all goes smoothly, the media report said, the FPG steel mill will begin operations by 2008.

FPG Chairman Wang Yung-ching reportedly has already informed senior MOEA officials of his group's decision to launch its steel mill project in the Yunlin offshore industrial zone and has asked for the ministry's support for the project, particularly in land acquisition and environmental impact evaluation.

Since the passage earlier this year of the Kyoto Protocol on limiting greenhouse gas emissions, industries that produce high levels of emissions, such as the steel and petrochemical industries, are now subject to stricter environmental impact standards, the MOEA officials noted, adding that the ministry will do its utmost to assist FPG in overcoming all difficulties to realize its new investment project as early as possible.

With the assistance of the MOEA, the media report said, FPG has managed to secure a 600-hectare plot of land in the Yunlin offshore industrial park for its new steel mill project. The group has already built a petrochemical complex in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE TO FORGE AHEAD WITH WHA BID: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Efforts to accelerate Taiwan's bid for observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision making body of the World Health Organization, will continue to forge ahead, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen stressed Monday.

Although Taiwan's bid to take part in the WHA as an observer was blocked again last year for the eighth consecutive year, Taiwan has gained stronger support from friendly countries, including Japan and the United States, Chen noted.

Taiwan will try again this year, Chen said, adding that all of Taiwan's diplomatic missions abroad have been instructed to consolidate ties with governments of their host countries to push Taiwan's WHA bid ahead.

Despite the fact that Taiwan has a solid economy and mature democracy, the island's diplomatic "space" in the international community has continued to restricted due to China's suppression and containment schemes, Chen lamented.
Nevertheless, Chen vowed, Taiwan will not be daunted by Beijing, which he said has played a "zero sum" game aimed at stealing away all of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

Although Taiwan, the 15th largest trading country in the world, has been barred from joining most of the world's organizations and activities that require statehood because of Beijing's interference, the island has never been absent from international efforts, including on the medical, health and humanitarian fronts, Chen added.

On news report that President Chen Shui-bian has instructed that a "Global Fund -- the Friends of Taiwan Association" be established and that his wife, first lady Wu Shu-chen, be made the chairwoman, to promote Taiwan's medical and human rights diplomacy, the foreign minister said he hasn't heard anything about the reported fund or anything from the president on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: 326 PROTEST TURNED INTERNATIONAL TIDE FOR TAIWAN: NSB DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: Saturday's protest march against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law has to some extent helped Taiwan turn the tide in its favor internationally, National Security Bureau (NSB) Director Hsueh Shih-ming said Monday.
Hsueh made the remarks while fielding questions from opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-feng after giving a key report on the protest march in Taipei.

Calling the protest a collective display of the Taiwan people's resentment of the law, Hsueh claimed that the activity in some ways helped Taiwan gain an advantage over Beijing in the international community after Beijing enacted the law March 14, justifying an attack on Taiwan under certain conditions it sets.

According to the NSB head, Beijing will continue keeping a close tab on Taiwan to see whether the island will resort to legal means, including adopting an anti-annexation law, to counter its Anti-Secession Law. Beijing is also expected to keep on seeking international understanding as a means of lessening mounting pressure arising from the law on itself, he added.

Hsueh said he believes that Saturday's protest has placed Taiwan above the fray in an international propaganda campaign against Beijing and that the international community is likely to further press Beijing to reopen dialogue with Taiwan to settle bilateral disputes.
The 326 March for Democracy and Peace was a successful exhibition of the Taiwan people's resolve to protect Taiwan's identity and a way to express their anger about Beijing, he said.

An estimated crowd of one million people took to the streets Saturday in Taipei, including President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh and former President Lee Teng-hui, to show their disapproval of the Anti-Secession Law.
There were 5,833 armed policemen at the event to maintain order and ensure the safety of the nation's leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE POET WALCOTT TO TALK AT COLLOQUIUM
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, March 28 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: West Indian dramatist and poet Derek Walcott, winner of the 1992 Nobel Prize in literature, is scheduled to appear at a colloquium to be held at Yuan Ze University in Taoyuan Monday afternoon.

Walcott, who is also a painter and a professor at a number of prestigious universities in the United States, is expected to have a "transcultural dialogue" with Far East Group Chairman Tony Hsu and several renowned writers in Taiwan, including Chen Juo-hsi, at the colloquium.

Coming from a multicultural background -- born in Castries, St. Lucia in 1930 to a British father and a West Indian mother, Walcott's writings are rich in cultural nuance, employing such topics as racial issues, identity and alienation of cultures, as well as the position of languages.

Walcott, who skillfully fuses folk island culture with the classical and avant-garde in his poems, could be an encouragement to Taiwan's literary circles at a time when Taiwan is enthusiastically promoting maritime culture, said a spokesman for the Kaohsiung City Government, which invited Walcott to Taiwan to take part in the 2005 World Poetry Festival in Kaohsiung.

In addition to taking part in the world poetry festival last Friday, Walcott attended a colloquium titled "Poetry, Language and Identity, " sponsored by the National Museum of Taiwanese Literature in Tainan City the same day, with various local poets, academics and literati also taking part.
Walcott, who from the age of eight envisaged himself becoming a poet, published his first poem at 14 and had his first verse collection printed by the time he was 18.

Walcott, who divides his time between the United States and Trinidad, exalts in the English language with his meticulously honed poems and evocative dramas, while also using a rich mix of Latin, French and Trinidadian patois.

In addition to poems and verse, Walcott also writes plays and epic poems. His 1990 epic poem Omeros, which echoes Homer's Iliad and Odyssey as it examines the Caribbean's colonial past and complex present, won him the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1992.

Often focusing on West Indian folk traditions, Walcott's plays include Dream on Monkey Mountain (1970), The Joker of Seville (1975), A Branch of the Blue Nile (1986), while his verse collections include In a Green Night (1962) , the autobiographical Another Life (1973) , Sea Grapes (1976) and Midsummer (1984).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATION HEADS FOR CHINA FOR 'COMMEMORATIVE' VISIT

TEXT.P: A delegation of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) left for China Monday for a visit aimed at paying tribute to the party's founder and martyrs as well as promoting economic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
It marked the first time that the KMT, which once ruled all of China, has sent an official delegation to visit the mainland since the party lost a bloody civil war to the Chinese Communists in 1949.
The 30-plus-member delegation, headed by KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, who is also a legislator-at large, will visit Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing during its five-day visit.

Chiang said prior to his departure that his mission will visit the cemetery in Guangzhou of the 72 martyrs who died in the failed Huanghuagang Uprising to overthrow China's last dynasty, the Qing, as well as the tomb in Nanjing of Dr. Sun Yat-sen who founded the KMT and the first republic in Asia -- the Republic of China (ROC).

"This year marks the 80th anniversary of ROC national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen's death and the 94th anniversary of the Huanghuagang Uprising. Without the revolution led by Sun and the Huanghuagang Uprising, there would not have been the birth of the ROC. Those events have sacred meanings to the KMT. Therefore, the delegation's visit bears profound historical significance, " Chiang said.

During its stay in Guangzhou in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong and Nanjing in central China, Chiang said, the delegation will also meet with Taiwan business people operating there, known locally as "taishang, " to collect first-hand information about their problems.
The delegation will also travel north to Beijing, Chiang said, adding that the delegation's itinerary there has yet to be finalized.
Media reports said Chiang may meet with senior Chinese officials during his stay in Beijing. But Chiang said no definite appointments have been made yet.

Chiang further said the KMT, as Taiwan's largest opposition party, is concerned about the 23 million local people's well-being and is willing to do something to help ease strained relations across the Taiwan Strait following Beijing's recent enactment of a law justifying its longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it thinks the democratic island is seeking formal statehood.
According to Chiang, the KMT, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20, 2000, is committed to defending the ROC's national dignity and constitutional system.

"We don't think that Taiwan should declare independence. Nor do we think that the Chinese mainland should use force against Taiwan. We believe that 'no Taiwan independence and no mainland attack' is the best strategy for the development of cross-strait relations and for Taiwan to maintain its competitiveness and prosperity in the face of China's rise as a regional economic power," Chiang said.

As there are many "taishang" in China, Chiang said the KMT delegation will take advantage of the visit to discuss with relevant mainland authorities measures to protect the rights and interests of "taishang" and help them resolve problems.

Asked whether his mission will help arrange for KMT Chairman Lien Chan to visit China in June as reported by local news media, Chiang said commemoration of the KMT's revolutionary martyrs and exploration of cross-strait economic issues are the only two purposes of the visit.
If Lien truly intends to visit China, Chiang said he is not the one who would be arranging Lien's itinerary.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BEGINS REGISTRATION FOR PRIMARIES FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) potential candidates began registering Monday for primaries for the year-end city and county chief elections.
DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang said the party has the best democratic mechanism and he is sure the best candidates will be produced through the primaries.

Except for one city and five counties, registration for primaries in 17 locations began Monday. Among those six, the DPP will adopt a recruitment approach in Keelung City and Hsinchu County, while the party's nomination in Hualien, Taitung, Kinmen and Lienchiang counties will be put off until later.

Su said that there are quite a few outstanding aspirants in some cities and counties, and that he'll have to wait for the end of the registration on April 1 to see exactly how many people have registered. If more than one person is vying for the same post, the party will attempt to field a single candidate through negotiations with those involved; however, if all the hopefuls insist on staying the course, the party's candidate will be decided by the primary system.

On whether he has communicated with the party's ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, on the elections, Su said that the two parties would coordinate if possible, but he added that the local situation would have to be taken into account.

The DPP has set up a coordination team for the year-end elections. The members of the team include Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, DPP Central Standing Committee member Trong Chai, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang, DPP Policy Committee Executive Director Ker Chien-ming and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen.
Meanwhile, an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian has decided to resign to seek the DPP's nomination to run for Ilan County magistrate.

Lin Te-fu registered at the DPP's Ilan headquarters Monday, saying that the Presidential Office will understand his decision to leave as advisor to concentrate on getting the party's nod to run in the year-end election.

Lin said he has been unsure if he should throw his hat into the ring over the last couple of weeks since he has been aware that former Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan announced his resignation from his post earlier this year to return to his hometown in Ilan to run for his old post. Chen Ding-nan served for two consecutive terms as Ilan County magistrate between 1981 and 1989.

But more than 5,000 Ilan residents recently signed a petition to support Lin, and many of them think that a transition of power to the younger generation would be good for the party's future, Lin said.

On the other hand, Lo Wen-jia, a former chairman of the Council of Hakka Affairs registered to run for Taipei County magistrate Monday. Former DPP Legislator Lin Feng-hsi registered for the Taichung County magistrate race.
Former Legislator Tsao Chi-hung registered his intention to vie for Pingtung County magistrate.

As Presidential Office adviser Chiu Mao-nan has also announced his bid for the Pingtung County Magistrate nomination, Tsao said he hoped that the party would find a solution to the conflict of both wanting to run for the same position; however, if this is not possible, then he said he will respect the outcome of the primary vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OPEN TO SECOND MEETING WITH PFP CHAIRMAN: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is open to holding a second meeting with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, Secretary-General to the President Yu Shyi-kun said Monday.

President Chen is willing to meet Soong for a second time if the PFP chairman agrees to the idea and the president will fully respect Soong's opinion in this regard as to how, when and where the meeting should be arranged, Yu said.
The top presidential aide's remarks came after a large protest against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law ended peacefully Saturday in Taipei.

A large number of Taiwan people, mainly supporters of the independence-leaning ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, took to the streets in downtown Taipei to voice their objections to the law that arbitrates "non-peaceful means" to handle Taiwan should the island edge toward independence.
President Chen Shui-bian also participated together with his family in the rally.

Soong met President Chen Feb. 24 in a gesture of reconciliation between the governing party and the opposition camp in view of cross-Taiwan Strait tensions, annoying backers of the opposition "pan blue alliance" of the Kuomintang, the PFP and the New Party.

Soong and Chen made public a 10-point joint statement following the meeting, in principle focusing on Chen's stance not to change the official designation of the Republic of China and not to declare Taiwan independence during his term.
Against this backdrop, Soong was opposed to Chen's participation in Saturday's protest.

In light of the message released by the Presidential Office about a second Chen-Soong meeting, Soong pointed out that it would be better for them to meet again after both have clearly thought things over and come up with better ideas than the 10-point joint statement already issued.

Claiming that he is in no hurry to meet Chen again, Soong urged both the ruling and opposition parties to face up to the reality and engage in rational exchanges to meet public expectations now that Saturday's protest is over.

Commenting on the sensitive cross-strait relations, Soong expressed his belief that the 10-point joint statement offers the best solutions to cross-strait disputes and that they must be carried out to serve that end.

Confrontation is not the way to settle cross-strait problems and the people in Taiwan want parity, dignity and peace in its dealings with mainland China, he said, adding that this is something of which Beijing must be cognizant.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATIVE CAUCUS AGAINST FORMATION OF CROSS-STRAIT PANEL

TEXT.P: The time is not right for the Legislative Yuan to form a special task force to handle cross-Taiwan Strait affairs or to organize a delegation of lawmakers to visit China, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokesman said Monday.

"We would be falling into China's trap if the legislature were to send a delegation to Beijing shortly after the enactment of its so-called anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, " said Lai Ching-teh, the DPP's legislative whip.

Lai made the remarks after Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, while commenting on a media report that China would welcome a visit to Beijing by a Taiwan legislative delegation, said earlier in the day that the legislature will form a cross-party cross-strait affairs panel as soon as possible to discuss the feasibility of sending a delegation to China.

Noting that China has faced international pressure following its March 14 enactment of a law justifying its longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it thinks the democratic island is seeking formal statehood, Lai said any Taiwan political party that sends a delegation to Beijing at present would be tantamount to extending a helping hand to China.

"A visit to China by a party delegation or a cross-party legislative delegation at the moment could also mislead the international community into concluding that opposition to China's law is not Taiwan's mainstream public opinion. Such misinterpretation would hurt our national interests," Lai argued.
As to the formation of a legislative cross-party task force to handle cross-strait affairs, Lai said the time is also not opportune for the legislature to discuss such a topic.
"We should wait until after the cross-strait situation changes, " Lai said.

The media report about Beijing's welcome of a Taiwan legislative delegation to visit China coincided with the departure of a delegation of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers and party officials for a five-day visit to China that will take the delegation to three Chinese cities -- Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing. It marked the first time that the KMT, which one ruled all of China, has formally sent a delegation to visit China since it lost a loody civil war to the Chinese Communists in 1949.
According to the media report, Beijing authorities have also invited Taiwan's another opposition party --the People First Party -- to send a delegation to visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GO SLOW WITH DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT TRANSPORTATION LINKS: POLL

TEXT.P: Sixty-two percent of those surveyed recently said that the government should go slow with the opening of direct cross-strait passenger and cargo flights and assess the situation cautiously, a poll released Monday showed.

The poll, published by Wealth Magazine, also found that only 20 percent said that the sooner the government opens direct cross-strait transportation the better, while 10 percent said the government should never open it.

The monthly commissioned Focus Survey Research to conduct the survey by calling on adults over 20 years old between March 7 and 9. A total of 1,086 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of 2.97 percentage points.

Asked whether China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law will increase the possibility of a cross-strait war, 50.1 percent said it will not, while 39.1 percent said it probably or definitely a possibility.

Asked whether President Chen Shui-bian will open direct cross-strait transportation links during his term, which will run until 2008, around 42 percent said he will, while nearly 37 percent said he won't.

On which political figures are most suitable to serve as cross-strait negotiators, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou received the highest rating at 17 percent, followed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator and former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen at 16.7 percent, former Premier and Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research Chairman Vincent Siew at 14.6 percent, and People First Party Chairman James Soong at 14 percent.

On who from the private sector is most suitable to serve as the top negotiator with the mainland, Lee Yuan-tseh, president of Academia Sinica topped the list at 24.9 percent, followed by Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching at 20.8 percent, and Chinatrust Financial Holding Company Chairman Jeffrey Koo at 12.5 percent.

Despite China's passage of the Anti-Secession law, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence, 58.9 percent of those polled said that direct cross-strait transportation will be positive, compared with 22.8 percent who responded negatively.

Those who think direct cross-strait transportation will add employment opportunities accounted for 30.3 percent, compared with 54 percent who said it will cut the employment rate. Also, 20.8 percent said they would consider working in mainland China after direct cross-strait transportation links were established, compared with 77.3 percent who said they don't consider such a possibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHASING OUT NUKE POWER IN 10 YEARS `IMPOSSIBLE': ECONOMIS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Despite the government's firm resolve to make Taiwan a nuclear-free country, it will be impossible for it to phase out nuclear power in the next 10 years, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.
Ho made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan after opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao raised questions about the government's nuclear power policy during an interpellation session.

Ho said that no more new nuclear power plants will be licensed to be built in Taiwan and that the existing four nuclear power plants will be gradually phased out in line with a quota-based management system. But she added that phasing out nuclear power altogether will be impossible in a 10-year period.

Pointing out the operating costs of nuclear power plants is cheaper -- at NT$0.64 per 1000W/Hr -- than the NT$1.5 per 1000W/Hr cost of thermo power, Lai contended that the government's goal of making Taiwan nuclear-free will be hard to achieve in the short term as nuclear energy still accounts for 20 percent of the country's total power generation.

Lai said that the public is deeply concerned about much-discussed hikes in water and electricity rates, and he asked Taiwan Power Company officials to elaborate upon the company's policy in the face of rising running costs due to soaring prices of oil, coal and liquefied natural gas in the world market.
According to Taipower Chairman Lin Ching-chi, the company will follow government instructions in raising its rates.
Buffeted by increased spending on fuel, the state-run company suffered a deficit of more than NT$9 billion (US$285 million) in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST NEW IMMIGRANT LEARNING CENTER INAUGURATED IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: A new immigrant education center, the first of its kind in Taiwan, was inaugurated Monday in the northern county of Taoyuan, to help foreign spouses of local citizens adapt to Taiwan's lifestyle quickly and smoothly.
The new facility, located in the Chungchen Elementary School in Taoyuan's Pingjen City, will offer language and other training courses for the 37,000-plus foreign spouses residing in the county.

Addressing the inaugural ceremony, Vice Minister of Education Fan Sun-lu said the Ministry of Education selected Chungchen Elementary School as the site for the center mainly because Taoyuan County has the island's third-largest population of foreign spouses after Taipei County and Taipei City.
If the future, Fan said, the ministry will set up similar education centers in central and southern parts of the country.
Speaking on the same occasion, Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun said one out of every seven babies in Taoyuan is born into a family with a foreign spouse.

To meet the demand of those families, Chu said, the county government will spend NT$32 million annually on specially designed education programs for foreign spouses and their children in order to upgrade the quality of the local population and help new immigrants adapt to life in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PARLIAMENT URGED TO PASS RESOLUTION ON CHINA'S NEW LAW

TEXT.P: The government will continue to monitor whether the interests and security of Taiwan businessmen operating in China have been affected by Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law and will urge Canada's Parliament to adopt a resolution opposing the law, a senior official said Monday.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a Canadian parliamentary delegation.

Wu told his Canadian guests that a noted Taiwan business tycoon has already fallen victim to China's Anti-Secession Law that codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it thinks the democratic country is seeking formal statehood.

On Saturday, Hsu Wen-lung, founder of Taiwan's Chi Mei Group, published an open letter in a local newspaper apparently throwing his support behind Beijing's "one China" policy and the Anti-Secession Law. Hsu's letter came as a surprise and an embarrassment to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party administration because he was one of President Chen Shui-bian's big supporters during Chen's presidential bid in 2000.

Hsu's support for Chen made his China business a target of retaliation by the Beijing authorities and the publication of Hsu's letter coincided with a "million person" protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's ill-intentioned law.
Wu said he believes that Hsu is the first victim of the new law.

The nation's top China policy planner expressed his gratitude for the Canadian government's explicit opposition to China's attempt to use non-peaceful means to solve disputes across the Taiwan Strait.

Wu further said he hopes the Canadian Parliament can adopt a resolution opposing China's Anti-Secession Law in order to pressure the Beijing leaders to pay attention to the international community's common expectation that cross-strait issues be resolved peacefully.
Stressing that Taiwan is a liberal democracy, Wu said that the people of Taiwan enjoy freedom of choice and freedom of speech.

"The Anti-Secession Law stipulates that unification is the only option for the development of cross-strait relations. Such a provision ignores the Taiwan people's freedom of choice, " Wu said, adding that by dictating "unification" as the Taiwan people's "legal and sacred obligation, " Beijing has unilaterally altered the cross-strait status quo.
Worse still, Wu said, the new law justifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan starkly violates the United Nations charter that requires peaceful solution to all international disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BEGINS TO CARRY OUT 'NON-PEACEFUL MEANS' AGAINST TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: China has already begun to carry out its "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan under the newly passed Anti-Secession Law by forcing a noted Taiwan business tycoon to express support for the law, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san claimed Monday,
Chiu was referring to Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group, who published an open letter Saturday supporting Beijing's "one China" policy and praising the Anti-Secession Law.

Hsu said in the letter that he was "comfortable" with the newly enacted law because independence will only push Taiwan toward war and bring disaster to the people, but the Taiwan authorities described the letter more as a "deposition" crafted by Beijing and signed by Hsu.

Chiu said that the law has seriously hurt cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the feelings of the Taiwan people, pointing out that hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets Saturday to express their opposition to the law.
He urged China to address the Taiwan people's will, to stop immediately its damaging and provocative actions and to take effective measures to improve cross-strait relations.

On top of the Anti-Secession Law, Chiu went on, China has continued to push for several measures that have exacerbated cross-strait relations, including forcing Taiwan businessmen and Taiwan students in China to take sides politically in an attempt to stifle Taiwan's democratic development.
He noted that Beijing has forced some heads of Taiwan businessmen's associations in China, as well as Taiwanese students, to express support for the legislation.

Beijing also asked Hsu, who has major investments in China, to express his support for the Anti-Secession Law on the eve of the March 26 March for Democracy and Peace in an attempt to embarrass President Chen Shui-bian, because Hsu was a big supporter of Chen in his presidential bid in 2000.

Chiu said that Beijing's crude approach does not change the fact that the Anti-Secession Law is a war authorization law and will not change the fact that Beijing is sabotaging cross-strait relations, Chiu said.
He urged Beijing to address the will of the Taiwan people and adopt measures to redress its "wrong policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIELD BUSINESSMEN FROM TAIPEI-BEIJING POLITICAL FIGHT: PFP CHIEF

TEXT.P: It is a pity for Taiwan that its authorities cannot shield its people from being forced by Beijing to declare their support for "one China," opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong said Monday.

Soong made the statement after reports that Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chi Mei Corp. and a former senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian was speaking with tongue in cheek when he declared Friday that he favors Beijing's premise of "one China."
In order to protect Chi Mei's huge investment in China, the reports said, Hsu had no choice but to parrot the Beijing line.

As a long-time supporter of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Hsu sent shockwaves across the Taipei political landscape with his statement on the eve of a huge anti-China protest sponsored in part by the DPP.

Instead of blaming Hsu for betraying his homeland, DPP politicians expressed sympathy with the business tycoon and vented their anger on Beijing for using Taiwan businessmen to sell its "one China" policy.
Soong said the Taiwan authorities should feel shame for local businessmen's dilema that was crystallized by Hsu's reluctant pro-China statement.

In order to hold their own against foreign competitors, Soong said, Taiwan businessmen have had to ventured into the China market, but the government's mishandling of its ties with China has increased the tension between the two sides, leaving these businessmen on the horns of a dilemma.
Soong said Beijing should stop playing Taiwan businessmen against the Taiwan authorities and that the DPP should stop stirring up the tensions across the Taiwan Strait for its own political ends.

Both Beijing and Taipei should realize that their closely interwoven economic ties make it impossible for them to confront each other in politics. The sooner they wake up to this reality and formulate their policy accordingly, the better it will be for people on both sides of the strait, Soong said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HAVE MEDICAL EXCHANGES WITH SOUTH PACIFIC COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue medical diplomacy by selecting five hospitals to have exchanges with their counterparts in Palau, Kiribati, Tuvalu and Marshall Islands, the Department of Health (DOH) said Monday.
Chang Wu-hsiu, head of the DOH's bureau of international cooperation, said Taiwan will provide medical equipment and technology to these countries.
He noted that Taiwan has signed health cooperation agreements with these countries and plans to present the results in international conferences.

He stressed that the exchange project has no time limit and if the hospitals are willing, they can continue to have exchanges with those countries, with the government providing a maximum subsidy of NT$1.5 million (US$47,468) a year.

On media reports that President Chen Shui-bian has instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Cabinet-level DOH to establish a Taiwan chapter of the Global Fund, Chang said that he was not aware of any such development.

He noted that the Global Fund is a U.S.-led fund-soliciting group with its headquarters in Geneva. The aim of the fund is to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, and countries or organizations can submit their projects on combating these diseases and ask the fund for sponsorship.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOKOHAMA MAYOR CALLS ON TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Yokohama City Mayor Niroshi Nakada called on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Monday and expressed hope that the two cities can have more exchanges and work toward Asian development.
The Japanese mayor also said that China, Japan and Taiwan have to develop peaceful dialogue on China's emergence.

Ma noted that cross-Taiwan Strait relations entered a new stage with China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, but said that a crisis can also be a turning point and claimed that while tabs should be kept on China's development, there is no need to panic.

On the other hand, he said that China has miscalculated Taiwan's situation, and does not know that most Taiwan people want to maintain the status quo. If one understands this point, the situation in the Taiwan Strait will not deteriorate to military crisis, according to Ma.

Ma, who concurrently serves as a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, noted that another KMT vice chairman, P.K. Chiang, is currently leading a 34-member delegation on a visit to China and is expected to meet high-ranking officials there with the aim of lowering cross-strait tension.
It is expected that more high-ranking KMT officials will visit China in the latter half of the year, Ma said.
Nakada conveyed the hope of promoting substantial exchanges between the two cities, including educational and cultural exchanges.
He said he hopes to begin some programs when he comes to Taipei again to attend the Taipei International Healthy City Expo 2005 this autumn.

DOC.HEADLINE: 54 INJURED BY TURBULENCE ON EVA FLIGHT

TEXT.P: Fifty-four people aboard an EVA flight were injured when the plane ran into turbulence on its way from Taipei to Tokyo Monday, according to a statement issued by EVA headquarters in Taipei.

Among the injured were 44 passengers and 10 crew members. Twelve of them were admitted to local hospitals for treatment, where two were listed in serious condition. The others were put up in a hotel in Tokyo after treatment, said the statement.
The Airbus A330-200, carrying 251 passengers and 16 crew members, was headed for Tokyo from the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
Among the passengers, 140 were Taiwanese, 104 were Japanese, and seven were from other countries.
Although the plane landed safely at Tokyo's Narita Airport, its return flight to Taipei was canceled so that the aircraft could be examined.
Two hundred and fourteen passengers who had booked seats on the return flight were also put up in a Tokyo hotel to await another flight the following day, according to the statement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, March 29, or the 20th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Charles Wesley, British religious leader, dies at the age of 81. He wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing." His brother, John, founded Methodism in 1738.
1790: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, is born. He succeeded to the presidency while serving as vice president upon the death of incumbent William Henry Harrison.
1827: More than 10,000 mourners attend German composer Ludwig van Beethoven's funeral in Vienna. Beethoven died on March 26 at the age of 57.
1867: The British North America Act establishes the Dominion of Canada, made up of the provinces of Quebec, Ontario, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick.
1911: Revolutionists raid the Ching dynasty's Canton government office. After fierce fighting, the rebels' attempt to overturn the Ching dynasty fails. Seventy-two of them die and are later buried at Huanghuakang, a knoll outside Canton. They later become known as "the 72 Revolutionary Martyrs of Huanghuakang."
1940: Wang Ching-wei establishes a puppet regime in Nanking, eastern mainland China, which is recognized by Japan on Nov. 19.
1948: The Republic of China's first National Assembly under the ROC Constitution opens with 1,631 delegates attending.
1959: Barthelemy Boganda, president of the Central African Republic, is killed in a plane crash.
1965: The Republic of China's Foreign Ministry closes its Commissioner's Office in Macao.
1969: The Republic of China's ruling Nationalist Party (Kuomintang) holds its tenth national congress.
1973: U.S. troops pull out of South Vietnam.
1974: The U.S. spacecraft Mariner 10 takes the first close-up pictures of Mercury.
1976: Dr. Robben W. Fleming, president of the University of Michigan, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: Christian services are conducted in Taipei for Dr. Lin Yu-tang, with President Yen Chia-kan and Premier Chiang Ching-kuo attending.
1979: Uganda's dictator Idi Amin Dada is driven from Kampala, the capital of the African country, and later hides in the interior. His army is soon defeated by Tanzanian forces sent by President Julius Nyerere to aid the Ugandan rebels.
1989: Soviet citizens give the thumbs down to the ruling Communist Party in the first real political choice they have had since the 1917 Revolution.
1989: French president Francois Mitterrand inaugurates the vast glass pyramid, a work by Chinese-born American architect I.M. Pei, at the entrance to the Louvre in Paris.
1993: Direct air service begins between the Republic of China and the United Kingdom.
1993: Edouard Balladur, France's new conservative premier, takes over for outgoing socialist Pierre Beregovoy.
1993: Murray McCully, New Zealand's Minister of Customs and Associate Minister of Tourism, leads a nine-member delegation to Taipei. He is the first New Zealand minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1998: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approves the marketing of the anti-impotence drug Viagra.
1999: Joe Williams, legendary American jazz and blues singer, dies at the age of 80.
2000: The Republic of China's first lady Tseng Wen-hui lodges a slander suit against Legislators Hsieh Chi-ta and Elmer Feng of the New Party, and Tai Chi, a member of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party names incumbent Defense Minister Tang Fei of the Kuomintang as premier-designate.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man has put his personal conduct in order, what difficulty should he find in governing a country? But if a man has not put his personal conduct in order, how can he put in order the people of a country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER MARKS YOUTH DAY, OUTLINES VISION FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng marked Youth Day Tuesday by climbing Tatun Mountain in suburban Taipei with a group of students, where he outlined his vision for Taiwan, in particular the country's relations with mainland China.

Wang appealed for peace between Taiwan and China in light of recent cross-Taiwan Strait tensions, and he unveiled his intention to invite Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee under the National People's Congress -- China's parliament -- to visit Taiwan.

"Now that our people have gone to the mainland for a visit, it is time for theirs to come to Taiwan, " Wang said, referring to a Kuomintang (KMT) delegation led by party Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang that headed to the mainland a day earlier.

Chiang's trip to China, on the eve of the March 29 Youth Day, is widely believed to clear the way for a planned mainland visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in June. Lien is slated to step down from the party's top post in August.
The time is right for the legislature to invite Wu to Taiwan to help promote sound exchanges and usher in peace across the Taiwan Strait, Wang said.

Pointing out that a legislative task force is also expected to be set up soon to help the government address the fragile cross-strait situation, he said that the Legislative Yuan would also consider sending a mission to visit China.

Asked if he himself would be willing to visit China, the legislative speaker made it clear that he would only do so under the principles of parity and reciprocity and when the time is ripe and with the approval of the Taiwan people.

He called on the government to step up exchanges among students across the strait and suggested academic accreditation between the two sides given that more and more Taiwan students are heading to China to study.

Stressing that Youth Day is a time to remember the young people that sacrificed their lives to help found the Republic of China in the party's uprising against the Ching Dynasty, China's last empire, Wang also urged visionary young people to join the KMT at a time when it needs new blood for reform and to push the nation ahead.

Wang's visit to Tatun Mountain with students was seen by some as a move to prop up backing for his bid to vie for the KMT chairmanship, as his staunch rival, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-joeu, has also kicked off his campaign.
Both Wang and Ma are vice chairmen of the main opposition party. The KMT has five vice chairmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES TO TAKE ANTI-SECESSION LAW INTO ACCOUNT

TEXT.P: The government's new measures concerning cross-strait exchanges will take into consideration China's recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, the vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday.
Liu Teh-hsun made the remarks in a breakfast meeting with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) caucus in the Legislative Yuan.

The KMT legislative caucus invited officials from the MAC and the Council of Agriculture (COA) to report on the future course of cross-strait relations after hundreds of thousands of Taiwan people staged a march Saturday to protest against Beijing's newly passed law.

KMT Legislator Su Chi said that the law, which justifies an attack on Taiwan under certain conditions it sets, is part of Beijing's carrot-and-stick approach toward Taiwan. He said that while enacting the law, Beijing has also tried to lure Taiwan with various incentives, including offering to allow the island's agricultural products to be exported to the mainland.
Su asked what the government will do in addition to staging the March 26 protest.

Noting that the private sector hopes to resume cross-strait talks and that the MAC said last month that cross-strait talks can be based on the bilateral talks in Hong Kong in 1992, Su also asked about Beijing's response.
In reply, Liu said, the government will not restrict cross-strait exchanges that are conducive to lowering cross-strait tensions.

Those exchanges will basically continue in a regular manner, but the government will take Beijing's Anti-Secession Law into account when considering new measures regarding cross-strait exchanges, he added.
He also said that the government wants to forge national consensus on a resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
Another KMT legislator, Kuo Su-chun, said that the Canton Fair in Guangzhou will be staged in mid-April, with five pavilions featuring Taiwan agricultural products.

In addition to exempting Taiwan agricultural products from a 17 percent value-added tax, Guangzhou will also facilitate customs clearance, Kuo noted, saying that the government should support the participation of Taiwan agricultural products in the fair.
Chen Chieh, KMT caucus whip, claimed that the COA has not only not been supportive of this, it has even boycotted such a move.

COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan explained that China imposes tariffs of up to 16 percent on agricultural products, and that on top of this, it imposes a 17 percent value-added tax, making it difficult to export such products to China. In addition, China only allows 12 kinds of agricultural products in after quarantine, and its custom clearance is too slow, he continued.

The private sector on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can consult and communicate on the long custom clearance period, but the issues of tariffs and quarantine will have to be left for the governments of the two sides to discuss, Lee said.

He explained that the government will not take the initiative to support Taiwan's agricultural products to be exported to the mainland and that it has not blocked Taiwan agricultural products from taking part in the Canton Fair. The government just doesn't have the budget to support the marketing activity, he said.

He added that the custom clearance facilitation will only be temporary, and that a continuation of such incentives after the fair is more important, which he said will require talks between the two governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RULES OUT REPRISE OF 'NO HASTE' CROSS-STRAIT POLICY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday the government will continue to promote peaceful dialogue across the Taiwan Strait and will uphold its "active opening, effective managing" cross-strait investment policy instead of reinstating the previous "no haste, be patient" strategy.

Hsieh made the remarks at a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lai Shyi-bao asked the premier whether the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration will revise its cross-strait policy after China's recent enactment of its so-called anti-secession law and the massive protest march in Taipei last weekend against Beijing's "ill-intentioned" legislation.

While acknowledging that Beijing's new law has further strained cross-strait reltions, Hsieh said the DPP administration, after a comprehensive evaluation, has decided to adopt a peaceful and rational manner in dealing with the new challenge.

"Peace and rationality are the best strategy to forge domestic unity and counter China's threat. International news media have given prominent coverage to our 326 March for Democracy and Peace in protest against the anti-secession law. Major countries around the world have also denounced the law that codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan, " Hsieh said, adding that all these developments have proved the efficacy of the government's response strategy.
As to the future development of cross-strati relations, Hsieh said the government will adopt a wait-and-see attitude for the time being.

"In the wake of the anti-secession law, we must watch Beijing's follow-up moves before we hammer out our new cross-strait policy. Once we are sure that our national security is not at stake, we will continue to promote peaceful cross-strait dialogue, " Hsieh said, adding that in some cases, "silence is golden."

Asked whether the government is likely to reinstate the "no haste, be patient" cross-strait investment policy implemented by the previous KMT administration headed by former President Lee Teng-hui, Hsieh said the DPP administration would not reimpose such a policy because it couldn't resolve practical problems faced by Taiwan businesspeople.

Hsieh said Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group, one of Taiwan's largest private petrochemical and optoelectronics groups, was the first local entrepreneur to fall victim to the anti-secession law.
According to Hsieh, Hsu launched huge investments in China during the KMT administration when the "no haste, be patient" policy was in place.
Hsieh said that although the "no haste" policy set stringent restrictions on China-bound investments, enforcement had been lax, resulting in many flaws and problems.

"The DPP administration has replaced such an ineffective policy with an 'active opening, effective managing' one. We would rather adopt a more relaxed policy toward China-bound investment while strengthening enforcement. Therefore, we have no plan to drop the 'active opening' policy or to reinstate the 'no haste' policy, " Hsieh stressed.

On Saturday, Hsu Wen-lung, who retired from the Chi Mei Group chairmanship a year ago, published an open letter in a local newspaper apparently throwing his support behind Beijing's "one China" policy and the anti-secession law.
Hsu's letter came as a surprise and an embarrassment to the DPP administration because he was one of President Chen Shui-bian's big supporters during Chen's presidential bid in 2000.

Hsu's support for Chen has made his China business a target of retaliation by the Beijing authorities, and the publication of Hsu's letter coincided with a "one million people" protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's law. Many local people believe that Hsu was forced to issue the open letter in exchange for Beijing's favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Schiavo Called Beyond Saving. A spokesman for Terri Schiavo's parents said that their court battle to keep her alive was over, and as their daughter began her 10th day without food or water after her feeding tube was removed by judicial order, a family lawyer said she was past the "point of no return."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE MUST ACT ON EXPO 2008 FOR EVENT TO GO FORWARD: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan must act in a timely fashion to push through legislation for the Taiwan Exposition 2008; otherwise, there is the risk that the event would have to be canceled, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

Hsieh made the comment at the Legislative Yuan, where a group of lawmakers, magistrates and county council speakers from Taoyuan, Tainan and Chiayi, the three counties designated to jointly host the event, had gathered to try and get the ball rolling for needed legislation so that they can start making concrete plans for the expo.
If the legislation is stalled and cannot be cleared by April, the premier said, it would be better to just call off the whole thing to avoid international embarrassment.

The premier explained the necessity for a special statute at a legislative question-and-answer session a few days ago, saying the bill is designed to give local governments a freer hand in preparing and raising funds for the expo.
Although the expo is three years away, time is actually short as much needs to be done, including passing the statute and creating a special budget, he said.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said he supports the project and promised to help coordinate lawmakers and expo officials when asked to do so.

According to the central government's plan for Taiwan Expo 2008, the exhibition will run from May to September at the three counties along the High Speed Railway at an estimated cost of NT$19.5 billion spread over the next four years. The main exposition sites will be in Taoyuan and Tainan, with a supplementary site in Chiayi.

The event is expected to attract about 5.5 million visitors -- five million foreigners and 500,000 locals. It is projected to generate NT$5 billion in revenues, according to the organizer, the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Gov't meets on oil price strategy
Malacanang will return to the drawing board and craft new strategies to mitigate the impact of rising prices of oil products on the transportation sector and the public amid complaints that the R1 diesel discount is no longer enough.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Palace: VAT bill will pass
PRESIDENT Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo has not bothered to talk to her allies in the Senate to enlist their support for the value-added tax (VAT) measure, confident that Congress would pass it during the three-day special session this week, according to one of her advisers.
The Philippine Star: Employers open to 4-day workweek
The Employers Confederation of the Philippines (ECOP) yesterday expressed willingness to adopt the government's proposed four-day workweek, as long as companies would not be required to grant overtime pay.
The Manila Times: Arrest foiled car bombing in Metro
The arrest of a Muslim convert and the seizure of his explosives cache prevented a car bombing in Metro Manila, a military spokesman said Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWANESE KILLED OR HURT IN INDONESIA'S EARTHQUAKE: MOFA

TEXT.P: No people from Taiwan were killed or injured in the earthquake that rocked Indonesia's Nias Island around midnight, officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

According to the Republic of China representative office in Jakarta, no tourists from Taiwan or ROC nationals living in Indonesia lost their lives or were hurt in the disaster -- just a few months after the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunamis hit the same region last year, Lin Sung-huan, director-general of the Asia-Pacific Affairs Department said.

The Jakarta representative office has relayed the ROC government's condolences to the Indonesian authorities and will continue to provide the government with information about the latest situation for it to assess assistance needs, Lin said.

Initial reports said that the death toll could reach 2,000 but more recent assessments carried on wire reports put the dead at around 300 in the aftermath of the strong quake measuring a preliminary 8.7 on the Richter scale that jolted Nias Island in Indonesia at about 15 minutes past midnight. Cities in eastern Sumatra, including Medan, lost electricity after the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 87.5 points to close at 5,961.24.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 6,035.77 and hit a low of 5,961.24 during trading. A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$61.93 billion (US$1.94 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 3.1 percent, followed by textile stocks at 2.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.6 percent, banking and financial shares and cement stocks both at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.2 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.1 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 862 to 79, with 83 stocks remaining unchanged.
