DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Powerful earthquake hits Sumatra.
A powerful earthquake of measuring up to 8.5 on the Richer scale hit Indonesia's tsunami-devased Sumatra island late yesterday causing major panic and power black-outs, officers and report said.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Powerful earthquake rocks Sumatra.
A powerful earthquake measuring 8.2 on the Richter scale hit Indonesia's tsunami-devasted Sumatra island 11:09:37 pm on Monday, According the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.103 to close at NT$31.776.
A total of US$897 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.725 and fluctuated between NT$31.700 and NT$31.802.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April lost 81 points to close at 5,973, with 34,733 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved down 68 points to finish at 5,981, with 263 contracts traded, while June futures lost 69 points to finish at 5,956, with 57 contracts traded.
September futures lost 64 points to finish at 5,860, with 110 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 61 points to close at 5,870, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 6,054 for April, 6,049 for May, 6,025 for June, 5,924 for September and 5,931 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

April TE futures moved down 3.05 points to close at 228.55, with 4,020 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 2.9 points to finish at 228.4, with 25 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 2.45 points to close at 228.05, with one contract traded, while September TE futures moved down 2.95 points to close at 227.65, with five contract transaction. December TE futures lost 5.7 points to finish at 226.8, with one contract traded.

April TF futures lost 15 points to finish at 958.8, with 4,554 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved down 15.2 points to end at 959, with 124 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down 16 points to finish at 958, with one contract transaction, while December TF futures lost 7.8 points to end at 962.4, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September..

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTY'S VISIT TO M'LAND A STEP BACKWARD: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: A high-level Kuomintang (KMT) delegation currently in China to meet with Chinese Communists to discuss "reconciliation" is an " incredible" situation that turns back the clock 60 to 80 years, President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday.

President Chen made the remarks when he was asked about P. K. Chiang, a vice chairman of the KMT, who is leading a delegation on a visit to China ostensibly to help lower cross-strait tensions. The president was at the inauguration of a youth learning institute.

Chen pointed out that the biggest differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are not about separate rule; rather, they are about different living styles and systems, saying that it is a matter of democracy versus communism, and peace versus threats.

If Taiwan continues to fracture along party lines and the ruling and opposition parties continue to bicker, Taiwan will disintegrate without any outside force having to intercede, which he said is the biggest potential crisis facing Taiwan.
"Only with a unified Taiwan will cross-strait relations be stable," the president stressed.

He said that recently "someone" has traveled to the other side of the Taiwan Strait to push for "reconciliation between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party," a situation that seems out of place in time and harkens back to the days of 60 to 80 years ago when the two parties were trying to find some common ground.

Taiwan currently promotes democratic and constitutional rule, the president said, so it is "incredible" to see the KMT and the Chinese Communists talking. Chen said he wondered what sort of agreement would they were trying to sign.
He said that the Communist Party of China still keeps a firm grip on the government and the military, but Taiwan is already a democracy, and no one should put the party above the nation.

Noting that Tuesday is Youth Day, the president said that all young people should think about the fact that the nation is now entering the 21st century, and that a country can only progress by moving ahead, not by backpedalling 60, 70 or 80 years.
"Believe in the people and 'Taiwan first' will be the correct option," he said.

President Chen also took the chance to explain the significance of a massive march in which hundreds of thousands of Taiwan people took to the streets to protest China's recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law.

Chen noted that in the past, large rallies were aimed at underscoring democratic reforms, or were held to make a statement about certain figures or policies, which he said were internal affairs of the nation, but this time "we stood together" against the outside threat of Beijing's law, which codifies the use of force against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

The march was also significant because the motivational forces behind the event were the people and not political figures. This time, political figures, including himself, Premier Frank Hsieh and many government officials gave no speeches, Chen said.

The president also said that the 326 March for Democracy and Peace was a "bona fide international press conference," not "his own, one-man press conference, " adding that a million people marched to show the world their opposition to Beijing's law, and the international media saw, heard and reported this.

Chen was responding to earlier remarks by James Soong, who said before March 26 that if he were president, he would consider many options, including holding an international news conference, and that he would not have taken to the streets himself.
Chen said that at the march, "silence spoke volumes," and that " political figures have genuine strength and the most influence when they are not saying anything."

The president said the 326 march was also significant in that the theme, " democracy, peace and safeguarding Taiwan, " is the common language of the people of Taiwan, and one on which the ruling and opposition parties share the most common ground.
The march had no radical rhetoric and the participants used a "rational, peaceful and humble" manner to display their will, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES PERSONNEL STRUGGLE BEHIND KINMEN COMMANDER'S REPLACEMENT

TEXT.P: Ministry of National Defense officials denied Tuesday a report suggesting that a personnel struggle was behind the recent replacement of the chief military officer on the frontline island of Kinmen.

Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh told legislators that Kinmen Defense Command Commander Cha Tai-chuan, who suffers from Meniere's syndrome, was transferred from the position so that he could receive health exams in Taiwan.
Meniere's syndrome is a condition of excess pressure accumulation in the inner ear.
Huo said the ministry will arrange another suitable position for Cha if he is physically able to resume his duties.

The ministry announced a day earlier that Cha's position was to be assumed by Army Deputy Commander-in-Chief Chia Fu-yi for the time being because Cha had been recalled to Taiwan for medical treatment.
However, a local daily reported Tuesday that a personnel struggle could have been the true reason behind Cha's replacement.
According to military spokesman Liu Chih-chien, Cha returned to Taiwan last week and is currently undergoing comprehensive examinations at Tri-Service General Hospital.

Liu said the ministry's decision to transfer Cha from his original position was made out of good intentions, as the position requires whomever is in charge to remain on standby at all times to deal with any contingencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATION VISITS HUANGHUAGANG MAUSOLEUM OF 72 MARTYRS
DOC.DATELINE: Guangzhou, March 29 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A 34-member delegation from Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) made a historic visit to the Huanghuagang Mausoleum of 72 Martyrs in suburban Guangzhou in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong Tuesday.

The delegation, headed by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who is also a legislator-at-large, paid tribute to the 72 revolutionary martyrs who died trying to overthrow the last Qing dynasty in the Huanghuagang Uprising prior to the establishment of the first republic in Asia -- the Republic of China.
A large crowd of Chinese citizens lined up to welcome the arrival of the KMT delegation at the cemetery. Nearly 300 Chinese, Taiwanese and foreign journalists covered the event.
Led by Chiang, all delegation members bowed three times before the monument commemorating the Huanghuagang martyrs. They also observed a moment of silence.
Later on, the delegation met with Taiwanese businessmen operating in the Guangdong area. In the afternoon, the delegation flew to Nanjing.

On Wednesday, the delegation is scheduled to visit the cemetery of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who founded the KMT and led the revolution to establish the ROC. The delegation will meet with Nanjing officials and Taiwan businessmen operating in Jiansu province before departing for Beijing.

The delegation's Beijing itinerary has not been revealed. According to reports, the delegation is expected to meet with Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, before concluding its Beijing visit and returning to Taipei via Hong Kong Friday.

The delegation arrived in Guangzhou Monday afternoon. Chiang and all delegation members then met with Guangdong Provincial Governor Huang Huahua and presidents of major Taiwanese trade associations in the province to discuss matters of mutual interest. In the evening, Huang hosted a dinner in honor of all delegation members.
Chiang's mission is the first official KMT delegation ever to visit China since the party, which once ruled all of China, lost a bloody civil war to the Chinese Communists and fled to Taiwan in 1949.
Chiang said after his arrival in Guangzhou that commemoration of the KMT's revolutionary martyrs and exploration of cross-strait economic issues are the only two purposes of the visit.

The visit came at a sensitive time when many Taiwan citizens are angry at China's enactment of a law justifying an attack on Taiwan under certain conditions it sets. In Taipei, pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmakers labeled the visit as a "trip of kowtowing to communist foes."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-BLUES' AGAIN BLOCK U.S. ARMS BILL FROM LEGISLATIVE AGENDA

TEXT.P: Once again, the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party Tuesday block a bill onto the legislative agenda for the purchase of a controversial package of weaponry from the United States.

The KMT and the PFP caucuses of the legislatures said that a special budget for the major arms procurement would increase the national debt, and so should not be referred to the National Defense Committee for review.

This was the second time the bill has been blocked from being put on the legislature's agenda since the Cabinet marked down the ceiling price for the procurement package from the original NT$610.8 billion to NT$480 billion (US$15.38 billion) because a plan to build submarines in Taiwan was dropped, and because the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. dollar.

The Cabinet first proposed a similar bill for the purchase of six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States last year, but it, together with a proposed special budget for the procurement, was shelved by the legislature owing to opposition from the majority "pan-blue alliance."
After the proposed statutes and budget were killed at the end of the last legislative term in January this year, the Cabinet had to re-submit them to the new legislature that started Feb. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TO LAUNCH EXPEDITION IN MAY TO DEFEND TIAOYUTAIS

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong-based Action Committee for Defending the Diaoyuislands (ACDD) is scheduled to launch an expedition to the Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea next month to assert Chinese sovereignty over the island group, ACDD Chairman David Ko said Tuesday.
During an telephone interview with CNA, Ko said that his committee has been planning this for a long time and that raising money is the major task at the current stage.

"Our target is one million Hong Kong dollars, which will be used to purchase boats to carry activists from all corners of the earth, " Ko told CNA. Ko said that as far as he knows, many activists from China, Taiwan, the United States and Canada have decided to take part in the sovereignty defending trip slated for mid-May.

Meanwhile, the ACDD is also launching an online signature campaign among ethnic Chinese to urge the United Nations to reject Japan's bid for a permanent seat in the U.N. Security Council, Ko said, adding that over 2,000 signatures have been received so far.

Japan first claimed the Tiaoyutai Islands in 1895, but China and Taiwan insisted that the islands have been Chinese territory for centuries. The uninhabited island group, known as the Senkaku Islands to the Japanese and called the Diaoyutais by China, is located some 102 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan.
China ceded the Tiaoyutai Island group to Japan in 1895 at a time when the last Chinese imperial dynasty -- the Qing dynasty -- was in sharp decline and losing territory to aggressive foreign powers.

After World War II, the islands were put under U.S. control, at which time the ROC government demanded their return. In 1972, however, the United States returned the islands to the Japanese government -- a decision that governments and patriotic groups on both sides of the Taiwan Strait continue to protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRWAYS OPENS KAOHSIUNG-JEJU, SOUTH KOREA ROUTE

TEXT.P: UNI Airways Corp. made its maiden flight between Kaohsiung and Jeju Island, South Korea Tuesday, according to a spokesman for the Taipei-based carrier.

The opening of the route marks a big step for UNI Airways in its ambition to build a comprehensive network in North and Southeast Asia out of Kaohsiung, the spokesman said, adding that the service is most convenience for people living in southern Taiwan.
The route was inaugurated with 133 passengers on board an MD/90 airplane.
UNI Airways already plies the Bangkok, Bali and Hanoi routes from Kaohsiung.

The carrier will run the Kaohsiung-Jeju route on a twice weekly basis every Tuesday and Saturday. The flight will depart from Kaohsiung at 10: 00 a.m. and return from Jeju at 2: 10 p.m. A one-way trip takes about three hours and 10 minutes.
In line with the launch of the new route, UNI Airways is also promoting a special four-night package tour of Jeju Island.

Jeju Island is a popular destination for honeymooners and has attracted a large number of tourists from Taiwan in recent years due to its scenery. Also, a number of locations on the island have featured in various South Korean soup operas that are popular in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'YOUTHHUB' WEB SITE OPENS AS YOUTH-ORIENTED PORTAL

TEXT.P: A Web site designed by the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) exclusively for young people opened Tuesday, with the inauguration ceremony jointly presided over by Premier Frank Hsieh and NYC Chairwoman Cheng Li-chiun.
Shouting "Youth Hub, Give Me A Hug" together with everyone at the ceremony, Hsieh used the Web site -- www.youthhub.net.tw -- to search financial management and insurance information.
According to Cheng, "youthhub" is a Web site integrating various services for young people and aims at giving them quick and easy access to various information they need.

Cheng said that through the Web site, young people can get various information concerning education, health, employment and business creation, sports and tourism, participation in public affairs, interpersonal relations, social welfare services, financial management and insurance, as well as laws and human rights.
In addition, the Web site also has a discussion zone, where young people can exchange viewpoints on various issues, thereby boosting exchanges among the youth, Chen went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT COMMISSION APPROVES THREE CHINA EXPANSION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan companies' China investment expansion projects were approved Tuesday by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs. They were worth a combined US$51.5 million.

Nan Ya Plastic Corp. was given the go-ahead to inject US$29.5 million into its subsidiary in Kunshan, Jiangsu province; Quanta Computer Inc. will expand its investment in Shanghai by US$16 million; and Hey Song Corporation will add US$6 million to its Suzhou branch, the commission said.

Between Feb. 16 and March 17, 247 investment projects to China worth US$358.44 million were given a green light. There were also 93 investment projects worth under US$200,000 apiece, with a combined value of some US$8.4 million.
Commission officials also approved four investment projects to Taiwan initiated by foreign investors and overseas Taiwanese businesses. Their combined value was US$26.26 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOSE ON DPP PAYROLL GET THREE PERCENT PAY RAISE

TEXT.P: Officials working for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will get a pay raise of 3 percent, effective April 1, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said Tuesday.
This will be the first raise for DPP officials since 2000.
Lee noted that government employees got a pay raise in 2001, but DPP workers have not had one since 2000.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang discussed the matter with Ker Chien-ming, head of the party's financial committee, and it was decided that the party would appropriate an additional budget to pay for the raises.

Cheng Wen-tsang, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, explained the situation amid reports that the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT) , is continuing to try to streamline the party because of financial problems.

Cheng said that his party couldn't be compared to the KMT in terms of the number of party members or the size of their offices, noting that the DPP has only around 180 officials. The KMT has about 1,600 on its payroll.

The DPP Central Standing Committee passed the additional budget proposal of NT$20 million (US$62,893) Tuesday. In addition to funneling around NT$4.7 million into the pay raises, the rest will be used in celebration of the 10th anniversary of the party's women's department and the formation of another committee.
DPP workers were elated to hear about the pay raise, Cheng said, adding that they often work for the party without taking off holidays, and everyone was happy to have some reward.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP SUPPORT INVITING CHINESE PARLIAMENT CHAIR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers expressed their support Tuesday for Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng's proposal to invite his Chinese counterpart, Wu Bangguo, to visit Taiwan.

Wang said earlier in the day that with the approval of legislators from across party lines, the legislature will send a delegation to visit China and invite Wu, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China, to visit Taiwan in an effort to enhance cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.

KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh said Wang's proposal will help temper cross-strait tensions following the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by China earlier this month and the massive demonstration against the law in Taiwan last week.
Chen said the legislature has an obligation to promote peace across the Strait to protect the interests of China-based Taiwanese businessmen.
PFP legislative caucus convener Chen Chih-pin said his party supports any efforts that are helpful to cross-strait peace.
Legislators from the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , however, strongly opposed the idea of inviting Wu to visit Taiwan.

According to TSU legislative caucus convener Lo Chih-ming, Wu's visit would stain the Legislative Yuan because the National People's Congress of China was the "executioner" who passed the Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan.
If Beijing retracts the law to show its goodwill to Taiwan, the TSU will support Wu's visit under the principles of equality and dignity, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESPONDS TO INDONESIAN EARTHQUAKE QUICKLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's official mission and private organizations in Indonesia responded quickly after hearing that a powerful earthquake hit northern Sumatra, Indonesia, shortly before midnight Monday.

The Taipei Economic and Trade Office In Jakarta sent officials to Medan Tuesday, hoping to get into the hardest-hit area of Nias, a small Indonesian island close to the epicenter of the magnitude-8.7 earthquake, before returning to Taipei to report to the government what kinds of assistance are urgently needed.
Wire reports said that hundreds of buildings in Nias had collapsed and that injuries were likely because the earthquake struck close to midnight and many people were in their homes.

The Indonesian chapter of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, which was one of the first charity groups to come to rescue and relief in the wake of the Dec. 26 tsunami disaster that affected many countries in Southeast Asia and South Asia, has also begun to send relief materials to Nias, while the Chinese Christian Relief Association and World Vision Taiwan have also contacted their Indonesian counterparts to see what kind of assistance they can provide.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND CONTINUES PUSHING FOR VOLUNTARY MILITARY SERVICE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: In efforts to promote a volunteer-based military, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) is planning to enlist a total of 6,561 volunteers this year, a MND official said Tuesday.
Deputy Defense Minister Michael Tsai said that the 2005 enlistment program will be completed in four phrases and that more than 3,000 have already volunteered.

Tsai made the remarks at the MND recruitment center, where the ministry carried out a publicity drive for the system. Some lawmakers wearing military uniform and camouflage helped tout the military's efforts to gradually replace conscripts with a volunteer force.
Until this year, no recruiting drive has been launched and no tests have been held to screen applicants for military service.

Under the new recruiting system, an average monthly wage of NT$27,750 will be paid to each volunteer, Tsai said, adding that besides the salary, there is other compensation that is expected to boost the monthly earnings to over NT$30,000.
A wide range of vocational training courses are also available to assist soldiers to apply for professional certification during their military service term, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REAFFIRMS GOVERNMENT'S ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT ENGAGEMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday he supports civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, but he stressed that any cross-strait engagements involving the exercise of public authority must be handled by the government.

Hsieh was responding to inquiries about his view on an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) delegation's current visit to China, which has been labeled by the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union as a "trip of kowtowing to the KMT's old communist foes."
The premier said he is not opposed to political parties or private groups organizing delegations to visit China to boost mutual understanding and forge rapprochement.
However, he insisted that any cross-strait dialogue, consultations or agreements involving the exercise of public authority cannot take effect without the participation of the government.

As to whether the delegation, headed by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, is likely to conspire with the Chinese communists to boycott Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, Hsieh said he believes Chiang will keep in mind Taiwan's overall national interest while engaging with the Beijing authorities.

"I don't know what Chiang's purpose is during his China visit. But as far as I know, he is a decent man. I believe he will take into account national interests and the Taiwan people's feelings during his China trip," Hsieh said.

Traveling at the head of a 34-member KMT delegation, Chiang, also a legislator-at-large who once served as minister of economic affairs and Legislative Yuan deputy speaker, departed Taipei Monday for a five-day visit to China to pay tribute to KMT martyrs and meet with Taiwan businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang."

As the visit comes at a sensitive time when many Taiwan citizens are angry at China's enactment of a law justifying an attack on Taiwan under certain conditions, local pro-independence activists have bashed the trip as "surrendering to the old enemy."
Fielding questions during a legislative interpellation session, Hsieh said the KMT, which once ruled all of China, has a historic feud with the Chinese Communist Party.
"It might not be bad for Chiang to head a delegation to visit the mainland to seek reconciliation between the two parties, " Hsieh said sarcastically.

After losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese communists in 1949, the KMT fled to Taiwan and ruled the island for 55 years until May 2000. It lost the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections but still manages to control a slim majority in the legislature thanks to its "pan-blue alliance" ally of the People First Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Hundreds Feared Dead After South Asian Quake.
Despite warnings, no tsunami has yet been reported after massive 8.7 earthquake strikes Indonesia's blighted Sumatran coast.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Powerful Quake Jolts the Seabed Off the West Coast of Indonesia
The earthquake sent a ripple of panic across a region still traumatized by the destruction from a deadly tsunami three months earlier.
The Wall Street Journal: Finally, an AIG Without Hank
Maurice R. "Hank" Greenberg, the insurance industry's most powerful figure for decades, decided to retire as nonexecutive chairman of American International Group Inc., succumbing to mounting law-enforcement scrutiny of the company he built.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICS CANNOT RESIST `PEOPLE'S DIPLOMACY': PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that health, medical care and disease control know no boundaries and claimed that "people's diplomacy" is something that cannot be blocked by political power.
Chen urged the international community to pay attention to what he described as "this trend of world development."
Chen made the remarks during a meeting with Lee W. Graber, president of the World Federation of Orthodontists.

Chen noted that Taiwan was excluded when an organization for orthodontists in the Asia-Pacific region was established in 2000 in Tokyo, but pointed out that the people of Taiwan are still involved in various international activities.
According to Chen, academic exchanges should be benevolent, disinterested and foresighted. There should not be barriers between different races and nationalities in the medical field, he added.

Chen said ideological and political considerations should not be allowed to limit academic exchanges or it will go against the spirit of the global village and hinder the progress of the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP QUESTIONS RATIONALE OF KMT'S 'CHINA RUSH'

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative whip questioned Tuesday the rationale of senior opposition Kuomintang (KMT) leaders' keen interest in making what he called "kowtowing" trips to China.

"It's outrageous that top KMT leaders are enthusiastic about visiting China at a time when many Taiwan citizens are angry at China's enactment of a law justifying an attack on Taiwan under certain conditions," said Chen Ching-chun, the DPP legislative caucus secretary-general.

Chen made the remarks after Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT vice chairman, said earlier in the day that the opposition-controlled legislature will soon form a special task force to handle cross-Taiwan Strait affairs that will organize a cross-party delegation to visit China.

With the consent of the ruling and opposition parties, Wang said, he himself would also be willing to visit China "with dignity." Moreover, Wang went on, the legislature plans to invite Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of China's rubber-stamp parliament -- the National People's Congress -- to visit Taiwan.
Responding to Wang's statements, Chen noted that a KMT delegation headed by another of the party's vice chairmen, P.K. Chiang, is currently on a visit in China.

"To the best of my understanding, KMT Chairman Lien Chan is planning to visit China this summer. And now Wang voices his interest in traveling across the Taiwan Strait. It's unthinkable that KMT leaders are crazy about visiting China at this sensitive moment, " Chen said.

Noting that the cross-strait issue is one of the government's most important public policies, Chen said forging a domestic consensus is crucial in dealing with the challenges posed by China's Anti-Secession Law.

"Now is not the right time to visit China. I'm afraid that the KMT's 'China rush' might be misinterpreted by the international community as 'Taiwan supporting the Anti-Secession Law.' Should that be the case, our national interest would be at stake," Chen pointed out.

He further questioned why, if the KMT can reconcile with communist China, it cannot respond to the DPP's repeated calls for domestic inter-party reconciliation. " I simply cannot understand why the KMT chairman would not meet with President Chen Shui-bian while thinking about meeting with Beijing's leaders," he added.

As to Wang's proposal to invite the Chinese parliamentary head to Taiwan, Chen said the DPP has consistently looked forward to peaceful cross-strait exchanges. Nevertheless, he said, a domestic consensus on the issue must be forged before sending out any invitation to senior Chinese officials.
Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said the KMT delegation's visit to China comes at the wrong time.
While the DPP welcomes cross-strait civilian exchanges, Lee said, the KMT delegation's visit at this crucial moment could have an adverse impact on Taiwan.

For one thing, he said, the KMT's move hurts Taiwan's image as a country with solid internal unity and might even mislead the international community into thinking that Taiwan has given into China's Anti-Secession Law.

Worse still, Lee said, it could give China the wrong impression that Taiwan no longer insists on its sovereign status or protests China's military threat in the wake of the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law.

Responding to the DPP's scathing bash, a KMT spokesman said the KMT, as Taiwan's largest opposition party, is obligated to help promote peaceful cross-strait exchanges. The KMT delegations's current visit is part of the party's efforts to help forge cross-strait rapprochement for benefits of people on both sides of the strait, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY `BECOMES STRATEGIC THINKING OF U.S.': FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Recent remarks by U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice indicate that democracy has "become the strategic thinking of the United States in dealing with the rise of China, " according to a report submitted Tuesday to the Legislative Yuan by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Under these circumstances, Taiwan should continue to promote the values of democracy and freedom to the international community and highlight its efforts and goodwill in maintaining cross-Taiwan Strait peace in order to secure a favorable position in the Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular relations, the report suggests.

The report, which analyzes relations between Taiwan, the United States and China after Rice's recent visit to Beijing, is set for presentation during the legislature's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee on Wednesday.

It notes that during her Asian trip earlier this month, Rice repeatedly stressed the values of democracy and freedom and said the democratic development of Taiwan is a positive message for China's future political development.

Rice also urged China to respect human rights and practice freedom and democracy as soon as possible, and added that Washington will enhance its alliances with Japan, South Korea and India, it points out.

The report says that as shown from Rice's remarks, the "one China" policy, the three communiques between Washington and Beijing and the Taiwan Relations Act remain the basics of the United States' cross-strait policy, while the North Korea issue and China's Anti-Secession Law are the two main reasons for uncertainty.

The United States is expected to maintain close consultations with China to facilitate the reopening of six-party talks on the nuclear problem in North Korea, and Taiwan will keep close watch of the situation, the report says.
Washington is also deeply concerned about the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by China and its continued military buildup, it adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: 5 CHILDREN FROM FOREIGN IMPOVERISHED FAMILIES VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Five children from impoverished families in South Africa, Colombia and Rwanda are currently on a pleasure trip in Taiwan on the sponsorship of World Vision Taiwan (WVT) , a spokesman for the charity group said Tuesday.

The five children visited a traditional children's amusement park in the central city of Taichung Tuesday. Under the guidance of park staff, they played traditional folk games such as spinning tops and stilt-walking.

The WVT spokesman said the organization arranged the visit mainly because it wanted to offer the children an opportunity to get a taste of life in Taiwan. The visit is the first overseas trip for all the children, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE RISES 47.3 PERCENT IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: The volume of trade between Taiwan and China in January grew 47.3 percent from the same period of a year earlier to US$5.81 billion, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Tuesday.
The figure accounted for 18.9 percent of the total value of the island's foreign trade during the same month, up 1.3 percent from the year-earlier level, according to BOFT-released statistics.

Taiwan's exports to China in January rose 42.3 percent year-on-year to US$4.12 billion, the highest single-month level in history, accounting for 27 percent of the island's total exports, the statistics show.
Meanwhile, imports from China increased 61.1 percent to US$1.68 billion, making up 10.9 percent of the total imports by Taiwan, in comparison with 8.9 percent a year earlier.
As a result, Taiwan recorded a trade surplus of US$2.44 billion, up 31.6 percent from the year-earlier level, according to the tallies.

BOFT Deputy Director-General Wu Hsin-hua said Taiwan's imports from and exports to China in January posted a growth of higher than 40 percent, mainly due to a lower comparison basis because last year's Lunar New Year holiday was in January.

Wu attributed the highest single-month export level mainly to a handsome increase in exports of organic chemicals, steel and related products, and plastics and related products, as well as oil products triggered by continuing hikes in international oil prices and great demand from China.
Wu said it is worth noting that China's top three import sources in January were Japan, South Korea and Taiwan in that order, with South Korea replacing Taiwan as China's second-largest supplier.
China's imports from South Korea hit US$5.19 billion, higher than the US$5.07 billion-worth of imports from Taiwan, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PROMISES NO BACKTRACKING ON CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC POLICY

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Tuesday that the government's cross-Taiwan Strait economic policy will not backtrack on the "no haste, be patient" policy, despite the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by China.
In a speech to the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, Wu pledged that the government will carry out the conclusions of the economic development conference of 2001.

He pointed out that the Anti-Secession Law attempts to unilaterally change the cross-strait status quo in which Taiwan and China are independent of each other and hurts the interests of the Taiwan people, who were prompted to voice their protest through a massive peaceful demonstration last week.

Owing to the frequent economic exchanges between Taiwan and China, a number of issues, such as imports of Chinese commodities, dual taxation and intellectual property rights protection, are pending negotiations, Wu noted.
Also, the launch of cross-strait charter cargo flights and direct transportation links are two other major issues that require negotiations between the two sides, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILL MEET LEGISLATURE'S REQUESTS WITHIN LAW: AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will yield to whatever requests the legislature make as far as they are within the law, the president's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, said Tuesday.

In reply to journalists' questions about the president's response to the legislature's request for him to re-nominate appointees for members of the Control Yuan, Yu said Chen's staff are studying the law governing the issue.

However, he was reserved about the legality of the legislature's request, saying that while one of the ways to determine the constitutionality of the request is to appeal for an interpretation of the Constitution by the Council of Grand Justices, the method is too slow to solve the problem facing the country.
Another way to break through the impasse between the legislature and the president would be negotiations, Yu said without elaborating.

The issue was caused by the preceding legislature, which turned down Chen's requests to approve his nominees for members of the Control Yuan and asked the president to replace en masse the nominees who, they claimed, fail to live up to public expectations for members of the Control Yuan.
The president refused, putting him at loggerheads with the legislature over the issue until the term of the legislature expired in February.

Instead of dying down with the end of the preceding legislature, the issue was rekindled with the swearing-in of the new legislature, which also refused to act on the president's nomination on the grounds that it was submitted to the last legislature.
In order to have the current legislature affirm the nominees, they claimed in a letter to the president Monday, Chen has to present his nominations to the legislature again.
Yu said he did not see why the president should re-nominate the appointees with the election of the new legislature, as the new legislature is supposed to finish the jobs left by its predecessor.
The issue should be solved through negotiations between the President's Office and the Legislative Yuan in consultation with the related laws, Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVITING CHINA NPC CHAIRMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN NOT VIABLE: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called on Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng Tuesday to make careful deliberations before extending an invitation to Taiwan to the chairman of China's rubber-stamp National People's Congress (NPC) amid escalating tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

William C.T. Lai, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, made the appeal after Wang said earlier in the day that with the approval of legislators from across the political spectrum, he will lead a delegation to visit China and invite NPC Chairman Wu Bangguo to visit Taiwan in an effort to enhance cross-Taiwan Strait interaction.
It is inappropriate for the legislature to send a delegation to China and invite Wu to Taiwan because China has recently enacted the Anti-Secession Law targeting the island, Lai explained.

"If we extend an invitation to Wu at present, " Lai said, "it would relay an erroneous message to the international community that Taiwan's legislature does not care about Beijing's enactment of the controversial law."

The Anti-Secession Law passed March 14 provides Beijing with the so-called "legal right" to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan if Beijing decides the island is moving toward formal independence. Officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council have slammed it as tantamount to a "blank check" authorizing China to use force against Taiwan.
Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) lawmakers expressed their support for the proposal made by Wang, who is also a KMT vice chairman.

KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh said Wang's proposal will help temper cross-strait tensions following the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by China earlier this month and the massive demonstration against the law in Taiwan last week.
Chen said the legislature has an obligation to promote peace across the Strait to protect the interests of China-based Taiwanese businessmen.
PFP legislative caucus convener Chen Chih-pin said his party supports any efforts that are helpful to cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIP IMPLANTS HELP COMA VICTIMS REGAIN CONSCIOUSNESS

TEXT.P: Six out of 12 patients in comas regained consciousness after being implanted with a chip in their central nervous systems, Liu Jung-dung, a neurologist at the Chung Shan Medical University Hospital in Taichung City, central Taiwan said Tuesday.

Liu said at a news conference that the chips, implanted by him into the patients' spinal cords between skull and neck, were connected to pulse producers implanted in the patients' chests, conveying pulses to stimulate and revive their brain cells.

Although all of the patients had been in deep comas for four months to seven years before the treatment, six of them regained consciousness several months after the implantation, and three of them who met the press at Tuesday's new conference had regained some speaking ability.

Liu said the experiment, started in February 2004, has found that the procedure is more effective for patients who went into a coma because of brain damage and have been in a coma for only a few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, March 30, or the 21st day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1746: Francesco Goya, Spanish court painter, is born. Over the course of his career, his works grew increasingly gloomy, especially those inspired by the French invasion of Spain.
1814: Britain and its allies march into Paris in triumph against Napoleon Bonaparte.
1842: Ether is used as an anesthetic for the first time, by American Surgeon Dr. Crawford Long.
1853: Vincent van Gogh, Dutch Post-Impressionist painter driven by insanity to suicide, is born. He sold only one of his paintings during his lifetime. "Sunflowers," one of his works, fetched a record price of 24.75 million pounds (US$39.7 million) at auction in London on March 30, 1987.
1855: The Taiping rebellion ends in China.
1856: The Crimean War, a bloody three-year conflict between Europe and Russia, ends with today's signing of the Treaty of Paris.
1867: The United States acquires Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1870: The U.S. Congress adopts the 15th amendment to the Constitution, stipulating that basic human rights cannot be denied on the basis of race or color.
1936: The construction of Taipei's Sungshan Airport is completed.
1940: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares the Nanking puppet regime, led by Wang Ching-wei, illegal.
1942: U.S. President Roosevelt announces establishment of the Pacific War Council in Washington. The council comprises China, the United States, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Canada and the Netherlands.
1955: In order to prevent mainland China from attacking Taiwan by force, U.S. President Dwight D. Einsenhower announces that the United States will assist in defending Kinmen and Matsu, two military outposts of the Nationalist government located opposite mainland China's Fujian province.
1972: Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Dr. Lorenzo Guerrero arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1973: The last U.S. prisoner of war is released and the last U.S. soldier withdraws, ending the U.S. military's role in Vietnam.
1974: A mainland jetliner arrives in New York in what is described as the first civilian flight from the Chinese mainland to the United States.
1976: A 25-member mission of the Belgium-ROC Friendship Society headed by the society's vice president, William Ugeux, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1976: Twenty-two Taiwan technicians leave for Saudi Arabia to build a sewage system in Jiddah.
1976: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the "Rehabilitation and Protection Act" to help released convicts re-enter society.
1978: Taiwan's first nuclear power plant begins operation with a capacity of 636,000 kilowatts.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan is wounded in an assassination attempt as he walks out of a Washington hotel. He is rushed to George Washington Hospital, where a bullet, which passed inches from his heart, is removed from his lung.
1990: Estonia's Parliament declares the Soviet Union an occupying power and pledges to seek full independence.
1992: The United Nations starts its efforts to return nearly 3.37 million refugees to Cambodia.
1998: Russian leader Boris Yeltsin says he will not run in the presidential election in 2000.
2000: Tse-chen Hsu, a 13-year-old genius pianist from Taiwan who was born blind, receives the Rosemary Kennedy International Young Soloists Award for 2000 at John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington D.C.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton reiterates his support for the "one China policy" and stresses that differences between mainland China and Taiwan must be resolved peacefully.
2001: The Association of World Citizens (AWC), a non-governmental organization, formally inaugurates Friday its 11th World Citizen Congress at Taipei's Grand Hotel, with representatives from domestic and foreign civic groups attending the event.
2004: The Republic of China cuts off diplomatic ties with the Commonwealth of Dominica.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If I cannot find equitable and reasonable men to have to do with, upon necessity I would choose men of enthusiastic or even fanatical character. Enthusiastic men are zealous and there are always limits which fanatical men would not pass."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO ACQUIESCE IN TAIWAN'S WHA BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 29 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing should acquiesce in Taiwan's bid for World Health Assembly (WHA) observer status as a means to mend the new rift in cross-Taiwan Strait relations caused by China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, a think-tank China hand said Tuesday.

Alan Romberg, senior associate and director of the East Asian Program of the Henry Stimson Center, said Tuesday that the new law, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence, has hurt the feelings of the Taiwan people.

If Beijing wants to mend its fences with Taiwan, it should give up its obstruction of Taiwan's bid to enter the WHA, the decision making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) , as an observer, Romberg said.

Romberg noted that "the orderly and upbeat nature of the demonstration on May 26 in Taipei reinforced the impression that the government has sought to make clear that the Anti-Secession Law is unacceptable in principle and to give Taiwan's citizens a way to express their displeasure, and that the government has no desire to do anything to raise cross-strait tensions."

Romberg, who once served as U.S. State Department deputy spokesman, told the Central News Agency that "one hopes that the next steps will be efforts from both sides to resume progress on charter flights and perhaps even to find a way to negotiate the 'three direct links.'"
"If Beijing wants to make a positive impression on the people of Taiwan, it should acquiesce this year in Taiwan's application for WHA observer status," Romberg said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN EXPECTED TO VISIT CHINA IN JUNE: HONG KONG DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, March 30 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chinese authorities have agreed in principle to the idea of Lien Chan, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), visiting the mainland in June this year, a Hong Kong daily on Wednesday quoted "reliable sources" as saying.

The Ming Pao reported that it was tacitly agreed last year that KMT Chairman Lien Chan would visit the mainland prior to his assuming the presidency in May 2004 if he won the presidential election with his running mate, People First Party Chairman James Soong, in March of that year.

If Lien had visited the mainland in his capacity as the KMT chairman and a president-elect according to the plan last year, Chinese President Hu Jintao would have met with him in person, marking the first rendezvous of the leaders of the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party in more than five decades, the Ming Pao reported.
The plan, nevertheless, was dropped after Lien and Soong lost the election by a tiny margin to President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu who were re-elected for a second term.

The daily quoted KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang and KMT Legislator Chu Feng-chih, who are currently on a five-day groundbreaking visit in China, as saying that if their current visit proves successful and the mainland authorities indeed show goodwill, KMT Chairman Lien Chan may visit Beijing in June this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN COULD SET NEW RECORD FOR OVERSEAS VISITS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he hopes to make a state visit to the Republic of China's African ally of Burkina Faso later this year.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Roch Marc Christian Kabore, speaker of the Burkina Faso parliament, who is currently on an official visit in Taipei.

The president told his guest that if an opportunity presents itself, he would like to visit Burkina Faso again late this year. Chen last visited the West African nation in August 2000, making him the first ROC president ever to do so.
If Chen does indeed visit Burkina Faso this year, he will become the first ROC president ever to make four overseas trips in a single year.

Chen visited two of the ROC's South Pacific allies -- Palau and the Solomon Islands -- Jan. 27-31 this year. He is scheduled to visit other South Pacific island nations, including the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu, between late April and early May.
Moreover, Chen plans to travel to Latin America in August or September to attend a summit meeting with the top leaders of the ROC's Central and South American diplomatic allies.

In preparation for Chen's second South Pacific diplomatic tour, an advance team, to be composed of officials from the Presidential Office, the Government Information Office and the National Security Bureau, will depart for the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu Thursday to look into hotel capacity, airport facilities and proposed activities to be staged during Chen's visit.
Presidential Office staff said the itinerary of Chen's upcoming South Pacific visit will be fleshed out after the advance team completes its inspection tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE TASK FORCE TO HELP CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that the special task force on cross-Taiwan Strait affairs that the legislature is planning to set up will facilitate direct and effective exchanges between Taiwan and China.

As to his proposal to invite Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China, to visit Taiwan, Wang said the proposal will have to be approved by the task force and the legislature before it can be carried out.

Wang, who is also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , put forth the proposal a day earlier and immediately met opposition from legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union.
On the controversial, on-going Chinese visit by P.K. Chiang, another KMT vice chairman, Wang said the trip is aimed at tempering cross-strait tensions.
Wang said the KMT hopes to do something for the country and should not be mistaken as intending to conduct some kind of peace talks with the Chinese Communist Party.
According to Wang, the KMT is seeking various means to try to remove the barriers between the two sides.
For example, Wang said, a visit by a KMT delegation earlier this year helped clear the way for the launch of special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights.
He said that the visit to China by KMT members is a kind of civil exchange and that the KMT does not represent the country without the government's authorization.
He also noted that the postponement of the KMT chairmanship election until July has nothing to do with incumbent Chairman Lien Chan's plan to visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROTESTS U.S. NOT TO CONDEMN PRC OVER HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan protests Washington's decision not to initiate a resolution condemning China at the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva this year, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Wednesday.

Washington announced in mid-March that it would not be sponsoring a resolution condemning China at the U.N. human rights commission in Geneva, citing "progress" in human rights in China, including the release of Uighur dissident and human rights fighter Rebiya Kadeer.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee meeting, Kau said that his office has exchanged views with Washington on this concern, but that he is willing to openly lodge a protest against the U.S. administration's decision not to condemn China's human rights record this year.
"It is very regrettable that the United States has decided to discontinue grilling China over its human rights record," Kao said.

During the interpellation session, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said Washington's decision was a "gift" given to Beijing days prior to U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to China March 20.

Lai ridiculed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for having been "strangely silent" over the U.S. change in attitude while at the same time sparing no efforts in condemning China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law as depriving the 23 million people of Taiwan of their human rights.
