DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES FALL SLIGHTLY ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices fell slightly on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the key weighted index moving down by 3.26 points to end at 5,957.98.
The weighted index reached a high of 5,980.5 during the day's trading session and dropped to a low of 5,940.18.

Paper and pulp stocks posted the largest fall of 1.6 percent, followed by foodstuff shares, down by 1.1 percent, while financial shares and plastics and chemical shares rose by 0.3 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively.
Losers outnumbered gainers 509 to 362, with 147 shares remaining unchanged on a relatively slim market turnover of NT$56.628 billion (US$1.8 billion). A total of 2.55 billion shares changed hands.

Market analysts suggested that investors take a wait-and-see attitude over the short term, as the weighted index has failed to rebound to above the 6,000-point mark after days of losses due to heavy selling pressure from foreign institutional investors and poor performance on Wall Street.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mixed Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained two points to close at 5,975, with 19,723 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May moved down seven points to finish at 5,974, with 146 contracts traded, while June futures increased one point to close at 5,957, with 34 contracts traded. September futures lost five points to finish at 5,855, with 64 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,973 for April, 5,981 for May, 5,956 for June, 5,860 for September and 5,860 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

April TE futures moved down 0.4 points to close at 228.15, with 3,208 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 0.45 points to finish at 228, with 21 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

April TF futures moved up 4.6 points to finish at 963.4, with 3,168 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures gained four points to end at 963, with 35 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FORGING ACCORD WITH CCP UNLAWFUL: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: It would be unlawful if an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) delegation visiting China was to forge any "peace accord" with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Wednesday.

DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung, a lawyer-turned-legislator, quoted Article 113 of the criminal law as stipulating that if individuals forge an agreement with a foreign government -- a move that requires official permission -- without the authority of the administration, they will be charged and could face prison terms of up to seven years.
Hsu called for KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who is leading the KMT delegation on a "groundbreaking" visit to Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing, not to break Taiwan law.

Hsu made the remarks at a press conference in which the DPP legislative caucus members continued to lodge a scathing attack on the KMT and to question the rationale behind the major opposition party's current "China rush" at a time when the people of Taiwan are still enraged over Beijing's enactment of its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Lai Ching-teh, a legislative whip of the DPP, chided the KMT for engaging in the "third KMT-CCP talks, " which he claimed to feature "three episodes " -- the other two being a visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan to China in person for a summit meeting with the CCP head, and a KMT/CCP joint establishment of a "unification council, " with both sides exchanging representative offices and both sides pushing for "three direct links" across the Taiwan Strait and the signing of a cross-strait peace agreement.

Lai asked whether Lien Chan will sign a peace agreement with Beijing, whether he will sign a peace agreement with the People's Republic of China or the CCP, and whether an agreement signed by a party that lost the presidential election in Taiwan would be legitimate.

Chao Yung-ching, another DPP legislative whip, ridiculed the KMT for acting like a peacock, saying that the KMT has fallen prey without knowing it to the "United Front" of the CCP, which has stepped up schemes to annex Taiwan via legitimate means and through exerting pressure on Taiwan businessmen operating in China

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP REVERSES SUPPORT OF CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM PACKAGE

TEXT.P: A leading legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Wednesday that the party has decided to reverse its support of a constitutional amendment package passed by the Legislative Yuan last August.
According to Lee Yung-ping, a whip of the PFP's legislative caucus, the decision was made in light of widespread disapproval of the package among constitutional experts.

The package still requires ratification by the ad hoc National Assembly, which is set to be elected May 14 for the sole purpose of considering the amendment package. Formed by representatives of various political parties in proportion to the number of ballots they garner in the poll, the National Assembly is expected to convene within 10 days of the election and complete review and endorsement of the amendments within a month.

Items in the package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.
Lee claimed that cutting the number of legislative seats almost by half will result in the domination of legislative committees by a small number of legislators.
The PFP prefers cutting the number of legislative seats to between 150 and 170.

According to Lee, most constitutional experts believe a German-style "single seat, two votes" system is better than a Japanese-style system adopted by the amendment package and that they are doubtful whether such a system will help improve the quality of legislators.

Also, Lee said, the PFP will seek to raise the ratification threshold of the National Assembly to a vote by a three-fourths majority from a 50-percent majority proposed in the draft of the National Assembly organic law.

In response to the PFP's decision, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh said the KMT respects the PFP's opinions but that it will stick to the original constitutional amendment package.
Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus, expressed his regret over the PFP's flip-flop.
Lai said the PFP's opposition to the reform package and its proposal to set a high ratification threshold for the National Assembly might make the reform even more difficult to achieve.
He reminded the PFP that the reform package was a promise shared by all political parties during the 2004 presidential election campaign and that every party is responsible for honoring this promise.
In addition to the PFP, the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , which is promoting a campaign to draft a new constitution, is also against the constitutional amendment package.

Angered by the PFP's and TSU's capricious attitude, members of a private group promoting a referendum on the fourth nuclear power plant project accused the two parties of setting a bad example and betraying their political integrity.
The Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association will launch its fifth round-the-island walkathon April 2 to push the concerned parties to complete the reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Prosecutors Go for the Full 10 Years.
The state prosecutor on Tuesday called for maximum 10-year sentences for Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev on multiple counts of tax evasion, fraud, embezzlement and falsifying documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.008 to close at NT$34.784.
A total of US$843 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$31.879 and was traded between NT$31.771 and NT$31.900 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PLANS TO SEND LOBBY MISSIONS ABROAD TO COUNTER BEIJING LAW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is planning to send lobby missions abroad in mid-April to voice Taiwan's objections in the international community to the anti-secession law passed by Beijing aimed at Taiwan, Vice Foreign Minister Kau Ying-mao said Tuesday.

Delegations will be dispatched to directly express Taiwan's stance to European countries, the United States and Japan on the law Beijing adopted March 14 that justifies an attack on Taiwan if Beijing thinks the island is moving toward independence, Kau said.

In line with the missions, the ministry has also ordered its missions overseas to issue position papers to make clear the government's position at a time when the European Union is weighing whether to lift an arms embargo on China and when the World Health Assembly is slated to open in May, he noted.

The negative impact of the arms embargo lifting by the E. U. on security in the Taiwan Strait and the health rights of the Taiwan people will also be heeded when MOFA officials meet their foreign counterparts, he said, adding that the lobby missions form part of the government's strategies to counter Beijing' threat against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KINMEN COMMANDER TO BE APPOINTED

TEXT.P: The commander of the army's eighth regiment, Wu Ta-peng, will be appointed commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said Wednesday.

The position has been assumed tentatively by Army Deputy Commander-in-Chief Chia Fu-yi since former Commander Cha Tai-chuan was recently recalled from the frontline island to Taiwan for medical treatment.
In addition to Cha, Kinmen Defense Command Deputy Commander Hu Chieh, and Chief of Staff Chang Ching-hsiang will also step down April 1.

Trying to clarify speculation that the adjustments are related to a personnel struggle within the military, Lee told the legislature's National Defense Committee that Hu will be transferred to another position because of his seniority, while Chang will get a promotion.
Lee said Cha will be appointed to another position if he is physical able to resume his duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATION VISITS ROC FOUNDING FATHER'S MAUSOLEUM IN NANJING
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, Jiangsu, March 30 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A 34-member delegation of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) made a historic visit Wednesday to the mausoleum of the party's late founder, Dr. Sun Yat-sen, in the city of Nanjing in the central Chinese province of Jiangsu.
It marked the first time that the KMT, which once ruled all of China, has sent an official mission to pay homage to its founder since the party lost a bloody civil war and fled to Taiwan in 1949.

KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, also a legislator-at large, who is leading the delegation, laid a wreath in front of a statute of Sun, who led the revolution to topple China's last Qing Dynasty and establish the Republic of China in 1911, on behalf of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and the rest of the party.
Led by Chiang, the delegation members bowed three times and observed a moment of silence to pay their respects.
Chiang's delegation was welcomed by hundreds of cheering and clapping Chinese tourists.

Officials from the Nanjing city government and the Jiangsu provincial government in charge of Taiwan affairs, as well as representatives of major Taiwanese trade associations in Jiangsu Province, accompanied Chiang's mission on its "commemorative" visit to Sun's mausoleum.
In the afternoon, the delegation flew to Beijing, where Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, is expected to host a dinner in honor of the delegation.

According to media reports, the delegation will discuss with the Chinese authorities in Beijing a range of trade issues, including whether China will open its market to Taiwan's agricultural products, medical and health-care operators, banking and insurance companies.

The delegation might also meet with Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, before concluding its Beijing visit and returning to Taipei via Hong Kong Friday, the reports said.

Chiang's mission arrived in Guangzhou Monday on its visit, which Chiang claimed is purely aimed at commemoration of the KMT's revolutionary forebears and exploration of problems faced by Taiwan businessmen operating in China, also known as "taishang."

On Tuesday, the delegation visited the Huanghuagang Mausoleum of 72 Martyrs in suburban Guangzhou in the southern province of Guangdong. The 72 revolutionary martyrs died trying to overthrow the Qing dynasty in the Huanghuagang Uprising prior to the establishment of the ROC.

The visit comes at a sensitive time when many Taiwan citizens are enraged at China's enactment of a law justifying an attack on Taiwan under certain conditions set by Beijing. In Taipei, pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmakers labeled the visit as a "trip of kowtowing to communist foes."

Some analysts said the trip's significance seems to lie in symbolizing rapprochement between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party, whose 1949 revolution forced the KMT to flee from China to Taiwan. Once fierce enemies, the two parties have found common cause in their commitment to unifying the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and dislike for Taiwan's independence-minded President Chen Shui-bian, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OPPOSES PROPOSAL TO INVITE NPC CHAIRMAN TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers expressed opposition Wednesday to Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng's proposal to invite Wu Bangguo, chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (NPC) of China, to visit Taiwan.
Legislator Trong Chai said Wang's proposal is very untimely, particularly in light of China's March 14 enactment of its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Chai also called Wang's proposal to recognize Chinese academic degrees "a very dangerous thing, " warning that "Taiwan could be subverted" by people who receive education in China if the proposal is adopted by the government.
Tsai Huang-liang said inviting Wu to Taiwan is not something the country and its people need.
He urged Wang to stop using cross-Taiwan Strait issues as a means of boosting his chances of winning his competition with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou for the upcoming KMT chairmanship election.
Pan Meng-an, meanwhile, accused Wang of betraying the sovereignty of Taiwan just to win the support of "pan-blue alliance" hardliners.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZERS TOUTS 326 MARCH AS SUCCESSFUL

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Democratic Alliance for Peace, an umbrella group formed exclusively to organize the March 26 protest march in Taipei, claimed Wednesday that the event was the "largest and most successful rally" in Taiwan's history.
Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang, who is one of the co-leaders of the alliance said the rally was unprecedented in terms of the huge number of people it attracted.

It was also significant in that it showed the world that Taiwan is different from China, where people's freedom of association is unheard of, and that the island is doing its utmost to keep the status quo in terms of its ties with China, while China is going out of its way to alter it, and might resort to force to do so.

He said President Chen Shui-bian called him after the march, lauding the enthusiastic participation of the public and saying that people's backing of Taiwan is the most reliable safeguard of the country's security.

Wang Mau-hsiung, a leader of the International Lions Club in Taiwan and a co-leader of the alliance, said the march successfully cast the island into the international limelight and drew international attention to China's military threat against Taiwan.
Wang said the government should ride on the people's anger with China to launch diplomatic offenses, including bids to join international organizations.

In an attempt to rebut the Taipei police department's estimate that only 275,000 persons marched, the alliance released the results of a survey that shows that 5.55 percent of those interviewed claimed they turned up for the event.
In view of the fact that the country has 16 million adults, the organizers claimed that 930,000 people took part, which is very close to their claim of 1 million participants.

Based on this formula, the organizers estimated that 230,000 Taipei City residents and 200,000 Taipei County residents showed up at the march, which contradicted Vice President Annette Lu's criticism that the capital city's residents were apathetic about the rally.
The survey, carried out between March 28 and 29, collected 1,293 valid samples among adults with the right to vote. It had an error margin of 3 percent, said the organizers of the march.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH INSURANCE FEES WAIVED FOR KIDS UNDER 3 FROM POOR FAMILIES

TEXT.P: Children under three from impoverished families will be exempted from national health insurance premiums from April 4 to coincide with the nation's Women's and Children's Day, Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday.

Noting that the new measure will benefit 24,000 children, Hsieh said it will be adopted in line with President Chen Shui-bian's earlier directive that the government assist low-income families with young children by excepting the children from health insurance payments.
The insurance premium exemption for children under three will help reduce the financial burden for low-income families by an estimated NT$137 million annually, Hsieh said.

The government has exempted out-patient and hospitalization fees for all local children under three since 2002, Hsieh said, adding that the results of a series of public opinion surveys show that 93 percent of respondents support this measure.

Hsieh also announced that the government will offer subsidies for elementary and junior high schools in aboriginal communities to purchase flat-panel TVs in connection with the planned launch of an aboriginal TV channel in July.

Meanwhile, Hsieh said the Executive Yuan will raise the ratio of female commissioners in various commissions or councils under its jurisdiction to accentuate the government's resolve to promote gender equality in political participation and policy formulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN SPOUSE COUPLES NEED MORE HELP IN TAIPEI: CITY COUNCILOR

TEXT.P: With more and more foreign brides marrying Taipei citizens, problems arising from these families are surging, a situation that the government must improve swiftly, a Taipei City councilor said Wednesday.

Speaking at a news conference, Councilwoman Lee Ken Kuei-fang said that the many problems emerging from mixed marriages have caused an impact on society as a whole and that the government must address the growing need to re-allocate the country's resources in its education and social welfare systems.

Citing municipal statistics, Lee said that more than 20 percent of those couples married last year consisted of a foreign spouse. Some 40 percent of them are couples composed of an elderly retired serviceman and a young foreign bride, she said, pointing out that problems related to the large gap in ages, poor financial situations, inadequate education and juvenile delinquency arising from such families have markedly increased.
She appealed for adequate government attention to these families and urged that effective measures be put into place to help them.

According a Taipei City Government official, 23,382 spouses from China had their domicile registered in Taipei City as of the end of January this year, not to mention those from countries in Southeast Asia and those from Canada, Japan, South Korea and the United States.

The official said that the municipal authorities have set up an ad hoc group in charge of providing assistance to couples of elderly retired servicemen and foreign wives. Assistance ranges from how to deal with children who grow up in a household with an elderly father and an young mother, to jobs and education, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXCHANGES DIALOGUE WITH KOREAN PHILOSOPHER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that although globalization is the mainstream value of the world today, it will result in the loss of cultural distinction if localization is ignored.

Discussing the issue with visiting South Korean philosopher Kim Young Oak, founder of the Institute of the History of Korean Thoughts, in a seminar held by the Council for Cultural Affairs, Hsieh said globalization co-exists with localization and that co-existence is the principle of all cultures.
Hsieh claimed that cultural diversity is a special feature of Taiwan because of its various languages and ethnic groups.
It is more difficult to seek co-existence in such a multicultural environment than in countries like Korea and Japan, which he said are formed by a single nation.

Citing the Taoist thought of ancient Chinese philosopher Lao-tse, Hsieh said "nature" is the co-existence principle of humans, heaven and earth and that only by following the co-existence of nature will eternity, balance and harmony be achieved.
Kim agreed that maintaining the identity of a regional culture is a basic issue in the face of the globalization trend.
He claimed that Taiwanese identity is temporary because it is always changing and cannot erase its connection with Chinese culture.

According to Kim, both Taiwan and South Korea have experienced multicultural exchanges and oppression by another country and have both developed a democracy after absorbing various cultures, schools of thought and conflicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Panel Says Annan Didn't Intervene in Iraq Contract.
A panel says U.N. Secretary General Coffi Annan didn't intervene in Iraq contract, but he was faulted for not taking more action once conflict of interest questions were raised.
The Wall Street Journal: Buffett Was Told Ahead of Time Of Deal With AIG.
Warren Buffett was told briefly in advance about a transaction that is now at the center of a regulatory investigation into an insurer he controls, and he believed the transaction could be done properly, a person familiar with the matter said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAUNCH OF CROSS-STRAIT CHARTER CARGO FLIGHTS REMAINS TO BE EVALUATED

TEXT.P: The launch of direct cross-Taiwan Strait charter cargo flights is pending an evaluation of the possible effects of the recent enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law, according to a statement issued Wednesday by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

The law, which authorizes the Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence, has impacted cross-strait exchanges in the short-term, the MAC noted.
The top mainland policy planning agency issued the statement to clarify remarks by MAC Chairman Joseph Wu in his speech to the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) a day earlier.

Wu told the ECCT in his speech that immediately after the two sides of the Strait reached an agreement on the cross-strait charter flight services for this year's lunar new year holiday, the government announced that the launch of cross-strait charter cargo flights was one of the issues it would actively promote and expected that there would be one regular cross-strait charter cargo flight a day, according to the statement.
Wu said that he lamented that Beijing had not responded to the proposal, the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR SIMULTANEOUS HOLDING OF 3 LOCAL-LEVEL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday he has directed the Ministry of the Interior and the Central Election Commission (CEC) to study the feasibility of having three local government elections held simultaneously.

Speaking before a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh said he hopes the elections of city and county government chiefs, city and county councilors, and township and village chiefs can be held on the same day to save costs and upgrade administrative efficiency.

According to original schedules, four elections should take place from this May through early next year -- the May 14 mission-oriented National Assembly election, the city mayor/county magistrate elections later this year, and the elections for city/county councilors and township/village chiefs early next year.

"Holding four elections in less than a year wastes national resources and increases social disharmony. I hope relevant government agencies can overcome various difficulties to realize the goal of having the three local-level elections take place simultaneously, " Hsieh said, adding that holding the three elections at the same time can underscore the government's commitment to administrative reform and upgrade the overall national competitiveness.

Responding to comments by some politicians that holding three local elections at the same time could further fuel vote-buying or election bribery, Hsieh said the misgivings are unfounded. "Both administrative reform and crackdowns on vote-buying are the government's main missions. They are not contradictory. It's not justifiable to claim that holding the three elections simultaneously would exacerbate or aggravate vote-buying, " Hsieh said, adding that stamping out election bribery has been the government's long-term goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MOST PEOPLE FAVOR HOLDING ELECTIONS AT THE SAME TIME

TEXT.P: Holding three local-level elections on the same day was favored by 58 percent of respondents to a survey released Wednesday by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) under the Executive Yuan.
Sixty-six percent favored rotating national and local elections every two years.
The poll was conducted to gauge the public's response to the Executive Yuan's plan to synchronize the time of various elections to save money.
The Executive Yuan is weighing holding the elections for county/city chiefs, county/city councilors and township/rural township chiefs, or the so-called three local elections, at the same time.

Also, the Executive Yuan is studying the possibility of holding the elections of president and lawmakers, the so-called national elections, simultaneously and rotating the national elections with the local elections every two years.
In disclosing the results of the survey, RDEC Vice Chairman Chen Chun-lin said that those who favor this plan cut across party lines, administrative boundaries and age groups.
Only 16 percent of respondents disapproved of the idea of synchronizing the three local elections, and 11 percent disapproved of rotating the national and local elections every two years.
The poll was conducted on March 21 with 1,110 valid replies and had a margin of error of 2.9 percentage points, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD TELLS ITALIAN DELEGATION ARMS EMBARGO ON CHINA MUST STAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland policy planner urged the European Union Wednesday not to lift its arms embargo against China.

Meeting with an Italian parliamentary delegation at his office, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu told his guests that lifting the arms ban would be misunderstood by Beijing authorities as the E. U. ignoring China's military threat to Taiwan.
Wu expressed his hope that the E.U. will convince China to abandon its option of invading Taiwan and to play a constructive role in improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

It was very significant for Taiwan that the European Parliament adopted a resolution to express its opposition to China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes the Beijing authorities to use "non-peaceful means" in dealing with Taiwan under certain circumstances, Wu noted.

Wu also asked his guests to convey the Republic of China government's appreciation to the Italian government for its opposition to China's option of using force in settling cross-strait disputes. He hoped that the Italian Parliament will adopt a similar resolution.

The five-member Italian parliamentary delegation, headed by Gustavo Selva, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, arrived in Taiwan a day earlier for a three-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. RULES WILL PRESSURE TAIWAN ELECTRONICS EQUIPMENT-MAKERS: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan makers of electrical and electronics equipment must make their manufacturing and recycling processes greener to meet stricter regulations that are to be imposed by the European Union (E. U.), a researcher said Wednesday.

Yang Chih-hsing, a senior researcher at the Industrial Technology Research Institute, urged domestic producers to swiftly adopt manufacturing techniques that will meet the E.U.'s eco-friendly standards for sustainable growth in view of the expected implementation of two new sets of rules that will restrict the use of certain substances and require a high level of recycling.

According to Yang, the directive on Waste Electrical and Electronics Equipment (WEEE) and the directive on the Restriction of the Use of Certain Hazardous Substances in Electrical and Electronic Equipment (RoHS) are slated to take effect in August 2005 and July 2006.
Under the terms of the WEEE directive, starting from Aug. 13 this year, each producer is required to be in charge of recycling their own waste goods, he said.

Pointing out that this requirement will put strong pressure on Taiwan manufacturers, in particular those with their own brands, he said that companies operating on a contract basis will also have to collaborate with their foreign clients.

Under the terms of the RoHS directive, the E. U. will limit the use of lead, cadmium and halogens, among other substances, beginning in July 2006, he explained, adding that products that fail to meet the set standard will be left on the shelf.

Yang claimed that more than 30,000 Taiwan companies will be affected by the new E.U. rules given that the value of Taiwan's electrical and electronics goods exports to Europe last year totaled NT$225.8 billion (US$7.15 billion), involving 34,533 businesses.

According to an investigation conducted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, only 5 percent and 3 percent of the domestic manufactures are qualified under the WEEE and RoHS directives, respectively. Around 37 percent and 13 percent said they have yet to adjust their manufacturing.

Ten categories, including home appliances, vending machines, daily consumption products, telecommunications and information industry goods, will be subject to the scrutiny of the WEEE and RoHS in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPRESSES CONCERN ABOUT KMT DELEGATION'S CHINA VISIT: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The United States has expressed concern about the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) dispatch of an official delegation to China, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Ying-mao Kau said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's foreign affairs committee, Kau said that although the U.S. government has publicly said it welcomes peaceful dialogue and interactions across the Taiwan Strait at both the government and private levels, some American officials have said in private that Taiwan should forge internal unity and consensus first to enhance its strength in negotiating with China.
As for the KMT delegation's ongoing visit to China, Kau said U.S. authorities have express their concern.

A 34-member delegation, headed by KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang is currently on a five-day visit. The delegation departed for the mainland two days after a million-person-protest-march in Taipei against Beijing's enactment of a law justifying its longstanding threat to attack Taiwan in case it thinks the democratic island is seeking formal independence. The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union has labeled the visit a "kowtowing trip to communist foes."
Kau said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has exchanged views with U.S. authorities on "matters of mutual concern" about the KMT's China visit. He didn't elaborate.
Instead, Kau told lawmakers that the United States does not want to see any "surprise" in the Taiwan Strait situation.
He further said the government is committed to crafting a "framework of peace and stability" for cross-strait interactions and resolving disputes through dialogue and consultations.
Nevertheless, Kau said after Beijing's enactment of the so-called Anti-Secession Law, cross-strait relations face new challenges.

He said the publication of an open letter by Chi Mei Group founder Hsu Wen-lung last weekend supporting Beijing's "one China" policy indicates that the "anti-secession" legislation has taken its toll on local businessmen with interests in China.

"Seeking cross-strait peace requires much more preparatory work. At the moment, the most crucial task is to forge domestic unity and consensus. We should stand united to let Beijing know that military threats are counterproductive and unhelpful to cross-strait engagements," Kau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MARCH 31 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, March 31:
09: 00, The Legislative Yuan's committees will start their sessions for the day.
10: 30, President Chen Shui-bian will visit the Industrial Technology Research Institute's headquarters in Chutung, Hsinchu County.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
12: 30, The National Science Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
14:00, Vice President Annette Lu will receive a visiting Canadian parliamentary delegation at the Presidential Office.
14: 00, The Taiwan Economic and Industrial Association will hold its congress at the Far Eastern Plaza hotel in Taipei.
14: 00, Taiwantrade.com will celebrate its third anniversary at the Taipei International Convention Center.
16: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
17: 00, A visiting German parliamentary delegation will visit Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at Taipei City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR PARTIES LINE UP AGAINST SYNCHRONIZED LOCAL-LEVEL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's plan to hold the three local-level elections together at the end of this year has pitted the country's two major parties against the three minor ones in the Legislative Yuan.
Both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the leading opposition of Kuomintang (KMT) spoke against it Wednesday on the grounds that it would be unfavorable to them.

In a rare sign of disagreement between the DPP administration and the party, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang said to hold these local elections abruptly without necessary measures to ensure the elections' clearness and fairness would only give corrupt candidates a perfect chance to fix them.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the DPP's Culture and Communication Department, said to hold elections together may save the government some money and is therefore a goal worthy of pursuit in the long term, but it should not be carried out in haste, or it could help grouped candidates buy votes on a large scale.

Citing a poll conducted by the Taiwan Provincial Election Commission among the governments and election commissions of various cities and counties, Cheng said most of them disapprove of this change, adding that the Executive Yuan should heed the opinions of these local governments and put the brakes on its plan.

KMT Legislator Chen Chieh, who is the whip of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the change was aimed at facilitating the DPP's plan to woo voters with its "pork barrel" policies in all three elections.

Meanwhile, the three minor parties in the legislature, namely the People First Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union voiced their support for the plan, saying it would save money for both the government and society.

DOC.HEADLINE: 688 COULD VIE FOR 300 SEATS IN MAY 14 NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION

TEXT.P: When the election is held on May 14 to fill the National Assembly, 12 groups of 688 people could be vying for the 300 seats of the mission-oriented body, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Wednesday after announcing that registration was closed.
The CEC will examine the qualifications of the would-be candidates endorsed by 12 political groups and arrange a draw on April 21 to determine in what order the groups will appear on the ballots.

Among the prominent parties, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) fielded 150 people to run on its ticket, while the leading opposition Kuomintang (KMT) entered 148, the People First Party 83, the Taiwan Solidarity Union 50, and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union 31.

According to the CEC, votes will be cast for political groups rather than any particular candidate, then the political groups will share the 300 seats in the National Assembly in proportion to the ballots they garnered.

The National Assembly is supposed to vote for or against a set of draft amendments to the ROC Constitution, notable among them is an amendment to cut by roughly half the size of the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, and an amendment to change the electoral system for lawmakers from a multiple-seat constituency to a single-seat one.

Among the 12 political groups that entered the race, the DPP, the KMT and three other little-known small parties support the changes, while the other seven groups, including the People First Party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, and the Non-partisan Solidarity Union, which are minor groups in the Legislative Yuan, have vowed to vote against them, according to the CEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, March 31, or the 22nd day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Rene Descartes, French philosopher, mathematician, and inventor of the technique of methodical doubt, is born.
1854: The U.S. Navy and Japan's shogunate sign the first U.S.-Japanese treaty. Under the treaty, Japan agrees to open two ports to U.S. traders, marking the end of more than 200 years of isolation from the outside world.
1858: China's Ching court capitulates to British and French demands for trade concessions.
1889: The Eiffel Tower is opened in Paris by France's premier.
1901: Gottlieb Daimler, German inventor, names his latest 53 mph, four-cylinder creation after his daughter, Mercedes.
1917: The United States acquires the Virgin Islands from Denmark.
1918: Daylight savings time goes into effect throughout the United States for the first time.
1927: Ching dynasty political reformer Kang Yu-wei dies at the age of 70.
1941: Germany launches a counter-offensive against the Allies in North Africa.
1947: The Nationalist government of the Republic of China promulgates laws governing the organization of the National Assembly; the organization of the five branches of the central government; the election and recall of deputies of the National Assembly; the election and recall of the president and vice president of the republic; the election and recall of legislators; and the election and recall of members of the Control Yuan.
1948: The U.S. Congress adopts the Marshall Aid Pact for Europe's post-war recovery.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the ruler and spiritual leader of Tibet, flees to safety in India after Chinese communist military occupation of Tibet makes his position in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa impossible.
1968: President Lyndon Johnson of the United States announces he will not stand for re-election.
1971: Chow Shu-kai, ROC ambassador to the United States, is named foreign minister, succeeding Dr. Wei Tao-ming.
1971: Dr. Lo Yun-pin, president of the National Cheng Kung University, is named minister of education, succeeding Dr. Choong Kow-kwong.
1974: Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, leaves Taipei for Tokyo to attend an executive council meeting of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League.
1983: Earthquake rocks the city of Popayan in Colombia, killing more than 500 people.
1988: Sir William McMahon, prime minister of Australia from 1971 to 1972, dies.
1991: The Warsaw Pact formally ceases to exist as a military force after Soviet commanders surrender their powers.
1992: The United Nations Security Council imposes an air and arms embargo on Libya.
1994: Twenty-four tourists from Taiwan are killed during a robbery at a tourist resort in mainland China's Zhejiang Province.
1998: The United Nations Security Council imposes an arms embargo on Yugoslavia.
2000: Former Taiwan Governor James Soong and his supporters formally establish Taiwan's 90th officially recognized political party, the People First Party. Soong is unanimously selected as PFP chairman.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that the working week will be shortened to 44 hours from the present 48 hours by year's end.
2001: A new page in the "three mini links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is turned when a mainland China-registered freighter enters a harbor on the Taiwan-ruled offshore island of Kinmen for the first time.
2001: The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, arrives in Taiwan on his second visit to the Republic of China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is sociable, but not familiar. A fool is familiar but not sociable."

TEXT.P: Senior security officials denied a media report Thursday that National Security Bureau (NSB) Deputy Director Huang Lai will retire soon.

NSB officials said the report is not true, insisting that Huang Lai has neither applied for retirement nor offered to resign. Therefore, the officials said, there is no such problem as to who will succeed Huang Lai as the NSB deputy director.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TALKS WITH CHINESE COMMUNISTS INAPPROPRIATE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Presidential Office official criticized the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday as behaving inappropriately by holding talks with the Chinese Communist Party immediately after China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

The official was referring to a meeting between a delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang and officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing Wednesday, in which both sides reached a 10-point consensus covering a wide range of issues including cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businesspeople, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the KMT move was "inappropriate in terms of capacity, timing and atmosphere" and that the Presidential Office will continue to watch related developments.

President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesdday called the Chinese visit by the KMT "out of place in time, " saying it seems as if the KMT is trying to seek some kind of reconciliation with the Chinese Communists like the old days during the civil war in China.

National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen pointed out that Beijing has defined the visit by the KMT delegation as being on the civil exchanges level but that the objectives of the 10-point consensus are not something that can be achieved at the civil level.

Meanwhile, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said that the Republic of China is a democratic and open country whose people are free to express their opinions and that any opinions they express will be respected.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened up and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 47.9 points to close at 6,005.88.
The bourse opened at 6,005.87 and fluctuated between 6,017.04 and 5,995.27 during trading. A total of 2.88 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.84 billion (US$2.24 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 1.4 percent and banking and financial shares gaining 0.6 percent.

Six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile stocks at 1.1 percent, cement stocks and paper and pulp issues both at 0.5 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 520 to 336, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIR REITERATES PARTY'S RESOLVE TO IMPROVE TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang reiterated in Beijing Thursday his party's resolve to help better Taiwan's economy and improve the people's livelihood, stressing this is something that requires efforts from both the ruling and opposition camps.
Chiang made the remarks after paying tribute at a memorial in suburban Beijing to Republic of China founding father Sun Yat-sen in the Chinese capital. Sun died in 1925 at the age of 59 in Beijing.

Chiang said he will make a report on his mainland China trip to the government after returning to Taiwan because adequate government policies and legislative cooperation are necessary to carry out any agreement his delegation has reached with the Chinese side during the visit.

Chiang's remarks came after the KMT mission and officials of the Chinese Communist Party signed a 10-point consensus late Wednesday to boost civil exchanges between Taiwan and China, ranging from agricultural and cross-strait passenger and cargo transport issues to labor and academic affairs. One of the most noteworthy elements was China's agreement to ink a Taiwan investment guarantee accord.

Traveling at the head of a 34-member delegation, Chiang flew to Beijing from Nanjing a day earlier on the third leg of a five-day visit to China -- the first of its kind since the KMT retreated to Taiwan after losing the Chinese civil war in 1949.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said that the opening of regular passenger charter flights across the strait and exports of Taiwan agricultural products to China are the two most urgent issues to the people in Taiwan.

Earlier in the day, the KMT vice chairman had lunch together with officials of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- Beijing's semiofficial body dealing with Taiwan in the absence of government-to-government contacts between the two sides.

Chiang is scheduled to meet Jia Qinglin, chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, and Tang Jiaxuan, one of the five state councilors, later in the same day. He is also slated to have dinner with Taiwan business people based in the Beijing area.

Chiang's China visit comes at a time when cross-strait relations have turned soured due to Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law on March 14, which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.
The main opposition KMT has repeatedly vowed since independence-minded President Chen Shui-bian's election in 2000 to do its utmost to help thaw relations between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 35 points to close at 6,010, with 17,500 contracts changing hands.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
April TE futures moved up 2.75 points to close at 230.9, with 3,745 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained three points to finish at 230.95, with 28 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

April TF futures gained 4.2 points to finish at 967.6, with 3,112 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved up four points to end at 967, with 47 contracts traded. DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN SERVED AS SECRET ENVOY TO CHINA: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) served as a secret envoy who held covert talks with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in Bangkok in 2003 to pave the way for his later visit to China, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Thursday.
Chen Chin-chun was referring to P.K. Chiang, who is currently leading a delegation on a five-day visit in China. The delegation visited Guangzhou and Nanjing before arriving in Beijing.

Chiang secured a 10-point list of topics agreed upon with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, in Beijing Wednesday covering a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, protection of Taiwan businessmen in China, mainland fishermen and the further opening of China's financial market.

Legislator Chen said that Chiang, a former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, visited Bangkok between Dec. 28 and Dec. 30 in 2003, ostensibly to deliver a speech on Taiwan's economic prospects over the next four years and to attend the inauguration of a support group for the "pan-blue alliance" ticket for president election in 2004 -- Lien Chan of the KMT and James Soong of the People First Party (PFP).

In fact, with the help of KMT-run enterprises, Chiang met with two delegations from Beijing, Chen alleged, adding that Chiang and six others met with Chinese Ambassador Yan Tingai as well as a ranking official from the Taiwan Affairs Office.
Chiang and Chinese officials also met in secret on another occasion, and the time and place is still being checked, Chen claimed.
He said Bangkok has become the "honeymoon" location of the KMT and the CCP, and that China's present ambassador maintains good relations with the KMT.
The first meeting was held at the Shangri-La Hotel in Bangkok, a favorite of Chinese dignitaries.

Chen said that the relations of the KMT and the CCP are "beyond what could be imagined, " adding that the situation was worrisome for the people of Taiwan because history has shown that whenever the KMT deals with the CCP, it is the CCP that comes out on top.
"The KMT should explain whether it has sold out Taiwan interests in its talks with the CCP this time," he said.
He also said that Soong was in the dark about the talks between the KMT and the CCP in 2003, and the KMT should also give him an explanation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU LASHES OUT AT KMT OVER DEAL WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) slammed the pro-unification opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Thursday over a 10-point consensus reached between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) a day earlier.

"The 10-point statement signed in Beijing Wednesday by KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang and Chen Yunlin, director of the CCP's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs was an insult to our country, "said Lo Chih-ming, convener of the TSU legislative caucus.

The KMT-CCP consensus covered a broad range of issues, including charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businessmen, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.
Lo said the KMT delegation had not received any government authorization before its departure for the ongoing China visit. Therefore, he went on, the consensus is not legally binding.

Noting that the KMT delegation has dared not mention the nation's title -- the Republic of China -- since its arrival on Chinese soil Monday, Lo said Chiang had struck the 10-point deal with the CCP at the expense of national dignity.

"The KMT has always claimed it is committed to defending the ROC. Why is it that no one in the delegation has dared to mention the nation's title since they set foot on Chinese soil? They also dare not display its party flag or the ROC national flag while paying tribute to the party's revolutionary forefathers in Guangzhou and Nanjing. It seems to me that the KMT delegation has surrendered national sovereignty to sign the 10-point consensus on humiliating terms," Lo said.
While Chiang has billed the China visit as a move to promote cross-strait peace, Lo said it has actually hurt Taiwan's national interests and has embittered the people.

"As the visit comes shortly after Beijing's enactment of a law justifying its longstanding threat to attack Taiwan, it could mislead the world into believing that the people of Taiwan do not oppose this law, " Lo said, adding that the visit was an insult to the participants of a protest march against the new law in Taipei last weekend that organizers said drew one million people.

Chiang's visit was also a slap in the face of the United States and Japan who have been doing their utmost to persuade the European Union to maintain its ban on arms sales to China, Lo said, adding he is worried that the KMT's reconciliation with China at this critical moment might lead E.U. members into wondering why the Europe Union can't lift its arms embargo against Beijing.

Meanwhile, Lo accused the KMT of intending to weaken Taiwan's defense capabilities by stubbornly stonewalling the passage of the Democratic Progressive Party administration's arms procurement package from the United States, including eight diesel-electric submarines, six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries and a squadron of 12 anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S AGREEMENT WITH CHINA COULD VIOLATE STATUTE: MAC

TEXT.P: If the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) signed any document with the Chinese Communists in China thinking they were acting on behalf of the Republic of China government, those involved would have violated an important section of the statute governing cross-strait relations, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Thursday.

A delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang held talks with officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing Wednesday and reached a 10-point consensus on a wide range of issues including cross-strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese business people, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

According to Chiu, if the KMT signed any written agreement with China, it would be in violation of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which prohibits civic organizations from signing any agreement on issues involving government authorities and politics with China unless they are authorized by the government.
According to the statute, violators can be fined up to NT$2 million (US$63,492), and if the offense is considered very serious, a jail term of up to five years can be imposed.

Chiu said the KMT, as a political organization, is unsuitable to assume the role of negotiator and that it is even more inappropriate for the KMT to maintain contact with China at a time when Beijing has enacted its Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan.
While more than 90 percent of the people in Taiwan are against the aggressive legislation, the KMT did not pass on this message to China during the visit, Chiu noted.
Chiu said he suspects the KMT reached the 10-point consensus with Beijing in exchange for a high-profile reception for KMT Chairman Lien Chan on a future visit to China.

Chiu pointed that since the Anti-Secession Law has triggered widespread resentment in Taiwan, China is trying to win the support of the Taiwan people by giving them the false impression that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have reconciled.
He urged all people in Taiwan to unite to reject what he called the "sugarcoated tricks of China."

He accused the KMT of dancing to China's tune in defiance of the majority public opinion in Taiwan, saying the party failed to conduct any careful assessment of the possible impact on Taiwan's security and economic interests before holding talks with China.

He said the government, for the sake of national security, its people's well-being and Taiwan's development, will continue to take necessary steps to prevent China from doing further damage to cross-strait peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DELEGATES URGED TO ABIDE BY ROC LAW DURING CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Any agreements inked by private individuals, civic groups or political parties from Taiwan with mainland China or other foreign countries are invalid, and the KMT delegates should watch their step while in China, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Thursday.

Cho urged a visiting KMT delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang to be extremely careful with what they do in China and stressed that they must not do anything that might violate any Republic of China law.

Urging the Chinese authorities to talk directly with the ROC government, he said that the government is willing to conduct negotiations with Beijing under the principles of parity, reciprocality and mutual benefits, at any place and time.
However, any agreements by any individual or political group made without the authorization of the ROC government with a foreign government are not valid in the ROC, he stressed.

The government spokesman's comments came after the KMT mission reached a 10-point consensus with officials of the Chinese Communist Party late Wednesday in Beijing to boost civil exchanges between Taiwan and China, ranging from agricultural issues and cross-Taiwan Strait air links to labor, academic affairs and the signing of a Taiwan investment guarantee pact.

Although the KMT has made it clear that the 10-point consensus is aimed at bolstering private sector exchanges, Chiang's visit to China has provoked strong criticism from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at a time when cross-strait tensions are mounting after Beijing adopted an Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan on March 14.

The main opposition KMT has designated Chiang's China visit an ice-breaking trip, as it is the first of its kind by a ranking KMT official since 1949, when the party retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese Communists.
The 34-member KMT delegation has visited Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing since Monday. It is slated to return to Taiwan Friday.

Average household incomes have fallen for the first time in almost 15 years, according to new government figures. The disclosures will come as a blow to Labour as it prepares to place the economy at the centre of its election campaign.

A senior Tory has refused to rule out a British withdrawal from the European Union should its vow to repatriate large swaths of policy face implacable opposition from Brussels. DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER CONFIDENCE INDEX HITS SIX-MONTH LOW IN MARCH: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer confidence index dropped to a six-month low at 75.13 in March, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the National Central University's Research for Taiwan Economic Development.
The survey shows that the figure is 1.83 points lower than that of February and is the lowest level since the 75.27 recorded in October last year.

While all six indicators used for the survey fell in March, the "timing to invest in the stock market in the next six month" saw the greatest rate of decrease, losing 3.80 points from February to stand at 57.50.
Coming in second is the "domestic price level in the next six months," which dropped 2.70 points from February to 54.25.
The "domestic economic outlook in the next six months" registered 74.25, down 2.15 points from the previous month.
The "family financial status in the next six months" stood at 72.80, down 1.15 points from the previous month.
The "timing to buy durable goods in the next six months" lost 0.9 points from February to stand at 107.2, and the "employment opportunities in the next six months" also dropped 0.25 points to 84.80.
The survey was conducted from March 18-23 on 2,080 adults around Taiwan via telephone, with a margin of error of 2.1 percent.
