DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES MONEY FOR INDONESIAN EARTHQUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has extended its sympathy and concern to Indonesia after a powerful magnitude-8.7 earthquake hit the remote Indonesian island of Nias earlier this week, a diplomatic official said Thursday.
Moreover, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said the government has donated US$50,000 for post-earthquake relief projects in Nias.
Lu said the government will decide to offer more financial aid or other relief assistance when the damage caused by the temblor is better identified.

Shortly after the report of the earthquake, Lu said the ROC's representative office in Indonesia conveyed President Chen Shui-bian's and the government's regards to Indonesian authorities through diplomatic channels.

In addition to US$50,000 donated by the government, Lu said the Indonesian chapter of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- Taiwan's largest charity -- donated 50 tons of rice to surviving victims in Nias.
As the post-quake situation in Nias remains unclear, Lu said the government will decide whether to offer further relief aid after the Indonesian government announces its stance on foreign assistance.

Monday's quake struck off Indonesia's Sumatra Island, some 120km north of Nias. An even-bigger quake that generated the region's devastating tsunami Dec. 26, 2004 hit an area along the Sumatran coast. The death toll from Monday's quake was estimated to reach 1,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAFFITI NOW ALLOWED IN FIVE TAIPEI PARKS

TEXT.P: Graffiti has become a recognized form of expression in Taiwan and now five Taipei parks are open to anyone wanting to piece, do a throwup or just tag.

Chen Wei-jen, director of the Public Works Department under the Taipei City Government, presided over an event Thursday held at a news conference at the Chungshan Fine Arts Park to announce the news, while children tried their hand at tagging.
Aside from the Chungshan Fine Arts Park, four other parks for graffiti include Ta-an Forest Park, Tienmu Park, Nankang Park and Changan Green Land Park, he said.

The city government is allowing graffiti in the parks primarily to let citizens express their ideas and opinions about life and let off some steam, he said, adding that the city government intends to take pictures of meaningful graffiti and exhibit it.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONSENSUS WITH CHINA WILL BENEFIT TAIWAN: KMT CAUCUS

TEXT.P: A 10-point consensus reached between P. K, Chiang, a Kuomintang (KMT) vice chairman, and Chen Yunlin, the director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, is good for Taiwan, the legislative caucus of the KMT said Thursday.

The caucus was responding to the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , which described the 10-point consensus as the KMT "dancing to the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) tune."
The DPP also said Chiang's visit was the result of a covert meeting between him and the Chinese ambassador in Bangkok in 2003.

KMT Legislator Lee Jih-chu said Chiang's delegation is only concerned with trade, and the 10-point consensus is beneficial for Taiwan, inasmuch as it covers a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, the protection of Taiwan businessmen based in China, Chinese fishermen, and the further opening of China's financial market.
As an opposition party, the KMT can only pave the way and coordinate policy, and the ruling party should be thanking the KMT instead of inciting the public to side against the party, Lee said.
KMT Legislator Justin Chou said that the DPP has said that in cross-strait exchanges where the government is unable to make headway, it welcomes the private sector to step in.
The KMT, as a private group, is doing just that and is now being given a bad name for it, Chou said.

Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, also said it is "unfounded" for the DPP to accuse the KMT and China of having arranged to sign a secret agreement, saying that is "out of the question."
Chiang's visit to the mainland should be helpful to the nation and the rights of the people, Wang said.

Meanwhile, a KMT spokesman said Thursday that Chiang used the principle of "Taiwan first" to reach the 10-point consensus with China, which he said has produced an amiable atmosphere for cross-strait exchanges, and the ruling party is angry because it feels ashamed for not being able to achieve such results itself.

Chang Jung-kung was responding to the Cabinet's criticism that the KMT vice chairman's visit to China was in an "inappropriate capacity, at an inappropriate time and under an inappropriate atmosphere."

Chang said that unless the DPP says that opposition party officials are not allowed to visit China and that only DPP officials can, there ought to be no problem with members of the KMT traveling to China. If the ruling party announces such an edict, Chang said, the party would obey it.

He also said that the "right time" is something that is created, unlike President Chen Shui-bian who has had five years since coming to office in 2000 to make a move, and has done nothing but let opportunities "go down the drain."

He also said that the KMT is hoping that cross-strait relations can return to a more relaxed atmosphere such as was apparent in the wake of the cross-strait charter flights for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen during the Chinese Lunar New Year, adding that a good atmosphere needs to be nurtured not sabotaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PEOPLE WILL STAND ON SIDE OF DEMOCRACY EVENTUALLY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan's freedom, democracy and human rights cannot be jeopardized or damaged and that he believes the 1.3 billion people in China will eventually stand on the side of democracy and peace.

Speaking via his personal Web site, Chen said despite the different opinions expressed by various sectors in Taiwan toward his decision to take part in last week's demonstration against China's Anti-Secession Law, he opted to stand and walk with the people to voice Taiwan's stance to the world.

Chen stressed that freedom, democracy and human rights are universal values for which the Taiwanese people have fought for over the past decades, and these achievements must not be jeopardized or damaged.
Chen said he is expecting the arrival of the day when the 1.3 billion people in China embrace democracy and peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMBALANCE IN TECHNOLOGY IMPORTS-EXPORTS MUST BE ADDRESSED: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that Taiwan's imbalance between technology imports and exports must be addressed if the country intends to maintain its international competitiveness.

Quoting government figures, Chen said that the ratio of Taiwan's technology imports to its exports stood at 1 to 0.25 between 1997 and 2002, meaning that when Taiwan exported NT$1 worth of technologies, it imported NT$4 worth of similar products at the same time.

Amid fierce competition worldwide in a time of knowledge-based economies, Taiwan must strive to turn its deficit in technology imports to surpluses in the way that it turned its overall trade deficit into a surplus over the past several decades to secure Taiwan's competitive edge in the new "global race" in the 21st century, Chen said.
Chen made the remarks during an inspection tour of the Industrial Technology Research Institute -- one of Taiwan's high-technology research strongholds -- located in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.

He said that although high-technology products have taken an increasingly larger share of Taiwan's export trade, up from 18.8 percent in 1985 to 46 percent in 2003, exports of technologies have been disproportionately low as compared with imports.

Noting that although the ratio of Taiwan's technology exports to technology imports stood at 0.05 to 1 in 1997, a proportional figure which increased five-fold to 0.25 by 2002, Chen said that there is still ample room for the country to catch up in this area.

Chen promised the country that the government will continue to funnel capital as well as resources into science and technology research and development under the banner of "Creating New Values, " a drive which will be the direction of Taiwan's industrial upgrading efforts in the years to come.

The government will also accelerate efforts to strengthen collaboration among the industrial, academic and research sectors, while reviewing or overhauling relevant laws and regulations to help improve the development of Taiwan's high technologies, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA OFFENSIVE WILL CORNER TAIWAN AGRICULTURE: DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agriculture will be backed into a corner by China now that Beijing has kicked off an offensive to deal with Taiwan with a two-pronged strategy, a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawyers said Thursday.

Pan Mong-an, Huang Wei-che, Lin Kuo-ching, Yen Wen-chang and Chen Hsien-chung, all lawmakers from central and southern Taiwan counties, issued the warning at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan following reports that a visiting Kuomintang (KMT) mission inked a 10-point consensus with Chinese Communist Party (CCP) officials late Wednesday in Beijing to promote civil exchanges, ranging from agriculture and air links to protection of Taiwan investors in China.

According to the reports, the Chinese side said that they are willing to provide preferencial measures to allow Taiwan farm exports to enter the China market and that they would welcome Taiwan farmers who wish to settle in five Chinese provinces.

Despite the offer made by the CCP officials, the DPP lawmakers warned of a total defeat of Taiwan's agriculture, arguing that the opening seems to be beneficial to Taiwan farmers in the short term but pointing out that it will greatly hurt the domestic industry in the long run.

Claiming that competitive farm products from Taiwan are popular everywhere in the world and that China is not the only market for them, they speculated that China might ask Taiwan to open up its market to cheap Chinese goods, leading to a crushing impact on the domestic industry.
Should Taiwan fail to tackle the development adequately, it will result in an outflow of Taiwan's expertise and the wiping out of the country's competitive edge, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC WANTS SECOND-GENERATION OVERSEAS TAIWANESE TO COME HOME

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) will offer 50 job opportunities for second-generation Taiwanese who were brought up on the island and then studied and settled oversees so that they can return to work in Taiwan.

NSC Chairman Wu Mao-kun said that students at European and American universities do not always go directly to graduate schools like in Taiwan, as they prefer to travel around the world to experience different cultures before returning to school to pursue advanced degrees.
Wu said that when these second-generation overseas Taiwanese enter this stage, the council wants to do all it can to attract them to Taiwan.

Wu said the program, nicknamed the "migratory bird program, " will be held this summer, and will initially offer 50 jobs, adding that such research institutes as Academia Sinica, National Laboratories, and science-based industrial parks can accept them to serve as assistant researchers or work in translation.
By doing so, the visitors can learn about the way things are done in Taiwan and about its people, Wu added.
Noting that second-generation overseas Taiwanese have begun to shine in their respective disciplines, if they return to Taiwan, it will help give Taiwan a higher international profile.
Prospective employers have agreed to offer the returning Taiwanese free room and board but they must pay for their own air tickets, Wu said.
In addition to the young recruits, Wu said that those Taiwanese who have retired from big overseas companies or research institutes will also be targets solicited by the NSC.

Under this program, Wu said that Taiwan hopes to introduce their lifelong wisdom and experience into Taiwan, hoping to have them observe Taiwan's industries, offer suggestions and introduce the latest innovative and research directions and marketing models into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROVIDE MORE INCENTIVES TO BOT PROJECTS: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government will provide more incentives for development projects under a build-operate-transfer (BOT) model so as to help local governments lure more business opportunities, the nation's top economic policy planner said Thursday.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , also said that with the global economy slowing down, the government needs to create domestic demand if it wants to promote economic development.
Hu made the remarks when he attended a meeting of the Taiwan Economic & Industry Association in Taipei.

Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, speaking on the same occasion, said that the government has little room to raise the ceiling on the national debt, while the advocacy of raising taxes has encountered opposition.
Continuing to promote economic development will need continued suggestions from the private sector for government reference, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STEPS UP EFFORTS TO PUSH FOR SIMULTANEOUS LOCAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has asked his chief of staff, Lee Ying-yuan, to seek the support of the various parties, especially the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , for his administration's plan to hold three local elections together at the end of this year.

Cho Rong-tai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said Hsieh has asked Lee to contact the DPP, as well as the main opposition Kuomintang, both of which have spoken out against the changes, in an effort to sell the plan.
Both parties claim that the plan will make it easier for the other party to rig the elections and will make it difficult for them to win.

Denying speculation that the plan is designed to oust DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang by virtually putting paid to DPP's hope of expanding its political map in the elections for city and county chiefs, city and county councilors and town and rural township chiefs, Cho said the idea of holding the three elections at the same time is simply aimed at saving money and making the process easier for the voters.

Hsieh would like to see the public becoming involved in the discussion by offering ideas to improve the reform rather than misinterpreting it as a political scheme and scuttling it, the spokesman said.

In a rebuttal of the DPP's claims that the Executive Yuan has not solicited its opinion on the plan, Cho said the idea of cutting the number of elections by holding them simultaneously was initiated by President Chen Shui-bian in January 2002, and again in September 2004.
It was raised by the premier in the Legislative Yuan March 11, when he said the Central Election Commission (CEC) is drafting a plan to carry out the change.
The next day, Cho said, an Extraordinary DPP Congress relayed a recommendation by its representatives to the CEC calling for the synchronization of various elections.
As this policy was asked for by the president and rounded out with the recommendation of the DPP, Cho said, it should come as no surprise, especially not to the DPP.
Cho said the reform is not designed to cater to any specific party and that it would be ridiculous if all major political parties claim it will do them harm.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DEAL WITH BEIJING DISPARAGES NATIONAL SOVEREIGNTY: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lashed out at the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) 10-point consensus with Beijing Thursday, saying the deal undermines Taiwan's sovereign status and impairs its national interests.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, said at a news conference that the 10-point consensus signed in Beijing Wednesday by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang and Chen Yunlin, director of the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP's) Central Office for Taiwan Affairs, was a"sugar-coated poison" and an embodiment of Beijing's newly enacted anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

The KMT-CCP consensus covers a broad range of issues, including charter flights across the Taiwan Strait, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businessmen, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

"It seems to me that the KMT has fallen into the snare set up by the Chinese communists, " Chao said, adding that Chiang might also have violated the Criminal Code that bans individual citizens from signing a contract or agreement with a foreign government without the government's authorization.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lai Ching-teh, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, said the KMT has apparently put its own partisan interests above national interests by sending an official delegation to visit China at this sensitive time and signing the consensus.
Lai said Chiang's visit in the wake of China's enactment of its anti-secession law justifying its longstanding threat to attack Taiwan has hurt Taiwan in three ways.

"First of all, it could help alleviate international pressure on Beijing over the anti-secession law. Second, Chiang's visit downgrades the cross-strait issue to a Chinese internal issue and enhances the 'legitimacy' of China's sovereignty claim over Taiwan. Third, the visit is tantamount to showing the world that Taiwan cannot handle the anti-secession law and is falling apart due to internal division and partisan infighting," Lai said.
He mocked the KMT's timidity in dealing with China, saying that Chiang's mission has not mentioned the Republic of China's national title since its arrival in China Monday.

"The KMT has always claimed it is committed to defending the ROC. Why is it that no one in the delegation has dared to mention the nation's title since they set foot on Chinese soil? They also dared not display its party flag or the ROC national flag while paying tribute to the party's revolutionary forefathers in Guangzhou and Nanjing, " Lai said. By accommodating Beijing's demand for "party-to-party" talks, Lai said, the KMT has compromised the ROC's sovereign status by agreeing to the so-called 10-point consensus on humiliating terms.

Claiming that the consensus fully embodies the provisions of China's anti-secession law, Lai said the people of Taiwan should condemn the KMT for striking a deal with its communist foes at the expense of Taiwan's overall interests. Lai said he is worried that KMT-CCP reconciliation could bring disaster to Taiwan.

Chen Ching-jun, chief secretary of the DPP legislative caucus, also heaped scorn on the KMT delegation's China visit, saying that the KMT, which ruled all of China before losing a bloody civil war and fleeing to Taiwan in 1949, owes the people of Taiwan a public apology for reconciling with Beijing right after its enactment of the anti-secession law.
"The KMT's 'peace talks' have no doubt sent the wrong message to the international community -- that is, Taiwan itself is seriously divided over the anti-secession law," Chen said.
The world "could misunderstand and think that some people in Taiwan accept the anti-secession law.... The saddest thing is that the visit has denigrated Taiwan's sovereignty," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD OFFERS `3RD OPTION' IN EFFORTS TO SOLVE CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan defended the rationale behind a visit to China by a KMT delegation led by his deputy, P.K. Chiang, claiming that his party is trying to bail the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) out of difficulties in addressing the cross-Taiwan Strait issue.

Lien, who is in Nagoya to visit the Expo 2005 Aichi, claimed that in the face of deteriorating cross-strait relations, the DPP has been unable to address the problem but has refused to consult with the opposition parties for better solutions.
In this regard, Lien said, continuing to evade the issue and act like an ostrich is one option, while wrestling to escalate cross-strait tensions is another.

As the major opposition party, the KMT is trying to offer a third option, Lien said, adding that while the government is unable to address the pressing issue, it would be the people's good fortune if the KMT helps the government out with wisdom and patience.

On the recently enacted anti-secession law which codifies China's longstanding threat to attack Taiwan if it thinks Taiwan is seeking formal independence, Lien said that peace is of ultimate importance and violence can never be a solution.

Meanwhile, he said, it is ridiculous as well as unjustifiable that the future of the entire population of Taiwan is put at stake simply because "a small number of pro-independence radicals" are steering Taiwan's China policy.

Lien is visiting Japan at the invitation of the Aichi Expo authorities. The pavilions that Lien is scheduled to visit include a mammoth pavilion, a Shinkansen magnetic suspension railway pavilion, and an International Red Cross pavilion.
Lien is scheduled to proceed to Tokyo Friday, where he is expected to meet with some Cabinet officials and parliamentarians.

DOC.HEADLINE: PICKING UP NEW ID CARDS REQUIRES FINGERPRINTS: MOI

TEXT.P: Picking up new identification (ID) cards will require fingerprints to be submitted unless the existing household registration law is revised before July 1, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.
The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) is scheduled to replace existing ID cards with a new forgery-proof version from July 1 this year, valid until June 30, 2006.

As the current regulations require fingerprints, Su said, the MOI has been preparing the replacement work in line with this principle and has begun formulating rules governing the preservation or storage of the fingerprints.
To ensure smooth proceeding of the ID card replacements, Su said, the MOI has organized training courses for relevant staff members to be launched from March 31 through April 15.
Starting June 1, MOI officials said, local household registration offices will notify people to submit one photo to be used on the new cards.
The photo must be clear and in color, must be taken without the subject wearing a hat or sunglasses and must have been taken within the last six months, the officials said.
The name and identification card number of the person in the photo, as well as the date when the photo was taken, must be written on the back of the photo, they said.
People must pick up their new identification cards in person, while a home delivery service will be provided for those suffering from a serious disease or those who are otherwise incapacitated.
The new cards will be pale purple and will have 21 forgery-proof features. Unlike the existing identification cards, which have vertical print, the writing on the new ones will be horizontal.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, April 1:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
10: 00, The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
11: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive a delegation from the overseas Chinese community in Osaka at the Presidential Office.
14: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a seminar on justice, wellbeing and human rights at the National Central Library.
14: 30, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao will attend the inauguration of a music group at the Ambassador Hotel in Taipei.
16: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive the Taiwan delegation to the 2005 Special Olympics World Winter Games at the Presidential Office.
16: 30, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will meet the media at Taipei City Hall.
21:00, An opposition Kuomintang delegation will return home from a visit to China via the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: DON'T VIEW TAIWAN FROM THE PERSPECTIVE OF BEIJING: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang urged the Beijing leadership Thursday not to view Taiwan from the perspective of Beijing.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung quoted Chiang as saying to Beijing officials while expressing Taiwan's contempt for the recently enacted anti-secession law that Chinese officials should try harder to understand the feelings of the Taiwan people and should put themselves in their shoes when addressing the cross-Taiwan Strait issue.

According to Chang, Chiang told his Beijing hosts that Taiwan independence is not mainstream opinion in Taiwan, but Beijing's enactment of the anti-secession law, which authorizes China to use "non-peaceful means" should it think Taiwan is moving toward independence, is only backfiring -- sending the wrong message to the majority of peace-loving Taiwan people.
Meanwhile, Chang went on, the KMT delegation has achieved its "commemoration" and "business and trade promotion" missions during its groundbreaking visit to China.

The 27-member delegation, led by Chiang, also reached a 10-point consensus with officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing Wednesday on a wide range of issues, including cross-strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese business people, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market, Chang recapped.
The KMT reached its preliminary consensus with Beijing while bearing the interests of the 23 million Taiwan people in mind, Chang claimed.

Saying that the 10-point consensus will have a positive and far-reaching impact on Taiwan, Chang said that it will "have to be implemented" by the Democratic Progressive Party-ruled administration with the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
The KMT delegation embarked on its five-day visit Monday, making it the party's first official delegation to visit China.

Members of the delegation first paid tribute at the cemetery of 72 martyrs who sacrificed their lives in the KMT-led Huanghuagang Uprising against China's last empire, the Ching Dynasty, in Guangzhou, southern Guangdong Province, Tuesday. The death of the 72 martyrs March 29, 1911 is designated as the Republic of China's National Youth Day.
The group then paid tribute at the mausoleum of ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing Wednesday before heading north to Beijing later in the day.
It is widely speculated that Chiang's mission could mark a stepping stone to a landmark visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the near future.
Chiang and his delegation are scheduled to return home Friday after wrapping up their visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: CEC TO DECIDE WHETHER TO SYNCHRONIZE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the Central Election Commission (CEC) will decide whether to hold three local elections together at the end of this year.

The premier visited Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang Thursday but failed to sell his administration's plan to hold three local elections simultaneously at the end of this year.
The two told journalists after a 40-minute closed-door meeting that more discussion is need to sort out their differences.

Hsieh said he was asked by President Chen Shui-bian to discuss the issue with Su after the DPP took issue with the Executive Yuan's plan to hold the elections of local government chiefs and councilors at the same time, claiming that it would give corrupt local politicians a field day with fixing elections.
The premier said the general public supports the revamp of the elections by holding them simultaneously, but the CEC under the Executive Yuan must decide when they will be held.
For his part, Su said, his party has always supported the idea of cutting down the number of elections, but this change should be carried out with a well-thought-out plan or it will lead to chaos.

Noting that grassroots politicians are worried about abrupt reform without complementary measures being put in place, Su said he relayed these opinions to Hsieh for his information and that hopefully, the premier and the CEC will make the best decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOINING WHA IS RIGHT FOR TAIWAN: EXECUTIVE YUAN SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Joining the World Health Assembly (WHA) is Taiwan's basic right and China has acknowledged that it has been wrong in thwarting Taiwan's attempts to join the organization by saying it can help Taiwan take part in WHA technical events, Executive Yuan spokesman Cho Rong-tai said Thursday.

Asked to respond to news reports that Chinese State Councillor Tang Jiaxuan told visiting opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang in Beijing earlier that day that China "might help" with Taiwan's WHA bid, Cho expressed skepticism that China, which has gone out of its way to quell Taiwan's WHA bid for the last eight years, will change its mind. He added that even if Tang did make the statement, it would not be worth celebrating. He did not elaborate.
As a member of the international community, Cho said, Taiwan is entitled to participate in the WHA and the WHA needs Taiwan to close the loopholes in its desease-prevention network.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SCIENCE COUNCIL TO INCREASE INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) will increase its international cooperation, focusing on more than 20 major programs that will link every corner of the world, the council's head said Thursday.

NSC Chairman Wu Mao-kun said that in addition to traditional technologically advanced nations, the United States military, Russia and East European countries are new grounds that the NSC is trying to explore.

The NSC and the Russian Foundation for Basic Research will jointly set up a technology research cooperation fund in June, Wu revealed, adding that the amount of the fund will be increased gradually to US$2.4 million in three years.
Besides, he went on, the NSC has already had two cooperation projects with the Russian Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and is negotiating with the institute to sign a cooperation accord.
The NSC has also increased its cooperation with Latvia and Lithuania by incrementing a tripartite cooperation fund from US$200,000 to US$300,000, Wu continued.
The NSC has also cooperated with French research entities and will launch research programs in Taipei this summer for French graduate students.
Meanwhile, it will cooperate with the French Institute of Research and Exploitation of the Sea to organize an international seminar in Taiwan and one in France this year.

Wu said that at the invitation of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, he will attend an international conference in May in Serbia in which he will give a speech on the development of Taiwan's information technology and its science-based parks.

The western Balkan peninsula, Central Asia and the Caucasus region, which are interested in Taiwan's information technology industry, are other potential areas for Taiwan to explore in the future, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STAYS OUT OF DISPUTE OVER ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stayed out of a dispute Thursday between the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over whether to hold three local elections simultaneously at the end of this year, saying through an aide that the matter should be settled by the relevant government agencies.
The president's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, said Chen supports the idea of holding the local elections simultaneously, but said the details should be determined by the relevant agencies.
He said the president's job is to lay down the direction of policy, while the administration's task is to work out detailed plans to carry it out.

The issue has pitted the Executive Yuan against the DPP, with Premier Frank Hsieh announcing earlier this week that the three-in-one election will be held at the end of the year, while DPP chief Su Tseng-chang warned it is doomed to fail because it will open the door to massive vote-buying in the absence of complementary measures.
